fields.headline: England near lift-off
fields.standfirst:
Victory over Germany is welcome but greater discipline is needed to progress further, says David Lacey
Euro 2000 special report

Richard Williams: Keegan and Shearer go on the attack
fields.trailText: Victory over Germany is welcome but greater discipline is needed to progress further, says David Lacey.
fields.body:
So one ghost has been laid, although for England another more recent spectre lies in wait. Two years ago Romania's 2-1 victory in Toulouse threw Glenn Hoddle's team off course in the World Cup. Tomorrow night Kevin Keegan's side will hope to reach the quarter-finals of the European Championship by denying the Romanians a win in Charleroi.

The substantial injection of confidence England will have gained from this 1-0 victory, their first over Germany in a major tournament since the 1966 World Cup final, must increase the chances of Keegan getting the result he needs back at the Stade Communal. However, the violent behavior of some of their fans, and Uefa's subsequent threat of expulsion from the tournament, could have the opposite effect. A draw against Romania will be enough because, though the Germans could also finish with four points by beating Portugal, they would stay below England having lost to them on Saturday.

By the same token although England can finish level on six points with Portugal, the group leaders, last Monday's 3-2 defeat against the Portuguese in Eindhoven would keep Keegan's side in second place. Thus England, should they reach the last eight, will face Italy in Brussels on Saturday for a place in the semi-finals.

If such a thought cast a dampener on Saturday's celebrations, it did not last long. For one thing England are not there yet and for another the knockout stage, with its golden goals and penalty shoot-outs, is altogether a different bag of tricks.

Yesterday England were entitled to bask briefly in the sunshine of satisfaction after allaying fears that their appearance in Euro 2000 would be humiliatingly brief, having thrown away an early 2-0 lead against Portugal with such careless abandon. "Everything is still in our own hands," said Keegan, "and that's the most important thing about beating Germany."

Saturday's win was hardly an epic, being more a case of a moderate team beating a rank bad one in a scrappy match. This was arguably the worst German performance since Stone & Stone came last in the 1995 Eurovision Song Contest with Verliebt In Dich.

And as Keegan admitted yesterday: "If I'm honest we can play better than we did. Certainly we can pass the ball better. If we're going to give it away as much as we did against the Germans then we're not going to go far in this tournament."

For England, nevertheless, the result was everything. Keegan might have suspected it was his lucky day when Romania lost to Portugal in stoppage time and Gheorghe Hagi, the hub of their team, got himself suspended for tomorrow after receiving his second caution in as many games.

The England coach must have been further convinced when David Beckham stayed on the pitch having responded to being barged off the ball by Ulf Kirsten with a petulant assault which sent the German striker flying. This time Beckham was lucky with his referee, Italy's Pierluigi Collina, who simply booked him whereas against Argentina in the 1998 World Cup Kim Milton Nielsen sent him off for less.

By contrast Alan Shearer was the epitome of disciplined aggression. While he might nowadays have the immobility of a ship's figurehead his instincts near goal have suffered less than his all-round pace. Certainly the header, eight minutes into the second half, that was to beat Germany belonged to the Shearer of old.

Beckham had been gratuitously fouled by Christian Ziege and put a particularly wicked spin on a free-kick which swerved and dipped past Paul Scholes and Michael Owen before bouncing past Jens Nowotny as the defender tried to intercept it. The ball reached Shearer, unattended to the left of goal, and he beat Oliver Kahn with an excellent header from an awkward angle.

The rest depended on how well England had learned the lessons of Eindhoven. As it turned out they had not shirked their homework. With Paul Ince working tirelesly to break up German movements in midield and Martin Keown, the replacement for an unfit Tony Adams, binding the back four more tightly, the gaps so effectively exploited by the Portuguese were no longer there.

Even then England could have paid heavily for the occasional lapse had Germany's finishing been remotely up to scratch. In the 65th minute Kirsten met Babbel's knock-down from a corner with a shot saved by Seaman with his feet. The re bound fell invitingly for Jancker who, with the goal agape, dragged the ball wide. Oliver Bierhoff, out of the tournament with a calf injury, would probably have scored.

Early discomfort
The efficiency with which Steven Gerrard supported Ince after replacing Michael Owen for the last half-hour, and the pace and tenacity of Nick Barmby, who came on for Scholes after 73 minutes, did much to deny the Germans another of their famous comebacks. Tactically the England coach may be keeping one page ahead of the class but this time he got it right.

Any reservations about England's performance may appear carping but the fact remains that until Owen's header, from Phil Neville's centre, was pushed onto a post by Oliver Kahn 10 minutes before half-time, Keegan's team had been so rigid that they were like table footballers strung out on steel bars awaiting a flick of the wrist to get them going.

With the Germans keeping leisurely possession and Matthaus strolling around his own half delivering one telling pass after another the situation, for England, looked unpromising. But after Shearer's goal Germany increased their tempo and opted for the direct approach, which was something Keegan's players were better equipped to deal with.

So the memories of 1970, 1990 and 1996 were finally purged and if England were less impressive in beating Germany this time than they had been in going out to them in previous tournaments at least the better side won.

Not that France, Holland or, if it comes to that, Italy will have lost much sleep about this on Saturday night.

webTitle: Fates are unkind to Czechs and Danes

fields.headline: Fates are unkind to Czechs and Danes
fields.trailText: Jorge Valdano on those teams making an honourable departure.
fields.body:
We should be fair towards those teams who are leaving Euro 2000 before time and who cannot be blamed for it.

Bereft of the Laudrup family, Denmark are one such case. They fought against their limitations and lost - despite group strength, struggling to the last and showing great dignity.

There are others who have also made an honourable departure: the Czech giants completed their tournament in crisis, but nonetheless leave us with a sense of loss.

No more Koller; no more Poborsky, a great entertainer who takes a real delight in European competition; no more Nedved, who sweated real football on the pitch (above all against Holland); no more Repka and his goggly mass-murderer eyes; no more Smicer and his great left foot, but who was dragged down by his team-mates' utterly irrational game ...

The Czechs played no worse than they did in England 96, where they reached the final; Denmark played no worse than in Sweden 92, where they won. All that has happened is that football has these quirks of fate, and what was given to them once has now been taken away.

Poor and rich
The Scandinavian sides are making their way in Euro 2000 at very different speeds: Denmark are out, Sweden are at death's door and Norway go from strength to strength.

Merely reaching these finals is worthy of praise, and shows the advantages of such a physical game, one in which the players are humble enough to think in terms of a group.

The Scandinavians believe in "all for one and one for all", a philosophy alien to Latin cultures. It makes them strong as a team and increases their value individually. They are top-class raw material, well built and with great competitive instinct.

I don't like having to recognise the quality of Scandinavian players, and not just because their style is completely different from ours.

To South Americans, northern European football is light years away from their way of life. It's the classic short-ball game versus the long ball, heat versus cold, football that sweeps away the opposition versus cool calculation.

Globalisation softens the barriers between these styles, but if three things remain the same - the weather,social conditions and a society's collective subconscious - someone born in Uruguay and someone born in Norway will continue to respond differently to soccer.

But to get to the point: the day Denmark played Holland, the Danish player Jan Heintze left the field to adjust a contact lens. The masseur who helped him was wearing a Rolex Daytona.

Then I realised my prejudice was a cheap South American product, dating from when soccer held no value on the stock market. That prejudice consists of believing that soccer forms part of the culture of the masses, and that it is impossible to play it well if you remove yourself from that suffering.

Like all prejudices this is a stubborn, stupid idea, but even after discovering the reason why I was so unfair, I still think exactly the same. At least it turns the tables on racism, directed as my prejudice is from poor to rich.

Peruvian 'illness'

Peru's Nolberto Solano had a good season at Newcastle but as soon as he starts to play for his national team his form takes a nose-dive.

The coach Paco Maturana knows all about this "illness" and he says: "Solano's problem is that he gets Peruitis." What he means by that is that he suffers badly from the negative atmosphere around him, even in his private life.

I get the feeling this problem doesn't exist in Europe, where the players tend to show a greater commitment and stronger discipline when they play for their national sides.

There are very few good players unaffected by worse players or the wrong kind of atmosphere. These are the geniuses, such as Maradona, who need only the ball at their feet for everything to change.

For others, even such as Zinedine Zidane, who we tend to say is a player who helps his team-mates to grow, we forget to add that he needs the intelligence and strong, long manoeuvring by his team-mates to better himself.

Zidane brings together all the necessary requirements when he plays for France: he provides a sense of involvement, feeling and intelligence. The coach has to ensure the right conditions are present. Maturana would say, with some envy, that "the advantage of Zidane is that he has Franceitis."

webTitle: Psion's Symbian arm is tipped for early flotation

fields.headline: Psion's Symbian arm is tipped for early flotation
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: There was speculation yesterday that Psion, the British hi-tech group, is planning a £5bn stock market flotation of Symbian, the mobile phone business it owns with handset manufacturers Nokia, Ericsson and Motorola.
fields.body:
There was speculation yesterday that Psion, the British hi-tech group, is planning a £5bn stock market flotation of Symbian, the mobile phone business it owns with handset manufacturers Nokia, Ericsson and Motorola.

Psion, cited by Microsoft founder Bill Gates as the biggest threat to his software empire, has developed an operating system for the new generation of internet enabled handsets through Symbian. The operating system, Epoc, is tipped to dominate the market.

The issue of a separate stock market listing for Symbian was first raised in March although at the time Psion's chief executive David Levin said the move was not yet on the agenda. Analysts had expected a float in about 18 months.

But reports yesterday suggested that the flotation had been brought forward to raise funds for the exploitation of the rapidly growing demand for mobile internet. Investment banks Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter are said to be competing for the mandate.

At least one source yesterday cautioned against expecting an early flotation. He said the feeling within Psion was that there would be a flotation but added that the business was still unlikely to reach the market before the second half of next year.

Analysts have suggested that almost 90% of the value in Psion shares is attributed to its 28% stake in Symbian.

Symbian was formed in 1998 and now employs more than 500 people. Its first deal was struck with Sony in April when the Japanese firm said it would use Epoc as the platform for its mobile data services.

Sony plans to launch a "smart" phone in Japan next year using Symbian software which will be capable of voice calls, web browsing and email as well as the downloading and storage of music. The handsets will go on sale in Europe and North America at a later date.

When the deal was signed, Symbian chief executive Colly Myers forecast that the company would achieve 75% market share for operating software in the new wave of phones by 2003.

Psion enjoyed a brief period in the FTSE 100 index but recently dropped out after a sharp fall in its share price.

The shares were unsettled by alliances struck by Ericsson and Nokia with Microsoft and Palm which appeared at the time to threaten their relationship with Psion.

fields.headline: Collective heartbeat
fields.standfirst:
Kirov Ballet
Royal Opera House, London
****
fields.trailText:
Kirov Ballet
Royal Opera House, London
****
fields.body:
When Diaghilev's Ballets Russes first came west, it was the works of Mikhail Fokine which gave the company their instant, cult success. However even Diaghilev, disloyally, soon began to find these works old-fashioned and today they've become even harder to stage with anything like their original intensity. So it's a tribute to the Kirov's all-Fokine programme that it does, remarkably, capture some of the novelty which so enraptured Europe in the early 20th century.

Chopiniana, Fokine's distillation of early Romantic ballet is essentially an ensemble piece and what's stunning about the Kirov's staging is how profoundly the dancers move as a single body. As they mesh their limbs in a delicate trelliswork, as they flutter apart and gently incline they create that brief, collective illusion, unique to dance, of individuals so connected by music and by style that they seem to share the same heartbeat.

The Kirov's Petrushka is, by contrast, more robustly Russian in detail than any production I've seen. The peasants at the street fair look straight out of Tolstoy and the dancing bear (only a man in a costume after all) is startlingly lifelike, a lumbering sullen beast whose mangy coat seems to harbour as much of a tormented soul as Petrushka himself.

The programme closes with Scheherazade, a ballet whose sensual extravagance usually retreats into coyness or topples into ludicrous vulgarity. With Altynai Asylmuratova dancing Zobeide, however, it becomes grand melodrama.

Until June 27.

fields.headline: Japan faces storm
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Masayoshi Son will take a major step forward in his attempt to reinvent Japan as an nation friendly to internet investors today with the start of trading on Nasdaq Japan.
fields.body:
Masayoshi Son will take a major step forward in his attempt to reinvent Japan as an nation friendly to internet investors today with the start of trading on Nasdaq Japan.

However, the new bourse, in which Mr Son's Softbank holding company owns a 50% stake, will be launched in stormy waters as internet-related stocks are still suffering from a global plunge. Softbank and its partners - the Osaka stock exchange and the National Association of Securities Dealers - have launched Nasdaq Japan as the first step in turning its namesake in the US into a 24-hour global marketplace for hi-tech shares. Nasdaq has already announced a link-up with iX - the planned merger of the London and Frankfurt markets.

The bourse has already caused waves in Japan, where the conservative Tokyo stock market has dominated the equities business, restricting flotations to long-established companies. Spurred by the prospect of new competition, the Nikkei established the oddly named Mothers, a market for venture companies last December that has attracted 10 initial public offerings in the past six months.

Nasdaq, which will provide much-needed competition in the equities sector, aims to move more quickly. In its first year it plans to list more than 100 firms, including about a dozen worth more than ¥1 trillion (£6bn), concentrating on internet-related start-ups.

"This is going to force the Japanese government, industry and society to change," Tatsuyuki Saeki, president of Nasdaq Japan, told the New York Times. "It is one of those events that comes along once or twice every 100 or 200 years and changes things."

However, the market will get off to a relatively low-key start today with IPOs by eight little-known companies. They include four hi-tech firms, a game software developer, a car dealer and a chemists chain.

fields.headline: Devoted to their icons
fields.standfirst:
Iron Maiden
Earls Court, London
***
fields.trailText:
Iron Maiden
Earls Court, London
***
fields.body:
"Scream for me London!" As 20,000 voices raise the roof of Earls Court, Bruce Dickinson, human foghorn and public image of metal stalwarts Iron Maiden, throws his hands up in the air, legs apart in an iconic pose. After a six-year stint writing books and fencing for fun, he's back in rock and roll.

With their operatic epics and record sales topping 80m, Iron Maiden are the granddaddies of metal. But while the kids love the clown masks of Slipknot, it's Maiden that their dads and Slipknot bow down to. And there's a lot of worshipping tonight. The atmosphere is one of devotion and disbelief, as the original ball-busting line-up of Dickinson, bassist Steve Harris, drummer Nicko McBrain and guitarists Jannick Gers, Adrian Smith and Dave Murray celebrate their past glories and present success of new album Brave New World at their only UK gig of the current European tour.

From new song The Wicker Man to firm favourite Twelve Minutes to Midnight, the crowd are word-perfect. As always, the stage sets are impressive. Dickinson appears suspended on a cross at the back of the set as explosions go off around him. Maiden have fun, with Gers running across the stage and carrying out a bizarre shaman dance. But it's Dickinson's awesome vocals and old-fashioned crowd-pleasing activities that do the legend proud.

But while the kids love the clown masks of Slipknot, it's Maiden that their dads and Slipknot bow down to. And there's a lot of worshipping tonight. The atmosphere is one of devotion and disbelief, as the original ball-busting line-up of Dickinson, bassist Steve Harris, drummer Nicko McBrain and guitarists Jannick Gers, Adrian Smith and Dave Murray celebrate their past glories and present success of new album Brave New World at their only UK gig of the current European tour. From new song The Wicker Man to firm favourite Twelve Minutes to Midnight, the crowd are word-perfect. As always, the stage sets are impressive. Dickinson appears suspended on a cross at the back of the set as explosions go off around him. Maiden have fun, with Gers running across the stage and carrying out a bizarre shaman dance. But it's Dickinson's awesome vocals and old-fashioned crowd-pleasing activities that do the legend proud.

webTitle: Gates cosies up in new ad

fields.headline: Gates cosies up in new ad
fields.standfirst:
The multi-billionaire and the mini-millionaire
Money Unlimited
The future of Microsoft: special report
fields.trailText: Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, is taking to the small screen. Innocuously dressed in a light blue sweater, the multi-millionaire is the star turn in a new advertisement that has just started to be broadcast on American television.
fields.body:
Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, is taking to the small screen. Innocuously dressed in a light blue sweater, the multi-millionaire is the star turn in a new advertisement that has just started to be broadcast on American television.

Adopting an approach which has reminded Americans of the "fireside chats" of Franklin Roosevelt in the 1930s and 1940s, Mr Gates promises his viewers that the "best is yet to come". The prime-time ad is the latest instalment in the company's campaign designed to help to win sympathy for its argument that it should not be divided.

The company is fighting back against a court ruling that it violated competition rules by abusing its dominant position. It is being penalised with an order that says it should be split in two.

Mr Gates, who appears in the ad alone and surrounded by computers, insists that Microsoft is already developing the "next generation of software". Without any hint of irony, he says: "We've been writing great software for the past 25 years. It's what we're all about. It's our passion and it always will be."

The ads make no direct reference to the complicated appeal process, which is getting under way and likely to result in a move by Microsoft later today to issue further legal documentation about its case.

It is the latest in a series of Microsoft ads which have appeared since the federal court's ruling. It is also the latest in a sequence of personal appearances by Mr Gates, who told students in Tokyo last week that he was a "rational optimist".

Without making any direct reference to his legal predicament, Mr Gates was quoted in Japan as saying: "I'm certainly about the most optimistic person you'd ever meet."

fields.headline: Oh, do shut up
fields.standfirst: Don't be around when the old charm fails to work. It is like watching the audience at a Tom Jones concert ask for their knickers back
fields.trailText: Firm favourites: Don't be around when the old charm fails to work. It is like watching the audience at a Tom Jones concert ask for their knickers back. Judi James tells you how you can cope with hecklers.
fields.body:
Heckling is great sport for the masses. Like the child in the story of the emperor's new clothes, it only takes one member of an otherwise adoring audience to call out a few ripe truisms for the whole pack to start turning feral.

It has a lot to do with group psychology and the power of the non-conformist individual. Or - to put it another way - one goes and they all follow suit. For a controversial or unpopular figure the effect can be upsetting but for a character of previous unblemished adulation like the the prime minister at the WI it can make you very, very sore.

You don't want to be around when the old charm fails to work. It is like watching an audience at a Tom Jones concert start to ask for their knickers back. You will probably never be asked to give a political speech but most of us will be expected to do a business presentation at some time in our careers. Perhaps you will get an easy ride. The audience will like you and sit listening in awe. But maybe you will be heckled like Mr Blair. Or go down like a fart in a lift. Some survival tactics are useful to avoid the same moment of lip-chewing horror that our prime minister must have endured.

The victim's survival guide


 Know your audience. People get fretful if you appear to have brought the wrong talk to the wrong event. Or if you've tailored it to a different group. The I've started so I'll finish style of presenting is never popular once things have started to go wrong. Get your facts right before you open your mouth. What will they want to hear? What is their experience of your subject-matter? Will they find your jokes and sly digs funny or will they want to call in the lynch mob?


 Be flexible. If your talk is brim-full of humour and nobody's laughing, cut out the gags and get on with the serious stuff. Monitor your audience at all times. Be aware of mood-changes or apparent disapproval. Be controversial if you like but always show an understanding or respect for their point of view as well.


 Never patronise. This is a red rag to a bull with any group. Knowledge is power but assumption is suicidal. Not all grey haired people are deaf or unable to understand long words. Not all young women are secretaries. Not all men are blokes who like beer and football. Never stereotype.


 If you're going to poke fun do it to yourself, rather than your audience.

 Find out about group dynamics before you start talking. It's wrong to be too judgmental but it never hurts to be warned about the sceptics or the troublemakers.

 Avoid hacking in to either character. Outright conflict or all-out put-down would be wrong at this stage as the group may side with them, rather than you.


 Acknowledge the heckle. If you don't want to stop, at least go for the wan smile. Try a brief comic wince that may get the audience laughing and sympathising with you, rather than them.


 Pray that no-one intervenes on your behalf. Possibly the worst-case scenario is when the chair cuts in to ask the audience to be polite enough to listen, as happened at the WI. This has the effect of making you look like you are not able to handle your own heckling and needs someone else to do it for you.

Tactical manoeuvres

Alternative gambits to consider would be:


 Stop talking. Step back. Stare at the floor a few moments. This relies strongly on the sympathy vote. They will think they have reduced you to tears. Few audiences are hard-faced enough to carry on heckling while you blub. Wait until they fall into stunned and guilty silence and then straighten up with a smile on your face.


 Listen politely. Angus Deyton does it well on Have I Got News For You. He waits while a team member buts in, a smile of utter politeness on his face. And then he carries on with his own lines.


 Return the compliment. Professional comedians go on stage armed with the most wonderful put-downs for hecklers. You could do the same, which would prevent the syndrome of only thinking of the best line once the presentation is over. An evening at a comedy club should provide enough fodder for a few presentations. Be warned, though, few hecklers can take a dose of their own medicine. You may find your hatchet job has been performed on the MD.


 Go Wilde. Writers like Oscar Wilde specialised in the witty put-down. These are subtle and clever enough to sink in after a few hours, as opposed to the "Could you ask your gorilla to be quiet, please?" variety. Buy a book of literary insults and memorise as many as you can.


 Hand over the mike. In extreme cases you can offer to let the heckler take centre stage and finish your talk for you. This will either shut them up or cause more problems when they take you up on your offer.


 Ask them their name. Get into a real dialogue with them. Throw out a few questions to discover their real views. Few hecklers can talk properly. Most can only manage sarcastic comments and run out of steam when it comes to stringing complete sentences together. Inviting real conversation may shut them up for the rest of the talk.

webTitle: All we need is an equal chance

fields.headline: All we need is an equal chance
fields.standfirst: IT skills are essential in the office, but many disabled people are denied training.  Hilary Whitney  finds two schemes determined to provide access for all
fields.trailText: IT skills are essential in the office, but many disabled people are denied training. Hilary Whitney finds two schemes determined to provide access for all
fields.body:
Moaning about it may be our favourite hobby, but most of us would admit that technology has improved the quality of office life beyond measure. Yes, crashing computers and email viruses are a pain, but few of us would opt to return to the days of wrestling with typewriter ribbons and carbon paper. As long as you can type and know your way round a computer, it's possible these days to leave much of the hard stuff to the software, while you get on with managing an ever-increasing workload.

But what happens if you can't type, or have difficulty operating a standard computer? How do you cope if you have restricted use of your hands, or impaired vision or hearing? For someone with a disability, the increased reliance on computers within the workplace can cause as many problems as it solves. And understandably, this impacts on their access to jobs - out of 3.8m disabled people of working age, more than three-quarters are unemployed.

Two national disability skills schemes are now working to help disabled people overcome problems in the workplace. Workability and AbilityNet both aim to give IT training to people with disabilities, and give them wider access to specialised equipment, to enable them to find work or further their careers. Such help is vital because even the most advanced technology is of very little use unless people are adequately trained - and that's before the issue of cost comes into play.

Workability was established in 1998 by the Leonard Cheshire foundation, one of the UK's leading charities for disabled people. The scheme was founded to help those disabled people who lacked the educational and IT skills that would enable them to find employment, and hopes to break down exclusion of many disabled people from jobs by providing equipment, training and help in looking for work. Participants are given their own home computer loaded with software donated by Microsoft, and offered training in computer skills. Some students attend courses at colleges around the country, but for those with mobility problems, coursework can be completed by distance learning, using email and the internet to cover modules in word-processing, spreadsheets and online communication. The project even provides participants with a network of "buddies" to give advice on setting up computer equipment in the home as well as how to operate the PC and software.

Amit Patel, 23, is one of the growing number of Workability's success stories. He had worked in the catering industry for some years, but felt he needed a career change, ideally to a desk-based job. Patel has cerebral palsy, and recognised that learning IT skills was essential if he was to get the office job he wanted. He enrolled on a course at Portland College, Nottingham, learning Word and Excel and internet skills. As a result he was able to apply for jobs online, as well as producing copies of his CV and covering letters. Patel's hard work paid off and he is now an administration assistant with an accountancy firm in Leicester.

Stephen Cumming is another satisfied customer. After being unemployed for a number of years, Cumming, 29, who has spastic hemiplegia which affects the movement on one side of his body, heard about Workability. He already had some IT knowledge and a PC, but once he was accepted onto the course the scheme supplied him with a modem so that he could access the virtual college. This meant he was able to benefit from course modules on word- processing and Excel packages as well as online communication and database software. After he completed the course, he found a job as an administrative assistant with the Inland Revenue. "Getting involved with Workability was a great boost for my confidence," he says.

But it is not only those with long-term disabilities who may need extra training. Melanie Rees, had worked for nearly a decade in the catering trade when she had a serious accident at work that resulted in a 30% loss in the use of her right hand. She realised that a new career was the only option and signed up at her local college of education for a three-month office skills course covering word processing, database and spreadsheet programmes, as well as basic office skills.

Her retraining was supported by AbilityNet, a registered charity which evolved in the 1980s out of the special needs department at computing giant IBM. AbilityNet is concerned with providing disabled people with adaptive equipment and advice to enable them to carry on with their work if they are disabled temporarily or permanently. This could mean ensuring that someone who develops RSI is provided with ergonomic equipment, or that someone who has been injured in a car accident is helped to stay at work.

Rees found using a standard computer keyboard uncomfortable and unproductive, so she was assessed by AbilityNet and advised to use a smaller, more compact one. When it is correctly placed, she can reach all the keys with her left hand with a relatively small arm movement. There is no reason why she shouldn't become an efficient one-handed typist - a tool called "sticky keys", for example (automatically supplied with Windows), eliminates the need to hold down two keys at once.

Since she has to use her left hand for everything, Rees also has to take care not to strain the muscles in her now-dominant hand. Facilities in Microsoft Office such as AutoCorrect and AutoText are a big help in correcting mistakes and entering standard paragraphs or larger pieces of text quickly. She also has a detachable armrest clamped to the table to provide extra support for her left hand and arm, and uses an ergonomically designed, left-handed mouse. In the classroom, voice-recognition software was not a feasible option, but in the future, in a quieter working environment, she hopes to explore the software's potential for entirely "hands-free" computing.

Rees is enthusiastic about the support she has received from Ability- Net. "I am really relaxed at my desk and my posture has improved as well as my efficiency. My colleagues are quite envious of my ergonomic keyboard and mouse as they are so practical and user-friendly. Without AbilityNet's advice and the solutions my consultant recommended, I would never have been able to keep up with the coursework and I would undoubtedly have suffered a lot of cramp and pain. With my new computer equipment, studying for a degree or working in an office are realistic options."

By widening disabled people's access to the workplace, both organisations believe that not only are offices made more equitable for all, but prejudices about the skills of people with disabilities will be broken down. This aim is echoed by the new Disability Rights Commission, launched this April to monitor the effectiveness of disability legislation and fight discrimination against disabled people. The pressure is now on employers to adapt working environments to meet the needs of disabled people. It might be as simple as installing some new software.

 To find out more about AbilityNet, ring freephone 0800 269545 or visit the website at www.abilitynet.co.uk To find out more about Workability, contact Leonard Cheshire on 020 7802 8200, or visit the website at www.leonard-cheshire.org

fields.headline: The office gossip
fields.body:
"The best trick for coping with pressure is to start early, before the phones start ringing!" says Vanessa Hales, who works as external relations officer and PA to the director of public affairs at ITN. "I get in at eight every morning and I get so much done. Working as an external relations officer means dealing with all the viewer queries, complaints and comments that come in via our messaging service - and that takes quite some time. The first thing I do in the morning is check the diary for my boss, Mark Gallagher. If there's nothing I need to do for him, I go straight on to the viewers' messages."

This is certainly a mixed postbag, but Hales's job is made easier because she has a large network of people who can offer help and advice. "People write in about all sorts of things, from wanting information about some medical issue we may have covered to asking why an event they know about didn't get any coverage. It's essential that the information I give them is correct, and I rely on other people within ITN to help me out, which takes the pressure off me."

In addition to juggling her two jobs, Hales is also involved with the public affairs programme and events organising. "Because my boss's brief is quite large I have a very diverse job. Some days it may simply be making sure that he has the right documents for a meeting, that the agenda is ready, that travel arrangements have been made, while at other times I may be organising a formal function. At the moment, for example, ITN is about to launch its 24-hour news channel and so we are organising ministerial dinners and briefings in the City, with which I am involved."

The first rule, Hales believes, is to focus on one task at a time. "One of the best ways to avoid feeling pressurised is to deal with things one by one. I always try to get one task finished properly before I start the next. I think it's also important to be able to say no - if someone asks me to do something and I'm hugely busy, I usually tell them that I'll help later if I can, but that at the moment I have to finish what I'm doing."

And rule number two? "For me, it's all about organisation. I'm obsessed with files - every project I'm involved in, every aspect of my job has a file. Although it might seem time-consuming to document every conversation and every piece of paper that goes across my desk, in the end it makes life much easier. If I know that everything is written down and I can lay my hands on it at a moment's notice, then I don't tend to get stressed."

And however pressurised the environment in the office, Hales believes it's important not to feel overwhelmed. "Things can get hectic. I might be replying to a viewer's query, then my boss will ask me to do something, the telephone will go and it might be Conservative Central Office with a query about the reception we're organising for their party conference. If I am interrupted, I just grab a Post-it and write down exactly what I was doing, so that nothing gets forgotten. If I tried to keep everything in my head, it would be a disaster."

And rule number two? "For me, it's all about organisation. I'm obsessed with files - every project I'm involved in, every aspect of my job has a file. Although it might seem time-consuming to document every conversation and every piece of paper that goes across my desk, in the end it makes life much easier. If I know that everything is written down and I can lay my hands on it at a moment's notice, then I don't tend to get stressed." And however pressurised the environment in the office, Hales believes it's important not to feel overwhelmed. "Things can get hectic. I might be replying to a viewer's query, then my boss will ask me to do something, the telephone will go and it might be Conservative Central Office with a query about the reception we're organising for their party conference. If I am interrupted, I just grab a Post-it and write down exactly what I was doing, so that nothing gets forgotten. If I tried to keep everything in my head, it would be a disaster."

webTitle: Little white lies - at a price

fields.headline: Little white lies - at a price
fields.standfirst: For those too honest to cover for the boss, or just short on new excuses, there's a website that will do the dirty work for you.  Claire Phipps  reports
fields.trailText: For those too honest to cover for the boss, or just short on new excuses, there's a website that will do the dirty work for you. Claire Phipps reports
fields.body:
It's a staple part of the secretary's role that definitely doesn't appear on the job description: lying for the boss. Telling an unwanted caller that the colleague sitting right next to you isn't around to answer the phone, or reassuring a business contact that, "of course she left on time for that crucial meeting", we've all done it. So commonplace, in fact, is the little white workplace lie that all but the most avowedly honest of us can manage it without so much as a twinge of conscience.

Sooner or later, though, there comes a time when the remit of the "personal assistant" is stretched to include covering for your employer's unscheduled - and sometimes rather too personal - activities. Forget typing speed and your degree, this role requires a talent for deceit, a headful of on-the-spot excuses and perfect timing. How else could you juggle the boss's spouse ("in a meeting"), senior partner ("doctor's appointment") and bank manager ("er, still in a meeting"), without making the odd slip-up? (Hint: the mother-in-law's funeral excuse will elicit sympathy from colleagues, but won't wash with the boss's wife.)

There is an escape route for those PAs currently risking Pinocchio syndrome while the boss idles away his or her office hours on the golf course, an extended lunch break or at the dentist's (depending on who's asking), in the form of a website designed to add a professional gloss to the ancient art of lying your head off. For a fee, Ace Alibi will do all that dirty work for you, providing convincing invitations to fake business conferences (£20) and official-sounding phone calls to confirm that the person in question really is needed elsewhere (£15). "It's not all that unusual," says co-founder John Watson. "Everybody has made an excuse for somebody else in the past. It's basically an extension of that."

It's certainly a step ahead of those overused, fall-back excuses, the Very Important Meeting and the sudden debilitating medical complaint. If your boss is planning a few days out of the office on "business", why not enlist Ace Alibi to provide just that? A specially designated telephone number will connect the suspicious straight to a "conference organiser" or "hotel receptionist", who should convince even the most sceptical that the guilty party really is hard at work. If the business trip is in Cardiff, the voice at the end of the line will be a Welsh one, 24 hours a day for as long as the act needs to be kept up. If that essential conference is in California, an invitation will arrive with a US postmark.

The idea for the sneaky service dawned on Watson and partner Scott Hill when a friend enlisted their help to spirit him away from his mother-in-law's birthday party and through the turnstiles of the Rangers-Celtic derby. "We sent him a letter saying that he had to be somewhere else," explains Watson. "It was such a great idea that we had to try it on a grander scale, so we put the site together. And since January, we've been swamped."

Most of those using the service, according to Watson, are professionals, but he can't be drawn on why they use it: "We don't ask," is his tightlipped response. Officially, Ace Alibi doesn't provide excuses for the workshy to skip the office, for fear of upsetting employment laws and contracts, but the "no questions asked" policy means that it never really knows what members are up to. Before you start planning a second life, though, bear in mind that it won't provide really long term cover - it caters for the occasional, rather than the pathological, liar.

It is here, claims the website, "to help you through this moment of madness" - and more than 1,000 people have had one of those moments since Ace Alibi was set up last year, which adds up to an awful lot of excuses.

Fortunately, Watson has a lot of "resourceful" friends, who have been roped in to answer phone calls from the doubters. The problem of recruiting staff for such a business is that you need a constant supply of convincing dissemblers who can be trusted absolutely. "We can't advertise for staff," says Watson. "With the amount of confidential information we have, it would be quite dangerous."

So the next time you find yourself making excuses for the boss's extramural pursuits, congratulate yourself on being both discreet and mendacious enough to warrant his trust. Then get on the phone to Ace Alibi. After all that lying, don't you think you deserve a few days off work?

fields.headline: Gamble pays dividends
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan is a gambler. He likes to bet on the videos of American horse meetings brought into the England camp, as well as on the Racing Channel that is piped in to their hotel in Spa. He is also fond of a bet on cards and it is said that he likes to go blind. When you win, you can win big. In Charleroi he did.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan is a gambler. He likes to bet on the videos of American horse meetings brought into the England camp, as well as on the Racing Channel that is piped in to their hotel in Spa. He is also fond of a bet on cards and it is said that he likes to go blind. When you win, you can win big. In Charleroi he did.

Learning of his penchant for the ponies adds up, which is more than his teams do when it comes to competing against greater numbers in midfield. In Charleroi he sent out a formation to face Germany that remained obdurately 4-4-2 despite evidence it didn't work against Portugal in the previous game. Letters to the Sports Editor, please, explaining how simple injury swaps, Martin Keown for Tony Adams and Dennis Wise for Steve McManaman, improve the team.

Perhaps Keegan believed that England could not cave in so dramatically this time; perhaps he believed, like the whole of Germany it seems, that this was the feeblest German team for many a year. On that score, at least, Keegan would have been right.

Germany were without Oliver Bierhoff up front, so England were confronted by two strikers in Carsten Jancker and Ulf Kirsten, of the ponderous type they encounter often in the Premiership. It must have been a relief for Sol Campbell and Keown after those dastardly dervish Portuguese.

With Lothar Matthaeus leg-weary in defence - he made his debut for the West Germans when Michael Owen was one - it offered England a gilt-edged opportunity to repeat their last win over the Germans in a major competition, that skirmish of 34 years ago.

They deserve their weekend of celebration, basking in the joy of a grateful nation after three points that go a long way towards taking them to a quarter-final against Italy. When the strategy is assessed, though, you can only hope that the confidence does not become complacency. There remains much room for improvement.

Initially the Germans dictated a cagey pace to the game with some possession football but the openings were marred by weak finishing - lame, low shots that failed to test fully the theory of David Seaman's demise. It was mediocre stuff to witness but at least the driving force of Paul Ince was receiving more support protecting his back four, Paul Scholes getting up and down the pitch to productive effect. Ince was a little fortunate, like others, that the referee, Pierluigi Collina, with whom he seems to have a relationship akin to Butler and Blakey in On The Buses, was at his most tolerant.

Finally England increased the tempo just before the interval with Owen's header that Oliver Kahn tipped on to a post. It was a spell of self-confidence, if not conviction, that culminated in Alan Shearer's goal. He continues to render us humbled when it seems the case against him edges towards the irrefutable.

Germany now found some urgency of their own and Carsten Jancker, twice, and Mehmet Scholl went, for England, worryingly close. At last Keegan balanced his books, sending on Steven Gerrard to stiffen the midfield, enabling Scholes, then Nicky Barmby to alternate between midfield and attack with more flexibility. Naturally the man withdrawn to make way was Owen rather than Shearer.

So was Matthaeus finally made to eat his famous words offered as a definition of football: '22 men run around after a ball for 90 minutes and then the Germans win.' After all the reservations about him and them, and the pain of a nation for 30-something years, Keegan and England needed this Teutonic.

webTitle: Agony, but I think it's over

fields.headline: Agony, but I think it's over
fields.trailText: Will Buckley puts TV coverage of the big game to the test
fields.body:
The big one. It doesn't come Bigger than this. Big head to Big head between two of the Biggest names in European television. Twenty years of Birt hasn't stopped them broadcasting.

On the number one button, the public servants; on the number three button, the flash entrepreneurs. The rules as follows: Football is a game of possession as is commentary. The object is to get control of the viewer and keep him as long as possible. One gaffe and it's over to the other channel. The winner will be the broadcaster who accumulates the greater number of minutes.

Over to Des with the team news. Light a fag. What in the holy name of Alan Shearer is that? The thunderous sound of a thousand smoke-alarms. Worried punters hurry out of the Posthouse Forte - your guilty correspondent has no time to put on socks and shoes. Outside the Forte, a relatively well-dressed man approaches a barefooted man and asks him for money. Disconcerting. Fortunately, the fire engines declare all-clear in time for the national anthems.

The BBC start with the ball: And it's a very careful start from Motty and Trevor. Motty, aware of the import of the occasion, doesn't attempt any recherche research. Trevor is Trevor. It's obvious with so few risks being taken that the refereeing must be punitive.

5:36. Motty says, 'The German marking's always sound.' Not recently it hasn't been.

5:38. Clive Tyldesley says, 'If you see him [Matthäus] stretching his back it's because of all his knife wounds.' Rubbish, it's because he's old.

12:26. After a long period of possession Trevor stutters over 'p...p...p...ace'. Unfair perhaps and it's possible that the video replay will show it was a mechanical rather than a Trevor fault, but... the decision's made.

21:56. Clive talks about 'everyone's biting their fingernails, it's been bitty', which is a bit graphic but just OK. Big Ron cracks a joke about the ref thinking Jancker might be his son. They're playing well when Ron says of a dubious offside decision against Owen, 'I think he's less than level'.

23:15. Motty mentions 'teacups trembling at home'. Was anyone, who wasn't stuck in a Forte Posthouse with a defunct mini-bar, really drinking tea?

31:45. Big Ron says, 'Fortunately for us the big leader they've got is not on the end of it.' No mention of them having big leaders, thank you, Ron.

35:14. Trevor says, 'yer actual throw-in'.

37:37. Big Ron says, 'They must think the Germans are going to come at us with a blitzkreig.' Second offence. Yellow card for Big Ron.

The BBC maintain possession until half-time which comes at 47.00. Score - BBC 26.33, ITV 20.17 .

ITV doddle half-time. The BBC are undone by Lineker's attempts to interupt Cruyff 'yup...yup...yup...Martin...MARTIN.' Bobby Robson lets loose a stream of 'littles' including calling Wise 'a great little through-ball merchant'. ITV start the second half.

53:05. Clive says, 'Seven internationals without a goal he was just waiting for Germany.'

64:43. Motty talks of 'Keegan and Company'.

72:13. Ron speaks of 'stickability' before Clive calls Barmby 'a born-again international'.

78:47. Trevor says, 'You don't really expect me to say definitely.' No?

87:37. Ron says 'ugly ball' once too often.

Motty plays out time before he says 'This is agonising... but it's over.' Already TV companies are devising crap game shows called 'This is Agonising...'

Second half: BBC 22.35, ITV 24.35.

Full-time: BBC 49.08, ITV 44.52 . All hail Auntie.

fields.headline: Lara 'laid bets' accusation
fields.trailText: The West Indies Cricket Board today launched a 'thorough investigation' into allegations that Brian Lara placed bets on matches in South Africa and supplied information to a bookmaker.
fields.body:
The West Indies Cricket Board today launched a 'thorough investigation' into allegations that Brian Lara placed bets on matches in South Africa and supplied information to a bookmaker.

Lara, who scored a 50 against England in the first Test at Edgbaston on Friday, is alleged to have put money on individual performances during matches in a triangular one-day tournament in South Africa in 1993.

A statement signed by a Cape Town businessman, who claims he handed £4,500 in winnings to the West Indian batsman, has been received by the United Cricket Board of South Africa's lawyers and will be passed on to the King Commission currently investigating match-fixing.

The allegations do not suggest Lara was involved in match-fixing and the affidavit does not specify whether he placed bets on games in which he was involved.

West Indies officials initially refused to comment on the claims, but Patrick Rousseau, the president of the West Indies Cricket Board, has launched an investigation into the charges. 'I've discussed these allegations with Brian and he's denied any involvement with anyone as implied in the report,' said Rousseau. 'Until any allegation is proven, I accept his position and support him fully.'

The businessman said he contacted South Africa's United Cricket Board, 'Because I'm angry that only South African cricketers are being accused of illegal activities when I know overseas players have also been involved.' The businessman said he learned of Lara's gambling habits through Stanley Behrman, a bookmaker in Cape Town. On 3 March 1993, Behrman gave the businessman 20,000 rand in an envelope and requested that he give the money to Lara for winning bets, according to the businessman.

'I met Lara at the players' enclosure [at Newlands Stadium in Cape Town] and gave him the envelope. He was expecting the money and left after a brief chat. After the game Lara and I had dinner,' he said.

fields.headline: My part in Cronje'sdownfall
fields.trailText: It is unseemly to brag and poor form to boast but such sentiments are usually uttered by those with plenty to be showy about. The less fortunate tend to operate on the principle - 'if you ain't got much, flaunt'.
fields.body:
It is unseemly to brag and poor form to boast but such sentiments are usually uttered by those with plenty to be showy about. The less fortunate tend to operate on the principle - 'if you ain't got much, flaunt'.

Last week, I discovered I had fulfilled a childish and unlikely dream - albeit one still shared by at least a generation of England cricketers - by playing my part in helping England achieve a Test match victory. And I'm talking a proper victory rather than a streaky win against Zimbabawe. Not even the most preternaturally defeatist child spends his sleeping hours dreaming about rolling over the Flower brothers.

The fact is that without various journalists having written punchy articles depicting Cronje as being ultra-negative, even by South African standards, England would not have won that Test in Cape Town.

It was these accusations allied to a handful of dollars and the offer of a leather jacket that enabled the bookie to convince Cronje that it would be good for his image, his bank-balance and his wardrobe if he were to make his extraordinary declaration.

Cronje acceded to the bookie's request and I'm surely allowed to kid myself that an article which was particularly vituperative in its intemperate and persistent use of terms of abuse such as 'rope' and 'jappie' may have tipped the balance.

Naturally I am happy to share the credit with the leather jacket, although until we know more about the garment - was it three-quarter-length, fawn, fake leather? - I would advise caution before we shower it with too much praise.

Now I'm not quite so unfortunate that I would swank about playing a minor role in the winning of one test match and a dead one at that. What excites me is that the ramifications from the Cronje affair may provide a possible way back for this England side.

I'll call it the domino theory. As the crims fall out, Cronje fingers Azharuddin who fingers A. N. Other who fingers A. N. Another who fingers A. N. Yetanother and so on until every professional cricketer in the world is drummed out of the game for life. Apart, of course, from the English cricketers who remain on the whole unfingered and when fingered rely on the 'why bother?' defence that holds good across the globe.

If this seems unlikely you should have been at Edgbaston yesterday because they sure as hell aren't going to win a Test Match any other way.

The story is best told in the language that most cricketers best understand - odds. England started at 7/1 and after Jimmy '11 r.p.h (runs per hour)' Adams had ground his way to 98 to steer his team to a lead of 218 they were a very cramped 14/1 at lunch.

In the afternoon they were unbackable - both in the literal sense that no-one of even unsound mind would think of betting on them, and in the practical one that the collapse was so rapid that the bookies didn't have time to lengthen the odds after the fall of one wicket before another one had tumbled. By tea, the book was closed. 'What about Headingly '81?' 'The book is closed, Sir.' We had reached that rarest of times: the unfixable cricket match. Even the bookies wouldn't bet.

The strange, or I suppose not so strange, thing was that batting had looked very comfortable for the West Indian tailenders in the morning. Reon King (Test average 1.9, highest score 4 not out) batted for a minute under an hour. To be fair to England they did manage to dismiss him for one which was, the alert will notice, better than average. To also be fair to England it was their only achievement that was anywhere near average.

Only Atherton offered hope. Hope not of victory but that he might make the lowest score by someone carrying their bat. But when he was fifth out for 19, A.B Tancred's record of 26 not out, set in 1888/9, remained intact. Tancred, incidentally, was South African. There's no escaping them.

Not even the most preternaturally defeatist child spends his sleeping hours dreaming about rolling over the Flower brothers. The fact is that without various journalists having written punchy articles depicting Cronje as being ultra-negative, even by South African standards, England would not have won that Test in Cape Town. It was these accusations allied to a handful of dollars and the offer of a leather jacket that enabled the bookie to convince Cronje that it would be good for his image, his bank-balance and his wardrobe if he were to make his extraordinary declaration. Cronje acceded to the bookie's request and I'm surely allowed to kid myself that an article which was particularly vituperative in its intemperate and persistent use of terms of abuse such as 'rope' and 'jappie' may have tipped the balance. Naturally I am happy to share the credit with the leather jacket, although until we know more about the garment - was it three-quarter-length, fawn, fake leather? - I would advise caution before we shower it with too much praise. Now I'm not quite so unfortunate that I would swank about playing a minor role in the winning of one test match and a dead one at that. What excites me is that the ramifications from the Cronje affair may provide a possible way back for this England side. I'll call it the domino theory. As the crims fall out, Cronje fingers Azharuddin who fingers A. N. Other who fingers A. N. Another who fingers A. N. Yetanother and so on until every professional cricketer in the world is drummed out of the game for life. Apart, of course, from the English cricketers who remain on the whole unfingered and when fingered rely on the 'why bother?' defence that holds good across the globe. If this seems unlikely you should have been at Edgbaston yesterday because they sure as hell aren't going to win a Test Match any other way. The story is best told in the language that most cricketers best understand - odds. England started at 7/1 and after Jimmy '11 r.p.h (runs per hour)' Adams had ground his way to 98 to steer his team to a lead of 218 they were a very cramped 14/1 at lunch. In the afternoon they were unbackable - both in the literal sense that no-one of even unsound mind would think of betting on them, and in the practical one that the collapse was so rapid that the bookies didn't have time to lengthen the odds after the fall of one wicket before another one had tumbled. By tea, the book was closed. 'What about Headingly '81?' 'The book is closed, Sir.' We had reached that rarest of times: the unfixable cricket match. Even the bookies wouldn't bet. The strange, or I suppose not so strange, thing was that batting had looked very comfortable for the West Indian tailenders in the morning. Reon King (Test average 1.9, highest score 4 not out) batted for a minute under an hour. To be fair to England they did manage to dismiss him for one which was, the alert will notice, better than average. To also be fair to England it was their only achievement that was anywhere near average. Only Atherton offered hope. Hope not of victory but that he might make the lowest score by someone carrying their bat. But when he was fifth out for 19, A.B Tancred's record of 26 not out, set in 1888/9, remained intact. Tancred, incidentally, was South African. There's no escaping them.

webTitle: 2000: England put an end to 34 years of hurt

fields.headline: England put an end to 34 years of hurt
fields.standfirst:
"It was hardly a fitting end to more than three decades of waiting - two ageing and pedestrian sides playing out one of the dullest games of the tournament - but sometimes the result is everything."

England v Germany: a rivalry of two halves

England under Sven - Observer special
fields.trailText: This was far from the greatest England performance of all time, but at the final whistle, when German heads dropped and Kevin Keegan's much maligned players leapt with joy, it felt a bit like it.
fields.body:
This was far from the greatest England performance of all time, but at the final whistle, when German heads dropped and Kevin Keegan's much maligned players leapt with joy, it felt a bit like it.

England are alive again in Euro 2000 after defeating their oldest rivals to move into second place in their group behind Portugal. Romania could still qualify at England's expense by beating them on Tuesday, but the only way the Germans can reach the quarter-finals is by beating Portugal handsomely on the same day and hoping England lose.

It was hardly a fitting end to more than three decades of waiting - two ageing and pedestrian sides playing out one of the dullest games of the tournament - but sometimes the result is everything. To put it another way, had England lost or even drawn to this woebegone German team it would have been one of the most savage blows to their self-esteem in all those 34 years of hurt.

Alan Shearer scored the all-important goal, not one of his most difficult but a strike destined to be remembered longer than many others, early in the second half. They had to survive a few subsequent scares, but England did enough to confirm they are not the worst team in their group. Indeed, England could swagger into the quarter-finals with confidence. They may need to, for Italy in Brussels are their most likely opponents.

The French sports daily L'Equipe described this match as a meeting of the dinosaurs, implying in that affectionately mocking tone it now uses for other countries' football that a process of natural selection is taking place to decide which behemoth of the old order becomes extinct first. By current French standards the football on offer in Charleroi was not very high up the evolutionary scale, but neither of these teams were looking to win points for technical merit. This showdown was about two things, history and the immediate future. The French might sneer, but they enjoy this atavistic rivalry as much as anyone. Press tickets for this boxy little ground were among the most sought after of the tournament so far, and L'Equipe and other French titles were right at the head of the queue.

England won the sartorial contest first, taking the field in a reprise of their World Cup-winning scarlet, while the Germans appeared in a ghastly shade of mortuary attendant green. English fans easily outnumbered their German counterparts as well, jeering during their opponents' national anthem then bellowing God Save the Queen loudly enough to drown out the whistles from the other end.

Germany began cagily, that is to say even more cagily than usual, with Lothar Matthäus positioning himself just in front of the back two defenders and trying to ensure there was always someone else picking up Michael Owen. The German veteran was beaten for pace by Alan Shearer as early as the fourth minute, but his blatant check on the England captain was only punished by a free kick.

The Germans began shooting first, but England's aim was better. From a Gary Neville long throw, Shearer won the penalty box header, Paul Scholes chased to return the ball smartly across goal, and with Oliver Kahn stranded Christian Ziege had to clear from under his crossbar under pressure from Owen. Midway through the half Jens Jeremies engineered a shooting chance for Mehmet Scholl, but his underhit effort was easily saved by David Seaman with the unmarked Ulf Kirsten unseen at the far post.

Owen was somewhat harshly called back for offside when Shearer had put him clear, but just at the point in the first half when German fans struck up an amusing chorus of 'You're shit, and you know you are', England made a couple of decent attempts to prove otherwise. Owen got a fine hearder on target from Phil Neville's left wing cross, but turned to see Kahn diving full length to tip the ball on to his left hand post. Then Scholes, one of England's busiest attackers, struck a volley sweetly but too high. David Beckham spoiled this encouraging patch by collecting an unnecessary booking for piling into Kirsten, although Jeremies was also cautioned seconds later for kicking Paul Ince. Honours even but England had arguably created the better first-half chances.

Germany helped correct that impression by opening the second half with a narrow miss from a Ziege free kick, but with both teams simultaneously pushing up their back lines and keeping their forward players closely reined, play was compressed in the middle and chances from open play few.

When the breakthrough came it was inevitably from a set-piece. Beckham's curled free kick from the right was intended for Owen, but he, Scholes, and the German defence missed it and the ball bounced once before reaching Shearer, who was never likely to miss with a free header at the far post. Germany never used to concede such soft goals, but after opening his account for the tournament the England captain was not about to complain. Neither was Keegan, who thanked the media for baiting his captain into scoring for the first time in eight games.

Germany were forced to abandon some of their caution, and they stepped up the pace. Carsten Jancker found himself in possession with his back to goal in England's six yard box, and though he has a turning circle only slightly tighter than the team bus, he still managed a shot which flew inches over. When Scholl broke through for a shot which rolled just the wrong side of Seaman's right hand upright, Keegan had seen enough. Off came Owen for Liverpool teammate Steven Gerrard, presumably to provide the midfield stiffening England had lacked against Portugal.

One could see Keegan's reasoning, one goal had every chance of being enough in this ambulatory affair although there is a risk of retreating too far from attack. England had a narrow escape in the 64th minute when Seaman saved from Kirsten from a corner, and Jancker drilled the rebound wastefully wide - scoring looked easier.

Nick Barmby helped redress the balance when he replaced the tiring Scholes. Markus Babbel was booked for dissent just before the end as German nerves began to frazzle and, remarkably, Matthaus stayed on the pitch for the whole 90 minutes, but his time is now surely up, just as it is for the era of German dominance.

fields.headline: Kumble does it quickly
fields.standfirst: Leicestershire wrap it all up in time for tea despite late resistance from Derbyshire
fields.trailText: Leicestershire wrap it all up in time for tea despite late resistance from Derbyshire
fields.body:
Whether the Grace Road faithful were hoping for a decent amount of cricket is a question that even they may have had difficulty answering honestly.

They wanted the win that would would elevate Leicestershire - winners in 1999 and third last year - into second place in this year's first division. Snapping up the last five Derbyshire wickets quickly would achieve that inside, perhaps, half an hour. Is that what they really wanted? Family shopping before lunch?

County cricket these days is continually posing such questions. At Worcester, Basingstoke, Headingley and The Oval there wasn't any play for a Saturday crowd, these games having raced to a conclusion on the third day.

At this rate it may be necessary to give a couple of points to teams who make it into a fourth day. Here, though, such points would have been won spuriously, for yesterday was effectively day three because of the loss of the opening day.

Here, as elsewhere, the side batting second simply wilted when faced with a target of 300-plus. Having slumped to only 133 in the first innings Derbyshire were 116 for five on the resumption. Logic suggested they might struggle to score 61 more and make Leicestershire bat again.

Yet it needed only one decent partnership to possibly embarrass the home side in the final innings. And the pitch was good: evenly grassed and dry, offering only modest bounce and turn. Whether Steve Titchard and Matthew Cassar had the commitment and the ability to seize the stage was another question.

Ominously, Anil Kumble threatened to tie up one end and to take most of the remaining wickets. The tall Indian may not have been operating on the sort of pitch on which he once took all 10 wickets in a Test but even on this surface his quickish leg-spin can be as effective as drip torture. So far in the two innings he had bowled 29 overs for 38 runs, and four wickets. He started meanly, but before long there was an uncharacteristic over. A no-ball was cut for three, and another ball that was too short followed that one to the boundary. Tichard looked a little uneasy, but Cassar hinted at effective defiance.

One might expect that from a player brought up in Australia - and who played for New South Wales colts - but his batting for Derbyshire has been notable more for its sunny complexion than hard figures. Last season 24 innings produced a top score of just 42 and an average of 18.

There was an insight into that record when Kumble flighted one generously, inviting the off-side drive. Cassar took the bait and opened his shoulders, only to change his mind and play a one-handed stroke, the ball lobbing very close to cover.

But later there were some genuine counter-attacks: a lofted straight drive to the fence off Kumble and then, against this fine bowler, successive pick-upshots to midwicket. The first went for six, the second for four, and they were clean, authoritative strokes.

The second of them ensured that Leicestershire would have to bat again. By this time Titchard was out, failing to keep down a ball from James Ormond that he should have had time to counter. But the real body blow came with another short ball that was bowled to Cassar, on 40, by Vince Wells. It may have been a little quicker than normal from the medium-pacer, and Cassar, cramped, could only sky it to mid-on.

Three balls later, Dominic Cork got his front pad but not his bat in the way of an off-stump ball and was lbw - as he had been, in identical circumstances, in the first innings. After that, the resistance of Karl Krikken and Paul Aldred was hardly here nor there - albeit that it must have frustrated Kumble, who despite many appeals, had taken no more wickets when finally he was rested at 2.20.

Requiring 47 to win, Leicestershire knocked them off without alarm. In fact, a 3.15 finish was perfect timing for the Grace Road faithful. Let no one suggest that it had all been fixed.

fields.headline: Downside of perfect pitch
fields.trailText: Just pause to consider how life must have felt for Mike Atherton and Mark Ramprakash yesterday morning, young men lucky enough to be opening the batting for England on a lovely summer's Saturday in June.
fields.body:
Just pause to consider how life must have felt for Mike Atherton and Mark Ramprakash yesterday morning, young men lucky enough to be opening the batting for England on a lovely summer's Saturday in June.

One thing they could be certain of is that they would get a knock later on, no doubt about it. No rain likely until next week, only three wickets to fall in the West Indies innings. What pleasure, you might feel, for men at the height of their profession.

High hopes must have had doubts mixed in. First the England batsmen, who had already started play and been in the field for 109 overs, were all too aware that the task was becoming harder and harder, run by relentless run.

Above all, our two opening batsmen must have felt their task to be uneven. England's bowlers, the wholehearted Darren Gough and the less threatening Andy Caddick, may have been encouraged by the uneven bounce; but our opening batsmen would be all too aware of the difference in quality in comparison with what they would be facing - every deviation in bounce increased by the height of the point of delivery, every variation a telling one because so few balls would be wasted.

Superficially, the task presented in this series for England batsmen looks similar to that faced by their predecessors in the late Seventies and Eighties. There are four big fast bowlers to be sure. But the style is different now. West Indies vintage 2000 does without bouncers, at least on this type of pitch.

Curtly Ambrose and Courtney Walsh regard them these days as something of a waste of energy, and even the faster Reon King and Franklyn Rose have bothered little with short-pitch bowling.

Instead, there is a relentless accuracy in which the half-volley seems a thing of the past, and yet hardly a ball can be left in total confidence. Everything counts. As Walsh said on Thursday, after taking five for 36 in conditions that were distinctly helpful, 'I didn't fight against the pitch,' by which he meant, I imagine, that he didn't need to force things.

Bowling within himself, angling the ball in towards the corner of the off-stump from behind his left ear, and allowing the pitch to help it dart in towards leg or, even more disconcertingly, hold and straighten towards the slips, all at 80-plus mph. I doubt if even he knows which way, or whether, the ball will move.

At the other end there is no let-off. When Curtly Ambrose first arrived on the scene, he was aptly described as a Tom Cartwright with an extra foot on top and an extra 15 miles an hour.

For those without long memories, I should say that Cartwright was the by-word in County Cricket for pin-point accuracy. You could stay in against him for an hour and not have a clue where a run might come from. Though Ambrose has now lost a bit in pace, I'd almost prefer to have the physical threat.

What can a batsman do? How, for instance, might Steve Waugh have approached the job, and what is it about him that might give him an advantage over England's batsmen?

Waugh is, of course, one of the best players in the world; I choose him for my thought experiment because his superiority over other good Test batsmen does not, as might be said of Brian Lara, consist in the ability to do things that no one else can do. Rather, his excellence lies mainly in doing even better what others do well.

Perhaps I could sum up Waugh's superiority, as I conceive it, in four factors: first, as one of the commentators said, Waugh manages not to follow the ball when it's moved away at speed. He does not 'offer' towards it. This may sound easy but it is actually fiendishly difficult.

All one's natural instincts as a ball player tell one to get as close to the ball that one is trying to hit as possible, but somehow Waugh has trained himself not to be drawn like iron filings to a magnet towards the out-curving ball.

A related quality is his imperturbability. If he plays and misses he frets less than the next man. He believed in his own ability even when looking all at sea. In this respect he is like Geoff Boycott, a great survivor when the odds were against him.

Third, Waugh has wonderful shot selection. He will not attempt to force the ball off the back foot early in his innings when there is danger of movement and of variable bounce.

Finally, having forced the bowler to bowl closer to the stumps by judiciously leaving anything wide, he is a master at getting the straight ball away wide of mid-on, with minimal risk.

To return to Atherton and Ramprakash. They were spared an awkward few minutes before lunch. But all their apprehensions were fulfilled in the minutes afterwards.

Ramprakash was trapped in front third ball. The ball that got him was difficult but perhaps not one that would have got him out when playing for Middlesex. I fear he freezes. Atherton needed all his wiles and luck to survive. After 20 overs he had scored nine runs and seen three others, besides his opening partner, go.

He might even have thought that the worst was over when he was out. So much for hopes.
