webTitle: Disappointing start, but I'm hoping to avoid Gower's fate

fields.headline: Disappointing start, but I'm hoping to avoid Gower's fate
fields.trailText: Ed Giddins offers his thoughts on the first Test, and his debut as a TMS summariser
fields.body:
There is something special about playing a Test match in front of your own crowd. This is a game I've been looking forward to for a long time and therefore it's been more than a little disappointing the way things have gone so far.

The West Indies might have had a bit of a rough trot lately, but they are still cricketing heavyweights and a very proud team. Their recent wins against Zimbabwe and Pakistan must have been big confidence boosters, and they are also sure to benefit from having the great Brian Lara back. It is impossible not to get excited about representing your country but when the opposition are one of the really big names in cricket then the incentive to perform and do well is enormous.

Things haven't gone our way but the atmosphere in the dressing room is still good. Of course there is an air of disappointment, that is only natural, but the guys have been venting their frustrations privately, which means the team has remained upbeat. Focusing on the positives is vital and that is what we are doing. A couple of bad days doesn't mean all the talent has disappeared - it just goes and hides in some funny places sometimes.

The way the calendar has been organised has meant that I haven't had any cricket since the last Test against Zimbabwe and this game, so I've had a bit of time to get involved in other things. Last week I had my first go in the commentary box when I joined the Test Match Special team for the Benson and Hedges Cup final. Anybody with an interest in cricket knows just how good these guys are and it was real thrill to work with the 'three masters'.

Aggers, Blowers ad CM-J are all very different in their approach to commentating and the contrast works wonderfully. Jonathan Agnew is very chatty and informal while Christopher Martin-Jenkins is far more technical at the microphone, discussing the use of line and length and the tactics employed.

Sharing a stint with Henry Blofeld really is an experience. The roles are clearly defined - he's the commentator and you are the summariser. I was frantically taking notes and praying something notable would happen so that I had a little to talk about at the end of the over.

Nasser Hussain heard me while he was in the car and he said he'd enjoyed listening. It was a great day - Lord's finals usually are unless you happen to lose one - and I'd love to be invited back on TMS . Not for any Tests this summer, though. It's going to be a very competitive summer. English cricket has some terrific supporters around the country and they don't get much better than the crowd that gathers for a Test match at Edgbaston. They are very good-natured and enjoy a bit of banter with the players. They certainly deserve to see some good cricket and hopefully we can give them that despite our disappointing start.

After all the excitement of the Lord's Test I don't really feel I've done myself justice in this game but I've always had great self-belief and I'll bounce straight back. On Friday evening I bumped into David Gower at the end of play and as things hadn't gone that well I thought I'd ask him if he had any words of wisdom. 'You've had one bad day against the West Indies,' he said. 'I had two whole series'.

I'll be doing my best to make sure that doesn't happen.

fields.headline: Akram is now a hero
fields.trailText: The Hansie Cronje match-fixing affair may be raging thousands of miles away at the King Commission in South Africa, but Pakistan's former captain Wasim Akram - implicated in his own country's recent Qayyum report - played key roles with both bat and ball to help Pakistan to a five-wicket victory over Sri Lanka yesterday.
fields.body:
The Hansie Cronje match-fixing affair may be raging thousands of miles away at the King Commission in South Africa, but Pakistan's former captain Wasim Akram - implicated in his own country's recent Qayyum report - played key roles with both bat and ball to help Pakistan to a five-wicket victory over Sri Lanka yesterday.

Akram claimed five wickets in a test innings for the twenty-fifth time and then scored an unbeaten 20 in 105 minutes after Pakistan, chasing a modest victory target of 131 had slipped to 89 for five.

He and Younis Khan, who made 32, took their side to victory, Younis sealing their triumph with two huge sixes off Muttiah Muralitharan who had threatened to turn the tables on Pakistan by taking three wickets.

Sri Lanka, 53 for two overnight, had been bundled out for 123 in their second innings shortly after lunch. Akram, who on Friday had claimed his 400th test wicket, finished with five for 45.

He dismissed Chaminda Vaas and Nuwan Zoysa off successive deliveries after the pair had put on 32 for the eighth wicket. Excellent bowling by off-spinner Arshad Khan, who claimed three for 30, had reduced Sri Lanka to 88 for seven.

Akram followed up his double strike to claim the prize wicket of former captain Arjuna Ranatunga and then bowled Test debutant Dilhara Fernando for nought to end the Sri Lanka innings.

fields.headline: The football
fields.trailText: Euro 2000 is shaping up to be a pleasant surprise, a wholly unexpected feast of open and entertaining football to confound all the dire predictions of chaotic organisation and hooliganism.
fields.body:
Euro 2000 is shaping up to be a pleasant surprise, a wholly unexpected feast of open and entertaining football to confound all the dire predictions of chaotic organisation and hooliganism.

Some of the ticketing and stewarding arrangements have been chaotic, and there is still time for trouble to erupt, but the first week has been blissfully devoid of anything to overshadow the football.

For the most part teams have been favouring attack and adventure, there have been hardly any draws and only one scoreless game, and already we have seen some terrific goals. With the additional blessings of warm weather, perfect pitches and real atmosphere this is what major football tournaments should be all about. Note to younger readers: before Fifa rule changes took effect in the mid-Nineties, major tournaments were not like this.

Even more surprising is the fact that referees have been running this tournament with a minimum of red cards and officiousness. They have made the odd mistake, but they have not been spoiling the spectacle for everyone else by rigidly enforcing the latest guideline or following instructions to the letter. One suspects Uefa has told them to relax and enjoy themselves, and remember that this is not a Fifa tournament. If so, congratulations are in order. If the rest of the competition lives up to its opening-week promise, we should be left with nothing but pleasant memories. It could all have been a lot better from an England point of view, of course, but not even Uefa can guarantee everyone a happy ending.

fields.headline: The fans
fields.trailText: Norway's huge army of Viking-helmeted fans have enlivened the tournament more than any other.
fields.body:
Norway's huge army of Viking-helmeted fans have enlivened the tournament more than any other.

Their sheer numbers - about 15,000 watched Flo, Iversen and Solskjaer overcome Spain - the noise they make and their uncomplicated joy simply at being at Euro 2000 are reminiscent of the republic of Ireland's supporters in Jack Charlton's hey-day. Like the Irish, the Norsemen know that despite some good results at major tournaments, their team will forever be underdogs - and seem to like that.

The scale and infectious enthusiasm of the Nordic contingent contrasts starkly with the poor turnout of, and subdued atmosphere among, both the Italian and Spanish supporters. Neither have really got noisily behind their respective sets of big-name players. The Spanish have little excuse, as Spain were one of the favourites for Euro 2000, while at least the Italians can point to the moribund state of calcio in Serie A , and the fact that pre-tournament at least few people expected Dino Zoff's Azzuri to do well.

The Slovenians deserve special praise. About 4,000 made the 600-mile trip across Austria and Germany to witness their team's debut at a major tournament, the epic 3-3 draw with arch-rivals Yugoslavia. Double that number are expected in Amsterdam today for the game with Spain which could prolong the tiny Alpine republic's unlikely but excellent football adventure. Like the Norwegians, they are friendly, boisterous and good-natured - everything the Ingerland mob are not.

Turkey's fans rightly earned their FA a £10,000 fine for attacking Scottish referee Hugh Dallas with missiles after the dodgy penalty he awarded Italy last Sunday. Until then, though, their chanting, hooter-blowing and drum-beating had shown the more admirable side of their legendary fervour. DC

fields.headline: Best and worst
fields.trailText: Best goal
fields.body:
Best goal

Almost any one of the five in the England-Portugal match. Both England goals were high-quality, especially the second, and all Portugal's efforts were either spectacular or deftly worked. Best of the lot was Portugal's second, a patiently engineered opening on the right followed by a precision Rui Costa cross and a perfect diving header from João Pinto. Amy Lawrence goes for Stefano Fiore (Italy against Belgium). Filip De Wilde didn't have to feel embarrassed about that one. And Ian Ridley takes Luis Figo against England, just ahead of Emile Mpenza's spectacular shot in the opening game.

Best player

Luis Figo was voted man of the match for Portugal against England, though some would have gone for Rui Costa. In the great wide world beyond Kevin Keegan's domain, however, Pavel Nedved has looked good for the Czechs and, equally predictably, Zinedine Zidane has been outstanding for France. For Lawrence, it's a bewildering choice between Zidane, Boudewijn Zenden and Slovenia's Zlatko Zahovic, who led by glorious example.

Best game

Has to be the England-Portugal match, which from a neutral point of view was exciting, eventful and full of wonderful goals. The quality of the finishing, and of Portugal's talented midfield players, elevates this game above the first week's other show-stopper, the dramatic 3-3 encounter between Slovenia and Yugoslavia.

Best moment

Towards the end of the first half in the Germany-Romania game Gheorghe Hagi, aged 35, took possession 35 yards from goal, looked up at the nearest opponent ahead of him, played the ball beyond him and left him for dead. At 39, Lothar Matthäus is not as fast as he used to be; a good job Hagi wasn't Thierry Henry. Amy Lawrence prefers Yugoslavia's three-goal salvo in six breathtaking minutes against Slovenia. One of the most compelling comebacks in tournament history.

Worst gaffe

Has to be the one from the opening game when Belgium goalkeeper Filip de Wilde trod on the ball and presented Johan Mjallby with the easiest of goals. De Wilde's mistake also led to a gaffe from a Belgian TV commentator, who swore down the microphone in a moment of madness. Jose Molina's gift of a goal for Norway was memorable, too.

Worst refereeing decision

Hugh Dallas' penalty award to the Italians against Turkey looked highly suspect, and came at exactly the wrong time for the Turks. Turkey might now believe Uefa officialdom has it in for them, especially as Sweden were awarded a ludicrous free-kick right on the edge of their penalty area in the last minute of the match in Eindhoven. Fortunately nothing came of it.

Biggest disappointment

Sweden, Turkey and Filippo Inzaghi. The Juventus striker looks out of his element away from Serie A . Neither quick nor physically threatening, he has spent most of his time so far straying offside and looking perplexed. For Amy Lawrence the biggest turn-off was a certain nation's backward followers spoiling everything. The fact that it was expected doesn't make it any more bearable.

fields.headline: Euro 2000: The diary
fields.trailText: No room at the inn
fields.body:
No room at the inn

Oasis wild man Liam Gallagher endured his own humiliation just before England suffered theirs against Portugal. The temperamental singer arrived in Finnegans Wake, an Irish bar in Hamburg, minutes before kick-off only to find the place packed with Germans keen to see their old rivals lose. All seats were taken so one of pop music's most famous faces had to stand at the back craning his neck to see the action. 'Liam's problem was that hardly anyone recognised him and nobody offered him their seat,' reports my spy. Within a few minutes a frustrated Gallagher, who as a megastar is used to having his every whim indulged, stomped off to find another venue, scowling darkly. Events in Rotterdam did not improve his mood.

Sitting down on ceremony

Happier scenes in the VIP box at the Philips Stadium, at least for the first 22 minutes. The FA's refreshingly relaxed new chief executive Adam Crozier - a Scot - defied the stuffed-shirt mentality which prevails in such self important gatherings by leaping from his seat and shouting 'Yes!' as Paul Scholes's header crossed the line. Culture, Media and Sport Secretary Chris Smith quickly joined in the stand-up rejoicing. Nobody else followed, though. Other FA personal such as chairman Geoff Thompson and spin doctor David Davies remained rooted to the spot. The other dignitaries present, mainly bigwigs from Uefa and Portugal's FA , were not wildly impressed by such public jubilation. A Uefa onlooker recounts: 'Crozier and Smith were both smiling, clapping and looking round expecting everyone else to be as delighted as they were. But most other people didn't think jumping out of your seat is the right thing to do and some didn't even bother politely clapping the goal.'

Thieves in the night

England's fans enjoying a weekend in Amsterdam before the Portugal game suffered a series of robberies from their hotel rooms. Curiously, the thieves ignored valuables such as cameras and instead stole passports and England shirts. Cunning criminals took advantage of the large number of visiting supporters, many sleeping several to a room, to simply turn up at the reception of some of the cheaper hotels, request a room key and then rifle through fans' belongings . While the Amsterdam police were sympathetic, British Consular staff viewed at least one trio of fans asking for help getting home with thinly disguised contempt. 'They treated us as if we were low lifes and were downright rude and unhelpful,' said Crystal Palace fan David Whitehill. 'They seem to think every England fan is a hooligan.'

In the closet

Confusion reigned at Slovenian coach Srecko Katanec's press conference after the thrilling 3-3 draw with arch rivals Yugoslavia. A German journalist quizzed Katanec about his side throwing away a three goal lead by asking 'Can you imagine that in three weeks you will be sitting at home in your back garden thinking to yourselves you should have won that game?' Through a translator Katanec confirmed 'The players aren't very happy in the wardrobe.' The assembled hacks looked baffled: had the notoriously tough coach locked them all away as punishment for their defensive frailty? Happily not. 'Sorry, in the dressing room,' the translator quickly corrected himself.

Sun-lover Zahovic is Spain-bound

Forget the talk of Zlatko Zahovic, Slovenia's two-goal hero against Yugoslavia, coming to White Hart Lane. The gifted midfielder is set to swap Olympiakos of Athens for Spain, not Spurs. 'He'll probably go to Real Zarajoza or Celta Vigo, both of whom want to sign him, or to Fiorentina, whose manager spoke to him this week,' confided a confidante of Zahovic. 'English football is too physical for his liking, plus he wants to play somewhere sunny.'

British success - could happen

Uefa's official Euro 2000 website could become the only British success of the tournament. The site, run by London based web company Sportal - whose advertising hoardings have surrounded every group match so far - notched up a unprecedented seven million hits by the first Monday, beating the total for the France 98 website by one million page impressions - already. So while English players might be limping a bit, at least British technology can still hold a lead.

fields.headline: Costinha's chance
fields.trailText: After the exhiliration, the comedown. The beautiful football played by Humberto Coelho's team against England was nowhere to be seen in this largely dull game.
fields.byline: Gillian Darley at the Gelre Dome
fields.body:
After the exhiliration, the comedown. The beautiful football played by Humberto Coelho's team against England was nowhere to be seen in this largely dull game.

Instead the Portuguese discovered a new hero when Francisco Costinha came off the bench to score in the 95th minute and head his side into the quarter-finals of Euro 2000.

Prior to his arrival both sides had seemed content to play for a point and the game was meandering towards a draw. However, just as Romania relaxed, Costinha saw his chance, leaping inside a crowded penalty area to nod Luis Figo's left-wing free-kick past Bogdan Stelea and guarantee Portugal's continued presence in the competition.

As the Portuguese celebrated, the Romanian players slumped to the ground in depression. None more so than Gheorghe Hagi - who could have played his final game in a major competition.

Hagi, who is expected to retire from international football, ruled himself out of Tuesday's game with England after picking up his second booking of Euro 2000, 16 minutes into the game for a needless foul on Joao Pinto.

Together with the yellow card he received for dissent against Germany, five days earlier, it means his talents will be absent in Charleroi.

Afterwards Romania coach Emerich Ienei questioned the time-keeping of referee Gilles Veissiere who failed to blow the whistle until the 96th minute, despite injury time being set at four minutes.

Ienei said: 'Unfortunately we lost in the last second, maybe even after the last second because the referee showed four minutes but four minutes was over.

'Perhaps it is revenge because two years ago in Portugal we won in the last second. It looked like a draw and a point is a point. I wasn't pleased with the quality of the game but a draw would have been a good result for us.'

Portugal initially started the brighter side, dominant in midfield with Figo orchestrating affairs. But, while the Barcelona winger offered early glimpses of class, he failed to find the killer touch and the game lost its way.

The best chance of the first half fell to Nuno Gomes who dragged his shot wide across the face of goal after Cristian Chivu was caught in possession. Manuel Rui Costa fired a more difficult chance wide from 20 yards but the Portuguese then became bogged down in a game littered with free-kicks.

Vitor Baia then caused alarm when he dropped a towering left-wing cross before redeeming himself with a bold interception at the feet of Viorel Moldovan, moments later. The Portuguese keeper was extended again by Adrian Ilie who angled a free-kick towards the top corner in 26th minute.

Clearly encouraged by their first-half performance, Romania started the second half brightly. Hagi teased and tricked on the wings, although admittedly with limited success. Moldovan saw a header deflected behind from Dorinel Munteanu's inswinging corner and Hagi was wildly off-target with a left-foot volley from a narrow angle.

Perhaps sensing that the game was slipping away from his side, Coelho sent on Sa Pinto and Sergio Conceicao for Joao Pinto and Gomes. But it was the arrival of Costinha for Rui Costa, which finally made the difference.
fields.bodyText: After the exhiliration, the comedown. The beautiful football played by Humberto Coelho's team against England was nowhere to be seen in this largely dull game. Instead the Portuguese discovered a new hero when Francisco Costinha came off the bench to score in the 95th minute and head his side into the quarter-finals of Euro 2000. Prior to his arrival both sides had seemed content to play for a point and the game was meandering towards a draw. However, just as Romania relaxed, Costinha saw his chance, leaping inside a crowded penalty area to nod Luis Figo's left-wing free-kick past Bogdan Stelea and guarantee Portugal's continued presence in the competition. As the Portuguese celebrated, the Romanian players slumped to the ground in depression. None more so than Gheorghe Hagi - who could have played his final game in a major competition. Hagi, who is expected to retire from international football, ruled himself out of Tuesday's game with England after picking up his second booking of Euro 2000, 16 minutes into the game for a needless foul on Joao Pinto. Together with the yellow card he received for dissent against Germany, five days earlier, it means his talents will be absent in Charleroi. Afterwards Romania coach Emerich Ienei questioned the time-keeping of referee Gilles Veissiere who failed to blow the whistle until the 96th minute, despite injury time being set at four minutes. Ienei said: 'Unfortunately we lost in the last second, maybe even after the last second because the referee showed four minutes but four minutes was over. 'Perhaps it is revenge because two years ago in Portugal we won in the last second. It looked like a draw and a point is a point. I wasn't pleased with the quality of the game but a draw would have been a good result for us.' Portugal initially started the brighter side, dominant in midfield with Figo orchestrating affairs. But, while the Barcelona winger offered early glimpses of class, he failed to find the killer touch and the game lost its way. The best chance of the first half fell to Nuno Gomes who dragged his shot wide across the face of goal after Cristian Chivu was caught in possession. Manuel Rui Costa fired a more difficult chance wide from 20 yards but the Portuguese then became bogged down in a game littered with free-kicks. Vitor Baia then caused alarm when he dropped a towering left-wing cross before redeeming himself with a bold interception at the feet of Viorel Moldovan, moments later. The Portuguese keeper was extended again by Adrian Ilie who angled a free-kick towards the top corner in 26th minute. Clearly encouraged by their first-half performance, Romania started the second half brightly. Hagi teased and tricked on the wings, although admittedly with limited success. Moldovan saw a header deflected behind from Dorinel Munteanu's inswinging corner and Hagi was wildly off-target with a left-foot volley from a narrow angle. Perhaps sensing that the game was slipping away from his side, Coelho sent on Sa Pinto and Sergio Conceicao for Joao Pinto and Gomes. But it was the arrival of Costinha for Rui Costa, which finally made the difference.

fields.headline: Slovenia 1 - 2 Spain
fields.trailText:
Slovenia: Dabanovic, Milinovic, Milanic,
Galic, Novak, Ceh, Udovic, Zahovic,
Pavlin, Rudonja, Karic.
Subs: Simeunovic, Nemec, Bulajic,
Knavs, Gajser, Istenic, Zlogar, Siljak, Acimovic,
Pavlovic, Osterc.
fields.body:
Slovenia: Dabanovic, Milinovic, Milanic,
Galic, Novak, Ceh, Udovic, Zahovic,
Pavlin, Rudonja, Karic.
Subs: Simeunovic, Nemec, Bulajic,
Knavs, Gajser, Istenic, Zlogar, Siljak, Acimovic,
Pavlovic, Osterc.

Spain: Canizares, Salgado, Aranzabal,
Guardiola, Abelardo, Hierro, Raul,
Perez Munoz, Mendieta, Etxeberria, Valeron.
Subs: Casillas, Molina, Helguera, Fran,
Munitis, Sergi, Gerard, Engonga, Velasco,
Paco, Urzaiz Aranda.

Referee: Markus Merk (Germany)

1 min Spain kick off, having made four changes to the team which lost against Norway in their first game. Slovenia remain unchanged.
4 GOAL! Slovenia 0 - 1 Spain The first significant effort of the match and you can smell the relief. Salgado's ball hits a defender and raul unleashes a drive high into Dabanovic's net from the edge of the area.
10 Pavlin shown the yellow card after a clumsy attempt to undo his own error in midfield.
13 Zahovic outskills Guardiola and the Spaniard is lucky to avoid a caution for his clattering challenge.
15 Mendieta buys a ticket from 25 yards, the keeper gathering at the second attempt.
21 The impressive Milanic tackles back on raul as he shapes to shoot. The Slovenia veteran has been his side's saviour a few times today already.
24 Milanic yellow carded after over commiting in the challenge. The freekick wide on the right is wasted by Spain, though.
32 Slovenia sneaking back into it. This time Ceh gets forward, feeds Rudonja whose finish is lazy but still bright stuff.
35 Rudonja lively again down the left with Slovenia looking to get forward more. A move inside is blocked majestically by Abelardo. Spain are hanging in there.
40 Camacho, the Spanish coach, is getting all animated on the touchline as Spain let the Slovenians get a foothold in this game. he wants to calm down, though. It's a bit warm, like.
43 Mendieta registers his first effort on goal but it doesn't bother Dabonovic too much.
46 Canizares makes his first real save, first racing out to cut out a half-decent through ball, then saving Rudonja's follow-up shot. Just in time for oranges and a natter with the boss - half time: Slovenia 0 - 1 Spain.

46 Slovenia kick off the second half, having brought on, in a Czech stylee, a large forward (Milan Osterc) for a nippier number (Saso Udovic; nippiness in this instance is relative).
48 Raul tries his arm, rifling over.
51 Raul gets goalside of Milanic but puts his header wide of Dabanovic's right-hand post.
54 Abelardo in in the nick of time to stop Zahovic meeting Karic's cross.
59 GOAL! Slovenia 1 - 1 Spain Euro 2000's Daft Goal competetion has its latest entry, though this time the officials may have a had a part in it.Rudonja sets off down the left and cuts it back towards Osterc and Zahovic. The latter claims it which is just as well, because the bulky substitute had not so much strayed as grazed in an offside position during the build up. Still, Spain are rocking, and that can only be funny.
60 GOAL! Slovenia 1 - 2 Spain Bloody typical. Spain back ahead. A marvellous little dart in from the left by Mendieta (who hasn't dived for a while now) lets Etxeberria in and he makes no mistake; in letting it through his arms at the near post, though, Dabanovic probably does.
67Abelardo grazes the Slovenian bar with a header from Mendieta's corner following good work by the Valencia wideboy.
68 Slovenia replace Milanic with Aleksandr Knavs.
71 Spain take off Perez Munoz for the altogether chunkier Urzaiz Aranda, raising the big question of the day - can he be as crap as last Tuesday?
75 Canizares saves well from Euro 2000's current top scorer (and who saw that coming?), Zlatko Zahovic.
78 Slovenia move it upfield well through Rudonja and Karic but Abelardo is having none of it.
81 Spain take off Josep Guardiola, apparently carrying a knock, for Ivan Helguera.
82 Miran Pavlin is replaced by the presumably more adventurous (it wouldn't be difficult) Milenko Acimovic.
85 Slovenia still look keen, but this game is drifiting out. Spain are containing their opponents' limited threat.
87 Spain, with my £3 in mind, shouldn't wonder, waltz forward but can't be bothered creating a proper shooting opportunity, Etxeberria's final ball plain idle. They had better not blow it now.
92 They don't. Spain seem back on track now as the referee's whistle signals their first points of the tournament - Slovenia 1 - 2 Spain.

fields.headline: Norway 0 - 1 Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Norway: Myhre, Berg, Bragstad, Mykland, Flo, Skammelsrud, Heggem, Eggen, Iversen, E. Bakke, Solskjaer. Subs: Olsen, M. Bakke, Andersen, Strand, Solbakken, Rekdal, Riise, Carew, Riseth, Bjornebye, Bergdolmo.

Yugoslavia: Kralj, Bunjevcevic, Jokanovic, Djukic, Jugovic, Mijatovic, Milosevic, Stojkovic, Komljenovic, Saveljic, Drulovic. Subs: Kovacevic, Cicovic, Djorovic, Govedarica, Korac, Dudic, Kezman, Nadj, J. Stankovic, D. Stankovic.

Referee Hugh Dallas

1 Norway kick off in a match that has draw written all over it, but both teams are eminently capable of winning if they play to their best.
2 Flo just fails to get on the end of a cross into the six-yard box to provide an early test for Kralj in the Yugoslavia goal.
3 Stojkovic picks up possession deep on the left, gets around the back and cuts it back towards Drulovic, but Norway clear.
5 Stojkovic is warned by referee Dallas for diving under a challenge by Flo.
6 Norway win a corner, Flo gets up but Kralj punches clear.
8 GOAL! Yugoslavia 1 - 0 Norway Yugoslavia win a free-kick wide to the right of the penalty area. The ball comes in and flies through everyone but Milosevic manages to get a slight touch and direct the ball into the far corner of the net.
11 Yugoslavia win a corner after Drulovic gets away down the left. The ball is played out to Drulovic and he drills in a shot from 25 yards that is blocked on the edge of the area.
13 Mykland slides the ball through to Flo on the edge of the area; Flo shoots but Kralj saves well to put the ball behind for a corner. Lots of shoving and shirt-pulling as Yugoslavia clear.
16 Milosevic breaks up a spell of scrappy play in midfield when he charges upfield towards a long ball but is caught offside.
18 Milosevic gets up in the area to knock down a deep cross from Drulovic; he finds Mijatovic but the chance goes begging.
20 Stojkovic tries to thread a long pass through midfield towards Mijatovic but the ball out-runs him.
21 Norway win a corner; Kralj claims easily.
22 Heggem has woken up to the fact that Drulovic is enjoying far too much space on the left, and that no one else is going to pick him up; this time he closes him down for a corner. Comes to nothing.
23 Bakke crosses from deep on the right; he finds Solskjaer who turns on the edge of the six-yard box but sees his snatched shot blocked.
27 Yugoslavia put together some nice moves that end with the ball being played out to the right. It then comes back into the feet of Mijatovic, he turns his man and shoots to the near post, but Myhre saves.
28 Booking Jokanovic
30 Penalty appeals by Norway, most vocally from Mykland, when Solskjaer dives on the edge of the six-yard box.
31 Booking Mykland for dissent after carrying on at the referee.
33 Bakke and Heggem combine well to win the ball deep on the right. Hegem crosses for Flo at the far post but once again Kralj gets there first.
35 Substitution One Liverpool man for another when Heggem is replaced by Bjornebye.
36 Jokanovic has a crack from fully 35 yards, straight at Myhre. Yugoslavia look to be in control of this game, passing to feet and building up from the back, but Norway are relying too heavily on long balls.
40 Norway seem to have resorted to gratuitous diving in a bid to gain some advantage, despite the fact that Yugoslavia are one of the acknowledged masters of this tactic.
43 The game hits a lull as Norway continue to strive for a smidgeon of invention in their style of play.
45 Half-time. None too hopeful for Norway who are being made to look pedestrian by a well-oganised Yugoslavia side aiming to erase memories the disastrous start they endured at the hands of Slovenia.

46 Yugoslavia kick off the second half and Mykland is lucky to escape without a booking after a particularly heavy blocking challenge.
47 Milosevic lays the ball out to Jugovic on the edge of the Norway area, but his crisp strike is straight at Myhre. Still no great urgency about Norway.
50 Stojkovic delivers a great pass across field to Mijatovic in space at the far post, but his shot is easy for Myhre.
52 Yugoslavia free-kick nearly thirty yards out. Easy again for Myhre.
53 Norway win a corner on the right. Iverson gets up well, but his header loops into the hands of Kralj.
55 Bjornebye finds Mykland running across the Yugoslavia area; Mykland goes wide and crosses from deep on the left - Bakke heads over the bar.
57 Mijatovic, in possession in the Norway area, takes too much time and is muscled off the ball. Norway win a corner, Skammelsrud takes but Yugoslavia clear.
58 Yugoslavia push up and win a corner on the right. Flo clears but Jugovic plays it back over to the left before Norway finally bring the ball out.
60 Yugoslavia break with Jugovic; he sprays the ball wide to the left, runs on and picks up the return for a shot from the edge of the area. Myhre saves.
62 Bjornebye shoots from distance - straight at Kralj.
63 Skammelsrud goes down injured after taking an elbow in the head from Jokanovic. He leaves the field for treatment.
66 Substitution Bakke for one too many late tackles.
67 Solskjaer sprays the ball out wide to Flo but he is barged off the ball for a free-kick. The ball is launched towards Iverson in the area, but Kralj races out to punch clear and send Iverson crashing down for a short spell on his back to receive treatment.
71 Substitution Iverson ends up leaving the field to be replaced by Carew.
72 Booking Jugovic crashes into the back of Bakke.
74 Komljenovic gets kicked in the face by his own 'keeper when doing his best to foul Carew as the Norwegian tries to beat Kralj to the ball.
75 Substitution Strand on for Bakke
76 Stojkovic and Milosevis combine well to find Mijatovic running into the far side of the area. Heggem manages to poke the ball just wide of the left-hand upright as the ref blows for offside.
79 Norway win a corner. Kralj punches away for another corner. Kralj saves.
81 Booking Drulovic. Another cynical tackle. Unclear why Yugoslavia need to resort to so much play-acting and dirty tactics when they can so obviously play neat, passing football.
84 Substitution Nadj on for Stojkovic.
86 Milosevic and Mijatovic switch the ball around in the Norway area before finding Nadj, but his strike is claimed by Myhre.
87 Substitution Kezman and Mijatovic.
88 Red card After only a minute on the field, Kezman is sent off for a challenge on Mykland. Referee Dallas has clearly has enough and snapped in reaction to all that has gone before. Kezman unlucky.
Substitution Govedarica on for Jokanovic
90 Carew with a late chance after Yugoslavia lose the ball in midfield. Solskjaer helps the ball for Carew to shot from close range - he puts it wide. Booking Nadj for shirt-pulling. Full-time. Yugoslavia by far the better side and should have won by a greater margin. Norway 0 - 1 Yugoslavia.

webTitle: England face threat of expulsion if more crowd trouble

fields.headline: England face threat of expulsion if more crowd trouble
fields.trailText: UEFA today warned England could be thrown out of Euro 2000 if fans cause any more trouble in the tournament.
fields.body:
UEFA today warned England could be thrown out of Euro 2000 if fans cause any more trouble in the tournament.

European football's government body this evening held an emergency meeting of executive members in the Belgian city of Liege in the wake of trouble in Brussels and Charleroi surrounding England's victory over Germany.

Addressing a press conference after the emergency meeting, UEFA chief executive Gerhard Aigner said: "UEFA will have to determine whether the presence of the English team in the tournament should be maintained should there be a repetition of similar incidents."

Hundreds of English fans were arrested in clashes with riot police in Charleroi and Brussels before and after England's 1-0 win over Germany. Most of them have been expelled.

UEFA President Lennart Johansson described the English hooligans as "a disgrace" and said the British government had not done enough to prevent them from travelling to the tournament.

Director of Euro 2000 Alain Courtois has also blamed the British government.

"I will make three simple statements. The first is that the British government did nothing of which they promised to do. This is a huge shortcoming," Courtois said.

"When I see what the German government and Football Federation did in comparison, it's extraordinary.

"Whereas on the other side (Britain), nothing was done or executed. It is not right that 14 extremely dangerous hooligans were able to enter Belgium.

"I would also like to point out certain parties wanted the incidents to take place so they would get into the media. There were cameras situated specifically in Charleroi to film the violence," added Courtois.

"Finally, what the Belgian authorities have done is what they said they would do. By that I mean stopping potential troublemakers at the borders - 500 people stopped, that was a good indication," he added.

"How these people can leave an island, we are talking about an island here, we are not talking about somewhere else, without being intercepted. Obviously there has to have been a very lax attitude from the British government.

"They said they had made plans and forged a layout to prevent this. Well if this is their plan, bravo," concluded Courtois.

Obviously there has to have been a very lax attitude from the British government. "They said they had made plans and forged a layout to prevent this. Well if this is their plan, bravo," concluded Courtois.

fields.headline: Sweet victory - but at what price?
fields.standfirst: Would victory over Germany enable England to ignore vital tactical lessons?
fields.trailText: Euro 2000: Would victory over Germany blind England to the vital tactical lessons, asked Ian Ridley
fields.body:
Take the two nations who did most to ignite the blue touchpaper of the football enthusiast's imagination in Euro 2000's first week. The French had Gallic flair to after-burn, the magnificent Portuguese were a whirling Catherine Wheel of a side whose formation was... well, if last night's match against the Germans had not presented more pressing business, a fire-fighting England would probably still be trying to work it out.

And, while they may have differed radically in the nominal shapes of their teams, there were many similarities between France and Portugal, both almost epitomising the modern international team when at their best in their opening games. They passed accurately, moved the ball swiftly when sensing the moment to attack and the darting movements of their midfield and front players were inventive and incisive.

Above all, they operated as a unit, defending together, moving forward together, supporting the player with the ball, recognising their areas of responsibility when the opponents were in possession. There may have been individual ability aplenty within the framework, but the team was the thing. In short, they were all the things that, for the most part, England have not been when the drum-banging stops and the need is for something more orchestrated.

Even against the weakest German side of this correspondent's life, last night in Charleroi there were familiar failings of both approach and execution. The hope is that a win provides more appreciation of what is undoubtedly a talented squad of players not yet being fully stretched to their capabilities. The fear is that it will mask the need for more coaching empowerment so that they can do themselves justice.

For there is instead something haphazard to Kevin Keegan's England. For all the coach's insistence on the value of their state-of-the-art preparation, the research and the video footage, there was against Portugal an old-fashioned look to their approach, a naivety that made you wonder if the thoughtful advances made under Terry Venables at Euro 96 had been a mirage. 'Where did England go wrong?' my son asked the day after the Portugal defeat. 'How long have you got?' I replied.

The most important aspect of the game these days is the midfield numbers racket. Venables may not have always understood figures on a balance sheet, but he did recognise immediately how many beans added up to five in the area of the pitch on which any game, every game, turns.

When the team sheets arrived hot from the photocopying machines at the Philips Stadium and then in Charleroi, you feared the worst. There England were, with two strikers plonked upfield again, and two banks of four, one too many in defence, one too few in midfield.

Senior players voiced reservations before the Portugal game, but Keegan was apparently his positive self; let us play our football in their half of the field, let them worry about us. It doesn't just happen like that, however. It happens with strategy and the confidence to implement that strategy, as Venables distilled and instilled at a 90-minute team meeting the day before that memorable June night four years ago when each player left convinced they would beat Holland. It was a bizarre experience looking down and watching the Eindhoven eye-opener unfold. Even at 1-0, even at 2-0 up, England were being outmanoeuvred, constantly vulnerable to the interchanging of Luis Figo, Rui Costa and Joao Pinto. In hindsight, Keegan said, they perhaps should have sat back for 15 more minutes rather than going for the kill. But how to achieve that without the right deployment of resources? And that comes from the coach.

The reservations became more voluble and frantic at half-time with the score now 2-2, notably from an over-worked and over-maligned Paul Ince as the holding player. But still Keegan felt that same again could win the game, though the evidence, based on two moments of David Beckham at his best against the run of play that didn't even lull the Portuguese into a false sense of insecurity, was flimsy. Only when the horse had bolted - Portugal leading 3-2, and Steve McManaman off injured - was Phil Neville pushed forward on the left to allow Dennis Wise to move infield to Ince's aid.

Last night against Germany at least we saw English finishing the game with a balance in the team more suited to the demands of the game. We saw, too, Ince restoring his reputation with a tigerish display inspirational to those around him. It has to be said,however, that neither he nor the team were confronted by the sort of movement that the better sides in this tournament possess.

Some wise critics have suggested that players should take responsibility for turning the tide as games unfold, should recognise the problems and regroup accordingly. It is a valid point but it does become difficult when Keegan's persona on the field, Alan Shearer, is ploughing his own unproductive furrow and the lack of mobility and flexibility filters from the front back through the team.

England were criticised for defending too deeply against Portugal, but it became inevitable with little pressure on the ball in midfield as the back four, apprehensive, retreated in an attempt to cut off the through ball. Keegan also reverted to his square-pegs-in-round-holes mentality. Tony Adams has not played in a back four in a competitive England match since Holland at Euro '96. Neither has he played on the right side of a four since the early days of Arsène Wenger at Arsenal.

Consequently England, as of yore, became stretched out again, Michael Owen left isolated and provided with pressure-easing high and long balls.The best that can be said is that it all gave England much to work on for last night's game. That and the fact that they did contribute to a memorable, marvellous game. It would be more refreshing to report that the plucky, defeated opposition played their part, however.

It is always dangerous to draw conclusions before the baggage of the first two games has been unpacked in the third, but the least England should do is take heed of the examples of the French and Portuguese.

At given times, had the game been stopped, both were probably more of a 4-5-1 shape and it is that which does offer huge possibilities, both offensively and defensively. England were not 4-4-2 four years ago; Teddy Sheringham dropped off Shearer to help out, then find space to invent play.

The French, for example, often use Thierry Henry's pace - a pointer for Owen - from deep and wide, getting him the ball in space so that he can cut inside and attack a backpedalling defence. They are alert, too, to new ideas of the game.

It was Fabien Barthez who first utilised the six-second, unlimited-steps rule for goalkeepers by scuttling to the speedily for a counterattack.

Then the Portuguese rotation. Before Monday's game, the billing was for Figo v Beckham, the best right-wingers in the world. So where exactly was Figo when he unleashed that breathtaking 25-yarder? Variation, to pull defences out of shape, is vital. Beckham needs the licence to roam and back-up from covering players.

In addition, France and Portugal have developed their players through a progressive youth system. The nucleus of the French have come through the Clairefontaine centre of excellence, overseen by Gerard Houllier. Many of the Portuguese were members of their world under-20 cham pionship-winning team.

Belatedly, England sought to catch up by appointing Howard Wilkinson as technical director, but as soon as they get a successful under-21 team, what happens?

In a political coup, Wilkinson ousts the manager Peter Taylor. The English may have been without several important players at the recent European Championship, but at times it was almost embarrassing to watch the team chasing the swift shadows of the Slovakians.

What else has the tournament shown thus far? The value of teamwork to get the most out of the gifted individual, certainly. Zinedine Zidane is the very model of the modern midfield player, strong but with touch and vision. Rui Costa reveals that artistry, and dribbling, need not die amid the team ethic.

The Dutch initially strugggled to knit their individuals to that pattern but are improving, the unlucky Czechs had a touch of Portugal about them. The heartwarming Slovenians and even the Belgians, working touchingly to cover each other's shortcomings, have had an all-together-now purpose to them, too.

Best examples of that hitherto, though, have been Italy, with the loss through injury of their goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon and lead striker Christian Vieri serving to galvanise them into collective responsibility. A limited group, also involving the dull, functional Swedes and the disappointing Turks, has helped.

For those reasons, the Italians currently appear an exception to a trend. The most disappointing of the 'bigger' teams have so far been Spain, England and Germany, who also embrace the most significant, best-supported, leagues in Europe. Clubs dominate thinking and television. We get our kicks on Channels 1 to 66.

And therein lies a worry. When the TV money-fuelled, overseas player-dominated Premiership kicks off again in two months - and covers up amid the gloating over last night's win over a waning football superpower - the danger is that the more signifcant message of Monday in Eindhoven, will be viewed as just a forgettable damp squib... rather than the rocket up the English game's arsenal that it should have been.

webTitle: TV chiefs may find greed a turn-off

fields.headline: TV chiefs may find greed a turn-off
fields.trailText: Asx the money kept rolling in to football's coffers last week from the television companies, analysis emerged showing that fewer and fewer of us are bothering to turn on our sets to watch.
fields.body:
Asx the money kept rolling in to football's coffers last week from the television companies, analysis emerged showing that fewer and fewer of us are bothering to turn on our sets to watch.

The discrepancy increased concern among TV executives that ignoring the diverging figures for much longer could lead to difficulties. 'There's a worry in the industry that we're all being taken for a ride,' one such executive told me soon after the Premier League announced that the sale of their packages had raised £1.645 billion for three years. 'Ultimately, the punter will say, "Well I'm sorry this is too stupid. I'm not paying this kind of money any more. It's bullshit".'

The figures produced by TV Sports Markets show that Sky's Premiership coverage is not as popular as it once was, with the average audience for the 60 matches screened last season dropping by more than 14 per cent to 1.013 million. And yet Sky agreed last week to shell out £1.11 billion for 198 matches over three seasons starting next summer. This values each match at £5.6 million, double the £2.8 million they are paying at present.

'Don't think that Sky, having paid all that money, are somehow going to absorb it, because they aren't,' the executive said. 'It'll get passed on and Sky have got to be very careful how much they pass on so that they limit the damage when people start pulling out. There's a straight-line equation in the business that suggests that if you put the price up to a certain level then you'll lose more people than the churn [customers not renewing subscriptions] that you'd get from not having the product in the first place.'

At the moment, Sky packages that include their sports channels have been held under £30 a month, but this barrier seems certain to be breached.

Even more uncertainty surrounds the £328 million paid by the US-based cable company NTL for 40 pay-per-view matches for each of the three seasons from 2001-02. One City analyst reckoned that NTL, in which Bill Gates has a three per cent stake, had 'massively overpaid' for the rights to matches that will be the second pick, after Sky have gone first.

'We estimate that NTL would need more than 500,000 homes to buy each game at a price of £9.99 to break even,' the analyst said. 'This compares to an average viewership of around 350,000 homes when the games are offered as part of a subscription package and are therefore at the margin free.'

NTL's plans for how they will use the rights are not yet clear. They may try to keep them exclusive to cable, but regulatory pressure means they will be hard pressed to stop Sky getting their hands on them, although, as the analyst pointed out, NTL 'may make enough noise in the market over the next 12 months to confuse a small number of potential BSkyB customers and prevent them subscribing.'

Not all observers have been peddling a pessimistic line for the broadcasters, though. 'Whatever it took, Sky had to have football,' one industry insider said. 'They wouldn't have had a business if they hadn't got it. Look ahead six to eight years when analogue [the traditional signal that is being replaced by digital] is switched off and Sky are as readily available as BBC and ITV. Until the end of the analogue terrestrial era, Sky have to keep football going and then they're laughing.'

The same insider saw sense in NTL's investment. 'They're building a business and it's worth it to them. Their telephone business is making money for them, but they haven't yet created a successful TV business. They've seen how Sky managed it and now they're doing the same thing.'

The loss of Match of the Day remains a colossal blow to the BBC despite countering a day later with the announcement that, from the season after next, they would be sharing FA Cup and England home international coverage with Sky.

A BBC source, disappointed at the loss, said there was a psychological reason for the Beeb's negotiators having yielded the highlights contract to ITV. 'It's very difficult for someone who has a contract to consider paying more than a certain multiple of what they're already paying. Bidders who are coming in, in this case ITV, don't see it as doubling their money, they're just paying an amount that they think is appropriate.

'There's always a premium for winning something away from someone else, but it's worth that much more because of all the publicity you're going to get and what it says about the strength of your organisation. The BBC should have borne this in mind.'

And, before it gets carried away, football should bear in mind that it may be unwise to go on pushing TV to the limits of its bank balance.

webTitle: The philosophy of football: not just a game of two halves

fields.headline: The philosophy of football: not just a game of two halves
fields.trailText: Football coverage has gone all philosophical notes Joe McGinnis, who can tell his Rijkaards from his Kierkegaards
fields.body:
As last week's readers may recall, I did warn against that third Martini.

What a state of Wildean bliss it was, was it not, after the second against Portugal, to see things 'as they are not'? Alas, how swiftly does illusion shatter. But is the facing of matters 'as they are' truly 'the most horrible fate in the world', as Wilde posited? By now Kevin Keegan and the bickering Germans will have provided an answer.

In any event, it was not the worst week I've ever spent in an armchair. Indeed, I was reassured to note that although the century and millennium may have been substituted, certain things do seem immutable: Spain's capacity to disappoint, Holland's capacity to display indifference, and Martin O'Neill's readiness to air his views regarding existentialism on national television.

To be accurate, I should say on international television, for I'm watching from America, yet having the quintessentially British experience of seeing Gary and Des, both live, and often on the same day - not to mention the added thrill of actually understanding what they're saying, a plateau I hope to reach vis-à-vis Big Ron no later than the quarter-finals.

And there's no quarrelling with Gary's point that the philosophy seminar was considerably more entertaining than the match (Belgium v. Italy) that kept intruding upon it, although I had hoped it might move beyond existentialism to take up the topic of 'Luc Nilis and The New Nihilism: Belgium's National Character Revisited'.

None the less, high marks to Gary and Martin for so swiftly taking down Johan Cruyff with a couple of good, old-fashioned, studs-up, existentialist two-footed tackles when he began to run on about such pointless abstractions as technique.

We must remember that Cruyff, for all his greatness, is the man who once said, 'If I'd wanted you to understand it, I would have explained it more clearly.'

How fine, then, to hear Martin coming in with, 'Your trouble, Johan, is you think everybody can play the way you did,' and Gary so swiftly adding, 'You can only beat the team you're playing against.' Many have subsequently commented that they'd never before seen Cruyff quite so at a loss for words, in any language.

All in all, it was a difficult first week for the Dutch. And it might have been even worse were it not for Pavel Nedved's decision to retest the merits of the Hegelian view that words spoken in haste are oft repented in leisure.

But Nedved - on the pitch very close to the Aristotelian ideal of 'speed uncontaminated by haste', and one of the few who (with Zinedine Zidane, Thierry Henry, Rui Costa and Luis Figo) made the first week sing - inexplicably shot himself in the foot before the Czech ship even left harbour, as Schopenhauer might have put it (but fortunately did not), when, on the eve of the match against Holland, and having been asked his opinion of referee Pierluigi Collina, under whose baleful stare he plies his trade so worthily in Italy, responded: 'I hate him.'

Having previously observed Collina in Machiavellian action when he'd felt his machismo offended, I knew from the start of the match that the only question was when, and not if.

I realise this places me rather squarely in the path of Camus, who has written that, 'The last judgment...takes place every day,' but as Martin O'Neill so trenchantly noted, Camus was nothing but a goalkeeper, anyway.

And, in the event, it went as I knew it would have had to have gone: a penalty given against the Czechs in the 90th minute, and three undeserved points for the co-hosts.

The next test for Rijkaard's personifications of apathy was against the denizens of Kierkegaard's domain, and I would have thought the outcome all but predestined had I not been brought up short by the great man's words midweek: 'I've watched all the games so far,' Kierkegaard said - no, no, excuse me, that was Rijkaard.

What Kierkegaard said was, 'Life can only be understood backwards, but it must be lived forwards,' thereby anticipating the instant replay by approximately 150 years. Rijkaard said, 'I've watched all the games so far, and I have been amazed by the determination of the teams taking part, except mine. My players prefer to play cards.'

One might have asked, then why did you choose them, but that would have lacked Cruyffian subtlety. Or, one might have asked, what else is new with the Dutch, but that would have simply been rude. Better, perhaps, to think of them as patriotic: 11 Hans Brinkers, all working as one, selflessly, on behalf of their nation.

Was it not, after all, economists from their own Bank of the Netherlands who, even before the tournament began, called upon them to lose? 'A further boost to [national] confidence could be harmful,' the economists wrote, noting that a Holland triumph might trigger a destructive inflationary spiral.

To play poorly, therefore, would be not a shortcoming on the part of the team, but rather evidence that they were responding to 'a sense of national duty'.

It is hard not to wonder what Spinoza, in his unyielding rationalism, would have made of such a proposition, although any philosopher who was born in Amsterdam and who died in The Hague might be said to have lived his life backwards. Too harsh a judgment? Perhaps.

Better to wait and hear what Gary and Martin and the unparalleled if occasionally indecipherable Mr. Cruyff have to say.

In any event, it was not the worst week I've ever spent in an armchair. Indeed, I was reassured to note that although the century and millennium may have been substituted, certain things do seem immutable: Spain's capacity to disappoint, Holland's capacity to display indifference, and Martin O'Neill's readiness to air his views regarding existentialism on national television. To be accurate, I should say on international television, for I'm watching from America, yet having the quintessentially British experience of seeing Gary and Des, both live, and often on the same day - not to mention the added thrill of actually understanding what they're saying, a plateau I hope to reach vis-à-vis Big Ron no later than the quarter-finals. And there's no quarrelling with Gary's point that the philosophy seminar was considerably more entertaining than the match (Belgium v. Italy) that kept intruding upon it, although I had hoped it might move beyond existentialism to take up the topic of 'Luc Nilis and The New Nihilism: Belgium's National Character Revisited'. None the less, high marks to Gary and Martin for so swiftly taking down Johan Cruyff with a couple of good, old-fashioned, studs-up, existentialist two-footed tackles when he began to run on about such pointless abstractions as technique. We must remember that Cruyff, for all his greatness, is the man who once said, 'If I'd wanted you to understand it, I would have explained it more clearly.' How fine, then, to hear Martin coming in with, 'Your trouble, Johan, is you think everybody can play the way you did,' and Gary so swiftly adding, 'You can only beat the team you're playing against.' Many have subsequently commented that they'd never before seen Cruyff quite so at a loss for words, in any language. All in all, it was a difficult first week for the Dutch. And it might have been even worse were it not for Pavel Nedved's decision to retest the merits of the Hegelian view that words spoken in haste are oft repented in leisure. But Nedved - on the pitch very close to the Aristotelian ideal of 'speed uncontaminated by haste', and one of the few who (with Zinedine Zidane, Thierry Henry, Rui Costa and Luis Figo) made the first week sing - inexplicably shot himself in the foot before the Czech ship even left harbour, as Schopenhauer might have put it (but fortunately did not), when, on the eve of the match against Holland, and having been asked his opinion of referee Pierluigi Collina, under whose baleful stare he plies his trade so worthily in Italy, responded: 'I hate him.' Having previously observed Collina in Machiavellian action when he'd felt his machismo offended, I knew from the start of the match that the only question was when, and not if. I realise this places me rather squarely in the path of Camus, who has written that, 'The last judgment...takes place every day,' but as Martin O'Neill so trenchantly noted, Camus was nothing but a goalkeeper, anyway. And, in the event, it went as I knew it would have had to have gone: a penalty given against the Czechs in the 90th minute, and three undeserved points for the co-hosts. The next test for Rijkaard's personifications of apathy was against the denizens of Kierkegaard's domain, and I would have thought the outcome all but predestined had I not been brought up short by the great man's words midweek: 'I've watched all the games so far,' Kierkegaard said - no, no, excuse me, that was Rijkaard. What Kierkegaard said was, 'Life can only be understood backwards, but it must be lived forwards,' thereby anticipating the instant replay by approximately 150 years. Rijkaard said, 'I've watched all the games so far, and I have been amazed by the determination of the teams taking part, except mine. My players prefer to play cards.' One might have asked, then why did you choose them, but that would have lacked Cruyffian subtlety. Or, one might have asked, what else is new with the Dutch, but that would have simply been rude. Better, perhaps, to think of them as patriotic: 11 Hans Brinkers, all working as one, selflessly, on behalf of their nation. Was it not, after all, economists from their own Bank of the Netherlands who, even before the tournament began, called upon them to lose? 'A further boost to [national] confidence could be harmful,' the economists wrote, noting that a Holland triumph might trigger a destructive inflationary spiral. To play poorly, therefore, would be not a shortcoming on the part of the team, but rather evidence that they were responding to 'a sense of national duty'. It is hard not to wonder what Spinoza, in his unyielding rationalism, would have made of such a proposition, although any philosopher who was born in Amsterdam and who died in The Hague might be said to have lived his life backwards. Too harsh a judgment? Perhaps. Better to wait and hear what Gary and Martin and the unparalleled if occasionally indecipherable Mr. Cruyff have to say.

fields.headline: Home truths from abroad
fields.standfirst: BBC2's Foot In The Door series gives eager recruits the chance to get started in their dream job. On Thursday the assignment is travel guidebook writing.  Mark Honan, a Lonely Planet veteran with 10 years' experience on four continents, gives the inside story on his job - no time to see friends, no time to laze around on the beach. And people say it's a life of glamour...
fields.trailText: BBC2's Foot In The Door series gives eager recruits the chance to get started in their dream job. On Thursday the assignment is travel guidebook writing. Mark Honan, a Lonely Planet veteran with 10 years' experience on four continents, gives the inside story on his job - no time to see friends, no time to laze around on the beach. And people say it's a life of glamour...
fields.body:
So you want to be a travel guidebook writer? Most people do. 'You lucky so-and-so,' I've been told countless times. 'Fancy being paid to be on holiday. What a great job.'

Think of the benefits, these travellers tell me. Eating in fancy restaurants. Bedding down in the top hotels. Spending arduous ('ha-ha') days researching the best beaches for sunbathing and swimming. Being treated like royalty because everybody wants a favourable mention in my guidebook.

That's the theory. The reality is there are plenty of hassles too.

Far from being treated like royalty, guidebook writers are an anonymous bunch. Most of us don't declare who we are when we check out places: we want to find out what sort of a deal an ordinary traveller would be offered. In hotels, we invent an excuse to see a selection of rooms. 'I'll be returning in a few weeks with my parents, uncle, long-lost half-cousin and their disabled cat.' That sort of thing.

If we do have to reveal ourselves, the red carpet is rarely rolled out. In Europe proprietors are often suspicious. 'What sort of book? I don't want to pay to be in a book,' they say aggressively. Even when they learn they don't have to pay - in fact, they can't pay - their attitude doesn't soften.

In Germany once, a hotel receptionist refused to let me view any of his empty rooms. 'Show your editor that picture instead,' he said dismissively, throwing me a brochure. In Switzerland, a proprietor was too lazy to tell me the full range of room prices. 'Fine,' I shot back, 'in that case I'm taking you out of the book.' My reward was to be chased down the stairs and out on to the street by a furious, swearing hotel owner.

In Asia, where Lonely Planet is recognised as the market leader, people do tend to fawn over you a little more, provided they manage to discover who you are. (Somehow, in India, everyone seemed to know I was writing for Lonely Planet, despite my denials.) But the odd free beer is usually as far as it gets. Accepting freebies is frowned upon, as we must be scrupulously objective in our write-ups. Accepting payments or discounts in return for positive coverage would mean the immediate termination of any research contract with Lonely Planet.

Guidebook writers have only moderate status within a large publisher. We can rarely keep copyright of our own words. It's the publisher's name that sells the books - the author's name is often relegated to an inside page, or perhaps even omitted altogether (not so in Lonely Planet books: we even get a blurb and a photograph). Rumours circulate that publishers consider authors a necessary evil - specifically 'Lower than a snake's arse,' according to some choice recent gossip.

In the early days of guidebook publishing there was more opportunity for diversity and creativity, especially with a cutting-edge publisher. Nowadays, the market is much bigger and more competitive. Travel books are a standardised 'product'. Each book within an imprint must have the same look, approach and useability. Authors have to adhere to a rigid 'house style'. It's the McDonaldisation of travel destinations. As a writer you can't help but feel disenfranchised.

This has increased the status of editors. They will ruthlessly police our words, dispensing swift justice to anything that fails to conform. Imperious decrees will be issued, containing copious demands for clarifications or background information. Authors must respond to these swiftly, no matter what other commitments they have. Once I arrived in the Solomon Islands, but had to wrench my mind back to Switzerland to deal with a thick wedge of editorial queries and proofs.

Don't count on making your fortune writing guidebooks. Newcomers want to do this job so much that they will do it for virtually nothing, at least at the beginning.

They will endure countless hardships to eke out their meagre budget and track down the information they need. They'll visit plush hotels, test the sweetest-sprung divans, then end up sleeping on hardboard bunks in cardboard shacks. They'll study poetic menus in gourmet restaurants, linger longingly to ask a few patrons how they enjoyed their multi-course feasts, then dine in the meanest roadside slop-shops. They'll check prices for first-class rail and club-class jets, then breathe deep on the clouds of smoke seeping from broken exhausts in battered buses. They'll do it because they enjoy it. Rather, they'll enjoy the first three days of their three-month trip, because it's new and fresh. After that it becomes a grind. We've all been through this rite of passage.

These new writers have quickly found that the so-called glamour has disappeared. They'll console themselves with the thought that once they've got this first book under their belt, they will have their foot in the door. Then they can start making some real money for their next book.

What they soon realise, as they're attempting to negotiate their new project, is that the next batch of wannabe writers is clamouring to write that same book for next to no money, their own 'isn't this cool' rose-tinted glasses as yet unshattered. Thus the one-contract veteran will have to settle for slimmer fees. Another bugbear is the deadlines which are as tight as an ageing swinger's belt. The reason for this is that publishers need to get books on the shelves before they are out of date. I would love to spend four months researching three chapters of India, even at the cost of earning less money per day. One day chilling out on the beach, the next day researching, and so on.

No chance. If it can be researched in two months, I will be given two months minus one week. I will have to work almost every waking hour, seven days a week: researching throughout the day, writing up or organising my notes at night. Travel becomes a joyless logistical exercise, conducted at a relentless pace. I will have to steam into town, check out everything in the guide and line up a few new entries. As soon as this is done I must ship out to the next place, casting wistful glances at the relaxed, time-rich travellers pondering where to have a leisurely beer. I will have nightmares about having my research notes being stolen. My dreams will be invaded by endless investigations of imaginary hotels, restaurants and train stations.

I will return home exhausted, with a backpack bulging with brochures, timetables and price schedules. I will have to forget I have friends I haven't seen for ages. Instead I will retreat to my office until the writing-up is complete. During that time I will fail to recognise the concept of a weekend or office hours. As the deadline approaches my stress levels mount. Every hour I am awake and not working, I will be trying to suppress the nagging thought: 'I could be working right now.'

At last the job will be finished - if I'm lucky, within deadline. I can afford a cou ple of days off now (unpaid, of course), before I start worrying about where my next contract is coming from. Before long I'm back on the road again, wrenching apart the strands that hold my life together in England.

Which heralds the next problem for the career guidebook writer. Taking two- or three-month research trips abroad is great in your carefree early twenties. As you get older and collect more commitments, this gets harder to organise. I am married now and our first child, a daughter, was born last month. Sadly, I know that important stages in her development will happen while I am somewhere else. The career of a guidebook writer tends to be a short one. Within Lonely Planet it is said that writers usually suffer 'burn-out' within five years.

All of this begs the question: if this dream job is so terrible, why am I still doing it?

Because, naturally, it does have its good points too. It's nice that people think I've got a cool job, even if I don't always think it's so cool myself. The research can be exhausting, but there's a genuine satisfaction in finding a place that stands out, and then describing it accurately and evocatively. It's good to be working out there in the real world, instead of being locked up in an office. Then there's the thrill you get when you see your guidebook in print for the first time. And I still love to travel, even if it's for the sake of work rather than for the sake of travel itself.

Perhaps this last point is the key message for wannabe guidebook writers and everybody else. We're out there on the road to do a job, and we can never be deflected from that. Writers who go out there and treat it like being on holiday will end up with just that - an overlong holiday. Plus a blown deadline, withheld fees and no chance of being offered another research contract. Ever.

fields.headline: Poor effort by rich Romanians
fields.standfirst: Next up for England:  Ageing East Europeans blame the West for latest disappointment, but shortcomings are of their own making
fields.trailText: Next up for England: a team of ageing East Europeans who blame the West for their disappointments, but whose shortcomings are of their own making
fields.body:
Romanian footballers must wonder why they bother playing European Championships and World Cups. A decade ago they knew: you played to win a fat contract in Italy or Spain. But now that they all have fat contracts, playing becomes a questionable activity. It's hard work, wipes out your summer holiday, and in the end the West cheats you anyway.

Yet Romania invariably turn up, do a couple of pretty things to stir mutterings about dark horses, and then, long before things get exciting, return home again. Or rather, return to their second-rank football club in a stable country with clement weather to rest for another two years.

This is quite a pleasant way of spending a career - it probably beats working in a Romanian coal mine - but at times it must be unsatisfying. As Gheorghe Hagi, their captain, said recently, it's all very well playing good football, but it would be nice to win something.

For Hagi and others, Euro 2000 is the last chance. He is 35, his brother-in-law Gica Popescu, Dan Petrescu and Bogdan Stelea are 32, while Dorinel Munteanu reaches that age on Sunday. Over the last decade these men have become Romanian legends. In the team's training camp in the village of Grimbergen near Brussels, Christian Chivu, the young left-back, is killing time by reading a 450-page biography called, simply, Hagi .

A few years ago Cornel Dinu, then manager of Romania, said: 'All the Latins have great trust in the next generation. That's what has always fooled us.' This time, there is little chance of Romanians making that mistake. The present ageing generation is the best they will have for decades to come. The next four games will decide whether this poor, corrupt nation of 23 million will get its first chance of communal celebrations since the execution of the Ceaucescus. For the Romanian team, it's now or never.

At times the players seem to accept that it will be never. Once they were contenders. At the World Cup of 1994, they beat Argentina 3-2 in one of the great matches of the decade. One round later they were eliminated. At the next World Cup, they swept their group, then defeated themselves against Croatia. They were younger then, so why should they succeed now? And does it matter? Going down in football history as a footnote may be regrettable, but what matters is becoming a multi-millionaire.

That's what Hagi seemed to decide during Romania's opening match against Germany. At first he did his best. But after he had lost the ball a few times to some overly energetic Germans, and the referee had denied Romania a penalty, he got angry, as he often does. He berated the Danish referee, Kim Milton Nielsen, and then planted his studs in the thigh of the prostrate German Christian Ziege. Gradually, however, his anger gave way to a sort of nihilist laziness. Hagi moped about, summoned the ball, and lost it again. He seemed to decide then that he had had enough. He wandered off in the general direction of a corner-flag, his head down.

The Romanian fans noticed, and began chanting his name. Hagi heard them, straightened his back, chased back 15 yards and dispossessed a German with a model sliding tackle. A few minutes later he granted himself a regal exit to the changing rooms. Hagi seldom plays more than an hour these days.

In Grimbergen I asked the Romanian manager, Emerich Jenei, whether he had grown fed up watching his captain spend half the game bawling out the referee. Jenei (who has called Hagi 'a fantastic man, an icon, a role model, a trailblazer, and an immense talent') said no. In fact, Hagi had been right to complain. Romania should have had a penalty. Even the German television commentators had said so. 'Previous matches at Euro 2000 have also been marked by grave errors by referees in favour of the big teams,' said Jenei.

Surely, I said, Romania were also a big team.

'Correction,' said Jenei. 'I didn't mean big teams, but rich teams.'

Romania, you see, is a poor team of rich players.
