fields.headline: Kill off the old players
fields.trailText: The English press thinks Alan Shearer (29 years old) should be dropped. German players hint that Lothar Matthäus (39) should be too. Only Romanians understand why Gheorghe Hagi (35) is still in their team. A few brave Dutch dissidents now publicly oppose Dennis Bergkamp (31). But in France, saying a word against Didier Deschamps (31) remains a faux pas almost as grave as ordering red wine with spinach. The team hotels packed with old men nursing an array of ailments make Euro 2000 resemble Eastbourne. The reasons the veterans are still picked vary per country, but are broadly as follows:
fields.body:
The English press thinks Alan Shearer (29 years old) should be dropped. German players hint that Lothar Matthäus (39) should be too. Only Romanians understand why Gheorghe Hagi (35) is still in their team. A few brave Dutch dissidents now publicly oppose Dennis Bergkamp (31). But in France, saying a word against Didier Deschamps (31) remains a faux pas almost as grave as ordering red wine with spinach. The team hotels packed with old men nursing an array of ailments make Euro 2000 resemble Eastbourne. The reasons the veterans are still picked vary per country, but are broadly as follows:

1. Veneration of the past. This applies particularly to England and France. Whenever Shearer is criticised, Kevin Keegan notes that he has scored goals for England in the past. That Shearer was fitter and quicker in the past is ignored. Bobby Charlton also scored goals for England in the past, but is no longer in the team. Keegan is merely the victim of an entire culture. The British disease is to explain all phenomena by reference to the past. So England's players have this week been urged to re-enact World War One, and so Michael Owen was substituted against Portugal because, in Keegan's words, 'he hasn't got the experience of most other players around that field'. In other words, Owen doesn't have enough of a past. When he does, he will presumably be picked until he is 40. The French suffer from a less virulent form of this disease. They venerate a specific moment in the past: the night of July 11, 1998, when they won the World Cup. Those who played then can choose their moment of retirement. No coach ever says, 'I'm picking old so-and-so because I venerate the past.' Rather, when the clapped-out one plays well - or in Shearer's case, when he scores three against a depleted Luxembourg - he is said to have 'silenced his critics'. This is statistically unsound. The old player is given many chances to fail, so he is bound to succeed once in a while. Moreover, he can play where he likes - Shearer as the front striker, Bergkamp and Hagi in free roles, Matthäus as a libero with neither defensive nor attacking responsibilities - no wonder he occasionally comes to life.

2. Attribution of magical qualities to one individual. This applies above all to Romania. When I asked their coach, Emerich Jenei, whether the 35-year-old Hagi was not rather slow these days, Jenei said: 'But psychologically he is very important. It is true that he is not as fast as he was, and that he does not participate in all phases of the game, but every ball he touches is right.' In Romania, when people glimpse a black Mercedes on the highway, they wander around for days saying, 'I've seen Hagi!', Super-humans are hard to drop. Magical qualities are attributed to every England captain. The job is invested by the tabloids with a quasi-military mystique. Keegan always describes Shearer as 'leading the line', as if he were taking a regiment over the top. The effect is to make Shearer - and in the sainted past, captains like Bryan Robson and Terry Butcher - appear somehow more English than other players. To drop the skipper would be unpatriotic. To ask him to play in Owen's service would be a transgression against hierarchy: privates don't lead the line. Deschamps, the French captain, was the nominated leader at a glorious moment of French history. Like General de Gaulle, he is therefore recalled beyond his useful life.

3. Fear. Coaches are conservative. They know old players better than new ones. So Roy Makaay, highest scorer of the Spanish champions La Coruna, may be a more effective striker for Holland than Bergkamp, but since no one knows for sure he is never given a chance to prove it. Ruud Gullit was sacked days after dropping Shearer at Newcastle. The previous Romanian coach is the previous coach because he confronted Hagi. The main beneficiary of fear at Euro 2000 is Lothar Matthäus. So close is he to various journalists at Bild newspaper and Kicker magazine that he virtually writes their articles. Erich Ribbeck, the German coach, is already much derided. If he drops Matthäus, and Matthäus leaks to the press, Ribbeck will suffer.

When a footballer turns 32, a commission of experts should rule whether he is allowed to keep playing for his country. If he is, he should have to pledge to keep quiet if dropped, played in a subordinate role, or used as a substitute, as Dragan Stojkovic (35) is for Yugoslavia. This method might sound crazy but would improve several teams at Euro 2000.

fields.headline: Let's go!
fields.standfirst: Ten things to do today
fields.trailText: Ten things to do today.
fields.body:
 Get the inside track on Arthurian Antics at Peveril Castle, Hope Valley, Derbyshire. King Arthur and Guinevere, with help from Pen the dragon, will regale junior audiences with tales of brave knights and daring dragons. Sessions at 12.30pm, 2pm, 3.30pm. Adults £2.50, children £1.30. Call 01433 620613.

 Take a whistle-stop tour of opera through the ages at Brinkburn Priory, Northumberland. Opera highlights from Gilbert and Sullivan in the chapel from 2.30pm. Adults £1.60, children 80p.Call 01665 570 628.

 Wander around Kew Gardens and enjoy its Chapungu Sculpture Festival, an exhibition of more than 60 sculptures from Zimbabwe in addition to the usual floral offerings. Open 9.30am-7.30pm. Adults £5, children £3. Call 020 8332 5655.

 Every Street, Manchester, and its place in the city's folklore so fascinated artist Bill Longshaw that he has used personal items of the street's residents to mount a massive social history exhibition at The Pump House People's History Museum, Manchester. Open 11am-4.30pm. Adults £1, children free.

Call 0161 839 6061.

 Shopping centres - retail heaven or consumer hell? You decide at the Museum of London's Shopping Centres exhibition, which reveals the hidden history of London's malls and asks if they responsible for the death of the high street. Noon-5.50pm. Adults £5, children free. Call 020 7600 0807.

 Broadstairs, Kent, was Dickens's holiday home and the town celebrates the fact with a festival, including Victorian cricket match at 2pm, music hall in the Assembly Rooms at 7.45pm and a performance of 'Boz by the Bay' by Gerald Dickens, the great man's great great grandson in the Pavilion at 8.15pm. Various prices; call 01843 601 364.

 Discover the mysteries of butterflies and insects during Flights of Fancy, a guided walk by the ranger service at Low Park, Hamilton, Lanarkshire. The walk starts at 2pm and will last for around an hour, with a naturalist on hand to answer questions. Free. Call 01698 426 213.

 In case you feel this summer hasn't provided enough of them already, more clouds will be on view at the Walker Art Gallery, Liverpool. 'Constable's Clouds' focuses on the artist's preoccupation with all things cumulus and nimbus by gathering a collection of his studies and paintings of clouds. Open noon-5pm. Adults £3, children free.

 Help to protect Croyde village, Devon, from Vikings as camps and raids are set up around the village as part of the North Devon Festival. Apart from the mock aggressors, visitors can enjoy an open air concert and barbecue, a duck race and children's entertainment. Starts noon. Free. Call 01271 346 436.

 Watch war-time newsreels in an old cinema and recreate past FA Cup Final glory at Great City, Newcastle's Discovery Museum's hands-on exhibition of the city's history throughout the last century. Open 2pm - 5pm. Call 0191 232 6789. Free.

fields.headline: Heroes honed at Highbury
fields.standfirst: France's bright young strikers will get better but famous wrinklies are beyond their tournament sell-by date
fields.trailText: France's young strikers are scaring the life out of the opposition, and can only get better
fields.body:
The vision was a long time coming. Years ago two long- limbed soul mates from the coarse Paris suburbs used to fantasise about leading their country's attack side by side. Last Friday night, with kick- off fast approaching in Brugge's Jan Breydel Stadium, Thierry Henry had a few bons mots in the ear of Nicolas Anelka. Here we go.

France's coach Roger Lemerre, who usually favours a lone striker, can no longer resist playing both his young livewires at the same time. With double the velocity and verve than your ordinary attack, in theory it is unstoppable. For half an hour, while they spun and sprinted and dragged their Czech markers to distraction, it was spellbinding. Zinedine Zidane, who Lemerre reckons is the best player on the planet right now, is rejuvenated by them. Whenever he glances forward he sees options, colours in which the artist can dip his brush.

Goal threats are just a kick away: spring the trap and they are uncatchable. Virtually every time France attack a goal looks on the cards. Frank Leboeuf captured the mood by saying he can 'feel the fear' in the opposition when France's cheetahs are on the run. But the scariest thing of all is that they can only improve. Afterwards Henry berated himself for squandering the chances to kill the game, while Anelka admitted he is still tuning up his game after a season largely spent stalling in Spain.

'I felt a lack of competition,' he explained. 'I get a lot of the ball and I'm not used to it! I've played 10 or 11 games all season at Real Madrid with players who didn't want to pass to me and suddenly I'm playing every three days with people who want to give me the ball. I feel the change of rhythm.' No pleasing some people, you might think. But if you see the expression as well as hear the words you realise this is not just another selfish complaint from the boy the English like to portray as a brat. He was chatty, relaxed, content as he spoke. There was no hint of bitterness or blame. It was just his opinion on his game, and he intends to make things right. He wasn't particularly bothered by the fact Henry had scored and he hadn't. Other days will be his and not Henry's. They are both comfortable with that.

Anelka has more serenity now. His experiences this year have mellowed him. He maintains a deliberately idiosyncratic image - take his appearance at a rare press conference with one trouser leg turned up to above the knee for no apparent reason other than to make the point he is non-conformist and proud of it - and he still believes his ability is peerless. But he now recognises the benefits of being a piece of the complete jigsaw. He has taken his place in the French 22 with relish. He has settled in and knuckled down.

'He's very enthusiastic,' observes Leboeuf. 'I think he was desperate to be in the squad because he really wanted to show to the world that he is a great player. Personally I really think he is. His integration is going well, he's really part of the team. He's not the guy who sits around on his own like everybody thinks. He shares with us many times. Of course he has affinities with the younger players like Thierry Henry and David Trezeguet, but he spends time with us and he's very nice. They have formed a little group but last night I was with Nicolas, Thierry and Sylvain Wiltord for a while talking. It's good.'

A couple of months ago it was likely he wouldn't make the squad at all. Dogged by injury and damned by a costly rift with his club, Anelka's career had been shunted into another self-inflicted siding. He was on the verge of a cut price £13 million move from Madrid back to his boyhood club Paris Saint-Germain. He played the day before it was due to be completed. He scored. The deal was off.

On such moments careers change course. He went on to score majestically for Real against Bayern Munich in the Champions League semi-finals, another quantum leap. He was back on the rails and recovering his fitness. Back in Paris Roger Lemerre thanked his lucky stars and looked forward to welcoming the prodigal son, maybe a little humbler and more mature than before, to the national team.

Anelka was due to be the hub of France's attacking hopes until this season saw him eclipsed by his pal Henry. Since the World Cup the Arsenal man had been demoted to the under-21s but his revelationary form at Highbury was too hot to be ignored.

Once he was back in the full squad the elder statesmen noted he needed some coaxing to ignite the blue touchpaper. Youri Djorkaeff had a word with the young striker, telling him, 'You have to have more belief in yourself because you can fly.' He reckons Henry's possibilities have no boundaries once he realises he is France's number one striker.

It's an interesting concept, France's number one striker, considering both Anelka and Trezeguet are also entitled to chase the same crown. There is an intriguing dynamic between them. Three years ago a three pronged attack of Henry on the left, Trezeguet in the middle and Anelka on the right won the under-21 title for France. They have grown up together, a bond cemented by friendship.

Trezeguet is now down the pecking order and recently he threw a wobbly in training. He's a bit unlucky, but the acceleration and penetration of Anelka and Henry wins the day. What a duo. The Arsenal striker winked and affected a romantic lilt: 'Playing together again was like a dream come true.'

Arsène Wenger, who nurtured both, believes they are the best pair in the world. 'They are not quick they are super quick. And as well as having speed and pace they are very powerful boys. And don't forget they are good football players as well. If you think of the development to come it is frightening. They can improve another 30 per cent. I would love to work with that pair.' He almost did.

Although Henry is receiving the early plaudits (it's Henry 2 Anelka 0 so far), the Arsenal manager believes Anelka will grow into the tournament. 'This championship could come at the right time for him. He has played maybe 15 games this season where Raul has played 70. That's a massive difference. And France's attackers are all young. The oldest, Wiltord, is 26. The next oldest is 22. That is unique. We won the World Cup but had no real offensive potential. We still have the same stability but much more explosiveness up front. It makes France the most dangerous team.'

webTitle: A few words in your ear...

fields.headline: A few words in your ear...
fields.standfirst: Sarah Turner  leads a tour of the world where fun and education go together - and parents get a break
fields.trailText: Sarah Turner leads a tour of the world of children's museums, where fun and education go together - and parents get a break
fields.body:
An afternoon at a children's museum can be salvation for anyone travelling with young people; a corner of a foreign country where there are other children to play with, where noise and mess can be made - a reward for hours spent patiently accompanying parents on a city-break circuit of proper museums (yawn) and sights (unspeakable).

In general, children's museums are a city thing - Britain's main one is Eureka! in Halifax, West Yorkshire, which opened in 1992. The nearest London gets to one is Launch Pad at the Science Museum - a bustling area of scientific interactivity (the grain store and turntable are particularly popular) that will move, and grow in size, to the Wellcome wing when it opens next month.

At Eureka!, there are hundreds of children racing around, pretending to be mechanics in a garage of scaled-down cars or playing in a scaled-down television studio. There is a child-size branch of Marks & Spencer, a mini-post office and a little factory - a mini-town square, in fact, with recognisable high street names. Upstairs, children can see what really happens when they flush a loo, thanks to a see-through toilet, and play in a child-sized kitchen. Nearby is a giant mouth to explore, complete with a wobbly tooth. There are buttons to push and cogs to be turned, but signs are kept to a minimum. 'We're not feeding facts, we don't want to inhibit kids, we want them to feel that this is a fun, playful place,' says Eureka!'s new director Leigh-Anne Stradeski. Unlike more conventional museums, children's museums don't have a remit that includes preserving the past. There is nothing that can't be replaced or repaired.

So might Eureka! actually be a theme park, albeit one with a built-in Early Learning Centre-ish feel-good factor to assuage parental guilt? Stradeski rebuts the sugges tion: 'Exhibits here are much more sensory, tactile, textured and open-ended than theme parks can offer. Any activity that we design has education at its heart.'

Nor does she see a day at Eureka! as a soft option for families: 'We don't want an adult reading at the side or just watching their child play,' - although, below us, at that very moment, a father was doing his best to read the paper while his daughter played by the roadworks in Eureka!'s town square.

Before Eureka! opened, they asked groups of children what they would expect to find in a town centre. Most considered roadworks to be a vital part of modern urban living, although Eureka!'s designers incorporated a mini-archaeological dig into it as well to be true to the educational message.

Children's museums originated in the US. Today, there are more than 250 of them, and every US city has one. New York and Los Angeles have two.

The tradition in the US is still to design children's museums that encompass both arts and sciences, and typically have sections that recreate life in the past, although what constitutes the past is usually unnervingly familiar to anyone aged over 50. European museums, such as newMetropolis in Amsterdam or Experimentarium in Copenhagen, are more likely to concentrate on sci ence and the future. Actually, Eureka! feels like a more focused Dome, which isn't surprising as several of the Dome's designers cut their interactive teeth on Eureka! (and if the Body Zone's eyeball is at a loose end next year Eureka! wouldn't mind inheriting it - the staff think it is rather better than the one in their Me and My Body section.)

Equally, there's the same sort of commercial involvement as at the Dome. It's just as good to talk at Eureka!, as BT has sponsored the Communication Zone there too, although the message is subtler at Eureka!, since its main exhibit is a yacht, giving opportunities to practise semaphore.

True to its educational core message, the early days of Eureka! featured a café full of healthy eating options. The food is more playful now, with more in the way of burgers and chips. The early visitors had felt that junk food was more in keeping with a day out, but the bins with prominent information about recycling are still there.

There is a child-size branch of Marks & Spencer, a mini-post office and a little factory - a mini-town square, in fact, with recognisable high street names. Upstairs, children can see what really happens when they flush a loo, thanks to a see-through toilet, and play in a child-sized kitchen. Nearby is a giant mouth to explore, complete with a wobbly tooth. There are buttons to push and cogs to be turned, but signs are kept to a minimum. 'We're not feeding facts, we don't want to inhibit kids, we want them to feel that this is a fun, playful place,' says Eureka!'s new director Leigh-Anne Stradeski. Unlike more conventional museums, children's museums don't have a remit that includes preserving the past. There is nothing that can't be replaced or repaired. So might Eureka! actually be a theme park, albeit one with a built-in Early Learning Centre-ish feel-good factor to assuage parental guilt? Stradeski rebuts the sugges tion: 'Exhibits here are much more sensory, tactile, textured and open-ended than theme parks can offer. Any activity that we design has education at its heart.' Nor does she see a day at Eureka! as a soft option for families: 'We don't want an adult reading at the side or just watching their child play,' - although, below us, at that very moment, a father was doing his best to read the paper while his daughter played by the roadworks in Eureka!'s town square. Before Eureka! opened, they asked groups of children what they would expect to find in a town centre. Most considered roadworks to be a vital part of modern urban living, although Eureka!'s designers incorporated a mini-archaeological dig into it as well to be true to the educational message. Children's museums originated in the US. Today, there are more than 250 of them, and every US city has one. New York and Los Angeles have two. The tradition in the US is still to design children's museums that encompass both arts and sciences, and typically have sections that recreate life in the past, although what constitutes the past is usually unnervingly familiar to anyone aged over 50. European museums, such as newMetropolis in Amsterdam or Experimentarium in Copenhagen, are more likely to concentrate on sci ence and the future. Actually, Eureka! feels like a more focused Dome, which isn't surprising as several of the Dome's designers cut their interactive teeth on Eureka! (and if the Body Zone's eyeball is at a loose end next year Eureka! wouldn't mind inheriting it - the staff think it is rather better than the one in their Me and My Body section.) Equally, there's the same sort of commercial involvement as at the Dome. It's just as good to talk at Eureka!, as BT has sponsored the Communication Zone there too, although the message is subtler at Eureka!, since its main exhibit is a yacht, giving opportunities to practise semaphore. True to its educational core message, the early days of Eureka! featured a café full of healthy eating options. The food is more playful now, with more in the way of burgers and chips. The early visitors had felt that junk food was more in keeping with a day out, but the bins with prominent information about recycling are still there.

fields.headline: Strange but pomskizillious little haven
fields.standfirst: Five miles by ferry from the barren mainland of Malta lies the verdant Mediterranean island of Gozo, which, says  Paul Frederick, is a delightfully eccentric, and surprisingly unspoilt, hangover from the Empire - complete with red pillar boxes and old British buses
fields.trailText: Five miles by ferry from the barren mainland of Malta lies the verdant Mediterranean island of Gozo, which, says Paul Frederick, is a delightfully eccentric, and surprisingly unspoilt, hangover from the Empire - complete with red pillar boxes and old British buses
fields.body:
Edward Lear said of Gozo in 1866: 'Its coast scenery may truly be called pomskizillious and grophibberous, being as no words can describe its magnificence.' He had a point. But it is the island's eccentricity, rather than its beauty alone, that make his words so apt.

Ancient Leyland buses chug around Gozo, looking for all the world like Art Deco radio sets on wheels. Blue lamps hang from the walls of the police stations; the mail is deposited in red pillar boxes.

Yet the hot wind that blows across the island, sometimes for days, comes from Libya, fewer than 200 miles to the south. The people speak a harsh mixture of Arabic and Sicilian - until they break into fluent English, often with a pronounced Australian or even estuary English accent. Artichokes grow in the tiny terraced fields, ringed by lemon and orange groves. Every way you turn, the countryside is overlooked by one of dozens of huge Catholic churches, each apparently capable of serving a medium-sized British town, let alone a tiny community on a small Mediterranean island.

Gozo is one of the three inhabited islands that make up the Republic of Malta. Its 26,000 inhabitants live in villages strung out across the tops of the island's fertile, flat-topped hills, or in the capital Victoria, dominated by an ancient citadel and massive eighteenth-century cathedral.

Each day during the summer tens of thousands of tourists sweep across the island, decanted from the ferries crossing the five-mile stretch of water from mainland Malta. Mostly they head for the rocky coastline, to swim in water so clear you can see shoals of fish hundreds of feet below the boats that carry sightseers round the island. Or they wander around Victoria's marketplace to pick among the collection of lacework, locally-blown glass and cheap, slightly dated sports clothes. But because Gozo has few beaches and only one true resort town - Marsalforn - at the end of the day they head back, leaving behind an island that seems to have survived the onset of mass tourism with its charm and character largely intact.

Many of those who do stay on rent one of the rapidly growing number of converted stone farmhouses. Ours was a beautiful, cavernous old building, with enormous, gloomy downstairs rooms that once housed the farm's livestock, and a swimming pool built into a terraced field. By contrast with Malta, Gozo is highly fertile, and in the spring the hills that dominate the island are cloaked with colour, so my daughters - tough enough to brave the Easter chill - could float in the pool and look out on acres of fields and hedgerows filled with wild flowers. But even during our stay the farmers had begun to harvest the flowers, clearing the fields of anything that could be used for winter feed for their cattle. By early summer, large tracts are as baked and bare as a brick.

So it is the coastline that attracts most visitors, and it is as magnificent as Lear suggested. Only Ramla, on the northern coast, has a beach of any size, its beautiful red sands overlooked by a massive statue of the crucifixion. Because there are few cafés and little shade, Ramla remains relatively uncrowded - we spent one glorious, boiling Easter day with the beach, and the rolling pink dunes behind, largely to ourselves.

Most swimmers dive off the rocks, and the island has become famous as a centre for scuba diving. Comino, the tiny, largely uninhabited island between Gozo and Malta, provides the most spectacular sport. Thousands use a flotilla of small boats from the two larger islands to travel to Comino each day, to fry on the rocks and swim in the crystalline water. Only a faint ring of engine-oil around the white rocks of the island, like scurf on a bath, suggests how damaging its popularity is becoming to the tiny island.

Gozo is littered with the debris of the history that has swept across the Mediterranean. It is believed to be the mythical Ogygia where Calypso lured Odysseus for a seven-year break from his journey home. Gozo claims the oldest free-standing structure, the massive stones that make up the temple at Ggantija, built around 3,000BC. The cathedral in Victoria's citadel is a fitting monument to the island's quirkiness. Its builders ran out of money halfway through the project, before a dome could be placed on top. So they hired an Italian artist to paint an extraordinary trompe l'oeil , a sweet piece of fun amid the heavy gothic architecture.

Eating in Gozo can be tricky. There are some excellent restaurants, although they are popular and advance booking requires a level of organisation we failed to meet. Otherwise, the fare is standard Mediterranean-resort-crossed-with-shopping-mall-English - freshly caught fish of an indeterminate breed, salads, pizzas, chicken nuggets etc.

The service can be truly eccentric. One habit is to describe, lovingly and at some length, a local delicacy, and when you choose it, bring something quite different - say, fish stew instead of rabbit pie. But it doesn't seem to matter that much. Gozo is wonderful fun. It has few of the attractions that most children demand, but mine loved wandering through the open countryside picking flow ers and chasing frogs, or rummaging among the market stalls whose owners seem far more interested in conversation than commerce. It is cheap and accessible. It has none of the pretensions or gaudiness of so many Mediterranean islands, wears its history lightly, and seems to survive its annual summertime invasions with its charm unscathed.

 Paul Frederick's visit was organised by Meon Villas (01730 230370). He flew to Malta from Gatwick on an Air Malta scheduled flight with transfer to Gozo by ferry and stayed in a 200-year-old farmhouse at Ghasri.

Prices for a one-week Meon Villas package at Razzett Gamiena villa in Gozo in May start from £435 per person, based on four sharing (from £400 for six sharing) and include flights, airport taxes, ferry transfer to Gozo, villa with private pool, welcome pack, maid/cleaning service and car hire with unlimited mileage.

fields.headline: End Owen's two-year sentence
fields.standfirst: Kevin Keegan's side must look to the striker who shone in France 98 but whose development has been stunted
fields.trailText: Paul Wilson says that England must play a team to suit the strengths of their key striker - and that isn't Alan Shearer
fields.body:
Michael Owen, modest young professional that he is, still thinks there are areas of his game he needs to improve before he can regard himself as a world class player and command the full respect of whoever happens to be England manager. Perhaps the Liverpool striker is not quite the finished article yet, but in the present England context he is almost certainly being too harsh on himself. Very few people up and down the country are clamouring for Owen to adapt better to England's style of play. On the contrary, the commonly held view is that Owen is one of the few gems we possess and it is about time England woke up and started playing to his strengths.

This ought really to have happened during the last World Cup, but never quite did, and two years on Owen still finds himself having to fit in around Alan Shearer and subject to the sort of indignity involved in being pulled off at half time against Portugal in favour of an Emile Heskey who looked hopelessly out of his depth. Kevin Keegan said Owen was gutted at that decision, and no wonder, though the player had enough sense to accept the decision and even begin to rationalise it. 'Obviously Alan Shearer and Emile Heskey are better than me at holding the ball up,' he said. On the evidence of the Portugal game there is scant evidence for this theory, but let that pass. It is Owen's attitude which is important, and the way he puts a disappointment behind him and looks forward to the next challenge.

'When you are brought off early in a game like that, you are waiting for the manager to tell you why' he said. 'You ask yourself questions. I must have been through the game a thousand times trying to see what I did wrong, and at one time I thought it was because I was the last person to touch the ball before Luis Figo scored his goal.

'But the manager just told me he wanted a different type of player up front, and I was perfectly happy with that. Holding the ball upfield is an area of my game I'm looking to improve, along with my left foot and my heading. Having said that though, a striker has got to take risks. If you are going for that half a yard advantage you are never going to get through a game without giving the ball away.'

Owen is far too discreet to comment on the records of Shearer and Heskey when it comes to giving the ball away, too canny even to discuss whether England ought still to be knocking up balls for the big men to hold and hopefully buy some time. How England play is down to Keegan, not Owen. Keegan has decided the object of the exercise is to get crosses in for Shearer, which is fine it it works but tends to leave Owen something of a spectator. 'I don't want the ball six feet in the air all the time,' he said.

Young enough to be patient, Owen also knows he is going to have the field to himself after this competition when Shearer retires from international football. In theory that should give Keegan a chance to re-examine his assets and formulate a new strategy based on the strengths of key players like Owen, David Beckham, Paul Scholes and Steve McManaman, but don't bank on it. Keegan is more likely to spend a couple of months persuading Shearer to change his mind, then another couple of games trying to get Heskey to take over the great man's mantle, before coming around to the seemingly obvious conclusion that Owen could lead the line alone, with either a Scholes or a Nick Barmby as a deeper-lying split striker.

'I've been used to playing with a strike partner all my career, but I think I could play up there on my own,' Owen said when the question was put to him. 'If we had midfielders making runs from deep and joining up in attack I think that would be brilliant. I'm best at using my pace to run at people and into space, I don't see myself as a target man. If I was up there on my own with long balls being pumped up to me to fasten on to I don't think it would work. I don't fancy being on my own up front in that sense.'

It sounds like the Portugal game all over again. Strictly speaking Owen was not on his own, but the real reason neither forward could hold the ball up was that England's midfield was rarely within shouting distance, so that passing moves broke down through lack of support. 'We never had a free midfielder running through,' he said. 'It's hard for strikers to do anything if the rest of the team is being dominated, though I still think if we played Portugal again we would beat them.'

That's wishful thinking, if not plain self-delusion, although what Owen means is that the Portuguese were up for it in Eindhoven - 'They played really well on the night, and you could tell by their reaction at the end they were delighted at the way they had played' - and might not necessarily be able to repeat that level of performance to order.

No matter, Eindhoven is history now, and Owen's old friends the Romanians are next. Pity he is hardly any nearer to spearheading the England attack than he was that evening two years ago in Toulouse when he came on as substitute and scored an equalising goal. 'Romania are the type of team who can cause us problems,' he said. 'They are not like us, they have lots of individual talents who are good on the ball. Much more like Portugal than Germany, but at least we know what to expect.'

fields.headline: Our choice
fields.trailText: Where to go and what to do: Montreux Jazz Festival | Eigg and Muck | Devon
fields.body:
Jazz up your summer

Summer music festival time is coming around again and those who are too grown up for Glastonbury might want to consider a short break at the Montreux Jazz Festival. Inghams is offering a seven-night holiday, departing from London at any time during the 34th festival, from 7- 22 July. If half- board at the Eurotel Riviera, in the heart of the action on the waterfront, may seem pricey at £627, try the three-star Hotel des Alpes at Glion sur Montreux (from £459).

The hotel is a short funicular ride from the centre of Montreux and its altitude can provide a welcome relief from the sweltering hub of the festival city. All prices include flights from London, half board accommodation and train transfers. Phone 020 8780 4433. Music-lovers who can't stand the pace for a full week can avail of Lakes and Mountains Holidays' three-night breaks to Montreux for £344 per person, including flight, and three-star hotel accommodation. Phone 01329 844 405.

Muck and Eigg raking

Take a trip with Naturetrek to the Inner Hebrides and not only will you get the chance to view excellent wildlife with an expert guide, but you can benefit from the opportunity to stay with the Lairds of Muck. Participants in the seven day walking tour will spend four days and nights on the island of Eigg and the rest of the trip on Muck.

Eigg is just eight miles square and is an hour's boat journey from Arsaig, Inverness-shire. Its diverse natural habitats and rich plant and animal life are such that the island has recently been purchased by a partnership of residents, local council and the Scottish Wildlife Trust for its protection. Accommodation on Eigg will be in farmhouse bed and breakfasts.

More guided wildlife exploration is possible on the neighbouring island of Muck where the MacEwan family, the Lairds of Muck, make their farm guesthouse available to walkers. The tour, which departs 8 July, costs £395, which includes accommo dation, all meals, transport between the islands and the guide's services.

Inquiries 01962 733051.

Horse around Devon

The choice of a car or a plane as a holiday mode of transport is just too easy for some. Otter Valley Horse Caravans has catered to the demand for a less modern style of transport by organising horse-drawn caravan holidays in Devon. The traditional hand-painted caravans are drawn by placid horses and full instruction in the handling of both the horse and the caravan is given before departure. Other support services include collection from local train and bus stations and luggage transportation between sites. The company recommends routes around the Blackdown Hills that include several suitable campsites at which to spend each night. Holidays are available until 31 October and for up to four people cost £220 for a long weekend and £450 for a week, including caravan and horse hire, equipment and support services. This might just be your chance to indulge your Wind in the Willows country lanes fantasies. Phone 01404 861168.

The winner of the Observer/Sunvil Peleponnese holiday featured in our Greece special on 4 June was W.S. White of Over Wallop, Stockbridge, Hampshire.

webTitle: Travel brochures fall victim to the online revolution

fields.headline: Travel brochures fall victim to the online revolution
fields.standfirst: The glossy holiday guide is on its way out, says  Joanna Walters,  and it could cost us
fields.trailText: The great British tradition of leafing through summer holiday brochures on a rainy afternoon, comparing the price of different packages and companies, could soon be a thing of the past.
fields.body:
The great British tradition of leafing through summer holiday brochures on a rainy afternoon, comparing the price of different packages and companies, could soon be a thing of the past.

JMC, the tour operating arm of Thomas Cook, has predicted that prices in brochures will disappear within the next two to three years - followed eventually by the colourful tomes themselves.

Terry Williamson, deputy managing director of JMC, said last week that access to the internet and digital television was 'exploding' so fast that traditional brochures would become unnecessary.

He forecast that, initially, the normal and rather complex pricing tables in brochures would be replaced by price 'bands' giving lower, medium and upper ranges of what a holiday would cost.

The consumer would then contact a travel agent or operator by telephone or online to get a firm quote.

Williamson forecasts that the practice of printing prices will soon be obsolete. And in time travel agents will have only interactive screens in their shops.

'We will effectively see brochures transferring out of paper into a new medium. Pricing as we know it today will become obsolete,' said Williamson.

He denied that removing pricing from brochures would reduce customer choice and also denied holiday companies would use the fact prices were not on display to put them up.

'People will not have to do all the complicated price calculations. And there will be more space on the pages of brochures for pictures of the resorts,' he said.

Williamson forecasts that increasingly people will use home and office computers, travel agents, internet cafés, digital television or mobile phones to book their holidays on the internet. They will feed in their holiday requirements on a travel website and receive a price quote on the spot, which they can book immediately.

Alternatively, consumers could punch in the maximum price they were prepared to pay and receive online feedback of holidays on offer at or below that price, he said.

Most UK tour operators print three or four editions of a particular brochure over the 18 months that the packages featured within are on sale.

They can change the prices of the packages displayed in the brochure only by publishing a new edition. Trading standards rules demand that prices for a particular package cannot rise from one edition to the next - they can only remain the same or fall.

Williamson admits that by removing published prices and distributing products only online or by telephone, tour operators will be able to change their prices as often as they want - even daily.

Holiday Which? spokeswoman Kate Levine said: 'We do not see everyone being able, or even keen, to have access to the internet. People like being able to look at a brochure and it is easier to compare prices by flicking page to page than on a computer screen. It is easier to shop around.'

She said the issue of whether prices would rise was difficult to predict. Tour operators should be able to present more comprehensive pricing information on the internet than in brochures, but there was not necessarily enough competition among the big companies to ensure that prices were kept down or properly explained, she added.

fields.headline: Water babies get on board
fields.standfirst: If Neasa MacErlean can defy duckings, cuts and bruises to   learn windsurfing in the sunshine of the Caribbean, so can you
fields.trailText: If Neasa MacErlean can defy duckings, cuts and bruises to learn windsurfing in the sunshine of the Caribbean, so can you.
fields.body:
I have just learnt to windsurf in three days. If you can stand on one leg and hold a suitcase at the same time, you could probably be a windsurfer, too.

Like running a marathon or doing the splits, gliding about on a windsurfing board is a feasible goal for most adults. The vital ingredient, of course, is steely persistence - in windsurfing terms, that is the willingness to clamber back on to the board from the water after you have fallen off seven times in 10 minutes.

This is a far more palatable prospect if the water you are immersed in is vaguely warm, so I took myself off to Grenada as one of seven beginners on a package holiday run by Neilson, the activity holiday specialists. Not only are the Caribbean waters idyllically blue and beautiful, but you are often glad to cool down from air temperatures in the nineties.

To our suprise, all seven of us - four men, three women - were out on the Grand Anse Bay within 10 minutes of the start of our first lesson. Lying on our stomachs on boards, we used our arms to paddle - an exercise that shows how close the sport is to swimming. Twenty minutes later we were plugging our collapsible sails onto the boards. This is the make or break stage. Do you have the doggedness to pull yourself onto the board from the water, achieve enough balance to crouch half-upright, haul the sail up out of the water using a piece of rope and start the whole process again when a small gust of wind sends you crashing beneath the waves?

Basically, you have to be a water baby to put up with all this. All seven of us were confident swimmers who even gained some pleasure from getting thoroughly and repeatedly soaked. You also have to accept the physical discomfort. All of us, and even our instructor Phil, suffered scrapes, bruises, abrasions or worse. Repeatedly climbing onto the board took some of the skin off our knees and shins. I was fairly typical in also getting large bruises on the hips (from banging into the board while in the water) and temporarily losing the imprint of my fingertips (from grasping onto the roughened surface of the plastic as I dragged myself upright). And you are certainly not safe even when you get to a standing position: falling off can cause its share of damage, too. The most proficient of our magnificent seven hurt his back in an awkward fall, and needed a day's rest. Another of the men cracked two ribs after landing on top of the boom, instead of falling cleanly into the sea. His decision to keep going with these injuries characterises the bravado (or foolhardiness, some would say) that most windsurfers have in large measure.

If you are still reading and remain enthusiastic, then you could well be true windsurfing material. Although there is plenty of pain, you can learn very fast on modern equipment. Within a couple of hours, the best of our group were sailing in and out of the shoreline, picking up sprinting-pace speeds and even managing to stop, start and steer without falling off.

By the end of the third day, the four most able and enthusiastic completed a triangular course, and received a Royal Yachting Association grade one certificate for their efforts. The RYA regulates the sport, now endorsing 250 instruc tion companies and sites as eligible to teach windsurfing in the UK and abroad.

I was one of the three laggards who did not pit ourselves against the triangular course. That would have meant a level of concentration and commitment more associated with work than play - and I preferred to do some mountain biking as well and to explore the rest of the aptly nicknamed 'Spice Island'. Even so, I was able to skim along the surface, change course and get some exhilaration from the experience. In our beach bar, Phil, the instructor, was adamant that all seven of us could 'easily' have got the certificate if we had wished to.

He and his colleagues have successfully taught a wide range of unlikely-sounding pupils, including two daredevil non-swimmers last summer, adults with mental health problems, pensioners (though usually with boating experience), children with learning difficulties and primary school pupils, aged six and above, who often take to the sport very rapidly (encouraged by Donald Duck sails and junior rigs).

You certainly do not have to be built like Charles Atlas to be a good windsurfer. In fact, many of the people who seem like swans on the water are overweight, hard-drinking and noticeably inelegant on land. Smoking is not a bar: two of our four certificate-holders are puffers.

About 250,000 people in the UK are thought to be regular windsurfers. In this rapidly developing, 20-year old sport there is a fast-growing contingent of women participants - encouraged by the fact that the boards and other equipment have become far lighter to carry than they used to be. Single men and women are a substantial part of the windsurfing holiday market. Many of the single people on our holiday, which included another 20 dinghy sailors, remarked on how enjoyable and easy the whole arrangement was for them. You very quickly bond with others when you are falling out of dinghies and off surf boards together.

My holiday cost £645 for the three-day course, plus another four days' stay with as much (or as little) extra tuition as we wished. The fee covered the flights, accommodation in very basic chalets and breakfast. Closer to home in Greece, the equivalent holiday would have been £312 for a week, and £398 for a far more cost-effective fortnight. (These prices are at the start of the season; at peak holiday time, they rise by between 20 and 100 per cent, depending on the location.)

There is also another advantage of windsurfing for male heterosexuals. 'The girls love it,' says Stu, another of our instructors. 'If you go with your surfing gear to Newquay, the girls follow you about. Windsurfing has become a fashion statement.'

Neilson: 01273 626 281.

Website: www.neilson.co.uk

A free windsurfing pack, including the 'Where to Windsurf' list, is available from the Royal Yachting Association on 02380 627 496.

webTitle: When the spinning had to stop

fields.headline: When the spinning had to stop
fields.standfirst:
Tony Blair has realised that he has to prove to the electorate that New
         Labour has a purpose greater than mere presentation
fields.trailText:
It gets them all in the end. The qualities that were seen as the shining virtues
         of a Prime Minister when the curtain goes up are redefined as their terrible vices
         when the cheers turn to jeers.
fields.body:
It gets them all in the end. The qualities that were seen as the shining virtues of a Prime Minister when the curtain goes up are redefined as their terrible vices when the cheers turn to jeers.

Margaret Thatcher was the battling Iron Lady when she arrived in office. She was a swivel-eyed autocrat when she was thrown out. Her replacement, John Major, was celebrated as a modest and consensual good bloke at his beginning. He was derided as a limp and dithering prat by his end. The clever technocrat that was Harold Wilson when he entered Number 10 was an unprincipled trimmer by the time he left. Events and disappointments turn strengths inside out until they are weaknesses.

So it was virtually ordained that it would happen to Tony Blair. He won office by brilliantly reaching out beyond his party's core base to construct a new coalition spanning old believers in Labour and fresh converts. Ken Livingstone, Roy Jenkins and Margaret Thatcher, albeit for different reasons, all wanted Tony Blair to be Prime Minister. Three years on, that talent for coalition-building is attacked as one of his worst weaknesses. The soured former Minister, Peter Kilfoyle, complains that the Prime Minister wants to be 'all things to all men'. Tony Wright, such an impeccably Blairite figure that he shares a Christian name with the leader, says the Government's message has gone 'fuzzy'. That very lightness of ideological being that helped float New Labour into power is now blamed for that sinking feeling in the polls.

What is most alarming for the Government is not that this has happened. As I say, this decay is programmed into the biological clock of politics. The worry for New Labour is that time is running so quickly. The ambition was to have at least two terms, a decade of progressive government. Less than a third of the way into that stretch, the reversing process is already well advanced.

The strong and unchallenged leadership that was once a key to Blair's electoral appeal has become control-freakism. A united party has become one in which dissent is suppressed. Once, there was general wonder at Tony Blair's consummate ability to cultivate whichever audience he happened to be standing in front of. Not only is the charm wearing thin, as was demonstrated by his unfortunate reception before the hatchet-faced battalions of the Women's Institute. The reputation for schmoozing has itself become a liability. The leaked memo from the guru of the focus group, Philip Gould, to the Spinner-General, Alastair Campbell, reveals how well appreciated this is within the inner circles of New Labour. Charm has become 'pandering'. Pragmatism is 'lacking conviction'. Flexibility is 'lacking the guts to be able to tough it out'.

Gould asks: 'What is TB's values problem?' The answer stares back at him and Campbell whenever they take a shave. The Prime Minister's values problem is that many people think he is the dummy and they are his ventriloquists. In Mr Gould's own words, Blair is seen as 'all spin and presentation, he just says things to please people not because he believes them'.

The cruel irony is that the Prime Minister, rather than being a creature of his spinmeister and focus grouper, made the infamous appearance before the WI in defiance of their joint advice that the speech was a dud. It's not true that Tony Blair is just a presentational confection, but that doesn't matter half as much as the widespread perception that that is the truth. And who was it who tutored us to treat perception as so all-important? New Labour.

Manipulation of image and mastery of the media, skills at which Tony Blair was once hailed as supreme, have become the most corroding factor, eating cynicism and disillusion into the standing of his Government and himself. Before the election, and in its immediate aftermath, the media devoted acres of print and hours of airtime to goggle-eyed accounts of the Millbank 'war-room' with its rapid-rebuttal units and Excalibur computer. The same media now condemns that to which they were once so enthralled.

There's a lot of hypocrisy and humbug about, not least when William Hague attacks the Government as all 'spin' and 'gimmicks'. Is there anything more gimmicky than the Tory leader's Save The Pound Day? If he sincerely rejects spin, then I presume Mr Hague will be sacking his own spin-nurse, the lovely Amanda Platell. Ken Livingstone, who has had much satirical fun at the expense of New Labour's spinners, has just appointed his own sultan of spin.

The media that condemn the Government for being obsessed with spin is even more fixated with the subject themselves. On Wednesday, there were several good political stories about, not least the widening Cabinet divisions about the single currency. But at the afternoon briefing of lobby correspondents, Britain's finest political journalists spent their time asking Alastair Campbell why he was not going to brief them so regularly in future. That was the lead political story on ITN news.

As is so often the case with New Labour, their mentors the other side of the Atlantic got to this place first. George Stephanopoulos, writer of the best memoir of the Clinton administration, records how the 'success at spin control' created a backlash against it. 'Elaborate staging only increased the tendency of sceptical reporters to focus on the process rather than the substance of what we were trying to say. The benefits of spin were being cancelled out by the press's resistance to it. Often we reacted by spinning even harder, but I was beginning to see the virtue in just letting stories go - Zen spin.'

Alastair Campbell is my least likely candidate to be a practitioner of a Zen approach to anything in life. I do not see him sitting cross-legged in a meditative transcendental state. Rumours of his retirement have been much exaggerated. He is not going to write his memoirs, take up the editorship of the Mirror or become Lord Campbell of Burnley, not for a while yet. What is true is that Campbell has decided to leave more of the briefings of the correspondents at Westminster to his deputy, an anonymous career civil servant called Godric Smith.

Campbell, even though, or perhaps because, he was once a lobby journalist himself, has always had a barely concealed loathing for his former colleagues. He announced himself to his first briefing of the Sunday political lobby with the words: 'Explain to me why I should waste my time with a load of wankers like you when you're not going to write anything I tell you anyway.'

You might expect the journalists to be overjoyed that they will not have this sort of abuse inflicted on them in the future. How long have they been complaining that Campbell is a brute and a thug? But they are not happy at all they are furious. 'We'll be the losers,' one political editor wailed at that briefing on Wednesday.

They don't want a dead bat from the civil service they want the spin bowler. The same people who have been whingeing all this time about being twisted and bullied by Campbell are now moaning that he won't be around so much to kick them anymore.

The attempt to lower his profile is of a piece with the switch of strategy indicated when Tony Blair said they had to stop 'fighting over every headline'. So is a decision to stem the cascade of announcements. Can New Labour really give up spin? Won't they crack when the headlines begin to fill with stories spun by the Conservatives and whipped up by journalists? Alastair Campbell did manage to forswear drinking and Tony Blair quit smoking, but I suspect they will find it more of a challenge to join Spinners Anonymous.

What's not in doubt is that the perception that New Labour is all presentation and no purpose has become dangerous to its health. One member of the Cabinet put it this strongly to me: 'This Government was elected by spin, and it is dying from spin.'

The epitaph that Tony Blair does not want to read on the tombstone of his Government is: The Wages Of Spin.

webTitle: Search for the hero inside your child

fields.headline: Search for the hero inside your child
fields.standfirst: Even the most timid child will love abseiling at a good summer camp. And they might even forget about Pokémon, says  Liz Myers
fields.trailText: Even the most timid child will love abseiling at a good summer camp. And they might even forget about Pokémon...
fields.body:
'We call it the Leap of Faith,' said the instructor, pointing to what looked like a telegraph pole with a trapeze dangling from a wire nearby. The idea, he explained, was that the child stands atop the pole and launches into the air, grabbing the trapeze on their way. As you do.

It occurred to me that this whole activity holiday business was something of a leap of faith. It sounded wonderful: Isle of Wight, seaside location; 'a special experience for every child', allowing them to 'develop new interests and explore new challenges'. Hmm. Challenges. Trouble is, our son is not a great one for challenges.

'List any medical problems or special needs we should know about in relation to your child,' the form had said. How about congenital timidity, an almost clinical lack of co-ordination and a pathological fear of anything new that might be 'hard'?

'Look, they offer dragon boating and 'aquafun' in their own pool...' Aidan, our eight-year-old, requires a major bribe to do even a width at the shallow end without putting his foot down. 'They go mountain biking...' Said son cycles a wobbly couple of laps of our street before begging to be allowed to put his bike away. Maybe the presence of a couple of friends would spur him on. No child wants to lose face in front of mates - especially if one's a girl. 'We're going to Canada next week,' Laura, my five-year-old daughter, had announced to the playground in general a few weeks earlier. 'Little Canada,' I hastened to add, as a couple of other parents looked impressed. 'It's on the Isle of Wight.'

The company that runs Little Canada, and a similar centre at Osmington Bay in Dorset, recently changed its name from Superchoice to 3D. Why 3D? No one seemed to know - though timid son thought the admonition that no one was allowed on the trampoline without a 3D instructor meant the instructor had to be there in the flesh: a two-dimensional picture of one would not do.

A flock of these multi-dimensional instructors made themselves available the minute we arrived and bore the kids away to view their 'common room' and bag bunks in their respective chalets, successfully dissolving any worries with their bubbly enthusiasm.

Well, if you were eight years old, who would you rather hang out with on holiday? Parents way the wrong side of 30 who occasionally like to sit in one place and read a newspaper? Or bouncy 23-year-olds who are still on for bopping with you at the evening disco after spending all day shepherding you from rock climbing to low ropes to circus skills?

And one of these really fun grown-ups even stays with you all night. Forget chilly dormitories and rows of washbasins: at 3D camps, under-10s sleep six to a centrally heated chalet, each with en suite facilities; there's a separate bedroom for an instructor, on hand to make sure teeth are brushed and to deal with any nightmares.

In fact it probably wouldn't matter how luxurious the accommodation was or wasn't. By the time your day has included, perhaps, abseiling, archery, canoeing, 'aeroball' (a cross between basketball and trampolining - particularly popular with Lauren, aged eight) and an after-dinner scavenger hunt, and you've made time for pillow fights, 'midnight' feasts and a healthy dose of talking after lights-out - which unconscious child is going to notice how comfortable their bed is?

This place has been called Little Canada ever since the Twenties, when a New Zealander called Howarth, struck by the beauty of the ancient woodland running down to a stony creek, had the idea of adding log cabins - probably one of the country's earliest holiday camps. Whether he had ever actually visited Big Canada, no one knows. By coincidence, Canadian troops were billeted in those same cabins during the Second World War and used the nearby Woodside Bay - now the scene of the children's Tuesday night campfire sessions - to practise for the D-Day landings. Today's chalets are all suitably named: our troop were sleeping in St Lawrence, and would head up past Newfoundland and Saskatchewan for dinner. And Aidan? You could almost say it was the making of him. Ten-pin bowling was 'brilliant'. Popmobility was 'embarrassing but I did it'. And 'Jacob's ladder' - an 'initiative' course (no assault courses any more) that involved getting all members of your team across an obstacle course using only a 10ft ladder - was 'hard, but cool: we found this really neat trick'. But coolest by far was The Matrix, a specially built version of TV's The Crystal Maze. Children solve puzzles to make their way through a series of four themed rooms: the office ('a prehistoric office, Mummy, from when they didn't have computers'), the Wild West Saloon, the Victorian haunted house and the spaceship. The whole lot is presided over by a 'Master' complete with floor-length purple velvet cloak. 'I can't tell you any of the answers, Mummy, because I would have to shoot you.'

There is also tunnelling, fencing, quad-biking and orienteering. The 'croc swamp' takes a game all children play - that one where your sitting room is a lake of piranhas, and every cushion in the house is pressed into service as a stepping stone - and makes it more exciting. Small wooden platforms take the place of your sofa cushions, and the kids use a short plank to traverse trickier sections. A thin rain falling steadily from a very English sky did not dampen the collective enthusiasm.

Really inclement weather would mar a child's summer camp experience, though indoor facilities such as a climbing wall, tunnel trail, swimming pool and IT labs would ensure the holiday was not ruined.

Which takes us back to that leap of faith. 'High ropes' - half a dozen 40ft-high poles linked by walkways, trapezes and zip wires - is one activity that would be made unacceptably dangerous by heavy rain, even though the children are securely harnessed and helmeted before ascending. How Aidan would handle it was a matter of intense interest. The zip wire involves leaping from the top of the highest pole, travelling 70ft to a spot on a tree some way away, then bouncing back to the lowest point before abseiling to the ground. The boy had clearly taken some persuading. 'I was sitting there on the platform and Dave said to shuffle forward, so I did. And then he pushed me.' The descent takes just a couple of seconds, but it was long enough for his anguished 'aarrgh' to turn into a triumphant 'yee-hah'.

It was only on the way home that we realised how all-consuming Little Canada had been. Like almost every male in the developed world who is over five but under five feet, the boys of our party are Pokémon crazy. Yet it was not until Portsmouth was well behind us and we had almost hit the M25 that Zapdos, Geodude and Pikachu reared their ugly (well, they are) heads. Nature trail, quiz and dragon boat had done what everyday life could not: relegate the exploits of Ash and Team Rocket to their proper place. Children can go on full seven-night holidays to Little Canada - a useful summer holiday solution for working parents; Osmington Bay also offers four-night stays - or they can opt for individual Adventure Days if they live, or are on holiday, nearby. This may seem an attractive way of offering your kids exciting activities without bidding them goodbye for a whole week, but I suspect it would be a tame version. However absorbing the sports and games, the real fun lies in the no-mum-or-dad camaraderie of the dormitory, in - for the boys at least - sitting up late giggling about 6ft willies and making up 'poems' about diarrhoea.

It is probably a long way from what the upstanding Mr Howarth had in mind, but given the state of my son's sponge bag after the holiday - soap and flannel in the same pristine state in which they had gone in - I must conclude that ' mens filthy in corpore even filthier ' would be a fair motto for summer camp.

 3D Education and Adventure Ltd, Little Canada Centre, New Road, Wootton, Isle of Wight. www.3d-education.co.uk. Tel: 0870 607 7733. A seven-night summer camp stay costs £314 per child.

fields.headline: Travel News
fields.standfirst: US pips Oz as Britons decide to go it alone
fields.trailText: US pips Oz as Britons decide to go it alone
fields.body:
An annual analysis of bookings across the American Express travel offices' network highlights a number of developing trends in the British travel market.

Last year's leader, Australia, has slumped to fourth place, leaving the top three places dominated by US destinations. The only new entry, Thailand, won a place at the expense of St Lucia. Overall the Caribbean islands suffered a poor year, thanks to flight over-capacity and hurricanes and lost ground to the Indian Ocean resorts.

The US enjoyed its prevalence because of a combination of cheap flights and accessibility to a wide range of destinations, as demonstrated by increasing demand for fly-drive holidays to less-established destinations like Virginia, the Carolinas and Colorado.

The perception of value-for-money, and the strength of sterling, boosted the Far East but concerns have been raised over subsequent price rises by hotels and airlines. The figures also show a growth in demand for smaller destinations like Comores in the Indian Ocean and Zanzibar in Africa. Average expenditure on package holidays was estimated at £1,500 per person.

However, political unrest was again cited as the key issue in deterring long haul holidaymakers. Zimbabwe, Sri Lanka and Fiji all suffered a drop in bookings, although Egypt has made a solid recovery since the terrrorist attacks of 1997.

The report's most significant conclusion was that the package holiday is being superseded by tailor-made travel: 68 per cent of bookings were for independent travel components (flights, car hire and hotels) against 32 per cent for package holidays.

A new spirit of adventure prevailed; travellers who had previously visited Thailand were now booking trips to Vietnam.

The US remains the most popular destination for independent travel, but was closely followed by last year's line-up: Australia, the Far East, Canada and New Zealand.

All are seen as 'safe' for the mainstream market as well as backpackers.

fields.headline: At your service
fields.standfirst: A top concierge reveals all
fields.trailText: A top concierge reveals all
fields.body:
The Lygon Arms, Worcestershire

Steve Pirone, Head concierge

Have you always worked at the Lygon?

Actually I just came back to the at the end of March - I was working in London for 16 months, but felt like a robot. Life in London can be a rat race and I was away from my family during the week, which was also difficult. Luckily the new manager at the Lygon called me and I decided to return to the Cotswolds for the quality of life: it was like going home.

I started at the Lygon Arms in 1990 and once you have been there for a while it gets into your bloodstream.

Any famous guests?

We don't have as many overseas visitors as the London hotels, but over the years I have met pop stars, Hollywood film stars and an ex-President. During the week we get a lot of corporate guests and at the weekend people come for the leisure activities. The Japanese and Americans love it.

Any unusual requests?

When people come out to the country they want to do things like hot-air ballooning and horse and carriage rides. However one lady did ask whether we knew a farmer. She wanted to give her husband a present of an afternoon's shepherding with some sheep and a dog. Fortunately there was no problem and we also provided a picnic and champagne.

What about a day out?

We don't book sightseeing tours but tailor private tours instead. Many people have computer printouts from the internet these days with lists of the places they want to visit. Stratford, Warwick and Stowe are popular, but I prefer to send people off on to the B-roads. There are lots of lovely little villages, like Blockley, Paxford and Ford, as well as gardens, stately homes and castles. There are also quite a few speed cameras which I warn guests about! We recently organised a late-afternoon horse and carriage ride for an American gentleman. When he got back he told us that it had made his holiday and that he had felt like royalty.

What about a night out?

Broadway is a small village so the options are quite limited. The hotel's brasserie and restaurant are both excellent and most guests eat in one or the other. There is a Greek and Italian restaurant in Chipping Camden, and an Indian in Broadway. Stratford is only 25 minutes away so the Royal Shakespeare Company theatres are always popular. Guests usually have some champagne before they go, and a candlelit supper when they get back. There is a small cinema in Evesham, but it is not one we recommend. It doesn't seem to have changed since the Seventies.

 The Lygon Arms: 01386 852 255

 Royal Shakespeare Theatre: 01789 403 403

webTitle: The top dozen children's museums worldwide

fields.headline: The top dozen children's museums worldwide
fields.trailText: Eureka! Halifax | Science Museum, London | Brooklyn Children's Museum | The Children's Museum, Boston | Chicago Children's Museum | Port Discovery, Baltimore | Please Touch Museum, Philadelphia | Children's Discovery Museum of San José | newMetropolis, Amsterdam | Experimentarium, Copenhagen | Citie des Enfants, Paris | Tokyo Metropolitan Children's Museum
fields.body:
Eureka! Halifax

Two floors of fun and educational games, designed for children up to the age of 12. The ground floor houses a mini-television studio and music room, a town square, with a scaled-down branch of Marks & Spencer, post office, bank, roadworks section and garage - changing wheels on the cars is a very popular activity. Eureka's 'house' covers both floors, with a see-through lavatory to learn how plumbing works, a kitchen and bedroom. The largest section is Me and My Body with giant tongues and eyeballs to touch and a Jaggeresque mouth to play inside - complete with wobbly tooth. Younger children have their own space with musical flowers and a ball pool.

Eureka is open seven days a week (except 24-26 December) 10am-5pm. Children aged three-12, £4.75, adults and children over 12, £5.75. Free admission for children under three. Discovery Road, Halifax, West Yorkshire HX1 2NE. (01422 330012/www.eureka.org.uk)

Science Museum, London

In a museum generally strong on buttons to push and levers to pull, Launch Pad goes to enjoyable extremes. Children can play with a two-way mirror, check out electrical currents and walk along a suspension bridge that sways just a little less than the Millennium Bridge. The two most popular exhibits are the grain depot - a series of cogs and wheels that needs teamwork to move grain around a circuit - and giant sound dishes that beam voices across the gallery. From 3 July, Launch Pad will be part of the Science Museum's Wellcome Wing, incorporating Pattern Pod for the under-eights.

The Science Museum is open seven days a week, 10am-6pm. Adults £6.95 before 4.30pm, free after that time, children 16 and under free at all times. Closed 27 June, 24-26 December. Exhibition Road, South Kensington, London, SW7 2DD. (0870 870 4868/www.nmsi.ac.uk). The Wellcome Wing opens to the public on 3 July.

Brooklyn Children's Museum

A sustaining chunk of the Big Apple - visitors can check out the Yankee Stadium, jump rope and make pizza at this venerable children's museum, founded in 1899. Other exhibits include nature trails and the chance to play musical instruments from around the world. This summer sees a major exhibition based on the Sesame Street characters.

145 Brooklyn Avenue. (00 1 718 735 4400/ ny.com/museums/brooklyn.children.museum). Open Saturday, Sunday and most school holidays 10am-5pm; Wednesday, Thursday and Friday 2pm-5pm. Closed Mondays and Tuesdays. $4 (£2.47).

The Children's Museum, Boston

Aiming to get younger children in the museum habit, the Children's Museum in Boston will be opening Playspace this summer - an area aimed at those aged up to three and fitted out with (skill-enhancing) toys. Older children can learn about the big outdoors by camping inside the newly enlarged museum, play on a giant desktop, take to the stage, find out how Japanese families live and learn the importance of blowing bubbles in the Science Centre.

300 Congress Street, Boston (00 1 617 426 8855/www.bostonkids.org). Open daily 10am-5pm, (9pm on Fridays). Adults $7 (£4.33), children $6 (£3.71), one-year-olds $2 (£1.24), under-ones free. Admission $1 (62p) on Fridays between 5-9pm.

Chicago Children's Museum

Pint-sized fans of ER can play in their own mini-hospital in this staggeringly well-equipped children's museum at Navy Pier on Lake Michigan. Other options include watching the forest come alive in the Treehouse Trails, getting lost in the Playmaze and becoming very wet building a dam in the Waterways section. Kids on the Fly is a branch of the museum at O'Hare Airport.

700 East Grand Avenue at Navy Pier, Chicago. (00 1 312 527 1000/www.chichildrens.museum.org) Open daily 10am-5pm (Thursday until 8pm), $6.50 (£4.02). Admission free on Thursdays from 5-8pm. Children under one admitted free.

Port Discovery, the Kid-Powered Museum, Baltimore

Further blurring the line drawn between theme parks and children's museums, this highly rated activity centre was put together with help from Disney Imagineering. Exhibits include Adventure Exploration - where children follow hieroglyphic clues to find a pharaoh's tomb and Miss Perception's Mystery House. There's also a three-storey climbing frame. For children under six there's the Sensation Station - with scaled-down climbing and crawling frames, books and toys.

35 Market Place, Baltimore, MD 21202. Tuesday to Sunday 10am-5:30pm (00 1 410 727 8120) (Closed Mondays, except for special school holidays) Open daily 29 May - 6 September. Adults $10 (£6.18), three-12 years $7.50 (£4.64), younger children free.

Please Touch Museum, Philadelphia

Particularly good for younger children - most of the activities and exhibits are geared towards those aged between one and seven. Exhibits include a miniature television studio, supermarket, tiny planes, trains and automobiles but the highlight is probably the play area based on Maurice Sendak's books - including oversized props based on his famous Where the Wild Things Are .

210 North 21st Street (21st and Race Streets). (00 1 215 963 0666/www.pleasetouchmuseum.org) Open daily 9am-4:30pm, 6pm summer. $6.95 (£4.30), children under one free.

Children's Discovery Museum of San José

Widely considered to be the best children's museum on the US West Coast, it offers an innovative child-centred presentation of past and present, from a turn-of-the-century house and porch with household implements and furnishings of the period, to a banking system and Jesse's Clubhouse - a multi-level tower with a video effects system which allows images and perspectives to be changed.

180 Woz Way, San José, California (001 408 298 5437/www.cdm.org) Open Monday to Saturday 10am-5pm, Sunday noon-5pm $6 (£3.71) , children aged under one free.

newMetropolis, Amsterdam

From the ashes of the now-closed Technologie museum has risen a brand new children's museum. With an eye to the future, exhibits include computer games where players trade information, money and places, while the energy section juggles lifestyle and the environment. Younger children have their own area to play, dress up as scientists or doctors, then watch themselves on television afterwards. 'Hosts' are on hand to help with language difficulties.

Oosterdok 2, Amsterdam. (00 31 20 5313233/www.newmet.nl). Open during school holidays 10am-6pm. Otherwise Tuesday to Friday 10am-5pm, Saturday to Sunday 10am-6pm Adults Dfl20 (£5.46), children aged between four-16 Dfl15 (£4.09), children aged three and under free.

Experimentarium, Copenhagen

Housed on the site of a former beer factory, older children can get drunk on fun with water, create their own perfume from a range of scents or use a simulator to see if they have the makings of a championship goalkeeper. Smaller children are catered for in the Kid's Pavilion, where they can dance through the poppy wood, play with mirrors and build a house with a crane.

Tuborg Havnevej 7, Hellerup. (00 45 3927 3333/www.experimentarium.dk) Monday, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday 9am-5pm, Tuesday 9am-9pm. Weekends and bank holidays 11am-5pm. Adults DKK79 (£6.38), children aged between three-14 DKK57 (£4.60), children two and under free.

Citie des Enfants, Paris

Part of the Citie des Sciences complex just outside Paris. Younger visitors get to build a house using cranes and polystyrene bricks, while older children learn about machines, the body and communication. Adults are kept in their place, allowed to observe rather than encouraged to participate with their children. More structured than most - but impressive.

Citie des Sciences et de l'Industrie, 30 av Corentin-Cariou, 19th (00 33 1 40 05 8000/www.cite-sciences.sgip.fr). Open 10am to 6pm Tuesday to Sunday (reservations advised to join the sessions). Day pass to Citie des Sciences 50F (£4.59), children aged under 16 F35 (£3.21). Sessions at Citie des Enfants cost F25.

With lessons in making origami and a pottery studio, there's an obvious reason for creative children to visit. 1-18-24 Shibuya, Shibuya-ku (Tel: 00 81 3 3409 6361). Open daily 9am-5pm (6pm in July and August) but closed two Mondays a month. Free.
fields.bodyText: Eureka! Halifax Two floors of fun and educational games, designed for children up to the age of 12. The ground floor houses a mini-television studio and music room, a town square, with a scaled-down branch of Marks & Spencer, post office, bank, roadworks section and garage - changing wheels on the cars is a very popular activity. Eureka's 'house' covers both floors, with a see-through lavatory to learn how plumbing works, a kitchen and bedroom. The largest section is Me and My Body with giant tongues and eyeballs to touch and a Jaggeresque mouth to play inside - complete with wobbly tooth. Younger children have their own space with musical flowers and a ball pool. Eureka is open seven days a week (except 24-26 December) 10am-5pm. Children aged three-12, £4.75, adults and children over 12, £5.75. Free admission for children under three. Discovery Road, Halifax, West Yorkshire HX1 2NE. (01422 330012/www.eureka.org.uk) Science Museum, London In a museum generally strong on buttons to push and levers to pull, Launch Pad goes to enjoyable extremes. Children can play with a two-way mirror, check out electrical currents and walk along a suspension bridge that sways just a little less than the Millennium Bridge. (0870 870 4868/www.nmsi.ac.uk). The Wellcome Wing opens to the public on 3 July.
