fields.headline: War and peas
fields.standfirst: The humble pea has survived centuries, but if you want a crop in June, you might have a battle on your hands
fields.trailText: The humble pea has survived centuries, but if you want a crop in June, you might have a battle on your hands.
fields.body:
We gave a Fork to Fork talk and demonstration at Hay Literary Festival the other week, which ended with questions from the audience. My children, who had acted as waiters, dishing out portions of spinach, orache and bacon salad, were astonished that grown-ups could ask so many questions about carrot fly or the intricacies of making compost. But as you slump into adulthood, the garden acts as a sump to absorb all the displaced anxieties that hedge every adult action. So much easier to agonise about the construction of the compost heap than the shreds and tatters of your life.

At the moment, the repository of my troubles is not the compost heap, which is doing fine, but this year's pea crop. My pea failure nags away at me. I like a pea. Everyone likes peas. Every garden has to have at least one row of peas - a symbol of freshness and productivity and a practical contribution to the table. Fresh peas, shovelled from the pod straight into your mouth, are a rolling green absolute. You measure other pleasures by it. If I live to be 100, I shall not forget the sight of my daughter Freya, seen from the bathroom window, her long auburn hair curling in tendrils, pea-like, quietly munching her way along a row of peas at seven o'clock on a sunny July morning. If you have children, it is worth growing peas - even just half a dozen plants growing up a wigwam in a pot - just so the kids can eat them raw and know what peas really taste like.

They have been part of European gardens for thousands of years, primarily for their ability to be stored, dried and then cooked to make a nutritious porridge. It seems the luxury of growing them just to shell and eat straightaway only began in the 16th century. Peas freeze better than almost any other vegetable, although to get the best of a pea, you must eat it within hours of picking, before the sugar starts to turn to starch. This is easy to do at home, although we never freeze peas because commercially frozen ones are very good and, anyway, we hardly freeze anything in its raw state, preferring when possible to eat things fresh as they come into season. I don't want peas in January any more than I want warm, wet, grey days without break from November right through to March.

But I do like peas in June, and I do not have any ready yet. Reading William Cobbett (The English Gardener , Bloomsbury Classics, £14.99), I see that this means I am either an incompetent, or just thoroughly unmanly. He writes: 'Ever since I became a man, I can recollect that it was always deemed rather a sign of bad gardening if there were not green peas in the garden fit to gather on the fourth of June.' I am writing this on the fourth of June, and there's not a single green pea fit to gather in the garden. Cobbett does go on to say that 'to have them at this season, the very earliest sort must be sowed... in November, and they must be sowed on the south side of a wall... the ground not being wet in its nature by any means'.

I did sow my peas in early December and, not having a wall at all, let alone a south side of one, and knowing how wet and cold our soil gets, I sowed them in pots. This is laborious, but four trays of 24 4in pots, two peas to each, were duly sown. They were an early variety, Feltham First, bred to survive more cold than later varieties. They were then put in a cold frame, watered and looked at daily for signs of incipient pea-ness. Nothing happened followed by nothing more. Eventually, of those 192 peas, precisely 10 germinated. These 10 are now producing flat pods in my daughter's piece of garden (decorated defiantly in the Home-Front-in-the-Garden school of design - all pink- and blue-painted pebbles, painted trellis, zinnias and tobacco plants. She does it because it teases, but I secretly love it and, other than my pitiful peas, she has grown everything from seed herself). The other 182 rotted. The trouble was that I used a potting mix with too much of our own loam in it, and this acted as a sponge. The lesson is to add plenty of grit to the ground for early sowings and make the compost sharp if sowing them in pots.

I sowed a batch of 'Alderman' in March and some 'Hurst Greenshaft' and 'Sugar Snap' in early May. Germination has been erratic, but there will be some sort of crop from all of them. However, attacks by mice and pigeons are common. Cloches help on early sowings, and earthing up (drawing the soil up along the row with a hoe) secures the roots and makes it harder for mice.

All garden peas crop much better if they are supported - ideally by pea sticks, if you can get them, or by netting supported along the row by canes. Modern pea breeding has concentrated on producing short-growing peas to make mechanised harvesting easier. But taller varieties take up no more space in the garden, and are likely to ripen better and crop more vigorously over a longer period. 'Alderman' is a particularly tall variety, reaching over 6ft in rich soil. Height is a virtue in the kitchen garden, adding much-needed green texture. And pea sticks look tremendous when staked out along the rows: they have that wonderful mix of aesthetic beauty and functional purpose that a hedge has.

Mangetout and sugar-snap peas are eaten pods and all. The former never really develop proper peas and retain flat pods, and the latter do so slowly, which means if you do not pick them regularly you can harvest the maturing peas and eat them as a normal variety. Both are without the hard wall to the pod that conventional peas have. There is a lot to be said for growing sugar snaps if you have limited space and limited patience for the bother of shelling peas. I veer between a nostalgic, glowing pleasure at the business of shelling peas around the kitchen table and an impatient desire for the fast-food immediacy of sugar snaps. Purple-podded peas are hard to get hold of, but worth growing if you can find them because they look absolutely lovely.

They can either be sown in drills a few inches deep, in a single row with each pea spaced two or three inches apart, or, as I do, in wider, flatter drills with two rows spaced four or five inches apart. Cobbett says firmly that there is no advantage in sowing more than single rows. Each pair of rows will need room to walk between, so should be 3ft apart. Again, Cobbett violently disagrees, insisting that each row should be 6ft or more apart, and goes into a long story of how his gardener had disobediently sown rows a mere 3ft apart but was proved wrong after a heavy rain 'smashed the whole of them down into one mass... the destroyed patch was, however, of precious advantage; for it made me the master of my gardener'. Much as I revere Cobbett, his advice is only applicable to the biggest of gardens or allotments and, anyway, my ambitions are more modest: I only seek to be master of my peas.

Preparing the ground for perfect peas

Peas take nitrogen from the air into the soil via warty nodules on their roots.This makes them an essential component in the rotation of vegetables in the garden. They grow best in a well-manured but light soil and they like cool, damp weather, but hate sitting in the wet.

The fastest-maturing varieties take about 12 weeks to mature, and the slowest can take up to 16 - but will go on producing pods for a month.

You can easily save your sown peas for next year's seed. Leave the pods on the plant as long as possible, lifting the whole plant just before the pods start to split. Hang up the plant in a dry shed or store the pods on a tray until they split open. Collect the peas and store them in an airtight container or paper bag in a cool, dry place.

webTitle: Steinbeck son rages at sex travesty

fields.headline: Steinbeck son rages at sex travesty
fields.standfirst:
Anger as film director spices up late classic by Grapes of Wrath author
Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Hollywood's treatment of one of postwar America's most revered novels, John Steinbeck's The Pearl, has come under fire this weekend from family members for its graphic sex scenes.
fields.body:
Hollywood's treatment of one of postwar America's most revered novels, John Steinbeck's The Pearl, has come under fire this weekend from family members for its graphic sex scenes.

The Steinbeck estate claims that the little-known film-maker Alfredo Zacharias's script - currently being filmed in Mexico starring Richard Harris and Lukas Hass - fabricates nude scenes and distorts the much-loved original.

Published in 1947, The Pearl is regarded as one of America's greatest postwar novels: a simple tale of a Mexican peasant fisherman's discovery of a pearl at the bottom of a lake. In The Pearl, Steinbeck documented all the hopes and travails of the American dream - as viewed by immigrants and natives themselves. The book was published to resounding critical and commercial success, and remains prescribed reading in American schools to this day.

The Steinbeck estate has sought to bring the book to the screen since the early Nineties. Previous film adaptations of Steinbeck's novels have always stayed faithful to the source material. The Elia Kazan-directed East of Eden, released in 1954 and starring James Dean, devotedly stuck to the original text. The film received four Oscar nominations.

Similarly, The Grapes of Wrath - Steinbeck's fictional account of migrant labour workers during the Depression years - was magnificently rendered by director John Ford. The movie is now regarded as a highpoint of Ford's career.

Thomas Steinbeck, son of the late novelist, entered a co-production agreement with Zacharias' Panorama Films in April 1992. Zacharias' previous output had showcased only low-budget releases: horror B-movies such as The Bandits, The Bees and 1981's Demonoid: Messenger of Death .

Discussions on a possible feature adaptation of The Pearl resolved in a licensing option of the original book two months later. But the partnership dissolved after differences over the screenplay, and the project was sent to arbitration in March 1996.

Zacharias's firm was allowed by the judge to continue production on the film. 'I found it incredible,' says Gail Knight, manager of the Steinbeck estate. 'We can't stop production - there has been little contact with Zacharias since.'

A working screenplay sent to her confirmed her fears. In a novel of only 119 pages, the Steinbeck estate has discovered 44 variations between the text and the screenplay - including various scenes not included in the original. In one scene, a peasant girl, Juanita, is viewed rubbing her face against her breast. The family currently has no access to a shooting script.

Thomas Steinbeck, 55, says: 'My father's writings are part of the photography of the US - his work to a degree defines the American spirit. So you have to be incredibly careful: his books continue to sell, and as his son I am in charge of his legacy.

'Hollywood and Steinbeck are a strange union anyway - but it has proved true to his vision in the past. And The Pearl remains one of his defining works. To see it trivialised would be a catastrophe.'

In 1962, Steinbeck received the Nobel Prize for Literature; he died six years later and was buried in his hometown of Salinas, California.

The author's agents are, understandably, concerned. 'Any film of The Pearl will have to remain true to the spirit of the original text,' says Samuel Pinkus, of McIntosh & Otis, New York-based literary agents for the Steinbeck estate.

Pinkus continued: 'We're adopting a wait-and-see policy; one course of action would be to bring an injunction against release. McIntosh & Otis has always sought to protect the reputation of one of America's most famous writers.'

A spokesperson for Zacharias refused to comment on the film's production. He also declined to reveal the film's production budget.

The late author supplied a critical account of Hollywood limitations in an essay, published in 1951, Some Random and Randy Thoughts on Books. Steinbeck wrote: 'One cannot conceive of a motion picture as being personal as a beloved book is personal. No television show is a friend as a book is a friend.'

Zacharias' previous output had showcased only low-budget releases: horror B-movies such as The Bandits, The Bees and 1981's Demonoid: Messenger of Death . Discussions on a possible feature adaptation of The Pearl resolved in a licensing option of the original book two months later. But the partnership dissolved after differences over the screenplay, and the project was sent to arbitration in March 1996. Zacharias's firm was allowed by the judge to continue production on the film. 'I found it incredible,' says Gail Knight, manager of the Steinbeck estate. 'We can't stop production - there has been little contact with Zacharias since.' A working screenplay sent to her confirmed her fears. In a novel of only 119 pages, the Steinbeck estate has discovered 44 variations between the text and the screenplay - including various scenes not included in the original. In one scene, a peasant girl, Juanita, is viewed rubbing her face against her breast. The family currently has no access to a shooting script. Thomas Steinbeck, 55, says: 'My father's writings are part of the photography of the US - his work to a degree defines the American spirit. So you have to be incredibly careful: his books continue to sell, and as his son I am in charge of his legacy. 'Hollywood and Steinbeck are a strange union anyway - but it has proved true to his vision in the past. And The Pearl remains one of his defining works. To see it trivialised would be a catastrophe.' In 1962, Steinbeck received the Nobel Prize for Literature; he died six years later and was buried in his hometown of Salinas, California. The author's agents are, understandably, concerned. 'Any film of The Pearl will have to remain true to the spirit of the original text,' says Samuel Pinkus, of McIntosh & Otis, New York-based literary agents for the Steinbeck estate. Pinkus continued: 'We're adopting a wait-and-see policy; one course of action would be to bring an injunction against release. McIntosh & Otis has always sought to protect the reputation of one of America's most famous writers.' A spokesperson for Zacharias refused to comment on the film's production. He also declined to reveal the film's production budget. The late author supplied a critical account of Hollywood limitations in an essay, published in 1951, Some Random and Randy Thoughts on Books. Steinbeck wrote: 'One cannot conceive of a motion picture as being personal as a beloved book is personal. No television show is a friend as a book is a friend.' burhan.wazir@observer.co.uk

webTitle: 'It was multi-national mayhem on the streets' - police chief

fields.headline: 'It was multi-national mayhem on the streets' - police chief
fields.standfirst: England's hopes of hosting the World Cup lie in tatters, report  Vivek Chaudhary in Charleroi and  John Arlidge
fields.trailText: It was as depressing as it was predictable. Last night's grim scenes of soccer violence were the culmination of 36 hours of chaos that engulfed two Belgian cities and involved fans from five countries.
fields.body:
It was as depressing as it was predictable. Last night's grim scenes of soccer violence were the culmination of 36 hours of chaos that engulfed two Belgian cities and involved fans from five countries. English fans fought German, Turkish, Moroccan and French in what a senior Belgian police officer described as 'multi-national mayhem'.

As fresh battles broke out ahead of the crucial match against Germany last night, England's reputation as a responsible footballing nation lay, like its battered and dejected fans, in the gutters of Brussels and Charleroi. Privately, the Football Association was last night preparing to scale down its bid to host World Cup 2006.

A senior official said: 'After our success in Euro 96 this is the worst thing that could have happened. It may not be all England's fault - it rarely is - but who will trust us with a global competition after seeing what England fans are capable of? It is difficult to see how our bid can make it.'

The latest chapter in England's long and shameful history of hooliganism started after the France versus the Czech Republic match on Friday afternoon when a group of England fans threw glasses at French fans outside an Irish pub in Brussels.

The English fans then attacked the pub. Riot police charged England fans drinking in bars around the Grand Place, pepper-spraying them and firing teargas. By nightfall on Friday the square was sealed off but word had spread around the city that the English had arrived.

More trouble broke out around 9pm when large groups of local North African youths and Turkish youths roamed the city centre chanting anti-English slogans. English fans in bars responded with anti-Turkish songs and several gave the ' sieg heil ' salute.

Around 100 angry North African youths had gathered in a square just off the Boulevard Adolf Max, which leads to the main square in the Belgian capital. In a bar opposite, a group of England fans took cover as bottles were hurled. The Moroccans were riled at reports that English fans had abused a North African woman.

In one of the most serious incidents of the night, an England fan was attacked outside this bar by a group of around 30 North African youths who swarmed across the road, halting traffic to attack him. He was punched to the ground and repeatedly kicked in the head. They only stopped when Belgian riot police moved in and scattered them.

Moments later a man of North African appearance was driving past a bar in the city centre when some England fans threw glasses at him and hurled anti-Turkish abuse. Two Leeds United fans died in clashes with Turks two months ago in Istanbul ahead of a match with Galatasaray.

The man leapt from his car, pulled out a baseball bat and attacked. England fans punched and kicked him but he retreated to his car and sped off. According to reports, he returned a few hours later with friends to confront the English fans who had attacked him. In the clashes which followed, an England fan was stabbed in the back.

Police continued to patrol central Brussels into the early hours of yesterday and followed groups of England fans who were looking for bars to drink in. Bars and restaurants in the city centre closed early. At one stage a group of local North Africans began marching towards a bar called Trap to confront over a hundred England fans outside it. Riot police baton-charged both sets of fans to disperse them.

In their familiar refrain, England fans caught up in the trouble protested their innocence and blamed police for being heavy-handed. Edwin Moore, 30, from London, who witnessed the attack on a fellow English fan outside the bar, said: 'It was really vicious. I have never seen anything like it. They were kicking his head as if it was a football and blood was pouring out of the guy's mouth. We've been getting abuse from local youths as we were walking around and the police have also been really tough. They think we're all trouble-makers but there are a lot of people here who just want to cause violence. It's not just the English fans.'

But others told a different story. Hardip Mothada, aged 31 from London, said: 'We're supposed to be here for a football match but a lot of the English fans have been making lots of racist remarks and singing racist songs.

'I even got some abuse myself because I'm Asian. I was close to one bar and I saw this middle-aged man of North African appearance walk past. A big English lad just walked up to him and punched him, shouting "you fucking Paki, you fucking Turk". The whole thing has been really scary and horrible and has put me off watching England.'

It did not take long for the bad blood of Brussels to reach Charleroi. By the early hours of Saturday morning the atmosphere in the main square, which had been upbeat and trouble-free, turned nasty. English and German fans had been taunting each other across the square for several hours. Riot police waited at the edges of the square. Fights broke out and police used water cannon to separate the groups as officers on horseback rushed in.

Some fans fled down side streets. Others were arrested. England fans responded by hurling missiles at the police.

Later, lines of riot police sealed off England fans at one side of the square and Germans at the other. Shortly before 4pm local time the Germans started throwing missiles at police confronting them but were immediately driven back to the edge of the square by the police using batons and water cannons.

Overall, more than 500 fans were arrested in the two cities. The first were deported last night and arrived in handcuffs at Manchester and Heathrow airports. Around 100 are expected to appear in court in Brussels on criminal charges including causing injury and inciting violence.

Francois-Xavier de Donnea, mayor of Brussels, said many hooligans had reached the Continent. Shadow Home Secretary Ann Widdecombe echoed him. She accused Jack Straw, the Home Secretary, of not doing enough to ensure hooligans were kept out of Belgium and Holland. Any fan subject to a domestic match ban must be banned from travelling abroad to games - even if never convicted of an offence, she said.

The proposal was considered by the Home Office but shelved amid civil liberties arguments. 'Jack Straw had years in which to do this. It's not as if we hadn't known Euro 2000 was coming. We need to take very tough measures,' Widdecombe said.

Home Office Minister Lord Bassam, visiting Belgium to observe operations to deal with fans, praised the firm action by the police. 'They promised a firm response and that is what we want,' he said.

Sixty Britons have been refused entry to the Low Countries since the tournament began. These included three members of the fascist group Combat 18.

fields.headline: Farewell to a loyal friend
fields.standfirst: 'If you upset me then you upset Brian Statham, too,' recalls Freddie Trueman of his fast-bowling partner
fields.trailText: Bill Bradshaw talks to Fred Trueman about his memories of Brian Statham, who died last weekend
fields.body:
Freddie Trueman spent yesterday following England's fortunes against the West Indies, but he would far rather have been at Old Trafford to keep a date he intended to honour for his best cricketing pal, Brian Statham.

Statham, one half of arguably England's finest new-ball partnership, died last weekend and his funeral took place on Friday. Trueman, as usual, was there for his old friend who would have celebrated his seventieth birthday yesterday. That landmark, one which Statham would not quite reach, was to have been the trigger for a dinner in his honour at his cricketing home in Manchester, as Trueman explains:

'We never lost touch. I'm going to miss him greatly. I spoke with Lancashire's Jim Cumbes and their financial man, Murray Bernie, about putting on a dinner for Brian to mark his birthday. We were all for it but when we realised how poorly he was, we had to think again.'

Fred raised a glass in memory of his old friend on Friday. Trueman and Statham. The names roll off the tongue and go together like ham and eggs and, well, mild and bitter. Both men were fond of their drink after a hard day's play but Trueman gives way.

'It's true we both liked to have a drink, but I wasn't in Brian's league,' he says. 'He loved to unwind with cigarettes and beer - well, lager actually. That was his drink. He rarely got drunk - not nastily anyway. But he could put a lot away. I always knew if he'd had a heavy night because his fingers would be black from smoking.

'My favourite drinking story about George - his nickname because Lancashire always had a George in their team and when they suddenly found themselves without one, Brian volunteered - occurred during a tour to the West Indies.

'We really were good mates and I roomed with him. One night we set out for the local cinema in British Guyana. A few of the lads were there and the usherette asked George if he wanted ice cream or nuts.

'He replied: "No, I'd rather have a lager". We all laughed, but a few minutes later the lass was back with a tray full of lagers. I've never seen anything like it and he was really made up. It made the cowboy picture seem a bit better!'

Trueman first met Statham in 1950 when Trueman's Yorkshire played Lancashire. They introduced themselves to one another and so began a lifelong friendship, cemented when they became England colleagues for the first time in 1954 in the West Indies.

'We both got the chance to bowl at George Headley, a West Indies legend who had played before I was born,' said Trueman. 'It was an honour as they had brought him back for the first Test of that series. In truth, he shouldn't have been out there, but I was glad of the privilege and so was Brian - even though we lost by 10 wickets.

'We got on well and liked similar things. We both liked to put our feet up in the dressing room, watch our batsmen face the opposition bowlers and, best of all, we were complementary to one another as bowlers.'

Although Statham is always mentioned in dispatches with Trueman, they often played with other partners. 'Of my 67 Tests for England, only 30-odd were with Brian. But there is no doubt he contributed to a lot of my Test victims and probably vice versa.

'We hunted in our own pack. That's because I moved the ball mainly away from the right-handed batsman while George moved it into them. If we had a left-hand, right-hand batting pairing against us, we'd often give them a single to enable me to bowl to the right-hander and Brian the left-hander... because his ball would then be moving away from a leftie. And the ball moving away is always considered the more dangerous delivery because there is less margin for error for the batsman.

'I also recall a series against South Africa in 1960 when George tipped me off about their batsman Peter Carlstein. He said he'd be a sucker for my fast yorker. He was spot on. I got him all right.

'Another time I had West Indies batsman Easton McMorris caught off his glove, but the umpire gave him not out. Later their captain, Gerry Alexander, asked Peter May, our captain, if they could bring Rohan Kanhai in because McMorris had gone to hospital to have his hand checked. I was livid and wanted to go after him when he came back, but never got the chance. He was at the other end and Brian put in a short one, hit him in the chest and he had to be taken off, coughing up blood. If you upset me then you upset Brian Statham, too - and the reverse was undoubtedly true.'

On another occasion, when Fred Titmus and wicketkeeper John Murray made their Test debuts, Statham reprimanded the pair for trying to run out the last man. Trueman recalls: 'He said: "What do you think you're doing - you don't run out number 10s or 11s. They're for me and Freddie!".'

The pair were born just eight months apart - Trueman was the junior partner - and their careers ended at much the same time both at Test (1965) and county level. Trueman quit Yorkshire in 1968 and found himself interviewing Statham for Granada TV after his friend's decision to say farewell.

'I told George that I was going and he said that he'd had enough too,' Trueman remembers. 'Yorkshire wanted me to stay and be captain but I'd decided enough was enough. They said at Headingley we were the best-paid cricketers in the land, but I know George was on £500 a year more than me - we'd both had enough. Sixteen years at the top is a long stint.'

While Trueman continued media work that had started while he was in his playing prime, Statham struggled in retirement. Fred nods in agreement but smiles at the thought: 'Brian had a fascination with work - he could sit and watch it all day!' By the late Eighties, Statham had fallen on hard times, but Trueman, once alerted, went into action and was the driving force behind a Statham testimonial dinner in London at the Grosvenor House Hotel. More than 1,000 guests turned up to pay tribute and help out Statham.

'The response was terrific,' says Trueman. 'We were able to buy George a car, help sort out their kitchen at home and invest something to provide him with something of a pension. The south of England really rallied round but, strangely, we found it harder going in Manchester where he had been a hero. There are some hypocrites around who are saying nice things now who were thin on the ground 11 years ago.'

For all that, one of Trueman's fondest memories comes from that period when he walked into an Old Trafford marquee with Statham. 'We were making a presentation,' he recalls. 'And when we walked into the place there was an impromptu standing ovation. It was lovely, absolutely lovely. He may be gone but definitely not forgotten - especially by me.'

webTitle: The Cook and Brown Euro row, June 2000

fields.headline: Labour struggles to keep the lid on its Euro squabbles
fields.standfirst:
Two of the country's most powerful politicians have abandoned any pretence of unity over joining the euro.
The Euro debate - Observer special
fields.trailText: Focus: How Cook and Brown fell out over the Euro. June 2000.
fields.body:
At 10.30am last Thursday, the fax in Tony Blair's outer office hummed into life. The Prime Minister's private secretary had been expecting an important delivery from the Foreign Office. And this was it.

From the fax came seven pages of neatly typed transcript, the speech the Foreign Secretary was due to deliver to the House of Commons that afternoon. It had arrived 'for comment', Civil Service speak for the fine tooth-comb process which all utterances on Europe have to go through.

The sense of expectation was high. That evening the Chancellor, Gordon Brown, was to give his Mansion House speech, the Treasury's key platform before the City. Would Robin Cook, a noted Euro-enthusiast, be able to square his message with Brown, archly cautious on Europe and particularly the single currency? The whiff of split hung heavy in the air.

The Government was just about holding the line. Blair had used Thursday morning's Cabinet meeting to make clear that he wanted to see all ministers falling behind the Government line. The Mansion House speech would be the definitive statement on official policy and should not be departed from. His colleagues nodded in agreement. It was an agreement that was not to last beyond that afternoon.

Heavy briefing during the week had suggested that Brown was to use his speech to demonstrate that he was in charge of policy in Europe. Simmering resentment among other members of the Cabinet was apparent but had yet to break the surface. But by yesterday any pretence that some of the most powerful politicians in Britain see eye to eye on this country's tactics towards Europe had been abandoned. It is a political story with all the pre-requisites - high drama, clashing personalities and a liberal sprinkling of farce.

Cook's speechwriters had, as ever, taken great care over the wording, going through the usual agreed European lexicon on what was allowed.

Any reference to joining the single currency had to be preceded with the word 'successful'. Brown's five economic conditions had to be referred to. The referendum and the fact that it was the people who would ultimately decide were also essential.

Cook's officials had dutifully written all the elements into the speech. It was faxed to Downing Street with some confidence. They waited for a response. And waited. And waited. The Foreign Secretary was due to stand up in the Commons and start his speech at 1.15pm. As the clock in the Commons chamber ticked towards start time, Cook still had his original speech in front of him. As usual, copies had been circulated to the expectant press gallery sitting above him. Nothing had come back from Downing Street, and Cook believed that his speech had been given the all clear. After all, it contained nothing that he hadn't said before.

Just before he got up he was tapped on the shoulder by a colleague and handed a brown envelope. In it was a handwritten note from his private office. Number 10 had been in touch, the note said. Please be aware of the Chancellor's speech this evening, the note said. We do not want to be a hostage to media accusations of splits, the note said. And that was it, no suggestion of which bits to cut or trim, just a warning.

Senior government sources said that the lateness of the missive came because of a mistake at Number 10. They assumed that Cook would be speaking after 3pm, the usual time for major debates to start in the Commons.

But last week was a 'constituency week', meaning that Parliament closes early to allow MPs time to get back to their seats. The early closure means that all debates are brought forward.

As he rose to his feet and with his original speech in front of him, Cook knew he would have to think quickly. He hadn't even seen the Mansion House speech. How was Cook to know what might sound like a split? He desperately scanned forward through his words, deciding to cut any sections that could be picked upon as being too Euro-enthusiast.

On page 2, half way down, came the line: 'At that point [2002] Britain could be the only member state outside the euro zone.' Cook skipped it.

It began in April when Peter Mandelson made a speech extolling the virtues of the euro. The Treasury immediately briefed journalists that they were amazed that the Northern Ireland secretary saw fit to comment on an issue clearly outside his remit.

It was placed in the Financial Times to ensure the message was read across Europe. The one person who Brown can't tell what to do on the euro is the Prime Minister.

But just as the debate appeared to be swinging away from the Chancellor there came an important interjection. Eddie George, the Governor of the Bank of England, dismissed accusations that the City would suffer if Britain delayed joining the euro. The Treasury was delighted.

Some senior Downing Street strategists are becoming increasingly concerned at Brown's insistence on taking the lead. Number 10 is worried that Brown's more cautious line will create future political problems. If Blair calls a referendum his political life will depend on the outcome.

So the Government is caught between two stools. On Friday afternoon, in the fetid atmosphere of the Downing Street press lobby room, Alastair Campbell, the Prime Minister's official spokesman, arrived with his usual cup of tea in a Burnley FC mug. With him was John Kingman, chief press secretary to Brown, and representatives from the Foreign Office and the Cabinet Office. It was an obvious show of unity but it revealed the ridiculous position the Government now finds itself in.

This afternoon Cook, Brown and Blair travel to Feira in Portugal for the final summit of the Portuguese presidency of the European Union. Cook and Blair will travel on one plane and will attend the socialist leader's dinner this evening. Brown will travel separately, needing to arrive at a different time because of the Ecofin meeting of European finance ministers.

'There will be journalists everywhere and Robin will be constantly asked about the euro and he'll talk about it,' said a government source. 'And every word will be seen as evidence of a split because of the week we've just had. What a mess.'

Save the pound - for the foreseeable future Backed by: William Hague, right, Michael Portillo, Frank Field, the former Labour Welfare Minister, Business for Sterling campaign group.

Wait and see Backed by: John Major, when Prime Minister.

Pro-euro - but don't rush us Backed by: Gordon Brown, John Prescott, the CBI, Alastair Campbell, the Prime Minister's press secretary, Tony Blair (sometimes).

webTitle: Join euro now, urges car boss

fields.headline: Join euro now, urges car boss
fields.trailText: Britain can afford to join the euro now that the pound is nearing the psychologically important three deutschmark barrier, says one of Britain's most influential industrialists.
fields.body:
Britain can afford to join the euro now that the pound is nearing the psychologically important three deutschmark barrier, says one of Britain's most influential industrialists.

Nick Reilly, boss of car maker Vauxhall and head of the economics committee of the Confederation of British Industry, told The Observer this country should prepare to adopt the single currency and that the Government should send out a clear message that it intends to join.

His call echoed the verdict of the Monetary Policy Committee's DeAnne Julius that 'economically it could go in'. Reilly said: 'We can be competitive at DM3. The issue should be debated clearly. The CBI membership is in favour [of joining the euro]. We should be prepared for it.'

Although the pound has started to weaken against the euro after two rampant years and economists indicate that interest rates may be reaching a peak, industry is still deeply concerned.

Last week steelmaker Corus, formerly British Steel, announced 1,500 job losses and aerospace giant BAe Systems cut 3,000.

Meanwhile, motor industry experts warned that a further 35,000 jobs in components firms could go in the next two years, on top of 25,000 jobs shed since September 1998. Carmakers are increasingly buying parts from eurozone suppliers to avoid the effects of the high pound. The lost business to UK firms could total £3.5bn over the next two years.

Vauxhall itself is already reducing the British content of its Vectra model from 60 per cent to as little as 40 per cent. Other manufacturers have indicated that this was the trend.

Reilly's comments drew strong support from pro-euro union leaders.

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, last week urged the Government to be more posi tive about the single currency: 'Increased productivity will raise the rate at which we are likely to go in. It is very good news that a major employer is saying that productivity has increased.'

The strongly pro-euro messages from both sides of industry went out at the end of a week in which Chancellor Gordon Brown reiterated the Government's cautious stance, and cracked down on Cabinet rifts over the single currency.

Reilly urged Ministers to take a bolder stance. 'It is the Government's intention to have a referendum. Given that there is a good possibility that it will indicate that we should go in, we should get ready for it,' he said.

The car chief, who said he was expressing his views as head of Vauxhall, highlighted productivity improvements forced on British companies in the past two years by the strong pound.

But despite improvements of up to 7 per cent a year many companies had found it impossible to withstand the increas ing power of sterling, which outstripped their efficiency gains. 'We have invested hugely in this country, but it is difficult. The investment intentions of industry are alarmingly depressing. There is big pressure to close down capacity, and we are fighting to keep it going.'

Reilly added to the growing chorus of warnings that Britain's impressive record of attracting inward investment was threatened.

fields.headline: 'No bums or willies please, Derek'
fields.standfirst: With Derek Jarman's long-awaited diaries set to be published next month,  Tariq Ali  recalls the time they first met - looking out on a radioactive sea, discussing Ludwig Wittgenstein
fields.trailText: With Derek Jarman's long-awaited diaries set to be published next month, Tariq Ali recalls the time they first met - looking out on a radioactive sea, discussing Ludwig Wittgenstein
fields.body:
It was almost 10 years ago. I was producing films and documentaries for Bandung Productions and Channel 4 was still interested in ideas. I suggested four films on philosophy, chamber epics constructed around the lives and ideas of Socrates, Spinoza, Locke and Wittgenstein.

They agreed to four scripts on the spot, alerting me to the fact that budgets were small and that I could not exceed £200,000 per film. By the time all the other scripts were written and approved, we had already filmed Spinoza with Henry Goodman in the title role, but the commissioning editor had moved on. His successor was also enthusiastic but, for some reason, not keen on Socrates and so the old Greek fell by the wayside. They asked who was going to direct Wittgenstein? I was still thinking. Spinoza had been beautifully filmed by Chris Spencer but the style was naturalistic. Wittgenstein needed to be different, slightly surreal.

On an impulse I rang Derek Jarman in Dungeness. I had never met him before, but had greatly admired two of his films - Caravaggio and Edward II - from afar. After speaking to him that morning I went out and bought a copy of Modern Nature from the Owl Bookshop on Kentish Town Road. I read it in the office for the rest of the day and finished it the next morning. To my great surprise I enjoyed it enormously. He was much more than a film-maker or a gay saint.

I know the date I made the call, because Jarman recorded it in his diary. It was 19 May, 1992. His enthusiasm surprised me. He told me that he had always wanted to make a film on the philosopher, but had never got beyond the title - 'Loony Ludwig'. I sent him Terry Eagleton's script, which was definitely not 'Loony Ludwig'.

He read it and rang me back the next day. He liked it and wanted to make the film. A week later I drove to Dungeness and found Prospect Cottage by the sea. The garden was, as had been claimed by every visitor, a work of art, but my enjoyment was restrained by the knowledge that we were overlooked by a giant nuclear reactor. It was then that his illness really hit me.

Nobody else I know would deliberately choose to live so close to a nuclear reactor. Derek no longer cared. Aids would carry him off sooner rather than later and he enjoyed living on the edge. He grinned as he told me that it was so lovely to swim on a deserted beach. 'In the summer I often run out of the cottage naked and straight into the sea. It's radioactive all right. Friends have tested it with Geiger counters. Sometimes the reactor ODs and the whole place lights up. It's really sensational. You know what I mean?' I did.

We spent most of the day discussing Wittgenstein. He knew exactly what he wanted. No Merchant-Ivory nonsense. No English Heritage atrocities. Apart from aesthetics we simply did not have the money to make that sort of a film. It must be austere in keeping with the philosophy. Wittgenstein would record his life in front of black drapes straight into the camera. As he notes in his forthcoming diaries, Smiling in Slow Motion: 'The visualisation must mirror the work - no competition from objects.' He was sure he would make it work. He asked which of his films I had seen and liked. I named them. He laughed.

After a pause I confessed that Sebastianne (the film based around Saint Sebastian that established Jarman as a gay director) had, alas, not succeeded in keeping me awake. It was sweet lemonade, whereas Caravaggio and Edward II were much stronger stuff.

'Why did you make Sebastianne ?' I asked him. The reply was instant. 'There was only one real reason. To show a hard-on on the screen.'

We discussed production details and it was the only time on that occasion he mentioned his illness. 'You'd better put an extra director in the budget. The insurers will insist on it. His name is Ken Butler and he shot the best two scenes in Edward II when I had to go into hospital.'

He looked so well that day that it was difficult to imagine him in hospital. As I was about to leave, I suggested to him that with Wittgenstein he should shock his fans.

'What do you mean? What do you mean?'

'Not a single bum or willy. Let the audience have withdrawal symptoms.'

He laughed. 'It's a deal. It'll make a change.'

And so it came about that the only sex in Wittgenstein is one fairly chaste kiss on the lips exchanged between Wittgenstein and Johnnie. Today the controllers of our TV channels would insist on maximum exposure.

We talked on the phone over the next few days and then I returned to Dungeness, this time by train. We went, as he records, to have lunch in the pub at Lydd and talked about everything. There was no God, there were no ghosts. He was prepared for blindness and death. It did not frighten him. He said something which has always stayed with me: 'If you want nothing, hope for nothing and fear nothing, you can never be an artist.'

He hated the monarchy and savaged the honours system. He was very angry with Ian McKellen for accepting a knighthood and entering 10 Downing Street. I was amused, but not in the least surprised to note the following entry quoted in his diary. This is the voice I remember so well: 'Vivienne Westwood accepts an OBE, dipsy bitch. The silly season's with us: our punk friends accept their little medals of betrayal, sit in their vacuous salons and destroy the creative - like the woodworm in my dresser, which I will paint with insecticide tomorrow. I would love to place a man-sized insectocutor, lit with royal-blue, to burn up this clothes-moth and her like.'

I had seen a reference in Modern Nature (a book which contained Derek's reflections on natural history as well as his own and was so well-constructed that a Belgian producer actually staged it in 1993) to a trip he made to Pakistan, and questioned him. It emerged that his father had been a senior air-force officer in India and had been seconded to help establish the Pakistan Air Force after independence in 1947. Throughout the Fifties, Derek had spent part of the summer holidays in the Himalayan foothills in northern Pakistan. The Air Force had a special holiday resort in Kalabagh, two miles north of Nathiagali, where my family spent every summer to escape the heat of the plains.

Those were idyllic months. As teenagers we climbed mountains, went for 20-mile walks, played tennis, mooned constantly over the girls, trying desperately to draw them into our fantasies. There was a freedom in the mountains untouched in those days by urban inhibitions. The thought that a young Jarman had only been a few miles away amused both of us. He had not discovered his sexuality at the time and roared when I told him that homosexuality in that part of Pakistan was very pronounced. The more snobby locals traced it back to the Greek generals and soldiers left behind after Alexander's conquests. 'If you had shown the slightest interest, Derek,' I told him, 'there would have been a queue outside your cottage.'

As we began preparations to film Wittgenstein he moved into the Bandung offices in Kentish Town, with Ken Butler at his side. Scripts were rewritten, actors auditioned. There was always a very special place in his heart for Tilda Swinton. 'If only she'd been a boy,' he would mutter.

Those were joyous days. We were short of money. The BFI helped out, but not enough. Derek was enraged. 'They've just given X a million and we can't even get a few hundred thousand.'

He asked me to telephone a Japanese producer who was 'always good for £50,000 or so'. Takashi did not let us down. Still, there wasn't enough to make a film that could be shown on the big screen. In order to make it happen, people worked virtually for free.

During filming, we were all amazed. Derek's energy was staggering. He drew on all his reserves and worked 12-hour days for two whole weeks. Ken Butler was not needed in the end, though his presence cheered us all. Throughout this period, Arif, Bandung's in-house cameraman, recorded Derek at work. There are 15 hours of tape and I watched some for the first time before writing this to refresh my memory: the zest for life dominates.

After the film was finished we stayed in touch. I went to the preview of Blue , Derek's film tribute to the painter Yves Klein, laughing to myself as sundry celebrities whispered to each other in bewilderment. They couldn't believe that all they would see was a blue screen with a voiceover. Over lunch at a greasy-spoon Chinese in Soho's Lisle Street he discussed The Raft of the Medusa . He wanted to make a film based on the Gericault painting. It would be a film about death. The people on the raft as Aids victims. He wanted me to get a commission. I rang George Faber at the BBC who commissioned it without any delay. A script was begun. We used to meet and talk. A new biography of J. Edgar Hoover had just appeared which revealed that he had always been a homosexual and a secret transvestite. We laughed and laughed. I suggested that The Raft might take a surreal turn. We should have a limo surrounded by G-men entering the studio and Hoover in a stunning red dress steps out and orders his cops to arrest the director. I suggested it might lighten the mood.

Some months later I got a letter from the St Petersburg Film Festival. They wanted to show Wittgenstein and were inviting Derek and me to introduce the film. I informed them that he was dead and I did not wish to travel alone.

 Smiling in Slow Motion by Derek Jarman is published by Century (£16.99) on 6 July. To order for £12.99 call Observer CultureShop on 0800 3168 171. Wittgenstein is available on video; Tariq Ali's new novel The Stone Woman is published by Verso on 8 July

By the time all the other scripts were written and approved, we had already filmed Spinoza with Henry Goodman in the title role, but the commissioning editor had moved on. His successor was also enthusiastic but, for some reason, not keen on Socrates and so the old Greek fell by the wayside. They asked who was going to direct Wittgenstein? I was still thinking. Spinoza had been beautifully filmed by Chris Spencer but the style was naturalistic. Wittgenstein needed to be different, slightly surreal. On an impulse I rang Derek Jarman in Dungeness. I had never met him before, but had greatly admired two of his films - Caravaggio and Edward II - from afar. After speaking to him that morning I went out and bought a copy of Modern Nature from the Owl Bookshop on Kentish Town Road. I read it in the office for the rest of the day and finished it the next morning. To my great surprise I enjoyed it enormously. He was much more than a film-maker or a gay saint. I know the date I made the call, because Jarman recorded it in his diary. It was 19 May, 1992. His enthusiasm surprised me. He told me that he had always wanted to make a film on the philosopher, but had never got beyond the title - 'Loony Ludwig'. I sent him Terry Eagleton's script, which was definitely not 'Loony Ludwig'. He read it and rang me back the next day. He liked it and wanted to make the film. A week later I drove to Dungeness and found Prospect Cottage by the sea. The garden was, as had been claimed by every visitor, a work of art, but my enjoyment was restrained by the knowledge that we were overlooked by a giant nuclear reactor. It was then that his illness really hit me. Nobody else I know would deliberately choose to live so close to a nuclear reactor. Derek no longer cared. Aids would carry him off sooner rather than later and he enjoyed living on the edge. He grinned as he told me that it was so lovely to swim on a deserted beach. 'In the summer I often run out of the cottage naked and straight into the sea. It's radioactive all right. Friends have tested it with Geiger counters. Sometimes the reactor ODs and the whole place lights up. It's really sensational. You know what I mean?' I did. We spent most of the day discussing Wittgenstein. He knew exactly what he wanted. No Merchant-Ivory nonsense. No English Heritage atrocities. Apart from aesthetics we simply did not have the money to make that sort of a film. It must be austere in keeping with the philosophy. Wittgenstein would record his life in front of black drapes straight into the camera. As he notes in his forthcoming diaries, Smiling in Slow Motion: 'The visualisation must mirror the work - no competition from objects.' He was sure he would make it work. He asked which of his films I had seen and liked. I named them. He laughed. After a pause I confessed that Sebastianne (the film based around Saint Sebastian that established Jarman as a gay director) had, alas, not succeeded in keeping me awake. It was sweet lemonade, whereas Caravaggio and Edward II were much stronger stuff. 'Why did you make Sebastianne ?' I asked him. The reply was instant. 'There was only one real reason. To show a hard-on on the screen.' We discussed production details and it was the only time on that occasion he mentioned his illness. 'You'd better put an extra director in the budget. The insurers will insist on it. His name is Ken Butler and he shot the best two scenes in Edward II when I had to go into hospital.' He looked so well that day that it was difficult to imagine him in hospital. As I was about to leave, I suggested to him that with Wittgenstein he should shock his fans. 'What do you mean? What do you mean?' 'Not a single bum or willy. Let the audience have withdrawal symptoms.' He laughed. 'It's a deal. It'll make a change.' And so it came about that the only sex in Wittgenstein is one fairly chaste kiss on the lips exchanged between Wittgenstein and Johnnie. Today the controllers of our TV channels would insist on maximum exposure. We talked on the phone over the next few days and then I returned to Dungeness, this time by train. We went, as he records, to have lunch in the pub at Lydd and talked about everything. There was no God, there were no ghosts. He was prepared for blindness and death. It did not frighten him. He said something which has always stayed with me: 'If you want nothing, hope for nothing and fear nothing, you can never be an artist.' He hated the monarchy and savaged the honours system. He was very angry with Ian McKellen for accepting a knighthood and entering 10 Downing Street. I was amused, but not in the least surprised to note the following entry quoted in his diary. This is the voice I remember so well: 'Vivienne Westwood accepts an OBE, dipsy bitch. The silly season's with us: our punk friends accept their little medals of betrayal, sit in their vacuous salons and destroy the creative - like the woodworm in my dresser, which I will paint with insecticide tomorrow. I would love to place a man-sized insectocutor, lit with royal-blue, to burn up this clothes-moth and her like.' I had seen a reference in Modern Nature (a book which contained Derek's reflections on natural history as well as his own and was so well-constructed that a Belgian producer actually staged it in 1993) to a trip he made to Pakistan, and questioned him. It emerged that his father had been a senior air-force officer in India and had been seconded to help establish the Pakistan Air Force after independence in 1947. Throughout the Fifties, Derek had spent part of the summer holidays in the Himalayan foothills in northern Pakistan. The Air Force had a special holiday resort in Kalabagh, two miles north of Nathiagali, where my family spent every summer to escape the heat of the plains. Those were idyllic months. As teenagers we climbed mountains, went for 20-mile walks, played tennis, mooned constantly over the girls, trying desperately to draw them into our fantasies. There was a freedom in the mountains untouched in those days by urban inhibitions. The thought that a young Jarman had only been a few miles away amused both of us. He had not discovered his sexuality at the time and roared when I told him that homosexuality in that part of Pakistan was very pronounced. The more snobby locals traced it back to the Greek generals and soldiers left behind after Alexander's conquests. 'If you had shown the slightest interest, Derek,' I told him, 'there would have been a queue outside your cottage.' As we began preparations to film Wittgenstein he moved into the Bandung offices in Kentish Town, with Ken Butler at his side. Scripts were rewritten, actors auditioned. There was always a very special place in his heart for Tilda Swinton. 'If only she'd been a boy,' he would mutter. Those were joyous days. We were short of money. The BFI helped out, but not enough. Derek was enraged. 'They've just given X a million and we can't even get a few hundred thousand.' He asked me to telephone a Japanese producer who was 'always good for £50,000 or so'. Takashi did not let us down. Still, there wasn't enough to make a film that could be shown on the big screen. In order to make it happen, people worked virtually for free. During filming, we were all amazed. Derek's energy was staggering. He drew on all his reserves and worked 12-hour days for two whole weeks. Ken Butler was not needed in the end, though his presence cheered us all. Throughout this period, Arif, Bandung's in-house cameraman, recorded Derek at work. There are 15 hours of tape and I watched some for the first time before writing this to refresh my memory: the zest for life dominates. After the film was finished we stayed in touch. I went to the preview of Blue , Derek's film tribute to the painter Yves Klein, laughing to myself as sundry celebrities whispered to each other in bewilderment. They couldn't believe that all they would see was a blue screen with a voiceover. Over lunch at a greasy-spoon Chinese in Soho's Lisle Street he discussed The Raft of the Medusa . He wanted to make a film based on the Gericault painting. It would be a film about death. The people on the raft as Aids victims. He wanted me to get a commission. I rang George Faber at the BBC who commissioned it without any delay. A script was begun. We used to meet and talk. A new biography of J. Edgar Hoover had just appeared which revealed that he had always been a homosexual and a secret transvestite. We laughed and laughed. I suggested that The Raft might take a surreal turn. We should have a limo surrounded by G-men entering the studio and Hoover in a stunning red dress steps out and orders his cops to arrest the director. I suggested it might lighten the mood. Some months later I got a letter from the St Petersburg Film Festival. They wanted to show Wittgenstein and were inviting Derek and me to introduce the film. I informed them that he was dead and I did not wish to travel alone.  Smiling in Slow Motion by Derek Jarman is published by Century (£16.99) on 6 July. To order for £12.99 call Observer CultureShop on 0800 3168 171. Wittgenstein is available on video; Tariq Ali's new novel The Stone Woman is published by Verso on 8 July

fields.headline: Young, gifted and gabby
fields.standfirst: At only 22, Samantha Morton is already a veteran, with searing performances in works as diverse as  Band of Gold and  Jane Eyre.  Burhan Wazir joins her for a frantic night on the town as she talks about her baby, her breasts and being cast against type as a mute in the new Woody Allen film
fields.trailText: At only 22, Samantha Morton is already a veteran, with searing performances in works as diverse as Band of Gold and Jane Eyre. Burhan Wazir joins her for a frantic night on the town as she talks about her baby, her breasts and being cast against type as a mute in the new Woody Allen film.
fields.body:
She arrives at the house in north London wearing jogging bottoms and a sweat-top, her hair discreetly tied back. Holding her four-month-old baby, Esme, in one arm, she organises a bottle of milk with her agent, this evening's babysitter. 'I'll blast the bottle in the microwave, shall I?' asks her agent. 'No. Heat it up in some warm water,' says Samantha Morton.

I've arranged to spend an evening in the company of Samantha Morton, currently starring in Woody Allen's new movie, Sweet and Lowdown, opposite Sean Penn. 'Samantha would like to go out and do something different,' her agent had purred a few days earlier. What about a gig, I suggested. Rap band Public Enemy? Monday? The agent agreed: 'That sounds great. We'll have a car take you.'

On Monday morning, the schedule changes. 'Samantha would like to meet at a pub near her house,' announces the agent, hinting at a non-negotiable contract. 'Can you be there for half-seven?' I agree. The telephone rings again at nearly 5pm: 'Er, Sam wants to do something else now. One of her friends is appearing at Rada. Can you get here for 6.15?'

I turn up at the house, scowling wildly. But as I sit swilling my tea in the kitchen, it's hard not to feel admiration for her. Juggling her child from arm to arm, she apologises for the change of venue. 'I feel so guilty. I'm really sorry about doing this. Ordinarily, I'd love to see Public Enemy.'

I have spotted Morton's work over the years; certainly she triggers strong memories. In the canon of young British actresses, she has few contemporaries who can match her range and aesthetic individuality. Her breakthrough was a 1994 episode of Cracker, in which she played a confused schoolgirl who is seduced and later killed. It led to a variety of similarly disturbing roles: in 1995, she played an out- of-control teenage prostitute in the ITV drama Band of Gold. The critically acclaimed performance was followed by her much-lauded turn in Carine Adler's searing film Under the Skin as Iris, whose grief over her mother's death pushes her into a hellish spiral of self-abuse and promiscuity.

She has also hinted at a deeper variety in her repertoire along the way: in 1997, she took the lead role in the TV film Jane Eyre. And that same year, she beguiled viewers as Sofia, the feisty heroine from the TV series Tom Jones.

This month and next, she has two feature films on release: Sweet and Lowdown and the indie drugs movie Jesus' Son, in which she plays the confused girlfriend of local loser Billy Crudup. Directed by Allison Maclean (Crush), Morton's performance is bound to elevate her rank alongside that of popular American alternative actresses like Chloë Sevigny.

Both are intoxicating films and Morton, still only 22, excels at both performances with her little witticisms and characteristic vulnerability. She is, she makes a point of telling me later, painstakingly dedicated to acting. 'I'm very lucky - I get lots of parts offered to me. A few scripts every week. But I am choosy, otherwise I'd last only a year in this business.'

Her rise through the ranks of British actresses has been remarkable. Her parents, Pamela and Peter Morton, were evicted from their Nottingham council home as their marriage broke down. Her father moved Samantha, her sister and brother in with 15-year-old neighbour Jane Waplington, whom he later married after making her pregnant. After several instances of neglect, the children were taken into care - Samantha was sent to various children's institutions and foster homes. At 13, she joined the Central Television workshop for young people, moving to London at the age of 16 and becoming a regular at the Royal Court.

Later, she will fleetingly describe her life in care - which she has, until now, tried to avoid talking about. 'I don't want to moan about it; lots of other kids go through care. It gives you a special kind of confidence,' she says. 'You instinctively want to make the best of everything, work harder than everyone else. Success drives you. And then there's that special pride when you achieve something.'

It's an extraordinary circumstance she finds herself in. Last year, while she was only 21, Woody Allen, after being handed a video of Under the Skin, personally lobbied her for the role of a mute in Sweet and Lowdown. But the experience of working with Allen, she says, left her strangely dislocated. 'He doesn't give you much direction, not that it was much of a problem. But he's not the kind of person who throws huge tantrums to get what he wants. And if you're looking for praise from him, there's none of that either. You come in, give out your lines, and that's it. You can't impress him - he's seen it all before.'

She had a similarly unaffected relationship with her co-star, Sean Penn. 'He's not the hard-drinking womaniser he once was,' says Morton. 'So I never saw him off the set. We'd work together - and he'd go back to his family. He's incredibly professional, of course, but detached from his co-stars.'

On the way to the Royal Academy of Dramatic Arts, at its temporary home near the Oval, Morton rolls down the window. She peers up at the passing buildings, inspects herself for blemishes in the passenger-side mirror, then turns around to glare at me. 'I never got into Rada,' she says. 'I was too fucking shit for them.' Then she backtracks: 'But I wouldn't have wanted to go anyway - they have this habit of remaking everyone in their own image of an actor.' She sighs.

The mini-cab driver pulls into Rada's car park. 'Can you turn up that song a bit?' she asks. The driver fiddles with the volume control, and Morton starts swaying to a recent hit by pop group Moloko. 'I love this song,' she says. 'Don't you just love it?'

We walk up the ramp, and into the network of studios. As I stand nearby, watching her interact with friends, she periodically introduces me. Later, she will be scolded for screaming with delight on spotting an old friend from Nottingham, Charlene. 'Please, could you keep it down,' cautions an attendant. 'We have performances going on here.'

The play, The Accrington Pals, is a grisly drama set in Lancashire against the backdrop of the First World War. A group of twentysomething men has enlisted to fight at the Battle of the Somme. The play re-enacts the ruination of the conscripts in the trenches, and the skewed anxieties of the women back home. As amateur productions go, it demands rigorous attention - several audience members can be heard sniffling back tears.

In one scene, a male lead shuffles into the darkened studio, dragging a quarter-filled tin bathtub behind him. As the lights go on, he is discovered to be naked. Emulating a Norman Wisdom routine, he waves his penis only feet away from the audience. 'Booger, booger, booger,' he cries, then settles into the bathtub. Horrified, I plunge my face into my hands. Morton, however, stares wide-eyed at the actor, screaming her approval: 'Waah-hah! Waah-hah! Waah-hah!' It's the most gloriously disorderly moment during the whole performance.

You didn't tell me that was going to happen, I tell her during the break. Scots are incredibly prudish about nudity, I continue, we're normally found wilting beneath blankets and puffa jackets, even on the beach. Morton laughs. She's wandered back from the ad-hoc Rada canteen, her tray laden with two coffees, a slice of caramel biscuit, one Danish pastry and two sets of sandwiches. 'Well, I didn't know that was going to happen, did I?' she says. 'But I'm glad - something was needed to break up the seriousness.'

Scoffing down a sandwich, she's only slurped a few mouthfuls of coffee when the interval ends. 'What am I going to do?' squeals Morton, her arms scooping up her food. 'I've fucking bought loads of stuff.' She leaves everything with a member of the counter staff; her friend Charlene smuggles in the caramel biscuit. 'Needs some school-canteen custard,' she says, offering me a corner. 'Old-fashioned custard: you can't beat it.'

After the play, Morton, Charlene, her old drama teacher and a few friends head off to a local pub. Morton had left the building hurriedly. 'I've got to fart,' she'd announced. 'It's been bottled up inside since the beginning.'

Morton has hardly said a word about herself all evening, leaving me to draw my own conclusions ever since the taxi ride. Trailing behind the pub-goers with me, Morton says, 'You must have wondered why I was laughing so loudly during that performance.' You didn't guffaw at any moment that could have been deemed inappropriate, I say. 'Yes, but I was only laughing loudly because I was so upset,' she says. 'That was incredibly moving.'

She pauses, that unblinking gaze seeking an explanation, perhaps even validation. I refuse to budge. Seconds later, as if to contextualise her screams of laughter in the studio, she admits offence at the dramatic gimmickry used by mainstream directors to illustrate the terrors of war. She says, 'I thought Schindler's List was like war as pornography. That girl singled out in the red dress, when the rest of the film was in black and white? Everyone knows the Holocaust was a horrible thing: why single out one incident?'

It's around here that I remind myself that she's still only 22 - a virtuoso actress still precocious about her fame. Throughout the evening, friends - old and new - have been showering her with praise for Sweet and Lowdown. And Morton is intractably self-effacing when faced with her glories. 'So what are you doing?', 'I loved your performance in that play' and 'I'm so proud of you' are all the defensive rebuttals of a blushing student whose promotion to head girl has just been broadcast over the school Tannoy.

'I am proud of what I've done,' she blurts. We're only doors away from the pub. Fiddling with her hair, she pulls her sweat-top around herself. 'You might think that's kind of impolite, maybe even a little rude. But, yes, I have achieved a lot. And I am proud of it. I look at my friends, these friends, and they're still starting out. I am years ahead of them; I worked hard for it.'

In the pub, Morton skips over to the bar and buys a drink for me, as well as a pint of Guinness for herself. 'I want to stay out all night now, but I can't,' she whispers. 'I've got Esme to think about.' Morton is currently estranged from actor-boyfriend Charlie Creed-Miles, the child's father. She looks mournfully at her friends - all undergraduates unburdened by responsibility. 'The films are good,' she says. 'But I get no time for my daughter. I'm going to take next year off.'

The conversation drifts to Morton's appearance at the Oscar Awards ceremony in March: 'My stylist had a fit, and I looked like a hooker gatecrashing the party.' And her infamous garb at last summer's garden party at Buckingham Palace with the Queen - the tabloids had delighted in ridiculing her for wearing flip-flops. 'The Queen's a right stuffy cow,' says Morton. 'She got right up me from the minute I got in there.' She lapses into a vivid impersonation of the royal inflection: 'And wot doo yoo doo?' Her friends, crowding in on every word, listen and laugh cordially. 'It all sounds amazing,' breathes Charlene. And as she holds court, Morton asks her friends to visit her soon. 'Are you sure I can call you?' asks one. 'Are you sure?'

I sit at the edge of the table, observing this ancient ritual: a reunion of teenage friends. Morton takes a gulp of Guinness, then laughs. 'Oh my God, you haven't even interviewed me yet.' It's a little past 11pm, and my tape recorder is lying idly beneath her chair. 'You've had that on the whole time,' she says, accusingly.

The wheels haven't moved all night, I say. 'But you've not even asked one question yet!' screams Morton, her familiar throaty laugh echoing around the pub. Charlene giggles: 'He hasn't asked you a question yet!' Says Morton: 'What kind of interviewer are you?' I ask her: When have you given me the chance to get a word in edgeways?

'Oh my God!' she yells. 'You're right. OK, how do we do this, then?' She makes me call her a car. 'We can do the interview in the car, then.' Charlene giggles: 'Samantha, you haven't changed at all. Not one bit.'

Later, sitting in her flat, the clock approaching midnight, and watching her stir what she describes as 'builders' tea', I start to quantify her ambitions. Still in her early twenties, Morton exudes the kind of theatrical appetite normally found in the sweaty pigpen of politics. 'I want to let you into my life,' she had said in the car, on the way back from Rada. 'Spending time with me and my friends means you get to see what I'm about. I want to let you watch me in a normal situation.'

I initially thought it a naive but laudable notion: The Interviewer ravished with access to His Subject. Only, Morton has engineered all the proceedings herself: discreetly overwhelming all situations before her, then mocking my submissive silence. Merely watching her hop around a room, gladhanding her friends, is tiring work.

Still, she possesses a little of the coy but eager politeness indicative of most twenty-somethings. Moving around her kitchen, where belongings sit unpacked in boxes, she asks me if I'm hungry. 'Want some of this?' she asks, offering a bowl of grilled cashew nuts. I decline politely, holding on to my tea. She says, 'What about some lemon biscuits?'

Her gaze is unflinching, and makes me look away. 'I'm just anticipating the next question,' she says, softly. To promote her latest film, her press officer lobbied for an appearance on TFI Friday, leaving '15 messages' on Chris Evans's answering machine. 'But he never got back to us,' says Morton. She looks hurt. Does a non-appearance on TFI Friday bother her that much? 'Yes. Maybe I don't look like one of the leggy blondes that he normally has on,' she says. 'But I'm sure the audience would have wanted to know me. I would have made sure I had a good time. And it would have been nice for his audience to have someone as different as me on the show.'

She is, she says, periodically perturbed by her appearance. For example, she is currently fixated with the size of her breasts. 'I'm breast-feeding my baby at the moment,' she says. 'They're huge.' She sits up straight at the table, thrusting her breast out in the exaggerated femininity of Monroe. 'Men can't keep their eyes off of them. Look! They're bloody huge.' And she talks about her impish mouth, her limbs that flail like someone attempting underwater gymnastics for the first time. 'I'll never get a part in a huge action blockbuster,' Morton says. 'I'm not a purist - I'd do it. I'm sure those films can be fun. There's a place for them in cinema.'

She continues: 'Everyone wants to look their best, everyone has dreams of wanting to look like something else. But we are who we are. I saw Minnie Driver at the Oscars, and it made me sad. She's just so thin, and she's bought into the whole Hollywood mystique.'

She admits, however, that if it wasn't for Esme, she would consider relocating to the US - particularly to New York. 'They don't envy success there, y'know? Here, I was nominated for an Oscar, and it's done little for my career. I thought it would have opened up new possibilities. People are just too quick to take a knock at you. No one likes a success here - no one wants you to be proud of your achievements.'

The tabloids, in particular, give her a hard time: revisiting old family feuds, poking fun at her unorthodox upbringing and sniggering at her early successes. 'It does bother me,' she says. 'They go and speak to people who know me from when I was in care: that's a deeply personal thing to do. But my friends don't say a word; they never have. Other people do, and I get angry. It's my fucking life, y'know. Leave my family alone.' Morton gets up from the sofa, and slides over to a dusty tape player near the fireplace. As a teenager, she ended up with her brother's old hip-hop albums. 'Do you like Digital Underground?' she asks. 'I listen to all kinds of music, but I do love rap. When you've been raised in care, rap music isn't just about guns and sexism. They're talking about real things you can hang on to, problems of identity that you have sympathy with. It's not just about the music, with rap: when I was in care, it meant a whole lot more than that.'

It's almost 12.30am, and I'm still clutching the now-lukewarm cup of tea she's prepared. Morton is talking about herself in the informal, Gen-X way that makes me less an interviewer, more a sounding board. 'This is a bit like therapy - I feel like I should be confessing to all kinds of things,' she pronounces, munching on another lemon biscuit.

I think of all the characters she's played throughout her career - scorned and abused women who show unexpected moments of redemption. And here she is, so eager to please. This kind of confessional undertaking must be unique to overachieving actresses, I decide. Musicians, sports stars and politicians rarely display such candour.

But I'm still vaguely aware that Morton is steering the interview. She has yet to relinquish control. The friends are hers; the music is her favourite; in the theatre, she's on familiar territory.

'I'm really tired,' she says suddenly, stretching back and yawning. She grabs a sandal-shaped phone and calls me a taxi. 'Would you like some more tea before you go?' I politely decline. At the front door, she reaches out for a polite peck on the cheek, and this 22-year-old, ultra-confident mother says she enjoyed the evening out. 'Send me the piece,' she whispers, before closing the door.

I leave the doorstep and walk towards the waiting taxi. On the way home, I reconsider the burning ambition Morton leaves in her wake. Acting must be like plastic surgery: you build, mould and sculpt. Still, you're never completely happy.

 Jesus' Son opens on 7 July
