On the way to the Royal Academy of Dramatic Arts, at its temporary home near the Oval, Morton rolls down the window. She peers up at the passing buildings, inspects herself for blemishes in the passenger-side mirror, then turns around to glare at me. 'I never got into Rada,' she says. 'I was too fucking shit for them.' Then she backtracks: 'But I wouldn't have wanted to go anyway - they have this habit of remaking everyone in their own image of an actor.' She sighs. The mini-cab driver pulls into Rada's car park. 'Can you turn up that song a bit?' she asks. The driver fiddles with the volume control, and Morton starts swaying to a recent hit by pop group Moloko. 'I love this song,' she says. 'Don't you just love it?' We walk up the ramp, and into the network of studios. As I stand nearby, watching her interact with friends, she periodically introduces me. Later, she will be scolded for screaming with delight on spotting an old friend from Nottingham, Charlene. 'Please, could you keep it down,' cautions an attendant. 'We have performances going on here.' The play, The Accrington Pals, is a grisly drama set in Lancashire against the backdrop of the First World War. A group of twentysomething men has enlisted to fight at the Battle of the Somme. The play re-enacts the ruination of the conscripts in the trenches, and the skewed anxieties of the women back home. As amateur productions go, it demands rigorous attention - several audience members can be heard sniffling back tears. In one scene, a male lead shuffles into the darkened studio, dragging a quarter-filled tin bathtub behind him. As the lights go on, he is discovered to be naked. Emulating a Norman Wisdom routine, he waves his penis only feet away from the audience. 'Booger, booger, booger,' he cries, then settles into the bathtub. Horrified, I plunge my face into my hands. Morton, however, stares wide-eyed at the actor, screaming her approval: 'Waah-hah! Waah-hah! Waah-hah!' It's the most gloriously disorderly moment during the whole performance. You didn't tell me that was going to happen, I tell her during the break. Scots are incredibly prudish about nudity, I continue, we're normally found wilting beneath blankets and puffa jackets, even on the beach. Morton laughs. She's wandered back from the ad-hoc Rada canteen, her tray laden with two coffees, a slice of caramel biscuit, one Danish pastry and two sets of sandwiches. 'Well, I didn't know that was going to happen, did I?' she says. 'But I'm glad - something was needed to break up the seriousness.' Scoffing down a sandwich, she's only slurped a few mouthfuls of coffee when the interval ends. 'What am I going to do?' squeals Morton, her arms scooping up her food. 'I've fucking bought loads of stuff.' She leaves everything with a member of the counter staff; her friend Charlene smuggles in the caramel biscuit. 'Needs some school-canteen custard,' she says, offering me a corner. 'Old-fashioned custard: you can't beat it.' After the play, Morton, Charlene, her old drama teacher and a few friends head off to a local pub. Morton had left the building hurriedly. 'I've got to fart,' she'd announced. 'It's been bottled up inside since the beginning.' Morton has hardly said a word about herself all evening, leaving me to draw my own conclusions ever since the taxi ride. Trailing behind the pub-goers with me, Morton says, 'You must have wondered why I was laughing so loudly during that performance.' You didn't guffaw at any moment that could have been deemed inappropriate, I say. 'Yes, but I was only laughing loudly because I was so upset,' she says. 'That was incredibly moving.' She pauses, that unblinking gaze seeking an explanation, perhaps even validation. I refuse to budge. Seconds later, as if to contextualise her screams of laughter in the studio, she admits offence at the dramatic gimmickry used by mainstream directors to illustrate the terrors of war. She says, 'I thought Schindler's List was like war as pornography. That girl singled out in the red dress, when the rest of the film was in black and white? Everyone knows the Holocaust was a horrible thing: why single out one incident?' It's around here that I remind myself that she's still only 22 - a virtuoso actress still precocious about her fame. Throughout the evening, friends - old and new - have been showering her with praise for Sweet and Lowdown. And Morton is intractably self-effacing when faced with her glories. 'So what are you doing?', 'I loved your performance in that play' and 'I'm so proud of you' are all the defensive rebuttals of a blushing student whose promotion to head girl has just been broadcast over the school Tannoy. 'I am proud of what I've done,' she blurts. We're only doors away from the pub. Fiddling with her hair, she pulls her sweat-top around herself. 'You might think that's kind of impolite, maybe even a little rude. But, yes, I have achieved a lot. And I am proud of it. I look at my friends, these friends, and they're still starting out. I am years ahead of them; I worked hard for it.' In the pub, Morton skips over to the bar and buys a drink for me, as well as a pint of Guinness for herself. 'I want to stay out all night now, but I can't,' she whispers. 'I've got Esme to think about.' Morton is currently estranged from actor-boyfriend Charlie Creed-Miles, the child's father. She looks mournfully at her friends - all undergraduates unburdened by responsibility. 'The films are good,' she says. 'But I get no time for my daughter. I'm going to take next year off.' The conversation drifts to Morton's appearance at the Oscar Awards ceremony in March: 'My stylist had a fit, and I looked like a hooker gatecrashing the party.' And her infamous garb at last summer's garden party at Buckingham Palace with the Queen - the tabloids had delighted in ridiculing her for wearing flip-flops. 'The Queen's a right stuffy cow,' says Morton. 'She got right up me from the minute I got in there.' She lapses into a vivid impersonation of the royal inflection: 'And wot doo yoo doo?' Her friends, crowding in on every word, listen and laugh cordially. 'It all sounds amazing,' breathes Charlene. And as she holds court, Morton asks her friends to visit her soon. 'Are you sure I can call you?' asks one. 'Are you sure?' I sit at the edge of the table, observing this ancient ritual: a reunion of teenage friends. Morton takes a gulp of Guinness, then laughs. 'Oh my God, you haven't even interviewed me yet.' It's a little past 11pm, and my tape recorder is lying idly beneath her chair. 'You've had that on the whole time,' she says, accusingly. The wheels haven't moved all night, I say. 'But you've not even asked one question yet!' screams Morton, her familiar throaty laugh echoing around the pub. Charlene giggles: 'He hasn't asked you a question yet!' Says Morton: 'What kind of interviewer are you?' I ask her: When have you given me the chance to get a word in edgeways? 'Oh my God!' she yells. 'You're right. OK, how do we do this, then?' She makes me call her a car. 'We can do the interview in the car, then.' Charlene giggles: 'Samantha, you haven't changed at all. Not one bit.' Later, sitting in her flat, the clock approaching midnight, and watching her stir what she describes as 'builders' tea', I start to quantify her ambitions. Still in her early twenties, Morton exudes the kind of theatrical appetite normally found in the sweaty pigpen of politics. 'I want to let you into my life,' she had said in the car, on the way back from Rada. 'Spending time with me and my friends means you get to see what I'm about. I want to let you watch me in a normal situation.' I initially thought it a naive but laudable notion: The Interviewer ravished with access to His Subject. Only, Morton has engineered all the proceedings herself: discreetly overwhelming all situations before her, then mocking my submissive silence. Merely watching her hop around a room, gladhanding her friends, is tiring work. Still, she possesses a little of the coy but eager politeness indicative of most twenty-somethings. Moving around her kitchen, where belongings sit unpacked in boxes, she asks me if I'm hungry. 'Want some of this?' she asks, offering a bowl of grilled cashew nuts. I decline politely, holding on to my tea. She says, 'What about some lemon biscuits?' Her gaze is unflinching, and makes me look away. 'I'm just anticipating the next question,' she says, softly. To promote her latest film, her press officer lobbied for an appearance on TFI Friday, leaving '15 messages' on Chris Evans's answering machine. 'But he never got back to us,' says Morton. She looks hurt. Does a non-appearance on TFI Friday bother her that much? 'Yes. Maybe I don't look like one of the leggy blondes that he normally has on,' she says. 'But I'm sure the audience would have wanted to know me. I would have made sure I had a good time. And it would have been nice for his audience to have someone as different as me on the show.' She is, she says, periodically perturbed by her appearance. For example, she is currently fixated with the size of her breasts. 'I'm breast-feeding my baby at the moment,' she says. 'They're huge.' She sits up straight at the table, thrusting her breast out in the exaggerated femininity of Monroe. 'Men can't keep their eyes off of them. Look! They're bloody huge.' And she talks about her impish mouth, her limbs that flail like someone attempting underwater gymnastics for the first time. 'I'll never get a part in a huge action blockbuster,' Morton says. 'I'm not a purist - I'd do it. I'm sure those films can be fun. There's a place for them in cinema.' She continues: 'Everyone wants to look their best, everyone has dreams of wanting to look like something else. But we are who we are. I saw Minnie Driver at the Oscars, and it made me sad. She's just so thin, and she's bought into the whole Hollywood mystique.' She admits, however, that if it wasn't for Esme, she would consider relocating to the US - particularly to New York. 'They don't envy success there, y'know? Here, I was nominated for an Oscar, and it's done little for my career. I thought it would have opened up new possibilities. People are just too quick to take a knock at you. No one likes a success here - no one wants you to be proud of your achievements.' The tabloids, in particular, give her a hard time: revisiting old family feuds, poking fun at her unorthodox upbringing and sniggering at her early successes. 'It does bother me,' she says. 'They go and speak to people who know me from when I was in care: that's a deeply personal thing to do. But my friends don't say a word; they never have. Other people do, and I get angry. It's my fucking life, y'know. Leave my family alone.' Morton gets up from the sofa, and slides over to a dusty tape player near the fireplace. As a teenager, she ended up with her brother's old hip-hop albums. 'Do you like Digital Underground?' she asks. 'I listen to all kinds of music, but I do love rap. When you've been raised in care, rap music isn't just about guns and sexism. They're talking about real things you can hang on to, problems of identity that you have sympathy with. It's not just about the music, with rap: when I was in care, it meant a whole lot more than that.' It's almost 12.30am, and I'm still clutching the now-lukewarm cup of tea she's prepared. Morton is talking about herself in the informal, Gen-X way that makes me less an interviewer, more a sounding board. 'This is a bit like therapy - I feel like I should be confessing to all kinds of things,' she pronounces, munching on another lemon biscuit. I think of all the characters she's played throughout her career - scorned and abused women who show unexpected moments of redemption. And here she is, so eager to please. This kind of confessional undertaking must be unique to overachieving actresses, I decide. Musicians, sports stars and politicians rarely display such candour. But I'm still vaguely aware that Morton is steering the interview. She has yet to relinquish control. The friends are hers; the music is her favourite; in the theatre, she's on familiar territory. 'I'm really tired,' she says suddenly, stretching back and yawning. She grabs a sandal-shaped phone and calls me a taxi. 'Would you like some more tea before you go?' I politely decline. At the front door, she reaches out for a polite peck on the cheek, and this 22-year-old, ultra-confident mother says she enjoyed the evening out. 'Send me the piece,' she whispers, before closing the door. I leave the doorstep and walk towards the waiting taxi. On the way home, I reconsider the burning ambition Morton leaves in her wake. Acting must be like plastic surgery: you build, mould and sculpt. Still, you're never completely happy.  Jesus' Son opens on 7 July

fields.headline: Evil Brits are in town (again)
fields.standfirst: Hollywood knows what Limeys are for
fields.trailText: Hollywood knows what Limeys are for
fields.body:
There is no secret formula to making a big, successful movie. No one is infallible in front of the fickle box-office masses. But there are certain ingredients that seem to work. That chap Spielberg appears to know what he is doing. And any film that features a character called Skywalker will probably make a tidy sum.

There are plenty more must-have factors for the intended hit, depending on the genre. Now that summer has arrived and the year's potential blockbusters prepare to jostle for multiplex seniority, we can expect: big budgets; big stars; big special effects. And, of course, sneering, smirking deliciously evil villains with British accents.

British actors have always found ready employment on the dark side of the screen. It must be something about those cut-glass vowels that shout depravity. In recent years we booed and hissed at Ralph Fiennes in Schindler's List and Anthony Hopkins as Hannibal Lector. This year, though, the stereotype has reached new levels. Not content with erasing those resourceful codebreakers from celluloid history in U-571, Hollywood has packed its biggest movies with wrong 'uns from Blighty.

In Mission: Impossible 2, Scot Dougray Scott squares up to Tom Cruise with global domination and Thandie Newton up for grabs. In Shaft, Samuel L. Jackson fights back against the Man who is our very own Christian Bale, somewhat adrift in Harlem, you might think. But what the hell, he is a Limey. So is Sir Ian McKellen who bids for world domination in X-Men. While Nicolas Cage's car thief in Gone in 60 Seconds labours under a death sentence passed by Brit gangster Christopher Eccleston.

The lesser-known Jason Isaacs stars as Mel Gibson's evil nemesis in the American Revolution epic The Patriot. Even Isaacs was taken aback by his character's villainous ways. 'I don't think I've ever seen anybody as evil as I am,' he remarked. 'I kill everything in my path. I think I cross every boundary known to man.' Oh dear, public school hubris rears its ugly head again.

webTitle: Geeks to shine on the silver screen?

fields.headline: Geeks to shine on the silver screen?
fields.standfirst: Hollywood producers are lining up to make the first dotcom film. But, as  Adam Smith  discovers, they are struggling to fire drama into the baud rates and IPOs. He offers solutions and suggests actors ripe to  play Gates and the gang
fields.trailText: Hollywood producers are lining up to make the first dotcom film. But, as Adam Smith discovers, they are struggling to fire drama into the baud rates and IPOs. He offers solutions and suggests actors ripe to play Gates and the gang
fields.body:
At first glance your typical dotcom success story is eminently resistible as a movie pitch. Boy meets net. Boy falls in love with net. Boy has brilliant idea of how to sell, say, broccoli and spanners online. Boy makes billions of dollars out of broccoliandspanners.com. Boy spends it all on brown loafers, ill-fitting slacks and bad haircuts. Boy still doesn't get out all that much. Rocky, it would appear, this ain't.

But if the realities, or at least the stereotypes, of dotcom triumphs and the newly moneyed people behind them are hardly the stuff of movie magic it's not acting as a brake on Hollywood producers intent on cashing in on what they see as fertile ground for feel-good storytelling. After all, these should be, they are no doubt reasoning, stories of rags to silicon riches: tales of two kids in the garage with Dad's old IBM and a great idea taking on corporate America at its own game... and winning!

As a result there is a plethora of movie and television projects in various stages of pre-production capitalising on the perceived hipness of the dotcom revolution. There are currently no fewer than three movies on the go entitled IPO (Initial Public Offering). An American TV network is pumping money into a reality-based TV show, featuring real net journalists setting up an internet magazine, that will be aired weekly, as well as online 24 hours a day. There are numerous adaptations of books and magazine articles about the early digital frontiersmen and women of Silicon Valley either in the pipeline or on the video shelf (the most successful of which, Pirates Of Silicon Valley, is notable more for its casting of forgotten Eighties teen star Anthony Michael Hall as Bill Gates than anything else - we rather fancy Michael Douglas as Gates).

Best-sellers The New New Thing by Michael Lewis and the appositely titled Geeks by Jon Katz are all among the treatments piling up on producers' desks. There's a sitcom pilot entitled, natch, sit.com knocking around and an untitled soap project aiming apparently to bring Dallas-style glamour and sexual intrigue to the denizens of Silicon Valley. Baud rates and option issues presumably replace Southfork and oil prospecting. Apart from their thematic heritage the only thing all these projects have in common is that you are unlikely ever to see any of them.

'Making a movie about the internet is as ridiculous as making a movie about the telephone,' says The Silicon Alley Reporter's Jason Calacanis who is, in fact, making his acting debut in a movie about the internet. Calacanis is a twentysomething net-gossip columnist who regularly irritates the industry with his Silicon Alley 100 (a list of the movers and shakers in the digital domain). The movie he's in, however, is spiced up with road-trips to Las Vegas and dalliances with expensive hookers.

It's a world away from the pale-faced alpha-geek pecking away at his keyboard secluded in his office cubicle with only a Newton's Cradle and post-it pad for company.

'The Silicon Valley-type people are frankly not good for movies,' he said. 'They don't dress well and they don't have the same sort of style that the LA or New York scene has.' And then there's the fundamental limitation that the bulk of even the most interesting dotcom billionaire's day is spent in front of an iMac. Drama requires action and scenery more compelling than the odd trip to the water cooler.

Calacanis's movie certainly has that. 'Peter Sarsgaard falls in love with an erotic dancer and goes to Vegas while we're doing our IPO,' he explains. 'So you have this internet backdrop, this tension of an IPO going on and the CEO is checking out and hanging with a stripper. It's a screwed-up love story with the internet as the backdrop.' All of which of course sounds dreadful (we'll know for sure when the movie, directed by Wayne Wang, premieres at this year's Sundance Film Festival).

But at least Calacanis has twigged that dotcom dramas, if they are to work, should use the net only as another kind of office against which office drama can play. It isn't the first time that Hollywood has had to cope with an emergent technology and got it utterly wrong. The most obvious example was the converse reaction to the arrival of television in the Fifties which sent the studio bosses into panic. The flickering eye that was rapidly appearing in the corner of every American living room was either ignored or rubbished.

It would be decades until televisions appeared as set dressing let alone as the subject of movies. Hollywood's nervousness about the new medium's potential for keeping punters in their armchairs and out of cinema seats persisted right up to the Seventies and Eighties with TV unfriendly films such as Network and Videodrome. Even in the Nineties movies like EdTV and The Truman Show continued the trend. But unlike the tube the internet was and is seen not as a rival but as an untapped subject for blockbusters and therefore an untapped revenue stream - the thing that gives studio executives sleepless nights.

The misguided attempts to weave the internet into movie scripts commenced almost as soon as the medium filtered into the public consciousness in the early Nineties. The Net, a cyber-thriller starring Sandra Bullock, floundered at the box-office in 1995, as did Hackers, a digital crime caper. The Lawnmower Man, proudly touted in 1992 as 'the world's first virtual reality movie', was awful, delivered in prosaic two dimensions.

One screenwriter, who prefers to remain anonymous, remembers penning a sequel to a low-budget horror movie in 1993. 'The thing was about an amorphous blob that was attacking New York,' he said. 'Two-thirds of the way through we got a call from the producer saying that there had to be "more internet" in it. We ended up sticking in endless scenes of people typing in front of computer screens and it ruined the script. There are only so many scenes about NY cops being unable to use Windows that you can do.'

And then there's the small matter of the public's attitude to the new breed of dotcom millionaires. After all, these are not, for the most part, inner city kids battling their way out of the ghetto with nothing but a modem and a dream. When online fashion retailer boo.com went down the latrine earlier this year there wasn't dancing in the streets, but there was certainly more than a touch of public schadenfreude as a set of upstarts were very publicly seen to be taken down a peg or two.

The same goes for lastminute.com's less than glorious share issue. For dramas about outrageous success to work, the protagonists must be seen to have worked hard before they get their final reel payoff. And preferably come from an impoverished background rather than the world of public school and fancy surnames à la Martha Lane Fox.

The king of high-concept hokum Don Simpson once remarked: '[A character] needs to be way down in the dirt before it's fun to watch them succeed.' The public's feeling about the set of newly minted millionaires is that they've been lucky rather than skilful. Making movies about their stories is like making a movie about someone who kicked a rock and found a gold nugget. Or won the lottery, with rollover. And films about lottery winners have historically failed to hit the box office jackpot as in It Could Happen To You starring Nicolas Cage. 'The public's reaction to an IPO is jealousy and scorn,' says Po Bronson, author of net nonfiction best-seller The Nudist On The Late Shift (itself in the process of being adapted for the big screen). The theme to be explored is 'how do we like that person rather than hate that person because we feel jealous?' he says.

None of this is likely to stop the movie executives desperate for a little of the new internet cash to rub off on their industry. Perhaps part of their motivation is sheer gall at being joined by another set who arguably make their millions more by luck than judgement - and we thought this was meant to be the preserve of movie producers? But the pattern is more than likely to repeat itself. Next year's big thing is tipped to be internet phones. Brace yourself for WAP: The Movie.

'The public's reaction to an IPO is jealousy and scorn,' says Po Bronson, author of net nonfiction best-seller The Nudist On The Late Shift (itself in the process of being adapted for the big screen). The theme to be explored is 'how do we like that person rather than hate that person because we feel jealous?' he says. None of this is likely to stop the movie executives desperate for a little of the new internet cash to rub off on their industry. Perhaps part of their motivation is sheer gall at being joined by another set who arguably make their millions more by luck than judgement - and we thought this was meant to be the preserve of movie producers? But the pattern is more than likely to repeat itself. Next year's big thing is tipped to be internet phones. Brace yourself for WAP: The Movie.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: A frothy and frivolous debut from India Knight, plus The Story Begins, The Blue Bedspread, Some Times in America and Losing Nelson
fields.body:
My Life on a Plate
India Knight
Penguin £5.99, pp247

Frothy and frivolous Knight's debut novel chronicles the domestic traumas of hapless Clara Hutt. Bored by married life, Clara yearns to recapture the heady mood (and slimmer figure) of her lost youth spent frolicking in 'GirlWorld'.

The quotidian obstacles she faces - an interview with an Irish dancer, an overbearing mother, the family hamsters nestling in the gusset of her knickers - do little to alleviate either Clara's ennui or that aroused in the reader by this slight, slightly entertaining fiction.

Knight's plot rambles around Clara's insecurities, finding humour in the mundane, and at the heroine's expense, before closing on a saccharine note despite - in fact, as a consequent of - a romantic trip to Paris for Clara and hubby that turns out to be anything but.

The Story Begins: Essays on Literature
Amos Oz
Vintage £6.99, pp118
Buy it at BOL

Amos Oz's slim collection of 10 essays is a joy to read. A spirited and erudite writer, he offers 'glances into the opening contracts of 10 novels or stories', from Chekhov through Kafka to Carver. Dotted with rhetorical questions, Oz's essays explore the techniques employed by an author to elicit a response from his reader, 'the contract enfolded in the beginning' of a story.

The essays are short and snappy, tinged with humour and beautifully written, particularly the piece on Gabriel García Márquez's The Autumn of the Patriarch.

In essence, what Oz aims to encourage in his reader is the necessity of finding the pleasure in reading over any compulsion to over-analyse literature, and in this he succeeds admirably.

The Blue Bedspread Raj Kamal Jha
Picador £5.99, pp228
Buy it at BOL

Raj Kamal Jha's enigmatic, anonymous protagonist sits in Calcutta at night, writing as the motherless newborn child he has collected from hospital lies asleep in the next room.

Given to understand that the baby is the man's niece under his temporary care, the reader gradually learns from the clues embedded in Jha's elliptical prose that his relationship to the child is more intimate.

As the man composes a fragmented family history for the infant, in which memories of incest and abuse render present realities intelligible and defuse the revelation planted at the novel's conclusion, Jha's India emerges as an atmospheric and sensual backdrop against which his characters move, distant yet sympathetic, cowed by life but never beaten by it.

Some Times in America
Alexander Chancellor
Picador £7.99, pp307
Buy it at BOL

Sometime editor of the Spectator, quintessential English gentleman Alexander Chancellor was the Washington correspondent for the Independent in the late 1980s, covering, among other diverting events, the Elvis International Tribute Week. In 1992, at the insistence of its editor Tina Brown, he took on the quintessentially American voice of 'Eustace Tilley' as editor of the Talk of the Town column at the eccentric, vicissitudinous New Yorker.

From such experiences derived this drily amusing memoir - in effect, a collage of anecdotes that reads like a society diary - rich in observations on the quirks of America and the Americans. Chancellor's perceptions of New York may be self-confessedly 'poignantly unoriginal' but as a whole Some Times in America is charming and idiosyncratic.

Losing Nelson
Barry Unsworth
Penguin £6.99, pp313

'I was Horatio's other self, the shadow side, the reverse of the medal, I could not lose him without losing myself,' insists Charles Cleasby, the obsessive protagonist of Barry Unsworth's latest tragic and sinister study of corrosive hero worship.

In his dank basement, Charles, a monomaniacal loner cautioned by his late father never to show his emotions, teeters on the cusp of madness as he re-enacts Lord Horatio Nelson's battles, described in minute, vivid detail.

But when Miss Lily, the secretary typing his book on Nelson, questions his idol's integrity, Charles begins to doubt the admiral, and thus his own fragile existence.

As Unsworth's deliberative character portrait accelerates towards its dramatic denouement, Charles finally escapes his hero's orbit, but at a cost to the last remaining shreds of his sanity.

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: With an unprecedented level of access Sampson has completed a comprehensive and masterful study of one of the greats of the 20th century
fields.body:
Mandela - The Authorised Biography
Anthony Sampson
HarperCollins £9.99 pp676
Buy it at BOL

He is one of the most important figures of the twentieth century - a man whose life spanned most of the past century and who now acts as a beacon for the conduct of statecraft for the next.

Nelson Mandela will be 82 next month and though no longer President of South Africa his voice resonates still throughout the country and beyond into Africa as a whole, providing hope for the troubled continent.

From his roots in the countryside of the Transkei, Mandela became a lawyer in the Fifties. In any normal country, a successful career would have beckoned.

But this was South Africa under apartheid and it would not tolerate a man like Mandela, throwing him into jail for 27 years. This was also the country and time of Anthony Sampson who, after leaving Oxford in 1951, went to Johannesburg and became editor of the black magazine Drum before joining The Observer for which he covered Mandela's trial in 1964.

Sampson came to know Mandela well and his close relationship with him made him the ideal writer of a biography to which the by-now President of the new apartheid-free South Africa gave his blessing.

With unprecedented access to Mandela himself, his letters written in jail and interviews with colleagues, friends and family, Sampson has completed a comprehensive and masterful insight into the private and public personae of his subject.

Biography can be a fickle friend of history, with its singular viewpoint. But to know the man as well as the message is important if we are to understand the South Africa of the past decade. Through Sampson we can do just that.

fields.headline: Children's Choice
fields.trailText: When Michael is washed overboard in a storm he finds himself on an island with a mysterious benign presence
fields.body:
Kensuke's Choice
Michael Morpugo
Mammoth £4.99, pp165

This terrific adventure story has just won the Children's Book Award - and deservedly so. Kensuke's Kingdom (with illustrations by Michael Foreman) is a well-told and original story which would appeal to boys and girls of 10-up.

The 11-year-old narrator, Michael, is sailing round the world with his parents. All goes well until they head into the Coral Sea off the north-east coast of Australia. Michael falls overboard in a storm and is washed up on an island. Tormented by hunger and thirst, he discovers food and water left for him. His benefactor remains a mystery But when Michael tries to light a fire to attract attention, Kensuke reveals himself. He is an elderly Japanese man - sole survivor of a ship that went down in the Second World War. He is determined not to return to the outside world, while Michael wants nothing more than to be reunited with his family.

The story of the deep bond that slowly forms between them and of the increasing conflict between their interests is beautifully plotted and described. Exciting and thought-provoking. And a good jumping-off point for talking to children about recent history.

fields.headline: A god of small things
fields.standfirst: The plot of Amit Chaudhuri's A New World might seem slight, but he is a master miniaturist
fields.trailText: The plot of Amit Chaudhuri's A New World might seem slight, but he is a master miniaturist
fields.body:
A New World
Amit Chaudhuri
Picador £12.99, pp208
Buy it at BOL

Amit Chaudhuri in what he calls the 'swamp heat' of Calcutta, but his writing is cool, almost air-conditioned. In three previous short novels, over the past decade, he has marked out a special territory for himself among Indian writers, as the natural heir to R.K. Narayan.

His books have none of the exclamatory playfulness of Rushdie, nor the compendious narrative drive of Vikram Seth or Amitav Ghosh. If great social shifts occur in his fiction, we hear about them from a tremendous distance and in passing: history is hearsay; if there are grand passions, only the anecdotal ghosts of them trouble the atmosphere of his prose. In some senses, Chaudhuri writes about the space between novels - and yet he has as much of life in each of his books as many of his contemporaries will capture in a career.

A New World does not offer much for the blurbist in terms of a plot summary. Even the most resourceful publishing PR would be struggling to gush over a precis that might read: 'An Indian lecturer in economics at an American university, recently separated from his wife, returns home to Calcutta for a few weeks' holiday with his son; he stays with his parents, who are retired.'

Chaudhuri's previous books, recently collected in one volume as A Freedom Song, were similarly lacking in potential for hype: 'Schoolboy from Bombay details his holiday in Calcutta'; 'Indian student at Oxford muses on his casual desire for fellow undergraduates'; 'Calcutta family fails to put on a play'.

In his first novel, A Strange and Sublime Address, his young narrator imagined writing a story about his impressions of his city, but feared that 'the story would never be a satisfying one, because the writer, like Sandeep, would be too caught up jotting down the irrelevancies and digressions that make up lives, and the life of a city, rather than a good story - till the reader would shout, "Come to the point".'

In this 'jotting of irrelevancies and digressions' and in his refusal to 'come to the point' lie the pleasures of Chaudhuri's writing: the absolute clarity of his phrasing, the perfectly mimicked rhythm of a conversation, the careful placing of a verb or a comma and, above all, his spare and truthful rendering of the subtle mechanics of close human relationships.

To some extent, all of Chaudhuri's characters are dangling men, caught between worlds and between lives. Jayojit, the economist in A New World, arrives in Calcutta already at one remove from his existence. His wife of 11 years has left him (in favour, we later learn, of her gynaecologist) and he 'hadn't felt desire in a long time'; when their son, Bonny, had been born, 'there had been a cutting off of sexuality' and it hasn't returned.

If Jayojit feels inured to his body, he reinforces that disjunction by refusing to immerse himself in his native city's more corporeal pleasures: he is not ready to take on Calcutta's food - he is careful about what his mother is feeding him; won't buy from the street vendors; checks that his water is boiled - or its traffic; he walks rather than risk a car. And he keeps himself brand-name clean by going into a chemist to order his Colgate toothpaste and his Dove soap and his Pond's talc.

The closest he gets to real interaction with Calcutta are the little trips he makes to the bank where he quietly imagines flirtations with the tellers. Otherwise, the city's teeming voices are like the sound of televisions from neighbouring flats, a 'form of public dreaming'.

And if Jayojit no longer feels at home in India, he also is estranged from his adoptive America. When he thinks of his life there, what comes to mind is wandering the aisles of a chill supermarket hoping to bump into an acquaintance. Though he hardly begins to acknowledge it, all the ties that once bound him to an identity are thus broken or frayed, and the novel charts his minute progress in trying to re-establish a workable sense of himself.

To this end, Chaudhuri employs sentences to capture the fragile syntax that might hold a life together. The many minor dislocations that attend Jayojit's homecoming, for example, are cast in stubborn elbows of clauses such as that which describes him greeting his mother, who can scarce believe he has made it back: '"Yes, ma," he said jovially, and bent his big body to touch, in one of those awkward but anachronistic gestures that defined his family, her feet.'

There is a Bengali habit of fathers calling their sons 'dadu'. Using this colloquial inversion, Chaudhuri examines the insecurities of Jayojit's relationship with his father, a retired naval officer, and with his son, who keeps him human. Neither relationship is a simple one: Jayojit's father is somewhat impoverished in his retirement, and clings to some of the formal grandeur of his old life, while his son is only beginning to come to terms with the fact of his parents' separation. Chaudhuri has always written with acuity about children, and he brings to life the tenderness and mutual dependency of Jayojit's relationship with his son through pure physical observation.

At times, reading some of these passages, you can be reminded of reading Joyce's Dubliners for the first time, where every sentence can seem a small act of beauty. The wider world rarely impinges on these everyday epiphanies. When it does, it is through Jayojit's occasional fretting about his own investments or his father's precarious finances.

There was a time when Jayojit's advice had been sought by the government as it prepared liberal economic reforms. For all his understanding of 'global trends' and 'third-world markets', however, Joyojit's macro-economics seems sublimely irrelevant to the minute reality of the new, market-driven economy, the question of whether, as his father wonders, 'it's easier - and cheaper - to have what's-her-name do the washing than to buy a washing-machine', or how his pension might best be invested.

But incrementally, such transactions reveal that 'even the - no especially the - free-market economy is held together by tiny rules more subtly graded than the caste system' - and as Chaudhuri teases out some of these 'tiny rules' he offers a glimpse of the ways global changes stealthily affect single marginal lives.

In the past, the author has explained how he has adopted a kind of Wordsworthian approach to his writing. If he has an idea for his novel, he does nothing with it for a month or so. 'If the idea still stays,' he says, 'it's worth writing about.' It is perhaps this kind of attentiveness to the quality of emotion that gives the miniaturist dramas he describes their affective force. Browsing in a bookshop at one point, Jayojit weighs in his hands some novels by younger Indian writers: 'They not only look light, they feel lightweight as well,' he says. Don't be fooled.

webTitle: Fancy a night on the tiles (and the chimneys)?

fields.headline: Fancy a night on the tiles (and the chimneys)?
fields.standfirst: Barbara Vine builds an urban narrative out of pediments and architraves in Grasshopper
fields.trailText: Barbara Vine builds an urban narrative out of pediments and architraves in Grasshopper
fields.body:
Grasshopper
Barbara Vine
Viking £16.99, pp416
Buy it at BOL

They are the sort of barmy, half-formed questions that pose themselves to anyone who walks around a city alone: 'I wonder who lives all the way down there? Would it be possible to get from here to there without touching the ground? What kind of things go on in a room like that?'

For most of us such silly, visual meanderings have their beginning and end in the moment it takes to think them. Not for Barbara Vine, aka Ruth Rendell. In her hands they are the foundations of an urban narrative - a vertiginous construction which is designed to perturb and scare.

In fact, in this, the tenth in a line of psychological thrillers from Vine, it is not vertigo at all, but rather claustrophobia that drives the plot. Clodagh, is a chronic sufferer and cannot bear to be confined in a small spaces. When the story opens she has been sent to live in London to try to forget the tragic and somewhat inevitable consequences of an electricity pylon-climbing accident.

Depressed and vulnerable, she drops out of college and embarks upon a series of sky-line adventures by scaling the rooftops of the mansion blocks around her new home in fashionable north-west London. Her strange, high-level existence is a form of therapy. It affords Clodagh and her group of friends a fresh perspective on life in the city, but one that soon shows them more than they wanted to know.

Grasshopper - so titled in reference to the insect-like pylons of Clodagh's misspent youth - appears at first to be a book about surviving trauma and reinventing yourself. Actually, though, the transformations of circumstance it chronicles are mere devices used to keep the reader guessing.

So, like the Wexford novels of Vine's alter ego, this story is a detective investigation. The reader is deliberately held at arm's length from the facts by the jumpy timeframe and Clodagh herself, who tells the story, is teasing in tone, frequently withholding key information.

In the manner of a much less worthy bit of romantic fiction, the real mystery to be solved is how Vine's heroine will finally find her true love. From early on we learn that she will end up with a husband, but we do not know who he will be.

Vine's great talent is in making sure that we care. Like all good storytellers, she concentrates on the prosaic details of day-to-day experience in order to soften up her audience for the unexpected that lies ahead. Every inanimate object in Clodagh's dingy basement flat is made quite tangible before we are then asked to go up with her into her Mary Poppins-like world of chimney stacks and slate tiles.

When it comes to the animate, however, Vine's touch is sometimes less sure. For instance, the personality of Beryl, a working-class cleaning lady who befriends Clodagh, is picked out in hackneyed Cockney phrases and she is at no time in danger of sounding like a sentient human being. Similarly, some of the young men in the story smack of the improbable. Guy Wharton, for example, or Silver, both of whom could have stepped from the pages of a Jilly Cooper. Other incidental characters are saddled with unconvincingly cheesy chat-up lines - such as Jonny's 'how about coming out for a drink with yours truly one of these fine nights?'.

What does work and certainly makes up for the odd shaky moment, is the intense sense of place that Vine creates. As with her previous novel, King Solomon's Carpets, London is a dominant presence. The novel is absorbed in city architecture and there is a gusto about the way each pediment and architrave is described. If some of the other imaginative mechanics are more transparently functional - I mean to say, a claustrophobic, reformed pylon-scaler who hangs about on the roof ? - it is not a fatal flaw.
fields.bodyText: Grasshopper Barbara Vine Viking £16.99, pp416 Buy it at BOL They are the sort of barmy, half-formed questions that pose themselves to anyone who walks around a city alone: 'I wonder who lives all the way down there? Would it be possible to get from here to there without touching the ground? What kind of things go on in a room like that?' For most of us such silly, visual meanderings have their beginning and end in the moment it takes to think them. Not for Barbara Vine, aka Ruth Rendell. In her hands they are the foundations of an urban narrative - a vertiginous construction which is designed to perturb and scare. In fact, in this, the tenth in a line of psychological thrillers from Vine, it is not vertigo at all, but rather claustrophobia that drives the plot. Clodagh, is a chronic sufferer and cannot bear to be confined in a small spaces. When the story opens she has been sent to live in London to try to forget the tragic and somewhat inevitable consequences of an electricity pylon-climbing accident. Depressed and vulnerable, she drops out of college and embarks upon a series of sky-line adventures by scaling the rooftops of the mansion blocks around her new home in fashionable north-west London. Her strange, high-level existence is a form of therapy. It affords Clodagh and her group of friends a fresh perspective on life in the city, but one that soon shows them more than they wanted to know. Grasshopper - so titled in reference to the insect-like pylons of Clodagh's misspent youth - appears at first to be a book about surviving trauma and reinventing yourself. Actually, though, the transformations of circumstance it chronicles are mere devices used to keep the reader guessing. So, like the Wexford novels of Vine's alter ego, this story is a detective investigation. The reader is deliberately held at arm's length from the facts by the jumpy timeframe and Clodagh herself, who tells the story, is teasing in tone, frequently withholding key information. In the manner of a much less worthy bit of romantic fiction, the real mystery to be solved is how Vine's heroine will finally find her true love. From early on we learn that she will end up with a husband, but we do not know who he will be. Vine's great talent is in making sure that we care. Like all good storytellers, she concentrates on the prosaic details of day-to-day experience in order to soften up her audience for the unexpected that lies ahead. Every inanimate object in Clodagh's dingy basement flat is made quite tangible before we are then asked to go up with her into her Mary Poppins-like world of chimney stacks and slate tiles. When it comes to the animate, however, Vine's touch is sometimes less sure. For instance, the personality of Beryl, a working-class cleaning lady who befriends Clodagh, is picked out in hackneyed Cockney phrases and she is at no time in danger of sounding like a sentient human being. Similarly, some of the young men in the story smack of the improbable. Guy Wharton, for example, or Silver, both of whom could have stepped from the pages of a Jilly Cooper. Other incidental characters are saddled with unconvincingly cheesy chat-up lines - such as Jonny's 'how about coming out for a drink with yours truly one of these fine nights?'. What does work and certainly makes up for the odd shaky moment, is the intense sense of place that Vine creates. As with her previous novel, King Solomon's Carpets, London is a dominant presence. The novel is absorbed in city architecture and there is a gusto about the way each pediment and architrave is described. If some of the other imaginative mechanics are more transparently functional - I mean to say, a claustrophobic, reformed pylon-scaler who hangs about on the roof ? - it is not a fatal flaw.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: This full cast dramatisation has a cracking pace and tremendous period charm
fields.body:
Have His Carcase
by Dorothy L. Sayers
Full cast dramatisation, with Ian Carmichael as Lord Peter Wimsey
Running time 2hrs 40mins
BBC Radio Collection £8.99
Buy it at BOL

'Where the carcase is, there shall be eagles gathered together!' cries Lord Peter Wimsey. He has rushed to north Devon to help his friend, Harriet Vane, solve a mystery. Miss Vane, the well-known writer of detective stories, had come down to Devon for a little relaxation, only to be woken from a doze on the cliffs by a seagull's cry and to find something 'really rather beastly' - the body of a man spread out on the rocks, his throat cut and his gloved hands still wet with oozing blood. He is quickly identified as the young Russian emigré who was about to marry a wealthy widow of mature years, much to the horror of her son.

So why had he cut his throat, ask the police. Or why, ask Lord Peter and Miss Vane, did someone cut it for him? Could this young man who constantly feared he might hurt himself and who had to rest in bed regularly, really be the heir to the Russian throne as he claimed? Gradually, they tease out answers to the clues - the encoded letters about Bolshevik plans, a distinctive razor found in the water - but there is one factor that 'spiflicates the evidence' - the time of death - and on this hinges the solution to the mystery.

The drama has a cracking pace with tremendous period charm: the cars with their imperious horns and caddish drivers; the 'Great Scots!' and 'all of a doo-das'; the Twenties dance music which ends each scene; the stereotypical Devon burr contrasting with the impeccable Queen's English. Surprisingly satisfying.

fields.headline: Perfect Cheek
fields.standfirst: Light romantic fiction is seldom as sharp as Mavis Cheek's Mrs Fytton's Country Life
fields.trailText: Light romantic fiction is seldom as sharp as Mavis Cheek's Mrs Fytton's Country Life
fields.body:
Mrs Fytton's Country Life
Mavis Cheek
Faber £9.99, pp331

Why Mavis Cheek is not as celebrated as Joanna Trollope or Mary Wesley is a mystery. She's got everything they have, in spades. If anything, she's an improvement on them, in that her sense of humour is wickeder and her literary allusions wider, as though Fay Weldon were the fairy at the top of her Christmas tree.

All Cheek fans (and there are many) have their own view as to why she has not made the top of the bestseller lists. My own theory is that the otherwise noble offices of Faber & Faber represent a sort of white man's grave for women writers. Proof? Exhibit A: Nicola Barker, recent winner of the £75,000 International Impac Dublin Award, is another member of the Faber stable only lately, after 10 years' highly original work, reaching a wider readership. Exhibit B: almost nobody has heard of Rachel Ingalls, whose earlier stories in particular rank among the strangest and most compelling I know.

Be that as it may, this book - her ninth - ought to be the one which gains greater attention for Mavis Cheek. Mrs Fytton has all the requisites to make it this summer's thinking-woman's beach wallpaper: jokes, revenge, an errant husband coming back to roost and a smattering of literary and historical references to make the reader feel less guilty for reading something so enjoyable.

The lot of the young, middle-aged, single (often reluctantly single) woman has long been under Cheek's microscope; no one knows the terrain better, nor examines it with more humour and brio. Mrs Fytton is a typical Cheek heroine, plucky and stubborn and sexy and nearly nice. Or, this being fiction wherein people change with an alacrity seldom found in real life, nice then not so nice, then nice again.

Society tends to turn its back on single ladies of a certain age, particularly when their lone status derives from having been dumped wives, as if one man's change of heart should be universally accepted as denoting that his former wife is fit only for her own company. Cheek has made the study of such women the central theme of her fiction and a continuing source of bitter-sweet humour.

Readers of earlier works will find themselves on familiar ground with Mrs Fytton. There is nothing pathetic about these women, none of the self-consciousness or self-pity of a Jean Rhys heroine. These are a grittier breed altogether, although Cheek tends to succumb to the forces of her chosen genre by instating (or, often, reinstating) a devoted and suitably penitent man towards the end of each book.

In the case of Three Men on a Plane, a triumvirate of suitors reappears in Pamela Pryor's life; in Pause Between the Acts, there are two (admittedly gay) men in the offing. Getting Back Brahms, thought by many to be Cheek's finest novel to date, begins with a jilted heroine and ends with (the capitals are Cheek's own) 'Excitement at the Scent of Victory'.

Mrs Fytton, who is generally referred to thus, in a tongue-in-Cheek homage to the Mrs Gaskell or Jane Austen-ish timbre of the story, has been a perfect wife ever since marrying her university sweetheart. She has helped Mr Fytton to build a flourishing business while producing two children and bringing them up in the old-fashioned way, by hiring au pairs and never asking him to change a nappy.

She has been the kind of wife who brings her husband a gin and tonic when he gets in from the office, asks about his day with genuine interest and never, ever refuses sex. She's the kind of wife every man wishes he had, until a petite blonde called Belinda falls at his feet. So it is that, at 40, she finds herself abandoned in Chiswick with two teenage children and a broken heart. A series of unsatisfactory liaisons ensue, culminating in a brief affair with an alcoholic German called Otto.

After Otto, Mrs Fytton, by now relegated to being the first Mrs Fytton, the blonde Belinda having been promoted to the Premiership of current wifedom, decides to move to the country. Once she is removed from London, the real comedy begins. Entirely according to Mrs Fytton's dastardly plan, the teenagers have a fit at the idea of living with her outside the city, moving instead into their father's newly decorated marital home in Wimbledon.

Once installed among the pale, brand-new soft furnishings, they behave as teenagers will: throwing parties, grinding pizza into the sofa covers, dispatching the fundamentalist Christian cleaning lady by showing her pornographic videos and emptying their stepmother's en-suite bathroom of its every unguent. Before long, Belinda can't bear it. Her soft, helpless fluffiness gives way to shrill recrimination; she refuses to have sex with her husband. All of which makes Mr Fytton feel more than nostalgic about his former wife.

Mrs Fytton, meanwhile, is doing what every woman who has ever moved away from London has to do: pickling, preserving and brewing. When she's not pouring vinegar through muslin or steeping wild hops in sugar, she gets to to know the locals, a brilliantly drawn collection of the lustful and the fraudulent.

If the major plot-twists of the story sometimes strain at the leash of the believable - character transformations and total reversals of intention were never so glibly arrived at - the supporting cast more than make amends. Mavis Cheek's fiction is entirely amiable; witty, sharp and vivacious.

Amy Jenkins, eat your heart out. This is how light romantic fiction is done.

fields.headline: When crime paid
fields.standfirst: Live fast and die young - a motto fit for The Enlightenment, as Peter Beaumont discovers in Con Men & Cutpurses
fields.trailText: Live fast and die young - a motto fit for The Enlightenment, as Peter Beaumont discovers in Con Men & Cutpurses
fields.body:
Con Men & Cutpurses: Scenes from the Hogarthian Underworld
Edited by Lucy Moore
Allen Lane £18.99, pp299

What is the defining image of eighteenth-century England? Is it that of Dorothy George's 'last old age of England, of solid, stable, rural England'? Is it the literary accomplishments of Swift, Johnson, Fielding and Defoe? Is it the dining-sets of Josiah Wedgwood? Or is it encapsulated in something darker - in the hanging fairs at Tyburn and by the lives of the men and women 'turned off' on the gallows.

In truth, the idea of Hanoverian England as England's last idyll has been rejected by modern historians who, as Roy Porter put it, have 'stripped off the civilised veneer of the "age of reason", revealing [that] beneath the perfectly powdered wig, emotional and psychological disorder seethed'.

By this appraisal, criminality was one of the grand themes in a society marked by corruption, violence and robbery, a rotten judicial and penal system and no police force.

But it was not simply a fear of crime that defined it. Crime was celebrated in a fashion perhaps unrivalled in any other era of English history. Highwaymen, housebreakers, pirates and prostitutes, especially the young and attractive, were treated like celebrities, although often the idealised version had little connection with the short and brutal lives of those 'turned off' on Tyburn Tree. But that idealised version, as expressed in hack biographies, ballads and ghosted addresses to the mob purportedly written by the condemned, captured the public imagination in the most visceral way.

At the executions of those who enjoyed public sympathy, like housebreaker Jack Sheppard, famous for his daring escapes from prison, weeping young women dressed in white like bridesmaids turned out. It was an attitude summed up by Mrs Peachum in John Gay's The Beggar's Opera of 1727 (itself inspired by Sheppard, one of the models for Macheath) as she sings: 'The youth in his cart hath the air of a lord, and we cry, there dies an Adonis.'

But of all the closely demarcated classes of criminal - from Strollers and Adam Tilers, Tail Drawers, Confek Cranks and Pudding Shammers, all specialising in a different kind of con or theft - the highwayman held pride of place. And of all types of criminal, as Lucy Moore explained in her previous book, The Thieves' Opera, 'the highwayman most clearly fitted the public's idealised version of an honourable outlaw... most obviously the accomplishments of the ideal highwayman were essentially those of a gentleman: horsemanship, courage, the ability to handle weapons well, wit and eloquence with which to disarm his victims, a certain insouciance, a sense of honour'.

The supposed effect of this 'gentleman of the road' on the morals of English gentlewomen was satirised in 1709 by Mrs Crackenthorpe of the Female Tatler, quoted by Moore in The Thieves' Opera, who 'mocked the fantasies of middle-class women dreaming mistily of being held up by a masked highwayman who kisses their sweaty palms as he takes their husbands' money'.

Con Men & Cutpurses is a companion to the previous book, which used the lives of Sheppard and the notorious fence and self-styled thief-taker general, Jonathan Wild, to examine crime in early eighteenth-century London. This time, Moore has collected a series of contemporary accounts to cast light on the way crime was seen, as interesting for what they say about the authors as for the criminals themselves. There is a strong whiff of hypocrisy about many of the accounts which glamorise the lives of prostitutes like Sally Salisbury or highwaymen like Claude Du Vall or burglars like Sheppard, while attempting a pious disapproval.

Perhaps we should not be surprised. For the drama of crime is the drama of 'us against them', the clever and charismatic member of the underclass who succeeds in escaping low birth to live like a gentleman, albeit briefly.

And under Tyburn Tree they made their exits as bravely as possible. For it was not enough simply to live a life of hazard but to go out as if life was an inconvenience cherished only by fools.

In this, the thieves of Hanoverian England showed an almost existential disregard for the cards they had been dealt at birth. Like social rebels of a later age, they had determined to 'live fast and die young'. The average age of those executed was early twenties.

It was a lifestyle summed up by highwayman Henry Plunkett: 'A brave man cannot want; he has a right to live, and need not want the conveniences of life, while the dull, plodding busy knaves carry cash in their pockets. We must draw on them to supply our wants.'

webTitle: All men are Nazis - even Jewish ones

fields.headline: All men are Nazis - even Jewish ones
fields.standfirst: While some feminists seek conciliation, Andrea Dworkin throws down the gauntlet in Scapegoat, her most radical book yet
fields.trailText: While some feminists seek conciliation, Andrea Dworkin throws down the gauntlet in Scapegoat, her most radical book yet
fields.body:
Scapegoat: the Jews, Israel and Women's Liberation
Andrea Dworkin
Virago £22.50, pp448
Buy it at BOL

Over the past few years, there have been dozens of books by women about the seismic shift in the feminist landscape, revisionist books, which see men as well as women as victims. Men are no longer the enemy, but fellow sufferers. The struggles and differences between the sexes are no longer a battle zone but a movement towards negotiation, compromise, partial success and partial failure.

Enter Andrea Dworkin with her dark and dismaying view of the world as a place of hatred, violence, deep and pornographic misogyny, rape, oppression, perversity, sadism, complicity. For her, there has never been a truce. All the social changes, she thinks, are grudging millimetres across the chasm that separates men from women. She is an unwavering radical. Like her or hate her, at least she is consistent, ideological, absolutist, alarmist. Her books - Intercourse, Pornography: Men Possessing Women, Life and Death - are confrontational and deliberately shocking. Men still hate women; sex is still inherently violent. It's war, unabated.

She has always been a pacifist, but she writes like a warrior, and now in Scapegoat, her new and most radical book yet, she lays aside her pacifism. 'I am an enemy of nationalism and male domination,' she writes in the preface. 'I believe that threatened people and individuals have a right to self-defence... I am a lapsed pacifist, I truly abhor violence and I believe that both nationalism and male domination are systems that promote and produce violence.'

This immediate linking of nationalism and misogyny forms the argument of Scapegoat. It is a book that has been nine years in the making, and which has been published alongside her own gruesome and detailed account of being raped. In it, she tells the history of the making of Israel and draws parallels between the Jews and women. Her sections are (often relentlessly) comparative - the chapter titles makes this absolutely clear: Pogrom/Rape; The State/The Family; Hate Literature/Pornography.

The politics of the Middle East are seen as a kind of prolonged macho destructiveness; the Holocaust is put side by side with the systematic oppression of women. The horrors of the gas chambers are more or less equated with some of the obscenities women have suffered through history.

The Nazi war against the human body is like men's war against the female body. The pre-Holocaust Jews, explains Dworkin, became known for their suffering and their spirituality. They were intellectual, sensitive, 'feminised'. After the Holocaust, it became imperative to make sure such a thing could never happen again. Jews had to fight back. Women, also equated with suffering and spirituality, also turned into objects, must fight back.

Women are the metaphorical Jews. Men are the Nazis. (Even, she admits sadly, Jewish men treat women as badly as anyone else, refusing to be victims by becoming tyrants themselves, thus turning Jewish women into an 'internal exile' in the Promised Land.)

Well, it's like Sylvia Plath said in 'Daddy': 'I think I may well be a Jew... I may be a bit of a Jew.' But Sylvia Plath said it in a poem (quoted by Dworkin) about female masochism and despair and rage: 'Every woman adores a fascist,/ The boot in the face, the brute/ Bruteheart of a brute like you.' It's her way of showing the murk and depth of her emotions, Andrea Dworkin says.

It is a book crammed with facts, with quotations, with an index and notes that occupy nearly 100 pages, with unblinking, unshrinking descriptions of murder and obscenity through history. She strides across the bloody, Jew-hating, woman-hating century, not just the facts of the Holocaust, but also the infanticide of baby girls in China, bride-burning in Africa, circumcision in Africa, anorexia in the UK and Britain, prostitution and abuse everywhere.

She discusses The Merchant of Venice and how it provoked Jewish murder; pornography and how it provokes female objectification and murder. She quotes Will Self, Disraeli, Vita Sackville-West, Amos Oz, linguistic theorists, Nazi diarists. Often the pages bristle with references. It's not metaphor, it's literal.

What should we do? she asks (Scapegoat is peppered with questions to the reader. These aren't expressions of puzzlement so much as a rhetorical throwing down of the gauntlet, pointing a finger: don't just stand there, act). Women should no longer allow themselves to be the scapegoat.

Like the Jews, they should become warriors, creating a female state (in which, however, they'd be kind to men, in a way that men have never learnt to be to women).

This Promised Land for woman, a land where women, having won the war, will lay down arms, is glimpsed only with difficulty through the barrage of scarifying pedagogy, of terrible words and terrible facts. It's a book that hardly breathes; there are no chinks of light, no room for doubt, no sense of ambivalence, no welcome for ambivalence.

Scapegoat 's power - undeniable, robust, fierce and steamrolling - is also its weakness. Its coherence is also its simplification. But that's Andrea Dworkin for you: a fighter; a pacifist (lapsed) doing violence with words.
fields.bodyText: Scapegoat: the Jews, Israel and Women's Liberation Andrea Dworkin Virago £22.50, pp448 Buy it at BOL Over the past few years, there have been dozens of books by women about the seismic shift in the feminist landscape, revisionist books, which see men as well as women as victims. Men are no longer the enemy, but fellow sufferers. The struggles and differences between the sexes are no longer a battle zone but a movement towards negotiation, compromise, partial success and partial failure. Enter Andrea Dworkin with her dark and dismaying view of the world as a place of hatred, violence, deep and pornographic misogyny, rape, oppression, perversity, sadism, complicity. For her, there has never been a truce. All the social changes, she thinks, are grudging millimetres across the chasm that separates men from women. She is an unwavering radical. Like her or hate her, at least she is consistent, ideological, absolutist, alarmist. Her books - Intercourse, Pornography: Men Possessing Women, Life and Death - are confrontational and deliberately shocking. Men still hate women; sex is still inherently violent. It's war, unabated. She has always been a pacifist, but she writes like a warrior, and now in Scapegoat, her new and most radical book yet, she lays aside her pacifism. 'I am an enemy of nationalism and male domination,' she writes in the preface. 'I believe that threatened people and individuals have a right to self-defence... I am a lapsed pacifist, I truly abhor violence and I believe that both nationalism and male domination are systems that promote and produce violence.' This immediate linking of nationalism and misogyny forms the argument of Scapegoat. It is a book that has been nine years in the making, and which has been published alongside her own gruesome and detailed account of being raped. In it, she tells the history of the making of Israel and draws parallels between the Jews and women. Her sections are (often relentlessly) comparative - the chapter titles makes this absolutely clear: Pogrom/Rape; The State/The Family; Hate Literature/Pornography. The politics of the Middle East are seen as a kind of prolonged macho destructiveness; the Holocaust is put side by side with the systematic oppression of women. The horrors of the gas chambers are more or less equated with some of the obscenities women have suffered through history. The Nazi war against the human body is like men's war against the female body. The pre-Holocaust Jews, explains Dworkin, became known for their suffering and their spirituality. They were intellectual, sensitive, 'feminised'. After the Holocaust, it became imperative to make sure such a thing could never happen again. Jews had to fight back. Women, also equated with suffering and spirituality, also turned into objects, must fight back. Women are the metaphorical Jews. Men are the Nazis. (Even, she admits sadly, Jewish men treat women as badly as anyone else, refusing to be victims by becoming tyrants themselves, thus turning Jewish women into an 'internal exile' in the Promised Land.) Well, it's like Sylvia Plath said in 'Daddy': 'I think I may well be a Jew... I may be a bit of a Jew.' But Sylvia Plath said it in a poem (quoted by Dworkin) about female masochism and despair and rage: 'Every woman adores a fascist,/ The boot in the face, the brute/ Bruteheart of a brute like you.' It's her way of showing the murk and depth of her emotions, Andrea Dworkin says. It is a book crammed with facts, with quotations, with an index and notes that occupy nearly 100 pages, with unblinking, unshrinking descriptions of murder and obscenity through history. She strides across the bloody, Jew-hating, woman-hating century, not just the facts of the Holocaust, but also the infanticide of baby girls in China, bride-burning in Africa, circumcision in Africa, anorexia in the UK and Britain, prostitution and abuse everywhere. She discusses The Merchant of Venice and how it provoked Jewish murder; pornography and how it provokes female objectification and murder. She quotes Will Self, Disraeli, Vita Sackville-West, Amos Oz, linguistic theorists, Nazi diarists. Often the pages bristle with references. It's not metaphor, it's literal. What should we do? she asks (Scapegoat is peppered with questions to the reader. These aren't expressions of puzzlement so much as a rhetorical throwing down of the gauntlet, pointing a finger: don't just stand there, act). Women should no longer allow themselves to be the scapegoat. Like the Jews, they should become warriors, creating a female state (in which, however, they'd be kind to men, in a way that men have never learnt to be to women). This Promised Land for woman, a land where women, having won the war, will lay down arms, is glimpsed only with difficulty through the barrage of scarifying pedagogy, of terrible words and terrible facts. It's a book that hardly breathes; there are no chinks of light, no room for doubt, no sense of ambivalence, no welcome for ambivalence. Scapegoat 's power - undeniable, robust, fierce and steamrolling - is also its weakness. Its coherence is also its simplification. But that's Andrea Dworkin for you: a fighter; a pacifist (lapsed) doing violence with words.

webTitle: Be wary. Europe is run by brickies

fields.headline: Be wary. Europe is run by brickies
fields.standfirst: Democracy in Europe, Larry Seidentop's brilliant analysis of the EU, highlights a lack of political vision
fields.trailText: Democracy in Europe, Larry Seidentop's brilliant analysis of the EU, highlights a lack of political vision
fields.body:
Democracy in Europe
Larry Seidentop
Allen Lane £18.99, pp272
Buy it at BOL

A thrilling, compulsively readable book about constitutional reform in the European Union? Come on, you must be joking. Yet that is exactly what Larry Siedentop provides. Compulsive, because brisk, erudite and full of intellectual fireworks. Thrilling, because he manages to recast the entire European debate, as endlessly rehearsed in slogans and mundane mumblings, and set it in a fresh context. He begins with what he knows best - the constitution James Madison and Alexander Hamilton wrote for the real federal superstate one hot Philadelphia summer 213 years ago. And from that perspective, the US experience, he asks deadly questions about the building of modern Europe.

Let's assume that the project is, in fact, about creating a vast federal state, because of the need for peace in this most ancient war zone; that the single market is crucial if you seek to be a big player in a multinational world. None of this, says Siedentop tartly, has any relevance to how that federation can be made to work in cohesive democracy. The confusion of means and ends is complete and potentially fatal. Where, after Adenauer, Spaak and Monnet, are the statesmen of vision who think about what they're creating? We are, alas, in the hands of bricklayers, not master builders.

Siedentop does not fear federalism, properly interpreted; indeed, balanced by a written constitution, a senate and other advances, it may be the only way forward for a fiendishly complex union which needs the diversity of its regions to find any human viability, government by consent. What he does fear is the Brussels of today, growing almost heedlessly as an extension of French centralism, a top-down bureaucracy which, in the end, must stifle consent.

The French (in his carefully constructed thesis) are the movers and shakers of the Europe we have. Their centralising élite was there at the heart of its construction, cajoling along a sheepish Germany; now, propelled by new apprehensions after the Wall came down, it is on the march again. What else is the euro and monetary union but the price that Paris exacted from Bonn for allowing German reunification? What else is the Stability Pact but a French gambit to muster a Mediterranean bloc to counterbalance Berlin, the Hague and Vienna? Why is the next European central banker a Frenchman? French nationalism does not quiver over political integration because it makes the rest of Europe more like France.

This isn't another Euro-treatise full of ghosts and villains. It is infinitely more subtle, an examination of frailties rather than a polemic. In spite of all its anxieties about the shape of Brussels to come, it contains nothing of cheer for William Hague. Siedentop is concerned with the quality of democracy, which must underpin any kind of democratic Europe. Britain, he concludes greyly, has nothing of such quality that can currently be exported across the Channel.

What made Britain an example to the world through the centuries was not its horror of written constitutions, but the natural balance of institutions - local government, the Church, unions, aristocracy - that curbed an overweening centre. That vanished with the old class system. Thatcher read the last rites for our social liberalism when she discovered market liberalism. In her world, and the world that followed, the law of the markets is absolute. If an economy works then, supposedly, everything works.

But even before the WI started heckling, we could see how false that is. People need a sense of identification as citizens, not just consumers. They'll need it more than ever in tomorrow's greater Europe of many surviving cultures and languages. Siedentop doesn't seek to suspend market forces, merely to say they are not enough; not a system of governance or a way of committed life.

Britain, before the stirrings of devolution, was out of this game. Prating about diminished 'national sovereignty' is not enough. France has discovered decentralisation, but late in the day. Germany's existing, slightly inert federalism makes it more of a bystander than a player. So what is this ever-expanding union? How will it find its constitutional peace in a time when constitutional change is, supposedly, the scorned preserve of the chattering, discredited classes? What would Madison and Hamilton have made of this pretty pass?

In short, Siedentop, a lecturer in political thought at Gordon Brown's unfavourite university, shifts far beyond the narrow trenches of national fear and asks, in the voice of a dispassionate outsider, what are we playing at? What is this project that even the French élite cannot explain to its masses for fear of irking the Germans? A secret vision is no vision at all. This is a book for every chancellery across our continent.
