fields.headline: Mind your peas...
fields.standfirst: Popular science doesn't have to dumbed down
fields.trailText: What is a popular science book for? Robin McKie thinks he's found the answer with Mendeleyev's Dream, Trilobite! and A Monk and Two Peas
fields.body:
Mendeleyev's Dream
Paul Strathern
Hamish Hamilton £12.99, pp309
Buy it at BOL

Trilobite! Eyewitness to Evolution
Richard Portey
HarperCollins £15.99, pp269

A Monk and Two Peas
Robin Marantz Henig
Weidenfeld & Nicholson £14.99, pp178
Buy it at BOL

Just how readable should a popular science book be? This may seem an odd question, one that simply invites the response of stating the obvious. Nevertheless, there is an important issue at stake here, as was made clear at last month's Aventis Science Book Awards, when jury chairman Lewis Wolpert passionately espoused the cause for making the genre more demanding of readers.

The biologist believes too many science writers are now running scared of complexity. As he pointed out, the public does not expect writers such as James Joyce or T.S. Eliot to be easy to follow. Indeed, readers positively relish these authors' intricacies, labyrinthine excesses and abstruse metaphors. So why then do we exclude science writers from such expectations, Wolpert asked. Why do we presume, with increasing insistence, that they - and only they - adopt the approach of the lowest common literary denominator and grind down the infinite subtleties of the universe to an easy-to-digest pap?

In short, science books should be written to produce as much cerebral sweat as do Ulysses and The Wasteland, a point exemplified by his jury's choice of winner - Brian Greene's long, dense and extremely technical The Elegant Universe (Vintage £7.99), an uncompromising treatise on cosmology filled with descriptions of six-dimensional Calabi-Yau spaces, orbifolding, and quantum foam.

And it is here that we reach the nub of the issue for, although elegantly written, the book is of such density and opacity it pushes the notion of popular science writing close to the precipice of incomprehensibility and leaves one fearful that it will only daunt, rather than attract, the uninitiated.

So it is worthwhile thinking for a moment about the purpose of science writing. This is a genre that is certainly not meant to be a seminal source of greatness, like Ulysses, although Wolpert's jury seemed to think this. In fact, the function of science writing is much closer to that of literary criticism. Both explain and analyse supreme feats of human imagination, artistic or scientific, and should help readers realise their implications. We should not make the mistake of comparing great primary works - the books of Joyce or the equations of Einstein - with secondary attempts to unravel their meaning. Making the latter more complex is merely adding an unnecessary layer of intricacy to the already vexed problem of understandability.

In other words, good science writing is very definitely about reducing issues to their simplest, clearest and most entertaining, a trend that should be embraced with relish, not disdain. And for demonstrations, readers need look no further than Mendeleyev's Dream, Paul Strathern's wonderful historical romp through mankind's attempts to understand the constituents of matter.

The story begins with the first Greek philosopher, Thales, who believed 'everything is water' (thus indicating he must have spent his holidays in Scotland) and ends with the life of Gregor Mendeleyev, the great Siberian chemist who dreamt of the idea of the periodic table of elements after falling asleep at his desk following a game of patience.

In between, we encounter a host of weird and magnificent characters: Henry Cavendish, who first made water from its constituent elements but who displayed such misogyny he would only converse with women by note; John Dalton, developer of the atomic theory of matter, whose admirers elected him to the Royal Society without his knowledge because his Quaker views forbade him to accept honours; and Antoine Lavoisier, 'the spirit of accountancy raised to genius', who first formulated the modern theory of elements but who got his head chopped off for running tax scams.

These were the fruitcake genuises who unravelled the byzantine nature of the elements and whose story is told with such wonderful panache by Strathern, culminating in the author's masterly description of Mendeleyev, whose Rumpelstiltskin temper, superhuman work effort and need to be mothered meant he was impossible to live with 'in any normal sense of the word'. His marriage only survived because his wife constantly moved house to avoid him, thus eliminating the pain of cohabitation, 'the ruin of so many relationships'. The end result is a witty, complexity-free confection that makes nonsense of the idea we need to make our science books more demanding and headache-inducing.

A Monk and Two Peas, Henig's biography of Gregor Mendel, discoverer of the laws of genetics, and Trilobite!, Fortey's homage to the humble fossil, also fare well by such standards, though both suffer from a lack of humour compared to Strathern. Henig gives us more than just a straight biography of Mendel, but a vital encapsulation of the importance of his work, while Fortey provides a real feel for the business of carrying out research, related as it is by one of science's more lucid exponents. There is not a single item of unnecessary intellectual baggage in any of the three books. Nor is there a need for one.

fields.headline: The war facts
fields.trailText: From the Iliad to Fatherland, no one ever went broke publishing a good war book.
fields.body:
From the Iliad to Fatherland, no one ever went broke publishing a good war book. In this genre, war stories don't come much more thrilling than the Bletchley Enigma codebreaking saga, a David and Goliath tale of plucky British intelligence overcoming the Nazi war machine and snatching victory, against overwhelming odds, from the jaws of defeat.

No wonder, then, that Robert Harris, a master storyteller, should have made it the subject of his engrossing thriller, Enigma, or that Hugh Sebag-Montefiore should want to explore the true history of wartime codebreaking. Enigma: the Battle for the Code (Weidenfeld & Nicolson £20, pp404) has the essential ingredients for a spellbinding war story: larger-than-life characters, nail-biting cliffhangers, murky, backroom in-fighting, breathtaking underwater drama and the clash of swastika and white ensign on the high seas.

Actually, the historical narrative that Sebag-Montefiore supplies is often rather more mundane than that. Although he acknowledges the spur of fiction (Harris's Enigma) as an inspiration, he quite properly focuses on the exploits of the unsung heroes of Bletchley Park - Gordon Welchman and Harry Hinsley for example - and the German spies, such as Hans Thilo Schmidt, who passed the key to the Enigma code to the French secret service as early as 1931.

And, of course, he returns to the tragic story (a sub-plot in the greater drama) of Alan Turing, the mathematical genius whose tortured homosexuality brought his life to a terrible and premature end in 1954.

This indispensable research (and Sebag-Montefiore's rather baffling 'codebreaking' appendices) unquestionably deepens and enriches our understanding of the Bletchley story, but it does not obscure the central fact about the activities of Hut Eight, namely that it was the cracking of the U-boat Enigma code - Shark - that neutralised the menace of the German blockade, enabling Allied convoys to outwit the U-boat 'wolf packs' and the Royal Navy to search out and destroy the U-tankers that re-armed the U-boats at sea.

Sebag-Montefiore demonstrates superbly that the seizure of the Enigma codebooks was, without doubt, among the crucial episodes in Britain's prosecution of the war. And also the most heroic. The scene in which 'Florrie' Foord dives into the icy waters off Trondheim to grab the canvas bag containing the Enigma codebooks is the stuff of war stories at their most gripping.

And movies, too. There is, as it happens, an almost identical scene in Hollywood's version of 'the battle for the code', U-571. Does it matter that there is not a shred of historical evidence to support the plot of this gung-ho American adventure story? I don't think so.

Thanks to Hugh Sebag-Montefiore and Hinsley's British Intelligence in the Second World War, the facts are secure. How could novelists and filmmakers resist such material?

robertmccrum@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Trucker is son of blues legend

fields.headline: Trucker is son of blues legend
fields.standfirst: Judge backs link to Robert Johnson, whose songs inspired world's greatest rock 'n' roll bands
fields.trailText: The troubled saga of blues singer Robert Johnson, poisoned at 29 by the jealous husband of one of his lovers, was reopened last week when a judge ruled that a retired truck driver was his son.
fields.body:
The troubled saga of blues singer Robert Johnson, poisoned at 29 by the jealous husband of one of his lovers, was reopened last week when a judge ruled that a retired truck driver was his son.

Johnson, a towering figure in twentieth century music who helped create the live fast, die young rock'n'roll stereotype, wrote the classic blues standards 'Love in Vain,' 'Hellhound on my Tail' and 'Rambling on My Mind'. He always said he had met the devil on a crossroads one dark Mississippi night and exchanged his soul for his talent.

Until last week's ruling by the Mississippi Supreme Court it was believed he had died without an heir. But 63 years after his death in 1938, the court ruled that Claud Johnson, from Crystal Springs, is the flesh-and-blood of a man so steeped in mythology that it is hard to say where the legend ends and the truth begins.

After years of legal battles, Claud Johnson should now receive more than $1 million in music royalties.

'All my life I have known that he was my father,' said Johnson, whose mother Virgie Jane Smith had an affair with the singer in 1931, resulting in his birth.

The musician visited Smith a year before he died. 'We were living in my granddaddy's and grandmama's house,' Johnson said. 'They were religious people, and they thought that the blues was the devil's music. People back then believed that.

'They told my daddy they didn't want no part of him. They said he was working for the devil. They wouldn't even let me go out and touch him. I stood in the door, and he stood on the ground, and that is as close as I ever got to him. Finally, he said, "Well, I might as well go." He wandered off, and I never saw him again.'

Relatives of Robert Johnson's half-sister have disputed Claud Johnson's claim, saying he only claimed kinship after Johnson's music became valuable in the Eighties.

webTitle: Kingpins of US crime clean up with Mafia.com

fields.headline: Kingpins of US crime clean up with Mafia.com
fields.trailText: The Cosa Nostra - pronounced dead after a sweeping crackdown, internationally and in New York - is back. Only now, the Italian Mafia is making a new kind of killing, moving into the dot.com bull market.
fields.body:
The Cosa Nostra - pronounced dead after a sweeping crackdown, internationally and in New York - is back. Only now, the Italian Mafia is making a new kind of killing, moving into the dot.com bull market.

The arrests of 120 men and women last week for the biggest stock market fraud in American history shows the Mafia has created a mirror-image of legitimate business on Wall Street.

The arrests spell out a chilling message: that although the established families of the Italian mob have been either wiped out or ousted from their traditional terrain of protection rackets and drug dealing, they have become more powerful and richer than ever by moving into the world of high finance. 'You have criminals becoming businessmen on Wall Street,' says Robert Castelli, a former officer in the New York organised crime task force.

Briefings to The Observer after the arrests reveal that the extent of the mob's slice of Wall Street stock dealing is even greater than that uncovered by last week's heist, and that Cosa Nostra families have formed strategic alliances not only with each other but with a former rival - the Russian 'Mafiya'. The indictments show that in moving from the criminal underworld into the financial sector, the Mafia has cast off its old antagonisms in order to form a bloc, cheating investors and reaping rewards worth millions.

'The main reason for the move into high finance,' says Barry Mawn, director of the FBI's New York office, 'is there's an endless pot of money. They can all make money'.

The indictments reveal that all five of the big Italian organised crime families in New York - Gambino, Genovese, Lucchese, Bonanno and Colombo - had come together in a formidable coalition to manipulate publicly-traded securities in 19 companies, cheating investors out of $50 million over a period of five years.

Court papers show a miasma of criminal infiltration of the securities industry, with the defendants in many cases aiming to exploit the internet boom, touting their front companies as dot.com players.

Some 20 defendants in particular are charged with a racketeering conspiracy. Among those arrested was 'Little Robert' Lino, a whizzkid accountant for the Bonannos, and Frankie Perisco, cousin of Alfonse Perisco, said to be the Godfather of the Colombo clan.

Officials say that the Mafia's quiet switch to white-collar crime and financial plunder began in the mid Nineties as a new generation of young mobsters, who were knowledgable about new technology and international finance replaced the gangsters and godfathers.

These young bloods within the old clans moved initially into three areas: health insurance scams, pre-paid telephone cards and brokerage houses on Wall Street.

The first lead towards this week's haul was the 1997 cracking of a health insurance racket run by a Mafia-backed company called Tri-Con. There were further indictments for 'loan-sharking' - offering loans to brokers in debt, then forcing them to sell stock before it became available to investors.

Sources in the organised crime division of the FBI told how the mob then established a network of stock promoters and security dealers in the all-important 'boiler-rooms' that sell stocks nationwide through cold-calling.

The authorities were called into Wall Street during 1996, after several traders and brokers were subjected to increasingly violent levels of 'persuasion' to deal in stocks and shares wanted or controlled by organised crime families as well as elements of the incoming Russian mob.

The mob's activities were confined, say authorities, to stocks traded on the 'bulletin board' of the NASDAQ markets, rather than issues through the New York Stock Exchange.

The prime mover in the Wall Street operation is the Bonnano family, which was believed to be heading for extinction less than a decade ago, after years of feuding with rivals and the ravages wreaked by then District Attorney Rudy Giuliani.

But the Bonanno family began its resurgence after the release and recovery of Joe Massimo, who seized control of the clan after coming out of prison in 1993.

Police sources say that Massimo's dazzling skills with computers and grasp of the financial markets combined with his close ties to the Sicilian homeland enabled the Bonannos to become the first crime family to crash the bull market during the mid-1990s.

Over the past three years, two of Massimo's men - Frankie Limo and recently Frank Coppa - have been indicted for multi-million dollar stock swindles.

The arrest of Coppa in March this year led investigators down an unexpected and disturbing trail.

He, along with 18 others, formed a cadre of stockbrokers who had cheated unsuspecting investors out of $40 million in an elaborate fraud scheme whereby blocks of stocks were purchased and artificially inflated by flooding the marketplace with misleading information.

The arrest showed that the Bonannos were making some terrifying alliances, and not just with former rivals from the Gambino family. Also indicted were two leading members of the Russian 'Mafiya'. Lewis Schirillo, assistant director for the FBI in New York, said 'they (the Russians) have the ability to bring in an international money-laundering angle, particularly with overseas accounts'.

The Russian mob have infamously penetrated the Bank of New York, whose former executive Lucy Edwards and her husband Peter Berlin were convicted in April for masterminding the largest money-laundering scheme in US history involving $10 billion in 160,000 wire transfers.

Sources tell The Observer that the alliance between the Italians and Russians was forged between the Genovese clan and the Zilber brothers, Vladimir and Alex.

The Russians then expanded their alliances to include the Gambinos.

fields.headline: Tax rebel weds at 36
fields.trailText: Scottish Socialist Party leader and former anti-poll tax rebel Tommy Sheridan took the plunge and married fiancée Gail Healy yesterday.
fields.body:
Scottish Socialist Party leader and former anti-poll tax rebel Tommy Sheridan took the plunge and married fiancée Gail Healy yesterday.

Mr Sheridan, 36, who long maintained he would never wed, married Ms Healy, also 36, in a traditional Roman Catholic ceremony in front of more than 200 guests at Glasgow's Our Lady of Lourdes Church.

Afterwards he said he hoped to meet the Cuban leader, Fidel Castro, during the couple's honeymoon in the Caribbean socialist republic.

webTitle: England's glory night marred by fans' riots

fields.headline: England's glory night marred by fans' riots
fields.standfirst:
Shearer scores in first win over Germany in 34
years  500 held by police after 'multi-national
mayhem'  Stabbed man critical
fields.trailText:
England last night claimed an historic Euro 2000
victory against Germany - their first win for 34 years in
competitive games against their arch rivals - but the
result was overshadowed by the behaviour of hundreds
of drunken hooligans who fought pitched battles with
rival fans ahead of the crucial match.
fields.byline: by Vivek Chaudhary  in Charleroi, Andrew Osborn in Brussels and John Arlidge in London
fields.body:
England last night claimed an historic Euro 2000 victory against Germany - their first win for 34 years in competitive games against their arch rivals - but the result was overshadowed by the behaviour of hundreds of drunken hooligans who fought pitched battles with rival fans ahead of the crucial match.

Alan Shearer, the England skipper, scored with a header in the 53rd minute on a night of tension inside the Chareloi stadium in Belgium. England, who now need a draw on Tuesday night against Romania to go through to the quarter-finals, were cheered off the pitch to thunderous applause and the strains of God Save the Queen.

English hooligans sank to a shameful new low, fighting with rival German and Turkish fans before the match. As politicians, players and the public last night condemned the scenes, hundreds of fans began arriving back in Britain in handcuffs after being arrested and deported.

At least one English fan was critically injured after running battles in the streets of Brussels and Charleroi. Riot police used water cannon and tear gas to quell the violence, which shocked residents of the provincial Belgian town.

The chaotic scenes - described by one senior Bel gian police officer as 'multi-national mayhem' - threaten to scupper England's hopes of hosting the World Cup in 2006. Privately, some FA officials said last night they would 'scale down' England's bid.

The drunkenness provoked condemnation from politicians last night. A Downing Street spokesman said Prime Minister Tony Blair was disgusted. 'He has never failed to condemn hooliganism wherever it may happen.

'He is determined that anybody who seems hellbent on going abroad and causing destruction should be condemned by everyone. The Belgian police have our full support for cracking down on hooligans as hard as they need to.'

But the Tories seized on criticism from the Belgian authorities that Britain had not done enough to stop trouble-makers travelling to the Continent.

The Football Association had pleaded with the Government to seize the passports of known hooligans but Ministers refused, saying it would infringe civil liberties. Ann Widdecombe, the Shadow Home Secretary, last night accused, Jack Straw, of being soft on trouble-makers.

Despite pleas for calm from England players, football chiefs and the authorities in Belgium and Holland - the two countries hosting the tournament - England fans began attacking French, Turkish and North African fans in Brussels on Friday night. The trouble quickly spread to Charleroi where English fans battled with Turks and attacked Germans.

Up to 520 fans were arrested, more than 20 of whom were found with weapons, and the first Britons to be deported began arriving back in Britain last night. Supporters arriving at Manchester and Heathrow airport shielded their faces as they were led away in handcuffs.

The trouble, which had been predicted weeks before the England-Germany clash, started when hundreds of England fans gathered in La Bourse, a popular area of Brussels city centre filled with bars and restaurants, for an evening's drinking before travelling south to Charleroi for the game.

After the France versus the Czech Republic match on Friday afternoon A group of England fans threw glasses at French fans outside an Irish pub in Brussels opposite the city's old Stock Exchange. Riot police baton charged England fans drinking in bars around the Grand Place pepper-spraying them and firing teargas.

fields.headline: Prescott attacks Labour spin machine
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: John Prescott yesterday launched a withering attack on New Labour's obsession with spin and placed himself firmly at the head of the campaign for a return to traditional politics.
fields.body:
John Prescott yesterday launched a withering attack on New Labour's obsession with spin and placed himself firmly at the head of the campaign for a return to traditional politics.

In an interview with The Observer, he demanded an end to the repetition of soundbites and said it was time for the Government to reconnect with its 'own people'. The Deputy Prime Minister said voters were tired of constantly repeated messages like 'boom and bust' and 'for the many, not the few'. He said they wanted messages that had substance rather than those that covered a lack of action.

Prescott said that politicians were often to blame for a growing disillusionment in politics. He said that some Ministers were guilty of simply 'reading the bloody script' when it came to appearances on television or radio.

'When you keep on saying "the many and not the few", it becomes a soundbite that people use, and you devalue it and it becomes the spin,' he said. 'It's not that the message isn't right, but as soon as you start with it, people say "Oh, I've heard all this before". Like boom and bust.

'And sometimes this language, if it is used in a regular way, it devalues the point although the point is sound, and we've got to learn that lesson.'

Although Prescott was careful not to name any colleagues, senior party officials said that the Chancellor, Gordon Brown, and the Education Secretary, David Blunkett, had often been criticised for sticking too strictly to the New Labour lexicon disliked by many.

Prescott's attack will hit hard at many in New Labour who feel that controlling the message is the key to winning the next election.

Prescott admitted that there was a great deal of disaffection among Labour's own supporters about the Government's record. He said that he was 'busting a gut' to go around the country and start selling the Government's message.

He said that he had sympathy with pensioners who felt hard done by because their pension increase had only amounted to 75p.

'There are signs that, for one reason or another, you are not retaining the confidence of the electorate. The classic example of that has to be the pensioners. I do think we have failed to get over exactly what we have done.

'You've got to keep the confidence of your own people, because if they don't have it, they don't communicate to anybody else. When accusations are made by your own people in your own party, for whatever reason, that does undermine confidence in your party.

'We've got to give greater priority to that. We need to put it in a form that people understand.

'There is a tendency to feel because we have done 80 per cent of our manifesto and we are announcing all these things, people get so confused with all the detail, it doesn't convince them.

'They think "Isn't this spinning, and spinning is about lying".

'At the heart of what Labour does, the essence of its belief, is fairness and justice. If the people don't feel it then you've got a real difficulty. It's no good walking away saying, "Well, we've done you okay". If they don't feel it, then they will stay away. That is the big priority in the campaign.

'A confident party has got to start telling the electorate what we've done and be judged against that.'

webTitle: PM's bid to halt banana dispute

fields.headline: PM's bid to halt banana dispute
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has written to President Bill Clinton in an attempt to head off increased sanctions against British companies in an accelerating 'banana war' between the European Union and the US.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has written to President Bill Clinton in an attempt to head off increased sanctions against British companies in an accelerating 'banana war' between the European Union and the US.

The US is preparing to issue a 'retaliation list' of companies to be hit by punitive import tariffs. Thousands of jobs in the Scottish cashmere industry, which exports most of its products to the US, may once again be under threat. Several other British industries, including cardboard packaging, have faced increased tariffs since last year.

The EU has infuriated the US by its refusal to end a system which gave preferential treatment to banana imports from former Caribbean colonies. The World Trade Organisation ruled 15 months ago that the EU should allow equal access to Latin American bananas.

Blair's letter stresses that it would be illogical to extend sanctions against UK exports when Britain is leading the way in Europe over attempts to solve the dispute. He has told Clinton there is no reason to retain, let alone increase sanctions.

Last year, the 'banana war' caused tension between America and Europe as Caribbean producers accused the US-owned companies which run the Latin American banana industry of using political pressure to lever out competition, claiming the dispute could inflict lasting damage on the Caribbean economy.

America's 'retaliation list' will be published on Tuesday.

fields.headline: Jet data glitch halts airports
fields.trailText: Air traffic controllers were trying last night to find the cause of a computer glitch that grounded dozens of flights, delayed hundreds of others and ruined the holiday plans of thousands of people yesterday.
fields.byline: by Robin McKie and Sarah Ryle
fields.body:
Air traffic controllers were trying last night to find the cause of a computer glitch that grounded dozens of flights, delayed hundreds of others and ruined the holiday plans of thousands of people yesterday.

The breakdown - at the West Drayton control centre in west London - stranded travellers amid sweltering chaos at Heathrow and Gatwick airports and paralysed flights throughout the country.

It was the second such fault to cause major disruption in a week, said the National Air Traffic Services, which runs the centre.

For much of the day, all flights to the Continent from British airports were grounded while Heathrow's Terminal One was closed to all arrivals. Victims included Home Office Minister Lord Bassam, who wanted to fly out to supervise police operations at last night's England-Germany match in Belgium.

Late last night airport officials were trying to move a huge backlog of passengers still waiting.

As travellers poured into Heathrow throughout the day, people sat on steps, luggage, trolleys and virtually every available floor space. The Association of British Travel Agents said it was 'a nightmare'.

The air control body blamed a computer that prints details of a plane's course, origin, destination and call sign, needed for controllers to organise plane movements over South-East England.

webTitle: Milburn acts on death rate 'scandal' of inner-city babies

fields.headline: Milburn acts on death rate 'scandal' of inner-city babies
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: New evidence has emerged that babies are three-and-a-half times as likely to die in some areas of the UK as others - with children of the poor at greatest risk.
fields.byline: by Gaby Hinsliff and Anthony Browne
fields.body:
New evidence has emerged that babies are three-and-a-half times as likely to die in some areas of the UK as others - with children of the poor at greatest risk.

The figures have prompted health secretary Alan Milburn to plan action to curb infant deaths.

Figures produced for the NHS National Plan reveal that a baby from inner-city Coventry or Bradford is three times as likely to die in its first year as a child born in rural Cornwall.

Underlining that lottery is a stark gap between the fates of richer and poorer families.

Louise Silverton, deputy general-secretary at the Royal College of Midwives, said: 'It's an absolute scandal.'

Despite warnings from some doctors that the trend is too difficult to reverse, Alan Milburn is considering setting strict targets to reduce infant mortality rates.

Milburn has told friends that if it is true that the real root cause of many illnesses is poverty, then Labour's existing pledge to wipe out child poverty - actually a voter-friendly way of tackling parental deprivation - can be harnessed to break the vicious circle.

He told colleagues last week: 'Our ambition as a Government is not only to improve the health of the nation overall, but to close the gap between the worst off and the better off. That means intervening sooner rather than later.'

Ministers plan to target poorer mothers well before birth with measures to protect babies in the womb. They will offer more antenatal care in deprived areas, help in giving up smoking, initiatives to improve diet and postnatal visits from midwives for several weeks longer than usual. Around 3,500 British babies die a year, and experts accept that poverty is not the only problem: care at birth also varies widely.

A report published this week by the Confidential Inquiry into Stillbirths and Deaths in Infancy will reveal that lives are lost because problem births are not diagnosed soon enough, experienced practitioners are not available, and many staff are not trained to use baby heart monitors.

Mothers are twice as likely to undergo caesareans in some health authorities as in others. 'There's no evidence to support that variation. It suggests that doctors are not practicing evidence-based care,' said Mary Newburn, head of policy at the National Childbirth Trust.

However, poorer nutrition and higher smoking rates among poorer mothers mean their babies are more likely to be born underweight, stacking the survival odds against them from the start.

And the example of other European countries - the infant mortality rate in Luxembourg is only 3.5 per 1000, compared to 5.9 in the UK in 1997 - shows Britain could and should do better in preventing infant deaths. One source said: 'We know from international comparisons that social class isn't actually an inevitable predictor (of infant mortality). It doesn't have to be like this.'

The Department of Health is now studying what targets would be achievable.

The bible of NHS anti-poverty crusaders is the 1998 Acheson report, which revealed that while five in every 1,000 babies born to parents in the top two social classes died in the first year in 1994-96, seven out of 1,000 babies born to parents in the two lowest social classes did.

Sir Donald Acheson demanded a rise in benefits for women and children to help narrow the gap. He also wanted healthy food to be more widely available, plus anti-smoking advice for pregnant women - twice as many unskilled as professonal women smoke.

Accidents, another major cause of infant deaths, are more common among families from lower socio-economic classes.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Speed king's grandson breaks his own UK land record
fields.body:
Speed king's grandson breaks his own UK land record

Don Wales, the grandson of Sir Malcolm Campbell, broke his own UK land speed record for electric vehicles by notching up 128mph on Pendine Sands, West Wales, where Sir Malcolm set three world land-speed records in the 1920s. The world record for electric vehicles is 245mph and is held in the United States.

Teenager's body found

A young woman whose body was found in a field by police acting on information has been identified as Kerry Jane Burton, 17, of Hugglescote, near Coalville, Leicestershire. The jobless teenager lived with her mother, stepfather and four younger stepbrothers and sisters.

We wish you a happy Father's Day - 7 million times over

The Post Office expects 7.25 million Father's Day cards to be posted this year, among the largest number ever.

Swimmers flee poison pool

Five people were taken to hospital after a chlorine leak at a Portsmouth swimming pool.

Lottery numbers

The winning numbers are 4, 22, 24, 25, 40, 43, bonus 6. Thunderball numbers are 3, 4, 11, 18, 31, Thunderball 2.

School loses 25 teachers

Twenty-five teachers have resigned from Ryde High School, Isle of Wight.

Spirits and spirituality

Villagers at Everleigh, Wiltshire, whose church closed, now worship in a courtroom in a pub, once used by 'hanging' Judge Jeffreys.

Cheesey feat

Water buffalo cheese, made in Nantwich with milk from Wales, is being sold in Chester. It is creamy, with a concentrated flavour.

Observer man honoured

The Observer 's Architecture Correspondent, Deyan Sudjic, was awarded the OBE in the Queen's Birthday Honours List. He was director of Glasgow UK City of Architecture and Design 1999.

War trophy

A rare set of First World War telegraphs has fetched £200 at auction in Swindon.

webTitle: Family fury over major 'left to die'

fields.headline: Family fury over major 'left to die'
fields.standfirst: Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: The family of a British major trapped in war-torn Sierra Leone last night launched a furious attack on the Ministry of Defence, saying it had abandoned him to his fate.
fields.body:
The family of a British major trapped in war-torn Sierra Leone last night launched a furious attack on the Ministry of Defence, saying it had abandoned him to his fate.

Major Andrew Harrison, who has dedicated his life to the armed services, is isolated in the south east of the West African state, surrounded by increasingly desperate rebels who have seized and murdered hundreds of hostages.

Steeped in the Army's culture by his father, also a soldier, it has been the 33-year-old's one ambition to fight for Queen and country since he was a young boy.

The career of the British Parachute Regiment officer has been impressive. He fought well in the Gulf War, worked in Northern Ireland as an adjutant at Sandhurst and, in his time off, taught young soldiers to ski.

No strangers to service protocol, Harrison's family were willing to stay quiet while the Ministry of Defence negotiated his freedom. But after letters to the MoD were ignored and appeals for explanations dismissed, they have determined to speak out despite, they say, 'unbearable pressure' to stay silent.

'There's been so much pressure put on the family by the MoD to say nothing that they feel harassed and intimidated. The pressure really has been unbearable,' a family friend told The Observer. 'The MoD left all their letters unanswered and gave every indication that they were simply making light of something that is obviously very disturbing.'

Harrison has been held by the rebels since the beginning of May when a group of observers were kidnapped by the Revolutionary United Front when monitoring a weapons handover. After 11 days in captivity, during which Harrison claims to have been beaten and tortured, he was handed over with the other monitors to the Indian battalion at Kailahun. Since then the RUF has restricted their movements to the UN compound.

'This is a family who have devoted their lives to the Army and who are feeling that they've been kicked in the teeth by their callousness now,' he added. 'They are a military family and they understand the seriousness of going against MoD advice by speaking out. But they feel this situation is far more serious than the MoD seems to appreciate.

'Andrew is not a man to be scared or intimidated... and so when he told them over a satellite phone that was smuggled through to him that he had taken a heavy beating during his kidnapping, they knew that he has suffered serious pain.'

But the MoD denies pressure has been put on the family and says everything possible is being done to rescue the major and his colleagues.

'The family can talk to the media as much as they want,' said a spokesman for the MoD. 'We're doing all that we can to ensure the safety of Major Harrison.'

webTitle: Key Trimble aide seeks poll battle

fields.headline: Key Trimble aide seeks poll battle
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Divisions in the Ulster Unionist Party are due to resurface tomorrow night when a key constituency meets to choose a candidate for a Westminster by-election.
fields.body:
Divisions in the Ulster Unionist Party are due to resurface tomorrow night when a key constituency meets to choose a candidate for a Westminster by-election.

The party's choice of a candidate to succeed the late MP for South Antrim, Clifford Forsythe, involves a complicated political dance which reveals the factionalism within the party and the receding importance of Westminster.

Although he has not publicly said so, UUP leader David Trimble would be happiest if the choice was his assistant in the office of First Minister, David Campbell, who is effectively chief of staff. Campbell, once sceptical about the Good Friday Agreement, 'rode in behind Trimble'. He is described as 'able and colourless', with the nickname of 'the undertaker'.

Trimble would be much less pleased by the selection of his former strategist, David Burnside, the public relations man who once worked for British Airways and was accused of masterminding a 'dirty tricks' campaign against Virgin Airways.

Last month Burnside seconded Jeffrey Donaldson's motion opposing Trimble's plea to the Ulster Unionist Council to allow him to re-enter government with Sinn Fein. Trimble won narrowly.

Burnside was also behind a motion passed at the council's annual meeting in March, making a reformed Executive conditional on keeping the 'proud name' of the RUC.

The third main potential candidate is Duncan Shipley-Dalton, one of the party's two Assembly Members for South Antrim, and perhaps the most enthusiastic supporter of the Agreement.

Shipley-Dalton is viewed as a double outsider with his English accent and his previous membership of the ill-fated Northern Ireland Conservative Party. He enjoys reminding 'armchair warriors' in the Young Unionists of his army service.

Trimble's supporters do not want him because his election to Westminster would leave a vacant Assembly seat, which would by filled by the co-option of the anti-Agreement John Hunter.

These machinations show that Trimble and his colleagues are concentrating their efforts on the Assembly and Executive, seeing Westminster as a glamorous posting which is largely irrelevant to running a devolved Ulster. As one Trimble supporter put it: 'What is the point in being the UUP education spokesman if all the decisions are being made at home by Martin McGuinness?'

The UUP constituency association of South Antrim will decide tomorrow night in the Dunadry Inn who will replace the anti-Agreement Forsythe, who worked hard in his area and on Commons committees but spoke only once in the House during 16 years as an MP.

The main unionist beneficiary of UUP bickering would be the DUP candidate, the Rev William McCrea, who lost his Mid-Ulster seat in 1997 to Sinn Fein's McGuinness.

fields.headline: BAe faces MoD fraud inquiry
fields.standfirst: Software engineer's allegations of financial malpractice trigger investigation into the loss of millions in taxpayers' money
fields.trailText: British Aerospace faces an investigation by the Ministry of Defence police fraud squad after allegations from a former employee that financial malpractice in the firm cost the taxpayer millions of pounds.
fields.body:
British Aerospace faces an investigation by the Ministry of Defence police fraud squad after allegations from a former employee that financial malpractice in the firm cost the taxpayer millions of pounds.

A former software engineer at Marconi Electronic Systems - now owned by BAe - claims there was a 'culture which accepted accounting irregularities as a normal part of the job'.

In a statement to The Observer, Rob McCartney, who worked for Marconi between July 1995 and April this year, said: 'It is my heartfelt conviction that these practices constituted fraud and cost the Ministry of Defence and hence the taxpayer substantial sums of money.'

The Observer passed McCartney's two-page statement outlining his claims and documentary evidence to the MoD police, which launched an immediate investigation into the allegations and will be interviewing McCartney tomorrow. Detective Chief Inspector Norman Love, of the MoD fraud squad, described McCartney's disclosures as 'very serious'.

Menzies Campbell, defence spokesman for the Liberal Democrats who has also seen the statement, said: 'At a time when the defence budget is under intense strain, these allegations raise very profound issues indeed'.

For a number of years McCartney worked on the Tornado maintenance programme at Marconi's north London offices. He claims team leaders regularly instructed staff to charge work on contracts that were going over budget to other contracts running under budget. Because the MoD limits the profit firms can make on certain contracts, McCartney states the MoD would be picking up the bill for Marconi's inefficiency.

One Marconi document seen by The Observer shows a £228,000 software project for the Tornado estimated to be running £31,000 over budget. On the top of the page, the project's supervisor has written in large letters 'spent up, do not use!' McCartney claims that all further work would have been charged to another contract at the taxpayers' expense.

On time sheets filled in by employees there is a bold warning at the bottom stating: 'Deliberate misbookings constitute fraud.' McCartney, described by BAe as 'competent and trustworthy', said: 'Lots of us knew it was wrong, but it was just accepted as a common practice to be told to book work to other jobs when a contract was heading over budget.'

McCartney also claims that the company spent vast sums of money moving people around offices charging costs to Ministry of Defence projects.

He said: 'We were told at an official team briefing that, regardless of the amount of time spent on moving, each person would only be allowed to book one more day to it and that all other time should be booked to the particular project they were working on.'

McCartney added: 'I believe the money booked to projects instead of to moving must have run into millions of pounds. Once again I am concerned that the MoD and the taxpayer wrongly picked up the bill for work.'

McCartney said smaller-scale fiddles were going on as well where 'sundry items' were bought for Marconi but charged to the MoD. He said: 'In one case a fridge was bought to store a single carton of milk for tea and coffee and the cost was charged to the MoD.'

A spokesman for the MoD police said: 'We have a zero tolerance to fraud... If the fraud squad investigation does not reveal sufficient information for a criminal prosecution, we will use all the information gathered to pursue action in the civil courts.'

In a parliamentary answer last month Defence Minister Dr Lewis Moonie told Menzies Campbell, defence spokesman for the Liberal Democrats, that contracts worth £2 million were being investigated for fraud, although the companies involved were not revealed.

It is not the first time Marconi has been embroiled in controversy over defence contracts. In the 1980s, Marconi was mired in a scandal following a two-year investigation by the MoD police involving contracts worth billions of pounds. But a criminal prosecution against senior employees of the company collapsed.

The Observer has also discovered that in 1995 Public Concern at Work, the body that helps whistleblowers, acted for an engineer at GEC-Marconi, as it was then, who claimed he was made redundant after raising concerns about financial malpractice. After the engineer brought an action for unfair dismissal, the company settled out of court for £25,000.

Rob McCartney, now working outside the defence industry, said: 'I have come forward now because I am sick to the stomach of politicians saying there is no money for the armed forces when there is this scandalous - and I believe fraudulent - waste of taxpayers' money going on.'

A spokesman for BAe said: 'We take all allegations seriously and will look into them. But these alleged events took place before BAe merged with GEC-Marconi last year and we will not comment until we have seen evidence and details of any alleged malpractice.'

McCartney also claims that the company spent vast sums of money moving people around offices charging costs to Ministry of Defence projects. He said: 'We were told at an official team briefing that, regardless of the amount of time spent on moving, each person would only be allowed to book one more day to it and that all other time should be booked to the particular project they were working on.' McCartney added: 'I believe the money booked to projects instead of to moving must have run into millions of pounds. Once again I am concerned that the MoD and the taxpayer wrongly picked up the bill for work.' McCartney said smaller-scale fiddles were going on as well where 'sundry items' were bought for Marconi but charged to the MoD. He said: 'In one case a fridge was bought to store a single carton of milk for tea and coffee and the cost was charged to the MoD.' A spokesman for the MoD police said: 'We have a zero tolerance to fraud... If the fraud squad investigation does not reveal sufficient information for a criminal prosecution, we will use all the information gathered to pursue action in the civil courts.' In a parliamentary answer last month Defence Minister Dr Lewis Moonie told Menzies Campbell, defence spokesman for the Liberal Democrats, that contracts worth £2 million were being investigated for fraud, although the companies involved were not revealed. It is not the first time Marconi has been embroiled in controversy over defence contracts. In the 1980s, Marconi was mired in a scandal following a two-year investigation by the MoD police involving contracts worth billions of pounds. But a criminal prosecution against senior employees of the company collapsed. The Observer has also discovered that in 1995 Public Concern at Work, the body that helps whistleblowers, acted for an engineer at GEC-Marconi, as it was then, who claimed he was made redundant after raising concerns about financial malpractice. After the engineer brought an action for unfair dismissal, the company settled out of court for £25,000. Rob McCartney, now working outside the defence industry, said: 'I have come forward now because I am sick to the stomach of politicians saying there is no money for the armed forces when there is this scandalous - and I believe fraudulent - waste of taxpayers' money going on.' A spokesman for BAe said: 'We take all allegations seriously and will look into them. But these alleged events took place before BAe merged with GEC-Marconi last year and we will not comment until we have seen evidence and details of any alleged malpractice.' antony.barnett@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Shock as NHS soars in world health league

fields.headline: Shock as NHS soars in world health league
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The World Health Organisation will this week declare Britain's NHS one of the best health systems.
fields.body:
The World Health Organisation will this week declare Britain's NHS one of the best health systems.

In the first-ever official ranking of the performance of health services, the WHO will declare that Britons have a better system than Americans, Canadians, Germans, Danes, Swiss, Swedes, New Zealanders and Australians - the very countries with which the UK is usually unfavourably compared.

The Department of Health declined to comment, although one government source said: 'I'm shocked.'

The World Health Report 2000, to be published on Wednesday, will declare that out of 191 health systems in the world, Britain comes eighteenth, far ahead of the US, in 37th place. This is despite the fact that Britain spends less on health than every other developed nation.

The report is likely to be welcomed by those who still support the founding principles of the totally tax-funded NHS, with little comfort for those who prefer to boost the idea of private health care.

The WHO claims that France has the best health system in the world, with only a few other major European countries, including Italy, Spain and Norway, ahead of the UK. Sierra Leone and Burma have the worst.

webTitle: Government car fleet fails 'Buy British' test

fields.headline: Government car fleet fails 'Buy British' test
fields.trailText: Almost half the Government's cars are made overseas, despite calls for consumers to show loyalty to the UK's embattled car industry, The Observer has learnt.
fields.body:
Almost half the Government's cars are made overseas, despite calls for consumers to show loyalty to the UK's embattled car industry, The Observer has learnt.

Official figures last week showed that 47 per cent of the cars operated by Whitehall departments are made outside the UK. In some departments more than two thirds of the cars used are made overseas.

The figures - indicating that the civil servant's first choice is a BMW, Volvo or Mercedes rather than a Rover or Vauxhall - have sparked outrage and calls from MPs for a new law requiring the country of manufacture to be displayed on all new cars.

Worst offenders include John Prescott's Department of Environment, Transport and the Regions, Jack Straw's Home Office, Mo Mowlam's Cabinet Office and Lord Irvine's Lord Chancellor's Department.

Only 29 per cent of DETR cars were made in Britain. The Home Office fleet is 31 per cent British made, the Cabinet Office 32 per cent and the Lord Chancellor's Department 39 per cent.

The news follows frantic attempts by ministers in the past few months to shore up the failing UK car industry, following BMW's dumping of Rover in March and Ford's announcement last month that it would end production at its Dagenham plant in Essex, costing 2,000 jobs.

The figures have drawn angry responses from Labour backbenchers, industry figures and union leaders.

Ian Pearson, MP for Dudley South, in the middle of Britain's West Midlands car production heartland, uncovered the figures through asking parliamentary questions.

Pearson was scathing about the results. 'This is an appalling track record, particularly given the crisis in the industry. The Government should be using taxpayers' money to set an example and buy British cars to keep our people in jobs.'

Pearson's knowledge of West Midlands car manufacturing saw him appointed by the Government to the emergency task force set up to deal with the Rover crisis.

Prompted by what he has discovered, he is consulting industry experts on a law which would require cars being sold in Britain to display their country of origin.

He is supported by union leaders. Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union said: 'There is a major problem here.'

However, the figures will be a relief for Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers. The DTI had the second best record, buying 13 of its total 19 cars from the UK.

A DETR spokeswoman said: 'Under procurement legislation we have to follow EU rules which mean we can't discriminate against other countries.' She added it was difficult to know where cars were made because components were manufactured in a number of countries.

A Cabinet Office spokeswoman said department cars were chosen on suitability and whether they came from an approved supplier.

webTitle: Libya hunt for embassy killer suspects

fields.headline: Libya hunt for embassy killer suspects
fields.standfirst: Gadaffi will let Yard question suspects in shooting of WPC Fletcher after The Observer reveals MI5 suspicions that Libyan agents murdered dissident
fields.trailText: Britain's most senior anti-terrorist police are to fly to Tripoli to interview the men suspected of murdering WPC Yvonne Fletcher, who was gunned down at the Libyan embassy in London in 1984.
fields.body:
Britain's most senior anti-terrorist police are to fly to Tripoli to interview the men suspected of murdering WPC Yvonne Fletcher, who was gunned down at the Libyan embassy in London in 1984.

The officers will also investigate the murder of Ali Abuzeid, a Libyan dissident whose death in 1995 is thought to have been a political assassination by agents of Colonel Gadaffi, the country's ruler. The Abuzeid case was reopened earlier this year after The Observer revealed that MI5 had suspicions that the murder was the work of the Libyan government, but had failed to pass on key information to the police.

Pressure will intensify on the Libyans to allow police to question Khalifa Bazelya, one of Gadaffi's top spies who now works as ambassador to Cyprus. In December 1995, only two weeks after the mur der of Abuzeid, Bazelya was expelled from Britain for intimidating dissidents and recruiting spies. He was never officially linked to the murder, but an MI5 document posted on the internet in April showed that the intelligence services suspected he was involved in violence in Britain. MI6 and MI5 tried to recruit Bazelya, then Libya's top diplomat in London, but he 'led them a merry dance' said one intelligence source.

Huda Abuzeid, the daughter of the murdered man, has waged a five-year campaign to expose Gadaffi's connection to her father's murder.

She told The Observer : 'I am pleased the police are going to Libya after all this time. I just hope that the people responsible for my father's death are finally brought to justice.'

In a sign of the extraordinary thaw in diplomatic relations between Britain and the Gadaffi regime, the Scotland Yard officers will be invited to Libya in the next few weeks.

The authorities in Tripoli have agreed to co-operate in tracking down the Libyan embassy staff who ordered a gunman to open fire on anti-Gadaffi demonstrators from a first floor window and the man who pulled the trigger. WPC Fletcher fell to ground in a hail of bullets and later died of her wounds.

The second in command of the Yard's anti-terrorist branch, John Bunn, will send senior officers and forensic experts who will use the latest DNA technology to link the suspects to evidence taken from the embassy after the murder and samples taken secretly from diplomats expelled from Britain in 1984.

Britain broke off diplomatic relations with Libya after the murder. They were restored only last year after Foreign Secretary Robin Cook negotiated the handover of the two suspects in the Lockerbie bombing and £250,000 compensation went to Fletcher's family.

The main suspect is Abdulgader Tuhami, a military intelligence officer and firearms expert who is though to have fired the shots. Police also want to see Moustafa Mghirbi, the chief intelligence officer, believed to have passed on Tripoli's orders to open fire. Officers are also keen to interview former press officer Ali Jalid and Omar Sodani, a diplomat once believed to have been executed for the murder in Libya, but now known to be alive.

Speaking last night from her home in Dorset, the murdered policewoman's mother, Queenie Fletcher, said she wanted the men responsible for her daughter's death to be tried for murder, though she didn't hold out any great hope because so long had passed.

'I'm sure they know who did it. It's just a matter of the time being right for them. The Government has raised our hopes before, but for me it just goes on and on,' Mrs Fletcher said.

She had not been consulted about the £250,000 compensation from the Government. She had always refused previous Libyan offers, calling them 'blood money'.

Police sources confirmed that anti-terrorist officers had been invited to Libya, but said negotiations about the Ali Abuzeid case were still 'extremely sensitive'.

Ashur Shamis, a leading Libyan dissident, said: 'It is encouraging and we just hope that it will lead to something concrete in both cases and isn't just another fudge. The British police have to be careful not to be given the run-around by the Libyans.'

The Observer has contacted Khalifa Bazelya, but he has so far refused to comment on the affair.

webTitle: Celtic Tiger looks sickly as inflation soars

fields.headline: Celtic Tiger looks sickly as inflation soars
fields.trailText: Is the Celtic Tiger about to slink back into the jungle with its tail between its legs? Last week's reports of inflation running at three times the European Union average, house prices soaring and rumbles of rebellion from the trade unions, all indicate the Irish economic miracle to be in serious trouble.
fields.body:
Is the Celtic Tiger about to slink back into the jungle with its tail between its legs? Last week's reports of inflation running at three times the European Union average, house prices soaring and rumbles of rebellion from the trade unions, all indicate the Irish economic miracle to be in serious trouble.

The latest consumer price index shows the annual rate of inflation has risen to 5.2 per cent, compared with an EU average of 1.2 per cent. As recently as December, the government predicted a rate of 3.5 per cent for this year. Economists believe the June and July figures will bring the figure up to 6 per cent and this could go higher in the autumn.

After years of high growth, low inflation and a dramatic rise in employment, the bad news has come as a shock, even to those who should have foreseen it, such as Ireland's ebullient Minister for Finance, Charles McCreevy. Last year 'Champagne Charlie', as he is known to friends and foes alike, was dismissing critics of his tax-cutting, high-spending policies as 'left-wing pinkos' who did not like to see ordinary people enjoying the fruits of their hard work.

The good times have been wonderful for many people. Emigrants who for many years were forced to seek work abroad have been coming home. Dublin and other cities are visibly booming.

The failure to control inflation is the most serious threat. It is difficult to see how the government, facing a general election and hit in the opinion polls by reports of sleaze, can deal with it. The obvious step would have been to raise interest rates to curb inflationary pressures, particularly in housing.

That has not been possible because of Ireland's enthusiastic embrace of the euro, which means control of fiscal policy has passed to the European Central Bank. The bank has urged Ireland to cut indirect taxes, which would bring down the price of alcohol and tobacco, as well as encourage competition. It would also put more money in people's pockets, the last thing needed now.

The most pressing problem is housing. The cost of houses is now way beyond the reach of first-time buyers. Since 1995, average house prices in Dublin have risen from £86,000 to around £200,000. Experts predict prices will double in the next five years. Speculation in the construction industry, more people returning from abroad and low interest rates have all contributed to this spiral.

Last week the government announced measures designed to curb speculation and make it easier for young couples to buy their homes. But with 54,500 new houses needed every year for the next five years, few people believe these proposals will solve the problem.

The fallout from the latest figures is expressed in angry mutterings from the trade unions. Ireland's economic success, and its capacity to attract foreign investors, has been largely based on wage restraint.

The recently agreed Programme for Prosperity and Fairness allows for wage rises of 5 per cent this year. Already many workers are saying that, with inflation at 5.2 per cent, the benefits of such increases have been wiped out. The same is true, only more so, of pensions and welfare benefits.

On Wednesday, the government meets representatives of the Irish Congress of Trade Unions to discuss anti-inflationary measures. But the ICTU president has warned it may be necessary to renegotiate the deal, if 'social chaos' is to be avoided.

Why has the dream gone sour? Some economists blame Ireland's decision to join the euro. They point out that Britain is still Ireland's largest trading partner and suspect the break with sterling was an expensive political error, designed to cock a snook at the old enemy.

The strength of sterling has helped Irish exports and brought more British tourists to this country. But it has also put up prices in shops, and soured relations along the border, where traders in Northern Ireland have suffered from the impact of the strong pound against the punt.

Others say Bertie Ahern and his Minister for Finance have been too complacent about letting the good times roll. The Irish have enjoyed prosperity all the more because of the long years of poverty and emigration that preceded them. Now, it seems, we must learn to house-train the Celtic tiger.

webTitle: Villains use their cars to attack police

fields.headline: Villains use their cars to attack police
fields.standfirst: Weapon on four wheels takes over from the gun, knife and cosh
fields.trailText: Speeding cars have replaced guns, knives and samurai swords as the greatest threat to the bobby on the beat.
fields.body:
Speeding cars have replaced guns, knives and samurai swords as the greatest threat to the bobby on the beat. In an alarming development, increasing numbers of criminals are turning their vehicles into lethal weapons to escape justice.

The last two police officers murdered on duty were both mown down by vehicles. The trend echoes what is happening in America where, despite the proliferation of guns on the street, the latest figures show that law enforcement officers are nearly twice as likely to die from being struck by vehicles or being involved in car accidents as they are from gunshot wounds.

Cars are also responsible for the vast majority of other deaths on duty with more than half of all police fatalities occurring as a result of accidents and collisions.

Of the last 10 officers to die on duty, two were hit by cars, six were involved in traffic accidents. By comparison, of the 40 police officers murdered prior to this, half were shot, stabbed or beaten to death.

The most recent case of death by car took place last September. Constable Raja Ahmed, who had returned to motorcycle duty in Manchester after suffering a broken arm, had been called to a road accident when he was struck by a stolen vehicle. A man has been charged with his murder.

In April last year, PC Jeffrey Tooley was mown down while on duty at a radar speed check. A van failed to stop and, as it evaded the check, it deliberately struck Tooley. He was dragged for several hundred yards and died a few hours later from severe head injuries.

An unexpected benefit of the introduction of body armour for all police officers has been that it offers greater protection in such situations. The garments, made to absorb the impact of a bullet, also acts as a cushion in a vehicle collision.

Forty per cent of officers whose lives have been saved by their armour were involved in incidents involving cars. By comparison, just 29 per cent of lives saved involved firearms.

Despite this, the number of officers incapacitated as a result of vehicular assault is also climbing fast. Earlier this month British Transport policeman Terry Wright was dragged 30 yards with his arm trapped in a car door as two suspected drug dealers tried to make a getaway. He had tried to grab the ignition keys, and was only freed when the car window clamping his arm shattered and he was thrown to the ground and knocked unconscious.

The incident took place a few days after a young policewoman was rushed to hospital with minor injuries after her patrol car was rammed by a stolen vehicle and smashed into a tree as she responded to a robbery at a supermarket in Bookham, Surrey.

The startling figures make traffic duty by far the most dangerous division of the police force, above and beyond those working in the SO10 undercover division and even the elite SO19 firearms squad.

Veteran police safety campaigner Jim McNulty says: 'While police officers are more likely to be injured if they are assaulted with knives or guns, they are much more likely to be killed on the roads.

'When a police officer comes into contact with a potential assailant he can always assess the situation and make a decision to step back, reducing the risk of injury. But if someone is trying to run you over, there isn't a lot you can do to protect yourself. The theatre of danger is greater because of the high speeds.'

fields.headline: Scientists abandon'inefficient' cloning
fields.standfirst: Dolly success proves hard to repeat as vast majority of experiments end in death or abnormalities.
fields.trailText: She was always going to be a hard act to follow, an animal in a million. But now researchers have discovered that Dolly the sheep, the world's first cloned mammal, may be even rarer and even more unusual than first appreciated.
fields.body:
She was always going to be a hard act to follow, an animal in a million. But now researchers have discovered that Dolly the sheep, the world's first cloned mammal, may be even rarer and even more unusual than first appreciated.

Scientists have found that although other cloned creatures - pigs, cows, goats and mice - have been created in the past couple of years, these few rare successes are proving extremely difficult to repeat. As one researcher put it: 'Cloning has turned out to be more art than science.'

In fact, results have been so poor that many scientists have abandoned attempts to clone creatures, and are returning to the laboratory to carry out basic research in an attempt to find out what is going wrong.

As Professor Keith Campbell, one of the team responsible for making Dolly, said: 'After we cloned the first adult sheep, lots of scientists assumed that it would soon be easy to make streams of similar clones, that it was just a matter of honing the technology. But now we are finding out that it is a lot more difficult than this. Cloning is turning out to be very expensive and very inefficient.'

At its heart, the problem involves a host of different scientific disciplines: in understanding what types of cell should be used as the founder of the proposed clone; in selecting the best donor animals; and in picking the right environments to grow their cells.

At present, scientists simply do not know the right criteria for consistently making a clone of an animal, a problem outlined in the current issue of the journal Science . It reveals that, even after a cloned embryo has been made and then implanted in a surrogate mother's womb, only two in 100 make it to successful, healthy birth. In the case of Dolly, it took almost 300 attempts at implanting an embryo into her surrogate mother before she became the first healthy cloned lamb to make it through to delivery .

'Even when an embryo does successfully implant in the womb, pregnancies often end in miscarriage,' states the Science report. 'A significant fraction of the animals that are born die shortly after birth. And some of those that survive have serious develop mental abnormalities, suggesting that something in the recipe is fundamentally wrong.'

In the case of cloned cattle, more than a quarter are alarmingly larger than normal and many abort spontaneously and mysteriously. Even among those of normal weight, many are found to have underdeveloped lungs, while others have dangerously elevated levels of potassium in their blood. Similar problems affect other species.

'We simply do not know why this is happening,' said Campbell, of Nottingham University.

Finding out the nature of this fundamental flaw is now an urgent concern for scientists. However, as most cloning research is now funded and carried out by major corporations, their demands for tight security and secrecy from their staff is seriously hampering the exchange of data, a point highlighted by Norton Zinder of the Rockefeller University in New York. Only a 'major diplomatic effort' by his staff could persuade leading scientists in the field to come to a special conference that was, ironically, aimed at improving communications in the field.

This failure to crack the fundamental problems of cloning has several key consequences. For a start, they suggest that the ethical dilemmas that are supposed to beset the field must be decidedly less pressing than previously accepted. As Science puts it: 'Human cloning - even so-called therapeutic to produce cell lines to be used in treating disease - may be a long way off. As for reproductive cloning, or actually creating living replica, it would be criminal at this stage in our abilities.'

Even creating replicas of our favoured pets now looks a remote prospect, despite the fact that in the past few months four different US companies have been set up to create clones from the cells of dead favourite cats or dogs. For a fee between £200 and £1,000, one of these companies will take a tissue sample from your ex-pet and store it cryogenically for about £100 a year - in anticipation of the day that scientists crack the secret of cat cloning or dog duplicating.

'People shouldn't get too excited about this one either,' said Campbell. 'It will take an awful long time before we can even consider cloning a cat in a routine way.'

fields.headline: PM tension
fields.trailText: In your article on the arms trade  B.J. Habibie is variously described as the 'President' and 'Prime Minister' of Indonesia, and it is implied that Indonesia is a military dictatorship.
fields.body:
In your article on the arms trade (News, last week) B.J. Habibie is variously described as the 'President' and 'Prime Minister' of Indonesia, and it is implied that Indonesia is a military dictatorship. In fact, Indonesia's head of state is President Abdurrahman Wahid, who was democratically elected over half a year ago. There is no Indonesian Prime Minister.
Clive Christie
Centre for Southeast Asian Studies
Hull University

Many thanks to Mr Christie and the many others who pointed out this outrageous solecism. Profuse apologies to them and all our readers.

fields.headline: A union of diversity
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The conflict in Northern Ireland is not about economics, religion or ethnicity. It is about identity and belonging. Those of us of Scottish and Anglican extraction, whose families have been a part of this island's history for more than 300 years, regard ourselves as the real British presence in Ireland. For us, our sense of identity and belonging, while rooted geographically in the soil of Ireland, lies politically in our citizenship of the United Kingdom. I see no contradiction in being both Irish and British.
fields.body:
The conflict in Northern Ireland is not about economics, religion or ethnicity. It is about identity and belonging. Those of us of Scottish and Anglican extraction, whose families have been a part of this island's history for more than 300 years, regard ourselves as the real British presence in Ireland. For us, our sense of identity and belonging, while rooted geographically in the soil of Ireland, lies politically in our citizenship of the United Kingdom. I see no contradiction in being both Irish and British.

My concept of unionism is a union of parts where the diverse peoples of these islands can come together in a common purpose of social advancement. Such a union should enrich and enhance rather than diminish or deny each group its sense of culture, identity and citizenship.

The United Kingdom is moving away from the idea of a solitary 'nation' governed by a unitary parliament. Areas such as the Isle of Man and the Channel Islands have their own degree of independence. Scotland has its parliament while Wales and Northern Ireland have their assemblies, and England edges closer to regionalisation. Meanwhile, Europe becomes more involved in our daily lives.

The United Kingdom of the future will certainly look very different to the United Kingdom of the past. Responsible unionists will acknowledge those differences and commit themselves to a unionism that is progressive.

It is important that all citizens of Northern Ireland look to the future and back political structures that will meet the political and social challenges of the new millennium. As a loyalist I welcome the creation of modern, progressive and innovative structures that meet the demands of a changing Northern Ireland within a changing United Kingdom and within a changing Europe. Such structures will also take into account the changing nature of the Republic of Ireland and the development of more agreeable relationships between the governments and the people of both jurisdictions.

It is clear, however, that good relationships across these islands will prove ineffective unless they are accompanied by good political relationships within Northern Ireland. A significant number of my fellow citizens aspire to a United Ireland and most identify closely with the political and religious ethos that underpins the Republic. A growing minority of republicans, while aspiring to a United Ireland, do not want to identify with the revisionist politics of post-1916 republicanism or the Catholic ethos that underpins that revisionism.

As an Irish Unionist I have no difficulty in endorsing the right of either republican nationalists or republican socialists to seek the achievement of those aspirations through peaceful and democratic means. Thus, while rejecting the political objectives of both Sinn Fein and the SDLP, I welcome the moves by the Sinn Fein leadership to embrace the democratic process. Nationalists and republicans are our fellow citizens and, being a sizeable minority within Northern Ireland, must be represented at executive level. In short, there must be a 'sharing of responsibility' between unionists and nationalists.

As a trade unionist whose politics are Labour-oriented I am committed to the politics of commonality, equality, and plurality. The party to which I belong attracts its support from the working-class, the workless class and the underclass. It is my hope that the implementation of the Belfast Agreement will facilitate a radical realignment of political groupings along the lines of issue-based politics.

At that stage there will be, I hope, a radical political realignment where those of us who aspire to a genuine social democracy can engage in debate and action on how best we can ensure that the social and economic benefits derived from the new politics will actually reach the people who need them most.

Billy Mitchell is a senior member of the Progressive Unionist Party.
