fields.headline: A vacuum in New Labour
fields.trailText: The time of reckoning approaches. The wind, and William Hague, howl outside the portals. Mephistopheles is coming to claim his price. And on the most important and urgent question facing the country, the Government still dithers.
fields.body:
At a block of flats in Richmond, one of London's most prosperous boroughs, the porter is facing an uncertain retirement. For seven years he and his wife have lived in the lodge, or tied house.

He is not a man to be lightly crossed. His duties are various, from polishing brass to carrying out emergency repairs to the lifts, taking bookings for the tennis court, grading bottles and glass into recycling bins and admitting deliveries to the flats of absent occupants.

Before he took this job he was a hospital porter, and can look forward to a small NHS pension. But his present employment offers no such entitlement, and he and his wife face retirement, which is imminent, not only on a very small income but - so far, at least - without a home.

Mr Porter, as I shall call him, is becoming bitter. It is not just that the borough cannot find a small apartment for his retirement. He reports he has been treated by housing officers with arrogance and disrespect. He has written to his MP and is threatening to 'take the matter to the national press'.

His case helps to explain why disenchantment with New Labour is so general. Mr Porter might have expected that more public housing would have become available under the Blair regime. Instead, Labour has continued the reforms begun by the Tories which transformed councils from providers into 'enablers' of housing.

His grievance is personal. A more generalised charge against the Government is its timidity. This had its roots in the decision to accept Tory public spending targets for the first two years of the Labour Government.

The public may perceive that our problems in the health service, the schools and the railways are rooted in the neglect of the Thatcher era. The trouble is that Labour has not acted decisively to reverse the trend. Now the public squarely blames the Government. In the theatre of politics, Blair is no longer the charming juvenile lead but a sadder Faustian figure locked in a bargain with the sinister Broon.

The time of reckoning approaches. The wind, and William Hague, howl outside the portals. Mephistopheles is coming to claim his price. And on the most important and urgent question facing the country, the Government still dithers.

As it happens I am a Europhile for historical and emotional reasons. John Keegan's superb History of the First World War, published earlier this year, reminds us of the price that Europe has paid for its chronic disunity, and the halting progress so far towards political union has been a major achievement of the late twentieth century.

Yet I am fearful that a generation of politicians with no historical grasp is replacing those wise men who saw the European imperative so clearly, and that statesmanship is giving way to petty nationalism. The Tory party is now becoming an English national party with the twin slogans of 'save the pound' and 'keep out the foreigners'.

In Scotland what the Tories stand for is not at all clear but seems to owe most to the 'keep down the rates' tradition of the old Conservatives who masqueraded as progressives in local government.

Last week the party lost a defector to the SNP, an impressive young Asian woman candidate who said she had been repelled by Hague's right-wing sentiments on emigration.

In Scotland we are fortunate to have an SNP which is largely gradualist, rational, moderate and inclusive. For Holyrood elections at least it offers a real alternative and perhaps the party needs to be blooded in administration there.

Yet that will not end the leadership vacuum that Labour has created around the question of the euro. Blair and Brown must seize events if they are not to sweep away by them.

He either fears his fate too much,

Or his deserts are small,

That puts it not unto the touch

To win or lose it all.

fields.headline: Naked lunchbox
fields.trailText: Kathryn Flett's review of Channel 5's  Naked Jungle noted the surprising lack of emphasis on nudity in the script of the show itself.
fields.body:
Kathryn Flett's review of Channel 5's Naked Jungle (Review, last week) noted the surprising lack of emphasis on nudity in the script of the show itself. However, isn't this exactly what naturism is supposed to be about - a return to a primordial, child-like state, free from adult prurience and hang-ups? Rather than being considered a shocking exception, perhaps the Naked Jungle could become the model for all game shows which, anyway, consist of slightly embarrassed grown-ups cavorting around like children.
Andrew Quarry
Taunton
Somerset

fields.headline: Pat piety
fields.body:
Sue Arnold's exposé of the Alpha version of Christianity (Review, last week) points up the big problem with much so-called evangelism - it is largely about Christians talking to themselves. Alpha is not really about challenging the world outside a narrow pietistic framework, but the well-heeled violinists and fashion photographers who frequent Holy Trinity, Brompton, may find this distinctly uncool.
Rev Geoff Reid
The Methodist Church Touchstone Centre
Bradford

fields.headline: Safety first
fields.trailText: Your story about the BAe146 (News, 4 June) could cause alarm to the public.
fields.body:
Your story about the BAe146 (News, 4 June) could cause alarm to the public. It does not represent the facts of the BAe 146 family of aircraft. They are highly popular with passengers, pilots, crews and operators and have provided more than five million safe flight hours. There are 350 aircraft with 52 airlines world-wide.

'Rollback' has been extensively studied, and fully understood since 1996. Airlines are required to install a modification at the next engine overhaul, which must be done by 31 December 2002.

References to toxic fumes in the incident in Sweden are still the subject of investigation by the Swedish authorities who have yet to issue their findings.

During the Australian inquiry by a committee of senators, with which we have co-operated fully, the Civil Aviation Safety Authority confirmed it was satisfied with the safety of the BAe146, as are civil aviation certification authorities all over the world.

The safety of passengers and crew takes absolute priority in our industry and any suggestion that this principle would be compromised by secrecy and cover-ups does a grave injustice to the integrity of everyone who works in the industry.
J.P. Weston
Chief Executive, BAE Systems
Farnborough
Hampshire

fields.body:
Last Sunday's Observer is to be congratulated for including three items on the topic of sleep disturbance (News, Comment and Life, last week). However, I was quoted as saying that Ritalin is related to cocaine. I said no such thing. Ritalin is related to amphetamine but not to cocaine.
Professor Gregory Stores
Department of Psychiatry
University of Oxford

fields.headline: Rivalry rocks the SNP
fields.standfirst: Salmond's cautious stance on independence gives comfort to his old enemies.  Alex Bell  and  Arnold Kemp report
fields.trailText: The SNP is trying to put behind it some nasty little local difficulties which last week tested to breaking point the view that there is no such thing as bad publicity. Behind the crisis is growing unease about whether the party's gradualism can survive the winds of populism.
fields.body:
The SNP is trying to put behind it some nasty little local difficulties which last week tested to breaking point the view that there is no such thing as bad publicity. Behind the crisis is growing unease about whether the party's gradualism can survive the winds of populism.

The removal of Ian Blackford as treasurer and a rap on the knuckles for Margo MacDonald from the parliamentary group involved some long-standing rivalries, particularly with convener Alex Salmond.

Then the week ended with yet more bad news. Lloyd Quinan MSP quit his post as a deputy spokesman on social justice, apparently 'furious' at MacDonald's treatment. His job went to Tricia Marwick who, along with Kenny MacAskill, charged with temporarily balancing the books, was once a so-called fundamentalist.

Beneath the surface turbulence lies the fear that the leadership's gradualist stance - which sees the road to independence as a long march with stages - will blur the party's commitment to its core objective and that, as one seasoned nationalist said, 'personal feuds will win out over policies'.

And as Tommy Sheridan, the leader of the Scottish Socialist Party now making a major impact on the political scene, hogged the headlines with his wedding in Glasgow yesterday, the old Nat gloomily added: 'If the leadership don't develop some populist policies soon, then the party will grow dispirited and won't campaign effectively.'

The immediate cause of Blackford's departure after a vote of no confidence was his attempts to rein in the party's overdraft, said to be in the region of £400,000. Some of this arose from last year's Scottish election campaign when the party tried to counter a fiercely hostile press by publishing its own newspaper. Blackford's view was that the cost of £60,000 brought no measurable effect. When Blackford said last year that there would be no 'jiggery-pokery' with the books, Salmond was furi ous at the implication of malpractice.

Salmond's rivalry with Blackford goes back much further. As young Turks, they were both expelled by then leader Gordon Wilson when he cracked down on the left-wing 79 Group in the early Eighties. Salmond was readmitted and quickly outpaced his contemporaries. Blackford went to London to make his fortune in banking, returning to the SNP after a period in the Labour Party.

By now their mutual dislike had crystallised and it was only a matter of time before they clashed. The immediate reason for Blackford's removal as treasurer was that by imposing stringent financial controls, he was threatening Salmond's ability to lead the party in general and to control the next campaign in particular. To do the latter he needs unfettered access to party funds. His immediate justification was that Blackford had made accountancy mistakes in the last financial report. Newspaper leaks about the SNP's debts were also laid at Blackford's door, a charge which he denies.

But Salmond angered many in the party by pursuing last Saturday's vote of no confidence in Blackford's absence. The party may not have entirely approved of Blackford, particularly after a highly critical newspaper article he wrote during last year's conference, but it also dislikes the appearance of unfair treatment.

The mistake Blackford made was to threaten to sue Salmond for defamation. The party is remarkably loyal and resents any attempt to publicise 'family' arguments. He was promptly suspended and his duties were handed over to MacAskill.

Sections of the media were portraying the events of the week as a terrible fury visited on the fundamentalists by the gradualists.

The notion that this is an ideological dispute between fundamentalists, who want outright independence as soon as possible, and gradualists, who want to arrive at independence through the increase in Holyrood's powers, is denied by all sides.

Yet senior strategists also acknowledge that there is an underlying problem.

They say that, even if the strategy of gradualism stays in place, the rhetoric must change to re-express the party's core values. The group of 35 MSPs is working hard to establish a new credibility for the party as a vehicle of government. Its short-term aim is to form the next administration and hold a referendum on independence.

fields.headline: Net rogues eye vulnerable prey
fields.standfirst: Website private investigators offering to trace lost loved ones cash in on misery, writes Amelia Hill
fields.trailText: As soon as her three young children have gone to bed, Helen sits down at her computer and logs on to search for her oldest child: the son she gave birth to when she was 16 and has never seen.
fields.body:
As soon as her three young children have gone to bed, Helen sits down at her computer and logs on to search for her oldest child: the son she gave birth to when she was 16 and has never seen.

For the next three hours at least, she will comb through websites dedicated to missing people, desperately posting messages and checking her email, hoping this will be the night he contacts her.

In the past year, Helen, an unemployed single mother, has spent more than £3,000 looking for the son she gave up for adoption under duress in 1981. It was money she could barely afford but, after drawing a blank with social services, she thought she saw an end to her search when a private investigator emailed her, promising to help.

'He told me it would cost just £75 plus expenses, with a no-win, no-fee guarantee,' she said. 'He told me to look at his website, which was amazingly official with tributes from people he had helped. I couldn't believe my luck.

'He was fine at the beginning, giving me a few leads but once I'd put my trust in him, he started demanding more and more money, and when I complained, he got quite aggressive and said he would stop if I wanted him to but I'd get no refund,' she said.

The trade in tracing missing people is just the latest to exploit the potential of the internet, and the numbers of those offering such a service have risen exponentially, say charities who believe the net's anonymity can provide a shield for those willing to cheat and exploit families.

'There has been a dramatic increase in the past six months alone in the numbers of sites claiming to help trace missing people,' said Sophie Woodforde, head of web development at the National Missing Persons' Helpline. 'Some of these people may be genuine but many are looking to make a quick buck from families desperate enough to try anything that comes their way.

'It's going to get even worse very soon. All the domain names containing the word "missing" have been bought up, mostly in the past few months, so we're going to see hundreds more sites hoping to cash in on this lucrative area.'

There are large profits to be made, even by bona fide sites. www.Missing-people.co.uk, due to open on 1 July, charges £852.60 a year simply to post a photograph alongside contact details on its noticeboard, but adds that it will pay part of this as a reward to finders. Sites that offer active searches also charge large sums: www.missinglinks.co.uk charges £425 for a 30-hour search; www.adoptionlink.co.uk asks for a non-refundable £375 plus up to £700 in expenses.

'It's horrifying,' said Colin Fairclough, director of the Family Tracing Service for the Salvation Army. 'The success rate of these people is highly questionable and impossible to verify. They charge huge amounts of money while charities such as the National Missing Person's Helpline, the Red Cross and ourselves charge nothing.'

LookupUK, a new website offering families access to search engines and facilities for free, receives around 1,200 visitors a day. Its director, Paul Field, is so concerned about rogue sites he is trying to set up an accreditation body to control the trade.

'Unscrupulous people used to hang around the Public Record Office approaching people looking for relatives,' he said. 'Now all they have to do is log on, type in "missing persons" and long lists of desperate people appear along with their contact details.'

Julie Goldsmith has been searching for her son since she was coerced into giving him up for adoption 30 years ago. When she started using the internet she received dozens of emails from people claiming to be investigators.

'These people trade on hope and fear,' she said. 'They offer a couple of names, charging up to £400 for what can be got off the electoral roll, and offer more information for more money. They've got no shame and no limits: they'll take you for everything you've got and leave you broken.'

fields.headline: Drug 'a £300mdrain on NHS'
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Jane Lewis has been crippled with rheumatoid arthritis for more than 30 years. Her inflamed joints and chronic fatigue disrupted her university career, forced her to use a wheelchair for many years, and left her with stomach ulcers triggered by her drugs. The condition has simply blighted her life.
fields.body:
Jane Lewis has been crippled with rheumatoid arthritis for more than 30 years. Her inflamed joints and chronic fatigue disrupted her university career, forced her to use a wheelchair for many years, and left her with stomach ulcers triggered by her drugs. The condition has simply blighted her life.

But salvation may be at hand. A revolutionary new drug, Enbrel, which is said to have transformed the lives of thousands of Americans in the past year, has been approved in Europe and will shortly become available in the UK.

But Enbrel comes with a high price tag. According to its manufacturers, Wyeth Pharmaceuticals, the drug will cost about £10,000 a year per patient, compared with the UK's current £1,000 annual average for rheumatoid arthritis medicines.

Given that an estimated 30,000 sufferers could benefit from the drug, doctors say its introduction is likely to add between £30 million to £300m a year to health budgets.

Nor will this funding dilemma be an isolated one. Scientists say that in the near future waves of other new drugs for conditions like diabetes will be released. Lessons learned with Enbrel could therefore have profound consequences.

The drug works by blocking the action of tumour necrosis factor which is released by the body's defence system when it mistakenly attacks the joint membranes.

Rheumatologist Professor Gabriel Panayi, of Guy's Hospital, London, said: 'It could transform lives, and although it is expensive, we should remember rheumatoid arthritis costs this country an estimated £1.3bn a year in medical bills, disability benefits, home helps, lost income and other outgoings.'

Health Secretary Alan Milburn has said he intends to look favourably at funding new medicines that promise significant improvements in patients' lives, regardless of cost. But mechanisms for providing such funding do not exist at present.

'What we don't want is postcode prescribing - people getting Enbrel because they live in an area where doctors have got spare cash to pay for it, and others being denied it because they live in the wrong place,' added Panayi. 'Yet unless we get some direct leadership from the top, this is the prospect we face.'

webTitle: 'Doing nothing is just not an option'

fields.headline: 'Doing nothing is just not an option'
fields.standfirst:
Opponents of the new controls are elitist, Thatcherite and afraid of democracy
Privacy on the net: special report
fields.trailText: Bad guys and mad guys are abusing the internet. Old crimes are being committed in new ways. Children, consumers, trading companies and financial institutions have all been targeted and harmed, some very seriously
fields.body:
Bad guys and mad guys are abusing the internet. Old crimes are being committed in new ways. Children, consumers, trading companies and financial institutions have all been targeted and harmed, some very seriously. No government can sit back and ignore these trends, and in the Regulation of Investigatory Powers (RIP) Bill our Government is trying to give law enforcement and security agencies some of the legal powers needed to catch up and help deliver what we all say we want the internet to be: a trusted medium.

The Bill has undoubtedly stirred up opposition, but it is a very unattractive opposition whose hallmark is elitist, largely Thatcherite, and contemptuous of the encroachment of 'non-expert' democratic politicians on 'their terrain'. At the core of the Bill's opposition are the usual suspects - commerce and big business - but they have succeeded in co-opting respectable parts of the UK's civil liberties communities.

One of the fiercest rows about the Bill has been engendered by the Government's proposals on encryption. Encryption technology allows anyone to encode any type of computer-based data. With the newer, stronger systems, once encoded the data becomes unrecognisable to anyone who does not have the correct key to unlock, to decrypt, the code. This might not only lead to a suspect escaping prosecution, but could also make it impossible for anyone to locate and help potential victims of any crimes which are being concealed under the encrypted cloak.

Encryption techniques have been around since the time of the Pharoahs, but now that they have become linked to the industrial scale and ubiquity of the internet they introduce a wholly new dimension. Science and technology potentially has given the criminal community the power to put aspects of their activity beyond any realistic possibility of surveillance.

In the Bill the Government is proposing to introduce a new power which would allow police to force a suspect to hand over the keys necessary to decrypt their files. Refusal to do so could result in a two-year jail sentence and a fine.

For those engaged in serious crimes, the temptation not to hand over the key will be huge. If you know you might be facing 20 years or life if the police get the evidence off your machine, what are you going to do? You will refuse to hand over the key and risk a maximum of two years and a fine. Several people have pointed to the potential unfairness of requiring someone to prove a negative: that their failure to hand over their key was not a wilful and deliberate act of defiance, but instead was the product of a genuine lapse of memory.

Let us not forget that the police would only have got the necessary authority to require the key to be handed over if they had first shown that they had reasonable grounds for believing that encryption technology was being used at the time, and a court was then later convinced beyond reasonable doubt that the accused's failure was deliberate.

The European Encryption Group Working Group says in its briefing paper on the Bill that it is concerned that this new power reverses the burden of proof and thereby 'deviates from the traditional structure of English criminal law'. The internet did not exist when 'the traditional structure of English law' was being put together and it seems to me we have a simple choice: we can either hang out a sign saying 'It's all over' and just wait for the next wizard invention to come out of Massachusetts or Seattle - or Barnsley, for that matter - and see where that takes us all, or we can recognise that the internet is creating new challenges which require new solutions, not all of which will necessarily be able to marry with approaches we have taken in the past. Surely no one is saying that all we have to do is ask someone if they will hand over their key and if they say 'Hey, I'd love to, but shucks, it just plum slipped my mind!' that that is an end to the matter? Maybe they are, but excuse me if I dismiss it for the nonsense it plainly is. Come up with a better solution and I'll buy it, but doing nothing is not an option.

Our political institutions are finding it hard to keep up with the pace of change being ushered in by the internet, and the commercial-industrial-technological complex which is driving it clearly has its own agenda and its own priorities.

So who will speak for civil society in this space? Who has the funding to commission independent technical research to come up with solutions to problems that industry thinks are benefits, or that it sees as being nowhere near as urgent as getting out the next release of an online game show?

We truly want a 'people's internet'. We need new institutions, perhaps ones which can work alongside the longer-established institutions of our democracy: trade unions, consumer and other interest groups, children's organisations, political parties and so on, both here and abroad, to start to take charge of an agenda which had been creeping up on us by stealth, but which now seems to be well and truly out in the open.

The internet carries with it great promise. We should settle only for the best it has to offer and reject the rest. Moreover, while we must always guard our liberties carefully and not give new powers to the state unthinkingly, we must equally not allow a simplistic and falsely-libertarian rhetoric to create a technologically driven nightmare in twenty-first century Britain. Techies do not rule, OK!

John Carr is internet consultant to NCH Action for Children and on the board of the Internet Watch Foundation, the industry's self-regulatory body.

webTitle: New web spy system is not up to the job, say the experts

fields.headline: New web spy system is not up to the job, say the experts
fields.standfirst: Privacy on the net: special report
fields.trailText: MI5 and the police faced embarrassment last night when electronics experts revealed that the new 'Big Brother' internet surveillance system - designed to enable them to monitor every internet user in the country - will not function properly.
fields.body:
MI5 and the police faced embarrassment last night when electronics experts revealed that the new 'Big Brother' internet surveillance system - designed to enable them to monitor every internet user in the country - will not function properly.

The Government Technical Assistance Centre (GTAC) will be introduced to the internet by the middle of next year. As a part of this facility, every Internet Service Provider in the UK will have to allow the police to fit a 'black box' to their computer systems. The black boxes will monitor emails sent and web pages accessed on that ISP. But experts fear the technology does not exist to monitor the enormous amounts of data that pass through ISPs.

Keith Williams, executive chairman of the London Internet Exchange, Europe's largest internet exchange, said: 'It is highly unlikely that any black box the Government will install shall attain the desired effectiveness. The public sector are not renowned for their use of the most up-to-date technology.'

The surveillance powers that the GTAC system will give the Government will be introduced under changes to the law made by the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Bill, now being debated in the Lords. The internet is developing at such a pace that any black box will most probably become obsolete in the estimated six months between when it is designed and built, and when it is introduced to the internet.

'Traffic on the internet has doubled every 100 days for several years, regardless of advances in technology' said Mitchell. 'For this reason, whatever technology they introduce will be much less effective within six months and the majority of it obsolete within a year.'

The system will cost an estimated £30m in the first year alone. As advances in technology make the internet faster, these machines will have even more data to process. Next year new ADSL internet connections are expected to be introduced, giving people internet access at 100 times the present speed through a telephone line. This will mean that the black boxes will have to be updated.

'It is clear that this year's box will not be next year's box' says Mitchell. 'The £30m is a recurring cost, payable each year.'

The Home Office has yet to give the specifications of these boxes and is discussing whether the taxpayer or internet users will pay for them. Campaigners fear that, however GTAC is funded, the eventual loser will be e-commerce in the UK as companies are forced to raise their prices to meet the costs of introducing such a system.

Tim Pearson, of the Internet Service Providers Association council, said: 'Mitchell is right in his diagnosis. What is more worrying is that the Government have yet to tell us exactly how they intend to implement this surveillance system. After several years of discussion, this is ridiculous. This is going to cost a lot more than the Government are currently saying.'

The Home Office last night responded: 'There will be no technical problems with this system. The appropriate technology will be employed and kept up-to-date.'

A Home Office spokesperson emphasised that GTAC will be primarily a centre for cracking the codes used to encrypt some internet traffic, and not directly connected to the black boxes.

He did concede, however, that information obtained by these boxes would be passed on to the GTAC centre.

webTitle: Civil service in web ads row

fields.headline: Civil service in web ads row
fields.trailText: Some of Britain's biggest companies are receiving free advertising on government websites in return for sponsorship and favours, an Observer investigation has discovered.
fields.body:
Some of Britain's biggest companies are receiving free advertising on government websites in return for sponsorship and favours, an Observer investigation has discovered.

Guidelines on such deals, intended to ensure openness and prevent companies receiving commercial advantages, are not being followed.

Companies involved include UK defence group BAe systems, telecoms operator Cable and Wireless, a leading firm of City lawyers, American drugs giant Merck Sharp and Dohme, as well as internet firms such as Lycos.

Internet experts indicate the value of advertising and sponsorship on government websites could run into millions. The Observer has established that:

 Companies receive advertising on websites without paying for it;

 Whitehall departments are accepting advertising while stating that they do not;

 Firms often receive these deals in return for favours - such as setting up or providing material for websites;

 Rules demanding that the value of these deals is spelt out are being ignored;

 Regulations banning sponsorship or advertising from firms involved in commercial negotiations with departments are being stretched.

The revelations have sparked a call for a ban on advertising and sponsorship on all government websites.

Liberal Democrat constitution spokesman Robert Maclennan, who tabled several parliamentary questions on the subject, says: 'These findings show that the integrity of government information is threatened. Advertising and sponsorship on government websites should be banned.

'There is disturbing evidence that many departments' use of websites does not conform with the Neill Committee's recommendations on openness. In particular, government departments are failing to make full disclosure of the details of sponsorship of their activities by the private sector.

'There is a very real danger that unacknowledged favours could be given to companies that directly sponsor government activity.'

Maclennan points to sites including an NHS one which has an advert for US drugs giant MSD.

webTitle: Hunt lobby scents blood at election

fields.headline: Hunt lobby scents blood at election
fields.standfirst: The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: Anti-blood sports MPs are under threat from a new Countryside Party which is to put up protest candidates at the general election.
fields.body:
Anti-blood sports MPs are under threat from a new Countryside Party which is to put up protest candidates at the general election.

The fledgling movement, set up by a former Countryside Alliance officer and a pro-shooting campaigner, plans to harry MPs in marginal seats by campaigning on rural grievances.

Labour's Michael Foster, who led the initial backbench campaign against blood sports, faces a challenge in his Worcester seat - captured from the Tories with a 7,000 majority in 1997. Seats in the West Country and Highlands are also likely targets.

Although the shoestring party has no chance of getting candidates elected, it hopes to cause maximum embarrassment in closely-fought seats where every vote counts.

The Countryside Alliance, whose president is Labour peer Baroness Mallalieu, has officially dissociated itself from the new party, arguing that voters should support those who can govern. But it in turn plans to mobilise its 387,000 supporters against anti-hunting MPs from all parties. It is drawing up lists of where candidates in rural seats stand on issues from blood sports to farmers' subsidies and the closure of rural schools.

The twin moves demonstrate the rural lobby's determination to turn the countryside into an electoral battleground, creating fresh headaches for Tony Blair.

The Government's much-awaited rural White Paper is being delayed until the autumn as Ministers struggle to strike the right balance. Labour faces clashes with the landowning lobby over the Countryside Bill's provision of a 'right to roam' for ramblers, with Tory peers threatening to wreck it in revenge for the hunting ban.

Ministers last week began making conciliatory noises to country voters, with Mo Mowlam promising an attack on rural poverty, and the Home Office more cash for rural policing. A Cabinet Office report on saving rural post offices is also imminent.

Peter Bradley, leader of Labour's rural MPs group, says his colleagues are bullish about their chances, saying: 'One of the reasons I think we may surprise a lot of people is because Labour MPs in rural seats have penetrated those parts of their constituencies the Conservatives never knew existed.'

However, the rural lobby insists the Government will feel a backlash at the polls.

The Countryside Party was launched in April by retired engineer Richard Malbon, chair of the shooting organisation, the Sportsman's Association of Great Britain, and Jim Crawford, an ex-regional officer for the Countryside Alliance in Scotland.

Operating on a shoestring, it has only a handful of active members so far. But Malbon, who describes himself as a disillusioned 'Tory with a small t', says it expects to fight at least four seats. 'We realise we have got an awful lot of work to do and not much time. But Foster's seat is a perfect one to go for.'

Although the Countryside Alliance politely wished the new party well, Alliance chief executive Richard Burge - a card-carrying Labour Party member - dismisses it as a pointless distraction.

The Alliance plans instead to interrogate all mainstream party candidates in rural seats on around 25 key issues, from hunting to closure of village schools, publishing the results before the election.

'We will make sure,' Burge says, 'that people know what their candidates think on particular areas. Hunting will be one of those, but they will be overwhelmed by the others. We will not tell them how to vote. We will say to our supporters, look at this and then you will go into the polling station and have that awful decision of "What do I do now?" for yourself.'

fields.headline: Net watchdog Bill faces axe
fields.standfirst:
Civil liberty and business lobbies campaign against proposal to intercept emails on the internet
Privacy on the net: special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw's much criticised Bill to regulate the freedom of the internet is facing disaster in the Lords as critics organise a guerrilla campaign against the Government.
fields.body:
Jack Straw's much criticised Bill to regulate the freedom of the internet is facing disaster in the Lords as critics organise a guerrilla campaign against the Government.

More than 48 pages of amendments have been proposed to block the Home Secretary's proposals to increase the powers of the police and MI5 to intercept emails and access personal information kept on computers.

Each of the 250 amendments will have to be discussed, delaying the Bill indefinitely and forcing the Government to give ground on key concerns over privacy and the costs to business.

Managers of the parliamentary work load are worried that delays similar to those suffered by the Financial Services Bill will block other Bills the Government wants to enact to show it is delivering on its election promises.

'It will be a misjudgment if they think they are going to get this through simply by saying businesses are crying wolf and civil liberty groups should not be listened to,' said Lord McNally, the Liberal Democrat peer who is leading the campaign against the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Bill.

'The more you look at it, the more you see the problems apparent in this flawed Bill.'

McNally said the Government would have to give ground on civil liberty and business demands before he and other peers would be satisfied. If the Government did not move, a coalition of Liberal Democrat and Conservative peers, together with the politically independent cross benchers and some Labour rebels, would join forces to wreck the Bill.

News of the hundreds of delaying amendments comes as Straw is put under increasing pressure to water down the Bill's proposals.

Businesses are furious at proposals forcing them to install internet 'black boxes' which could be used by the security services to look at confidential data.

The Home Office says the powers are necessary to prevent widespread fraud. It also wants to force private users to allow access to encryption codes for their computers as a weapon against paedophiles and other criminals.

Last week, Straw dismissed a claim by the British Chambers of Commerce that the need for black boxes would cost businesses £46 billion over the next five years.

There have been suggestions that up to 40 per cent of ecommerce companies could decamp abroad or go offshore if the Bill becomes law. 'The important thing is not to shoot the business goose before it lays any golden eggs,' McNally said.

Straw said critics were relying on scaremongering to try to undermine the Bill. 'It is unclear how the £46bn figure is arrived at,' he said in a letter to the Financial Times . 'The year-by-year estimates are literally incredible. The BCC document is riddled with flawed assumptions.'

He said crime cost the country £50bn a year and that new powers were needed so that 'ecommerce is better protected from user attack by serious criminals'.

The Confederation of British Industry and the Institute of Directors have raised concerns about the Bill.

Last week, Stephen Byers, the Trade and Industry Secretary, said he was aware of business concerns. 'The question is, what does the Home Office know about the commercial world,' one source said. 'The answer is, not much.' The new regulations were originally proposed as a DTI Bill, but it was moved to the Home Office when the criminal ramifications became clear.

Civil liberties groups have said the Bill contains attacks on people's freedom. The Home Secretary will have powers to demand keys that allow the public to encrypt work on their computers.

If people fail to hand over the keys or forget their encryption codes they face going to prison for up to two years.

Why the Government says the RIP Bill is a good idea...

 Gives police powers to monitor and intercept emails and websites through which criminals have been able to communicate.

 Some data on computers, like child pornography, is encrypted. The Bill makes it illegal to not decrypt data when police ask.

 It brings the UK into line with the surveillance measures of some other European countries.

Why campaigners say the RIP Bill is a bad idea...

 Cost and maintenance of necessary surveillance equipment will be passed on to internet user, threatening UK's competitiveness as an ecommerce market.

 The Bill allows government to monitor sites you visit and who you email - without a warrant.

 You could be jailed for two years for forgetting passwords.

webTitle: 'Dated' Evans faces the last TFI Friday as lads

fields.headline: 'Dated' Evans faces the last TFI Friday as lads
fields.trailText: Chris Evans's television show TFI Friday, once considered the flagship of the New Lad culture, is facing the axe. Tim Gardam, head of programmes at Channel 4, has told colleagues it is 'unlikely to be recommissioned' and he is looking for replacement formats. The last edition is now expected to go out in November.
fields.body:
Chris Evans's television show TFI Friday, once considered the flagship of the New Lad culture, is facing the axe. Tim Gardam, head of programmes at Channel 4, has told colleagues it is 'unlikely to be recommissioned' and he is looking for replacement formats. The last edition is now expected to go out in November.

The red-headed millionaire 'roaring boy' of the Nineties no longer fits the image the channel wants to project to its younger viewers. Evans's former adversaries in radio and television production will be pleased to hear that his legendary interest in starlets and lager drinking is about to be officially stamped 'out of date'.

The music and chat show, which revolves around the personality of Evans, has been running for five years, and initially built a big following among members of a thriving, youth-oriented culture. Speculation that its fortunes were going downhill has been rife in TV circles since early spring, but Channel 4 repeatedly denied any decision had yet to be taken.

Evans has been involved in lengthy discussions with the station's commissioning editors since research showed that his show was no longer watched by the younger viewers. Channel 4 wanted it to appeal to viewers aged between 16 and 25.

But those who hope they have seen the back of 'Evans TV' are likely to be disappointed. Channel 4 is aware of the creative clout wielded by both Evans and his company, Ginger Productions. The new late-night show The Priory, also made by Ginger and hosted by twentysomethings Zoe Ball and Jamie Theakston, has proved a success with young viewers this year. One scenario would see Evans and the TV company kept happy by moving him into a more 'middle of the road' chat show. Channel 4 played a careful game in the spring because it feared either of its keenest rivals, BSkyB and Channel 5, would pick up TFI Friday once Channel 4 admitted its intentions.

While the show has lost its cutting edge - and is no longer broadcast live - it is still a desirable product, and draws as big an audience as it did two years ago, a creditable 2.5 million. It goes out at tea-time on Fridays and is repeated on Friday nights. Evans's reputation for acting on impulse when his services are not appreciated is a worry to Channel 4 chiefs. He walked away from Radio 1's breakfast slot after clashing with the station's then controller, Matthew Bannister.

Evans, 33, made his TV name on Channel 4's The Big Breakfast before striking out to run and present the acclaimed Don't Forget Your Toothbrush for the same station. He recently sold his firm Ginger for £75 million.

Since TFI started, he has stayed in the headlines with a series of publicity stunts, which some believe include staging a one-week relationship with former Spice Girl, Geri Halliwell, last year. In September, he was upbraided by the Independent Television Commission for making a child guest cry during a TFI Friday contest.

fields.headline: Racists rule streets of Ireland
fields.standfirst: A horrific attack has left black people in fear of their lives in a country known for its 'thousand welcomes', reports John Sweeney
fields.trailText: It had been a double celebration in the land of a thousand welcomes. English couple David and Laverne Richardson were on their first trip to Dublin, marking their wedding anniversary, to visit their 25-year-old son, Christian, who was the birthday boy.
fields.body:
It had been a double celebration in the land of a thousand welcomes. English couple David and Laverne Richardson were on their first trip to Dublin, marking their wedding anniversary, to visit their 25-year-old son, Christian, who was the birthday boy.

The threesome left the Thai restaurant and, no taxis being around, started the long walk to Christian's flat when the trouble started. The family come from Bristol but whereas David is white, Laverne and Christian, who moved to Dublin for work, are black.

'Niggers out,' 'black bastards' and 'monkeys' shouted a group of white Irish yobs standing outside a chip shop on Pearse Street, just north of Trinity College. They threw beer cans at the Richardsons as they hurried away.

Mrs Richardson said: 'We kept walking, trying to ignore them but they kept shouting at us.' Christian said: 'They left me alone but they went for my parents. One was trying to grab my mum's bag. I was trying to defend them both. Then I heard my mum scream: "He's got a knife." Suddenly there was blood everywhere. It was awful.'

Mrs Richardson recalled: 'Christian was jumping in the middle of the road asking people to stop, but no one did. I was really terrified. By the time it was all over David was lying on the pavement. Blood was pumping from his mouth and back. A woman came along and put a bag under his head and by then there were loads of cars around us. But it was too late by then. It was too late.'

David Richardson, 46, is still in intensive care, with stab wounds to his chest, shoulder and neck. Doctors fighting to save his life pumped in 18 pints of blood during surgery last Sunday at St James's Hospital. The family was warned not to have high hopes earlier in the week, but the latest news is that Mr Richardson, though severely ill, is a little better.

Later, the Garda raided houses nearby and recovered blood-stained clothing. Three arrests have been made and DNA tests are being carried out.

This openly racist attack was by no means the first in Dublin this year. Irish MP Frances Fitzgerald believes that the 'growing number of attacks' shows there is 'now a crisis on our streets'. Some 27 unprovoked assaults were reported in the first three months of the year, she said.

Like the rest of (rich, white, northern) Europe, Ireland is now receiving more asylum-seekers than ever before. The Irish Home Affairs department deals with up to 1,000 asylum-seekers a month, up from just 39 in all of 1992. Most come from Africa and eastern Europe.

The pressure comes partly because of Ireland's economic miracle. The country which for most of its life has bled emigrants is now attracting immigrants on a scale never before imagined. The rest of northern Europe has, to a better or worse degree, come to terms with a multi-cultural society, but Ireland is probably the most 'white' country in western Europe. It is true that racist attacks and murders take place with depressing frequency on the other side of the Irish Sea, but legislation is in place in Britain to counter racist crimes. No such legislation exists in Ireland, and many African refugees have little respect for the Garda, the Irish police.

In April, a group of around 70 African asylum-seekers and refugees protested in Dublin city centre after a Nigerian teenager was attacked and left with head injuries.

It's never-ending. I have suffered all sorts of racial abuse. Once someone spat in my face. Some fellows urinated in my letterbox. I have been called "nigger" countless times, and had my apartment spray-painted with obscenities.'

On 30 May he went with a friend to give a lecture on racial awareness to a youth group in inner city Dublin. His friend's car was wrecked by a group of youths, armed with knives. 'There was nothing we could do. We phoned the Garda three times and no one came. Meanwhile, these youths pulled the car apart. Eventually, we flagged down a passing Garda car and they organised someone to take the wreck away.'

Tambwe recalled that a friend of his had been attacked in a nightclub, with someone breaking a bottle on his head. Far from coming to protect him, 'the bouncers grabbed him by the throat and threw him out of the club. When the ambulance came, the ambulanceman made a racist remark: "if you were in your country, you wouldn't get this help. Go back home".'

The racism of the ambulanceman was, Tambwe believed, indicative of Ireland's true attitude towards black asylum-seekers.

Then something happened to suggest he was not exaggerating. As my colleague took his photograph, a grey van crawled by and the - white - passenger yelled abuse at Tambwe. In the centre of Dublin the grey metal shutter of what was an Afro-Caribbean shop has been daubed with the word 'nigers' - the racists can't spell - which no one in authority has cared to clean up.

'I wasn't born a refugee or an asylum-seeker. It's my circumstances,' said Awogboro. He said he wanted people in authority to 'accept us for what we are and to sympathise with us. I don't want to live like this. I want to be part of this society.'

Awogboro said Irish immigrants in the US were not called refugees, they were called Irish Americans, 'so why not have a change of policy in Ireland?'

Ireland's record is by no means all bad. In Kildare, an old army barracks square has been converted into a trailer park for refugees from Kosovo. Fellanza Balaj, 17, from Pristina, pointed to 21 teddy bears she had been given by Irish well-wishers. 'It's been great here. I have lots of Irish friends, and I work in the pizza factory. I want to go home because I miss home, but I love Ireland.'

Her brother, Mohammed, sports a Guinness T-shirt and a soft Irish brogue. 'I had to learn the accent because everybody kept on saying "wha?" It's easy for us [but] at the mosque in Dublin I meet Algerians, Iraqis, and they say it is very difficult for them. We are war refugees and everyone understands that. But for the others, life is not so good.'

Fellanza and Mohammed may have been too polite to say so, but they are white. Well, now I know. When I walk down the street I keep on looking around, just to check that no one is going to hit me.'

fields.headline: Women wave bye-bye to Tony
fields.standfirst: Labour's gender gap nightmare returns, says  Kamal Ahmed,  as voters condemn 'broken pledges'
fields.trailText: In the front room of an unassuming house in Enfield, north London, Deborah Mattinson poured a glass of wine and sat back to listen. Sitting around her were eight women recruited two weeks earlier to tell Mattinson their views on the Government. The message was not a happy one.
fields.body:
In the front room of an unassuming house in Enfield, north London, Deborah Mattinson poured a glass of wine and sat back to listen. Sitting around her were eight women recruited two weeks earlier to tell Mattinson their views on the Government. The message was not a happy one.

Mattinson had set up the focus group meeting earlier this year to investigate one of the most important issues facing Labour: why are women turning against the Government? It was 6pm when the first group filed in and, nervously at first, started to explain how they felt.

The meeting lasted 90 minutes. A second one of similar length followed. As they sipped their Chardonnay, the mood became more gloomy. On health, education, support for families - 'We thought this Government was going to be different,' the women said. 'We were wrong.'

Behind a set of double doors in the corner of the room, unknown to the eight women, sat Harriet Harman, the former Social Security Secretary, who was in the final stages of writing her hard-hitting report on Labour's relationship with key women voters.

She was not surprised by what she heard and her report, written with Mattinson and published today, reveals the depth of the problem. Whether it is Worcester Woman (the fabled resident of Middle England who reads the Daily Mail and worries about her local grammar school closing) or Wigan Woman (a new incarnation raised by the report, more heartland orientated, the single mother struggling to keep a job) the Government is not getting its message through.

'There is an emerging dissatisfaction gap,' the report, 'Winning for Women', says. 'Women voters - especially those in the 35-44 age group -- are significantly less likely to be satisfied with the Government's performance than are men. This confirms an underlying vulnerability in Labour's support that could cost votes at the general election.'

'It's a missed opportunity, so much was promised,' one woman said. 'They're too timid, too afraid of rocking the boat.' Another said: 'I feel they've been quite dishonourable, all those broken election pledges.'

The message first started filtering through last summer as research revealed an increasing 'voter problem' among women. Yes, the Government had done a lot with the New Deal, the Working Families Tax Credit, new maternity rights: but women thought the arrival of Blair meant a new type of politics. They felt disappointed.

At the time the Government was still miles ahead in the polls; maybe it was a mid-term blip. But Harman could see the first flicker of something vital to Blair's future electoral success . If women start deserting Labour, it is only a matter of time before that disaffection turns men away as well.

Harman agreed to write an article for the Labour modernisation journal Renewal , raising the issue for the first time. Mattinson's research backed up her feelings, and in January the two women arrived at the Commons to brief backbench MPs. But it is only now that the full seriousness is becoming clear.

Mattinson is someone who has to be listened to. The chairwoman of the political analysts Opinion Leader Research has deep connections with Labour. She has the ear of key Downing Street strategists and is likely to be closely involved in preparing the election campaign.

The document drawn up by Mattinson and Harman has been passed to Downing Street, where officials are beginning to work out a way to halt the slide. It will be a difficult task. The report says much needs to be done to convince women that Labour is for them. It highlights their 'growing impatience that Labour should deliver on the areas of their key concerns; health, education and helping them manage their complex lives'.

On a whole raft of issues Labour is failing. There is too much testing in schools ('I'd abolish testing, it takes up too much time,' one woman said); the Government has missed out on health ('If I or my child go to hospital, we'd like to be looked after by someone who hasn't been on duty non-stop for 48 hours'); middle-income women feel they are being squeezed between rich and poor ('It's the likes of us, people in the middle, that get hit, we miss out on every score').

It was very different on that sunny day in 1997 when Blair walked onto College Green and was photographed with 101 women MPs.

'However, by May 2000,' the report says, 'the symbolic disappearance of prominent women had not gone unnoticed. Women are felt to be marginalised - further rein forcing the view that it is business as usual rather than time for a change.'

It is a problem that goes back many years. Even in 1997, Labour's best-ever electoral year, female support was 2 per cent higher for the Tories than for Labour. Now the gender gap is in danger of growing again.

The slow handclapping from the WI 10 days ago was more than a protest from a few bad-mannered blue-rinsers. It added to the impression that the Prime Minister is out of touch with huge swaths of the electorate.

Blair made the point then that Labour 'should not fight for every headline'. He should take it on board. The report says that nothing irritates women more than the constant stream of multi-billion-pound announcements that peppers the media.

'Women voters are not impressed by announcements about millions of pounds to be spent on health and education; they simply become cynical if they do not see improvements at their local school and hospital,' the report says.

Blair has now warned colleagues against ratcheting up spending pledges, as this can lead only to disappointment. It may be too little too late. Blair has called for an end to control freakery; for less centralisation; for more money to go into health and education. But the message is not getting through. And the more he fails to understand why, the more the women in that front room in Enfield will turn against him.

 Women in the key 35-44 age group are up to 13% less likely to be satisfied with the Government than men.

 In the 1970s the Gender Gap - the difference in support for Labour between men and women - soared to 12%. In 1997 it still stood at 2%.

 The 1997 general election was the first where, if only women had voted, Labour would still have won. Every other election has seen majority female support for the Tories.

 Women are waiting for the Government to deliver on their key concerns: health, education and the balance between home and work life.

 Of the 26 Labour seats up for re-selection only one has gone to a woman; 11 have gone to men and 14 are still to decide.

Rows in Parliament

Spin

Women like:

Delivering on policy

Women MPs

Health

Education

Family-friendly policies

fields.headline: End this barbaric pursuit now
fields.standfirst:
There is no case for fox-hunting

The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: Fox-hunting with packs of dogs has been one of the most contentious and hotly debated issues in British life for more than a century. This week, in a long awaited Bill, the Government promises to move to ban fox-hunting, so the debate will be joined again in earnest.
fields.body:
Fox-hunting with packs of dogs has been one of the most contentious and hotly debated issues in British life for more than a century. Its defenders insist that the issue is partly one of liberty, partly practical pest control and partly the continuance of the countryside's sporting and cultural heritage. Its critics insist that how a society treats animals is a fundamental statement of the values that underpin its civilisation - and that the sanctioned dismemberment of foxes by dogs is a foul stain on us all. This week, in a long awaited Bill, the Government promises to move to ban fox-hunting, so the debate will be joined again in earnest.

British public opinion has been solidly against fox-hunting for decades, with the recent polls suggesting that even in rural areas there is a massive majority against it. But that has not prevented the Countryside Alliance and other rural lobbyists from mounting a rearguard action against any legislative ban. They have campaigned on the chief elements on which their arguments depend - liberty, pest control, jobs and tradition - with calculated ferocity.

Last week's report on hunting with dogs, chaired by Lord Burns, the former head of the Treasury, removes much of the force of their argument. The estimates on job losses and the importance of hunting as a means of pest control have been vastly overstated, judges the report. There are no overwhelming economic or practical reasons to keep the sport alive.

The argument now revolves around the issue of liberty and raises the old conundrum of how much a society should allow individuals to follow their own interests and passions, even if they are against the settled will of the majority. In the past, The Observer has taken the view that one way through the maze is to offer individual counties the opportunity to have local referendums. But our view against fox-hunting has hardened, in part because of the self-serving, overblown and sometimes hypocritical arguments of the pro-hunting lobby.

The majority of Britons believe that animals should be treated with humanity. We have an exhaustive range of laws, covering everything from how we treat domestic pets to the conditions in which animals are killed in abattoirs. The liberty to visit fear, pain, mutilation and death on an animal is one that the majority are no longer prepared to grant.

fields.headline: The king? Not I
fields.standfirst:
Let Prince William lead his own life

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Happy birthday, William Windsor. From Wednesday, what you do with your life is for you to decide. At least it should be. But, unlike any other 18 year old, your future has already been chosen by your genes. The son of a plumber or a brain surgeon does not reach maturity knowing that his only destiny is to be a plumber or a brain surgeon. Your life is not your own.
fields.body:
Happy birthday, William Windsor. From Wednesday, what you do with your life is for you to decide. At least it should be. But, unlike any other 18 year old, your future has already been chosen by your genes. The son of a plumber or a brain surgeon does not reach maturity knowing that his only destiny is to be a plumber or a brain surgeon. Your life is not your own.

The future will be more than comfortable, of course, but think ahead to the endless tours of places that bore you, where you will be compelled to pretend to enjoy meeting people who do not interest you. Every detail of your personal life will be distorted and demeaned by a rapacious and salacious media which will treat you as a hero until they decide it is time to make you a villain.

Ahead of you stretch decades of time-filling until the day finally comes - and it may not arrive until you are a balding 60 year old - when the position decided for you by birth becomes vacant. And - who can tell? - you might get to the year 2042 only to find that you wasted yourself waiting for a job that has been abolished.

Is this really the life you want? The life that killed your mother and has driven your father half-mad. Say you won't do it. Abdicate the throne and renounce the crown before they imprison you. Take it back from history. Make it your own life. You will have come of age, and you might help your country to grow up as well.

fields.headline: Prince of the pin-ups
fields.standfirst:
The outpouring of pictures that reveal William at 18 are intended to show how ordinary he is. But, says Kathryn Flett, they do the very opposite.
The future of the monarchy: special report
The British Monarchy
fields.trailText: These studiedly 'casual' pictures of the heir to the throne's heir are attempting to sell us a paella-making, footie-loving, techno-dancing, Net-surfing, all-things-to-everyone People's Prince - a Diana with balls.
fields.body:
Despite the fact that these studiedly 'casual' pictures of the heir to the throne's heir are attempting to sell us a paella-making, footie-loving (though, puzzlingly, Aston Villa-supporting), techno-dancing, Net-surfing, all-things-to-everyone People's Prince - a Diana with balls - they serve mostly to highlight the extraordinary differences between William and practically every other 18-year-old in the country. I mean, his favourite sport is water polo. What is water polo, precisely? Are horses involved? Is it a part of the National Curriculum, alongside Lara Croft Studies and The History of Pokémon?

Yesterday, in the build-up to the England v Germany match, the tabloids seized gleefully on the shot of a smiling William in his 'jolly-good-show-old-sport' Union Flag waistcoat. Inspired by the Austin Powers films, emblazoned with the words 'Groovy Baby' and made for him by a Savile Row tailor, this cheery garment has, of course, absolutely nothing whatsoever to do with William's level of support for In-ger-land, but is worn simply as one of the arcane perks of being an Etonian prefect - or a member of 'Pop'.

This is, I suspect, an early 21st-century post-modernist 'Pop'-cultural signifier of the very first order: American actor playing a spoof 'British' cinematic detective inspires future English king and pupil at top school to make bold sartorial statement by which he can mete out discipline to his junior subjects while hoodwinking the proles that he is, perhaps, maybe, one of us.

Obviously one does not wish to imply that William's support for the national side is anything other than a given - despite the fact that it's quite a tough call genetically. Anyway, forget about the football team bonding pictures, or that one where he is clearly rustling up some Chicken Tonite as part of a Care in the Community project. Do not attempt to fathom the unfathomability of the one in the swimming pool in which he is wearing a Princess Leia hat (William is 'Keeper of Swimming' apparently, which sounds like a title bestowed by Yoda: 'You, William, are charged with the power to field The Force and Keep the Swimming, yes?').

Ignore, too, that full-length moody black-and-white taken in the sun-dappled cloister (he must have mislaid the teddy bear), because the only image that will inspire lip-tremblingly sentimental monarchists to update their dusty scrapbooks is the super-spooky Diana-clone shot - the one in which the pensive doppelgänger prince-in-a-polo-neck oozes depth, sensitivity and Boy Band glamour in equal measures, begging to be Blu-tacked right up there next to Ronan Keating on the dorm walls of a thousand pubescent Tamara Folkestone-Hovercrafts. And this is surely the picture that, autographed, will also make it on to the walls of Princess Britney's tour bus, too.

Yes, yes, I know he's gone to great lengths to deny their relationship, but this is clearly just a smart smokescreen to avoid getting duffed up by his chums and be forced to play the Wall Game all night in the nude. And, frankly, who can blame him?

So, anyway, Prince William is 18 and he seems like a lovely lad. Now could we just ignore him for a few more years, until either the official 21st-birthday photo session or a pap-snapped beach romp with Princess Britney, whichever comes first? No? Thought not.

webTitle: British score highest in sex league

fields.headline: British score highest in sex league
fields.standfirst: A new study  of sexual behaviour surprisingly shows Britons to be tigers and the suave Italians wimps
fields.trailText: British men, often portrayed as cold fish who prefer hot water bottles and nightgowns to nights of passion, can hold their heads high. The first atlas of sexual behaviour has revealed them as the sexual tigers of Europe. They start young, have lots of sex and last a lot longer than anyone else.
fields.body:
British men, often portrayed as cold fish who prefer hot water bottles and nightgowns to nights of passion, can hold their heads high. The first atlas of sexual behaviour has revealed them as the sexual tigers of Europe. They start young, have lots of sex and last a lot longer than anyone else.

In total, the average British person has sex 2,580 times during his or her lifetime, with five different people. However, they are also about the most unfaithful in Europe, with 42 per cent admitting to sexual infidelity.

Perhaps more shockingly, Italian men - dark, suave and sophisticated, and the supposed dream lover of every British woman - are revealed as the pandas of the Continent.

Their reputation as the world's hottest sex machines is shattered by a barrage of humbling statistics that reveal the naked truth: they start having sex late, they don't have it often, and when they do it's all over in the blink of an eye. In fact, Italians are the least sexually active people in Europe, and when they do have sex, it lasts the shortest time.

Every day 120 million acts of sexual intercourse take place around the world - resulting in 910,000 conceptions. On average, it lasts 21 minutes in the UK, compared with 17 in Germany, 14 in Italy and 10 in Thailand (where they do it quickest). The Brazilians, who average 30 minutes, are the world's sexual gold medallists (although 44 per cent of Brazilian women confess faking orgasms).

The Penguin Atlas of Human Sexual Behaviour - a serious academic study dressed up as soft porn - categorises each nation by its most intimate details, painting a fascinating but often bizarre insight into different cultures.

The revelations can be unflattering: 46 per cent of American women think a good night's sleep is better than sex. They can be disturbing: 23 per cent of Germans are sexually stimulated by underarm odour. And they can be upsetting: in Egypt, 80 per cent of women suffer female genital excision,although it is banned by law.

The author, Professor Judith Mackay, an adviser to the World Health Organisation and a fellow of the Royal College of Physicians, also helps explain the behaviour of certain relatives: 'Some aged ants, aphids, wasps, bees, naked vole rats and Caribbean snapping shrimps abandon procreation and invest their energies into helping relatives' genes survival,' she writes.

It isn't only the Italians who have their reputation shattered. Irish women - often portrayed as good girls oppressed by the weight of Catholicism -lose their virginity at 16, younger than most other women in Europe, a year before Swedish women and two years before British ones.

Other stereotypes are dramatically confirmed. Gallic pride is unchallenged, with the French having the most sex of anyone in Europe, doing it more than 130 times a year. Apart from the Irish, women from Finland, Denmark and Iceland are the most sexually advanced in Europe: on average, they lose their virginity at 16, and by the age of 18 around three-quarters of them are having sex.

In Europe, it's in the traditional Mediterranean countries that women develop latest. Only one in four women of 18 in Greece and Portugal is sexually active, and on average they wait till they are 19 to lose their virginity.

During the Second World War, jealous British men dubbed Americans as over-sexed, and little seems to have changed.

By almost all measures, Americans are more sexual than British people. Both men and women lose their virginity younger, and they have sex more times a year than their limey counterparts - and the sex lasts a lot longer (well, seven minutes).

However, the US is bucking one global trend. Whereas in most of the world, young people are becoming sexually active at an earlier and earlier age, it is rising in America - possibly as a result of increasing sex education. High school children are more likely to be virgins - and less likely to have had multiple partners - than they were 10 years ago.

Even so, the West is revealed as being far more sexual than developping nations - with the exception of Africa.

In the West, men and women lose their virginity at about the same age. But in most developing countries, women become sexually active much later than men. In Kazakhstan, Thailand, Ecuador and the Philippines, women usually lose their virginity after the age of 20.

In many developing countries, there are far stricter rules governing women's sexuality. In most of Asia, under 10 per cent of women younger than 20 have had sex outside marriage. In Britain and Germany, it is 70 per cent.

All over Latin America, women usually wait till they are over 18 for sex. For men, it is closer to 16. In some countries, such as Peru, statisticians claim men are losing their virginity three years earlier than women, which begs the question of who they are losing it to.

In stark contrast, women in Africa start having sex many years earlier than men. Throughout much of West Africa - including Mali, Niger and Guinea - women lose their virginity at 15 on average; in most of the rest of sub-Saharan Africa, it is 16. For men, it's usually a couple of years later.

These age differences are reflected in attitudes to marriage partners. Zambia and Nigeria are two of the most ageist countries in the world, with men looking for wives who are more than six years younger than themselves. In most of Europe, and North America, men look for wives who are less than two years younger than themselves.

The Atlas of Human Sexual Behaviour also grimly reveals the darker side - and dismal consequences - of sex.

Britain has more teenage abortions than any other county in Western Europe, with 20 per 1,000 women aged 15 to 19 having abortions every year, compared with two per thousand in Germany. In many other countries, the figure is far higher, with 45 per 1,000 teenage girls in Bulgaria having abortions every year.

It is not only teenagers who are unable to control their fertility. Worldwide, 300 million couples have no access to family planning. In Africa, less than 10 per cent of married women are using a modern form of contraception.

The lack of contraception is starkly reflected in the number of babies that women have. The average number of births per woman is under two everywhere, except Africa, Middle East and South Asia.

But, by a large margin, it is African women who have the largest families. They start young, with more than 10 per cent of teenage girls giving birth in Africa each year. In Guinea, one in four girls aged 15 to 19 gives birth every year.

By the time they have finished, women in almost all Africa countries have had more than five babies each. In Niger, they have eight babies each.

The lack of safe contraception is also reflected in the epidemic of sexually transmitted diseases, particularly Aids. Across the world, 18.4 million people live with Aids, but Africa is by far the worst hit continent. In all of southern Africa, more than 10 per cent of people are HIV positive. In contrast, Europe - with years of safe sex campaigns - has ended up the most Aids-free area of the world outside Central Asia and the Middle East. In Britain, fewer than 0.1 per cent of people are infected.

Sex has also become one of the world's largest industries. In Thailand, the sex industry is worth $25 billion a year, employing 200,000 child prostitutes. But that total is dwarfed by the US, with 300,000 child prostitutes, and Brazil, with 600,000.

British

World's highest number of unmarried teenage pregnancies. Average life includes sex 2,580 times with five partners. More stamina (21 mins), and more women under 20 who have extra marital sex, than rest of Europe.

Thais

Lose virginity very late (over 20 for women) quickest lovers in the world (10 mins). Less than 10 per cent of women under 20 have sex outside marriage while 90 per cent of Thai men have sex before marriage. Highest rate of condom usage in the world.

Americans

Into cyber sex - biggest users of online pornography. Americans ask for dates via email as much as face to face. Only country where the average age for virginity is rising. Longest sex sessions in the developed world (28 mins) and also the most sex in the developed world at over 130 times a year.

Brazilians

Make love for longer than anyone else (a worldbeating 30 mins). More partners in the last year than anyone else on the planet, and consequently more tolerant of infidelity than anywhere else in the world.

Nigerians

Less than 10 per cent of women use modern contraception. On average, each woman has more than six children. One in five teenage girls has a baby each year. Up to 5 per cent of them have Aids. Women lose their virginity young, with Nigerian men generally seeking wives who are more than six years younger.

Italians

These shy sexual pandas lose their virginity later than anyone else in Europe (19 for men, 20 for women), have less sex than anyone in Europe (less than 100 times a year), and have quickest sex in Europe (14 mins).

 'The Penguin Atlas of Human Sexual Behaviour' is published on 3 July at £12.99

fields.headline: Society is to blame
fields.standfirst:
Football thugs are made, not born

Football violence: special report
fields.trailText: Once again, England has been confronted by the shaming spectacle of its football fans running amok at an international football tournament. There will be the usual exhibition of hand-wringing and condemnation. But there are no excuses. It is time we faced the facts. It is English society that produces slobbishness, violence and xenophobia.
fields.body:
Once again, England has been confronted by the shaming spectacle of its football fans running amok at an international football tournament. There will be the usual exhibition of hand-wringing and condemnation. But there are no excuses. It is time we faced the facts. It is English society that produces slobbishness, violence and xenophobia.

The Conservative Party and its allies in the press like to mock political correctness, but the first target for change has to be the increasing cultural acceptance of a xenophobic attitude to foreigners - and that means the language which we use. The tabloid and right-wing broadsheet press and those who ape it on television and radio argue that their continual use of comic-book Second World War imagery over the Germans is no more than harmless fun. That the bile poured over the European Union is deserved. That the language used to describe asylum-seekers reflects the popular mood.

They are wrong. What has been constructed is a daily infusion of poisonous, mindless jingoism feeding prejudice and hatred. No less seriously, it is one that interacts with a growing sense of powerlessness and lack of self-esteem among those at the bottom of our unequal society. Typically, bullying and aggression stem from the weak rather than the strong. The drunk, violent, bare-chested English football fan, tattooed with the cross of St George, is the product of a winner-takes-all-society in which he has little chance, but which gives him the chance to ventilate his frustration by identifying foreigners as the enemy.

You will not read this diagnosis in the right-wing press that has done so much to produce this phenomenon, but that does not make it any less true. A liberal, tolerant, more equal society would produce less football violence. Until we have it, expect more of the same.

fields.headline: Pressing the PCC
fields.trailText: Lord Wakeham says that the Press Complaints Commission is an independent body because it has 10 lay people, including himself, not connected with the newspaper industry.
fields.body:
Lord Wakeham says that the Press Complaints Commission is an independent body because it has 10 lay people, including himself, not connected with the newspaper industry. But the PCC is funded entirely by the newspaper industry and therefore it pays his wages. How independent is that?
Terry Sanderson
London W5
