fields.headline: BBC staff fear Dyke onslaught
fields.standfirst:
In the rebranding of the BBC, current affairs looks set to be shunted into the graveyard slots.
The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Any traveller who returns from a long trip overseas this winter is likely to be baffled when they switch on the television. The great bongs of News at Ten will - in all probability - boom out from BBC1 while, half an hour later, Match of the Day's genial host Des Lynam will have been reunited with his old show over on ITV. Strange times, maybe, but the swap will hardly constitute radical change. More like a game of musical chairs.
fields.body:
Any traveller who returns from a long trip overseas this winter is likely to be baffled when they switch on the television. The great bongs of News at Ten will - in all probability - boom out from BBC1 while, half an hour later, Match of the Day's genial host Des Lynam will have been reunited with his old show over on ITV. Strange times, maybe, but the swap will hardly constitute radical change. More like a game of musical chairs.

The real changes are yet to come. And they will go to the core of what is still internationally understood, and revered, as 'British Broadcasting'. According to the director-general, Greg Dyke, and his newly invested sidekick, director of television Mark Thompson, the BBC brand must move on or die. The pair have prepared the way for the big announcements of this summer, when the DG will speak at the Edinburgh Television Festival.

Along with the mooted development of two new 'genre' channels - splitting television broadcasting into broad areas of appeal for age and interest - Thompson and Dyke are also determined to challenge the idea that populism - even commerciality - must always spell the end of quality television. The BBC should be giving the public what it wants and ought to quickly give up on the 'patronising' idea of trying to improve its viewers. 'Shouldn't the BBC focus on the tastes of the majority of people who actually pay for it, rather than on the rarefied cultural demands of the few?' asked Thompson in a key speech in Canada last week.

While hands are thrown up in horror at clumsy handling by the BBC of its flagship sports programme, the real battle for the soul of the corporation is being fought over the most sensitive area of all - the BBC's famed commitment to current affairs. Months into his reign, Dyke has managed to alienate the journalists regarded as the organisation's biggest asset.

To many, Thompson's speech appeared to call for the outright abandonment of BBC values. He, however, attempted to spike their guns by labelling them pessimists.

'To them the schedules of public service channels like our own BBC1 are loaded with symbolic meaning...a last bastion against the forces of commercialism and the global entertainment and marketing industries. Any change is almost bound to be for the worse. So they peruse the schedules and the programme-mix looking for the first sign of sell-out, of dumbing-down.' Already the first signs of strain are showing. Newsnight and Panorama, once-great bastions of public service news coverage, are both in limbo.

Newsnight retains good-sized audiences of around one million - good considering it is a late-night news programme - due in part to the charisma of Jeremy Paxman. But this month it has been badly shaken by the strong suggestion that the main evening news on BBC1 will be moved back to 10. The programme's presenters and reporters feel such a move would inevitably steal their thunder. How could they come on with their accustomed late-night authority, predicting the next day's big issues, if BBC1 had only just done the same? Worse, what if they were shunted still further back into the night? As reported in The Observer a fortnight ago, the current programme review considered moving them back to 11pm.

But the most concrete proof yet of growing unrest within the rank and file of BBC News and Current Affairs arrived on Friday. Tony Hall, the director of news and current affairs, sent out a clipped note of reassurance to all those involved with news gathering. It read: 'Earlier this week I said I'd keep you in touch with any developments in the Television Strategy. I thought you would like to know that the issue of moving Newsnight from 10.30 is off the agenda. As and when things become clearer, I'll let you know.'

This may not exactly qualify as glasnost, but it is a marked departure from the secretive management line on the review strategy so far. In the words of Thompson's speech last week: 'There are no sacred cows.'

If, suddenly, Newsnight qualifies as a rare - if not unique, sacred cow - the fear is that it may well prove to be to the cost of its equally revered colleague, Panorama . As one insider who works on the programme said: 'Dyke will only have given way in the case of Newsnight in order that he can gain ground somewhere else. Panorama will have almost nowhere to go now. It would be up against Newsnight if it followed a later BBC1 news programme and there is no obvious room left for it on BBC2.'

Those working on Panorama believe the Dyke approach to news and current affairs 'strands' within the schedule actually signals the end of public service broadcasting. 'They should say what they mean. Moving Panorama to BBC2 would just be the beginning. Next they would move it to BBC3, then BBC4 and then finally on to some digital news channel. The sad thing is, current affairs can be popular if it is done with confidence and with money, like 60 Minutes in America.'

Why on earth should the BBC ask for licence fee support if they are operating with commercial values?'

Panorama staff are also scathing about the idea that BBC2 could become the home of serious news, in the way that Radio 4 is, for example. Such a plan would go against the introduction of family programmes and arts and history zones under Jane Root and her predecessor. 'There is a real tug of war in BBC2. Jane Root does not like heavy current affairs programmes invading her channel.'

It was sold as the real This Life , which may have been a mistake. Insiders claim Root was only interested if cameras could follow barristers to their bedrooms.

Root denies the thrust of this story. There is no way, she told The Observer, that she would sanction that sort of invasion of personal lives of subjects in a documentary.

The BBC is involved, she conceded, in negotiations to produce a series about the legal process with access to a high-profile chambers. She may have spoken about the difficulty of telling the stories without going into court, but that is as far as it goes.

'We can find a place for programmes that are hard to schedule on BBC1 but which would be jewels in our crown. We can also innovate and enliven the BBC with new, unexpected programmes.'

Whether Panorama will hop channels is unclear. The strand has, though, recently been cut from 38 episodes a year to 30. This is a move that finds favour with some in News and Current Affairs.

One senior journalist said: 'I am in favour of BBC News trying to do a little less, but do it better. I would say 'distinctive' should be the key word if we want to survive, but unfortunately that does not seem to be the way we are going.'

webTitle: The long shot from Long Island

fields.headline: The long shot from Long Island
fields.standfirst:
When New York's Mayor Giuliani dropped out of the race with Hillary Clinton for the US Senate, a smiling lawyer came out of nowhere and is now neck and neck with the First Lady

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: At first it  was considered Rick Lazio's ill-fortune to be defined in terms of others. 'I was a nobody,' he said candidly on the radio last week. Lazio was the stand-in that the Republican Party was forced to scramble when the world's most famous mayor, Rudy Giuliani of New York, pulled out of the race against Hillary Clinton for election to the United States Senate. 'It was a tremendous shock to Rick,' says Andrew Siben, a friend of his for 15 years. 'He simply wasn't expecting it.'
fields.body:
At first it was considered Rick Lazio's ill-fortune to be defined in terms of others. 'I was a nobody,' he said candidly on the radio last week. Lazio was the stand-in that the Republican Party was forced to scramble when the world's most famous mayor, Rudy Giuliani of New York, pulled out of the race against Hillary Clinton for election to the United States Senate. 'It was a tremendous shock to Rick,' says Andrew Siben, a friend of his for 15 years. 'He simply wasn't expecting it.'

The nomination made Lazio the underdog in a contest with a superstar First Lady and her presidential campaign manager and formidable fundraising machine. When Lazio tripped up and fell flat on his face at a Memorial Day parade it augured ill, recalling a similar mishap that befell Bob Dole, who fell off a podium shortly before being trounced by Hillary Clinton's husband in 1996.

Over the past few weeks, however, Rick has achieved something remarkable. Lazio has stopped Hillary's juggernaut in its tracks. The First Lady - who had stolen a confident march against a Giuliani wounded by both health and marital problems - has peaked according to the latest polls. Now she is barely ahead of the young challenger.

Whether this is to do with Hillary's numerous blunders, or with Lazio's canny game, is open to question. Despite Lazio's grin, his smooth skin and inane, preppie good looks, he is a man fired by ambition - as scheming a politician as his party could ever hope for. He is not unlike his opponent's husband - a man whose rise in politics comes not from rocking the boat, but by angling endlessly for a chance to row it and be all things to all people. An examination of his voting record shows him to be a moderate Republican but with some good friends on the hard Right.

Lazio was born in 1958 in Lindenhurst, New York, son of a car-parts dealer. Hard to believe now, but he was a quiet, introverted child. The 1976 West Islip school yearbook features a picture of a cherubic young man in a Herman's Hermits haircut, a member of the coin and stamp clubs. Urged by his father (himself an eager Republican) to study, the young Riccardo Lazio won himself a place at the exclusive Vassar College, in the New York suburb of Poughkeepsie.

Vassar was an anomaly. It had, until a year before Lazio's arrival, been one of America's most exclusive single-sex, twin-set-and-pearls women's colleges. With the first intake of men - coinciding as it did with the era of student protest - old Vassar experienced a cultural meltdown. One college acquaintance of Lazio told The Observer : 'It was like this. People would knock on your door and ask you to sleep with them. If you said yeah, fine. If you said no, they'd just move on to the next room.' Another spoke about 'parties when I remember naked women swinging from the chandeliers'.

Throughout his time at college, however, and despite this bacchanalian atmosphere, Lazio faithfully dated a serious student called Jeanie McSweeney, who later went to work in the Ronald Reagan White House. For all the licentiousness of the day, Lazio and McSweeney did not have sex together until years into their relationship, according to those who know him.

In the meantime he was busy organising college Republicans to assist in the Mid-Hudson 1976 Congressional campaign of James L. Buckley. It was unsuccessful, but enabled Lazio to put some political credit in the bank. (During the recent scramble to find a successor to Giuliani, it was former Senator Buckley who invited Lazio to Washington for a crucial lunch with the Republican Party's national leadership. It was that meeting that clinched the nomination.)

Following in Giuliani's footsteps, the young Lazio became a public prosecutor and district attorney for New York's Suffolk County from 1983 to 1988. He then won an election to the county legislature and went into private law practice. By now, he and Miss McSweeney had parted company and he married Patricia Moriarty, a nurse.

In 1992, Lazio entered national politics with a dirty and dogged campaign, which everybody seems now to have forgotten, but which should serve as a cautionary tale to Hillary Clinton. It was a challenge for a seat in the House of Representatives against a formidable incumbent and 18-year political veteran, Tom Downey, who had been elected to Congress aged 25 and was fighting Lazio with a kitty worth $1.4 million. Lazio, in response, ran up 151 personal overdrafts worth $276,000 at various banks, rooted out an undeclared junket trip to Barbados that Downey had taken, plus a number of dubious patronage appointments he had made - and won.

Lazio's too-eager-to-please, genial veneer still conceals the steel that it took to beat Downey, maintaining his sugar-coated image in Republican Party's files as a 'retail campaigner'. One former aide recalls: 'He'd disappear on a weekend without a phone or pager, and we'd later find that he'd spent the day at the mall saying "hi" to people.' Indeed, the latest edition of New Republic magazine writes him off summarily as a 'fresh-faced Long Island Republican'.

At home, he likes to cut a liberal, gad-about-town social profile, to be seen at the most fashionable restaurants and bars. But he also has a track record of alliances with the hard Right. He manoeuvred himself into the inner sanctum of the disgraced former House speaker, Newt Gingrich, becoming his effective bag-carrier. He is currently one of the élite team that serves Republican chief whip Tom Delay of Texas, regarded as the hardest right-winger on the Washington block. He is also one of two special assistants to the Republican's House leader, the ruthless Dick Armey.

His allies call Lazio 'a bridge across the ideological spectrum with friends in every camp'. His enemies see in him a chancer, an opportunist, a man who will ride whatever horse will carry him furthest.

The idea is for everyone to find something in his voting record they can agree with. He challenged the National Rifle Association and in 1998 backed a reform bill to limit the amount spent on political campaigns, both of which angered his chums on the Right. Meanwhile, he has backed private-school vouchers and the $792-billion tax-cut bill, which were the brainchildren of those same chums.

All of which makes campaigning difficult for Hillary Clinton - and for Lazio. On Thursday, Hillary responded to poor poll results by taking the offensive and accusing Lazio of being a marionette for the gun lobby with a voting record 'against the interests of women and children'. None of which is strictly true.

Lazio had opened his campaign with a searing attack on Hillary's 'far Left' politics, which is an absurd description of a campaign desperate to roll back on as much radicalism as it can between now and November.

The upshot is that each is now biting and scratching like Brooklyn alley cats. Hillary should win, and probably will - the Democrats are gloating over the abyss in stature between Lazio and the First Lady - and while Lazio will fight with a smile, he will fight tough. And if he wins his victory would be the hardest blow of all to the precarious Clinton legacy.

Indeed, everyone in New York and beyond thought that the Clinton v Giuliani heavyweight bout would be the political equivalent to Clay v Liston. If so, Clinton v Lazio will be more like Fight Club, no rules and nasty.

Riccardo Lazio

DoB: 1958 (Lindenhurst, New York)

Lives: Bay Shore, Long Island

Married to: Patricia Moriarty (two daughters - Molly Ann and Kelsey)

Educated: Vassar College, New York; American University (law)

Job: Republican Congressman for the Second District, New York (since 1992)

Previous job: Assistant DA

webTitle: Cronje: mad, bad or  just plain greedy?

fields.headline: Cronje: mad, bad or  just plain greedy?
fields.standfirst: He was a hero to millions, but he threw it all away.  John Arlidge  and David Shapshak , in Cape Town,  ask what possessed him to pawn his place in history for a few tainted dollars
fields.trailText: When Hansie Cronje walked into the King Commission last week to face claims that he was at the centre of corruption in world cricket, the confident stride of a winning captain had given way to a hesitant shuffle.
fields.body:
When Hansie Cronje walked into the King Commission last week to face claims that he was at the centre of corruption in world cricket, the confident stride of a winning captain had given way to a hesitant shuffle. Gone was his trademark grim-faced but determined look. He entered, a man who had grasped temptation and was now walking under the floodlights of global humiliation.

In Cape Town's Centre for the Book, a cramped library, his demeanour was as dark as his moral gloom since his five-year flirtation with bookmakers and the illicit world of gambling was exposed just over two months ago. Never verbally forthcoming, the closest glimpse into the mind of South Africa's most successful captain was his painful understatement: 'Words cannot begin to describe the shame, humiliation and pain I feel in the knowledge that I have inflicted this on others. To my wife, family and team-mates, in particular, I apologise.'

For the normally unemotional Cronje, it was a remarkable transformation. Here was a man who was once the epitome of diplomatic impartiality, always neutral in his language. On the field, there was an edge, he was always tense - always the responsible one who, it seemed, could win games by sheer willpower. But last Thursday he was a picture of misery and humility.

Although he read out a damning confession, he maintained a strict coolness. The most emotional moment of his fall from grace had happened behind the scenes. It was on the morning of 11 April that the scandal broke: shortly after 2am Cronje addressed a handwritten letter to his pastor, Ray McCauley.

Referring to the approaches of bookmakers and the eventual temptation that he succumbed to, he said: 'When Satan comes knocking on the door, always keep your eyes on the Lord Jesus Christ and ask him to protect you from any wrong. The moment I took my eyes off Jesus, the whole world turned dark and it felt like someone had stuck a knife through my chest.'

When Indian police charged Cronje with cheating, fraud and conspiracy nine weeks ago nobody could have imagined the tawdry story about to unfold. Cronje's sordid confessions, laced with biblical references, have left South Africans at a loss to unravel the complex character of the most successful captain in Springbok cricketing history.

A once unblemished character in the eyes of an adoring nation, Cronje was a 'reborn' Christian who turned to God after accidentally killing a little girl who had darted in front of his car as he was travelling to Empangeni in Zululand for a provincial game in the early 1990s. After that day, he says, he has never allowed himself to shy away from his moral responsibility.

In his testimony last week he was quick to take all the blame himself. 'The greatest honour which can be bestowed upon any cricketer is to lead his country's national side. I have failed in my moral and professional duties.' Of his attempts to get his team-mates Herschelle Gibbs and Henry Williams to lie about the $15,000 he offered them to underperform in a one-day international against India, he said: 'I hoped to save them from the predicament in which I had placed them: instead I compromised them and worsened their position.'

For a broken man, who stands to lose all his income as well as his reputation, he insisted: 'My only consolation is the knowledge that, despite my inexcusable behaviour, South Africa has in fact never thrown or fixed a match.'

It is small comfort for a man who, until his fall from grace, had been too good to be true. Part of a minor cricketing dynasty - his father also played for South Africa - in the Afrikaner hinterland of the Orange Free State, Cronje made his provincial debut in 1987 at the age of 18.

By the age of 21 he was captain, before being selected for the national team at the age of 23. Two years later he was the team's regular captain.

But the Cronje story has many twists in it. The 'legend version' has it that Cronje was a symbol of the Afrikaner's journey out of the laager of apartheid isolation to the brave new world of internationalism, a post-apartheid hero for those still struggling to cast off the shackles of an apartheid mindset. But he was also an irritable adversary whose thirst for a win bordered on the fanatical.

In 1998 the Australian press all but called him a cheat after television footage showed him rolling the ball under his studded foot during a one-day international (players are not allowed to tamper with the ball or alter its shape). No official action was taken. During the same tour Cronje caused a stir when he hurled a stump through the door of the umpires' changing room after his side had lost a Test match they should have won in Adelaide.

It has been widely acknowledged that he stormed out of a meeting two years ago with Ali Bacher, the head of South Africa's United Cricket Board (UCB). When Bacher, who has striven to restore South Africa's credibility after decades of anti-apartheid boycotts, suggested the quota system proposed by the government to get more black players in the team should at least be tried, Cronje was defiantly opposed. He argued that Test players should be picked solely on merit.

The two were at loggerheads again last week. Cronje backtracked on Bacher's statement to the King investigation that Cronje had accepted between $10,000 and $15,000. He later recanted, but insisted he had not done anything to damage South Africa's reputation, nor had any of his team-mates. Amid the fall-out a simple question remains. Why did he do it?

There is a theory that Cronje has fallen on his sword for the good of his fellow-accused. This might be the case. He has, it is true, taken full responsibility himself. But he has done so reluctantly, flushed out by media insistence and without the fulsome explanation that the doubters still demand. He said as much himself, referring to Herschelle Gibbs and Henry Williams.

'It would be a tragedy if any of these players were to be lost to South African cricket because of my wrongdoing. I beg the commission and the cricketing authorities not to deprive the game of their talents and beg the UCB to reinstate both Herschelle and Henry to the national squad. Herschelle lied to the UCB, his employer, at my request. Herschelle, forgive me.'

Was Cronje almost a victim of circumstances - led on by mysterious forces which confused an otherwise first-rate player and religious man? Perhaps. Cronje himself has complained that pressure from bookmakers to throw matches was intolerable. Hundreds of offers were received from a string of bookies. In all, he says he accepted nearly $100,000 while turning away a further $620,000. Not nearly what he earns a year through his cricket contract and lucrative sponsorships.

In one episode Cronje recalled how a London book-maker called Sanjay gave him a cellphone box filled with US dollars in exchange for match information. Cronje said he had not counted the cash, which he kept at home in a filing cabinet with other money. While on tour in India in March and April last year, he was repeatedly pressed by Sanjay to fix results.

'The pressure was heavy...calls would come through to my room as late as two and three o'clock in the morning. 'I had taken money from Sanjay and it became increasingly difficult to resist his requests to...manipulate results.' Initially he held firm but later agreed to try to fix a game in Nagpur for $80,000. 'Since that day, in a moment of stupidity and weakness, I allowed Satan and the world to dictate terms to me, rather than the Lord. Bookmakers were calling me almost four times a day from then on.'

As for Cronje himself, he has a simple answer to the question of why he fell in with the bookies. He did it for 'greed' - pure and simple. Taking cash off bookmakers was 'an easy way to make money', he told the King commission last week. Cronje first took cash during a tour of India in 1996 when, he alleged, former Indian captain Mohammed Azharuddin introduced him to a bookie or gambler called Mukesh Gupta, known as MK.

'MK asked if we would give wickets away on the last of the Test to ensure that we lost,' said Cronje, who added that he never spoke to any of the players about this, but South Africa lost the match anyway. 'I had effectively received money for doing nothing,' he said. 'I thought I could keep the money without having to influence anything. But it became obvious that I had got myself into a situation which was going to be very difficult to get out of.'

Cronje was greedy, corruptible, dim and calculating. He was also vulnerable, indecisive and naive. In his case the combination was curiously combustible. Whatever the truth behind the downfall of an Afrikaner legend, he is, in the eyes of much of the South African public, a hero. The more he is flogged, the more he is loved.

An opinion poll by the Star newspaper in Johannesburg found that 94 per cent of respondents supported Cronje and/or believed he was innocent. Callers to radio stations were equally vocal in their belief that, even if Hansie had erred, he should be forgiven. Perhaps this is the proper Christian response. Truth and reconciliation, Nelson Mandela called it.
fields.bodyText: When Hansie Cronje walked into the King Commission last week to face claims that he was at the centre of corruption in world cricket, the confident stride of a winning captain had given way to a hesitant shuffle. Gone was his trademark grim-faced but determined look. He entered, a man who had grasped temptation and was now walking under the floodlights of global humiliation. In Cape Town's Centre for the Book, a cramped library, his demeanour was as dark as his moral gloom since his five-year flirtation with bookmakers and the illicit world of gambling was exposed just over two months ago. Never verbally forthcoming, the closest glimpse into the mind of South Africa's most successful captain was his painful understatement: 'Words cannot begin to describe the shame, humiliation and pain I feel in the knowledge that I have inflicted this on others. To my wife, family and team-mates, in particular, I apologise.' For the normally unemotional Cronje, it was a remarkable transformation. Here was a man who was once the epitome of diplomatic impartiality, always neutral in his language. On the field, there was an edge, he was always tense - always the responsible one who, it seemed, could win games by sheer willpower. But last Thursday he was a picture of misery and humility. Although he read out a damning confession, he maintained a strict coolness. The most emotional moment of his fall from grace had happened behind the scenes. It was on the morning of 11 April that the scandal broke: shortly after 2am Cronje addressed a handwritten letter to his pastor, Ray McCauley. Referring to the approaches of bookmakers and the eventual temptation that he succumbed to, he said: 'When Satan comes knocking on the door, always keep your eyes on the Lord Jesus Christ and ask him to protect you from any wrong. The moment I took my eyes off Jesus, the whole world turned dark and it felt like someone had stuck a knife through my chest.' When Indian police charged Cronje with cheating, fraud and conspiracy nine weeks ago nobody could have imagined the tawdry story about to unfold. Cronje's sordid confessions, laced with biblical references, have left South Africans at a loss to unravel the complex character of the most successful captain in Springbok cricketing history. A once unblemished character in the eyes of an adoring nation, Cronje was a 'reborn' Christian who turned to God after accidentally killing a little girl who had darted in front of his car as he was travelling to Empangeni in Zululand for a provincial game in the early 1990s. 'The greatest honour which can be bestowed upon any cricketer is to lead his country's national side. I have failed in my moral and professional duties.' It is small comfort for a man who, until his fall from grace, had been too good to be true. Part of a minor cricketing dynasty - his father also played for South Africa - in the Afrikaner hinterland of the Orange Free State, Cronje made his provincial debut in 1987 at the age of 18. But he was also an irritable adversary whose thirst for a win bordered on the fanatical. In 1998 the Australian press all but called him a cheat after television footage showed him rolling the ball under his studded foot during a one-day international (players are not allowed to tamper with the ball or alter its shape). No official action was taken. During the same tour Cronje caused a stir when he hurled a stump through the door of the umpires' changing room after his side had lost a Test match they should have won in Adelaide. It has been widely acknowledged that he stormed out of a meeting two years ago with Ali Bacher, the head of South Africa's United Cricket Board (UCB). There is a theory that Cronje has fallen on his sword for the good of his fellow-accused. This might be the case. He has, it is true, taken full responsibility himself. He said as much himself, referring to Herschelle Gibbs and Henry Williams. 'It would be a tragedy if any of these players were to be lost to South African cricket because of my wrongdoing. I beg the commission and the cricketing authorities not to deprive the game of their talents and beg the UCB to reinstate both Herschelle and Henry to the national squad. Herschelle lied to the UCB, his employer, at my request. Herschelle, forgive me.' Was Cronje almost a victim of circumstances - led on by mysterious forces which confused an otherwise first-rate player and religious man? Perhaps. Cronje himself has complained that pressure from bookmakers to throw matches was intolerable. Hundreds of offers were received from a string of bookies. In all, he says he accepted nearly $100,000 while turning away a further $620,000. Not nearly what he earns a year through his cricket contract and lucrative sponsorships. webTitle: Villagers massacred in bloody caste feud

fields.headline: Villagers massacred in bloody caste feud
fields.trailText: The chaotic state of Bihar confirmed its reputation as the most lawless place in India yesterday when gunmen from a private army massacred at least 34 villagers in a bloody caste feud.
fields.body:
The chaotic state of Bihar confirmed its reputation as the most lawless place in India yesterday when gunmen from a private army massacred at least 34 villagers in a bloody caste feud.

The black-clad gunmen descended on the village of Miapur early yesterday. They dragged villagers from their beds, lined them up and mowed them down with automatic weapons.

The victims were mainly members of the lower-caste Yadav. They included six children aged between five and eight. Twenty-two people died immediately and the rest later, intelligence officials in Patna, Bihar's capital, said yesterday. Eighteen were injured, 10 critically.

Detectives last night said the attack was carried out by the Ranvir Sena, a banned upper-caste landlord army whose murderous six-year feud with left-wing groups representing the lower castes has turned Bihar into a killing field. This latest massacre was the eighth major caste-related attack in the past six months. So far this month, 44 people have died.

Though no group claimed responsibility for the Miapur massacre, it is believed to be a Ranvir Sena revenge attack following the murder of 11 upper-caste villagers last Sunday.

Miapur, a remote off-road settlement, is only six miles away from Senari, where the Maoist Communist Centre (MCC) party slaughtered 34 of the upper Bhumihar caste in March last year.

'The situation in the village is very tense, with villagers complaining that, despite complaints to the local police that there might be attacks, no preventative measures were taken,' Manish Kumar, a reporter with Star TV, said yesterday.

About 400 police poured into Miapur yesterday, only to find that survivors were refusing to release the bodies of the dead until Bihar's Chief Minister, Rabri Devi, visited. Devi later arrived at the scene with her husband, Laloo Prasad Yadav, India's most notorious politician, who ran the state until forced out by corruption scandals and appointed his wife successor. Yadav, who emerged from poverty to be a champion of the lower castes, promised a government job to each family affected by the tragedy and ex-gratia payments of £1,500 per victim.

The massacre is set to plunge Bihar into violent political turmoil again. Last year a series of caste-related killings prompted India's Prime Minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, to try direct federal rule. But his proposal failed to get enough votes in parliament because it was not supported by the Congress party, the main partner in Bihar's coalition government. Congress is reconsidering its position following the latest killings.

webTitle: In the depths of the jungle a dark nightmare unfolds

fields.headline: In the depths of the jungle a dark nightmare unfolds
fields.standfirst:
The British withdrawal from Sierra Leone has left the country at the mercy of the rebels. Jason Burke in Freetown finds the peacekeepers' boasts ring increasingly hollow as the nation sinks further into violence
Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: The soldiers' eyes are glazed - though whether by drink, drugs or combat it is impossible to say. They walk along the clay road with the rain sluicing off their fatigues and bleeding away in thick streams through the red earth.
fields.body:
The soldiers' eyes are glazed - though whether by drink, drugs or combat it is impossible to say. They walk along the clay road with the rain sluicing off their fatigues and bleeding away in thick streams through the red earth.

The sky is dark and thick with clouds, and there is a distant thudding of thunder. It is hard to say what smells worse - the unwashed, drunken, beaten soldiers or the rotting vegetation all around.

This is the road to Mile 91. It stretches like a raw, red weal through the drab green jungle and swamp of central western Sierra Leone. To the North and East lie the ill-defined front line and rebel territory. To the South and West is land that the government and the United Nations, bolstered by the British armed intervention of four weeks ago, claim to control.

The British combat troops have now gone. The last Royal Marines have climbed aboard their helicopters. In a few days they will be in the bars of Tenerife. Two hundred men of the 2nd Battalion of the Royal Anglian Regiment have stayed on to train government troops. A few score specialists remain to advise the local government and armed forces on how to prosecute the war against the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) - the rebels who hold half the country and its crucial diamond fields.

Last Thursday John Prescott, the Deputy Prime Minister, sipped tea with the Sierra Leone President, Ahmed Tejan Kabbah, in Freetown, the picturesque capital, and restated the UK's long-term commitment to turning the West African state - a former British colony and now probably the poorest country in the world - into a stable, prosperous democracy. He sounded sure it would happen.

The UN spokesmen were equally optimistic. But hopeful words cannot hide the horror of the situation in Sierra Leone. This weekend the blithe assurances of the politicians, the British Army and the motley collection of UN 'peacekeepers' are looking increasingly unrealistic.

In the past three days the rebels have launched a dozen or more assaults on the UN and government positions. The UN dismiss the strikes as 'probing attacks' and the British military say the rebels have received a 'bloody nose'. But the highly mobile RUF is striking, seemingly at will, deep into 'government-held' territory. Though they have yet to inflict casualties, they have forced the government forces on to the back foot; 230 peacekeepers - and a British officer - are still surrounded by the rebels and key objectives remain unsecured. In fact, a glance at the map shows that Freetown's forces are barely holding on to the territory they recaptured following the arrival of British troops five weeks ago.

The RUF's grip on its diamonds, the lifeblood of the movement, is unthreatened. There have even been armed clashes between the disparate factions that make up the government forces. Though the UN and the British downplay them as 'ongoing squabbles', the most recent - on Thursday night - seriously rattled senior officers. Privately they admit that the cohesion of Freetown's forces is a grave concern.

Deep in the jungle, the most nightmarish of all scenarios is unfolding. It is estimated that more than 100,000 refugees have been displaced by the recent fighting. Many are without food and shelter. These are people who have watched close relatives raped and hatcheted to death, who have had their houses burnt down around them, who have survived for days on roots and mangoes.

Help will not come soon. A bid by the World Food Programme to distribute aid last week at a town only 30 miles from the vital Lungi airport was halted by an RUF attack. Aid workers describe the situation as 'an emergency' and speak of 'famine' potential.

This is a country where 12-year-old children carry British-issued automatic rifles, where barely pubescent girls talk of the men they have killed, where aid workers need a helicopter gunship flown by a South African mercenary to evacuate them when the UN retreat during a rebel attack, where for the price of a grilled chicken dinner women sell themselves on a beach as helicopters wheel overhead and Bob Marley pumps from a blaring jukebox. It is difficult to see much light in this darkness.

Thirty-five miles inland from Freetown is the town of Masiaka - a cluster of shacks and rotting, colonial-style villas. The government forces mass here before going up to the front. There are the official government soldiers in their newly issued British uniforms and weapons, the Kamajor irregular militia festooned with plastic charms, mirrors and conch shells and rumours of cannibalism, Gbenthi bushmen armed with hunting rifles and spiked clubs. One old bungalow, its colonnades rotten, mildewed and pocked with bullet scars, serves as the headquarters of the 'West Side Niggahz' - the name has been sanitised by the authorities to the 'West Side Boys'.

Smoking cannabis and sucking 'gin popsicles' - fiercely alcoholic ice lollies - the fighters loll in rotten armchairs with rocket launchers and machine guns scattered around them. A bucket of potent palm wine lies empty but for a few cloudy dregs. Bullet belts gleam dully in the flat afternoon light.

Just over a year ago these fighters joined the RUF in 'Operation No Living Thing' and raped, burnt and looted their way through Freetown. President Kabbah fled. Now they are fighting on the government side and, for the moment, have restricted their criminal activities to stealing British-supplied weapons from their supposed comrades and extorting money at vehicle checkpoints. Last week there were two shoot-outs between the West Side Niggahz and government troops. No one doubts that more will come.

The Observer visited Masiaka to watch the handover of 134 children who had been freed from the rebels. In the derelict school where they were housed they told their stories. The younger ones, some only five or six, had been camp-followers, washing clothes and fetching firewood for the soldiers. But many of the older children were fighters.

Mariana Mansaray, 15 and wearing a blue gingham shirt and green skirt, was one. A facial tic and appalling stammer made it virtually impossible for her to talk. Slowly and painfully, she told how she had been abducted by the rebels two years ago, repeatedly raped and then injected with some kind of drug. At first she had carried ammunition to the frontline troops but was soon in combat herself. 'They gave me drugs, sir,' she said with her entire jaw contorted into a rictus of pain as she tried to speak. 'Then I was fighting for them, sir.' How many people had she killed? Her neck muscles - standing out like steel cables - pulsed and spasmed before she choked out the answer. 'Plenty,' she said.

Around her sat others with similar stories. One seven-year-old boy spoke of how his 25-year-old father had initiated him into the RUF by teaching him how to hack off arms - the rebels' calling card since their bid to stop people voting in Sierra Leone's 1996 election from which the RUF was banned. He was taught to ask if his victims wanted 'long' or 'short sleeves' - amputation above or below the elbow. Others spoke of watching their villages burn to the ground or how the rebels had killed their parents and then given them the stark choice: join up or die.

A short distance from the old school a hundred or so government soldiers were piling on lorries to take them up to the front. Many were staggering drunk and waved their rifles and 'gin popsicles' in the air. One sucked on a joint and tried to blow the smoke into the mouth of the regimental mascot - a monkey.

Their commander, Colonel Anthony Mansare, stood near by. 'High spirits are no problem,' he said. 'The rebels are all around, so we need to be motivated. They are fast, so we need to be faster.'

Quite how easily the rebels could strike was shown later when, just a few miles away, a detachment of RUF in canoes attacked a Jordanian unit guarding a key bridge and, having been driven off, torched a local village. The Jordanians were at least 20 miles to the rear of the forward-most UN troops and 50 miles behind the front.

Brigadier Gordon Hughes MBE is the commander of the British forces remaining in Sierra Leone. The largest detachment is based at Benguema - a small town astride the road the RUF took last month in its blitzkrieg advance that threatened the capital city and precipitated the British intervention. The Royal Anglians will be there for six weeks. 'They are ready for any eventuality and will defend their positions,' said Hughes, a tall, lean, earnest man. However, he was at pains to stress that their main role was training a thousand carefully screened troops to form the core of a new government army.

Marching on Benguema camp's drill square the new recruits looked fit and motivated. There are fears, though, that their immediate impact on a 10-year-old war may be limited. 'We are here for the long term,' Hughes said. 'It could be weeks or months or years.'

Spread out through Freetown are the headquarters of the various components of Unamsil - the United Nations Mission to Sierra Leone. The UN force is being brought up to its full strength of 13,000 and there are moves to provide another 3,500 troops and strengthen its mandate. There are the Jordanians and the Indians, but also Kenyans, Zambians, Pakistanis, Guineans, Bangladeshis and men from a dozen other countries. The key element are the battle-hardened Nigerians who last year drove the RUF and its allies out of Freetown to end a two-month-long occupation.

In May, UN units fled in the face of the rebel advance, leaving weapons and even armoured personnel carriers behind. Now officers are sure that Unamsil will stand and fight. 'This is a test case for peacekeeping,' said one UN official. 'We can't afford to fail. The worry is that if we stay the course we will get sucked into a UN version of Vietnam.'

Brigadier Hughes last week called on the RUF to 'give up the fight'. But few believe that the rebel leadership will heed his call even if their troops want them to. In recent weeks the rebels have suffered reverses: they been forced to abandon their recent gains and their leader, Foday Sankoh, has been captured. But the conditions that led to the creation of the RUF remain broadly unchanged.

The movement burst on the scene in 1991, a few years after Sankoh and Charles Taylor, the current President of neighbouring Liberia, met in a Libyan training camp. When in 1990 Sierra Leonese forces came to the assistance of government troops fighting Taylor's brutal insurrection in Liberia, a scheme the two men had hatched while guests of Libya's Muammar Gadaffi was put into action.

Sankoh launched the RUF, forcing Freetown to pull back its troops and allow Taylor to batter his way to power. The pay-off was the diamonds. The RUF seized the great mines in the south of Sierra Leone and Sankoh - made Minister for Minerals in return for a truce last year - split the multi-million-pound proceeds with his friend. Taylor has always ensured that the RUF has sufficient weaponry, mainly brought in from Eastern Europe.

Now, with Sankoh in jail, radio intercepts reveal that the Liberian leader is actually directing the RUF's operations in person. 'Take away the diamonds and the RUF will collapse,' a senior British officer said briskly last week and though there are other factors - economic and ethnic - he was basically right.

Pressure is slowly being brought to bear on Taylor. Last week the European Union blocked a £33m aid package to his country - but no one expects the Liberian President, or his brutal proxies within Sierra Leone, to be denied the diamonds soon. And as long as the RUF has diamonds, Sierra Leone will have a war.

From Masiaka the road to Mile 91 leads east - lined with wrecked vehicles and the shells of buildings destroyed in the various bouts of fighting that have racked the country in the past 10 years. The UN has said that it was unsafe but officials of the Red Cross agreed to take The Observer to see the scale of the unfolding humanitarian crisis. At almost every village refugees swarmed around aid distribution points, clamouring for a bucket, blankets and some plastic sheeting. A little flour and oil would come later from the World Food Programme. They all told similar stories. They could not stay at home because it was too dangerous.

Most came from Lunsar, where fighting between government troops and the rebels has been raging for nearly two weeks. Others came from the town of Makena which, they said, was being sytematically levelled by the RUF. Kardiatu A. Kamara was typical. A 28-year-old teacher, she had left Lunsar a week ago to trek with her nine-strong family along jungle paths to reach a village close to Mile 91 where she had heard there was shelter. She was heavily pregnant, so the 30-mile trek had taken four days.

'It was terrible,' she said. 'We dug wells for water and lived on [cassava] roots and leaves and some mangoes when we found them. The rebels took all our money and food and most of our clothes when we left our home. Now we have nothing.'

Kamara said her 13-year-old brother was sick with 'swell-swell' - chronic infection caused by insect bites and lacerations sustained during the walk. His limbs and face were puffed up to twice normal size. She was afraid he would die. Many had lost relatives in recent days. fields.bodyText: The soldiers' eyes are glazed - though whether by drink, drugs or combat it is impossible to say. They walk along the clay road with the rain sluicing off their fatigues and bleeding away in thick streams through the red earth. The sky is dark and thick with clouds, and there is a distant thudding of thunder. It is hard to say what smells worse - the unwashed, drunken, beaten soldiers or the rotting vegetation all around. This is the road to Mile 91. It stretches like a raw, red weal through the drab green jungle and swamp of central western Sierra Leone. To the North and East lie the ill-defined front line and rebel territory. To the South and West is land that the government and the United Nations, bolstered by the British armed intervention of four weeks ago, claim to control. The British combat troops have now gone. The last Royal Marines have climbed aboard their helicopters. In a few days they will be in the bars of Tenerife. Two hundred men of the 2nd Battalion of the Royal Anglian Regiment have stayed on to train government troops. A few score specialists remain to advise the local government and armed forces on how to prosecute the war against the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) - the rebels who hold half the country and its crucial diamond fields. Last Thursday John Prescott, the Deputy Prime Minister, sipped tea with the Sierra Leone President, Ahmed Tejan Kabbah, in Freetown, the picturesque capital, and restated the UK's long-term commitment to turning the West African state - a former British colony and now probably the poorest country in the world - into a stable, prosperous democracy. He sounded sure it would happen. The UN spokesmen were equally optimistic. But hopeful words cannot hide the horror of the situation in Sierra Leone. This weekend the blithe assurances of the politicians, the British Army and the motley collection of UN 'peacekeepers' are looking increasingly unrealistic. In the past three days the rebels have launched a dozen or more assaults on the UN and government positions. The UN dismiss the strikes as 'probing attacks' and the British military say the rebels have received a 'bloody nose'. But the highly mobile RUF is striking, seemingly at will, deep into 'government-held' territory. Though they have yet to inflict casualties, they have forced the government forces on to the back foot; 230 peacekeepers - and a British officer - are still surrounded by the rebels and key objectives remain unsecured. In fact, a glance at the map shows that Freetown's forces are barely holding on to the territory they recaptured following the arrival of British troops five weeks ago. The RUF's grip on its diamonds, the lifeblood of the movement, is unthreatened. There have even been armed clashes between the disparate factions that make up the government forces. Though the UN and the British downplay them as 'ongoing squabbles', the most recent - on Thursday night - seriously rattled senior officers. Privately they admit that the cohesion of Freetown's forces is a grave concern. Deep in the jungle, the most nightmarish of all scenarios is unfolding. It is estimated that more than 100,000 refugees have been displaced by the recent fighting. Many are without food and shelter. These are people who have watched close relatives raped and hatcheted to death, who have had their houses burnt down around them, who have survived for days on roots and mangoes. Help will not come soon. A bid by the World Food Programme to distribute aid last week at a town only 30 miles from the vital Lungi airport was halted by an RUF attack. Aid workers describe the situation as 'an emergency' and speak of 'famine' potential. This is a country where 12-year-old children carry British-issued automatic rifles, where barely pubescent girls talk of the men they have killed, where aid workers need a helicopter gunship flown by a South African mercenary to evacuate them when the UN retreat during a rebel attack, where for the price of a grilled chicken dinner women sell themselves on a beach as helicopters wheel overhead and Bob Marley pumps from a blaring jukebox. It is difficult to see much light in this darkness. Thirty-five miles inland from Freetown is the town of Masiaka - a cluster of shacks and rotting, colonial-style villas. The government forces mass here before going up to the front. There are the official government soldiers in their newly issued British uniforms and weapons, the Kamajor irregular militia festooned with plastic charms, mirrors and conch shells and rumours of cannibalism, Gbenthi bushmen armed with hunting rifles and spiked clubs. One old bungalow, its colonnades rotten, mildewed and pocked with bullet scars, serves as the headquarters of the 'West Side Niggahz' - the name has been sanitised by the authorities to the 'West Side Boys'. Smoking cannabis and sucking 'gin popsicles' - fiercely alcoholic ice lollies - the fighters loll in rotten armchairs with rocket launchers and machine guns scattered around them. A bucket of potent palm wine lies empty but for a few cloudy dregs. Bullet belts gleam dully in the flat afternoon light. Just over a year ago these fighters joined the RUF in 'Operation No Living Thing' and raped, burnt and looted their way through Freetown. President Kabbah fled. Now they are fighting on the government side and, for the moment, have restricted their criminal activities to stealing British-supplied weapons from their supposed comrades and extorting money at vehicle checkpoints. Last week there were two shoot-outs between the West Side Niggahz and government troops. No one doubts that more will come. The Observer visited Masiaka to watch the handover of 134 children who had been freed from the rebels. In the derelict school where they were housed they told their stories. The younger ones, some only five or six, had been camp-followers, washing clothes and fetching firewood for the soldiers. But many of the older children were fighters. Mariana Mansaray, 15 and wearing a blue gingham shirt and green skirt, was one. A facial tic and appalling stammer made it virtually impossible for her to talk. Slowly and painfully, she told how she had been abducted by the rebels two years ago, repeatedly raped and then injected with some kind of drug. At first she had carried ammunition to the frontline troops but was soon in combat herself. 'They gave me drugs, sir,' she said with her entire jaw contorted into a rictus of pain as she tried to speak. 'Then I was fighting for them, sir.' How many people had she killed? Her neck muscles - standing out like steel cables - pulsed and spasmed before she choked out the answer. 'Plenty,' she said. Around her sat others with similar stories. One seven-year-old boy spoke of how his 25-year-old father had initiated him into the RUF by teaching him how to hack off arms - the rebels' calling card since their bid to stop people voting in Sierra Leone's 1996 election from which the RUF was banned. He was taught to ask if his victims wanted 'long' or 'short sleeves' - amputation above or below the elbow. Others spoke of watching their villages burn to the ground or how the rebels had killed their parents and then given them the stark choice: join up or die. A short distance from the old school a hundred or so government soldiers were piling on lorries to take them up to the front. 'We are here for the long term,' Hughes said. 'It could be weeks or months or years.' The UN force is being brought up to its full strength of 13,000 and there are moves to provide another 3,500 troops and strengthen its mandate. There are the Jordanians and the Indians, but also Kenyans, Zambians, Pakistanis, Guineans, Bangladeshis and men from a dozen other countries. But the conditions that led to the creation of the RUF remain broadly unchanged. The movement burst on the scene in 1991, a few years after Sankoh and Charles Taylor, the current President of neighbouring Liberia, met in a Libyan training camp. When in 1990 Sierra Leonese forces came to the assistance of government troops fighting Taylor's brutal insurrection in Liberia, a scheme the two men had hatched while guests of Libya's Muammar Gadaffi was put into action. The RUF seized the great mines in the south of Sierra Leone and Sankoh - made Minister for Minerals in return for a truce last year - split the multi-million-pound proceeds with his friend. Taylor has always ensured that the RUF has sufficient weaponry, mainly brought in from Eastern Europe. Now, with Sankoh in jail, radio intercepts reveal that the Liberian leader is actually directing the RUF's operations in person. From Masiaka the road to Mile 91 leads east - lined with wrecked vehicles and the shells of buildings destroyed in the various bouts of fighting that have racked the country in the past 10 years. Most came from Lunsar, where fighting between government troops and the rebels has been raging for nearly two weeks. A 28-year-old teacher, she had left Lunsar a week ago to trek with her nine-strong family along jungle paths to reach a village close to Mile 91 where she had heard there was shelter. She was heavily pregnant, so the 30-mile trek had taken four days. 'It was terrible,' she said. 'We dug wells for water and lived on [cassava] roots and leaves and some mangoes when we found them. webTitle: 'Victorious' Russians wait in fear for next suicide bomber

fields.headline: 'Victorious' Russians wait in fear for next suicide bomber
fields.standfirst:
Three months ago, Vladimir Putin's army boasted of its capture of the Chechen capital. But Amelia Gentleman in Grozny finds the conquerors' morale shattered
Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: An uneasy atmosphere of heightened nervous tension has spread among Russian officers patrolling the shattered streets of Grozny after Chechen rebels launched a series of devastating revenge attacks last week on army checkpoints in the capital.
fields.body:
An uneasy atmosphere of heightened nervous tension has spread among Russian officers patrolling the shattered streets of Grozny after Chechen rebels launched a series of devastating revenge attacks last week on army checkpoints in the capital.

Weakened by the nine-month Russian assault, Chechen guerrillas have switched their tactics - abandoning large-scale resistance in favour of dispatching lone suicide bombers to destroy Russian posts, or mounting small lightning raids on enemy positions.

One by one, dozens of Russian soldiers have been killed in an unrelenting sequence of ambushes. Shrewdly calculated to cause maximum distress by their random nature, the attacks have had the desired effect: the morale of Russian troops in the capital has been debilitated.

Last Sunday Sergei K, 25, a commando officer from Siberia, saw two of his closest colleagues blown up when a Chechen suicide bomber detonated explosives in the boot of his car at a checkpoint on the capital's outskirts.

It was 5.30pm, just half an hour before the night curfew was due to begin, when the white Lada stopped a few metres from the roadblock. The driver stepped out, presented his documents and opened the boot to show soldiers what was inside. The bomb was triggered as the car boot opened; all three men died instantly.

Security measures in the capital were intensified, with new bands of military police sent to guard the city roads. An order prohibiting the delivery of fresh water to the city was issued - despite the complete absence of drinking water within the capital - because generals were concerned that explosives could be hidden in the trucks. But despite these strict precautions, last Wednesday and again on Thursday more soldiers were killed in similar Chechen missions.

Even the most hardened members of the elite security forces sent to police Grozny now admit to feeling unnerved. 'The work we're doing is terrifying; I'd be a fool to pretend otherwise. Guarding these checkpoints has become the most dangerous job in Chechnya,' Sergei said, standing behind a makeshift new barricade in the city centre built from cement sacks and barbed wire. 'I know what happened to Yura Kovalyev could happen to me. One minute he was telling me about his small son who was about to have his second birthday, the next minute I watched him being blown up. I ran over to try to give him first aid, but it was too late. We had to collect up the bodies instead.'

It is more than three months since the Russian army triumphantly declared that they had seized Grozny from the separatist rebels, but they have yet to take decisive control of the ruined trophy city. Every night its inhabitants are woken up by sniper shots rattling through the silence, as Chechen fighters target Russian posts under cover of darkness. Every morning officers gather to calculate how many more of their men have been killed or injured during the night.

As many as 500 rebels are thought to remain in the capital, making their way brazenly from one side of the city to the other - concealed from sight amid the ruins - their sole task to launch attacks on the Russian soldiers trying to cling on to the city. Small groups of Chechen fighters, who know the terrain intimately, hide in the bombed-out shells of Grozny's apartment blocks. This is a scenario painfully familiar to veterans of the 1994-96 Chechen war, when a Russian victory over Grozny was later reversed by rebel fighters who seized back the city.

'Soldiers in the city are on full alert. Every car coming into the city is scrutinised thoroughly. But it's impossible to know where to expect the next attack, which is why the situation is so tense,' Mikhail Sulomatin, a military police officer, said.

The chaos in Grozny reflects a wider picture of disarray, as rebels adopt similar terrorising tactics on military bases throughout the state. Police Captain Alexander Zuyev witnessed another guerrilla attack last Monday in the Argun region, as his troops drove over a home-made Chechen land mine. One soldier died at once, another had his leg blown off and died a few hours later in the military hospital, four more were badly injured.

'After the explosion, fighters started firing on us from the woods nearby. Now that the leaves are out and everything is green, it's much easier for them to hide in the undergrowth, so they can get away with this kind of attack,' he said. 'Over the past week the situation across Chechnya has become much more dangerous for us. The Chechens have hit on a clever way of frightening our men.'

Russia's problems in the region extend far beyond these escalating rebel attacks. With all of Chechnya - except for a remote stretch in the mountains - nominally under Russian control, Kremlin officials are searching desperately for a way to establish a more permanent hold over the area.

Politicians attempted again last week to impose a pro-Moscow leadership on the Chechen nation. On Monday, Akhmed Kadyrov, a local Muslim leader, was named as the new head of Vladimir Putin's administration in Chechnya, but his appointment was greeted with quiet suspicion in the region.

Russia has struggled for a long time to find an appropriate loyal figure to head Chechnya after the war. The last Moscow-appointed Chechen leader, Bislan Ganta-mirov (released from a Moscow prison, where he was serving a corruption sentence, to fulfil the role) did not last long. He was dismissed last month, accused of collaborating with the rebels.

Alongside this hunt for a peacetime leader, a much-publicised reconstruction programme continues, attempting to restore stability after the chaos of two brutally destructive wars. Russian officials are fond of releasing updated figures on the numbers of schools and hospitals which have been reopened in parts of the country previously devastated by the conflict and the administrative chaos that preceded it.

But the impact of these announcements was undermined last week when Nikolai Koshman - the Russian-appointed official who was until recently in charge of restoring civilian normality to Chechnya - announced in a bitter newspaper interview that government funds for reconstruction had already dried up, crippling the programme to rebuild the nation. This short-sighted economising would lead to greater bloodshed, he warned, because the unemployed, impoverished Chechens would willingly take up arms and flee to the rebel bases in the mountains.

And life for those Chechens uprooted by the war has become no easier, despite the lull in the intensity of the Russian attack. In a refugee camp in Znamenskoye, northern Chechnya, 10-year-old Yakha Yasoko is still waiting for a new leg eight months after her left leg was amputated because the wounds she received when her home in Grozny blew up around her had turned gangrenous.

Visiting doctors have provided her with a pair of children's crutches, but promises to build her a prosthesis have never materialised. 'There isn't enough money here to feed the children properly, let alone to pay for something like a false leg,' her father, Takhir Yasoko, said.

The family continues to live in three campbeds in one corner of a tent, surrounded by other refugees, none of them able to return home, because their houses have been destroyed.

'We thought for a while that we would return to Grozny. But there's nothing left of our house there, and no one can help us buy materials to rebuild it. We have no choice but to stay here,' Yasoko said.

webTitle: Mugabe heads for defeat at the polls

fields.headline: Mugabe heads for defeat at the polls
fields.standfirst:
Electoral fraud, violence and police crackdown may not be enough to save Zimbabwe's tired and hated regime
Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Harare, it seems, is under siege. Police have thrown up 24-hour roadblocks on every major thoroughfare entering Zimbabwe's capital, stopping vehicles and searching for weapons.
fields.body:
Harare, it seems, is under siege. Police have thrown up 24-hour roadblocks on every major thoroughfare entering Zimbabwe's capital, stopping vehicles and searching for weapons.

Motorists arrested for minor offences are handcuffed to their vehicles. Police say it is an exercise to reduce armed crime. Many say the government is flexing its muscles before next weekend's parliamentary elections.

But not all the officers are hostile. The policeman checking my bag ruefully agrees that prices are far too high because of Zimbabwe's 60 per cent inflation. 'It's time for a change,' he says in a low voice, implicitly endorsing the opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC).

Despite the Mugabe regime's blatant use of violence, electoral fraud and misuse of the police force, the impetus for change appears to be unstoppable. An opinion poll released on Friday says the MDC will win 70 of the 120 elected parliamentary seats.

The elections are the most important since the 1980 vote which brought majority rule. The choice is between Robert Mugabe's government, which promotes violence, murder and mayhem, and the MDC, which calls for respect for human rights and the rule of law.

Public support for the MDC is palpable. That is why the government is using every trick in the book. These include making the police force accomplices to the political violence that has racked the country. Government officials say the elections will be free and fair. But all objective observers agree that this is impossible.

Police commissioner Augustine Chihuri asserted last week: 'Political violence is being over-publicised by the media. The violence that has characterised this election is common in other countries.'

That was rich, coming from the man responsible for preventing the police from taking action against the illegal farm invasions, from stopping violence against opposition supporters and from arresting known murderers.

The argument that Zimbabwe's pre-election violence is acceptable in comparison with more serious violence in other African countries is a line of reasoning articulated by Mugabe and parroted by several Cabinet Ministers. But Zimbabwe's violence is different and much more objectionable because it has been sponsored by the government itself.

webTitle: Seeds of death litter Lebanon's liberated fields

fields.headline: Seeds of death litter Lebanon's liberated fields
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Beaufort Castle, built by the Crusaders in the twelfth century and occupied by the Israelis until last month, has become the central attraction in a new deadly tourist trail in south Lebanon.
fields.byline: Henry McDonald in Tibnin, South Lebanon
fields.body:
Beaufort Castle, built by the Crusaders in the twelfth century and occupied by the Israelis until last month, has become the central attraction in a new deadly tourist trail in south Lebanon.

Thousands of curious Lebanese, many of whom never ventured near the South during almost 20 years of occupation, are swarming around the ancient ramparts of the medieval fortress along with the other 100-odd Israeli and South Lebanon Army positions that stretch from the Mediterranean to the Golan Heights.

But their journey to places such as Beaufort, which is situated on a mountain top where Crusaders once resisted the besieging armies of Saladin, contains a lethal threat - landmines.

According to UN peacekeepers, the Israelis and their client SLA militia have left an estimated 70,000 anti-personnel mines in and around their abandoned compounds, including the castle.

Last week, a young boy from Sidon was killed while visiting a deserted SLA stronghold that fell to the Iranian-backed Hizbollah during Israel's withdrawal from Lebanon on 22 May.

The child was foraging for souvenirs in the compound when he spotted a camera. The camera turned out to be a booby trap left by the SLA before they fled into Israel.

In the areas controlled by the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon (Unifil) peacekeeping troops are trying to clear mines and unexploded ordnance that rained on South Lebanon like confetti for two decades.

On Tuesday, I paced nervously through a field behind a home in Rashaf village, close to the Israeli border. In front was Commandant John Phelan, an Irish bomb disposal officer, who was preparing to blow up an unexploded 120mm mortar bomb discovered by a farmer.

As he wrapped masking tape around three sticks of plastic explosive which he laid beside the Hebrew-marked mortar shell, Phelan explained the dangers facing Lebanese visiting the liberated zone for the first time in decades.

'The locals who lived here throughout the occupation don't go near the compounds, they are careful about mines and unexploded ordnance. By and large the people walking into the compounds are "tourists" from Beirut and other places in the North who may be looking for souvenirs.'

Unifil's deputy commander, another Irish officer, General Jim Shreenan, said the force was so concerned about the landmines that the UN was calling in Swedish and Ukrainian engineers to clear areas around the old compounds with Nato de-mining machines.

While there is wild talk in the Western media that the UN could be poised to pull out of Lebanon within a year, officers on the ground regard this as premature. 'I think it will be years before they make the South safe for everyone to get back to a normal life,' said Phelan.

Ahmed Ossaili wants the Irish to remain close to Rashaf. For 15 years he lived under the shadow of the SLA compound. His house is peppered with bullet and shell holes. His wife is blind in one eye after a splinter struck her during a machine-gun attack on the village. He said:'Please tell the world the UN should stay and help our government clear this area.'

fields.headline: It's all Leo's fault
fields.standfirst:
Fatherhood has just made Tony Blair look like a wimp

Blairs' baby: special report
fields.trailText: A recent 'yobs' strip cartoon in  Private Eye showed a young father proudly wheeling his child down the street in a baby buggy to be greeted by the Yobs sitting outside the pub with a shout of 'Puff!'
fields.body:
A recent 'yobs' strip cartoon in Private Eye showed a young father proudly wheeling his child down the street in a baby buggy to be greeted by the Yobs sitting outside the pub with a shout of 'Puff!'

Many people have been trying to explain the sudden decline in Tony Blair's popularity and the apparently puzzling circumstances in which he was barracked by the Women's Institute when he addressed them recently at Wembley. All sorts of suggestions have been made - that Blair was tired, that his speech was too political, that the Women's Institute is a Tory conspiracy etc etc.

I think myself that baby Leo has a lot to answer for. The Prime Minister may have thought that becoming a father again would go down well with the voters and might even help him to win the next election when it comes.

It might have done had Blair reacted differently. As it was, when he was filmed running out of Number 10 clutching his special mug of tea and later photographed lying on the carpet alongside little Leo he succeeded only in looking a bit of a charlie.

More seriously is the debate which appeared to be going on between Mr and Mrs Blair about whether or not the Prime Minister should take time off to bond with his new offspring. Blair seemed to be the loser, leaving people with the impression that he is under the thumb of his bossy wife. The consequence of all this was to leave Mr Blair looking far from manly - certainly not the type to command the respect of the massed ladies of the WI.

Brown's sauce

Following Gordon Brown's recent outburst on university admissions, Roy Jenkins made the best comment of anyone when he compared Brown to Chairman Mao launching his Cultural Revolution - 'designed not to achieve any practical result but just to stir things up for political purposes, to spread unease and create damage'.

Chairman Brown's clever ploy was to focus on a vaguely defined élite, an old school tie network which needs to be eradicated. In the same way another Chairman Mao-style diversion is being created with the great fox hunting controversy, where hatred can be stirred up against an amorphous body of red-coated toffs engaged in cruelty to animals.

The important point in both cases is that the Government can give the appearance of radicalism without any mention of money or the growing gulf between rich and poor - two little words which will never be mentioned.

In last Tuesday's Evening Standard it was reported, on one page, that a Railtrack engineer had been rejected when he proposed safety improvements at Paddington, and on the City Page that Railtrack chiefs, including the man responsible for safety, are to receive massive bonuses ranging from £25,000 to £37,000 (the Chief Executive, Mr Gerald Corbett, meanwhile will go without his bonus and do his best to make ends meet with a salary of £400,000).

Some old-fashioned people (even possibly, Lord Jenkins) may regard such a situation as scandalous. But one thing is certain. No one in the high echelons of the New Labour party, least of all Gordon Brown, is likely to make any reference to these matters or to attack the huge salaries which people like Mr Corbett pay themselves, let alone make a comparison between those salaries and the lack of money made available by Railtrack to ensure the safety of their passengers. Much better to imitate Chairman Mao and stir up hatred of plummy-voiced types riding to hounds or getting into Oxford by unfair means. That way no harm is done and you can even be sure it has the approval of the very rich men who edit the tabloid press.

A barren press

Alastair Campbell's decision to slip back into the shadows, abandoning his high-profile position at the centre of our national life, is supposed to dampen down all the talk about spin doctors which has been upsetting so many people recently.

Never mentioned when this topic is under discussion is the role of the press. Yet we ought all to be asking why, when the likes of Alastair Campbell are putting spin on this or that story, the hacks aren't giving them the cold shoulder and looking elsewhere for the news?

The more they complain about the power of the spin doctors, the more journalists seem to be tacitly admitting that they are mere stooges who can be manipulated by the Campbells of this world to report the news the Government wants to be reported.

The public is thus left with the impression that a political journalist is a person sitting by his phone waiting for a call from someone at Number 10 to tell him what story to write for tomorrow's newspaper.

Gone completely, in this modern scenario, is the notion that information is something that is hard to come by and that considerable patience and guile may be required in the difficult job of ferreting it out with the help of well-placed moles and subversives in high places.

If the spin-doctors have gained an ascendancy, as is claimed, then that is entirely the fault of the press. Governments after all will always do their best to pull the wool over our eyes. The job of the press must be to try to pull the wool away.
