fields.headline: Our zero privacy
fields.standfirst:
What ever you do where ever you go, they're watching you. And now they'll be reading your emails too

Privacy on the net: special report
fields.trailText: The Government is proposing to give itself, the secret police, honest police, and indeed, each and every civil servant, the power to bug the phones, cars, homes, pagers, emails and internet use. Warrants to intercept will not be issued by a judge, but by Ministers. The law will thus place spies above the rule of the law courts.
fields.body:
The Home Office has a new sneer for those who question its assault on rights to do everything from protest to be tried by juries. In the past, we have been Old Labour 'dinosaurs' ignorant of the authoritarian necessities of hard times. Without contradiction, we then metamorphosed into 'woolly Hampstead liberals' despite our inability to afford a broom cupboard in Hampstead. For a brief, marvellous moment the most cynical of politicians decided their critics were 'cynics' for refusing to endorse their cynicism. Perhaps they heard the howls of hollow laughter. Perhaps they thought there ought to be a connection, however faint, between words and the phenomena they purport to describe. For whatever reason, Jack Straw has ruled that all who regard him as a public menace will henceforth be known as 'paranoids'.

The cause of the linguistic shift is the reaction to the extraordinary Regulation of Investigatory Powers Bill, currently before Parliament. The Government is proposing to give itself, the secret police, honest police, and indeed, each and every civil servant, the power to bug the phones, cars, homes, pagers, emails and internet use. Warrants to intercept will not be issued by a judge, but by Ministers. The law will thus place spies above the rule of the law courts.

Liberty and other human rights groups have been banging on about the threat of uncontrolled surveillance for months. Because they represent paranoid/liberal/Old Labour/cynics they were ignored by most MPs. Last week, however, the issue took off. Simon Davies, a visiting professor at the London School of Economics and the director of Privacy International, estimated that the Government's insistence that internet service providers fit black boxes so MI5 can monitor what their customers are reading and writing may cost Britain £46 billion as hi-tech companies conclude that a country demanding the right to pry without independent checks wasn't a safe place to do business in.

The Financial Times hyper-ventilated. The state was demanding powers 'that Joseph Stalin would have used with relish', it cried. The British Chamber of Commerce and the Federation of Electronic Industries went wild. Stephen Byers 'forcefully' conveyed their concerns to Straw. All Blair's chirping about ebusiness leading Britain into a century of opulent gee-whizzery suddenly had a tinny ring.

It's great to have the FT and its readers on side. But to be fair to Straw - this notebook's raison d'etre - he is merely imitating business. What is truly frightening is the ability of private and public power to stare into corners.

Millions leave democratic society behind when they go to work. The technologies which nerdish boosters claim are bringing choice and freedom are putting powers to invigilate in the hands of managers, as well as policemen, beyond the imagination of Henry Ford. If the Government is reading emails and monitoring website hits, then so are employers. Last year, to quote one of many examples, five workers at Rolls-Royce in Bristol were fired and 10 more were punished after a search of messages found that dirty pictures had been emailed from its workstations.

You might argue that nudes are deplorable and the upright have nothing to fear; just as Straw argues that people who use the internet only to read material MI5 approves of have no reason to trouble their silly little heads about his bill. Yet at Rolls-Royce staff were disciplined for sending gossip on company time as well as the odd bit of filth and the firm ignored the sale of porn mags in its site shop. And if Straw is interested only in capturing criminals why does he refuse to allow judges to rule if invasions of privacy are tolerable?

Reassurances that the innocent have no reason to fret also miss the psychological effect of knowing you're being watched. The next time you surf the net and hit a sex or radical site by mistake, will you feel someone or some computer has logged your interest?

If you don't have a terminal, what about your phone? Mohamed al-Fayed became notorious for bugging staff at Harrod's who complained to union representatives about his sexism and racism. Ali F may be a bully and buffoon, but there's nothing exceptional about him. A study by Davies's Privacy International found that 200,000 bugs a year are sold quite legally in Britain. The most sophisticated - Direct Intelligence Access Listening (DIAL) systems - are powered off the telephone line and can run without maintenance for years. Crispin Sturrack, who works for the security consultants Cope Whiterock, described DIAL and its rivals thus: 'These things are getting smaller and cheaper by the day. And our job is made harder because they are now almost undetectable and unrecognisable.'

As with bugs, so with cameras. The current issue of Index on Censorship is sobering reading for anyone who believes the knowledge economy nurtures freedom. It details how Britain spends more on CCTV surveillance than any other European country (£385 million last year). New digital cameras can link faces and number plates to data banks of targets' images and the Driver and Vehicle Licencing Centre's records and, indeed, be programmed to track mugs and cars. The soothing Straws say if you're not a criminal you've nothing to worry about. CCTV is a deterrent. They ignore the push to produce lenses that can be hidden without the surveyed knowing they're there to deter. Cameras 42mm square which can see in virtual darkness cost £100.

We must ask what happens when people realise they have good reason for suspecting they can be tracked at work and on the streets? It's not as if the monitors are interested only in crime prevention or malingering. Spying has always attracted creeps. Chris Norris and Gary Armstrong, lecturers at Hull and Reading Universities, got into CCTV centres and saw police voyeurs getting their thrills watching, but not arresting, prostitutes at work.

Soon every employee will have to produce a copy of his or her criminal record. A survey by the Metropolitan Police found that 86 per cent of records were wrong and many mistakes were so bad the alleged criminals could sue. More than a million workplace drug tests were conducted last year as body searches without a warrant became the fashion. Straw will extend mass sampling to police stations. You might think you're not at risk if you're clean, but checks in Ontario found 40 per cent of tests were inaccurate. A drug test means urinating in front of a manager, police officer or medic (who has to certify the right piss has been taken). Isn't this a public humiliation? Isn't it likely that a population which is watched and sampled without judicial oversight, and is wary of reading the wrong email, at home or work, will become passive and suspicious?

Outside the call centres where every key stroke and visit to the loo is studied, there is little evidence that people are cowed. The reaction to Straw's internet snooping is the first sign of a general understanding that paranoia is the sanest of responses to the enormous resources corporate and state spies now have at their fingertips. Scott McNealy, the CEO of the cutting-edge company Sun Microsystems, gurgled recently: 'You have zero privacy - get over it!' There is an alternative: Get Straw - or at least don't be so cowed that you would vote for him and his sort again.

Bringing the multinationals to book

At first glance the misery of the black South Africans coughing up their guts because they had the misfortune to be hired by the British-owned asbestos company, Cape plc, is sad but irrelevant. But to multinationals their condition raises a legal question as important as the addled Pinochet prosecution was to dictators: do courts control conglomerates or vice versa?

About 2,000 former Cape employees suffering from lung disease will ask the Law Lords tomorrow for the right to sue for compensation. Their lawyers' pleas look damning. Cape mined and milled asbestos until 1979 in South Africa. As early as 1931 asbestos companies, including Cape, were regulated in Britain. By 1954, the link between asbestos dust and painful deaths was clear. Cape's British workers have had £30 million compensation.

Yet Cape allegedly treated its South African workers as disposable serfs. They weren't issued with protective clothing and haven't received a penny compensation. Asbestos levels are claimed to have been 30 times higher than the British limit. Dr Gerritt Schepers, a health inspector for the South African government of 1965, which wasn't that bothered about the treatment of black workers, reported children 'trampling down fluffy asbestos, which all day came cascading over their heads. They were kept slepping by a burly supervisor with a hefty whip.'

Cape may have a counter argument. If so, its lawyers are insisting that it must be heard in the South African courts. But Cape pulled out of South Africa 20 years ago. The alleged decision to expose their staff to fatal illnesses was made in Britain. The resulting profits flowed to Britain. Yet the company is saying the trial should be heard in a country where it has no assets which can be seized if the judge finds against it. To date, the British courts have pretty much backed Cape. If the Law Lords don't reverse the perverse rulings we will be in a world where companies can trade globally, but be sued locally; where the World Trade Organisation can overturn the democratic decisions of national governments in the interest of corporations, but British courts refuse to make those same companies accept their responsibilities.

Warrants to intercept will not be issued by a judge, but by Ministers. The law will thus place spies above the rule of the law courts. Liberty and other human rights groups have been banging on about the threat of uncontrolled surveillance for months. Because they represent paranoid/liberal/Old Labour/cynics they were ignored by most MPs. Last week, however, the issue took off. Simon Davies, a visiting professor at the London School of Economics and the director of Privacy International, estimated that the Government's insistence that internet service providers fit black boxes so MI5 can monitor what their customers are reading and writing may cost Britain £46 billion as hi-tech companies conclude that a country demanding the right to pry without independent checks wasn't a safe place to do business in. The Financial Times hyper-ventilated. The state was demanding powers 'that Joseph Stalin would have used with relish', it cried. The British Chamber of Commerce and the Federation of Electronic Industries went wild. Stephen Byers 'forcefully' conveyed their concerns to Straw. All Blair's chirping about ebusiness leading Britain into a century of opulent gee-whizzery suddenly had a tinny ring. It's great to have the FT and its readers on side. But to be fair to Straw - this notebook's raison d'etre - he is merely imitating business. What is truly frightening is the ability of private and public power to stare into corners. Millions leave democratic society behind when they go to work. The technologies which nerdish boosters claim are bringing choice and freedom are putting powers to invigilate in the hands of managers, as well as policemen, beyond the imagination of Henry Ford. If the Government is reading emails and monitoring website hits, then so are employers. Last year, to quote one of many examples, five workers at Rolls-Royce in Bristol were fired and 10 more were punished after a search of messages found that dirty pictures had been emailed from its workstations. You might argue that nudes are deplorable and the upright have nothing to fear; just as Straw argues that people who use the internet only to read material MI5 approves of have no reason to trouble their silly little heads about his bill. Yet at Rolls-Royce staff were disciplined for sending gossip on company time as well as the odd bit of filth and the firm ignored the sale of porn mags in its site shop. And if Straw is interested only in capturing criminals why does he refuse to allow judges to rule if invasions of privacy are tolerable? Reassurances that the innocent have no reason to fret also miss the psychological effect of knowing you're being watched. The next time you surf the net and hit a sex or radical site by mistake, will you feel someone or some computer has logged your interest? If you don't have a terminal, what about your phone? Mohamed al-Fayed became notorious for bugging staff at Harrod's who complained to union representatives about his sexism and racism. Ali F may be a bully and buffoon, but there's nothing exceptional about him. A study by Davies's Privacy International found that 200,000 bugs a year are sold quite legally in Britain. The most sophisticated - Direct Intelligence Access Listening (DIAL) systems - are powered off the telephone line and can run without maintenance for years. Crispin Sturrack, who works for the security consultants Cope Whiterock, described DIAL and its rivals thus: 'These things are getting smaller and cheaper by the day. And our job is made harder because they are now almost undetectable and unrecognisable.' As with bugs, so with cameras. The current issue of Index on Censorship is sobering reading for anyone who believes the knowledge economy nurtures freedom. It details how Britain spends more on CCTV surveillance than any other European country (£385 million last year). New digital cameras can link faces and number plates to data banks of targets' images and the Driver and Vehicle Licencing Centre's records and, indeed, be programmed to track mugs and cars. The soothing Straws say if you're not a criminal you've nothing to worry about. CCTV is a deterrent. They ignore the push to produce lenses that can be hidden without the surveyed knowing they're there to deter. Cameras 42mm square which can see in virtual darkness cost £100. We must ask what happens when people realise they have good reason for suspecting they can be tracked at work and on the streets? It's not as if the monitors are interested only in crime prevention or malingering. Spying has always attracted creeps. Chris Norris and Gary Armstrong, lecturers at Hull and Reading Universities, got into CCTV centres and saw police voyeurs getting their thrills watching, but not arresting, prostitutes at work. Soon every employee will have to produce a copy of his or her criminal record. A survey by the Metropolitan Police found that 86 per cent of records were wrong and many mistakes were so bad the alleged criminals could sue. More than a million workplace drug tests were conducted last year as body searches without a warrant became the fashion. Straw will extend mass sampling to police stations. You might think you're not at risk if you're clean, but checks in Ontario found 40 per cent of tests were inaccurate. A drug test means urinating in front of a manager, police officer or medic (who has to certify the right piss has been taken). Isn't this a public humiliation? Isn't it likely that a population which is watched and sampled without judicial oversight, and is wary of reading the wrong email, at home or work, will become passive and suspicious? Outside the call centres where every key stroke and visit to the loo is studied, there is little evidence that people are cowed. The reaction to Straw's internet snooping is the first sign of a general understanding that paranoia is the sanest of responses to the enormous resources corporate and state spies now have at their fingertips. Scott McNealy, the CEO of the cutting-edge company Sun Microsystems, gurgled recently: 'You have zero privacy - get over it!' There is an alternative: Get Straw - or at least don't be so cowed that you would vote for him and his sort again. Bringing the multinationals to book At first glance the misery of the black South Africans coughing up their guts because they had the misfortune to be hired by the British-owned asbestos company, Cape plc, is sad but irrelevant. But to multinationals their condition raises a legal question as important as the addled Pinochet prosecution was to dictators: do courts control conglomerates or vice versa? About 2,000 former Cape employees suffering from lung disease will ask the Law Lords tomorrow for the right to sue for compensation. Their lawyers' pleas look damning. Cape mined and milled asbestos until 1979 in South Africa. As early as 1931 asbestos companies, including Cape, were regulated in Britain. By 1954, the link between asbestos dust and painful deaths was clear. Cape's British workers have had £30 million compensation. Yet Cape allegedly treated its South African workers as disposable serfs. They weren't issued with protective clothing and haven't received a penny compensation. Asbestos levels are claimed to have been 30 times higher than the British limit. Dr Gerritt Schepers, a health inspector for the South African government of 1965, which wasn't that bothered about the treatment of black workers, reported children 'trampling down fluffy asbestos, which all day came cascading over their heads. They were kept slepping by a burly supervisor with a hefty whip.' Cape may have a counter argument. If so, its lawyers are insisting that it must be heard in the South African courts. But Cape pulled out of South Africa 20 years ago. The alleged decision to expose their staff to fatal illnesses was made in Britain. The resulting profits flowed to Britain. Yet the company is saying the trial should be heard in a country where it has no assets which can be seized if the judge finds against it. To date, the British courts have pretty much backed Cape. If the Law Lords don't reverse the perverse rulings we will be in a world where companies can trade globally, but be sued locally; where the World Trade Organisation can overturn the democratic decisions of national governments in the interest of corporations, but British courts refuse to make those same companies accept their responsibilities.

fields.headline: Australia bitten by £41bn gambling bug
fields.trailText: Behind the tinted glass doors of the Returned Services League club in the west Sydney suburb of Marrickville, music, laughter, voices in several tongues and the clatter of the one-armed bandits or 'pokies' fill the air.
fields.body:
Behind the tinted glass doors of the Returned Services League club in the west Sydney suburb of Marrickville, music, laughter, voices in several tongues and the clatter of the one-armed bandits or 'pokies' fill the air.

It is Saturday night. At one table a Vietnamese family plays keno, a kind of hi-tech bingo. A group of grey-haired Ukrainian men throw down cards in a poker game. Two women wearing chunky gold rings sit listlessly at pokie machines, pouring in coin after coin all night.

The scene is similar across town at trendy bars in Darlinghurst, Double Bay or Bondi, and across Australia, where gambling has long been a social mainstay. Now there are fears it is too much.

Official figures released last month show Australians gambled £41 billion in 1998-99, an increase of about 8 per cent on the previous year. The average adult legally gambles about £2,900 a year. Figures, distorted by vast sums spent by a few high-rollers, are still alarming. Global comparisons are unavailable but Australia may rival Japan for the title of world gambling leader.

The government applauds works paid for by gambling - schools, hospitals, roads - but church and counselling groups say negative effects far outweigh benefits.

The president of the Baptist Union of Australia and head of the Inter-church Gambling Taskforce, the Rev Tim Costello, said: 'I don't have a day go by without calls-because a partner has lost the family home, been sacked, or is facing criminal charges through gambling. I have already been to four funerals of people who committed suicide as a result of gambling.'

Many Australians see gambling as much a part of the culture as cold beers and prawns on the barbie. Historians say it first took place in Sydney soon after convicts landed in 1788. One of the oldest games, two-up, a version of pitch-and-toss, is outlawed except for Anzac Day.

webTitle: Slaves revolt in valley of the dotcoms

fields.headline: Slaves revolt in valley of the dotcoms
fields.standfirst: California's digital highway divides the rich from the poor. Ed Vulliamy in Palo Alto sees Hispanic cleaners demand justice from company bosses for justice
fields.trailText: The Berlin Wall may have fallen, but Highway 101 still cuts through Palo Alto in California.
fields.body:
The Berlin Wall may have fallen, but Highway 101 still cuts through Palo Alto in California.

To the west is Atherton, a world of unreal numbers where billions are earned by the executives and managers of the cyber-age. It has the highest median real estate value of any town in America - $2.5 million per housing unit. On the other side is the troglodyte world of those who service it - janitors, day-workers, maids and delivery boys. East Palo Alto is among the poorest slums in the state, with entire families sleeping three to a room.

They call it the 'digital divide'. To the west, up Silver Creek, the road climbs through sumptuous greenery to houses with names such as Tuscan Hills, Enchantment and Jasmine. To the east, people lounge in the heat outside dingy apartment blocks, with teenage girls on the corners and men picking fights.

Luis Gonzalez lives here. Originally from Torreón in Mexico, he is a janitor by trade. During his 11pm to 7am shift at the Hewlett-Packard computer company he cleans the floors, tiles and lavatories. After five hours' sleep, he begins his day job, watering and tending lawns. He needs the money to support his three children.

To the west the light of the moon shines on Martin Clayton's swimming pool at his mock-Italian mansion, with mock terracotta roofing. Waiters in white serve cocktails. Clayton is a freelance software developer currently busy at Sun Microsystems, one of the main beneficiaries of the impending Microsoft break-up. 'Here's to it,' he says, raising a glass of Absolut-and-tonic.

To the east, Alicia Sosa, a janitor for Sun Microsystems, is afraid to let her daughters play on the porch because of shooting between drug dealers. Sosa and her family rent one room in a three-bedroom single-family house for $500 (£330) a month. They share a kitchen with 17 other people. Her neighbour Ricky Mendez is preparing to move on from his $10-an-hour early-day job at an IBM chip-manufacturing plant to the night job as a casual gardener, which he needs to make ends meet.

To the west, elegant moms with pretty children shop in a mall with a faux-Parisian theme street, Disneyland-style, with imitation gas lamps. Of the 65,000 residents of Santa Clara County, one in nine is worth more than $1million and there are 13 billionaires together worth more than $45bn. To the east, the police report a rapid rise in domestic violence, drug-dealing, petty crime and prostitution. A quarter of children live below the poverty line.

The digital divide has become a way of life. 'There are groups in the valley who just are not participating in the digital economy,' says Doug Henton, author of a report showing the disparity of wealth across Highway 101 to be widening. Teachers, police officers, non-digital engineers are moving out in droves. Stephen Pult, who left town because he couldn't afford the rent, now has a two-hour commute to the San Carlos police department. It operates flexible schedules and long weekend shifts because no beat officer lives within range.

The schools crisis is even more acute. One, Santa Clara United, hopes to build apartments to be let to teachers at affordable rents. In local government the story is similar. The parks director's job at San Carlos remains vacant after four months, even though it carries a handsome $78,000 a year salary.

Carlos Mendoza has to commute to a homeless shelter. In the James F. Bocardero Centre in San José, Carlos, a geriatrics nurse, lives in a cubicle alongside an assortment of semi-recovered crackheads and ex-convicts. 'I hate it here; it's a trap,' he shrugs.

For others the 'rolling hotel' is home for the night. At 11pm the only bus service to run 24 hours in Silicon Valley leaves Menlo Park. Aboard are people such as Luna Saltillo - 'the Midnight Cowgirl' as she calls herself. For a $5 'unlimited travel' day ticket, No 22 will take her and her worldly possessions, in an 'Apple' logo bag, to San José and back again. She lived in one room with her daughter, but the rent went up and she moved out. Now, she is a part-time cashier; her daughter is in care.

In April, President Clinton came to East Palo Alto and his pledges included new training opportunities. In March, Jesse Jackson assembled the chief executives of Hewlett-Packard, Cisco, and other companies to discuss 'getting low-income communities into the digital revolution'.

Recently there have been stirrings of rebellion. The 5,000 union janitors who clean more than 70 per cent of the buildings in Silicon Valley went on strike. In a surge of union militancy, strikes were won by teamsters, car and aerospace workers and parcel couriers. The janitors were its most audacious and surprising manifestation. At first, Silicon Valley met the janitors' claim for a 16 per cent pay rise and improved benefits with silence. But the cleaners were gaining massive public support and winning strikes in other cities - Los Angeles, San Diego and Chicago.

Leaders of the mainly Hispanic Catholic community urged the dotcom employers to 'extend a fair measure of their prosperity' to these 'hard-working men and women'.

There was no response, although union negotiators had by now talked their way into the boardrooms of nine companies. Their propaganda depicted the employers as deep-pocketed villains. The first crack in the dotcom edifice appeared when Genentech, the biotechnology colossus, backed the janitors' demands.

Hundreds of people took to the streets to voice their support for both the firm and the union. A sit-in blocked traffic along dotcom's gilded arteries, Palm Drive and El Camino Drive. There was a stand-off with the police outside the entrance to Hewlett-Packard. Silicon Valley had never seen such effrontery.

Finally, the employers made a major concession and the janitors voted to accept a package worth 9 per cent. Peace and clean floors will remain, astride the digital divide, for the moment.

Back down Silver Creek stands a handsome house amid bright flowers. Now it's another luxury dotcom home. But it was where John Steinbeck wrote The Grapes of Wrath, his classic novel about the tribulations of migrant workers, like those now working in the garden.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
Yemeni kidnappers strike again

Tribesmen in Yemen have kidnapped Italian archaeologist Alberto Alessio and a Yemeni companion. A week earlier a Norwegian diplomat had been killed in a shootout between the police and his captors.

Nuclear retreat

Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer, Germany's most prominent Green party member, said he backed a government plan to end nuclear power by 2020, a longer time span than some in his party had sought.

Curbs on media boss

Lawyers for Vladimir Gusinsky, owner of Russia's only independent media firm, said they would protest against travel restrictions placed on him after his release from a Moscow jail where he had been held on fraud charges.

Laser breakthrough

Using a laser to treat psoriasis with ultraviolet rays appears to clear up the skin condition without exposing the rest of the body to potentially damaging radiation, according to a study by Massachusetts General Hospital and Harvard Medical School.

webTitle: The big issue :  This liberal conservatism

fields.headline: The big issue :  This liberal conservatism
fields.trailText: Teachers are fed up with the perpetual reorganisation of education. Has the Government thought through its latest wheeze - 'children taking lessons in different institutions'?
fields.body:
Stop messing with education

Teachers are fed up with the perpetual reorganisation of education. Has the Government thought through its latest wheeze - 'children taking lessons in different institutions' (News, last week)? How much time will children spend trailing between different sites? Will transport be provided - increasing traffic congestion - or will they walk, with potential risks to their safety and temptations to truant? How would this work in rural areas?

The money should be invested in reducing class sizes and in providing the best possible teaching and resources. The Government sees private schools as setting the standard, but do Etonians go to Harrow for Maths while Harrovians nip to Eton for Geography?
Kay Driver
Professional Association of Teachers
Derby

Not adding up

You say that two-thirds of students with three A grades at A-level attend comprehensive schools (Leader, last week). In fact, in 1999 only 21 per cent of them came from comprehensive schools; 9 per cent came from state grammars, 15 per cent from grant-maintained schools, 12 per cent from sixth-form colleges. The numbers suggest that education gets steadily better the more it escapes the control of local authorities.
Alan Ryan
New College
Oxford

Time to move on child poverty

The Government has indeed put welcome measures in place to begin to eradicate child poverty in the UK (News, last week), but over a time-scale and against a target of 60 per cent of the national mean income that leaves the poorest children suffering for 20 years. The least poor benefit first.

Other governments undertake the measurement of the adequacy of minimum incomes but not the British Government. This omission contributes to the reasons why the UK has the highest rate of underweight babies in Europe and to the widening differential in life expectancy.

It is a national scandal that pensioners from the families of manual workers should expect to die, on average, nearly 10 years younger than their professional colleagues.
Paul Nicolson
Zacchaeus 2000 Trust
London N17

As your report highlights, the scale of child poverty in this country is a scandal, yet where is the public outcry over the fact that one third of children affected by poverty in the European Union live in the UK?

The Government has declared its aim of eradicating child poverty within a generation, but its current strategy will not tackle those in greatest need. A policy which focuses almost exclusively on getting adults into work will undoubtedly benefit some children, but do nothing for people who cannot work. Reform of the benefits system would make the single greatest contribution to the eradication of child poverty.
Roger Singleton
Barnardo's
Ilford
Essex

While we are pleased that The Observer recognises the burning issue of child poverty as front-page material, I would like to redress the balance of your headline by underlining Unicef's support for the Government's strong commitment to eradicate this shameful legacy. The varied measures that have been put in place are already having a very positive impact in reducing the numbers of poor children.
David Bull
Unicef UK
London WC2

Peter Hitchens's opinions on the Sixties (Comment extra, last week) may have hit one nail on the proverbial head at least: 'Post-Wilson Britain has been a disaster. It has schools that cannot teach, a health service that doesn't work and public transport that is a disgrace.'

Assuming he means post-1970, the Conservatives have been in power for 22 of the 30 years since then. If he means post-1976, the year Wilson resigned, the weight of history is slightly less; only 18 years of mainly Thacherite rule from a total of 24 years.
Brendan Prendiville
Paris

If Peter Hitchens's so-called Conservative establishment failed to create a succeeding generation to continue along what he believes was the 'right' path, then thank goodness for that!

Otherwise, women today would have to terminate any unwanted pregnancies in the back streets illegally with knitting needles, more Derek Bentleys and Timothy Evanses would have been wrongfully hanged, and doubtless, I would have been called up to fight a futile war on behalf of Hitchens's 'Conservative establishment' in Vietnam.
Nigel Baldwin
Portsmouth

Will Hutton is right that there is a liberal diaspora. But it is not confined to the cities and shires of Britain. This despairing liberal social democrat - like many others, I suspect - gave up on Thatcher's authoritarian Britain and its Trot Opposition 16 years ago and has never regretted it. The subsequent performance of the Government of Mr Tony 'anti-forces of conservatism' Blair has only reinforced the rightness of the decision.
Howard Rose
Castleknock
Dublin

Will Hutton, in his article explaining liberal philosophy, puts emphasis on children's rights in the 'smacking' debate. Like so many of his contemporaries, however, the emphasis is always on 'rights' but rarely on the concomitant 'duties' of the other parties involved, to ensure these rights. Nowhere is this deficiency seen more starkly than on the abortion issue, where children's rights, at any time from conception almost up to birth, are flagrantly denied. But as in Nazi Germany, society stands aside, fully aware, and in the UK alone, that the numbers involved have almost reached the six million of the Jewish Holocaust. When will society open its eyes to this truth.
John Hindmarsh
Sale
Cheshire

A policy which focuses almost exclusively on getting adults into work will undoubtedly benefit some children, but do nothing for people who cannot work. Reform of the benefits system would make the single greatest contribution to the eradication of child poverty. Roger Singleton Barnardo's Ilford Essex While we are pleased that The Observer recognises the burning issue of child poverty as front-page material, I would like to redress the balance of your headline by underlining Unicef's support for the Government's strong commitment to eradicate this shameful legacy. The varied measures that have been put in place are already having a very positive impact in reducing the numbers of poor children. David Bull Unicef UK London WC2 Peter Hitchens's opinions on the Sixties (Comment extra, last week) may have hit one nail on the proverbial head at least: 'Post-Wilson Britain has been a disaster. It has schools that cannot teach, a health service that doesn't work and public transport that is a disgrace.' Assuming he means post-1970, the Conservatives have been in power for 22 of the 30 years since then. If he means post-1976, the year Wilson resigned, the weight of history is slightly less; only 18 years of mainly Thacherite rule from a total of 24 years. Brendan Prendiville Paris If Peter Hitchens's so-called Conservative establishment failed to create a succeeding generation to continue along what he believes was the 'right' path, then thank goodness for that! Otherwise, women today would have to terminate any unwanted pregnancies in the back streets illegally with knitting needles, more Derek Bentleys and Timothy Evanses would have been wrongfully hanged, and doubtless, I would have been called up to fight a futile war on behalf of Hitchens's 'Conservative establishment' in Vietnam. Nigel Baldwin Portsmouth Will Hutton is right that there is a liberal diaspora. But it is not confined to the cities and shires of Britain. This despairing liberal social democrat - like many others, I suspect - gave up on Thatcher's authoritarian Britain and its Trot Opposition 16 years ago and has never regretted it. The subsequent performance of the Government of Mr Tony 'anti-forces of conservatism' Blair has only reinforced the rightness of the decision. Howard Rose Castleknock Dublin Will Hutton, in his article explaining liberal philosophy, puts emphasis on children's rights in the 'smacking' debate. Like so many of his contemporaries, however, the emphasis is always on 'rights' but rarely on the concomitant 'duties' of the other parties involved, to ensure these rights. Nowhere is this deficiency seen more starkly than on the abortion issue, where children's rights, at any time from conception almost up to birth, are flagrantly denied. But as in Nazi Germany, society stands aside, fully aware, and in the UK alone, that the numbers involved have almost reached the six million of the Jewish Holocaust. When will society open its eyes to this truth. John Hindmarsh Sale Cheshire

webTitle: Muslims torn between belief and finance

fields.headline: Muslims torn between belief and finance
fields.standfirst: Islamic law forbids interest.  Colin Frier  on how it works in practice
fields.trailText: Islamic law forbids interest. Colin Frier on how it works in practice
fields.body:
Iqbal Khan, who holds global responsibility for Islamic finance within HSBC, is a man on a mission. He recognises that British Muslims have very strong and often distinct financial needs, but accepts that neither HSBC nor the UK's financial institutions has done anything like enough to meet them.

'There is a need to integrate British Muslims into mainstream financial services,' he says.

And he is determined to play his part. But until that happens, many of the UK's 1.5 million Muslims will remain torn between the practical necessities of economic life, and their traditional Islamic beliefs.

Although not all British Muslims take the same view, many do have fundamental religious objections to the basic principles on which British financial products, services, and indeed, institutions, are based.

Although most of us take the idea of interest for granted, many Muslims regard it as money earned on money and therefore not fairly earned. But it does not stop there. To varying degrees, depending on their interpretation of and adherence to Islamic law (Sharia), Muslims also have concerns about any form of insurance that is not strictly mutual. As a result, British Muslims often avoid any contact with banks, insurance companies and building societies, or if they do have dealings with them, they do so only with extreme reluctance.

Abdullah, an accountant from London, has gone to extraordinary lengths to straddle the divide between the secular financial world and his religious beliefs. 'I have a no-interest bank account, which I arranged specially with Barclays,' he says. But that is only the beginning of the financial sacrifices he is prepared to make. Instead of taking out a mortgage, he pays £12,000 a year rent (but would pay double), and buys a new car every two years in order to take advantage of the free insurance offered by dealers. And he is looking for another job.

So why give himself so much grief? 'I never give or take interest, because it is in the Koran, and because our prophet addressed the issue and made it sinful,' he says.

Not surprisingly, Abdullah says he finds it difficult to live in an 'interest-based' society. But for the sake of short-term financial gain 'I am not going to compromise', he says.

Richard Thomas of the Arab Banking Corporation says: 'Most British Muslims would prefer to use an Islamic system.' But because British financial institutions have not woken up to Muslims' specific needs, he says , 'a large proportion of Muslims pay rent, don't have bank accounts, and don't participate fully in the mainstream economy'. The Government's social exclusion unit confirmed this last year, he adds: 'It discovered that Muslims are one of the most disadvantaged groups in the community when it comes to access to financial services.'

Abdul Malik from east London says: 'The majority are doing their best to live in the Islamic way, but it is difficult because they don't have any real choice.' He has a credit card, pays it off as soon as possible, but admits a strict Muslim wouldn't have one. Yet when buying a car, he always pays cash rather than taking out a conventional loan with interest. 'I don't compromise on little things like that,' he says.

And even his family who, he admits, are not as strict as he is, 'didn't buy a £220,000 house in north London, because they couldn't buy it in the Islamic way'. Malik says that despite their misgivings, the majority of Muslims are forced to go to a British bank. 'Either that, or keep money under the mattress,' he says.

However, according to Nasr-Eldin Ayoub-Bey of the Institute of Islamic Banking and Insurance, many British Muslims have happily adopted western views: 'As with other religions, being a Muslim doesn't automatically make you pious.'.

Nihal, from Ealing, has lived in the UK for 20 years. Originally from the Middle East, she has a mortgage, a bank account, and counts her family as practising Muslims. 'These things aren't an issue,' she says. And although she admits 'it's a sensitive subject', when it comes to financial matters, she adopts a pragmatic approach. 'It is impossible to carry out all the Sharia requirements,' she says. And even if alternatives more in keeping with Sharia were available, she says she wouldn't adopt them.

The Islamic Investment Banking Unit (IIBU) is one organisation that has identified demand among British Muslims for financial products which adhere to strict Islamic principles. Part of the United Bank of Kuwait, it has been providing British Muslims with home finance according to Sharia law since 1997.

'There are 2,600 ways to buy a house in the UK, but only two ways to do so in Sharia. And we offer both,' says Clive Beacham, IIBU's financial products manager. These have been approved by the IIBU's scholars, who must decide whether a product is halal (acceptable) or haram (forbidden) before it can be launched.

Beacham says the essential difference between conventional mortgages and IIBU's financing arrangements stems from Islam's abhorrence of usury - charging money on money. So whereas with a mortgage, the lender advances funds to the borrower, and charges interest for the use of that money, Sharia financing avoids anything to do with interest. And, says Beacham: 'Though it took longer to make it work in the UK, there are many advantages for the customer.'

Beacham explains how the plans work: 'With the Murabaha plan, the customer gives us a down payment of up to 20 per cent, we buy the property and sell it back to the customer at a profit.' A fixed- term deal of 15 years, with the overall amount to be paid and the monthly instalments known right at the start, he describes it as 'elegant and simple'.

The other method, known as Ijara, is based on leasing and a promise to buy.

Beacham says that the company is feeling its way towards developing other financial products, but admits that in a banking environment where the rules are not written with you in mind, progress is difficult.

But if and when IIBU launches any new products, it is likely to face stiff competition. Iqbal Khan says: 'HSBC is looking at launching a Sharia-compliant global equity fund, and is also considering other products on the retail side.'

Other banks, such as Barclays and Citibank, already have their own Islamic banking units. However, despite such initiatives, and others internationally such as the Dow Jones Islamic Index in the US, progress is unlikely to be straightforward.

Khan says that the speed at which products can be brought in 'depends on the regulatory environment': products such as the equity fund can come on stream sooner than others, such as home finance. However, he says: 'The FSA [Financial Service Authority] has been positive, and we are hopeful.'

Whether or not it will offer Muslims a real alternative, Khan seems determined, at the very least, to widen the choices available. 'The third or fourth generation of Muslims deserve the chance to choose in the same way that people can now choose ethical or environmentally-friendly financial products,' he says.

And whatever their beliefs, most people will say amin to that.

fields.headline: 'Base' behaviour on interest rates
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.body:
In June 1998, I borrowed £5,000 from First National Bank. On the credit agreement, the double glazing salesman wrote the interest rate at 23.8 per cent (1.79 per cent a month) but said the finance company would confirm the exact figure.

First National wrote in November that its base rate was 12 per cent, so this was what I thought I would be paying. There have been several rate changes since, but every time First National advised me of these, it only ever showed the base rate. I was never told that I was actually paying above the base rate. I believe this deception has cost me £685.
HT, Farnham

 The agreement you signed with the double-glazing salesman, acting for First National Bank, shows the APR but not the base rate. The next communication, direct from the bank, came five months later and said 'our base rate today is 12 per cent' without mentioning an APR. The bank claims this is logical because 'APR is material only up to commencement of the agreement', while base rate is relevant 'only after the agreement takes effect'. You were never told that you would pay an amount above base rate, and were never shown both figures at the same time.

The Finance & Leasing Association's code of practice requires lenders to use plain English and clearly explain terms and conditions. First National denies misleading you over interest rates, even inadvertently, but you should complain to the Association that you could not understand First National's documents nor calculate the exact rate of interest payable when rates changed.

Dotcom shares: A real clubbing

I am chairman of an investment club currently trading in a Charles Schwab Market Master Investment Club account. On 17 April, I ordered £4,000 worth of shares in On Line and was quoted 777 shares at £ 5.15 each. When I received confirmation, Schwab had charged £6.30 for 635 shares. I checked the price via Yahoo and by Teletext and the highest price I saw was £5.31. The shares closed on the night of the 17 April at £4.95, and yet Schwab executed our deal at 8 am the following morning at £6.30. Schwab said it checked the price with Reuters and it was correct.
PD, Durham

 Because you did not place a limit on the price you were prepared to pay, you have been caught by the extreme volatility of dotcom stocks.

You placed your order 'at best' on the Monday, but the price had jumped by the time Schwab executed the order the following morning - simply because the market makers marked up the price of On Line shares. Market makers' job is to make profits for their employers. So, like a street trader selling flowers on Mother's Day, they set their prices at the level they think they can achieve. When a company's shares are tipped in a news paper, or the company makes an encouraging 7am announcement, market makers increase the price.

Pension closure: Foreign affairs

In 1969 my employer, Star Shipping, arranged a pension for me with Legal & General. I was domiciled in Japan at the time and had no residence in the UK. Two years later, Star Shipping transferred me to London and the pension continued, all the premiums being paid from Norway.

In 1982, they transferred me to the US, and I was told by L&G's agents that the pension would have to be closed if I stayed out of the UK for more than two years, which I did. Was it legal to close the pension and, if so, why was it accepted in the first place? The Star Shipping pension trustees have no knowledge of any responsibility, and Legal & General says it was only administrator.
TC, Cambridge

&'149; Legal & General has checked your file again and says the pension was set up on a broker's instruction, so it had no knowledge of your background. But the Occupational Pensions Advisory Service (Opas) can look into this for you. Telephone the helpline on 020 7233 8080 and the adviser will tell you what information they need to investigate.

All-risks cover: Hollow ring

I reported the loss of a ring to Eagle Star, which had merged with my insurance company, Zurich. Eagle Star told me my policy did not include cover for jewellery. I sent them a copy of my policy, showing that jewellery was included with house contents, but Eagle Star phoned to say it was included only if stolen from the premises, a contradiction of their previous advice.
IT, Scarborough

 Zurich has checked and found that your old insurance policy included 'all-risks' cover, for which you paid extra. This is the section that means you can claim for something you lose when you are away from the house; without it, you can claim only if the ring had been lost or stolen from home.

When you renewed with Eagle Star, which is now the brand name for Zurich policies, you chose not to pay the extra for all-risks.

Pension units: No FT comment

I have contributed to a self-administered pension with Legal & General since 1992. I was informed at the time that I could monitor the value of these funds in the Financial Times and this was the case until the beginning of March, when L&G stopped publishing the price of units. I was given the name of someone to phone but all I got was a voicemail, which has not been replied to. Neither does the website give unit prices. Couldn't they at least publish the prices on the internet, which would cost them virtually nothing and could be updated daily?
RK, Shearsby

 Legal & General has several generations of pension units, aside from unit-trust units, but those still quoted in the Financial Times do not apply to your policy. L&G has to pay the Financial Times tens of thousands of pounds a year to publish its prices, so it decided to restrict the list.

There is no limit to the volume of information L&G can put on its own website and, following your enquiry, the pensions department is trying to discover why these prices are not included.

The person you phoned says he did reply but you were out and he chose not to leave a message on your answering machine. L&G has now given you the name of a call centre agent who will give you up-to-the minute prices and instructions for finding them on the MoneyExtra website (www.moneyextra.com)

Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER and include a telephone number. Do not enclose SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The newspaper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.

webTitle: Forget the figures, read the small print

fields.headline: Forget the figures, read the small print
fields.trailText: Jim Stretton, chief executive of Standard Life, describes as 'sinister' the suggestion that the Financial Services Authority should consider banning the use of past performance statistics in adverts for investment products.
fields.body:
Jim Stretton, chief executive of Standard Life, describes as 'sinister' the suggestion that the Financial Services Authority should consider banning the use of past performance statistics in adverts for investment products. In fact, what is sinister is investment companies' determination to use such figures to tempt investors, despite repeated studies which show that relying on past performance is about as much use as betting on last week's lottery numbers.

Investors would do far better looking at the small print.

Making generalisations about what is a good or a bad product is impossible. Much depends on individual circumstances: age, wealth, the amount to be invested and the like. But, once you decide which type of investment is best for you - often with the help of a financial adviser - there are a number of statistics that can help you choose.

Perhaps the most important is what the provider charges, directly and indirectly. Firms hotly dispute this: indeed, some companies, such as Jupiter, have made their reputation by charging higher fees for delivering consistently good performance. But the statistics on the performance of Individual Savings Accounts produced by Fitzrovia, demonstrate that the cheap, Cat-marked funds, which meet Government standards, are way ahead of their dearer rivals. It believes that, just one year into the life of an Isa, the gap between Cat and non-Cat Isa may never be closed.

Next there is flexibility: is it possible to change the investment amount, or to suspend payments? Then there are the complex issues of volatility and consistency: how does investment performance fluctuate, and how well do the managers meet their performance targets?

If these statistics alone could be produced in a meaningful form to investors, it would be a powerful counterbalance to the barrage of performance statistics.

The FSA, aware of the furore a review of advertising statistics would cause, has backed off the subject. It is, however, wading boldly into other areas with its plan for comparative tables, to be published early next year and available by phone or on its website. These will compare things like costs and flexibility across different product providers, although it seems to have struggled with a sensible measure of volatility.

That at least will be a useful advance, although the FSA will have to work hard to ensure it is in a form investors can understand.

webTitle: How your home could be a winner

fields.headline: How your home could be a winner
fields.standfirst: Live near Wimbledon, Silverstone or St Andrews? You could make a tidy sum from letting during big sporting events, writes  Graham Norwood
fields.trailText: Who in their right mind would want a home near a world-class sports venue - with all the traffic, crowds and litter that would bring?
fields.body:
Who in their right mind would want a home near a world-class sports venue - with all the traffic, crowds and litter that would bring?

Some people end up there by accident - newer householders in Kent may find themselves living near a Grand Prix track if Brands Hatch takes over from Silverstone in 2002. Their older neighbours may be pleased - or infuriated - to have it back.

Others deliberately move house to be near a sports venue - and even make a profit from it. Probably the most lucrative residential rental market in England is at Wimbledon, south-west London, for the two weeks of the tennis championships.

There are few local hotels and, as tennis tournaments go, Wimbledon is long - two weeks. And some male players and sponsors warm up for it at the Stella Artois tournament, which is only a stone's throw away at Hurlingham's Queen's Club. For that period, some of the world's top players choose to rent a house rather than lie in a hotel room. If your home is very local - a maximum of 15 minutes' walk from the All England Club - you can be in for a spectacular return for two weeks.

According to Joanna Doniger, who runs the Tennis London letting agency, rents range from about £2,000 a week for a two-bedroom, two-bathroom flat in Wimbledon village to about £7,000-£8,000 a week for a five-bedroom, four-bathroom property with a secluded garden near the club. Owners get about 85 per cent of that fee; the rest goes to the agency as commission.

Over its 15-year history, Tennis London has built up a business accommodating about 500 people in some 150 properties during the Wimbledon fortnight.

So what is Doniger's advice for residents thinking of letting? 'Your house must have good bathrooms. Tennis players bring their friends and they all want to get to the club at the same time, so they're all getting ready at the same time. And the double beds must be large - tennis players are huge.'

But don't expect Formula One world champion Mika Hakkinen to rent a house near the Northamptonshire village of Silverstone for the British Grand Prix - nor to risk getting stuck in mud by bringing a road car to the track. F1 drivers either stay in multi-million pound motorhomes or fly by helicopter from the circuit to hotels (Hakkinen and the McLaren team have stayed at Raymond Blanc's Le Manoir aux Quat' Saisons in Oxfordshire in recent years).

But there is still plenty of scope for local residents to use their homes to profit from the Grand Prix weekend. Pam and David Holton run a bed and breakfast in the village and, as the race approaches, they organise nearly 40 other properties which take paying B+B customers for a few nights.

Almost all of the residents take fewer than six paying customers into their homes, which means they do not have to undergo health and safety inspections. And if, over the course of the weekend, they make £3,250 or less before expenses, there's no tax payable thanks to the Inland Revenue's Rent-a- Room scheme.

The Holtons' own permanent B&B business began four years ago. On the Saturday practice day for the Grand Prix, four Japanese tourists asked them if they knew of a bed and breakfast in the village. There were 100,000 people already at the track, and the village has only 750 houses - but the Holtons felt sorry for the four and offered accommodation. The business has grown since then.

In the six months leading up to the race, the Holtons will play host to anyone from a grandstand builder to an RAC marshal. They often have visiting contractors working for Eddie Jordan's F1 team which is based nearby. 'The circuit has done a huge amount of good for the village,' says Mrs Holton.

Of course, not everyone who lives close to the venues of big sporting events can use their home to make money - some genuinely enjoy being just down the road from the cheers.

Islington education officer Ken Witham has lived 200 yards from Arsenal's Highbury football ground since 1980 but is a fan of the club for both the football and what it has done for local residents: 'The club and the council pay for residents' parking permits for Saturday afternoon and weekday evening games, and there are special litter collections after games and sometimes on Sundays too.'

'Touch wood, but I think violence is a thing of the past. The all-seater ground now holds about 38,000 instead of over 50,000 - and things like increased prices mean the crowds are more middle-class now than they used to be.

'For women and children it can be a little uncomfortable travelling on the Tube or walking nearby at some times on a Saturday afternoon, but that's because of sheer numbers of people around.'

Property prices in streets surrounding the ground have been just as buoyant as in any comparable Islington street, according to local agents. And the possibility of the ground expanding by the compulsory purchase of some nearby homes has receded. 'It's certainly not putting anyone off,' says one agent.

The British Matchplay golf tournament, run by Mark McCormack's IMG organisation and involving just 12 players, uses 10 of the houses on the Wentworth Estate - again organised by Doniger of Tennis London. The homeowners receive between £5,000 and £6,000 each for the week, with IMG and the tournament sponsors paying not only for the players to use the large homes but also for staff to cook meals and clean during their stay.

So if you live near a major sporting event, what are the dos and don'ts to maximise the benefits of your property?

 Do be realistic and accept that this opportunity only applies if the venue is remote - there is more chance of people wanting to beat traffic queues and avoid travelling long distances.

 Do check if there are hotels nearby which normally take the visitors - for example, there is very little house rental around the Grand National at Aintree, because Liverpool is well served by hotels.

 Do check with the Inland Revenue's Guide to Property Income (available from Room 433, 22 Kingsway, London WC2B 6NR) if you intend to let out your home.

 Do consider upgrading your insurance if you vacate your property completely during the rental period.

 Don't over-advertise - if you can only accommodate four people for one weekend, why use the internet, which may attract several thousands enquiries from around the world?

 Don't try to do everything yourself - agents can advise on whether your home has the right facilities and can handle the tenants, often for just 15-20 per cent of your rental value.

Don't be tempted to modify your house to make it more attractive - adding another bathroom may get you a slightly better rental during Wimbledon fortnight, but will it 'overdevelop' the property and make it difficult to sell in the long term?

And finally, don't wait too long - estate agents at St Andrews in Fife began work a year ago to find homes to let out for the British Golf Open next month.

webTitle: A thumping good Reed? The market thinks so

fields.headline: A thumping good Reed? The market thinks so
fields.trailText: Brewing a storm | Stagecoach strife
fields.body:
Say it often enough and eventually the City will believe you. That must be what Crispin Davies, the new chief executive of Reed International, must be thinking. Last week, he told the audience at a Merrill Lynch media conference pretty much the same as he had told the City when the group announced its results in February.

Then, the shares were unmoved; now, they have jumped 20 per cent in the space of two weeks. The difference this time round is that Davies was not just talking a good game; he was delivering the first concrete evidence that he will actually do what he promises. There were four main pieces of good news.

First, on scientific publishing, he revealed that 35 per cent of its academic and scientific customers are now on its online Science Direct service, up from 25 per cent last year. That suggests that the internet service is something customers want and will be willing to pay a premium for. Second, there are early indications that Lexis, its US legal database, is regaining some of the ground lost to Thomson-Westlaw. Third, the two key new appointments - of executives to head the business and legal divisions - are imminent. That means that, by the end of September, 12 of the 15-strong senior management team will be new. Finally, Davies indicated that the group could actually exceed its target of £130 million cost savings this year.

That was particularly good news given that many in the City had doubted whether the £130m was achievable at all, given Reed's past dedication to ever-widening margins. But if it can actually deliver the £130m, rising to £170m next, their forecasts look a little more secure. In sum, Davies gave investors a real reason to buy the shares for the first time in years. They have long looked cheap compared with their media peers, but every time someone made a buy case, there was yet another piece of bad news from the group. Now, it seems, the news flow is starting to turn positive at last. Is there more to go for? The recent jump in the shares has put them on a rating of 25 times earnings - and left them 540p above the level where Throg Street cited them as a New Year share tip.

If Reed can achieve its other key promise of 7 per cent annual revenue growth by 2002, that will look cheap, but buyers may have to be patient.

Stagecoach strife

Why pay more than £400,000 a year for an outside finance director when we have a 'wee laddie' who could do the job for a fraction of the price. Those comments by Stagecoach chairman Brian Souter about his new finance director, 34 year-old Martin Griffiths, did little to ease concerns about the composition of Stagecoach's board, or the ability of its executives to question his decisions. Judging by the results for the year to March, Souter has some explaining to do.

True, profits before exceptionals were up 11 per cent to £244m. But what happens next concerns the City. The most immediate worry is Coach USA, the US bus company bought last year and proving very troublesome. In the first nine months of Stagecoach's ownership, the 7 per cent rise in revenues was outstripped by a 10 per cent rise in costs. That was doubly disappointing given that Stagecoach owes its reputation, and much of its growth, to its ruthless cost-cutting.

It is confident that management changes and new monthly targets will get it back on track. But some worry that, before the takeover, Coach was piling on the acquisitions to boost its sales line without worrying about the quality of the businesses, nor how they fitted with existing operations. Nor can Stagecoach afford to invest too much time in getting Coach USA back on track. The US bus business is fast consolidating - witness the 15 acquisitions made by Coach in the nine months since Stagecoach acquired it. The group will have to scale back those ambitions, but in doing that it runs a greater risk of being left behind - not least by other British operators such as National Express and First Group.

There is at least the prospect of higher profits at Coach, given a fair wind and some management effort. Elsewhere in the group, the picture looks bleaker. Bus profits fell marginally, despite higher turnover, as costs rose. Cost pressures are is unlikely to abate; oil prices continue to rise and Stagecoach has no forward cover for next year.

Labour costs are also under pressure - the group privately fears industrial action this year. Rail looks better, increasing profits by 16.3 per cent. But franchise renewals are looming and there is no guarantee of it keeping South West Trains - nor of how much it will have to bid to do so. Virgin Rail faces a reduction in subsidy and increased investment.

Last year could prove the high point for the business. It will certainly be the high point for group profits, barring dramatic action in the next few months. The sale of the Porterbrook leasing firm, just after the year-end, means profits this year will roughly halve. That puts them on a multiple of around 11 times earnings, which is not cheap for a business with so many uncertainties. Souter made a determined effort to stamp out speculation that he was planning to take the group private.

There is little reason for anyone else to buy them either.

Brewing a storm

Brewing, the City would agree, is not a fast-growing business. So it is not surprising that it applauded Bass's decision to sell its Tennent's, Worthington and Grolsch brands to Interbrew for £2.3 billion, a generous 23 times earnings. What is surprising is that, stripping out the brewing business, the remaining hotel and restaurant operations are valued at just 11 times earnings. Yet their prospects are far more exciting than those for beer. The discrepancy is partly because Interbrew can cut the costs in Bass brewing substantially by merging it with the Whitbread brewing business, acquired last month.

Factor in those savings and the multiple will fall. But that does not explain the undervaluation of the rest of the business. Sir Ian Prosser attributes it to the new economy, but that is a little dated now. Rather, it is likely to reflect concern about whether Bass will invest the proceeds of the brewing sale wisely. Its record on previous acquisitions, such as the Inter-Continental hotels group, and Allied's pubs is good enough to suggest that it will not squander its cash. Buy for the long term.

webTitle: With so much at stake, your money could be better spent

fields.headline: With so much at stake, your money could be better spent
fields.trailText: People aged 40 or more with little in the way of savings could be better off spending their spare cash rather than investing it in a stakeholder pension, according to draft advice issued by the pensions and investment watchdog, the Financial Services Authority.
fields.body:
People aged 40 or more with little in the way of savings could be better off spending their spare cash rather than investing it in a stakeholder pension, according to draft advice issued by the pensions and investment watchdog, the Financial Services Authority.

The FSA has drawn up draft 'decision trees', to help people decide whether they should invest in a stakeholder scheme or not. A decision tree entitled 'How much should I save for when I retire?' indicates that people aged 40 or more, who can only afford to save £20 a month, could receive a monthly pension of less than £47. This, combined with the basic state pension, is not enough to exceed the minimum income guarantee, a means-tested benefit which currently ensures that a single person receives at least £339.95 a month.

In guidance notes accompanying the decision trees, the FSA says: 'Particularly if you are over 40, have little pension or other savings and cannot afford to save much, the little you are able to put into a stakeholder may not be enough to bring your total retirement income above the MIG. It would then be wasted.'

Some pension providers and independent financial advisers fear this information will discourage the over-40s from saving. But Martin Campbell of Virgin Direct does not think the FSA has gone far enough in clarifying the situation: 'We would like the Government to state a minimum funding level for people of different ages - a clear benchmark showing whether it's in their interests to save in a stakeholder, or whether they should be considering an alternative form of saving.'

Someone saving a small amount in an Isa, for example, could use their savings to pay off part of their mortgage and thus prevent the money counting against their means-tested benefits after retirement.

In contrast, the low charges and flexibility of stakeholder schemes should prove advantageous to investors on average or higher earnings. The 1 per cent cap on annual charges is expected to become the industry norm for personal pensions, and the lower profit margins and increased competition between pension providers is likely to result in a flood of mergers and takeovers, making the choice of a specific stakeholder scheme easier.

However, Nick Bamford, of independent pensions adviser Cranleigh Informed Choice, says that even wealthier investors would benefit by keeping part of their savings outside of a pension scheme. He said: 'While the tax advantages of pensions are undoubtedly attractive, you cannot access any of your money until you reach retirement age. As you never know when you might need some capital, it's a good idea to put some of your money into an Isa or some other accessible investment scheme.'

A new Trades Union Congress webpage (www.tuc.org.uk/stakeholder ) contains information and can answer questions about stakeholder pensions.

For the FSA's draft decision trees, visit www.fsa.gov.uk, click on publications, followed by discussion papers and download PDF 1.23MM.

webTitle: When the spinning had to stop

fields.headline: When the spinning had to stop
fields.standfirst:
Tony Blair has realised that he has to prove to the electorate that New Labour has a purpose greater than mere presentation

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair won office by brilliantly reaching out beyond his party's core base to construct a new coalition spanning old believers in Labour and fresh converts.   Three years on, that talent for coalition-building is attacked as one of his worst weaknesses. The soured former Minister, Peter Kilfoyle, complains that the Prime Minister wants to be 'all things to all men'.
fields.body:
It gets them all in the end. The qualities that were seen as the shining virtues of a Prime Minister when the curtain goes up are redefined as their terrible vices when the cheers turn to jeers.

Margaret Thatcher was the battling Iron Lady when she arrived in office. She was a swivel-eyed autocrat when she was thrown out. Her replacement, John Major, was celebrated as a modest and consensual good bloke at his beginning. He was derided as a limp and dithering prat by his end. The clever technocrat that was Harold Wilson when he entered Number 10 was an unprincipled trimmer by the time he left. Events and disappointments turn strengths inside out until they are weaknesses.

So it was virtually ordained that it would happen to Tony Blair. He won office by brilliantly reaching out beyond his party's core base to construct a new coalition spanning old believers in Labour and fresh converts. Ken Livingstone, Roy Jenkins and Margaret Thatcher, albeit for different reasons, all wanted Tony Blair to be Prime Minister. Three years on, that talent for coalition-building is attacked as one of his worst weaknesses. The soured former Minister, Peter Kilfoyle, complains that the Prime Minister wants to be 'all things to all men'. Tony Wright, such an impeccably Blairite figure that he shares a Christian name with the leader, says the Government's message has gone 'fuzzy'. That very lightness of ideological being that helped float New Labour into power is now blamed for that sinking feeling in the polls.

What is most alarming for the Government is not that this has happened. As I say, this decay is programmed into the biological clock of politics. The worry for New Labour is that time is running so quickly. The ambition was to have at least two terms, a decade of progressive government. Less than a third of the way into that stretch, the reversing process is already well advanced.

The strong and unchallenged leadership that was once a key to Blair's electoral appeal has become control-freakism. A united party has become one in which dissent is suppressed. Once, there was general wonder at Tony Blair's consummate ability to cultivate whichever audience he happened to be standing in front of. The Prime Minister's values problem is that many people think he is the dummy and they are his ventriloquists. It's not true that Tony Blair is just a presentational confection, but that doesn't matter half as much as the widespread perception that that is the truth. And who was it who tutored us to treat perception as so all-important? New Labour.

The same media now condemns that to which they were once so enthralled.

Is there anything more gimmicky than the Tory leader's Save The Pound Day? If he sincerely rejects spin, then I presume Mr Hague will be sacking his own spin-nurse, the lovely Amanda Platell. Ken Livingstone, who has had much satirical fun at the expense of New Labour's spinners, has just appointed his own sultan of spin.

The media that condemn the Government for being obsessed with spin is even more fixated with the subject themselves. On Wednesday, there were several good political stories about, not least the widening Cabinet divisions about the single currency. But at the afternoon briefing of lobby correspondents, Britain's finest political journalists spent their time asking Alastair Campbell why he was not going to brief them so regularly in future. That was the lead political story on ITN news.

As is so often the case with New Labour, their mentors the other side of the Atlantic got to this place first. George Stephanopoulos, writer of the best memoir of the Clinton administration, records how the 'success at spin control' created a backlash against it. 'Elaborate staging only increased the tendency of sceptical reporters to focus on the process rather than the substance of what we were trying to say. Alastair Campbell is my least likely candidate to be a practitioner of a Zen approach to anything in life. I do not see him sitting cross-legged in a meditative transcendental state. Rumours of his retirement have been much exaggerated. He is not going to write his memoirs, take up the editorship of the Mirror or become Lord Campbell of Burnley, not for a while yet. What is true is that Campbell has decided to leave more of the briefings of the correspondents at Westminster to his deputy, an anonymous career civil servant called Godric Smith.

Campbell, even though, or perhaps because, he was once a lobby journalist himself, has always had a barely concealed loathing for his former colleagues. He announced himself to his first briefing of the Sunday political lobby with the words: 'Explain to me why I should waste my time with a load of wankers like you when you're not going to write anything I tell you anyway.'

You might expect the journalists to be overjoyed that they will not have this sort of abuse inflicted on them in the future. How long have they been complaining that Campbell is a brute and a thug? But they are not happy at all; they are furious. 'We'll be the losers,' one political editor wailed at that briefing on Wednesday.

They don't want a dead bat from the civil service; they want the spin bowler. The same people who have been whingeing all this time about being twisted and bullied by Campbell are now moaning that he won't be around so much to kick them anymore.

The attempt to lower his profile is of a piece with the switch of strategy indicated when Tony Blair said they had to stop 'fighting over every headline'. So is a decision to stem the cascade of announcements. Can New Labour really give up spin? Won't they crack when the headlines begin to fill with stories spun by the Conservatives and whipped up by journalists? Alastair Campbell did manage to forswear drinking and Tony Blair quit smoking, but I suspect they will find it more of a challenge to join Spinners Anonymous.

What's not in doubt is that the perception that New Labour is all presentation and no purpose has become dangerous to its health. One member of the Cabinet put it this strongly to me: 'This Government was elected by spin, and it is dying from spin.'

The epitaph that Tony Blair does not want to read on the tombstone of his Government is: The Wages Of Spin.
