fields.headline: Endowments nightmare comes true
fields.trailText: First the predictions, now the reality. Homeowners have been warned that their endowments might not pay off their mortgages, but optimism has been easy because 25-year policies have been maturing at ever-higher values, reflecting the shares boom 20 years ago.
fields.body:
First the predictions, now the reality. Homeowners have been warned that their endowments might not pay off their mortgages, but optimism has been easy because 25-year policies have been maturing at ever-higher values, reflecting the shares boom 20 years ago.

Now the falling returns are being counted in real pounds and pence. A new survey by magazine Money Marketing shows that this year the average pay-out for a 25-year endowment is down, compared with last year.

Falling returns do not necessarily mean a mortgage deficit, but it is a pointer to the way things are going. And even if policies do repay loans, this will fall short of the promises made to many homeowners about dazzling pre-retirement surpluses.

The survey also confirmed that few firms yet offer schemes that will meet the 1 per cent a year charging cap for the Government's stakeholder pensions.

The Association of Unit Trusts and Investment Funds lamented Government's 'interference' in such charges, and urged a review. In an industry where charges have blighted the returns on so many products, that time is not yet come.

This week's prize for the silliest insurance policy goes to the company promoting cover against 'flying, biting, stinging or crawling insects and rodents'. A spokesman was unable to give any figures on the statistical likelihood of household infestation but I think I'll take my chances with ant powder. Full marks for PR ingenuity, however, with an email guaranteed to catch the eye of junk mail-weary computer slaves, headlined, 'Pest Master Protection Plan'.

webTitle: Fed up with football? Here's yet another baseball movie. Say it ain't so, Kevin...

fields.headline: Fed up with football? Here's yet another baseball movie. Say it ain't so, Kevin...
fields.standfirst: Costner is stuck at first base, Veronica Guerin's story is less dramatic than real life, the writer of Erin Brockovich fails Sandra Bullock, but at least time travel is still gripping
fields.trailText: Frequency | For the Love of the Game | When the Sky Falls | 28 Days | Supernova | Small Time Obsession
fields.body:
Frequency (118 mins, 15) Directed by Gregory Hoblit; starring Dennis Quaid, Jim Cavaziel

For the Love of the Game (137 mins, 12) Directed by Sam Raimi; starring Kevin Costner, Kelly Preston

When the Sky Falls (107 mins,18) Directed by John MacKenzie; starring Joan Allen, Patrick Bergan

28 Days (109 mins, 15) Directed by Betty Thomas; starring Sandra Bullock, Steve Buscemi

Supernova (90 mins, 15) Directed by Thomas Lee; starring James Spader, Angela Bassett

Small Time Obsession (119 mins, 15) Directed by Piotr Szkopiak; starring Alex King, Juliette Caton

For once the posters are spot on. Back to the Future meets The Sixth Sense. That is Frequency, a cat's cradle of time travel with added serial killing. Jim Cavaziel is a disillusioned New York cop, wallowing in Scotch and lost love, who digs out his dead dad's old ham radio and - hey presto! - finds himself talking to Pa Frank (Dennis Quaid) across 30 years. Quaid was a fireman who died in a warehouse fire. Can Cavaziel, by warning him of the inferno to come, change the history of the next three decades? You bet: and everything - from newspaper headlines to the memory of friends - changes simultaneously. But now, with the change, his mum (a shimmering newcomer, Elizabeth Mitchell) is set to die young herself, murdered by a maniac with a penchant for slashing nurses.

The plot, by Toby Emmerich, is like a Russian doll, ripping away mechanically from layer to layer. Gregory Hoblit is a director graduate of the Hill Street Blues Academy. He handles the fires, murders and mayhem with jaggedly exciting aplomb. This, for most of the way, is a roller coaster of a thriller which only goes splat at the end - about three twists too far. But that doesn't matter too much because, for all the guff about parallel universes, the true heart of Frequency is just another love story, this time between father and son. Quaid, the nearly-star of the past two decades, is honest and tender and giving; Cavaziel, the son who thought he'd lost him, has a dogged, hangdog empathy. When they talk baseball and the New York Mets - the hinge of reunion - their relationship lives. Tune to the right human frequency, the only one that matters.

If a little of that tale is long on baseball, though, try For the Love of the Game which is very long on baseball indeed. Weary of Euro 2000 already? Here's Kevin Costner as a 40-year-old wonder pitcher for the Detroit Tigers about to lose the magazine writer he doesn't know he needs (Kelly Preston) and rescue a wretched season by stuffing the New York Yankees in the final game. Much of the 137 minutes are spent in flashback as Costner, face frozen in constipated introspection, winds up Yankee Stadium (as well as himself for the great decision).

This is the third and least of Costner's baseball essays: without the emotional swell of Field of Dreams or the acerbity of Bull Durham . Dana Stevens's screenplay rarely escapes novelette slush, and all Sam Raimi's directorial skills can't spring many surprises. But it is not a total dog. Costner conjures up his old anxious integrity: Preston, the Mrs Travolta who survived Battlefield Earth , manages wounded devotion well. The real trouble for non-fans of baseball is structural. Because you know how many innings there are to go, you know requited love is stuck at first base. Maybe Costner might fancy cricket next? The first film to take five days - without a proper ending.

If there's a target audience for a film about the life, times and death of Veronica Guerin, I suppose it's me. I was there a few hours after her murder at a meeting she was due to address: all around, there was wincing shock that a brilliant reporter could be shot down in Dublin (or indeed any Western city boasting a patina of civilisation) because of what she wrote and the drug barons she sought to expose. Thus her story, When the Sky Falls, delivered by John MacKenzie of The Long Good Friday, one of Britain's tautest action directors, ought to carry a particular charge. Alas, it is perfectly decent in a penny-plain way, but oddly uninvolving.

There is nothing wrong with the casting. Joan Allen (the Hi honey! from Pleasantville ) is a gossamer thin but radiant, staunch Guerin - here lightly disguised as one 'Sinead Hamilton'. Gerard Flynn, Jimmy Smallhorne and Liam Cunningham fish balefully on the dark side of the Liffey. The exploration of Ireland's druggy underworld carries brutal conviction. But this is drama, not documentary, and the trouble is that we all know how it ends, so momentum drains inexorably as the beatings come and go, mere preludes to the awful coup de grce . We're told what happened, but not why. Why Guerin, loving mother and wife, risked everything? Why, on this rendition, her editors let her court such danger? Why she was as she heroically was? Three scriptwriters - including her friend and colleague, Michael Sheridan - can't seem to reach beyond the indomitable surface: perhaps because, even now, no one truly understands what ticked underneath.

From one tragic, real journalist to a tragic, synthetic journalist. All downhill, of course. Sandra Bullock is a big-city columnist who pops pills, swigs booze and makes cringingly embarrassing speeches at her sister's wedding, whereupon she staggers into her car and wipes out somebody's front porch. Her sentence is the movie's title: 28 Days (in the Serenity Glen Rehabilitation Centre). She begins in caustic denial, spraying defiant wisecracks at pious platitudes. 'Can I have that stitched on a pillow?' But gradually, Sandy realises she's got A Problem.

The most interesting thing about 28 Days is that it has done pretty well at the US box office. How, you wonder, can that be? Is it a comedy? Not exactly, though the supporting chorus of recovering addicts is mostly played for farce. (Even Ben Elton might jib at a comedy about drug abuse, sex addiction and self-mutilation). Heavy drama, then, in the Days of Wine and Roses mould? No. Bullock, Hollywood's archetypal kookie waif, is more The Girl with the Golden Orthodontist. The nearest the director, Betty Thomas, comes to a settled style is Soviet workers' film education unit, circa 1957. This is heavy-message territory, and I mean heavy. There's a supremely clunky finale as our heroine and her sister (Elizabeth Perkins) are reconciled. 'I've been such an arse,' says Sandy. 'Every arse needs someone_ to take care of them,' says sis.

The script, amazingly enough, is by Susannah Grant, fresh from Erin Brockovich . Did somebody think that Bullock, stuck in a rut as everyone's favourite Julia Roberts reserve, would get a similar lift? She's gallant and appealing, and this is her best for yonks. But the verbal dross around her is total quagmire. Oh Susannah!

So to the bottom of the Second Division with a mystery question. Who is Thomas Lee, the director of Supernova? Answer: Walter Hill, who made a lot of action movies, including The Driver , in the Seventies and Eighties. Why, then, doesn't he claim this spaced-out yarn as his own? It seems promising enough, a kind of intergalactic ER. Paramedic spaceship Nightingale 229 gets emergency call from deserted mine on rogue moon. Various nude members of crew, experiencing connubial bliss, rush to action stations.

Enter Peter Facinelli, who may or may not be the ex-lover of Nightingale's doctor, Angela Bassett. Facinelli turns out to be a Terminator 2 or Alien 3, with extraordinary powers of self-regeneration. Will acting captain James Spader and Bassett save the day? Will a lava lamp blow up the universe and re-make it in some malign image? Does anybody care?

Sadly, Small Time Obsession can only be a non-league contender. Piotr Szkopiak, its writer, producer and director, is a south London Pole telling the Balham/Catford/Woolwich yarn of other first-generation Poles flirting with petty crime. Lumpen plot, nil excitement or revelation; your heart goes out to a young cast - especially Juliette Caton - who deserve something better than this routinely stuffed cabbage.

fields.trailText: Encounters: New Art from Old | Turner Prize short list
fields.body:
Encounters: New Art from Old
National Gallery, London WC2 to 17 September

Turner Prize short list

No British show in living memory has had a grander cast of contemporary stars than Encounters: New Art from Old at the National Gallery. Twenty-four of the world's leading artists have been invited to respond to one of the museum's old masters with a work of their own.

The dance-card is dazzling: Freud with Chardin, Oldenburg with Vermeer, Bourgeois and Twombly with Turner. Anthony Caro returns to Duccio in 1311; Euan Uglow skips forward to Monet, who was still alive when Balthus, oldest of the living artists, was already copying Poussin.

This invitation to understudy the masters is a tactful ruse for infiltrating ancient with modern, for slipping the twenty-first century into a museum that stops at 1900. But it is also a chancy enterprise, as likely to produce outright duds, it seems, as contemporary masterpieces.

The museum as muse is a natural subject for a show for the simple reason that art always comes from art. At the Prado, for example, you can see what Velázquez made of Caravaggio, what Goya took from Velázquez and how Picasso fretted over Goya from first to last. At his own request, Turner hangs next to Claude Lorrain in the National Gallery, precisely to acknowledge the debt.

Ever since the boom-age of museums in the nineteenth century, artists have been copying the art of the past to see how it worked. If you don't see many easels at the National Gallery today, it may be because the museum opens to artists after hours.

Which is precisely how Lucian Freud came to transcribe Chardin's Young Schoolmistress at dead of night over several months. Of all the works in this show, Freud's are undoubtedly the bravest: three hard won copies horribly exposed beside the sublime original. Freud works and reworks Chardin, struggling to discover the secrets of his grace. But each study is progressively coarser and more laborious until the contrast between the artists becomes wincingly painful. The best that can be said of this exercise is that it expresses Freud's devoted humility.

Other artists have taken the invitation more lightly. Patrick Caulfield extracts Zurbarán's gleaming beaker from the seventeenth century, adds designer beer and incorporates the updated vignette into a contemporary tapas bar. Jeff Wall photographs a Blackpool donkey, camera-shy in its lowly stall, as a counter to the imperious grandeur of Stubbs's thoroughbred Whistlejacket. R.B. Kitaj plants a cigar-chewing billionaire in Vincent's humble chair, signing the picture 'Ronald' in solidarity with his downtrodden forebear.

This monologue says a great deal about Kitaj and nothing about Vincent or his chair. But the dialogues the gallery hoped for are going on elsewhere. Hockney's fascination with Ingres produces not one but three dozen love letters, inscribed in portraits of the museum guards. Each isolates a separate element of Ingres's genius: his gift for sketching a perfect head in seconds, his couturier's attention to clothes, the way he tucks the gesturing hands into the final portrait as signposts to the sitter's character.

Hockney's works hang in the temporary galleries - they would crowd out the Ingres upstairs. But Encounters spreads right through the museum: Caro's sculptures, adding a third dimension to Duccio, are in the Sunley Room; Hodgkin's version of Seurat's Bathers hangs, Turner-Lorrain style, next to its inspiration.

It's a fine reprise, a semi-abstract summary that quickens the stillness of the original. Seurat's motionless smoke becomes a rippling banner, his pointillist dots float free like airy bubbles, barely contained by the frame. You begin to see how much Seurat must have contributed to Hodgkin's distinctive idiom.

If Manet means anything to Jasper Johns, on the other hand, he hasn't declared it here. Johns's painting, an expanse of grey encaustic draped with a length of string, looks very much like all the other works in his recent 'Catenary' series. This is the tricky thing about a show like this. The National Gallery sends out polite invitations to the great and the good and is then forced to reap what it sows. How else to explain the inclusion of Balthus's ghastly soft-porn nymph or the faeryland symbolism of Christopher Le Brun, gallery trustee?

There are two masterpieces in Encounters, both of them begun before the exhibition was conceived, both independent of the past masters with which they are paired. One is Frank Auerbach's stunning London landscape, a ferment of scarlet vectors and dawn-breaking clouds that just happens to have a compositional affinity with Constable's Haywain. The other is Bill Viola's extraordinary video, The Quintet of the Astonished.

Before you is a static frame of four men and a woman, dressed in dateless clothing, huddled together like the mourning figures beneath the Cross. Each is expressing a deep and separate reaction to some unseen event - from anguished fury to beatific trance. The background is shallow and dark, the lighting a little like a Caravaggio. It is some time before you realise that the figures are moving imperceptibly; the picture is alive.

What you see is a 50-second film, slowed down to eight minutes of near-frozen time. The configuration changes, the expressions alter, welling, peaking and subsiding. Viola's film visualises emotion in its universal state, rippling through the passage of time. It also condenses in one intensely beautiful tableau all the sorrowing crowd scenes in the National Gallery.

Glenn Brown, short-listed this week for the Turner Prize, is the quintessential nearly-new artist. Brown paints flawless reproductions of photographs - photographs of famous paintings. You can't see a brushmark in his pictures which, in turn, erase all the painterly nuance of the originals. His work is introverted, styleless and melancholy, as if he were trapped in a world where art was finished.

Tomoko Takahashi is equally obsessive. Since graduating from the Slade, she has catalogued all the molehills in a Somerset field and sorted tons of discarded junk on the floor of the Saatchi Gallery - brass tacks, defunct machines, cigarette butts and so on. I liked the way she lit this archipelago with flickering bulbs and tellies, but the sum never amounted to more than the shored-up ruins.

Wolfang Tillmans's photographs are just as null as he wants them to be: off-handed shots of club scenes and German pals relieving themselves on sofas. These used to appear in I-D . Now they have unaccountably leaked into the gallery system and on to the Turner shortlist.

Which leaves Michael Raedecker, who won last year's John Moores Prize for his beautiful painting of a desert, eerily stitched and sequinned. Perhaps he will win the Turner, too, though Brown is already tipped. Of all the work in this year's sensation-free shortlist, Raedecker's is the least bleak.

webTitle: A bird on the lights, action in the bushes - it's bucolic opera

fields.headline: A bird on the lights, action in the bushes - it's bucolic opera
fields.trailText: Le Nozze di Figaro | Jessye Norman
fields.body:
Le Nozze di Figaro

Garsington Opera, Oxfordshire

Jessye Norman

Hampton Court Palace, Surrey

How funny is Mozart's Le Nozze di Figaro? Some productions play the opera as knockabout and lose the essential buoyancy; others treat it as something so fragile that they miss its robustness. Although crisply conducted by Stephen Barlow, Garsington Opera's new production favours the latter and laughs are correspondingly thin on the ground. If they proliferate after the dinner interval, I'm not sure Stephen Unwin's staging can take all the credit.

Raising a laugh is always difficult when Garsington insists on performing in the original language, providing, instead of subtitles, a printed libretto with translation. I found it depressing to see so many people following the text rather than the action. If that is what happens with a repertoire staple like Figaro , it must be the more so when Garsington stages the rarities that it is rightly proud of (Robert Schumann's Genoveva opens next Sunday).

Garsington audiences can picnic in grounds that make Glyndebourne's look suburban. The gardens are visible from the marquee that constitutes the auditorium, and Unwin sometimes creates a split-screen effect by having peripheral action among the bushes. Given that Neil Warmington's set and Mark Bouman's costumes hold little visual interest, it is easy to look at the flowers instead.

All very agreeable, and perhaps we should be content with the vaguely bucolic experience, but the singers deserve more. At last Wednesday's first night, there were several eye- and ear-catching performances; and everyone sang the recitative as if it mattered, which it does. Caddish and haughty, Peter Savidge's Count had greater presence than Franzita Whelan's hesitant Countess; her voice, though, is rich and creamy, and on a warmer night she will come into her own. It was Mark Stone's Figaro, though, who ran the show. Singing with poise and intensity, he came close to making every word, every gesture, matter, no mean achievement in this somewhat anti-theatrical context.

The Hampton Court Palace Festival gets the picnicking in before the main event, so that last Tuesday's performance by Jessye Norman had the benefit of a clear, balmy evening slowly turning to night. The effect was magical, quite unlike the concert-hall experience, and the festival duly attracts a different audience from the one Norman might get at the Barbican, say. Before she came onstage, I heard someone say to her companion: 'Isn't it a shame Lesley Garrett isn't doing it this year?'

It's hard to imagine Garrett doing comparable justice to such exquisite pieces as Berlioz's Les Nuits d'Eté and Ravel's Schéhérazade . They were respectfully received, but it was only when Norman turned to Gershwin that the first cries of 'Brava!' were heard.

Norman's Gershwin is less mannered than many classically trained singers. Her embellishments have an authentic jazz tang and she doesn't exaggerate the emotions simply to prove that she's enjoying herself. No doubt it helped that, to cope with the open-air acoustic, she was amplified, but many singers take that as an excuse to go for broke; Norman's approach was the very opposite of barnstorming. Her 'The Man I Love' had a yearning delicacy, while the inevitable 'Summertime' became a sad lament, the singer's decorations occupying a middle ground between baroque and the blues.

Nothing wrong with giving your audience what it expects, but I was more moved by her Berlioz and Ravel, although the tempos that she and conductor Jane Glover adopted sometimes bordered on the laborious. We think of Norman as a singer with a big voice, but her control of dynamics was ravishing, right down to the most fragile pianissimos that a passing plane threatened to overwhelm. Glover and the English Chamber Orchestra provided substantial orchestral interludes by Delius, Elgar and Copland, so that Norman's contribution barely lasted an hour, including a raucously exaggerated encore from Bizet's Carmen , but I don't think anyone felt short-changed.

 Figaro is in rep at Garsington until 7 July (01865 361636)

Fiona Maddocks in on holiday

webTitle: The tsar thought it merely 'very nice'

fields.headline: The tsar thought it merely 'very nice'
fields.standfirst: ...look where that got him
fields.trailText: The Sleeping Beauty
fields.body:
The Sleeping Beauty Kirov Ballet, Royal Opera House, London WC2

Tchaikovsky was sorely miffed by the tsar's reaction to his new ballet. 'Very nice' was all that Alexander III could think to say. Tchaikovsky noted the banality in his diary with five exclamation marks.

Considering that The Sleeping Beauty's score is the greatest ballet music ever written, for a production in 1890 that had consumed over a quarter of the imperial theatres' budget, the response was hardly adequate. But the tsar may have been disconcerted by the ballet's implicit advice to rulers: don't be a vacillating tyrant; beware of snubbing powerful opponents; be kind to peasants. Alexander was not to recognise a prophetic warning to his heir: never let a cossetted royal child prick its finger.

Tsar Nicholas II lost the imperial throne to the revolutionaries. The Imperial Ballet survived, renamed the Kirov, and The Sleeping Beauty endured Marxist views on what the people wanted. Almost a century later, the ballet has been restored to its tsarist splendour, against stiff resistance from the old guard. Convinced that progress was best, former Communists in the Maryinsky Theatre thought it revanchist to bring back the original mime and choreography, let alone spend a fortune on copying dated designs and extravagant costumes.

The new guard at the Kirov/Maryinsky, ballet director Makhar Vaziev and his assistant Sergei Vikharev, persisted. What to us may seem simply a conservation exercise turns out to be radical - and very Russian. If the Royal Ballet did this production, we'd probably be as dismissive as The Observer was about Diaghilev's 1921 London revival: 'A spectacle too endlessly the same to endure four hours' complete attention.' But reclaimed by the Kirov as part of its inheritance, this Sleeping Beauty is a glimpse of ballet heaven.

It is not precisely the 1890 original: even it were, we would not watch it with the eyes of spectators only recently accustomed to electric lighting on stage. Petipa's choreography has been decoded by Vikharev from notation made for a 1903 revival by the regisseur , Nikolai Sergeyev. Since Sergeyev taught a reduced version to the Royal Ballet in the Thirties, most of the steps are familiar. What is new is the epic scale of the ballet - the sense it gives of Petipa as a theatrical director deploying massed forces.

The Royal Opera House stage can only just accommodate the 120 dancers and extras. Performers are stacked in symmetrical patterns, interwoven like the garlands they carry for Aurora's birthday celebrations. Costumes delineate rank: clogs and aprons for peasants, heels and feathered hats for courtiers, stripes for pages, mini-crinis for aristocratic fairies and attendants.

Colours can be garish. Children in scarlet wind their way through merrymakers in Prussian blue and white. Cherubs with golden wigs accompany the Lilac Fairy, who wears a plumed helmet and carries a feather-duster staff when she isn't dancing. Yes, she does have a variation in the Prologue, one of two in her name in the notated score. Veronika Part danced and mimed divinely. Of the two Auroras I saw, Svetlana Zakharova was the more appealing. Slender and vulnerable on needle legs, she gave a musical portrait of Aurora as period princess and modern technician. Diana Vishneva was dazzling but too keen to show off her virtuoso skills.

In the last act, Aurora brings her 100-year-old dowry to the court of Versailles, where her marriage is blessed by the immortals. The fairies are enthroned on clouds in an allegorical tableau. Even wicked Carabosse is there, guarded by seraphs. Rulers of all ages remember: evil and unrest may be contained but not eliminated.

fields.headline: Two pilots in one hot airship
fields.trailText: One clue to understanding this government is that it is run by a duumvirate. Students of ancient history will recall that duumvirates tended to be unstable. Constitutional historian Peter Hennessey sees Tony Blair as chief executive, and his Ministers as branch managers, while Gordon Brown 'through the instrument of the comprehensive spending reviews and the detailed public service agreements attached to them, exerts more sway over departmental policy outcomes that any previous Chancellor'.
fields.body:
One clue to understanding this government is that it is run by a duumvirate. Students of ancient history will recall that duumvirates tended to be unstable. Constitutional historian Peter Hennessey sees Tony Blair as chief executive, and his Ministers as branch managers, while Gordon Brown 'through the instrument of the comprehensive spending reviews and the detailed public service agreements attached to them, exerts more sway over departmental policy outcomes that any previous Chancellor'.

One insider says: 'Brown is chief executive and Blair non-executive chairman.' Hennessey says: 'This is not a relationship of command centre and obliging periphery; it's a careful, though temperamentally difficult, division of labour between the Downing Street neighbours.' Yes, the Duumvirs are the Prime Minister and the Chancellor, and every now and again they have to deal with Europe. This is usually when the pro-euro lobby stirs up trouble, and rumours proliferate about a switch to a more positive euro policy.

Brown then has to take time off from his comprehensive spending reviews and his detailed public service agreements to restate the policy of 'prepare now and decide after the election'. Last week was like that. The pro-euro lobby was everywhere, and it was convenient for the Chancellor that the latest burst of pressure coincided with the annual Mansion House speech, at which Brown duly took the opportunity to announce in great detail that the Duumvirate had not budged an inch.

The Chancellor's position is that the election should be fought on the platform of 'it's the economy, stupid' and that conditions for entry are all-important. Listening to some of the pro-euro lobby, you would think that one of the most difficult decisions for a British government in many a decade is so important politically that the economic aspects hardly matter. As pilot of the underpowered airship called Euro Policy, the Chancellor attracts a lot of flak. Yet it is interesting to note that Bob Worcester, one of the most experienced pollsters in the business, believes Brown's strategy is absolutely right. Worcester recently argued that the Government could turn public opinion around quite dramatically in the course of a referendum campaign; but he told me last week that it makes perfect political sense for the Government to resist the Conservative tactic of mak ing the future of the pound the principal election issue.

A strong body of opinion has it that circumstances will force the Government to display more enthusiasm about the euro in the run-up to the election; and the belief in Westminster is that one member of the duumvirate, the Prime Minister, has approved of the 'euro' remarks from other Cabinet members that have so annoyed the Chancellor. Blair cannot afford either to lose his Chancellor or to allow Brown's position to be weakened. Brown is known for his prudence; Blair for the marked element of caution in his character.

However hard the more ardent Europhiles push him, Blair must have nightmares about a situation in which a 'single issue' election (the euro) endangered his 180-seat majority. The Government is committed to joining a 'success ful' euro if the economic conditions are right and the people approve. Labour, after all, as political commentator Alan Watkins often reminds us, is the 'People's Party'. Many of my best friends are ardent Europhiles; but when you think of the endemic problems of inflation and low productivity that have plagued the British economy for years, it is surprising that people are prepared to dismiss so lightly the Chancellor's argument that there should be more evidence of 'sustainable' economic convergence with mainland Europe.

Most observers dismiss the 'convergence' tests as a mere figleaf for a decision that is essentially political. It is not difficult to imagine the disastrous economic and political consequences if the British economy entered the euro at too high an exchange rate; and, with due respect to the Nobel Laureate Robert Mundell, three deutschmarks to the pound sounds dangerously high as an entry rate. And that would be forever... As I understand the Chancellor's strategy, it is to make the British economy strong enough to cope with entry to the euro. He knows that, for all the cheap gibes made in this country against the putative 'structural rigidities' in the eurozone, the eurozone is in fact performing a lot better than in the days when pre-Maastricht restrictive economic policies held it back. It is also in high-tax, high-public-spending Scandinavia that the leadership in mobile phone technology has emerged. Meanwhile, for all the parallels drawn between the so called 'Anglo Saxon' economies, US productivity growth has been more impressive in recent years than the UK's. You have only to look at the map to know where the British economy belongs.

And you have only to read paragraph two of the Maastricht Treaty to know what we have signed up to: 'The Community shall have as its task, by establishing a common market and an economic and monetary union ...' The joker in the pack is that there is no formal time-limit on the 'temporary' opt-out from the euro.
fields.bodyText: One clue to understanding this government is that it is run by a duumvirate. Students of ancient history will recall that duumvirates tended to be unstable. Constitutional historian Peter Hennessey sees Tony Blair as chief executive, and his Ministers as branch managers, while Gordon Brown 'through the instrument of the comprehensive spending reviews and the detailed public service agreements attached to them, exerts more sway over departmental policy outcomes that any previous Chancellor'. One insider says: 'Brown is chief executive and Blair non-executive chairman.' Hennessey says: 'This is not a relationship of command centre and obliging periphery; it's a careful, though temperamentally difficult, division of labour between the Downing Street neighbours.' Yes, the Duumvirs are the Prime Minister and the Chancellor, and every now and again they have to deal with Europe. This is usually when the pro-euro lobby stirs up trouble, and rumours proliferate about a switch to a more positive euro policy. Brown then has to take time off from his comprehensive spending reviews and his detailed public service agreements to restate the policy of 'prepare now and decide after the election'. Last week was like that. The pro-euro lobby was everywhere, and it was convenient for the Chancellor that the latest burst of pressure coincided with the annual Mansion House speech, at which Brown duly took the opportunity to announce in great detail that the Duumvirate had not budged an inch. fields.headline: Languorous liaisons
fields.standfirst: Trust the French to make an 'adult movie' that is elegant, intense and melancholy...
fields.trailText: Une Liaison Pornographique
fields.body:
Une Liaison Pornographique (81 mins, 15) Directed by Frédéric Fonteyne; starring Nathalie Baye, Sergi Lopez

Sometimes a diet of Hollywood waffle and syrupy strings sits heavy on the psyche; sometimes you need spare, understated simplicity. Une Liaison Pornographique provides exactly that movie minceur. There's nothing here for Channel 5 and the post-Cheggers yobbo slot. This is grown-up filmmaking for grown-up people.

No names and no background pack drill. Nathalie Baye is Her, a chic Parisian who - just once - advertises for sex with a stranger in a cheap magazine. Sergi Lopez is Him, a squat bear of a Catalan who answers the ad and turns up at the appointed café on time. She has booked a cheap hotel round the corner. Well, let's get on with it! And they do - a kinky, though non-specific, encounter the News of the World might get excited about. Same again next week? OK. See you. The mating rituals are back to front. They begin with clinical lust, and then, all unawares, he wrecks it. How about a drink and dinner? Their minds start to engage.

Neither Frédéric Fonteyne's direction nor Philippe Blasand's screenplay offer us any clues about who Baye and Lopez are, where they come from, what they do. The format is constructed, quite lightly, around anonymous interviews with the pair looking back in wry melancholy. That sounds irritating - too stuffed with arty portent and Gallic symbolism, but, in fact, it works perfectly. There is so little you need to know to know these lovers well. We aren't shown the initial couplings. The hotel door along the red corridor closes behind them. It is only much later that she suggests they make love. But haven't we been doing that? says Lopez. No, let's make normal love, me on top if that's all right? And then the bedroom door opens and they chatter and mumble their way through the act. Pull the sheet over my head, she says at the last. 'I screw my face up when I come.'

Baye is one of the great film actresses of the past two decades: precise, haunting, submerged in her character. Here, she is by turns plain and beautiful, nudging into middle-age and frightened, from bitter experience, of risking too much until risk carries her away. It is Lopez, though, who defines the relationship, with his flat, peasant face and his slow, winning smile. He would have answered that ad: but he would also have instinctively added the romantic dimension. He's the salt of the earth. They are good, damaged souls: they deserve each other and some joy as the door finally opens. When they find out they're in love, he cries, stolid on a brasserie chair surrounded by the clatter of cutlery. A private moment.

Dr Feelgood, of course, makes an excuse and leaves at the very start. This is not going to end in conventional happiness. It is the love of regret, mistakes, misunder standings, just as the sex between them is occasionally perfect and often not. Ordinary men and women; ordinary successes and failures; the laughs of togetherness and the pains of parting. But there's no tragedy at the close, no bleakness - only a drawing back into self, a sense that what they shared survives in a time capsule of warm recollection. Fonteyne has peeled away all the usual trappings and left us with the core: a relationship etched in essentially human terms. He began with prize-winning short films and he retains his flair for close-packed brevity. Eighty-one minutes have you there for every emotion, every sentence which links Him and Her. A terse, enclosed, intense world, and an affair to remember.

 Philip French is on holiday

webTitle: A country house? Suits you, Sir

fields.headline: A country house? Suits you, Sir
fields.standfirst: Pop is middle-aged now, and so are its fans. So what better place for Sir Elton's concert than a stately pile?
fields.trailText: Pop is middle-aged now, and so are its fans. So what better place for Sir Elton's concert than a stately pile?
fields.body:
Elton John
Burghley House, Lincs

As any fool promoter of classical music knows, there's nothing like the civilising proximity of a stately home to turn your culturally aspirant middle-management type into someone willing to spend a balmy summer's evening pretending to enjoy the bellowing of Lesley Garrett from the relative safety of an outlying picnic rug. So you can see why the lure of Pimms and strawberries beneath the spreading chestnuts and corporate marquees of old England might likewise appeal even to passing admirers of Sir Elton John.

After all, pop music is as middle-aged as most of its fans now, while grand country houses have long been the retreat of choice for rock stars looking to separate themselves from the vulgar hordes. This could be the beginning of a trend. Watch out for similar solo tours of the nation's rural piles from the likes of Phil Collins and Eric Clapton and other giants of leisure-oriented adult entertainment. Who knows, in the future, when they're having trouble getting about, Phil, Eric and Elton may even go one step better and invite us all into their lovely homes for a 100,000-person sing-song round the old Steinway.

As for Burghley House... well, it's a lovely, peaceful spot - apart from the sheep, which understandably have more to bleat about than usual - and you could arguably have an enjoyable enough time just loitering near the beer tent watching the paying guests ambling past in their dress-down kit of polo shirts, pressed Armani jeanwear, pastel sweaters and deck shoes.

Even the inevitable handful of paunchy, soft-rock aficionados, who are sporting thinning mullets and leather waistcoats, have the razor-burnt look of off-duty stationery reps. We take our seats, which are like plastic school chairs clipped together for security purposes. It's a bit thigh to thigh. And I don't think I am being overly fattist when I report that the chap in front of me is so huge that the blimp of his kidneys is bulging through the back of his chair and into my lap. Anyway, Elton comes on stage to rapturous polite applause looking a picture of full detox health in pale blue suit and specs and familiar boyish thatch of someone else's hair. He goes straight into 'Your Song', which everyone goes duly potty about, followed by a couple of unfamiliar album tracks. His voice seems to have lost nothing down the years, though I notice he refuses the falsetto hurdle on 'Daniel' - or 'Dan-yell' as he insists on pronouncing it - which means there's no way he's going to attempt 'Goodbye Yellow Brick Road' without surgical assistance.

But you have to love him. He treats the audience like adults, thanking us, grinning the Elton grin, pointing his finger at anyone caught whooping beyond the call of duty, explaining what all the songs are about and playing them as we expect them to be played. He is not a man about to ruin everything by surprising us with the unexpected. I didn't find myself nostalgic for the feathered, ruffed and pantalooned Elton of the Seventies who might come on dressed as Donald Duck or the Queen of Ruritania, with nine pianos at his disposal and windscreen-wiper specs shaped like the Taj Mahal. And there was none of the preening twit you sometimes see when he gets together with his kissy showbiz pals. Just a decent chap running through some of the best songs in pop and keeping the customer satisfied. I'm glad he's settled down and stopped taking drugs. I'm glad he doesn't mind being the same average weight as his audience. We could be at Pontins.

There are times, though, when he seems to be enjoying it all a bit too much. 'Honky Cat', a plinking pantomime of a song that is already too long at three minutes, is extended by about a year to make room for a bar-room piano marathon of Bobby Crush proportions, climaxing in a rumble of bass notes capable of dislodging every filling in Lincolnshire. Elton may be playing on his own but he has one of those Yamaha pianos with built-in orchestra and box of earthquake noises. It can do the hoovering too, he says. How we laugh!

'Rocket Man' is great, with a big screen showing complementary spacey images culminating for some reason with the spiralling double helix beloved of TV programmes trying to explain what DNA is, though by now the endings to the songs are getting longer and the effects louder, more apocalyptic and more likely to prod erstwhile respectable members of the audience into individual acts of boldness. 'Yeah!' one shouts, standing up and fisting the air. Another gets up, and another. 'Yeah!' It's like a mob scene from On the Waterfront. The ground is shaking. A light goes on in the big house on the hill. The huge man in front leaps to his feet, sucking a row of seats into the vacuum behind him. 'Yeah!'

I'm afraid I can't get fantastically interested in 'Tiny Dancer', which has a jaunty toe-tapping section of the kind favoured by gymnasts and ice skaters, and sure enough even the sheep start clapping along. In the annals of live performance, there is nothing worse than a crowd that thinks it has a sense of rhythm. Elton courts further audience participation with a pounding run-up to 'Philadelphia Freedom', which has everyone on their feet and for some time I am in danger of being elbowed to death by my fellow revellers.

On the other hand, it's now dark enough to eat my Snickers bar. And the lighting man, who has enjoyed few twiddling opportunities up till now, is understandably gagging to do something creative. 'Shine a light, shine a light...' sings Elton. Yes! The lighting man shines a light. Duh. But the crowd goes wild. And by the time we get to 'Burn Down the Mission', with Elton gurning and sticking his leg out Jerry Lee Lewis-style, people who started the day as ordinary sedentary workers are at the front baying for autographs.

There follows 'Crocodile Rock', another ballady thing in memory of John Lennon and something else haunting and poignant that I don't quite catch the name of. If anything, Elton is too good value for money and by the time we get to 'Don't Let The Sun Go Down On Me', the sun is in danger of coming up again. I decide to listen to 'Candle in the Wind' on the way to the car park. Well, I wouldn't want to see it all end in tears.

 Elton's tour continues at Hylands House, Chelmsford on 15/16 July; Margam Park, nr Port Talbot (19 July); Castle Ashby, Northamptonshire (22 July); Hyde Park, London (27 July); Raby Castle, Darlington (29 July). Call 0870 906 3813

webTitle: Pull up a car seat and make yourself at home

fields.headline: Pull up a car seat and make yourself at home
fields.standfirst: The current exhibition at the V&A elevates Ron Arad from industrial scavenger to modern guru
fields.trailText: Ron Arad
fields.body:
Ron Arad Victoria and Albert Museum, London SW7

Given the Victoria and Albert Museum's history as an institution dedicated to exploring all the many and various meanings of design, it could not have found a more appropriate figure as the subject of its first exhibition in 12 years devoted to the work of a contemporary designer than Ron Arad.

It was back in the designer decade of the 1980s that it last ventured anything similar, and then it was Neville Brody, the graphic designer responsible for the look of The Face who was invited to exhibit.

Arad's work has much more physical presence than Brody's designs on paper. He makes furniture that could be sculpture, but he is also an ingenious and gifted designer, one who is as interested in ideas as much as technique.

And his work addresses some of the major questions facing an institution such as the V&A in which you can find Raphael cartoons as well as snuff boxes, Bauhaus chairs and Frank Lloyd Wright interiors. Is design a decorative, and therefore supposedly 'minor' art, or is the manufacturing of objects that have at their heart a utilitarian purpose a means of exploring some of the issues facing a technologically sophisticated culture?

On the one hand, design is about the creation of anonymous mass-produced objects, by people who spend a lot of time worrying about injection moulding, or about the precise degree of curve needed to blunt the sharp edges of a computer monitor. On the other hand, it is also about how to make objects that feel good to touch and to use.

Design has become the sometimes cynical process of making what were once serious, unselfconscious products - watches, for example, or cameras and even cars, into toys for adults, pandering to our fantasies about ourselves, ruthlessly tapping into our willingness to pay to be entertained or flattered by our possessions. The designer is there to make products that look expensive even if they are cheap to make, which look rugged and therefore glamorous, often when they are flimsy or playful, even when they are actually gas-guzzling cars.

Design is seen to be a species of activity not to be considered in the same breath as art, which is supposedly about a whole category of entirely different things. But if you consider what it was that informed much of Duchamp's thinking, or Warhol for that matter, they are certainly intimately concerned with many of the same issues that underpin design.

The readymade urinal or the multiple Mao screen prints are certainly telling us something about our relationship with objects, and about the impact of mass production on culture. They are even telling us about the transfiguring, alchemical power that art has to make base materials into priceless fetishised objects with an enormous price tag.

Design does the same thing, although the mark-up that comes with a Philippe Starck signature can't compete with a Hirst, just as a supposedly 'original' Rietveld chair, arguably as powerful a work of De Stijl art as a Mondrian, sells at a fraction of the cost of a painting.

The V&A has done Arad proud, giving him a free rein in the museum's most public spaces. Unwinding through the entrance hall, and on into the heart of the museum Arad has created a catwalk that shows the range of his work, from some of his earliest experiments with recycling and salvage, to his most recent designs intended for industrial production. Arad originally trained as an architect, which may be what gave him an interest in working on a scale that few designers can match. He has recently installed a giant wind wand, an infinitely slender 50 metre gash of red carbon fibre, equipped with a light at the tip that moves gently back and forth in the breeze at Canary Wharf as if daring the high-rise towers around it to do the same. But it is for his boldly sculptural welded metal furni ture that he is best known.

He began by creative recycling, more from necessity than as a conscious choice. Just out of college, nobody was going to manufacture his work. Working as a traditional craftsman didn't appeal. But scavenging discarded industrial materials and putting them to new uses offered the chance of making objects that had some of the polished characteristics of mass production at a scale that was within his means. He worked on a series of readymades, in the manner of Duchamp. A seat salvaged from a time-expired Rover became an armchair, a scooter seat turned into a stool, and he used scaffolding to make bedsteads.

Then he started to work in metal, welding and forming it into shape in his own workshop with a group of assistants. His work was intuitive. He would start on a piece without quite knowing where it was going, and allow the characteristics of the process shape the result. He made furniture in limited editions, creating objects that belong to a hard-to-categorise, in-between breed. Not utilitarian, necessarily, and not exactly art, either.

Arad has now dispensed with the workshop, but he has found ways of using his computer as both a pencil and surrogate workshop. Images conceived on the screen can be used as the template to create physical objects directly; he puts the techniques of mass production to work to create individual pieces, in a way that seems to run directly counter to the idea of industrialisation. He likes to make objects that aren't identical but which manage to have a unique identity of their own, even when they are made in large numbers. But at the same time as working on these one-off pieces, he has also designed a shelving system squeezed out of machines by the kilometre which has become a best- seller, and the two newest objects that he is showing at the V&A are not one- offs, but eminently practical folding chairs designed to be sold in their thousands, if not hundreds of thousands.

The two aspects of his work inform each other. One can provide the inspiration for the other, though in the process production techniques, materials and prices alter radically. This is not the only way to look at design, but it is a powerful argument for the continuing relevance of design, and for the V&A's commitment to it.
fields.bodyText: Ron Arad Victoria and Albert Museum, London SW7 Given the Victoria and Albert Museum's history as an institution dedicated to exploring all the many and various meanings of design, it could not have found a more appropriate figure as the subject of its first exhibition in 12 years devoted to the work of a contemporary designer than Ron Arad. It was back in the designer decade of the 1980s that it last ventured anything similar, and then it was Neville Brody, the graphic designer responsible for the look of The Face who was invited to exhibit. Arad's work has much more physical presence than Brody's designs on paper. He makes furniture that could be sculpture, but he is also an ingenious and gifted designer, one who is as interested in ideas as much as technique. And his work addresses some of the major questions facing an institution such as the V&A in which you can find Raphael cartoons as well as snuff boxes, Bauhaus chairs and Frank Lloyd Wright interiors. Is design a decorative, and therefore supposedly 'minor' art, or is the manufacturing of objects that have at their heart a utilitarian purpose a means of exploring some of the issues facing a technologically sophisticated culture? On the one hand, design is about the creation of anonymous mass-produced objects, by people who spend a lot of time worrying about injection moulding, or about the precise degree of curve needed to blunt the sharp edges of a computer monitor. On the other hand, it is also about how to make objects that feel good to touch and to use. Design has become the sometimes cynical process of making what were once serious, unselfconscious products - watches, for example, or cameras and even cars, into toys for adults, pandering to our fantasies about ourselves, ruthlessly tapping into our willingness to pay to be entertained or flattered by our possessions. The designer is there to make products that look expensive even if they are cheap to make, which look rugged and therefore glamorous, often when they are flimsy or playful, even when they are actually gas-guzzling cars. Design is seen to be a species of activity not to be considered in the same breath as art, which is supposedly about a whole category of entirely different things. But if you consider what it was that informed much of Duchamp's thinking, or Warhol for that matter, they are certainly intimately concerned with many of the same issues that underpin design. The readymade urinal or the multiple Mao screen prints are certainly telling us something about our relationship with objects, and about the impact of mass production on culture. They are even telling us about the transfiguring, alchemical power that art has to make base materials into priceless fetishised objects with an enormous price tag. Design does the same thing, although the mark-up that comes with a Philippe Starck signature can't compete with a Hirst, just as a supposedly 'original' Rietveld chair, arguably as powerful a work of De Stijl art as a Mondrian, sells at a fraction of the cost of a painting. The V&A has done Arad proud, giving him a free rein in the museum's most public spaces. Unwinding through the entrance hall, and on into the heart of the museum Arad has created a catwalk that shows the range of his work, from some of his earliest experiments with recycling and salvage, to his most recent designs intended for industrial production. Arad originally trained as an architect, which may be what gave him an interest in working on a scale that few designers can match. He has recently installed a giant wind wand, an infinitely slender 50 metre gash of red carbon fibre, equipped with a light at the tip that moves gently back and forth in the breeze at Canary Wharf as if daring the high-rise towers around it to do the same. But it is for his boldly sculptural welded metal furni ture that he is best known. He began by creative recycling, more from necessity than as a conscious choice. Just out of college, nobody was going to manufacture his work. Working as a traditional craftsman didn't appeal. But scavenging discarded industrial materials and putting them to new uses offered the chance of making objects that had some of the polished characteristics of mass production at a scale that was within his means. He worked on a series of readymades, in the manner of Duchamp. A seat salvaged from a time-expired Rover became an armchair, a scooter seat turned into a stool, and he used scaffolding to make bedsteads. Then he started to work in metal, welding and forming it into shape in his own workshop with a group of assistants. His work was intuitive. He would start on a piece without quite knowing where it was going, and allow the characteristics of the process shape the result. He made furniture in limited editions, creating objects that belong to a hard-to-categorise, in-between breed. Not utilitarian, necessarily, and not exactly art, either. Arad has now dispensed with the workshop, but he has found ways of using his computer as both a pencil and surrogate workshop. Images conceived on the screen can be used as the template to create physical objects directly; he puts the techniques of mass production to work to create individual pieces, in a way that seems to run directly counter to the idea of industrialisation. He likes to make objects that aren't identical but which manage to have a unique identity of their own, even when they are made in large numbers. But at the same time as working on these one-off pieces, he has also designed a shelving system squeezed out of machines by the kilometre which has become a best- seller, and the two newest objects that he is showing at the V&A are not one- offs, but eminently practical folding chairs designed to be sold in their thousands, if not hundreds of thousands. The two aspects of his work inform each other. One can provide the inspiration for the other, though in the process production techniques, materials and prices alter radically. This is not the only way to look at design, but it is a powerful argument for the continuing relevance of design, and for the V&A's commitment to it.

fields.headline: Moby Dick gets it again
fields.trailText: Woody Allen | How the West Was Shot | And the Band Played On
fields.body:
Woody Allen R2

How the West Was Shot World Service

And the Band Played On R3

Someone called Woody Allen to ask if it was true that Monica Lewinsky was in his new film. She wasn't, he told Mark Kermode in Woody Allen but if she could act and if he had a plot she was right for, he wouldn't hesitate to cast her. That's the way celebrity works in America, he said, sounding unhappy.

Every lawyer from the O.J. Simpson trial now has a TV show, every hostage gets a tickertape parade in New York and the most famous name in the US belongs to a girl who happens to have had sex with the President. 'The people that we celebrate indicate a certain culture run amok.'

It made a change to hear Allen talking normally and it says much for Kermode's interviewing technique that he managed to prise so much from a man who famously dislikes the media. This was a serious conversation and though I missed those famed one-liners - 'If you could live your life over again, Mr Allen, what would you do differently?' 'I wouldn't read Moby-Dick ' - it was interesting to hear his views on music and magic, the fore most passions of his life apart from his ex-wife's adopted daughter, of course.

I hadn't realised what an accomplished jazz clarinettist he was. He didn't go to Hollywood to collect his Annie Hall Oscar because it coincided with the night he was playing with his band in New York. That was the other enduring thing about Allen the man, not Allen the mouth - he is modest. 'They come to see me because I am a movie actor; I am not doing enough musically for anyone to pay 25 cents to see me.'

Twenty five cents is what moviegoers paid to see westerns starring John Wayne in the Forties. The World Service's series telling the history of the western - How the West Was Shot - has moved from John Ford's favourite location, Monument Valley, Utah, to Almeria in Spain, the setting for Clint Eastwood's spaghetti westerns directed by Sergio Leone.

'To make good westerns, you have to film the location as if it were a beautiful woman,' Ford advised his cameramen. Leone only had two words of English - 'Watch me' - followed by an elaborate mime. It seemed to be enough.

Only one programme to go, alas, in John Drummond's breathtaking panegyric on the state of British orchestras, And the Band Played On. If you are looking for one example of why Radio 3 is the most informed, intelligent and best music station, this is it.

webTitle: Should I put my senile mother in a home?

fields.headline: Should I put my senile mother in a home?
fields.trailText: Moral muse
fields.body:
My mother is 82 and has senile dementia. Three months ago I persuaded her to give up her home (she rented a flat for 52 years) and move in with me, my husband and two children of 21 and 18. She has her own room but needs care virtually 24 hours a day.

Our family life is going to the dogs. My husband is losing his patience and is now suggesting that we put her in a home. I cannot do this as I am sure it will be the end of her. In more lucid moments she has joked about bottles of pills rather than a home. At the same time I do not want to destroy the home we have built for our children. Her dementia is only going to get worse and this could continue for a number or years. Where do my loyalties lie?

L.R. Ilford

My unlimited awe and respect for you for taking on such a burden are tempered by the thought that you cannot possibly have perceived the size of the problem you were accepting.

I do not believe that any person should sacrifice herself completely to the care of someone else. I am certain that you already take the lion's share of the work involved. Your children are on the verge of independence, and your mother's difficult presence could cause them to drift sooner rather than later. And it is not inconceivable that your husband could find the environment so intolerable that he would walk out. If your mother was in full possession of her faculties she would be appalled to think of the havoc she is causing for you and your family and the terrible impositions she is making on you.

Your GP should put you in touch with the psycho-geriatric services in your area, where your mother can have her problems assessed by a specialist. They will explore the possibility of maintaining her at home, but if it is clearly not feasible, they will discuss the range of options. If the collective decision is for nursing home care, this will be effected via the social work department, and if your mother has financial assets she will be required to pay for accommodation, I'm afraid. Some homes have dementia wings where they can wander round a circular area within a secure perimeter, so they do not feel frustratingly confined.

Sedating medication is used to keep restlessness controlled, and it is important that the right balance is achieved in terms of comfort for the patient without excessive somnolence.

I'd say the principle of the greatest good of the greatest number applies here. The four of you will have heartfelt relief if she goes into care; and she will benefit from professional care in a controlled environment.

Readers' replies

Most people with dementia develop irritating and difficult behaviours which take a terrible toll on their carers. I work as a staff nurse in a home where our residents receive (and give) much affection and warmth. We do not know them as they once were but grow to love them for who they are now.

Their preferences cannot be accommodated in the way they might if they were with their families; but because we are not related to them, we can deal with their needs more patiently than their nearest and dearest.

After a period of guilt and sadness, the families of our residents usually express enormous relief at having finally realised that they must let them go.

M.M. of Lancaster

Your mother will inevitably get older and frailer and will need more care than you can give her to the point that professional carers will have to take over.

If your family understands that the present situation cannot last for ever it may be easier for them to cope - she is, after all, not their mother and they do not have the same feelings of responsibility that you do.

Contact your local social services department and the Alzheimer's Disease Society. There are home carers to help her with washing and, dressing and respite care so that the family can have a week off occasionally. You may even be entitled to an Attendance Allowance.

If you (and your family) can feel that your mother has had the best life with you which is feasible under the circumstances, even for a short time, this should help the guilt feelings when you can no longer cope.

R.A. of Chesham

Next week's dilemma is from K. T. of London

I was adopted when I was a baby and could not have wished for better parents. As far as I am concerned they are my real parents in every sense of the word.

But since I had my own child, a few months ago, I keep wondering about my biological parents in a way that I never did before.

My partner is of the opinion that I should leave well alone as I am bound to hurt my parents and myself in the process. But I still have this desire to know where I came from. What should I do?

Write to Observer Review or email mailto:margaret.cook@observer.co.uk. Views on each week's problem to reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Women's Journal

fields.headline: Too much, too young...
fields.standfirst: Children of eight are now reaching puberty, and pre-teen sex is not unusual. New research suggests that Lolita is no longer fiction - it's fact. But how can parents come to terms with the reality of their children's bodies?
fields.trailText: Children of eight are now reaching puberty, and pre-teen sex is not unusual. New research suggests that Lolita is no longer fiction - it's fact. But how can parents come to terms with the reality of their children's bodies?
fields.body:
Anthropolgists looking back at the dawn of twenty-first century Britain may surmise that we were schizophrenic: a society that idealised childhood, but demonised the problematic, sexualised adolescent. At its crudest, this means the birth of the Prime Minister's baby is attended by sentimental euphoria, while girls and boys born barely a decade before are already the objects of our horror. Indeed, the latest research suggests that the first dark signs of adolescence - menstrual blood and pubic hair - are now often occurring in children as young as eight or nine. Whither childhood?

Moreover, despite what appears to be the best combined efforts of parents and media to sit hard on the lid of this particular Pandora's box, the early onset of puberty in some of our children is almost certainly directly linked with early sexual activity. You may not want to hear this, but we may now be living in a time when Lolita is no longer a literary study in perversion, but a unisex, medically and sociologically substantiated reality.

The new research - featured in the forthcoming three-part Channel 4 series, Sex From 8 to 18, and conducted by Professor Jean Golding, of the University of Bristol, on an initial sample of 1,150 eight-year-old children in Avon - reveals that one in six eight-year-old girls has started puberty, with signs of breast buds, pubic hair or both, compared with only one in 100 a generation ago. Similarly, one in 14 eight-year-old boys now has pubic hair, when, back in the Sixties, this was a mark of the over-13s.

'We don't actually ask parents if they are surprised by the early onset of puberty in their children,' Golding tells me. 'But it's incredible how many of them, off their own bat, will say: "Thank goodness you asked that question!" They are all worried that their child is exceptional, but we are able to reassure them that it does appear to be extremely common.'

Part of the blame for the ongoing blizzard of misinformation, confusion, and anxiety concerning puberty could be put down to the fact that, until very recently, the international model for all research on pubescence was a British report compiled in 1962 by Professor James Tanner. For his study, Tanner focused on a mere 200 boys and girls in children's homes in London. There followed a wait of almost 40 years, ended in 1997, by research on 17,000 American children, aged from three to 13, which was conducted by Dr Marcia Herman-Giddens. In America, child sexuality is said to be even more a problem - with 'fast sex' replacing 'fast food' in the schoolyard. As Herman-Giddens's study concluded that the average age for puberty had gone down dramatically, raging hormones could well be to blame.

Two paediatricians, Rosemary Jones and Fiona Finley, based in Bath, acknowledge the value of the US study, but feel that merely applying its findings to this country might be shortsighted. They are currently trying to set up their own study, which would feature thousands of British children. The chief problems for Jones and Finley appear to be time, money, and, remarkably, the still prevalent Victorian repressiveness - the 'cover the table legs' primness - of British culture.

As Clare Richards, series producer of Sex From 8 to 18 , observes wryly: 'It says something that it takes two concerned mothers - community paediatricians, who've seen the anecdotal evidence - to get off their backsides, and say something has to be done.'

Jones agrees: 'You've got to have a really good excuse to look at a well child's body in this country. We can show children photographs and life drawings all we like, but sooner or later, we've got to "have a look" at some of them.' Jones reveals that part of the routine check of a boy's pubescent development is sizing their testicles with a set of differently sized beads. 'At a certain size, a threshold of about four millimetres, it's an indicator that hormone production is under way,' she says. 'But it's not as if you can go around doing these tests on the street!'

Of course, if it were just a matter of physical development, the public would probably be about as interested in all this as they would be in stat sheets on how our generally improved health is affecting the size of children's feet (rather a lot, as it happens). The fact that pubescence is, by definition, sexual, transforms this research into scientific dynamite - not to mention a primal tinderbox of morality and unease. Just as some of our children are said to be drowning in premature hormones, so is society reeling from the prospect of hordes of 'horny' children, some as young as 10, having sex in the streets. While for paedophiles this could be construed as a weird form of encouragement ('We are all too painfully aware that this research could be cynically manipulated,' says Richards), most adults would be appalled by the thought of suddenly sexualised children.

Indeed, it seems to me that we are, as a nation of parents, colluding in either ignoring, or, even worse, fetishising the problem of 'teenage sexuality'. Hence the routine media hoo-ha over under-age pregnancies, which always seems to subtly suggest that only those girls who 'actually get pregnant' are having sex, while the rest of British childkind are presumably still busy playing with Lego, and thinking Jenny Agutter is rather brill in The Railway Children. Observing this wilfully ostrich-like, not to mention quasi-bigoted, reaction (socially deprived young girls are three times more likely to keep the baby, rather than have an abortion), one could almost start wishing that British parents would start growing up intellectually as fast as their children are obviously doing physically. However, the real question is, what do we do about it? 'Hairy', 'budding' and even 'sexually active' they might suddenly and scarily be, but they are still our children. So how do we go about helping them?

The experts seem to agree that the best way forward is a combination of early information, and better (much better) communication. The common consensus is that, however they look or act, it may take some time for early pubescents to catch up emotionally with their fast-changing bodies, and they need all the support they can get. Indeed, when researching this article, and talking to youngsters - some of whom are featured in the interviews below - I was greatly struck, by how, even while using highly potent, adult, some might say shocking language and imagery to describe the sexual behaviour of themselves and their peers, the majority retained their innate child-like vulnerability.

These schoolkids are not the pages of Lolita come to life, nor are they manifestations of our 'declining standards'. They're ordinary young people, at the mercy of their own biology, who are in need of understanding, tolerance, and - perish the thought - the occasional bawling out. Children in adults' skin.

In their own words: 'Girls just want a cuddle. But the boys pressurise them'

Fallon (15)

My mother helped me a lot during puberty - she wasn't embarrassed like some mums. There was sex education at primary school, but that was more to do with periods, what a Tampax does with water, stuff like that. We did contraception when we were 13, but a lot of the kids had already had sex, a long time before. Parents would be amazed by what some of their 'little angels' get up to. With the boys, it's not so bad. It's like: 'He's 16 now, he's probably having sex.' But, with the girls, it's like their parents can't picture it - they blot it out because they don't want to know.

Girls are wanting to experience sex at 13, 14, and younger. Some of them sleep with one person after another, and they hardly know the boys sometimes. With others, it's their first ever boyfriend, and they're having sex straight away. I think these girls don't really want sex a lot of the time - they just want a kiss and a cuddle, or they just want to be with a certain boy because they like him. But the boys pressurise them. It used to be just kissing, but now it goes much further. Kissing, feeling, wanking the boys, letting boys finger them. After enough times, it gets closer, and they have sex properly.

I don't know why it's all getting so fast. If a girl is really dirty, then she deserves to be called a skit [slut], but it's like even really little girls, of about 12 or 13, go through so much pain and stress. I think they should wait. It's all about sex, when it should be about making love. Some boys are really honest and nice, but most of them are just after a sex life.

Oliver (16)

I started noticing girls properly three or four years ago, but the younger ones in my area seem to be getting involved in sex earlier, around 10 or 11 or so. I'm quite surprised myself. There's kids getting each other pregnant and having abortions. You think, what's happening? I have black and white friends. Some white parents are completely open about what their kids do, and like to talk things over, but that's embarrassing. Black parents are more religious and strict, and they can't have any idea what their kids get up to. If they did, they'd be beating them. There's no such thing as sex education in school - how can you be taught something you already know?

It's mainly the girls who drink, smoke, sniff coke, take ecstasy and LSD. When girls go out, they're crazy. But girls are more romantic than boys, they're into fairytales. When you're a boy growing up, the testosterone's building up, and sometimes you just have to go out and get a piece, ride the ride, have a little 'practice'.

If a boy's after a one-night stand, he'll look for a skit. A skit is someone who's up for anything with anyone, anywhere, even when you're in school. Boys just got to talk to them, and they give them a blow job, or have sex. If a boy manages to get with loads of girls, he's seen as a don, a romeo, or a player. There's no such thing as a male skit.

There are girls who are decent and gain your respect. Decent girls know how to keep their mouths and legs shut. Then there's skits. Some skits are young, 14 and that. There's even skits as young as 12 running about, and that's not good. No one treats skits well. Decent girls fight them, and boys use them for sexual experience. You can do what you want to skits and they'll still sleep with you. Like one boy kicked a skit out after they'd done it, and she was back at his house the next day.

Another time, I saw this girl and four boys, all around my age, underneath an arch. You could just see their heads, and hear this boy shouting: 'Do it, do it! Faster, faster!'. Then the other three boys were on her. She's a skit. Boys knock on her door, and she just goes around and gives them a 'shine' [oral sex]. She wants to be popular, but the boys got no respect for her. I wouldn't have anything to do with a girl like that. She offered once. I said 'No'.

If a boy sleeps with lots of girls, it's different, it's an accomplishment. There'll be this big group of you, and they'll all be bragging about what they've done. Like: 'We were playing on the computer, I was feeling her up, and then I 'pressed' her [had sex].' If a boy has been going with a girl for a while, or she's not a skit, he won't say nothing.

Most people use condoms, unless they're gagging for it, or stupid. Nobody's worried about HIV, not with girls our age, but a few have got pregnant. There's this one boy everyone calls 'Daddy', because he's got a kid at 15. I'm too young for that kind of responsibility.

In their own words: 'Sex is fun, and everyone should know it.'

Lucie (16)

My body started changing when I was about 10. By the time I was 12, my breasts started feeling really sore. I went to the doctor, and he said: 'They're starting to grow.' I got hair and stuff a bit later. At about 12, my periods started. I was so excited, I cried - I was like, 'Oh mummy! Oh god!' My mum was really supportive and that made all the difference. You're so emotional during puberty. The hormones come along and it's like - right, you're going to be in a bad mood now.

I lost my virginity at 13. I was on the pill, and it was with one of my friend's older brothers who was 18. I wasn't frightened, it didn't hurt, but now I've slept with some other people, and I know how exciting sex can be, I can see that it wasn't very good. After that, the sex just kept happening, I don't know why. I've never even found men's bodies that attractive. I like their shoulders and backs, but nothing else.

My present boyfriend is 25 - I get on better with people who are a bit older. Last year, I went with a 17-year-old and it was bizarre. He was nice, but he was always wanting to hang out with his mates and drink cider, and I'm past all that. I can't wait to get to college. I get name-called at school and it's upsetting sometimes. But I also feel more confident, less naive, than other girls. When horrible drunks come on to me in pubs, I can handle them. Why shouldn't girls be advanced? I like to experiment, try different things. Sex is fun and everyone should know it. It shouldn't just be about guys pleasuring themselves.
