fields.bodyText: Anthropolgists looking back at the dawn of twenty-first century Britain may surmise that we were schizophrenic: a society that idealised childhood, but demonised the problematic, sexualised adolescent. At its crudest, this means the birth of the Prime Minister's baby is attended by sentimental euphoria, while girls and boys born barely a decade before are already the objects of our horror. Indeed, the latest research suggests that the first dark signs of adolescence - menstrual blood and pubic hair - are now often occurring in children as young as eight or nine. Whither childhood? Moreover, despite what appears to be the best combined efforts of parents and media to sit hard on the lid of this particular Pandora's box, the early onset of puberty in some of our children is almost certainly directly linked with early sexual activity. You may not want to hear this, but we may now be living in a time when Lolita is no longer a literary study in perversion, but a unisex, medically and sociologically substantiated reality. The new research - featured in the forthcoming three-part Channel 4 series, Sex From 8 to 18, and conducted by Professor Jean Golding, of the University of Bristol, on an initial sample of 1,150 eight-year-old children in Avon - reveals that one in six eight-year-old girls has started puberty, with signs of breast buds, pubic hair or both, compared with only one in 100 a generation ago. Similarly, one in 14 eight-year-old boys now has pubic hair, when, back in the Sixties, this was a mark of the over-13s. 'We don't actually ask parents if they are surprised by the early onset of puberty in their children,' Golding tells me. 'But it's incredible how many of them, off their own bat, will say: "Thank goodness you asked that question!" They are all worried that their child is exceptional, but we are able to reassure them that it does appear to be extremely common.' Part of the blame for the ongoing blizzard of misinformation, confusion, and anxiety concerning puberty could be put down to the fact that, until very recently, the international model for all research on pubescence was a British report compiled in 1962 by Professor James Tanner. For his study, Tanner focused on a mere 200 boys and girls in children's homes in London. There followed a wait of almost 40 years, ended in 1997, by research on 17,000 American children, aged from three to 13, which was conducted by Dr Marcia Herman-Giddens. In America, child sexuality is said to be even more a problem - with 'fast sex' replacing 'fast food' in the schoolyard. As Herman-Giddens's study concluded that the average age for puberty had gone down dramatically, raging hormones could well be to blame. Two paediatricians, Rosemary Jones and Fiona Finley, based in Bath, acknowledge the value of the US study, but feel that merely applying its findings to this country might be shortsighted. They are currently trying to set up their own study, which would feature thousands of British children. The chief problems for Jones and Finley appear to be time, money, and, remarkably, the still prevalent Victorian repressiveness - the 'cover the table legs' primness - of British culture. As Clare Richards, series producer of Sex From 8 to 18 , observes wryly: 'It says something that it takes two concerned mothers - community paediatricians, who've seen the anecdotal evidence - to get off their backsides, and say something has to be done.' Jones agrees: 'You've got to have a really good excuse to look at a well child's body in this country. We can show children photographs and life drawings all we like, but sooner or later, we've got to "have a look" at some of them.' Jones reveals that part of the routine check of a boy's pubescent development is sizing their testicles with a set of differently sized beads. 'At a certain size, a threshold of about four millimetres, it's an indicator that hormone production is under way,' she says. 'But it's not as if you can go around doing these tests on the street!' Of course, if it were just a matter of physical development, the public would probably be about as interested in all this as they would be in stat sheets on how our generally improved health is affecting the size of children's feet (rather a lot, as it happens). The fact that pubescence is, by definition, sexual, transforms this research into scientific dynamite - not to mention a primal tinderbox of morality and unease. Just as some of our children are said to be drowning in premature hormones, so is society reeling from the prospect of hordes of 'horny' children, some as young as 10, having sex in the streets. While for paedophiles this could be construed as a weird form of encouragement ('We are all too painfully aware that this research could be cynically manipulated,' says Richards), most adults would be appalled by the thought of suddenly sexualised children. Indeed, it seems to me that we are, as a nation of parents, colluding in either ignoring, or, even worse, fetishising the problem of 'teenage sexuality'. fields.headline: Take a tip m'lord - save cookie talk for teatime
fields.standfirst: Privacy on the net: special report
fields.trailText: 'This is a rotten argument, but it should be good enough for their Lordships on a hot summer afternoon.' This note to a ministerial brief was once inadvertently read out by a government spokesman in the House of Lords.
fields.body:
'This is a rotten argument, but it should be good enough for their Lordships on a hot summer afternoon.' This note to a ministerial brief was once inadvertently read out by a government spokesman in the House of Lords.

The story comes irresistibly to mind as the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Bill winds its grisly way through the Upper House. The Bill is being shepherded through by a chap called Lord Bassam of Brighton, aided and abetted by a cove named Bach. Neither of them appears to know anything about the technology of the internet, though M'lord Bach seems to rely heavily on the advice of a Baroness Thornton, who in real life is Mrs John Carr, and thus the spouse of a well-known campaigner against child pornography on the internet.

The atmosphere is a cross between Gilbert and Sullivan and Kafka. There is, for example, a lot of ho-ho-hoing whenever a technical term is mentioned. When challenged by Viscount Goschen on the subject of cookies at one point last week, Bassam looked nonplussed. 'We are getting more and yet more pieces of technological verbiage,' he puffed. 'They grow by the hour. Cookies is one of them - and HTTP is another.' Another peer asked about the possibility that an internet user might access a non-government-approved website by mistake. 'As to whether I would wander into a website other than where I might want to be,' joked Bassam, 'I am not sure I have the competence. But perhaps that is an admission too far.'

Snigger, snigger.

Watching this booby mess with our freedoms is like seeing a monkey casually dismantling a clock. One of the points at issue last week was whether the Government is entitled to snoop without a warrant on our use of the web. The Home Office position is that whereas a warrant is required for the interception and reading of online messages, no such warrant is needed for the monitoring of what the Bill calls 'communications data'.

What does 'communications data' mean in this context? Answer: the logs of an individual's 'clickstream' - the complete record of sites he or she visits while browsing the web, and the URLs of all the files delivered by web servers in response to clicks.

The Home Office rationale for this is that while a warrant is required to tap an individual's telephone, the authorities already have the power to demand - without a warrant - that telecoms operators provide logs of telephone numbers dialled by an individual, and that logs of a clickstream amount to the same thing. In other words, the RIP Bill is simply extending current practice in the monitoring of telephony to the monitoring of the net.

The cynicism implicit in this is breathtaking. A record of a person's clickstream is not analogous to a log of telephone numbers dialled - for the simple reason that web pages are, for the most part, public documents. Knowing the numbers dialled by an individual may yield useful information to the authorities but does not, by itself, reveal the content of the conversations which took place.

However, if you have access to the clickstream, you can ascertain the content of everything that the target has read, viewed or downloaded. And because everything is in digital form, the whole process can be automated. The algorithm goes like this: read the URL; fetch the page; parse the content; decide whether content matches certain criteria; store decision; read next URL. A five-year-old could write the code to do it.

Despite the blustering of Jack Straw and his ermined monkey, the essence of the RIP Bill remains unchanged. A Labour government proposes to give MI5 unfettered access to everything British subjects do on the web. It's a lousy argument, even for their Lordships. They should throw it out.

John.Naughton@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Misogynist, homophobe... hero
fields.standfirst: His lyrics are loathsome, but the critics love him and his new album is topping the American charts. Now rapper Eminem is facing jail - but he's more popular than ever. It isn't because he's white, is it?
fields.trailText: His lyrics are loathsome, but the critics love him and his new album is topping the American charts. Now rapper Eminem is facing jail - but he's more popular than ever. It isn't because he's white, is it?
fields.body:
Two weeks ago, US rapper Eminem's second album, The Marshall Mathers LP, soared to the top of the US charts. When the first week's sales figures were released, few could dispute the Detroit rapper's arrival as a major-league player. The album - featuring tales of rape, shootings, drug overdoses and throat-slittings - shifted 1.7 million units in only seven days, making it the fastest-selling rap album ever.

Such sales seemed to vindicate the opinions of US rock critics who, for the most part, have been wildly enthusiastic about the rapper's work. On the release of the new album, Newsweek explained away Eminem's misogyny by noting with approval: 'Eminem [is] arguably the most compelling figure in all of pop music. He picks on himself almost as much as he does the people on his enemies list. By flipping his razor-sharp lyrics on himself, Eminem subverts the smirking superiority that plagues mainstream rap, a wily underdog move that lets him get away with more than he could otherwise.'

The LA Times gushed: 'Eminem is simply exercising his creative impulses - putting on disc all the forbidden thoughts and scandalous scenarios that accompany adolescence and just watching the fallout.'

'My little sister's birthday, she'll remember me

For a gift I had 10 of my boys take her virginity

And bitches know me as a horny-ass freak

Their mother wasn't raped, I ate her pussy while she was asleep'

Eminem, 'Amityville'

In recent weeks Eminem's supposedly satirical take on gangsta rap has begun to seem less of a joke. On 8 June, he was charged for allegedly brandishing a gun at Douglas Dail, a member of rap group Insane Clown Posse, in Detroit. Eminem was charged with possession of a concealed weapon and brandishing of a firearm. At his arraignment the next day, he was released after posting 10 per cent of his $100,000 bail. Dail later recanted his initial statement to police and currently refuses to comment.

Only a day earlier, Eminem had been charged, on a separate incident, with assault and carrying a concealed weapon. Those charges related to a fight the previous weekend, when he allegedly saw a barman kissing his wife, Kimberley Mathers, outside a Detroit night club. Prosecutors say Eminem pistol-whipped the man with an unloaded weapon. He faces nine years in prison if convicted on both counts.

The charges have done his career little harm - a summer tour of the US, starting in a fortnight, is already selling out fast. And in the past three weeks, MTV has dedicated at least four special programmes to the rapper, culminating in an Eminem Weekend last week; coverage which beats anything it has given any other rapper in its history. That MTV is a regular provider of anti-violence public announcements seems to have hardly bothered the programmers.

The validity of Eminem's music is unquestioned in the US media - despite civil rights groups charging him with glorifying homophobia and violence against women. His latest album is full of trademark slurs; his wife, mother, and teenie-singer Christina Aguilera all have their characters assassinated.

'Shit, Christina Aguilera better switch chairs with me

So I could sit next to Carson Daly and Fred Durst

And hear 'em argue over who she gave head to first'

Eminem, 'The Real Slim Shady'

'Eminem's defence of his lyrics is that he makes use of fictional characters who only speak their mind. We don't think that's a viable defence for homophobia,' says Steve Spurgeon, Director of Communications for Glaad, the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation. '[This album] contains the most blatantly offensive homophobic lyrics we have ever heard. Ever. We can't bring ourselves to condone it merely on his right to self-expression.'

Glaad's position on Eminem is unusual - the organisation rarely advocates censorship. Eminem's critics, however, cite his lionisation as the first white rapper to transcend race in the music sub-genre. 'He's a role model for teenagers,' continues Spurgeon. 'His opinions have to be questioned.'

'Some bitch asked for my autograph

I called her a whore, spit in her face and laughed...

All bitches is ho's, even my stinkin'-ass Mom'
Eminem, 'Under The Influence'

Eminem grew up in Warren, a squalid suburb on the outskirts of Detroit. The city boasts a burgeoning rap scene, due to a large black population. The young Marshall Mathers quickly distinguished himself on the local rap scene in the mid-Nineties; excelling at local competitions where participants were encouraged to trade battle rhymes against each other.

Eminem's debut album, 1995's Infinite, was little-noticed on its release, and the rapper would almost certainly have faded into obscurity. But a demo sent to a Los Angeles radio station ended up in the hands of rap producer Dr Dre who landed Eminem a production deal. Dre, the mentor of rappers Ice Cube and Snoop Doggy Dogg, signed Eminem to his label, Aftermath, and the X-rated album, The Slim Shady LP, went on to sell over three million copies amid a storm of controversy. Even the old chestnut 'His own mother couldn't love him' could be accurately applied to Eminem, as his Mom, stung by the merciless attacks on her morals in the album's lyrics, initiated a million-dollar lawsuit against her son.

Accolades were almost immediate - in the US media, Eminem has already been cited as the first articulate blue-collar musician since Nirvana's Kurt Cobain. Rock magazines such as Rolling Stone and Spin have acclaimed him as a white-trash poet - part Muhammad Ali, part Lenny Bruce. The mainstream charts, say his defenders, are currently held hostage by teenage boy-bands. Eminem's music, likened to an updated version of the dustbowl blues, provides adult relief. The critics have been so unanimous and euphoric in their praise for his lyrics that they seem to have backed themselves into a liberal corner; in music-press circles it is almost heresy to draw attention to Eminem's homophobia and misogyny.

'New Kids On The Block suck a lot of dick

Boy-girl groups make me sick

And I can't wait 'til I catch all you faggots in public - I'ma love it

Talkin' about I fabricated my past

He's just aggravated I won't ejaculate in his ass'
Eminem, 'Marshall Mathers'

Yet Eminem's true-blue rants plough an unfamiliar territory, even in the annals of rap music. His music highlights a genuine self-loathing unique to his apolitical generation. Gangsta rappers before him have unleashed broadsides at their enemies, but they were always limited to civic institutions such as the police or government. In Eminem's case, anyone - even his fans - is fodder for his hatred. It makes for extremely entertaining but ultimately worrying listening - a soundtrack to a life that celebrates its lack of redemption.

'The US pop industry is currently obsessed with the teenage market,' says Rolling Stone writer David Fricke. 'Even our magazine regularly cover groups like the Backstreet Boys and N'Sync. Eminem seems to be about the last stand against all the homogeneity.'

'If Eminem wants to express views that are homophobic, he has every right to. If he's anti-feminist, then that's his prerogative,' says Joan E. Bertin, executive director of the New York-based National Coalition Against Censorship. A free-speech advocate for 25 years, the NCAC has ardently endorsed several generations of popular musicians - Bertin cites shock-rockers Judas Priest, Ozzy Osbourne and Marilyn Manson as her most high-profile campaigns.

'Personally, I would not advocate the kinds of statements that Eminem makes,' says Bertin. 'But I also disagree with censorship of any kind - I have a real problem with anyone who tries to enforce a general consensus. In Glaad's case, I find it unfortunate that they have taken such a stand. Gays and lesbians are often the most censored group in our society - why advocate censorship of anyone else as a remedy?'

The stringency with which US rock critics have mounted Eminem's defence rankles with some rap writers who view his lighter treatment as evidence of the US music industry's inherent racism. Generations of black rap bands have, in recent years, been subject to public humiliation by right-wing focus groups determined to halt the rise of America's largest pop sales sector.

'Black rappers are regularly vilified for expressing similar views,' says Nelson George, author of Hip Hop America. fields.bodyText: Two weeks ago, US rapper Eminem's second album, The Marshall Mathers LP, soared to the top of the US charts. When the first week's sales figures were released, few could dispute the Detroit rapper's arrival as a major-league player. The album - featuring tales of rape, shootings, drug overdoses and throat-slittings - shifted 1.7 million units in only seven days, making it the fastest-selling rap album ever. Such sales seemed to vindicate the opinions of US rock critics who, for the most part, have been wildly enthusiastic about the rapper's work. On the release of the new album, Newsweek explained away Eminem's misogyny by noting with approval: 'Eminem [is] arguably the most compelling figure in all of pop music. He picks on himself almost as much as he does the people on his enemies list. By flipping his razor-sharp lyrics on himself, Eminem subverts the smirking superiority that plagues mainstream rap, a wily underdog move that lets him get away with more than he could otherwise.' The LA Times gushed: 'Eminem is simply exercising his creative impulses - putting on disc all the forbidden thoughts and scandalous scenarios that accompany adolescence and just watching the fallout.' 'My little sister's birthday, she'll remember me For a gift I had 10 of my boys take her virginity And bitches know me as a horny-ass freak Their mother wasn't raped, I ate her pussy while she was asleep' Eminem, 'Amityville' In recent weeks Eminem's supposedly satirical take on gangsta rap has begun to seem less of a joke. On 8 June, he was charged for allegedly brandishing a gun at Douglas Dail, a member of rap group Insane Clown Posse, in Detroit. Eminem was charged with possession of a concealed weapon and brandishing of a firearm. At his arraignment the next day, he was released after posting 10 per cent of his $100,000 bail. Dail later recanted his initial statement to police and currently refuses to comment. Only a day earlier, Eminem had been charged, on a separate incident, with assault and carrying a concealed weapon. Those charges related to a fight the previous weekend, when he allegedly saw a barman kissing his wife, Kimberley Mathers, outside a Detroit night club. Prosecutors say Eminem pistol-whipped the man with an unloaded weapon. He faces nine years in prison if convicted on both counts. The charges have done his career little harm - a summer tour of the US, starting in a fortnight, is already selling out fast. And in the past three weeks, MTV has dedicated at least four special programmes to the rapper, culminating in an Eminem Weekend last week; coverage which beats anything it has given any other rapper in its history. That MTV is a regular provider of anti-violence public announcements seems to have hardly bothered the programmers. The validity of Eminem's music is unquestioned in the US media - despite civil rights groups charging him with glorifying homophobia and violence against women. His latest album is full of trademark slurs; his wife, mother, and teenie-singer Christina Aguilera all have their characters assassinated. We don't think that's a viable defence for homophobia,' says Steve Spurgeon, Director of Communications for Glaad, the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation. '[This album] contains the most blatantly offensive homophobic lyrics we have ever heard. Ever. We can't bring ourselves to condone it merely on his right to self-expression.' Glaad's position on Eminem is unusual - the organisation rarely advocates censorship. Eminem's critics, however, cite his lionisation as the first white rapper to transcend race in the music sub-genre. 'He's a role model for teenagers,' continues Spurgeon. 'His opinions have to be questioned.' 'Some bitch asked for my autograph I called her a whore, spit in her face and laughed... All bitches is ho's, even my stinkin'-ass Mom' Eminem, 'Under The Influence' Eminem grew up in Warren, a squalid suburb on the outskirts of Detroit. The city boasts a burgeoning rap scene, due to a large black population. The young Marshall Mathers quickly distinguished himself on the local rap scene in the mid-Nineties; excelling at local competitions where participants were encouraged to trade battle rhymes against each other. Eminem's debut album, 1995's Infinite, was little-noticed on its release, and the rapper would almost certainly have faded into obscurity. But a demo sent to a Los Angeles radio station ended up in the hands of rap producer Dr Dre who landed Eminem a production deal. Dre, the mentor of rappers Ice Cube and Snoop Doggy Dogg, signed Eminem to his label, Aftermath, and the X-rated album, The Slim Shady LP, went on to sell over three million copies amid a storm of controversy. Even the old chestnut 'His own mother couldn't love him' could be accurately applied to Eminem, as his Mom, stung by the merciless attacks on her morals in the album's lyrics, initiated a million-dollar lawsuit against her son. Rock magazines such as Rolling Stone and Spin have acclaimed him as a white-trash poet - part Muhammad Ali, part Lenny Bruce. The mainstream charts, say his defenders, are currently held hostage by teenage boy-bands. Eminem's music, likened to an updated version of the dustbowl blues, provides adult relief. The critics have been so unanimous and euphoric in their praise for his lyrics that they seem to have backed themselves into a liberal corner; in music-press circles it is almost heresy to draw attention to Eminem's homophobia and misogyny. 'New Kids On The Block suck a lot of dick Boy-girl groups make me sick And I can't wait 'til I catch all you faggots in public - I'ma love it Talkin' about I fabricated my past He's just aggravated I won't ejaculate in his ass' Eminem, 'Marshall Mathers' Yet Eminem's true-blue rants plough an unfamiliar territory, even in the annals of rap music. fields.headline: Dell boy's winning ways
fields.standfirst:
Jamie Doward meets the Texan billionaire who went from selling PCs at university to challenging the market leader directly
<A HREF="http://www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/efinance">E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Jamie Doward meets the Texan billionaire who went from selling PCs at university to challenging the market leader directly
fields.body:
Michael Dell is talking football. English football. In London's Lanesborough hotel the 35-year-old Texan billionaire is holding court over lunch. Someone tells him that the country is in mourning thanks to England's desultory performance against Portugal. Dell looks curious. 'Do you think it wouldn't have been so bad if you'd lost to a bigger team?' he asks with genuine interest.

It is a revealing moment. For Michael Dell, who started flogging upgraded IBM PCs to his college mates at Austin University in Texas at the age of 18, winning is everything. You don't turn your company into the world's largest direct computer systems supplier with a market value of $120 billion and sales for the last four quarters of $27bn by being anything other than abnormally focused on reaching the number one slot.

But Dell is relaxed over lunch, making goofy jokes about his competitors and, at the same time, he is drumming home the Dell message. He seems more reachable than most of his fellow computer billionaires. There is none of the remoteness of Microsoft's Bill Gates or the flamboyance of Oracle's Larry Ellison.

And yet although he seems unassuming, Dell clearly knows how to play hard ball. As a teenager he made money organising stamp auctions before moving on to sell newspapers. He started Dell in 1985 with $1,000, dropping out of his biology course to focus on building his company from the bottom up.

The company's success has been based on what looks now to be an obvious premise. Sell to the customer direct and strip out the cumbersome middleman who takes a cut for selling your product. Back in the Eighties this was a revolutionary decision. Initially the PCs were sold over the phone. The emergence of the internet gave the company the ability to go global.

Dell's competitors, chiefly arch rival Compaq, the world's largest supplier of PCs, have been worrying what to do about its sales methods ever since. Compaq wants to increase its direct sales volumes, but this will antagonise its salesmen. Compaq is still attempting to resolve this tension, a task which has already cost it a CEO and several other executives. In the interim Dell is making hay while the sun shines.

Or at least it has been. Dell might exude bonhomie, but he knows his company can't stay still. Fears about a bottoming out of the PC market have taken their toll on the company's share price. Last month Dell unveiled its worst set of results since 1994. Back then its share price slid 54 per cent. Last month it gave up more than 20 per cent as Wall Street tried to second-guess what Dell, who owns more than 14 per cent of the company, will do next.

Dell's pay packet took a hammering as a result. In the financial year to 28 January, his salary, complete with share options and bonuses, came to a paltry $14 million. Paltry that is if compared to the $109m he made the previous year.

Dell believes all the hype about the PC being dead is overdone. Well he would, wouldn't he?

But there is logic in his argument, which is, to summarise: soon we won't have to access the internet through phone lines. New developments in wireless technology provide new opportunities. But we will still need servers - the bits of equipment that guide traffic around the internet and direct us to web sites - to handle all of this. This is good news for Dell which wants to corner the server market.

More than 40 per cent of the growth in the global server market came from Dell. And Dell adds: 'Handsets are not going to need all that extra bandwidth. But 3lb Dell notebooks that you can use anywhere are made for that sort of thing. That's a very exciting prospect. We don't plan on going into the phone business.'

Nevertheless, Dell Ventures, the company's venture capital arm set up with a $6bn war chest, is on the prowl in wireless-wise Europe, looking to buy into some of the emerging companies which will shape the mobile world of tomorrow.

'If there are any companies out there that want to be considered, they should submit their business plans now,' Dell says wryly.

He might be a keen advocate of the PC but, significantly, Dell hints that the company is looking at the personal digital assistant (PDA) market. 'It's interesting,' are two words which might make the likes of 3Com shudder. Dell is already working with Psion on developing a range of Bluetooth technologies that allow different devices to connect to each other without wires.

Dell Ventures, which Dell is adamant won't be floated off ('it's fundamental to our business'), is only one example of the way the company is trying to diversify. It is also developing a network of e-business partnerships with the likes of Arthur Andersen so that it can offer its clients services rather than just hardware.

The underlying point, however, is not hard to grasp. Apart from the fact that selling services is a huge growth area, by creating a network of alliances Dell also cleverly opens up a new sales channel. The partners sell the clients some services and, while they are about it, how about some Dell hardware with it?

Dell likens the internet to electricity in terms of its importance. And, as with electricity, too much intervention, he believes is dangerous. On Tuesday Dell met Tony Blair for a discussion on the internet. Dell used the meeting to protest against suggestions that the internet should be subject to new forms of taxation, obviously a key concern for a company which makes the majority of its money by selling online. 'There shouldn't be a discriminatory tax system. We're not asking for subsidies, but we're just saying there shouldn't be new taxes.'

Taxing the internet is a remote threat to Dell. More worrying is the position Dell will be left in if Microsoft is broken up. Perhaps more than any other company in the world, Dell owes a thank- you to Microsoft for creating an established set of industry standards and allowing the world's PCs to talk to each other, thus ensuring their proliferation.

Dell is sanguine about a break-up. 'The key issue for us is this - is it going to change the demand for our products? Customers who like Microsoft are going to buy from it if it is two companies rather than one.'

And, in an obvious rebuke to the US government for meddling in the business affairs of successful companies, Dell says: 'If we were looking for an organisation to design software for us, the Justice Department would be pretty low on our list.' His support for Microsoft is understandable given Dell's psychology. Michael Dell likes winners.

webTitle: If only I hadn't given him my address...

fields.headline: If only I hadn't given him my address...
fields.trailText: True confessions.
fields.body:
Two single girls and a couple of cheap plane tickets. Destination: Turkey. My friend and I vowed there would be no holiday flings - only travel and culture. But within three days, we were sitting on a hillside with two Turkish boys sipping wine and watching the sun rise. We abandoned ruins to devote ourselves to our holiday romances and returned home to wander about with dreamy expressions on our faces.

We quickly snapped out of it. (Well, you do, don't you?) We'd exchanged addresses but we wouldn't be writing.

Two years later, the unthinkable happened. In the middle of a dinner party, my phone rang. Nihat was in London. He had enrolled on a year's course in Kensington to improve his English. He wanted to meet. Desperate to get him off the phone, I agreed.

My flatmate told me not to worry: 'It's ancient history - he won't have any expectations after all this time. Just make it clear there's no chance of anything happening.'

But during the days leading up to our meeting, something shifted in me. The memories came drifting back and I found myself looking through old holiday photographs. What's more, I was single - I hadn't had a date in ages.

My heart was beating fast as I emerged from the Tube station to meet him. There he was, as gorgeous as ever and carrying... oh God, he was carrying one of those roses - the ones in cellophane wrappers that street-sellers flog to tourists. I almost turned and ran but then I stopped. He was Turkish and this was his first time abroad - how could he know the roses were embarrassing?

I started seeing him. He introduced me to college friends. I, on the other hand, told nobody. My unease was partly due to the way we'd met, but there was more. Nihat was incredibly right wing, not exactly in tune with my left-leaning friends. And we had absolutely nothing in common: his ideal date was a night at the Equinox disco in Leicester Square.

For the first month, I enjoyed the illicit novelty but then it began to turn sour. 'Who is this Steven you are seeing tomorrow?'

'He's a friend.'

'I think he will make a pass at you.'

'I've known him for years!'

'I don't want you to go out with other men. You are my girlfriend.'

Then there was his negativity. He said he was missing his family. His mother sent him food parcels and he retreated to his room where he sat, chewing dolmades, saying: 'In Turkey we have delicious food... in Turkey the people are friendly... I hate England.'

I tried to force him to go out and do things. He hated everything. One beautiful day, three months after he had first called, I dragged him to Richmond for a picnic. I lay on the grass while he sulked under a tree.

'What's the matter now?'

'This is boring.'

'But I thought you'd like to get out in the sun.'

'I don't want your English sunshine. We have better sunshine in Turkey.'

It could have been such a perfect day - if only he wasn't there. I stood up, packed up the picnic basket, said a curt goodbye and went home. I haven't seen or heard of him since.

If you have a true confession, email kim.bunce@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Settling down to sanity, and a spot of Shiatsu

fields.headline: Settling down to sanity, and a spot of Shiatsu
fields.standfirst: Diary of a dot.com
fields.trailText: Diary of a dot.com
fields.body:
For the past few weeks The Observer has chronicled the diary of a dotcom start-up. Flametree.co.uk, started by Jayne Buxton and Rosemary Leith, aims to be the 'portal for women who want to balance their lives'. The site, launched just over a week ago backed by nearly £1 million in private funding, includes features, online discussion forums, and e-commerce services.

Thursday

Jayne and Rosemary are jubilant. The Flametree site has generated 10,000 page impressions within three days of its 'soft' launch. As a result people have been emailing from Australia, Canada, Japan, the Middle East and the US.

Jayne reads some: 'I just wanted to say how impressed I am with your website. Your features could have been written especially for me.' And another: 'It may become a life changer for me.'

All this before promotions really start. Flametree is to send out 200,000 postcards in the first salvo.

The problem is to work out which postcards to send. A cute picture of wellington boots has been scrapped. However, a card showing toes and a rubber duck in a bubble bath has been given the nod, as has a picture of water running over smooth stones. This was chosen to convey tranquillity, a visual metaphor which, it is hoped, backs the Flametree brand and its emphasis on balance.

Some emails contain suggestions on how the site can be improved. As a result, Flametree has added two new forums - one aimed at single parents and another dealing with stress-related issues. All emails receive a personal response. One of the firm's advisers, Ally Svenson, who founded the Seattle Coffee chain, stressed to Jayne and Rosemary the importance of responding like this because of the way it helps build relationships. 'We want to show how valuable the customer's response is,' says Rosemary.

Unfortunately, Flametree may have been a little bit too successful at launch. The company's server was swamped a couple of times, requiring a software upgrade. This proved somewhat problematic to Chris, content and technical manager. Chris has adapted his mobile phone so that it messages him if his PC detects any delays while automatically accessing the site's web server every 10 minutes. In this way Chris can monitor any user difficulties.

Now, as things start to settle down, Jayne and Rosemary hope to 'establish some sanity'. Flametree.co.uk, started by Jayne Buxton and Rosemary Leith, aims to be the 'portal for women who want to balance their lives'. fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: Granted exposure | Double trouble
fields.body:
Granted exposure
Well, there's chutzpah for you. What odds would you have been given on Ross Kemp (formerly Grant of Eastenders ) appearing on the front cover of the News of the Screws ' television listings mag within a month of the paper appointing said actor's partner, Rebekah Wade, as ed? The few cynics that exist in newspaperland might suggest the two facts are not unconnected but really, of course, it's just a coincidence. The former hardman of Albert Square is starring in a new programme this week in which he plays himself playing Grant playing a legal eagle, sort of explain helpful Wapping sources who argue that this means Ross will appear on the front of lots of glossy organs in coming weeks. Cynics, back in your cages.

Double trouble
Meanwhile, the wags who argue the strange correlation between the ever-increasing appearances of pouting, pert, 21-year-old Brummie stunner Rebekah on the Sun 's Page 3 and La Wade's switch from number two at the Currant to the big gig at the Screws is more than a coincidence, were given new ammunition on Friday. The gorgeous Rebekah (the Brummie one) appeared again for what seems about the fifth time in a month, helping to fan the rumours that Sun editor Dave Yelland really does have a sense of humour after all and is merely entering into a playful jape with his former colleague. However, our eyes are drawn to a letter to the editor of the Page 3 website which states 'Page 3 destroys lifelong friendship'.

Belgium's language problem
Soon we may have a famous Belgian on our hands. A football commentator for RTBF, the country's state television channel, displayed some distinctly unMotsonesque language during Belgium's opening Euro 2000 clash with Sweden. When the Belgian keeper gifted a goal to Sweden's Johan Mjallby, the man with the mike bellowed out live on air: 'What a c***, what a c***'. Needless to say, the highlights were definitely of the edited variety.

Run-down clockwork Orange
Whither Alison Palmer, newly appointed spinmeister for mobile phone company Orange? Palmer, interviewed in PR Week on 5 May shortly after her appointment, gushed: 'I see Orange as a reflection of me'. She then went on to negotiate a long discourse about how she was a 'very glamorous person' who loved clothes and loved to be in 'with the in crowd' (dont'ya know?) Presciently, she admitted she had to be 'first, first, first with everything'. Well, Palmer and Orange parted terms a fortnight ago, making her career one of the shortest ever in the rarefied world of PR. Definitely another first. Sadly for PR Week , the piece concluded that 'Palmer's future looks distinctly Orange'.

Heads I win, tails you lose
Go figure. City spin machine Brunswick gets a half million pound 'success' fee if it helps Standard Life stay mutual. But if it fails in this noble defence it will earn a million notes for overseeing the subsequent float. Crazy guys, crazy fees.

webTitle: Gary v Des: forget score draws in the ratings war

fields.headline: Gary v Des: forget score draws in the ratings war
fields.trailText: Steve Barnett: On broadcast
fields.body:
The golden rule of forecasting is never to make a short-term prediction - meaning any period of time in which your crass stupidity might be rumbled. Number of digital TV homes in five years' time, by all means. Audience share for BBC television in 2010, certainly. By then, the next generation of microchip technology will have saved you from embarrassment.

But rules are for breaking, so here, in true kamikaze fashion, is a prediction that will be rendered true or false within 24 hours of its appearance. It concerns the England v Germany match. Not the silly game between 22 players on the pitch, whose result will be at least 12 hours old by the time you read this, but the keenly anticipated on-screen battle between the BBC's Gary and ITV's Des.

I predict that Gary will wipe the floor with Des by a margin approaching two to one. Even with the doyen of football presentation on its side, ITV will trail a poor second in the ratings battle. This has nothing to do with superior presentation, line-up of pundits, or pre-match scheduling. It's all about history, tradition and branding.

As a national institution, the BBC remains the place to go for other national institutions: royal weddings, royal birthdays (usually), general elections, millennium celebrations, national sporting disasters and the occasional sporting triumph. What started as a monopolistic obligation has become one of the great defining elements of the modern BBC, setting it apart from the growing band of commercial operators desperate to grab our attention. Whenever there's a choice, it's still Auntie who gets our vote for the great occasion.

This is something the Premier League forgot this week, and football may suffer the consequences. Soccer is the national sport, and Match of the Day has been another national institution which in its own way has enhanced and enriched the national game. Football has benefited not just from its availability every Saturday night to virtually every household in the country, but from its association with the BBC brand name. The game itself will still be universally available after next season, and probably a lot earlier than on the BBC. But Match of the Day will be gone.

In its place will be a different brand with a different set of values, more associated with the need to attract as many viewers with bulging wallets as possible. No doubt ITV coverage will be just as technically advanced and well produced - probably better. Behind every programme, however, will be a sneaking suspicion that it needs to pull off some smart commercial tricks to justify that annual investment of £60 million. Will the fans think that ITV is treating soccer as a national treasure, a game to be loved and cherished? Or as a commodity to be exploited and hyped in order to recoup at least some percentage of its huge bid?

To those who think the importance of channel branding is nonsense if the on-screen 'product' is identical, I offer one nugget of television sports trivia: between 1985 and 1986 the audience for the Derby plummeted from 4.4 million viewers to 1.7 million - not because the race was shifted to 7am but because coverage moved from ITV to Channel 4. Of course, there's a world of difference between a minority channel barely four years old and a mass entertainment channel with a 45-year history - but ratings for soccer highlights will fall, and there will be no more reward points from an association with the BBC brand.

This depends on the BBC brand actually surviving. Given this week's announcement from wunderkind director of television Mark Thompson that BBC television should be reorganised into 'genre-based' channels, this is by no means certain.

The prospect of a BBC1 devoted entirely to light entertainment, while anything remotely challenging or cerebral is shunted off to BBC2, will not enhance the public broadcaster's reputation for offering quality and diversity across the board. The assumption is that the new 'suite' of channels will continue to fulfil the BBC's commitments. In practice, BBC1 will begin to look uncomfortably similar to ITV, while current affairs and documentary programmes will be unable to profit from audiences inherited from mass appeal programmes.

It will then be just a matter of time before we hear calls for the privatisation of BBC1, leaving a marginalised BBC2 doing the kinds of 'worthy' things some people think is all a public broadcaster ought to be doing anyway. At that point - and here's a prediction that obeys the golden rule - we can kiss goodbye to the BBC brand value that makes it not just a quality national asset but provides an aspirational benchmark for other broadcasters.

s.barnett@wmin.ac.uk

fields.headline: Tangled web of Whitehall sites
fields.standfirst: If the Government is taking ads on its web pages, surely it should be making some money from them, says  Oliver Morgan
fields.trailText: If the Government is taking ads on its web pages, surely it should be making some money from them, says Oliver Morgan
fields.body:
The government is facing calls for the abolition of lucrative advertising and sponsorship deals on its websites after it emerged that Whitehall departments are not generating the revenue they could from them and guidelines are not being followed.

The value of advertising and sponsorship is increasing every day and could run into millions, according to internet experts.

Companies with space on government sites include a leading firm of City lawyers, an American pharmaceuticals giant, UK defence company BAe Systems, and telecoms group Cable and Wireless, as well as internet companies such as Lycos.

Advertising and sponsorship are often given in return for services from companies - such as helping to set up websites or sponsoring exhibitions. But the benefits to the Government, taxpayers, or the companies themselves are often not made clear, despite regulations stating they should be. Many departments have said in answers to parliamentary questions that they have no advertising on their website or those of their agencies or non 'departmental public bodies'.

But advertisements often appear on sites for 'public/private' bodies or voluntary sector organisations with close links to those departments, such as the Treasury's Private Finance Initiative Taskforce or the National Health Service Confederation. The sites are accessible through the Government's main portal at www.open.gov.uk.

Other departments, such as the Foreign Office, which state they do not have advertising on their pages, in fact run company logos, some of which have live links to sites with further information and company home pages. The departments claim that such material is not advertising; it is allowed in return for providing material for websites, and generates no revenue.

Cabinet Office rules say that advertising is permitted on government websites, subject to a series of regulations. But guidelines on advertising and sponsorship, which state that the returns should be tangible and specified, are sometimes not followed. And regulations that state that companies doing business with government departments should not sponsor their websites are being stretched to the limit.

Liberal Democrat constitution spokesman Robert Maclennan, who tabled a series of parliamentary questions on the issue, said: 'These findings show that the integrity of government information is threatened. I find this practice deeply worrying and wide open to abuse. Advertising and sponsorship on government websites should be banned.

'There is a very real danger that unacknowledged favours could be given to companies that directly sponsor govern ment activity.' The Neill Committee into standards in public life recommended full disclosure 'including value received, of sponsorship of government activities by private and voluntary sectors'. Several departments told The Observer that they did not calculate the value of such deals.

The Foreign Office includes eight advertisements, including ft.com and Rough Guides magazines, on its 'Planet Britain' pages - and many have live links to company sites. But no calculation had been made to work out the value or benefit to either the companies or departments.

Foreign Office minister Peter Hain also stated in a written answer to Maclennan that there was no advertising on foreign office sites apart from two sponsorship deals with Eagle Star and Glaxo Wellcome which contributed £35,000 and £6,000 respectively to the website and have their logos posted there.

Maclennan has similar concerns about the Cabinet Office, where there are links to business services group PriceWaterhouseCoopers and distributor TNT, and the Ministry of Defence, which has had live links to defence giant BAe systems from its pages. The creation of 'public-private' and charitable trust organisations with links to departments also creates real difficulties in 'policing the border between the public interest and private enterprise'.

He points to the Treasury Taskforce as an example. Berwin Leighton, one division of which specialises in valuable private finance initiative work with the Government, has a sponsorship deal with the Treasury's PFI Taskforce, which last week was renamed UK Capital. It has a logo on the Taskforce homepage, giving a live link to its own website.

The taskforce was set up by the Government to oversee negotiations on PFI deals - where hospitals, schools roads and other public projects attract private money. The Berwin Leighton site lists a number of projects in health, education, defence and transport, where it has been involved.

Government guidelines state: 'Sponsorship should not be sought or accepted from firms which are involved in significant commercial negotiations with the host department... or which may be affected by the exercise of that department's regulatory or licensing work.'

A Treasury spokesman told The Observer that the taskforce was not technically part of the Treasury, but was a private company limited by guarantee, even though it is publicly owned and operates out of government offices. 'That puts them in a different position to other non-departmental public bodies,' he said.

Health ministers also claim there is no advertising on departmental, agency or non departmental body websites. However, a live link to drugs giant Merck Sharp and Dohme, which is a large supplier to the NHS, appears on the website of the NHS Confederation, which is made up of 95 per cent of the hospitals and health authorities which make up the NHS.

Officials say the advertise ment does not break rules because the confederation is a registered charity, independent from the department. But they conceded that it is funded directly by NHS hospital and health authority members, and so indirectly receives Department of Health money.

The taskforce and NHS Confederation sites are accessible through the Government's main portal at www.open.gov.org and has itself accepted advertising from internet search engine Lycos, IBM and Cable and Wireless and others.

There is not a clear picture of how many 'hits' (visits to websites) have been made, because departments use different web servers to host their pages. The government's web host, CCTA, operates some 200 government sites on four servers and includes a few departments such as health. These sites receive 13 million hits each week.

Some departments keep a tally of hits. DTI websites received 67 million hits in the year to May, averaging 1.3 million a week. The treasury website receives around 20 million a year and got 330,000 three weeks ago. An industry rule of thumb is that 1,000 hits are worth £25, suggesting a value well into the millions for advertising space.

It is unclear how many of those hits will be on pages where there is advertising. But one industry expert said: 'This is very valuable property. We are certainly talking about millions of pounds every year.'

webTitle: Hoover tries to dust itself down

fields.headline: Hoover tries to dust itself down
fields.standfirst: The firm that gave us a new verb has suffered a series of crises. Now it is facing a court battle with arch-rival Dyson.  Nick Mathiason  reports
fields.trailText: The firm that gave us a new verb has suffered a series of crises. Now it is facing a court battle with arch-rival Dyson. Nick Mathiason reports
fields.body:
The vacuum cleaner was invented by an asthmatic janitor from Ohio called Murray Spangler - and it was his brother-in-law, William Hoover, who built factories and gave a name to the world's first electric labour-saving device.

But after nearly a century of cleaning up, Hoover has lost its sparkle, not least because of competition from the inventive James Dyson, who moved the goalposts with his bagless, brightly coloured vacuum cleaners.

The Hoover company, formed in 1908, coined the jingle 'It beats as it sweeps as it cleans'. As well as selling by the million, the machine went on to become the first mass-produced mod con to become a verb.

By the Nineties it was looking for marketing ploys, and came up with the infamous 1992 advertising gimmick which offered consumers two free air tickets for every £100 spent on Hoover products.

It seemed like a good idea at the time. But the trouble was that the offer was open-ended rather than first-come-first-served - and 600,000 people lined up for their tickets.

The cost to Hoover's former US owner, Maytag, is not known - it is at least £25 million, and probably nearer £50m. Maytag was forced to sell the company - it initially offered it for £1 but, when there were no takers, Jerry Kamman was parachuted in.

He slashed marketing budgets, trimmed the workforce, increased Hoover's unit prices and built up stock. The company appeared to be making money. It was sold for £100m to Candy, a northern Italian family-run concern. Candy today admits it overpaid.

After the free flights fiasco came Dyson's reinvention of the vacuum cleaner in 1993. Dyson's Cyclone has cleaned up in a market worth £455m here. His slice is now more than £200m annually.

Overseas consumers are still not convinced that the Cyclone bagless system sucks up more dust than a conventional disposable bag. Consumer tests tend to back this up. Vacuum cleaners now are equipped with motors up to 70 per cent more powerful than before Dyson came on the scene.

But although competitors, including Hoover, at first slated Dyson, they have now brought out similar products.

And that's where Hoover's final problem comes in. Dyson has taken a string of competitors to court over their advertising claims and alleged copyright infringements.

On 17 July he will claim in the High Court that Hoover's Vortex bagless machine has infringed his copyright. If found guilty, Hoover could be forced to withdraw its machine. For its 3,000 UK workers in south Wales and Merseyside, that would spell disaster.

Although Hoover has been reluctant to face the press since the tickets debacle, its Italian managing director, Alberto Bertali, has now decided that the time has come for him to move out of the shadows.

The 56-year-old has spent much of his working life away from home: first in Turkey, and then since 1995 in this country. Hoover , he says, has been 'quite a big challenge' - by which, one gets the impression, he means that it has been the biggest battle of his life.

Candy bought the company but did not inherit any liability for the ticket fiasco, which for a while made the company the country's biggest supplier of holidays.

'It wasn't ill-conceived,' he says. 'It was ill-managed. Basically it was the reason we managed to buy Hoover.' From a distance, Bertali had looked on in amazement as news of the free ticket fall-out spread throughout the world. 'On a £100 sale, they could only make £15 profit. We were scratching our heads.' But a greater headache was the antiquated factories, starved of investment. Bertali persuaded his chairman, Peppino Fumagalli, to invest £20m in its plants and cut unit prices by 25 per cent.

Hoover this year made its first profit since the fiasco, but Bertali believes it would have returned to profit earlier had it not been for the strong pound. Exports account for 40 per cent of output, so the strength of sterling 'is a sore point that is really killing us'.

Two years ago, Hoover cancelled contracts with local suppliers and started importing parts. 'It was a pure currency thing.'

Government officials intervened. 'They tried to convince us it was the euro that was weak rather than the pound. It's partly true. Since the euro was created, it has lost 15 per cent. But the pound has lost roughly 30 per cent against the lira and the mark.'

Hoover for one would consider scaling down its UK operation if Britain refused to join Euroland.

'We have invested heavily here,' Bertali said. 'We employ 3,000 people, so it's not an easy decision to pull out. But we've got to consider seriously where to invest.'

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: Dixons | Alba | Furlong Homes
fields.body:
Dixons isn't served over Freeserve stake
Shares in Dixons, the electrical retailer, have swayed with every piece of news - or the lack of it - about progress of the mooted sale of its remaining stake in Freeserve, the internet service provider. So far, investors who want an end to Dixons being valued as a technology stock have been disappointed.

Rumours of buyers have remained just that. With brokers such as Salomon Smith Barney questioning its value and internet statistics suggesting it is losing ground to the likes of Yahoo! and MSN, Dixons may be hard-pushed to get the 650p a share it is reputed to be demanding.

Even achieving that would not necessarily mean a bonanza for Dixons shareholders. It is highly unlikely that any buyer would pay cash: indeed, T-Online, which seems to be about the only one still in the frame, would probably pay entirely in shares. That would leave Dixons owning a smaller stake in a bigger company, but probably do little to quell the volatility of its shares.

Meanwhile, Dixons' margins remain under pressure and it will struggle to beat last year's strong sales figures by much. Excluding the Freeserve stake, the shares still stand on more than 30 times forecast earnings. That looks too high. Sell.

View to a killing
John and Daniel Bush, the father and son who run consumer electrical company Alba, saw its share price rocket by 19 per cent last Wednesday. It has gained modestly since, closing at 735p last Friday.

Why? Because the company last week finally announced it has perfected a television which can also access the internet so simply even Tony Blair could use it without lessons.

Investor sentiment was also boosted by a 26 per cent surge in Alba's pre-tax profits to £19.3 million, which was more than £2m ahead of analysts' predictions.

The Bushes, who previously made a splash with the £30 pump for turning your bath into a whirlpool, are hoping an intensive advertising campaign will help shift 500,000 of its new style TV sets by Christmas at £200 each.

This may be asking a lot but, thanks to a partnership deal last month with Virgin Net, it has become an internet portal. The new television sets may sell at a loss but income from advertising, e-commerce and telecom charges should offset that.

Analysts are now predicting 2001 pre-tax profit of £20.5m.

Alba has been a highly volatile stock this year. But it could replicate the dynamic stock market fortunes of Freeserve. A target share price by Christmas is 850p. A short-term buy.

Home in on property
Builder Furlong Homes is expected to announce an agreed merger tomorrow with another UK company. Furlong was forced to say last Thursday that it was having talks after its shares leapt almost 15 per cent.

A deal would herald the long-anticipated consolidation of the housebuilding sector. It is one of the mysteries of the financial world that this sector is in the doghouse.

House prices, while cooling, are still powering ahead, and up to 700,000 more homes are expected to be approved for the South-east over the next 15 years.

A bid for Furlong is likely to be around 290p - only 5 pence up on Friday's close .

There may not be much scope for investors to fill their purses on Furlong. But other companies in the sector are worth a look.

Like Countryside Properties. Three weeks ago, chief executive Graham Cherry hinted he was considering a management buyout to drive up the share price. While that may be some way off, shares in Countryside, which at 114p are 40p off its 12-month high, are worth snaffling. Buy for the long term.

webTitle: Mineral riches fuel war, not the poor

fields.headline: Mineral riches fuel war, not the poor
fields.standfirst: Jamie Doward  reports on the spiral of violence and greed still squandering Africa's inheritance
fields.trailText: Jamie Doward reports on the spiral of violence and greed still squandering Africa's inheritance
fields.body:
A few miles outside the Angolan capital of Luanda lie a motley collection of rusting Russian T54 and T72 tanks. The tanks were junk even before the Angolan government bought them. Their transmission systems were so jammed that they had to be hauled off the container ships using chains. The corroded machines are immovable testimonies to the connections between scarce, natural resources and some of the world's most violent conflicts.

Most of Angola's diamond mining industry has been under the control of Unita rebels for much of the past decade, giving them an income of $3.7 billion. Between 1992 and 1998, the country's government has in return used the income it receives from the world's oil companies each year, estimated to be between $1.8bn and $3bn, to buy weapons and pay its army. More than 90 per cent of the Angolan government's income comes from oil.

The amount of money being spent by both sides represents a colossal and tragic waste of money, almost impossible to comprehend. Despite the country's wealth of natural resources, it ranks 160th out of 172 nations in the human development index.

What wealth there is goes to various elites while the population starves. More than 80 per cent of Angolans live in poverty. The country's president, Eduardo Dos Santos, was forced to admit as much in 1997 when he said: 'Two thirds of the Angolan population live on less than a dollar a day.'

The UN has slapped an embargo on Angolan diamonds, and the big-name mining companies, such as De Beers, have severed their ties.

However the precious gems are still finding their way out of the country. Angolan diamonds are now being sold through one company - a company which is partly owned by a man who has for the best part of a decade kept the country's government in arms.

Diamonds are big at the moment. The conflict in Sierra Leone was initially sparked by a desire of Charles Taylor, the ruler of Liberia, to control his neighbouring country's diamond reserves.

And now the focus has shifted to the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). Last week The Observer revealed how the Foreign Office had stepped into the row surrounding mining firm Oryx, which was looking to float on London's Alternative Investment Market. The firm, which has a concession to mine in the Mbuji Mayi area of the DRC, has attracted attention because of its close links with the Zimbabwean and Congolese governments, which have profit-sharing agreements with Oryx.

Oryx disputes that it is mining in a conflict zone; Foreign Office Minister Peter Hain disagrees. Oryx feels hard done by. It is a relatively small company operating in an area which is also being mined by a Belgian firm partly owned by diamond giant De Beers. Nevertheless the spotlight on Oryx is understandable given the attention already being paid to the actions of Robert Mugabe's government and the bitter fighting in Kisangani in the east of the DRC.

But it also diverts attention from the wider picture. Everywhere you look, the DRC is being plundered of its natural resources. The Rwandan army seized many of the region's tantalite mines. Tantalite is used in the production of gun barrels. Likewise, the gold mines are coming under control of both Ugandan and Rwandan forces. Meanwhile, a railway line connects several copper mines to Zambia. The copper is taken from the DRC to Zambia where, according to pressure group Global Witness, it is picked up by Zimbabwean troops.

Global Witness, set up in 1993, highlights the links between conflict and natural resources, points out that what is happening in parts of the DRC is nothing new.

Throughout the early Nineties the Khmer Rouge made up to $20 million a year to keep itself in arms by selling timber to Thai government and military officials. The Khmer Rouge also did very well offloading sapphires and rubies mined near its stronghold in Pailin.

The Cambodian government, during the latter half of the last decade, signed secret illegal deals to allow Vietnamese loggers to fell Cambodian timber, much of which was subsequently made into garden furniture and sold across Europe under bogus 'environment-friendly' labels. The money found its way into the pockets of key military officials who were instrumental in establishing a coup d'etat in 1997.

According to Global Witness, in 1996 the Cambodian government was making around $100m a year from selling timber-felling concessions. Today, because of extensive deforestation, that government is lucky if it makes around a fifth of what it was earning four years ago. Gleaning such figures is no easy task. One of the main problems analysts face when trying to work out to what extent the trade in a particular natural resource is helping fuel a conflict is that, for obvious reasons, no one is sure exactly where the money is going.

Take the acquisition of oil drilling rights in Angola for example. In July last year, the Angolan government awarded the rights to three deep-water oil blocks to consortia led by BP-Amoco, Elf Aquitaine and Exxon respectively. Global Witness believes a high proportion of the $900m 'signature bonus' (the money paid upfront) went straight into the pockets of the Angolan presidency. Unfortunately none of the oil companies gives detailed breakdowns of how much it spends on acquiring concessions on a country-by-country basis, so working out where the money flows is almost impossible.

Last year the Foreign Office's Hain acknowledged this when he stated in a speech at the School of Oriental and African Studies that: 'The oil companies who work in Angola, like BP-Amoco, Elf, Total and Exxon - and the diamond traders like De Beers - should be open with the international community and the international financial institutions so that it is clear these revenues are not siphoned off but are invested in the country.'

An admirable sentiment, but one which so far looks impossible to achieve. None of the oil companies is prepared to give detailed breakdowns in its accounts - unless its competitors do the same.

'It would take little more than a change in accounting practices,' said Simon Taylor, a director of Global Witness. 'You could apply it to all the other extractive industries.'

But if the companies themselves are reluctant to take the initiative, there are at least tentative signs that the world's governments are becoming more serious about clamping down on the trade between weapons and scarce natural resources.

Last week the EU blocked a £35m aid package to Liberia because of its government's involvement in supplying rebel forces in Sierra Leone with arms in return for diamonds. And France, which currently holds the presidency of the UN Security Council, has started to express an interest in how Laurent Kabila, President of the DRC, funds his army's fight against rebel forces.

There is now also a real chance that a global certification system to register the provenance of each diamond is set to become a reality. But diamonds, as even the most cursory glance around the globe's hotspots reveals, are only part of the story.

webTitle: Unions use anti-strike legislation to bring employers back to the table

fields.headline: Unions use anti-strike legislation to bring employers back to the table
fields.trailText: The days of wildcat strikes may be over, but unions are getting ever cannier at using the spectre of industrial action to bargain for better working conditions with their employers.
fields.body:
The days of wildcat strikes may be over, but unions are getting ever cannier at using the spectre of industrial action to bargain for better working conditions with their employers.

Figures collected by the Trades Union Congress for a Trade Union Trends survey out on Thursday show that the number of ballots for industrial action has almost doubled in the last year, while the number of strikes has remained roughly flat.

The TUC concludes that unions are using strike bal lots to win better deals for their workers without resorting to stoppages.

General Secretary John Monks said: 'The figures will show that unions are acting effectively for their members without causing unnecessary disruption.

'There is no conflict between effectiveness and responsibility in today's modern unions.'

Unions argue that the figures prove that they are acting responsibly - against a background of recent events indicating that their power is at last on the increase after nearly two decades in the industrial wilderness. Since legislation in the Eighties, ballots are compulsory before a strike is called.

Figures out last month showed that union membership was rising after years of decline. And earlier this month a compulsory union recognition process came into law under the Employment Relations Act.

The TUC figures show that unions carried out 983 ballots for industrial action in the year from last June, compared with 464 the previous year.

Of last year's ballots, 126 became full-blown industrial action, while 155 strikes resulted from this year's votes.

TUC officials say ballots are producing votes for strike action in 95 per cent of cases, indicating that unions were managing the process better than in the past. Such tactics were used, for example, in a dispute where management wanted to put closed-circuit TV cameras into a factory.

Managers backed down after a pro-strike ballot by the Manufacturing Science Finance union.

fields.headline: Widget makers' tale of woe
fields.standfirst:
Joanna Walters and Oliver Morgan on the havoc wreaked by a strong pound on the UK car components industry
Ford at Dagenham: special report
fields.trailText: Joanna Walters and Oliver Morgan on the havoc wreaked by a strong pound on the UK car components industry
fields.body:
If Ford had closed all its plants in Britain in the last two years there would have been a national crisis accompanied by at least a Ministerial resignation. More than 25,000 jobs lost in one go - uproar!

But wait: an equivalent number of jobs has been lost in the British car components industry in the past 18 months. However, because widgets aren't glamorous, because the jobs are scattered across the country, and because no single company is associated with the loss, the cull has barely been noticed.

The Engineering Employers Federation, which collected the figures, is braced for further losses as motor industry experts warn that even more jobs - at least 35,000 - are threatened in the next two years. The supply sector is in danger of losing as much as £3.5 billion of business as worried car manufacturers, alarmed by the continuing strong pound, buy more and more components from abroad.

One by one, the big names that make cars in the UK are warning that the British content in their vehicles is shrinking and will continue to do so unless the pound comes down further or Britain joins the single currency.

About £500 million worth of buying power has been switched from the UK to the 'eurozone' or eastern Europe since autumn 1998, as the pound has soared, measured first against the deutschmark and now against the euro.

As car models come up for replacement or a 'mid-life facelift', the manufacturers prepare to sign contracts that will lock in supplies and prices for at least the next five years. Unless the pound continues to fall or Britain commits itself to joining the euro, many more of those contracts are likely to be given to overseas component makers, and the UK supply industry will take a huge hit.

Professor Dan Jones of Cardiff Business School said: 'If you are deciding where to buy parts for your next-generation vehicle, those decisions will last for up to eight years - the lifecycle of a car. It looks as though a lot of those decisions will be made, for economic reasons, outside this country so that carmakers can hedge their bets.'

Jones said it was 'a real shame' for British component makers because they had made tremendous strides in quality and productivity against their European rivals over the past few years. 'But that is not enough when the pound is against you.' He is worried that at least 25,000 jobs could go in the UK supply industry in the near future as sourcing drifts to the Continent.

That means small and medium-sized family firms contracting sharply or folding; larger UK firms closing factories in particular areas; or foreign-owned firms such as Bosch and Siemens, who have bases in this country, bringing in parts from their eurozone factories instead.

Vauxhall is expected to bring out its new version of the Vectra car in 2002 and started making decisions about where to buy parts for it two years ago when the level of the pound against the Deutschmark was already a concern.

The result is that while 60 per cent of the parts for the current Vectra are made in Britain, the next generation will have only between 40 and 50 per cent British content. If the final figure is 40 per cent, that will be business worth around £150m lost to UK component makers and gained by overseas ones.

Vauxhall chairman Nick Reilly told The Observer last week: 'That is a pretty big number if you are taking it out of the earnings of individual suppliers. And that is just one Vauxhall model.'

He said that two years ago the pound was shooting up and UK suppliers began to look less and less competitive. At the same time the carmakers were trying to squeeze ever more productivity out of their own UK plants - up to 7 per cent a year - and were already asking suppliers to drop their prices. Add in the currency factor and suppliers were hit by a double whammy.

Total spending on components in the UK has actually risen in the past two years - from £8bn to £8.5bn as car output has risen from 1.2 million 10 years ago to 1.5 million in 1995 and 1.75 million last year.

Many of the job losses have been part of an inevitable push towards higher produc tivity and shopfloor automation. But the currency effect in the past two years came without warning and has wounded an industry that was fast improving.

Rover, Vauxhall and Ford have all bought a greater proportion of their components from abroad over the past two years as new models such as the Rover 75, the Vauxhall Astra and the Ford Transit came on stream .

An industry source said last week: 'If the pound stays around this level, you wonder who will be able to compete in the British components industry, who will be left?'

Before BMW sold Rover to Phoenix and Land-Rover to Ford, it was talking about switching a quarter and eventually up to half of its annual £4bn supply spending outside Britain. The British content of Rover cars was set to fall from an average of 85 per cent to 60 or even 50 per cent.

BMW still plans to make the new Mini at the Cowley factory it retained after selling the bulk of Rover Group. But it is likely to buy only 40 per cent of its components in the UK.

The futures of Rover cars and Land-Rover production are up in the air now under the new owners. Rover needs to develop replacements for the 25 and 45 models and wants to buy a basic platform from another manufacturer. If that is Volkswagen, as many predict, the floorplans will come from Germany - more lost British jobs.

Meanwhile, French-owned Peugeot has an excellent factory in Coventry, where it is busy turning out the popular new 206. But it has always bought more than half its components from France, and although the company has not announced a new strategy, sources at the company have forecast that even more of its supplies will come from abroad in future.

Tod Evans, managing director of Peugeot manufacturing in the UK, recently joined other UK motor chiefs to lobby prime minister Tony Blair, as revealed in The Observer , about the damage being done to the carmakers and their suppliers by high interest rates and the strong pound. The delegation was led by Nissan chief Sir Ian Gibson, but the industry's pleadings appear to have fallen on deaf ears in Downing Street.

The delegation was hardly out of Number 10 when Nissan announced that unless it could cut costs by 30 per cent at its factory in Sunderland - which would involve a huge squeeze on suppliers - it would move the right to produce the next Micra to one of its Continental factories. The factory has already switched 10 per cent of its £800m annual British supply spending out of the UK since 1998.

The decision will be made by the end of the year, but if Sunderland loses the Micra, the UK supply industry will lose another £250m of business.

Toyota and Honda have also warned that the UK content going into their factories in Derby and Swindon respectively faces shrinkage in the next two to three years.

Nick Matthews at the Warwick University-based Manufacturing Group said Toyota had demanded a 20 per cent price cut from UK suppliers; the alternative was to switch the business to the Continent.

The issue of supplying the Japanese-owned factories is particularly sensitive: they were allowed to set up in the UK in the late Eighties and early Nineties on the back of promises about putting 70 per cent 'local content' into their cars. But now under the Maastricht Treaty 'local content' must now mean 'anywhere in the EU'.

Things look bleak for British suppliers. But Vauxhall's Reilly is not totally gloomy. 'There are opportunities for big productivity gains out there,' he says, 'and if we work very, very hard, we can avoid a crisis.'
