webTitle: Oh for a beaker of warm Seventies

fields.headline: Oh for a beaker of warm Seventies
fields.trailText: Andy Beven: Comment
fields.body:
Let's do the time warp again. Opec is meeting in Vienna ; the Iranian hawks are facing up to the Saudi doves; petrol price rises threaten the UK's well-being.

What next? Shortages of sugar and toilet paper? The three-day week? Colonel David Stirling leading his ghostly militia through the Home Counties to save us from the enemy within by supporting a 'government of national unity'?

Well, not really. For a start the cost of a barrel of crude would have to be $70, not $30, to recreate the price shock of the early Seventies. And Western economies depend less on oil than they did then - the US, for example, uses about 25 per cent less per capita than in 1978.

Then there is the green dimension. The Royal Commission on Environmental Pollution says a 20 per cent reduction in British CO2 emissions is not enough, and even that clearly entails a reduction in energy consumption. Given consumers' failure to curb their car use for moral reasons, perhaps the stick of increased prices at the pumps is the only way to move towards this target.

Of course, this doesn't help hard-pressed manufacturers with their transport costs, but surely everyone agrees it would be better if much more freight was moved by rail.

No problem there then, except that rail freight is already nearing capacity and without massive investment in the network, which could not bear fruit for years, the option to shift from truck to track is not open to us. Was life always this complicated?

Not to some people. Sir Edward Heath, the grand old grump of British politics, popped up on the radio the other morning in celebration of the thirtieth anniversary of his 1970 election victory. This was not, as you might imagine, an occasion that had champagne corks flying all over Britain, and it appeared that even Sir Edward's joy was not unalloyed.

He wanted to remind us of a forgotten statistic: that he left office with unemployment at only 580,000. His tone suggested that he was still deep in the longest sulk in British parliamentary history, but in some ways it was a timely reminder.

Yes, we know that in 1974 the British economy was a fool's paradise, with stroppy workers not bothered by their poor productivity and the beast inflation slavering at the door, but in mitigation poor old Mr Morning Cloud had been severely buffeted by a real oil crisis. The point is that back then unemployment of a million was unimaginably scary.

Yet now its drop to 1,600,000 - in the ILO's waffle-adjusted statistics - is no longer a source of pure joy. When the US jobless total falls, so, routinely, does Wall Street, and over here it is only just conceded that any fall will not lead to a terrifying wages and prices spiral. The real legacy of the Thatcher era is that a whole generation, which saw the passing of the 3 million mark, has been numbed to rises in the dole queue.

In the past few days alone Corus, the former British Steel, has announced 1,500 redundancies, and C&A is reluctantly cutting nearly 5,000 more. Given those firms' links with the Sixties and Seventies, the Tardis factor is again firmly with us. This feeling is accentuated when, as The Observer reveals this week, another 35,000 jobs are going in the car components business, on top of the 25,000 lost in the past two years.

Of course, there is not one single cause. C&A is not only a (lack of) fashion victim; it is also punished by the over-expansion in retail space and cut-price rivals. But in the other two examples, the strong pound is again blamed. Sceptics will say it is just an excuse - and given that Corus sees Poland as a source of steel they have some justification. Similarly, the age-old problem of productivity hangs around the components business. But it cannot be denied that the strength of sterling... and suddenly, oh my god, we're back to the euro question.

No time warp there - it's newish - but we can trace it back to Sir Ted with his enthusiasm for Europe and detestation of needless job losses.

It's almost enough to make you long for the simplicities of the Seventies. Until you remember bri-nylon shirts.

fields.headline: West held over a barrel
fields.standfirst: Petrol price rises are hurting but Opec is determined to resist demands for greater oil output, writes  Oliver Morgan
fields.trailText: Petrol price rises are hurting but Opec is determined to resist demands for greater oil output, writes Oliver Morgan
fields.body:
For the Porsche drivers of Chelsea, the distant gyrations in international oil production have come home to the petrol pump.

The fuel in London SW3 has passed through £4 a gallon. As the Petroleum Retailers Association points out, the price of a litre at the Chelsea Cloisters filling station was 91.9p last Wednesday - perhaps the highest in the UK, and 19p above the symbolic figure.

Few will shed tears for drivers who probably don't even notice the cost, and high prices in central London bear little relation to the average 84.9p - or £3.85 a gallon - paid by mere mortals outside the M25.

Nevertheless, average petrol prices across the UK have risen - from 68.9p a litre a year ago - and, as Ray Holloway of the PRA says, they are more than likely to break through the 87.9p-a-litre barrier soon.

We Brits may be phlegmatic - the reasons for price rises are complex and have as much to do with the 21 per cent increase in fuel duty since 1997 as with politicking in the Vienna headquarters of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec). The knock-on effects are not what they were in the Seventies either, when we were more dependent on oil.

But in the US there has been a hell of a row. The proportion motorists pay to the US government in tax is a fraction of that paid in the UK, and if prices go up, drivers want to know why. This being an election year, US Energy Secretary Bill Richardson pointed his finger at Opec and demanded increased oil production to bring down gasoline prices.

His assault started in the spring, when prices were passing through the $30 a barrel level. At its March meeting, Opec added 1.7 million barrels a day to output. All Opec countries except Iran and Iraq signed an agreement saying that if the price moved out of a $22-to-$28 band, it would increase or cut production accordingly. But the price has not fallen - and the agreement has not held. Last week prices for some crude oil benchmarks passed through $32 a barrel. US gasoline prices have risen from $1.48 a gallon to $1.66 since April.

This week Opec meets again, and the US is hoping for another increase of at least a million barrels a day.

But why has the US been so wrong-footed by Opec, which less than two years ago was seen as a disorganised rabble? Analysts point to several political factors.

Relationships have altered: there used to be a simple rift between doves led by Saudi Arabia - whose huge reserves mean it is less concerned about short-term revenues - and hawks such as Iran, who take the opposite view.

The turning point was a rapprochement between Opec's wild card, Venezuela, which had been busting production quotas, and Saudi Arabia. Agreement between Saudi Arabia and Iran has also been reached.

As Paul Harsnell of the Oxford Institute of Energy Studies says: 'You have to judge its performance by results. The relationships have been good, the PR has been good, and management of the market has been good.'

Against this background, Julian Lee of the Centre for Global Energy Studies points out that Opec is nervous about overdoing things for the West's benefit. 'Last time they increased production, they timed it so it coincided with the 1997 Asian crisis, and the price went through the floor to $10 a barrel.'

Opec's revenues slumped - from $160 billion in 1997 to $107bn in 1998 - and it won't want to repeat that. But to be fair, says Lee, the problem is not really with crude - but oil products. The key 190 US oil refineries producing petrol for the nation's gas guzzlers are working at full tilt.

'The US is facing problems because its petrol inventories are so low,' says Lee, pointing to figures showing US stocks slumping to 340 million barrels in December last year from 410 million in March. 'Much refining capacity was not used earlier in the year, when they should have been building up for the summer.' Stocks last month were around 351 million barrels.

Looking ahead, says Lee, the US may need more than a million barrels a day to allow greater petrol production - because it should also be building up stocks of heating oil for winter. But that's a problem for after the election.

webTitle: Safeway and 'greedy' Portuguese farmers in cork and bottle row

fields.headline: Safeway and 'greedy' Portuguese farmers in cork and bottle row
fields.trailText: Safeway has infuriated customers by accusing Portuguese cork farmers in Europe's poorest region of being greedy.
fields.body:
Safeway has infuriated customers by accusing Portuguese cork farmers in Europe's poorest region of being greedy.

The comments stem from complaints about the company's switch from corks to plastic stoppers for wine. The bark of cork oak trees sustains the subsistence farming practised for centuries in the Alentejo region of southern Portugal.

Robin Law, spokesman for Safeway chairman Carlos Criado Perez, told customers who complained of the switch that cork trees were being stripped too often, that farmers were driving out wild pigs, and that the environmental damage had forced the chain to switch from natural to plastic corks. 'The plastic corks we are using should actually help the preservation of the cork forests,' he added.

The claims were dismissed by environmentalists and forestry experts, as well as by Portuguese politicians, who blame US multinationals for persuading wine retailers to use their synthetic products.

Dr Luis Palma, a cork forestry expert, said: 'The regular stripping of cork oaks improves the vigour of the trees. The bark will not come off if it is not ready, so it impossible to strip too often.'

The plastic cork industry argues that natural cork can sometimes 'taint' wine. Plastic is used in one in 20 wine bottles worldwide, and one in four in some high street retailers in the UK. But according to Excell laboratories in France, chemical compounds in many plastic corks can migrate into the wine.

Cork strippers in Portugal have now begun this season's work. Last week crowds watched bark being stripped from the 217-year-old Whistler Tree (pictured above), the world's oldest cork oak tree - named after the noise of the thousands of birds who annually pass through its branches.

The claims were dismissed by environmentalists and forestry experts, as well as by Portuguese politicians, who blame US multinationals for persuading wine retailers to use their synthetic products. Dr Luis Palma, a cork forestry expert, said: 'The regular stripping of cork oaks improves the vigour of the trees. The bark will not come off if it is not ready, so it impossible to strip too often.' The plastic cork industry argues that natural cork can sometimes 'taint' wine. Plastic is used in one in 20 wine bottles worldwide, and one in four in some high street retailers in the UK. But according to Excell laboratories in France, chemical compounds in many plastic corks can migrate into the wine. Cork strippers in Portugal have now begun this season's work. Last week crowds watched bark being stripped from the 217-year-old Whistler Tree (pictured above), the world's oldest cork oak tree - named after the noise of the thousands of birds who annually pass through its branches.

webTitle: US group tipped as suitor for RJB mines

fields.headline: US group tipped as suitor for RJB mines
fields.trailText: US coal and real estate group Drummond Company is being tipped as the most likely suitor for beleaguered British pit operator RJB Mining.
fields.body:
US coal and real estate group Drummond Company is being tipped as the most likely suitor for beleaguered British pit operator RJB Mining.

RJB has hinted that its suitor is a private US operator, and industry experts believe Drummond is the most likely candidate.

The company, based in Birmingham, Alabama, operates mines in the US and Colombia, as well as having property interests in California and Florida.

RJB revealed last week that it had received a bid approach after its shares jumped 11p to a year high of 60p. They closed the week at 66p. Analysts indicate that a buyer be interested not only in RJB's 13 deep mines and 16 opencast sites, but would also be eyeing up the company's property portfolio.

When RJB bought British Coal from the government in 1994, it took over 50,000 acres of land - of which 15,000 acres is around mines, 7,000 is 'brownfield' and 28,000 is farmland. It has a total workforce of 8,000.

Analysts say the land itself could be worth 80p a share, with the mining assets up to a further 90p. Charles Kernot, mining analyst at BNP Paribas, said: 'Because of its exposure to both property and coal mining, Drummond would make a good fit for RJB. It would use its mining expertise and could realise the value of the land.'

webTitle: Mortgage, pension - and all that jazz

fields.headline: Mortgage, pension - and all that jazz
fields.standfirst: How can I improve both my music and my finances, Paul Milnes asks  Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: How can I improve both my music and my finances, Paul Milnes asks Helen Pridham
fields.body:
Vital statistics

Paul Milnes

Age: 54

Lives in: South London

Occupation: Education adviser for information technology

Earns: £26,400

Mortgage: £55,000

Debts: Bank loan £1,800, credit card £600

Investments: Around £5,000 in shares, £5,000 in bank account

Pension: Member of occupational pension scheme

Aim: To check effect on pension and mortgage of going part-time

Paul has a passion for playing jazz piano. So great is his enthusiasm that two years ago he cut a day off his working week in order to spend more time at his piano. He is now planning to reduce it by another day from January. This means he will be working three days a week at the University of North London, where he provides computer training for primary school teachers.

It is not that there is not enough to do at work. On the contrary, Paul says giving up now is difficult because of the growing emphasis on technology in schools. He has delayed his further cut from September until next January because of his department's workload.

But he feels taking time off is the only way to go where he wants with his music. He has already noticed the difference: 'It has been beneficial, not only in performance terms but in an increased sense of well being.'

Nevertheless he admits to concern about finances. He has been getting some gigs, but he admits: 'You don't make a fortune from jazz.' When he cuts his days, his salary will reduce by a further 25 per cent. Although he hopes to supplement his income by building up his own freelance database and website design business, called Soft and Sound, he admits he has not made much headway so far in his one free day a week.

It is the longer term he is more worried about, in particular mortgage and pension. His mortgage is on a fixed rate of 3.89 per cent until September, when he faces a considerable hike in payments. He is repaying the loan through a number of endowments - one with Sun Alliance due to mature in 2008, and two with Norwich Union paying out in 2010. But with all the bad publicity about endowments, he is not sure whether these will produce enough to pay off his remaining mortgage.

He owns 800 Norwich Union shares (worth £3,500-£4,000), 100 shares in Abbey National, and three small (£250) holdings in Unigate, Vocalis and the Just Group. He is planning to start an investment club soon with some friends, and thinks he will contribute £50 or £60 per month.

He has been building up an occupational pension with the Teachers Pension Agency to which he has contributed 6 per cent of his salary for the past 22 years; for the past four years he has also paid £100 a month net into an AVC. He wonders if reducing his working week will limit the amount he can contribute to his AVC.

Adviser 1: Sharon Linnard

Paul's decision to reduce his hours and increase his other activities could mean not only a reduced income but additional expenses as he builds up his music and internet businesses. He is also likely to see his mortgage outgoings rise when his fixed rate expires.

If Paul finds the best option is to remain with Northern Rock on its variable rate of 7.79 per cent, the monthly cost of his mortgage will go up by about £178. So it may be best, after he has repaid his bank loan and credit card, to hold remaining money on deposit to be called upon if needed. Part of this could be held in a mini cash Isa so that interest is tax-free. Once his position is clearer, longer-term savings can be considered.

Regular savings into an equity Isa may be advisable in addition to or instead of the investment club. An Isa should offer a greater spread, so less risk.

Under the teachers' pension scheme, Paul's pension will be directly linked to his earnings: reducing his hours will therefore reduce the pension he receives when he retires. Continuing AVCs at £100 a month is unlikely to be a problem, but Paul should check this.

He could also compare the projected returns from the AVC scheme with what he would get by putting this contributions into a personal pension plan. With a personal pension, he can take part of his benefits at retirement as a tax-free lump sum, whereas AVCs must normally be taken as pension.
 Sharon Linnard works for accountant KPMG.

Adviser 2: Charles Levett-Scrivener

The rules for pension benefits are very complex for employees who initially work full-time and then go part-time. However, under rules to ensure that part-time workers are treated fairly, any period of part-time work must be converted into full-time equivalent. As Paul already has 20 years' full-time service, Inland Revenue limits will allow him to draw a full pension at normal retirement date, but things will be more complex if he takes early retirement.

There is a chance that if he continues with his current AVCs, he may end up overfunding his pension. However, the Teachers' Pension Agency would be responsible for carrying out a headroom check to confirm that he is not. Once he has actual earnings from his music and freelance work he will be able to make contributions based on the stakeholder personal pension rules.

Paul is worried that his endowments may not fully repay his mortgage. He may be pleasantly surprised with the plan that ends in 2008. Those taken out in 1990 may be more problematic, as they have not benefited much from the high returns of the 1980s.

He will receive a cash sum from his pension, which could pick up any deficit. However, there is still a good chance that if investment returns are satisfactory over the next 10 years, the plans maturing in 2010 will fully repay his mortgage.

 Charles Levett-Scrivener works for financial adviser Towry Law.

Advice is for guidance only.

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: Intelligent plays have staged a comeback in London's West End thanks to the business sense and creative talents of theatre impresarios Brigid Larmour and Nick Salmon. Nicole Kidman didn't do any harm either
fields.trailText: Intelligent plays have staged a comeback in London's West End thanks to the business sense and creative talents of theatre impresarios Brigid Larmour and Nick Salmon. Nicole Kidman didn't do any harm either.
fields.body:
Brigid Larmour I am not sure we were intended to be such a double act. Two years ago, we were brought in to look more creatively at the work going into the West End. My perspective was that there was a terrific amount of faulty work being slung into theatres in order to make an impact. We were asked to counterbalance that. Nick, who had already done every job you could name in the entertainment industry, was there to programme the theatres, whereas I came in, at 38, to travel around and find interesting work.

Nick concentrated on producing, while I dealt with the writers and actors. I soon realised I needed more practical business experience to make it work. So that's when I moved across the corridor to be next to Nick's office. I was fascinated by what he knew. I didn't recognise his devilish sense of humour at first - the hint of green in the armour. I could see he was part of the theatrical old guard and yet someone who obviously knew everyone in the West End.

We work well together because we both understand that you can't predict a success and that not all venues suit every play. We were able to start trying out some work in the regions, such as Hedda Gabler with Francesca Annis, which was great, but in the end not right to bring to London. We didn't feel it had the momentum. I have learned a certain caution from Nick. As a result, we have had commercial and critical hits, such as Spend, Spend, Spend , Tom Stoppard's The Real Thing and Samuel Beckett's Krapp's Last Tape .

I brought the Beckett over from The Gate in Dublin by promising they would get artistic credit. This is how we became known as people who value the work. And productions such as Nicole Kidman in The Blue Room at the Donmar Warehouse showed you could actually take risks.

Until I came to ACT (Associated Capital Theatres), subsidised theatre had been my life. I had worked as artistic director with the Contact Theatre company in Manchester and so I knew how to find work and develop it. Nick, though, has a grip on the terrifying financial realities, but claims he can't read a script. The truth is, we need each other's strengths. Together we have bridged the gap between subsidised quality theatre and the West End. Too much separation had grown up between them. In the end, neither Nick nor I can ever know that we have a certain hit, but you can have an instinct. My job, unlike Nick's, is never to be cynical. We are like chalk and cheese or, perhaps, Fred and Ginger.

Nick Salmon I would say Brigid and I are more like God and Mammon. I am the professional cynic most of the time, where as she... well, whatever she is, it works. We were brought in because Associated Capital Theatres was programming rubbish and allowing theatres to go 'dark', which is very expensive indeed.

There was a real shortage of good-quality product to fill the venues. Theatre owners cannot afford to have dark theatres. It hits our bottom line very quickly, so the temptation is always to take any work simply because it is there.

Don't misunderstand me, though, my decisions are still absolutely commercial. It is just that this is not a predictable business, so you have to be able to take risks.

I was very interested in John Hurt, commercially speaking and, of course, in Beckett's work. But in the end we had to go into a smaller theatre for Krapp's Last Tape because there is not a huge amount of audience interest in Beckett out there. It was a hard decision, because we had two potentially dark theatres and yet we put it into The Ambassadors in the end, which was not even our theatre.

Brigid and I did get the quality up. In fact, there is only one show we've done together which was rubbish, and I am not saying which one.

Our most illustrious association is with Sam Mendes and The Donmar Warehouse. We helped him set up Warehouse Productions, his own theatrical production company. Backing Sam was an act of faith, but we knew his potential. He is a modest guy and actors love working with him.

My interest in the theatre dates back to my schooldays at Wellington, but I learned about it all, and about the West End in particular, during a long time spent as an agent in partnership with Peter Crouch. We represented a lot of the popular acting stars of the 70s, including Glenda Jackson, Bernard Cribbins, Wilfred Bramble and Ronald Fraser. As a result, I know full well that the biggest asset the commercial theatre has is the subsidised theatre. Later on, I became involved with the film industry and worked with the director Bryan Forbes. From this era, I can proudly cite films such as The Go Between and The Railway Children .

Theatre has to be much more cautious than film these days and, because of this, a lot of the new playwrights coming up are writing for small spaces and for a small cast. In fact, it is not just the play, the whole thing has now shrunk. The themes as well.

If we don't start thinking a bit bigger, the TV and film industry will continue to be the only industries that can benefit from both the training and the talent. .

webTitle: Barred Oryx weighs up flotation in Dublin

fields.headline: Barred Oryx weighs up flotation in Dublin
fields.trailText: Diamond mining company Oryx, whose listing on London's Alternative Investment Market was pulled after intervention by the Foreign Office, is now looking to float in Dublin or North America.
fields.body:
Diamond mining company Oryx, whose listing on London's Alternative Investment Market was pulled after intervention by the Foreign Office, is now looking to float in Dublin or North America.

The AIM float, via a reverse takeover of another mining company, Petra Diamonds, was abandoned 10 days ago after Oryx's financial adviser, Grant Thornton, walked out. Last week The Observer revealed how the Foreign Office had pressurised the Stock Exchange authorities to block the listing.

This followed controversy over Oryx's links to the governments of Zimbabwe and the war-torn Democratic Republic of Congo. The exchange authorities subsequently demanded answers to several technical questions from Grant Thornton, although it had completed its due diligence process into Oryx's affairs and concluded that the company should be allowed to list.

The Observer has also established that the overseers of AIM listings had approved the float five days before it was due to happen.

Now the company's senior management is considering a listing on one of several other stock exchanges. Dublin is one option, but Canada or the US are also being considered.

Oryx is understood to be talking to its lawyers about possibly taking legal action against Grant Thornton.

Geoffrey White, Oryx's deputy managing director, said: 'Our current strategy is to try to list on the AIM. We are still hoping that whoever has a problem with our seeking a listing will clarify that problem.

'We are asking for an explanation. But if we can't get a listing here we have to look at the pros and cons of listing elsewhere.'

Oryx has a concession to mine diamonds near the town of Mbuji Mayi in the Democratic Republic of Congo, and intends to share any profits from the venture with the Congolese and Zimbabwean governments, which are involved in the fighting.

Foreign Office Minister Peter Hain recently said the company should not be allowed a London listing because it was operating in a 'clear conflict zone'.

fields.headline: Ticket to chide
fields.standfirst: Bus drivers beware! Ann and Vera, Hammersmith & Fulham's bus spies, are on to you. By Peter Silverton
fields.trailText: Bus drivers beware! Ann and Vera, Hammersmith & Fulham's bus spies, are on to you
fields.body:
It was High Street Kensington, Jim, but not as I knew it. I was a stranger in a familiar land. Which was the idea. 'See that,' said Ann Rosen. Small and round, with an all-white crop, Ann pointed at the gap between the number 31 bus and the High Street Kensington kerb.

'They stop away from the pavement. They shouldn't, but they do.' The bus driver - Ann's 'they' - looked worried. Then that's Ann for you. 'It depends on the driver and training,' added Ann's companion, Vera Godden. She peered out through frisbee-sized spectacles and said: 'Lots of companies are not paying for driver training.' The driver - trained or not - looked even more worried. Then that's Vera for you.

Ann and Vera were my dates for the morning. We'd met under the clock at Hammersmith Bus Exchange. They were taking me on the buses, giving me a guided tour of public transport through older eyes and oversized glasses.

We're all getting older. That's life. More of us are getting more of a life than ever before, though. So we are becoming 'older still'- the phrase used by Mr Tony last year when he launched Better Government For Older People. It's a two-year programme in search of 'a strategy for an ageing population'. Transport is a significant part of it. 'Being able to travel locally with ease and confidence is crucial to older people's independence and well-being,' said Mark Beauchamp, of Kensington & Chelsea.

The borough put 40 older people 'undercover' to spy on London buses, but they'll no longer talk to the press - ever since they were lampooned in a piece by Hunter Davies, a man with an unfortunate moustache whose own spring has long since turned to grumpy autumn.

He wouldn't have dared do it to Ann and Vera, I can tell you. Both women of a maturity which would make it ungallant - maybe even impractical - to count the candles on their cake, they are 'bus spies' for the borough of Hammersmith & Fulham. Like all London's pensioners, they travel free within the whole 50-mile diameter of the city's furthest reach, thanks to a Freedom Pass - available to women at 60 and men at 65. That's discriminatory, I said, ribbingly. 'Those who feel discriminated against should kick harder,' said Ann, firmly but with a grin. Vera walks awkwardly, with a slight limp. 'Tib and fib on the right leg,' she said, dismissively. She worked in the accounts department of Joe Lyons - the food manufacturer that was to Hammersmith what Ford was to Dagenham - and she worked for the Labour Party. She's now vice-chairman - her word - of the local Age Concern. Ann, a former headmistress, is chairman - again, her word - of Hammersmith's Better Government For Older People. Both are lifelong agitators. You wouldn't want to meet them in a dark committee room.

Do you feel listened to? I asked, naively. 'We make damn sure we are,' said Ann. 'Wouldn't you pay attention to Vera?' she added, producing a list of bus routes. The ones we were to take were clearly marked, all of them new, low-floor single-deckers, built with older people in mind - buggies and wheelchairs, too.

And take them we did, only getting lost once. We all blamed each other for that. If truth be told, we were probably distracted by the constant dialogue with fellow passengers which Ann and Vera's presence produced. 'This bus is quite nice,' volunteered a sharply dressed woman on a number 49. 'But it keeps you waiting 45 minutes at times. And some of the drivers aren't good.' On a C1 to South Ken, Vera went into battle with the driver on behalf of a registered blind person, unable to see that her free pass had gone out of date.

Legislation has decreed that our buses should be more accessible. Privatisation, however, has meant that, while London Transport lays down the rules, each bus company comes up with its own solution. London now has 2,200 low-floor buses, more than any European city; but all of them seem to have a different lay-out, none of them ideal. Essentially, the problem is that lowering the floor at the front of the bus means there are more internal steps at the back - how else could you clamber over the engine and the wheel arches?

The result is that the front section of the bus has to satisfy the directly contradictory needs of both the disabled and the ageing. Wheelchairs need flat, open space. Older people want seats - single ones, ideally, as they are far easier to get in and out of. Also, that flat front section is the very bit of the bus that every Londoner feels is theirs to occupy when standing up.

So what did our two agents with a licence to bus think of the new low-floor buses? They weren't that enthusiastic, to be frank. 'That bus there is wheelchair accessible, for example,' said Ann. 'It's meant to have a sign. But it doesn't.' One had no single seats. Most did not have enough stop bells or horizontal bars. When you can't move so fast, it's important that you have something to hang on to and that a stop bell is close to hand wherever you're sitting. Of the buses we sampled, their favourite was the number 28 to Harrow Road - enough space for both older people's seats and for two wheelchairs.

She peered out through frisbee-sized spectacles and said: 'Lots of companies are not paying for driver training.' The driver - trained or not - looked even more worried. Then that's Vera for you. fields.headline: My roots
fields.standfirst: A week in Monty's garden
fields.trailText: A week in Monty's garden
fields.body:
It has been so warm and wet that anything can be moved with impunity, and we have taken advantage of this. Like any keen gardener, neither Sarah nor I can resist buying or growing plants, and to fit newcomers in, we inevitably have to shuffle the existing planting arrangements.

So I planted out the Salvia elegans and other salvia cuttings that I took last autumn. S elegans only just gets a place in the Jewel garden, as its magenta-ish flowers are almost pink - and pink is strictly banned. The dozen plants are tucked away at the edge of a path so that its pineapple-scented leaves can be fingered in passing.

But S guaranitica is an important blue and needs careful placing. I moved some Knautia macedonicas, then saw that a recently planted cardoon was going to sprawl all over these when it got going, so I moved that before the roots got established, then found three sites for the salvias. Last year, they did not flower until September, so I expect more effort this year.

There are fresh vignettes every day in the Jewel garden. There's a red peony half smothered by the lime yellow of the Rubus thibetanus, and the poppy 'Patty's Plum' is finally hitting its stride after three years and growing 6ft tall - it bears half a dozen wonderful rich, smoky flowers. The geums, especially 'Mrs Bradshaw', are bounding back like old friends, the amazing alliums still going strong, with A schubertii mind-bogglingly strange.

The roses are at last spilling free, although there has been a lot of balling with all the wet weather. One of the most successful combinations is the geranium 'Ann Folkard' with its lime-green and magenta flowers, and the new stems of the rose 'Scharlachglut', whose new stems are a deep purple, which then rise up to the rich crimson flowers.

For those of you following my experimentations with soil blocks, I think I have now got the perfect peat-free mix: three parts coir, two parts perlite, one part sieved loam and one part sieved garden compost. Mix thoroughly and wet until it is sticky and awkward to handle. Make the mix much wetter than seems practical.This makes lovely open but self-supporting blocks, and the roots quickly establish in it. I use 2in blocks for just about everything, and put them straight into seed trays which take 24 blocks each. No pots, no pricking out and, so far, healthy plants.

fields.headline: Where are they now?
fields.standfirst: Alf Lewis went for a walk - and never came back. His great-nephew  Jason Cowley has written a novel about a man who disappears and talked to the families of some of the 250,000 Britons who 'vanish' every year. Where do they go and why?
fields.trailText: Alf Lewis went for a walk - and never came back. His great-nephew Jason Cowley has written a novel about a man who disappears and talked to the families of some of the 250,000 Britons who 'vanish' every year. Where do they go and why?
fields.body:
On 29 June, Rev Michael Aikman will have been missing for exactly one year. Since he disappeared from his home in Whitstable, Kent, leaving behind his wife and two young sons, there have been no confirmed sightings of him, although his blue Ford Sierra was found abandoned a couple of days after he vanished on a clifftop at St Margaret's Bay, near Dover. He left behind a brief note in which he explained that having 'almost double-booked' two weddings, he was finding his job 'stressful' and was 'going away'.

There was nothing in the note to suggest that he was planning to kill himself or might walk out of his old life of clerical rigour and into a new one, perhaps living as someone else, somewhere else. Aikman was 35 when he left the family home, a resonant age, in the Biblical sense that he was halfway through the journey of his life.

He was certainly worrying about his job, but not unduly so, says his wife, Ruth. 'I remember going up to bed and the next morning coming down to find that he'd gone. He'd left the note, saying that he wanted to clear his head. I expected him to be back by lunchtime.' Twelve months on, she is waiting for him to return. 'The hardest thing is not knowing whether he will come back, whether he is living a new life, or whether he's dead. What has happened is so out of character for Michael. He really enjoyed his job and was much appreciated. I have no idea why he drove off that night.'

Ruth Aikman is sure that her husband is alive, not because of some mystical intuition, but simply because his body has never been found. 'I think the fact that he parked his car by St Margaret's cliff was merely a coincidence.' What of the suggestion by a Scottish medium that he is 'living among New Age travellers in the Highlands? (There have been unconfirmed sightings of him in Scotland.) 'I don't know about that,' she says. 'All I want is for him to get in touch. I miss him, the children miss him. They are always asking about him. The whole thing has been incredibly painful and upsetting.'

According to estimated figures from the National Missing Persons Bureau, as many as 250,000 people disappear in Britain every year. Many of them are teenagers and young adults, the ghostly-grey presences you see loitering in doorways and begging for 'spare change' in most major cities. But an increasing number of people are choosing to commit what in America has long been known as 'pseudocide', which means faking your own death so as to exchange one identity for another, an old life for a new.

In his bestseller, How to Disappear Completely and Never Be Found, Doug Richmond wackily offers a series of pointers on how to commit pseudocide, including how to evade police detection, arrange for a new driving licence, get a job and how to make it appear that you left the country before disappearing altogether.

One suspects that Richmond's eccentric book may have been adopted as a kind of self-help manual by Karl Hackett, who used the Paddington rail crash last September as an opportunity to fake his own death. What happened was macabre. On the day of the crash, someone called Lee Simm contacted the police to say that his close friend, Karl Hackett, was missing and believed to have been on the mangled train.

Soon afterwards, Brian Hackett, Karl's father, attended a memorial service for the dead of Paddington, believing that he had discovered the truth about his son, who he had not seen for more than a decade. But police became suspicious when Hackett's body was never recovered from the wreckage. Further investigation revealed that Karl Hackett was anything but dead. Not only had he made the call to the police himself but had long since assumed a new identity and the name of an old friend, Lee Simm, who committed suicide in the mid-1980s. He even had a driving licence in that name.

After being charged at Horseferry Road magistrates with wasting police time, Hackett said: 'People disappear every day - and some like me do it because they have had enough. You can change your name, move to a new area and start again. It tears your heart out to throw everything in the bin and start from scratch, but I've been living an honest and decent life. I've made mistakes in the past, but I don't think I should be punished for the rest of my life for what I did in my youth. This whole thing has been a nightmare, but I'm not going to start again. I'm going to stay Lee Simm.'

There is something strangely moving about the inner turmoil of Karl Hackett, about his longing to slip out of the robes of one identity and to start again as an 'honest and decent' new man, free from past 'mistakes'. Yet in this age of computerised records and databases, where every indiscretion, health blemish and motoring offence is relentlessly logged and used against us, how difficult it is to achieve the liberation Hackett sought. And how many of us long to achieve just that!

My own family has long been haunted by a disappearance. In my childhood, I recall whenever our extended family met up, at Christmas or on someone's birthday, how the conversation inevitably turned to Alfred Lewis, my mother's Uncle Alf, who was affectionately known as the 'wanderer'. He set out for a walk one winter weekend and never returned. He had gone, disappeared, trailing nothing but thin streams of gossip, rumour and accusation behind him. He was 25.

On more than one occasion, men - 'fantasists' my grandmother, Alf's sister, called them - walked into police stations and claimed to be him. They actually claimed to be my missing great-uncle. 'What drives people?' I heard my mother say. 'What makes them claim to be someone they're not?' It's a good question and one to which the case of Karl Hackett-Simm perhaps provides a partial answer.

There were many 'sightings' of Alf in the years after he vanished. The best of these was when a friend of my grandmother's, on holiday in Queensland, claimed to have seen him in a restaurant, with a woman and two young children. This story had a curious romance; we liked the idea of Uncle Alf ending up as a family man in sunny Australia, rather than as a corpse at the bottom of a pond or sleeping rough on the streets of London. It somehow fitted with his image as a wanderer.

I never met Uncle Alf - he disappeared long before I was born - and yet, in a curious sense, I feel close to him, feel I understand what made him run. For who, at some time, hasn't been preoccupied with dreams of leaving? Who hasn't longed to escape the tyranny of the self, the same self we're condemned to be. If only I could start again, we say, it might be different. But even if we started again, as Aikman may well have done, there is little guarantee that we would ever get what we wanted.

'Fairy tales and legends,' wrote Kierkegaard, 'often tell of a knight who suddenly catches sight of a rare bird of which he then sets off in pursuit, since in the beginning it seemed quite close, but then it flies off again until at last night falls. The knight is separated from his companions and lost in the wilderness in which he now finds himself.'

Is there a more compelling narrative archetype than the quest? From the Odyssey to many of the Biblical parables to The Divine Comedy to The Faerie Queen to Paul Auster's New York Trilogy, writers have been drawn again and again to the metaphor of life as one long, extended quest for an elu sive truth or meaning. The idea that true happiness is not of this world, that our lives are no more than a transient prelude to something purer and more permanent, is central to the quest, to the idea that a search for a missing person mimics, on a local level, the more generally universal search for a hidden God, the father who never shows Himself, or ever appears in our lives.

Georges Simenon, in his novel, Monsieur Monde Vanishes, writes well about this subject, in the parable of a wealthy man who decides to disappear from his life of ordered, affluent routine, leaving behind his wife and family in Paris. Without warning, he takes a train to Marseilles and strives to live intensely, on the margins of society - in nightclubs, underground bars and small hotels. For the first time in his adult life, he feels a liberation, stripped, as he is, of all responsibility.

But then, one evening, he sees his wife in a hotel. She seems wan and broken; she has become a morphine addict. Monde is moved by her plight and reveals himself to her. They return to Paris, Monde having become a man 'who had laid all ghosts, who had lost all shadows, and who looked you in the eyes with cold serenity'.

Monsieur Monde Vanishes is written from the perspective of the troubled hero. Which is a shame because what interests me as a writer is less the psychological trauma of the departed than the effect wilful disappearance has on those left behind, on Uncle Alf's baffled family, on the grieving wife and children of Michael Aikman.

When I was researching my first novel, Unknown Pleasures, which is about a young man's obsessive search for the truth about his father who disappears without warning, I spoke to a Reverend Roger Taylor, whose father went missing when he was a baby in the 1920s. Harry Bertram Taylor was a struggling salesman from Wigan who, in Roger's resonant phrase, 'went wrong'. 'He couldn't handle money,' he adds, by way of explanation.

In 1922, Taylor senior, after the breakdown of his marriage, sailed to New York, from where the family received occasional letters. 'But these tailed off and my mother eventually had him legally presumed dead in 1926, in order to qualify for a widow's pension.' So that was that, Taylor thought, until, in early middle age, he became increasingly oppressed by the presence of his father's always-absence, by something mysteriously incomplete and unexplained in his life. So began his search for Taylor which, in turn, became a more general search for the secrets of himself and his own identity.

Taylor travelled to New York, constructing a narrative of his father's American adventure: that from 1922 to 1926, he'd sung in a church choir in Manhattan, after which he'd joined the chorus of Frederic Austin's revival of The Beggar's Opera.

When the tour ended in 1928, Harry Taylor found temporary work in Ontario, where his sister lived. 'But in 1929, he went wrong again with the firm that had given him a job,' his son says. 'Money was always my father's great weakness. Fortuitously for him, about now, the opera company came together again and played in Toronto. They re-engaged my father, who now changed his name to Thomas. When investigators came looking for him, he was concealed and spirited over the border. There the trail goes cold.'

Not a day passes but Taylor, who is in his seventies, thinks about his father and wonders what became of him. He understands that searching for a missing person, particularly one so lost to the past, is like committing yourself to the following of a grail, a grail which offers no possibility of resolution but merely lies before you like a long, flat road winding endlessly through open countryside to nowhere in particular.

'It's the endless not knowing that troubles you most,' he says. 'Did he die during the Depression? How did he originally get into America? What happened to him once he changed his name and assumed a new identity?'

The searcher, he knows, can never stop posing questions. What is it like being condemned to live without a sense of an ending? Well, the problem for Taylor, as for Ruth Aikman, is the lack of resolution in his own and in his father's life. A disappearance, unlike a death, frustrates, fascinates and tantalises precisely because of its lack of closure. The missing person becomes a creation of memory and imagination, both outside time and time's victim. There is never a chance definitively to mourn; everything and nothing might have happened to that absent person. He or she might be dead or alive; rich or poor; fulfilled or regretful.

It is the person left behind who suffers most, who grapples with feelings of incompleteness, inadequacy, with Ruth Aikman's deep perplexity of 'not knowing'. But, as she says, when there is no body there is 'always hope', even if, as in her case, as in the cases of so many of the disappeared, the cruel passing of time may render any hope forlorn.

 The National Missing Persons Bureau can be contacted on freephone 0500 700 700.

Jason Cowley's novel, Unknown Pleasures, is published by Faber & Faber (£9.99) on 19 June. To order a copy for £7.99 plus 99p p&p call Observer CultureShop on 0800 3168 171

The knight is separated from his companions and lost in the wilderness in which he now finds himself.' Is there a more compelling narrative archetype than the quest? From the Odyssey to many of the Biblical parables to The Divine Comedy to The Faerie Queen to Paul Auster's New York Trilogy, writers have been drawn again and again to the metaphor of life as one long, extended quest for an elu sive truth or meaning. The idea that true happiness is not of this world, that our lives are no more than a transient prelude to something purer and more permanent, is central to the quest, to the idea that a search for a missing person mimics, on a local level, the more generally universal search for a hidden God, the father who never shows Himself, or ever appears in our lives. Georges Simenon, in his novel, Monsieur Monde Vanishes, writes well about this subject, in the parable of a wealthy man who decides to disappear from his life of ordered, affluent routine, leaving behind his wife and family in Paris. Without warning, he takes a train to Marseilles and strives to live intensely, on the margins of society - in nightclubs, underground bars and small hotels. For the first time in his adult life, he feels a liberation, stripped, as he is, of all responsibility. But then, one evening, he sees his wife in a hotel. She seems wan and broken; she has become a morphine addict. Monde is moved by her plight and reveals himself to her. They return to Paris, Monde having become a man 'who had laid all ghosts, who had lost all shadows, and who looked you in the eyes with cold serenity'. Monsieur Monde Vanishes is written from the perspective of the troubled hero. Which is a shame because what interests me as a writer is less the psychological trauma of the departed than the effect wilful disappearance has on those left behind, on Uncle Alf's baffled family, on the grieving wife and children of Michael Aikman. When I was researching my first novel, Unknown Pleasures, which is about a young man's obsessive search for the truth about his father who disappears without warning, I spoke to a Reverend Roger Taylor, whose father went missing when he was a baby in the 1920s. Harry Bertram Taylor was a struggling salesman from Wigan who, in Roger's resonant phrase, 'went wrong'. 'He couldn't handle money,' he adds, by way of explanation. In 1922, Taylor senior, after the breakdown of his marriage, sailed to New York, from where the family received occasional letters. 'But these tailed off and my mother eventually had him legally presumed dead in 1926, in order to qualify for a widow's pension.' So that was that, Taylor thought, until, in early middle age, he became increasingly oppressed by the presence of his father's always-absence, by something mysteriously incomplete and unexplained in his life. So began his search for Taylor which, in turn, became a more general search for the secrets of himself and his own identity. Taylor travelled to New York, constructing a narrative of his father's American adventure: that from 1922 to 1926, he'd sung in a church choir in Manhattan, after which he'd joined the chorus of Frederic Austin's revival of The Beggar's Opera. When the tour ended in 1928, Harry Taylor found temporary work in Ontario, where his sister lived. 'But in 1929, he went wrong again with the firm that had given him a job,' his son says. 'Money was always my father's great weakness. Fortuitously for him, about now, the opera company came together again and played in Toronto. They re-engaged my father, who now changed his name to Thomas. When investigators came looking for him, he was concealed and spirited over the border. There the trail goes cold.' Not a day passes but Taylor, who is in his seventies, thinks about his father and wonders what became of him. He understands that searching for a missing person, particularly one so lost to the past, is like committing yourself to the following of a grail, a grail which offers no possibility of resolution but merely lies before you like a long, flat road winding endlessly through open countryside to nowhere in particular. 'It's the endless not knowing that troubles you most,' he says. 'Did he die during the Depression? How did he originally get into America? What happened to him once he changed his name and assumed a new identity?' The searcher, he knows, can never stop posing questions. What is it like being condemned to live without a sense of an ending? Well, the problem for Taylor, as for Ruth Aikman, is the lack of resolution in his own and in his father's life. A disappearance, unlike a death, frustrates, fascinates and tantalises precisely because of its lack of closure. The missing person becomes a creation of memory and imagination, both outside time and time's victim. There is never a chance definitively to mourn; everything and nothing might have happened to that absent person. He or she might be dead or alive; rich or poor; fulfilled or regretful. It is the person left behind who suffers most, who grapples with feelings of incompleteness, inadequacy, with Ruth Aikman's deep perplexity of 'not knowing'. But, as she says, when there is no body there is 'always hope', even if, as in her case, as in the cases of so many of the disappeared, the cruel passing of time may render any hope forlorn.  The National Missing Persons Bureau can be contacted on freephone 0500 700 700. Jason Cowley's novel, Unknown Pleasures, is published by Faber & Faber (£9.99) on 19 June. To order a copy for £7.99 plus 99p p&p call Observer CultureShop on 0800 3168 171

fields.headline: Inns of historic interest
fields.trailText: The Ostrich at Colnbrook, Berkshire (01753 682 628), on the High Street, is one of England's oldest pubs, dating from 1106. King John stayed there on his way to Runnymede to sign the Magna Carta. The pub also found fame in the first-ever crime novel, The Clothier of Reading , written by Thomas Delaney in 1598, about a serial-killer landlord. You may be relieved to learn that The Ostrich no longer offers accommodation. It does, however, provide good food and hand-pumped ales such as Courage Best and Marston's Pedigree.

The Ostrich at Colnbrook, Berkshire (01753 682 628), on the High Street, is one of England's oldest pubs, dating from 1106. King John stayed there on his way to Runnymede to sign the Magna Carta. The pub also found fame in the first-ever crime novel, The Clothier of Reading , written by Thomas Delaney in 1598, about a serial-killer landlord. You may be relieved to learn that The Ostrich no longer offers accommodation. It does, however, provide good food and hand-pumped ales such as Courage Best and Marston's Pedigree.

The part-Georgian, part-Victorian Noel Arms in Chipping Campden, Gloucestershire (01386 840 317), on the B4035, is where Charles II is believed to have stayed after the Battle of Worcester in 1651. The Noel Arms, first known as The George, was once a centre of the wool trade, where merchants stayed and carried out their business deals in the Assembly Room. The beers on offer include Bass and Hook Norton. Accommodation is available.

The George Hotel in Dorchester-on-Thames, Oxfordshire (01865 340 404), on the High Street, is linked to the abbey church across the road, founded in 635 by St Birinus. The church survived Henry Tudor's dissolution, as did The George, built in 1450 as a hospice. The estate was bought in 1540 by Richard Bewfforest, who turned the hospice into an inn. It flourished as a resting place for travellers at an important crossing place on the Thames, and did good business when Dorchester became a garrison for troops during the Civil War. Today it has retained its galleried frontage and beamed interior. Accommodation is available, the ales come from Brakspear in Henley, and there is excellent bar food.

Among the attractions at The Bell in Horndon-on-the-Hill, Essex (01375 642 463), on the B1007, off the A13, is a 95-year-old collection of hot cross buns. The inn is 500 years old and its timbers, from wrecked ships, are even older. The village was at the crossroads of routes between London and the Essex ports, and the wool towns of East Anglia and the Channel ports. During the reign of Queen Mary, a local landlord who refused to convert to Catholicism was burned at the stake in the yard. The Bell has won acclaim for the quality of its food, an extensive wine list and such excellent ales as Draught Bass and Fuller's London Pride. Accommodation is available.

The Black Swan in York (01904 686 911), on Peaseholme Green, was built in the 14th century as a townhouse for the rich merchant Bowes family, ancestors of the Queen Mother. It became an inn in the 18th century and General Wolfe, who captured Quebec from the French, was born there in 1727. The inn was carefully restored in the 30s: don't miss the oak panelling and moulded ceilings, along with good bar food and fine ales, including Draught Bass, Fuller's London Pride and Yorkshire Terrier. Accommodation is available.

All of these pubs appear in Ted Bruning's new book, Historic Inns of England (Prion, £14.99)

fields.headline: Six of the best...
fields.standfirst: ...places to go for healthy Sunday fare
fields.trailText: ...places to go for healthy Sunday fare
fields.body:
It's all very well to imagine that lazy summer Sundays are best suited to a bit of salad for lunch and the afternoon spent lolling in a deckchair, but the reality is that omnivores crave a little more on their day of rest. The solution in our house is to splash out on a joint of really good meat, large enough to leave in the oven for an hour or so without having to fiddle with it too much.

By 'really good' I mean organic, a criterion fulfilled admirably by Meat Matters (freephone 08080 067 426), an organic meat company that offers free, refrigerated delivery in London and along the M25 (£5 elsewhere) with no minimum order. Its lamb (£13.85 per kg) comes from crossbreeds whose origins, Welsh mountain lambs and Suffolk ewes, reflect their split lifestyle. During the spring they feed on the Pembrokeshire pastures; spring lamb, at £17 per kg, has a mild taste. In July, the lambs are taken up into the mountains, where the heather and herbs growing on the hillsides impart a particular flavour to the meat. Similarly, Meat Matters' chickens (£6.60 per kg) benefit from an idyllic life at Springfield Poultry in Herefordshire, grazing in an apple orchard and snacking on organic feed.

Visitors to the windy shores of north Norfolk can enjoy summer roasts for lunch any day of the week at Morston Hall, Morston, Holt (01263 741 041). Chef-patron Galton Blackiston cooks rack of pork ('The important thing is to get a good crackling') and serves it with what he calls a 'niçoise garnish' of grilled peppers, olives, aubergines and courgettes. Morston Hall steered clear of veal for a couple of years, but has bowed to new demand this season, with loin of veal pot-roasted over vegetables to keep it medium rare.

If you can't be bothered to scrape potatoes when you could be sipping Pimms, then proper bread may be the answer. Award-winning bakers De Gustibus, which supplies most of the delicatessens in Oxford (as well as County Delicacies, 35 St Mary's Butts, Reading, 0118 957 4653, and Umberto's, 9 Greyhound Walk, Thame, 01844 214 040), has just opened a new shop at 4 Southwark Street, London SE1 (020 7407 3625). Despite a complete absence of fanfare, the venue has been overwhelmed with customers eager to carry home one of the famous sourdoughs. Interestingly, 80 per cent of De Gustibus's sales in Oxfordshire is accounted for by ciabatta. It's this barely-cooked bread that, cut in half, makes a marvellous substitute for soft baps if you're thinking of a roast meat sandwich. A Mediterranean version of this simple feast is served in the shop. Called a muffuletta, it features salsa made with capers, peppers, chilli, oregano, garlic, tomatoes, olive oil and lemon juice, plus cold cuts, and benefits from being pressed under a weight for an hour or more, so that the juice soaks in.

In Ross-on-Wye, a different ethic prevails, at least among the 'discerning stomachs' that comprise Trevor Rogers's customers at Oat Cuisine, a vegetarian café and shop on Broad Street (01989 566271). Rogers bakes his own bread in variations according to whim. If it's Friday, it must be sesame and oatmeal, 'for its cholesterol-lowering effects'. He used to make deliveries in the local area, but found that people preferred to come into the shop to make their own selection from the enormous range of salads. The coleslaw walks out of the door 'even when it's minus 20 outside', which may be evidence that some people are pleased not to cook whatever the weather.

fields.headline: Clear skin, from scratch
fields.standfirst: A daily diet of simple, unprocessed food could be the key to alleviating the nightmare of eczema in children
fields.trailText: A daily diet of simple, unprocessed food could be the key to alleviating the nightmare of eczema in children.
fields.body:
I had mixed feelings about summer as a child: on the one hand, I loved the sunny days, but on the other I felt for a friend, who found wearing summer clothes agonising. Like thousands of other youngsters, she'd suffered from eczema virtually from birth, and not only were her limbs badly scarred with rough, red vesicles, but the presence of pollen in the atmosphere irritated her condition even more. One of the main problems with eczema is that the irritation that it inflicts makes sufferers scratch, thereby breaking the skin's surface and causing it to bleed and weep, and perhaps also to become infected. Although we tried to keep her scratching down to a minimum by helping to wrap her in soft cotton bandages, eczema nevertheless made her childhood summers insufferable. I wish we'd known then what I know now, however; there is a lot we could have done to relieve some of her discomfort.

Eczema is often caused by the body's intolerance of - or oversensitivity or allergic reaction to - certain foods, the most common being cow's milk and eggs. If your child suffers from eczema, it is therefore worth avoiding these foods for a couple of weeks to see whether the symptoms improve. In the case of cow's milk, exclude all of its forms and sources, including yogurt, cream, butter, skimmed-milk powder and foods containing lactose, casein and whey (you'll need to check food labels carefully). You should also avoid all egg derivatives, such as lecithin or ovalbumin (and remember that pasta and cakes can contain these ingredients).

Since a few children have an adverse reaction to lactose (the sugar that is contained in mammalian milks), it's best to avoid all forms of milk, including goat's or sheep's milk, during the food trial. It may be that non-bovine dairy products can be safely included in the diet later, but I recommend that you seek advice from a dietician first. If you ascertain that your child has a milk sensitivity, there shouldn't be any long-term nutritional implications if they take an alternative source of calcium.

Another common irritant is chicken, which is relatively easy to avoid. A more difficult challenge, however, is presented by azo dyes, including tartrazine, sunset yellow and amaranth, which are labelled with E numbers ranging from 100 to 180. These colourings are used in such manufactured foods as fruit juices, sweets, biscuits and ice cream. I recommend that you exclude all processed foods from your child's diet, including some that may be labelled 'natural', 'wholesome' or 'nutritious' - all of which are unregulated descriptions. Although excluding all processed foods from your child's diet may become a nightmare in practical terms (and you will need to tell their school and friends' parents that they shouldn't be given processed foods), it is worth persevering with.

As with the majority of adverse food reactions, quantity plays a significant role. Some children can eat a small amount of a dairy product or the odd, additive-containing snack without their eczema being triggered. If this is the case, treating them to such a food once a week may make life more manageable and enjoyable for everyone, without aggravating their skin condition. The systems of some of the children I treat, however, are so sensitive that one mouthful of the trigger food causes their skin to erupt. In addition, a stressed gut is more likely to absorb a greater amount of the allergen, so if your child is upset, make sure that they stick to 'safe' foods.

If, having followed the trigger-food avoidance diet, nothing changes in the condition of certain children, I initiate an exclusion, or 'few-food' diet for a couple of weeks. This involves restricting their diet to a handful of what are generally regarded as the least allergenic foods, such as turkey, cabbage, potatoes, bananas, tap water, and little else. This is an extremely hard regime to follow (although we increase the range of foods once we've calmed the skin down) and should only be conducted under the guidance of a paediatric dietician. Yet such stringent efforts can reap appreciable rewards. One little boy came to me covered in oozing, raw vesicles; just three weeks into the few-food diet, it took a close look to see the patches of rough skin. He now sleeps much better, too, which means that everyone in the family is happier.

Another nutritional strategy that I've successfully tried with older children is encouraging them to eat oily fish, such as mackerel, tuna, pilchards and salmon. These fish contain omega 3 and omega 6 fatty acids, which alter the body's biochemistry, in particular changing the inflammatory reaction that aggravates eczema. If you give them a portion of oily fish a day when their skin is at its worst (three times a week represents a good all-round skin-food dose during less critical periods), it is likely that they will experience substantial relief. If the omega fatty acids are to be effective, the child's intake of saturated animal fats - such as butter and cream - should be kept to a minimum. Sardines on toast, a tuna-based pasta sauce or some naturally smoked mackerel pté spread on a slice of warmed ciabatta are all good dishes to start with.

Above all, try not to make food and eating a huge issue. Although you should ideally give your child a 'safe' alternative drink or snack so they don't feel discriminated against, if they occasionally consume something that triggers their eczema, don't make a big deal of it. Make sure they drink plenty of water to flush the trigger food out of their system and tell them that they're less likely to have problems with their skin if they don't eat the 'bad' food. If you blow the issue up out of proportion, they're much more likely to binge on the forbidden food in secret, resulting in a far more destructive scenario in which you'll never know what they're eating or drinking.

 Jane Clarke is a state-registered dietician and author of the Bodyfoods series of books

fields.headline: Second opinion
fields.standfirst: Is Lasik, the new laser surgery for shortsightedness, the miracle cure we've been led to believe?
fields.trailText: Is Lasik, the new laser surgery for shortsightedness, the miracle cure we've been led to believe?
fields.body:
YES Dr Manek Patel, eye surgeon at Optimax, Britain's largest group of eye-care centres

Throughout the world, people are switching to this new technique because it is quick, relatively painless and reliable. It takes 5 minutes per eye, and improves your sight immediately. People are able to dispense with glasses and contact lenses, and it changes their lives - they might want it for diving or sport. When Richard Branson had Lasik, he was back at work the next day.

The old laser eye surgery technique, PRK, is painful, unpredictable, slow and people don't want it. Lasik is painless and a very polular option. In the US, 90 per cent of laser eye surgery is Lasik and around 1m patients have so far undergone treatment. It will probably be a similar story here in Britain within the next 5 years.

Many ophthalmologists have had it done. I was at a conference recently and no one there was aware of any problems. It is well established and trusted. It is true that no one knows what the long-term effects, say after 10 years, are. But what can we do? Are we supposed to use it on 10 patients and then wait 10 years for the results? Science doesn't work like that.

NO John Marshall, professor of ophthalmology at St Thomas's Hospital, London

This surgery is immensely successful and large numbers of patients are very, very happy. Still, I wouldn't have Lasik myself. fields.headline: Born with HIV
fields.standfirst: Thanks to combination therapy, HIV babies are now reaching adolescence. Wendy Moore reports on the pressures they face
fields.trailText: Thanks to combination therapy, HIV babies are now reaching adolescence. Wendy Moore reports on the pressures they face
fields.body:
Matthew is just like any other teenager. He likes drinking with his mates, messing about on his computer and going out with his girlfriend. He is the typical adolescent bundle of contradictions: one minute cocksure, defiant and mature beyond his years, the next vulnerable, desperate to conform and childishly naive. But on top of the emotional roller coaster faced by any 17-year-old, Matthew - not his real name - is growing up with a secret that haunts him every day. He is HIV positive.

Matthew was born with HIV, transmitted from his mother, who, along with his brother, died of Aids when Matthew was small. Nobody expected Matthew to survive long, either. But his fighting spirit - and new drugs developed in the last few years to keep the virus in check - has helped him confound the medics. Now he is possibly the longest-surviving youngster born with HIV in the UK.

It is not a position he wants to shout about. 'If you have HIV, you just want to live your life as normal,' he says. 'I would like to be able to go out there and just live my life without a secret.' But the stigma of HIV makes that impossible.

Many other youngsters live with the same secret. Children who were never expected to become teenagers are now presenting health professionals with dilemmas they thought they would never face. About 600 children have been born with HIV in the UK since the early 80s, and nearly 450 survive today, according to the Public Health Laboratory Service. Most, but not all, were born to parents of African origin. The statistics show that 69 youngsters have reached their teens, although some have been lost to official records.

Many people will remember the emotive pictures of Princess Diana in the 80s holding tiny babies with Aids. Now that some of those youngsters are reaching adolescence, the 'sympathy vote', as one HIV expert puts it, has evaporated. Most lead double lives, unable to reveal their diagnosis to friends, teachers or families.

Matthew has known he was HIV positive since he was four. He was told by social workers after his mother died, and was placed with foster parents. Both his mother and father - whom he does not see - came from Africa. Outwardly, he looks like any other healthy youngster. So far, the virus has never made him ill, although he must take care to avoid infections that could turn serious, and he is on almost permanent medication. Yet from early on, Matthew learned to keep quiet about his diagnosis.

'When I was young, I understood it had to be a secret. My mother [his foster mother] made this clear as I was growing up,' he says. All through school, he could not tell classmates. Now at sixth-form college, only his best friend and - since December - his girlfriend, know. 'I would love to walk out there with a big banner and say, "I am HIV positive," and for people to just walk on by,' Matthew says. He feels he cannot 'because for many people, HIV means death. You have HIV, you will die. You have HIV, you are dirty. These are the common themes.'

The only place Matthew can talk openly is at the London youth group Teen Spirit, a weekly club for children with HIV and those whose parents are HIV positive. Run by the charity Body and Soul, next door to the Great Ormond Street Hospital, where Matthew attends the family HIV clinic, it opened three years ago and offers the only meeting space in the UK for teenagers to talk about their HIV status. About 40 youngsters attend each week to make friends, play music, eat and chat. Others keep in touch by telephone and email.

Behind Teen Spirit's doors, Matthew is a role model for others struggling through adolescence with HIV. He can unburden himself. Outside, he's terrified of being found out. It took him months to tell his girlfriend. 'I had to think about the consequences,' he explains. 'If she was to tell her mum or other people, then I would have to move away.' Luckily, she has stood by him. It is his first serious relationship and, again leading the way for other teenagers, Matthew is having to grapple with the deadly serious business of safe sex. Teen Spirit members are well versed in the dangers of passing on HIV through unprotected sex. 'I know my responsibilities,' says Matthew. 'I would not take risks. I wouldn't be able to live with myself.'

Matthew wants to go to university, become an interior designer and eventually have children, although he knows he may have to adopt, rather than risk passing on HIV. It is quite possible, according to HIV experts, that Matthew may realise his ambitions. There is no reason why he should not live into his twenties and perhaps beyond, says Margaret Clapson, HIV clinical nurse specialist at the clinic Matthew attends. She helps treat 125 children, aged from two months to 17 years. Nearly 40 are over 10 years old and some - like Matthew - are into their teens. But this success brings with it a host of new difficulties for hospital staff.

Children born with HIV are surviving longer than doctors expected because of the development in 1996 of combination therapy, which blends several drugs into a powerful cocktail to repress the virus. The drugs regime is rigid and may mean taking 15 tablets daily at set times. Lapses mean the virus can become resistant to those drugs and so a new combination has to be tried. Persuading teenagers to stick to such routines is a major headache.

'This is a problem that, five years ago, we didn't think we would have,' says Clapson. 'We didn't think these children would live past 15.' Many teenagers are loath to take medicines they have to hide or that interfere with their social lives, she says. One 15-year-old is refusing medication despite having nearly died. For Matthew, who has also let his regime lapse, the next combination will be the last. If that fails, he is reliant on scientists developing new medicines. Other teenagers have not even been told they are HIV positive. They may be told they have to take medicines to stay well, but their parents feel unable to tell them their diagnosis, despite staff's efforts to persuade them. At 16, staff will do it anyway because, under the Children Act, they have a right to know.

'I think it is wrong for any 16-year-old not to know,' says Clapson. As well as explaining the importance of taking medication, they may well be sexually active, she explains. She recently had to tell one 16-year-old boy who - like some others - had already guessed. The clinic offers counselling to help youngsters cope with their diagnosis, and also with bereavement. Many have lost families to Aids or are helping to care for sick parents.

Still, for many teenagers, one of the worst aspects of HIV is the stigma. Matthew and other teenagers attending Great Ormond Street Hospital have refused to transfer to adult care. Rightly or wrongly, at 17 they do not want to attend a clinic along with openly gay men, drug abusers and prostitutes, says Clapson. So far, adult services have agreed to come to them.

At St Mary's Hospital, west London, doctors and nurses are treating about 120 HIV-positive children, including 15 teenagers. Consultant paediatrician Dr Gareth Tudor-Williams fully expects the number of teenagers to grow. 'Any of the children who have survived the first 10 years are very likely to survive the next 10,' he says. 'With the right treatment, many of these kids will survive into their twenties.'

Ensuring teenagers stick to treatment is a big problem. 'It is a struggle to persuade teenagers that they are not invincible and that they must carry on with the medicines,' he says. Hospital staff try to organise drug regimes so that youngsters do not have to take tablets during school, when they would have to explain them to classmates, and negotiate with schools to explain a child's long absences. For these teenagers, too, HIV carries a powerful stigma.

But one young person is determined to break down the HIV taboo. Clint Walters contracted HIV when he was 17, in just his second gay relationship. Appalled at the lack of help for young people, last year he decided to launch Health Initiatives for Youth UK - based on similar groups in the US - to provide support for other HIV-positive youngsters, aged 15 to 27. Now 20, he spends much of his time visiting schools to talk openly about having HIV in the hope that other teenagers may learn from his mistake. 'There are a lot of young people out there who are not educated and not aware, and they are finding themselves in the same position I was in,' he says.

Discussion of HIV during sex education in schools is minimal, he says, and teachers are often scared to talk explicitly about safe sex. He fears ignorance is fuelling increased infection. 'I was 17. I never knew anyone with HIV. I never knew anything about it,' he says. Now he wants to stand up and be counted. 'Yes, I am positive. I am not ashamed of it.'

HIV: the facts

* Many people now think that HIV is no longer a problem in the UK, yet the virus is as much a threat as ever. Last year saw the highest number of new infections for a decade - 2,457 diagnoses - and for the first time most were through heterosexual contact. Public health experts are concerned that ignorance and complacency could soon unleash an explosion in HIV infection.

* More than 40,000 people have been infected with HIV in the UK since first reports in the 1980s. Of these, 41 per cent have developed Aids and nearly a quarter have died.

* Up to this year, 614 children have been born with HIV and 441 survive. A total of 69 are now believed to be teenagers.

* All pregnant women are now offered antenatal testing for HIV. If the test is positive, taking anti-viral medication can reduce the chance of passing HIV to the baby. Avoiding breast-feeding reduces risk further.

* Combination therapy is delaying the onset of AIDS. Many people with HIV are living healthy lives.

* Recent studies show that risky sexual behaviour is increasing, particularly among gay men. There have been huge increases in such STDs as gonorrhoea - cases rose by 26 to 30 per cent last year, especially among the young. These figures, along with the highest teenage-pregnancy rate in Europe, suggest that the safe-sex message is not getting through.

Contacts

Health Initiatives for Youth UK 020 8830 4547 or www.hify-uk.com
