fields.headline: Watch it...
fields.standfirst: ...the International Indian Film Awards
fields.trailText: ...the International Indian Film Awards
fields.body:
The Indian film industry is the second largest in the world. It grosses an annual turnover of more than $200m internationally, sells 600 billion tickets worldwide and produces at least 800 movies a year.

The International Indian Film Awards: it's a mouthful and a paradox. But the words 'International Indian' perhaps best describe lovers of Indian movies, who are scattered in worship all over the world. It is fitting, then, that next Saturday's event is being held at the Greenwich Millennium Dome, the place where East meets West. The glitterati of Mumbai (those who still term the industry 'Bollywood', take note) will be honouring their icons in the first-ever IIFA ceremony.

There should be plenty to see, not least the Skyscape arena, the largest entertainment venue in the UK. Then there will be Aishwarya Rai, Miss World 1994, who is nominated twice for a Best Actress award.

Ms Rai is also the proud holder of the title 'most beautiful woman of the century' in a Times of India poll. If she wins, she may be crowned by the current Miss World, Yukta Mookhey, who is 20 years old, and the inimitable Amitabh Bachan, whose tight white 'hero' trousers are the stuff of legend for young Indians everywhere.

Tickets for the arena are by invitation only, but IIFA will be telecast live across Britain, India and the world (by Sony Global Network) and simultaneously webcast on catchuslive.com, an interactive website, complete with online voting and a karaoke function for all your slushy English and Indian favourites.

The singular nature of Indian movies - addictive three-hour epics - will be celebrated through categories such as Best Playback Singer, and Best Actor/Actress in a Negative Role (in other words, villain), while the intense glamour will be mirrored by the industry stars, who are all guaranteed to step out in dazzling and flamboyant fashion.
 ITV will show highlights of the International Indian Film Awards next Sunday at 4pm

fields.headline: The way we live now
fields.standfirst: Drug wars: Celexa vs Prozac - the selling of happiness
fields.trailText: Drug wars: Celexa vs Prozac - the selling of happiness.
fields.body:
America can be happy again. Or so Howard Solomon promised recently from the stage of the San Diego convention centre, surrounded by drug sales reps. Solomon is chief executive of Forest Laboratories, US licensee manufacturer of Celexa, son of Prozac, the hottest antidepressant on the market in the States.

He read from a text the heartbreaking recollections of an author who experienced clinical depression. 'Every morning and night, I look at the pills in my hand,' wrote the anonymous depressive, 'and sometimes they seem like writing; hieroglyphics saying that the future may be all right and I owe it to myself to live on and see'. What Solomon didn't say was that the 'author' was his son, whose book on battling depression is slated for publication this year.

In less than two years since it won the federal go-ahead to be unleashed on the depressives of America, Celexa has already claimed a 13 per cent share in the $6.3bn market for this kind of pill, the worried rivals being Prozac, Zoloft and Paxil. But all these antidepressants are the same. The Medical Newsletter, a non-profit making journal that monitors new drugs, found 'no advantage' in Celexa over its rivals. According to research, they all do the same thing: they improve the mood of around 65 per cent of the patients who take them.

Many observers say that Celexa has done what it has done, not because of chemistry but because of hard sell. Good marketing by pushy reps. Reps who hold up the lines to see the doctor, handing out fistfuls of samples and freebies. Reps who have nearly doubled in number in the past five years from 36,000 working across America in 1994 to 68,000 last year. Solomon admitted as much in his San Diego pep-speech. He told the reps that Celexa, a Danish product from the Lundbeck company, was going to be 'the most promoted antidepressant, with the most successful sales force in the country'. It won him a standing ovation.

The pharmaceutical industry has become one of the most successful industries in America over the past five years. But for all their outlandish profits, America's drug companies are preparing for war. It has been a strange time for them: a few weeks ago, a rare executive order from President Clinton ended years of bitter wrangling and obliged five manufacturers of the principal medicines against HIV infection to make their drugs more cheaply available throughout sub-Saharan Africa. The companies, citing copyright law, had engaged the government of South Africa in legal action to stop its production of generic copies at lower costs. The order leaves the drug companies facing what they see as a multi-front attack from politicians, business leaders, lobbying groups and angry consumers.

Clinton and Gore are pushing for Medicare coverage of prescription drugs that the industry fears would result in price controls. In an election year, polls show voters are getting wise to the fact that they pay higher prices for prescription drugs than in Canada or Europe. Insurers and employers are joining the fray, and the protest.

This crossroads will only propel the companies shift away from research and development of drugs towards emphasis on 'cosmetic' medicines; fat-blocking drugs, Viagra for sex, and the lucrative but competitive antidepressants. And it will only intensify the counterassault from the drug companies ever-inflated advertising budgets and platoons of sales reps.

Forest's job was to convince doctors that Celexa was free of risky side effects and a select few doctors were paid to test the drug on five patients each. Then followed the blizzard of gifts bearing the company logo. Celexa was pitched as 'cleaner' than Prozac, which was dismissed as making some patients jittery. Celexa could interact better with other drugs, since it leaves the patient's system more quickly than its rivals. Above all, Celexa was less likely to cause sexual dysfunction and make you fat. There was even an experiment, in which a group of men who ejaculate prematurely were able to extend their time from an average of 22 seconds to a full 44 seconds. By the day of the San Diego launch, 15,000 doctors had prescribed the drug. Paxil and Prozac began the counterattack. Men on Paxil could extend their time before ejaculation even longer - 170 seconds.

Meanwhile, Elizabeth Shin had started studying at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. She was under treatment for depression by the college doctors. They were trying out a new drug, Celexa, and were ready to evaluate her three Tuesdays ago. By then, Elizabeth was in the severe burns unit of Massachusetts General Hospital, having set herself ablaze. She died four days later.

No one can sensibly suggest that Celexa was responsible for Elizabeth's death. She had, said her friends, spiralled downwards after the breakup of a romance; she had ambition to the point of excess; she lacked confidence and was nonsensically worried about her weight. But the Celexa, say her parents, was prescribed to replace sleeping pills, and it may, they allege, have had 'negative effects'. Peter Breggin, a psychiatrist and co-author of a heretical book entitled Your Drug May Be Your Problem , says that 'unexpected, out-of-character suicides have been associated with newer antidepressants. Bad effects can happen immediately, any supposed good effects can take at least four weeks.'

What the hell. The Celexa hard sell is on. Don't worry, America, be happy.

Solomon is chief executive of Forest Laboratories, US licensee manufacturer of Celexa, son of Prozac, the hottest antidepressant on the market in the States. He read from a text the heartbreaking recollections of an author who experienced clinical depression. 'Every morning and night, I look at the pills in my hand,' wrote the anonymous depressive, 'and sometimes they seem like writing; hieroglyphics saying that the future may be all right and I owe it to myself to live on and see'. What Solomon didn't say was that the 'author' was his son, whose book on battling depression is slated for publication this year. In less than two years since it won the federal go-ahead to be unleashed on the depressives of America, Celexa has already claimed a 13 per cent share in the $6.3bn market for this kind of pill, the worried rivals being Prozac, Zoloft and Paxil. But all these antidepressants are the same. The Medical Newsletter, a non-profit making journal that monitors new drugs, found 'no advantage' in Celexa over its rivals. According to research, they all do the same thing: they improve the mood of around 65 per cent of the patients who take them. Many observers say that Celexa has done what it has done, not because of chemistry but because of hard sell. Good marketing by pushy reps. Reps who hold up the lines to see the doctor, handing out fistfuls of samples and freebies. Reps who have nearly doubled in number in the past five years from 36,000 working across America in 1994 to 68,000 last year. Solomon admitted as much in his San Diego pep-speech. He told the reps that Celexa, a Danish product from the Lundbeck company, was going to be 'the most promoted antidepressant, with the most successful sales force in the country'. It won him a standing ovation. The pharmaceutical industry has become one of the most successful industries in America over the past five years. But for all their outlandish profits, America's drug companies are preparing for war. It has been a strange time for them: a few weeks ago, a rare executive order from President Clinton ended years of bitter wrangling and obliged five manufacturers of the principal medicines against HIV infection to make their drugs more cheaply available throughout sub-Saharan Africa. The companies, citing copyright law, had engaged the government of South Africa in legal action to stop its production of generic copies at lower costs. The order leaves the drug companies facing what they see as a multi-front attack from politicians, business leaders, lobbying groups and angry consumers. Clinton and Gore are pushing for Medicare coverage of prescription drugs that the industry fears would result in price controls. In an election year, polls show voters are getting wise to the fact that they pay higher prices for prescription drugs than in Canada or Europe. Insurers and employers are joining the fray, and the protest. This crossroads will only propel the companies shift away from research and development of drugs towards emphasis on 'cosmetic' medicines; fat-blocking drugs, Viagra for sex, and the lucrative but competitive antidepressants. And it will only intensify the counterassault from the drug companies ever-inflated advertising budgets and platoons of sales reps. Forest's job was to convince doctors that Celexa was free of risky side effects and a select few doctors were paid to test the drug on five patients each. Then followed the blizzard of gifts bearing the company logo. Celexa was pitched as 'cleaner' than Prozac, which was dismissed as making some patients jittery. Celexa could interact better with other drugs, since it leaves the patient's system more quickly than its rivals. Above all, Celexa was less likely to cause sexual dysfunction and make you fat. There was even an experiment, in which a group of men who ejaculate prematurely were able to extend their time from an average of 22 seconds to a full 44 seconds. By the day of the San Diego launch, 15,000 doctors had prescribed the drug. Paxil and Prozac began the counterattack. Men on Paxil could extend their time before ejaculation even longer - 170 seconds. Meanwhile, Elizabeth Shin had started studying at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. She was under treatment for depression by the college doctors. They were trying out a new drug, Celexa, and were ready to evaluate her three Tuesdays ago. By then, Elizabeth was in the severe burns unit of Massachusetts General Hospital, having set herself ablaze. She died four days later. No one can sensibly suggest that Celexa was responsible for Elizabeth's death. She had, said her friends, spiralled downwards after the breakup of a romance; she had ambition to the point of excess; she lacked confidence and was nonsensically worried about her weight. But the Celexa, say her parents, was prescribed to replace sleeping pills, and it may, they allege, have had 'negative effects'. Peter Breggin, a psychiatrist and co-author of a heretical book entitled Your Drug May Be Your Problem , says that 'unexpected, out-of-character suicides have been associated with newer antidepressants. Bad effects can happen immediately, any supposed good effects can take at least four weeks.' What the hell. The Celexa hard sell is on. Don't worry, America, be happy.

fields.headline: A Kentish Town killing
fields.standfirst: Despite 200 witnesses, a two-year investigation and a £21,000 reward, the police seem no nearer to catching Ronald Hinkson's killer. Andrew Anthony chronicles the conspiracy of silence and fear surrounding the murder of his old school friend
fields.trailText: At 20st and 6ft 3in, Robert Hinkson was never likely to be victim, but two years ago he was stabbed to death. And despite 200 witnesses, a two-year investigation and a £21,000 reward, the police seem no nearer to catching his killer. Andrew Anthony chronicles the conspiracy of silence and fear surrounding the murder of his old school friend
fields.body:
In the school photograph that was never taken, Ronald Hinkson does not stand out as a potential murder victim. Even allowing that there is no physiognomical protection against random violence, Ronald's good-naturedly mischievous expression was nothing if not disarming. He always looked somehow as if he got the joke and was prepared to share it with you.

Group photographs from childhood contain a curiously magical quality. The viewer is instinctively drawn to look for clues in the subjects' faces, as if the secret of fate is hidden in their half-formed features. The school Ronald and I attended was too poorly organised to arrange a massed sitting for the camera, so all that is left to be studied are snapshots from evanescent memory.

Among the school's 1,200 or so kids, I now know, was a senior government policy adviser, at least one murderer, an MP, an armed robber, numerous small-time crooks, and hundreds of blamelessly invisible members of society. Most, as far as I'm concerned, have disappeared, erased from recollection; a small minority are vague outlines, an assemblage of odd details and indistinct flashbacks; then there are 20 or 30 who remain vividly present.

Ronald is part of the latter group, although he was a couple of years below me, which normally means below the radar of recall. A large boy, who grew up to be an imposingly large man, he had a sly grin and a casual stroll - what we used to call a 'bowl' - that were enough to set him apart.

He lived a couple of streets from me, went to the same primary and secondary schools, and had a brother in my tutor group. I often saw Ronald around the neighbourhood and we'd usually exchange a smile or an acknowledgment, but we were never friends, just as we were never enemies. For some reason, which I never thought about, I liked him. And I was not alone. Over 1,000 people packed into a small church in Gospel Oak, north London, for his memorial service.

When I read that he'd been killed, I felt a muted kind of sadness. I thought about his family and their loss, but I suppose I thought not unselfishly about myself, about the unseen proximity of death and the tragedy of meeting it in your thirties. And I thought about the aching smallness of it all. Ronald was murdered half a mile from his home, and less than a mile from our old school. He was in a bar on a night out with his friends.

That was back in September 1997. I didn't follow the story very closely. After the initial shock, I stored the glumness away in a mental file that was beginning to overflow with bad news from my childhood neighbourhood: murders, drug wars, imprisoned friends, a cousin who'd become a junkie and petty criminal, another who'd committed suicide, stabbings, beatings and muggings - contemporary street life. All of this in the semi-gentrified area of Kentish Town.

While I didn't exactly forget about Ron, I let him become another grim anecdote to share with people I'd run into from my teenage days. Then, just before Christmas, I was driving through Kentish Town when I saw a huge poster draped over a railway bridge. Emblazoned on it was an image of Ronald, not the amused kid in the imaginary school photo, but a grown man, a father it turned out, a pensive adult with plans and responsibilities. The message read:

You know who killed Ronald Hinkson

You know where his killer is

You saw or heard what happened

You could secure justice for Ron's family

Underneath there was a Crimestoppers number to call and a police inquiry line. The message also included an offer of a reward of £21,000. The wording was disturbing, more like an accusation aimed at unnamed locals than a communal appeal for information. The whole effect was immediately striking, not least because it made me realise that more than two years later the man responsible for Ronald's death had still not been found. How could someone be murdered in front of hundreds of witnesses and his killer get away? And why? Was he just in the wrong place at the wrong time or was the wrong of a deeper, more threatening nature?

On the night he was slain, Ronald was taking part in a celebration that he and some of his friends had made an irregular social ritual. About once every couple of months, five or so friends would meet up for an evening to mark one of the group members' birthdays. Having become the father of a baby son, Reuben, earlier that year, Ronald seldom went out to pubs or clubs.

He worked most nights as a graphic designer. On his last day alive, he spent the morning and afternoon laying a floor in the home he shared with his son's mother, Tracy Hill, in Camden Town. At that small flat, I visited Tracy one afternoon this spring.

A resolute young woman with strong dark hair and a handsome face made unjustly sad, she spoke of Ronald and herself as a couple who were arriving at the good part of their lives. 'Having Reuben was the best thing that ever happened to us.'

Photographs of Reuben decorated the walls and there was a striking shot of Ronald in sharp profile with close-shaved head, wearing a white T-shirt. 'He was terrible at DIY,' Tracy recalled. 'I usually did it all. But he was proud of the floor and my parents came to see it.' At around 5pm on 13 September 1997, Ronald and Tracy went to a neighbour's party for an hour or so until Ronald's friend Joel called by to pick him up. 'They left at about 6.30,' she remembered. Then, without pausing, she turned the everyday banality of that detail into crushing finality. 'And that was the last time I saw him.'

Sometimes, especially after a spate of violent crime, there is a ready impression, picked up from press and TV reports, that people are murdered all the time. The reality is less dramatic and much less dangerous. Statistically, in any given year, there is a 1-in-80,000 chance of suffering a violent death. And the probability of being murdered by a stranger is significantly smaller, moving towards the 1-in-a-million mark. That figure begins to rise again, however, if you live in the inner city and you are male and black and under 35, like Ronald. But it's still negligible. In other words, neither Ronald nor Tracy had any reason to expect that evening to be his last.

After collecting a couple of other friends, the group headed for the Vulture's Perch, a renovated pub in Kentish Town Road, the high street, that is already beginning to look ancient. The shops change and the pubs change - or at least their names do - but Kentish Town Road has remained stubbornly the same for as long as I can remember.

There were now six friends - Joel, Gary, Richard, Nicholas, Gary and Ronald. Not that they would have been concerned with the symmetry, nor perhaps even noticed it, but three were black and three were white. Kentish Town is not immune to racism and there are pubs in which few black faces are seen. On the whole, though, it is an unaffectedly integrated area: Ronald's mix of friends was not in the least conspicuous.

Richard had turned 30 and they were drinking champagne. By all accounts, it was a lively evening, and the group joshed with anyone who came within its orbit. When closing time arrived, they were keen to continue the celebrations. There were few options after 11pm. The choice was between the after-hours places in Little Cyprus, in Camden Town, or Barzaar, a late-night bar on Camden Road. Ronald said he knew a doorman at Barzaar. As they left the Vulture's, Ronald put a phone call in to Tracy to say he would be late.

If the high street has stayed much the same over the years, the rest of Kentish Town has undergone huge changes. In the 70s and 80s, middle-class families moved into those parts of the neighbourhood whose Victorian housing had survived Camden Council's year-zero plan to replace terraced streets with council estates. In the 80s, and increasingly in the 90s, the drug economy replaced some of the traditional employment, such as the railways and Camden Council, which had off-loaded workers. Between 1992 and 1997, drug trafficking offences in the borough went up five-fold. It's a cycle that has been repeated in inner cities all over Britain. The only difference with Camden is that the results sit cheek-by-jowl with the equally dramatic influx of monied professionals.

The effects have been particularly extreme in one corner of the borough, the area surrounding Queen's Crescent market, which is almost landlocked by railway lines and road-blocks. Walking with an old school friend around Queen's Crescent, where Ron and I grew up, I was surprised at the number of places he pointed out that are now drug-dealing houses. He told me about an old neighbour and schoolmate of ours who was jailed a couple of years ago for the murder of another local in what was described as a disagreement over drugs. Before the case came to trial, the main witness, who refused police protection, was also shot dead. Jesus, I thought, that's the kind of thing that happens in The Sopranos, not Kentish Town.

'Queen's Crescent has become a no-go area,' said another former resident, some weeks later, as we drove through. A few days previously, a 58-year-old woman had been sexually assaulted in Marsden Street, in the heart of the neighbourhood. Two days later a man was found dead, one block away, on the corner of Rhyl Street - my old street - and Malden Road. At first, people were saying he'd been shot. But a post-mortem found that he had died as a result of an epileptic fit. Yet rumours as to the cause of death persisted when it emerged that the previous day he'd been set upon by a gang of youths. It seemed instructive that the first assumption locals jumped to was that the poor man had been gunned down.

My school friend, a giant hulk of a man, and not an easily intimidated character, was anxious to remain anonymous. According to him, the main dealers were linked in various ways to a north London crime family that has gained near legendary status for its ruthlessness. The family's name has been connected with countless murders as well as a multi-million pound drug empire.

On the surface, Queen's Crescent makes for an unconvincing no-go area. For a start, a quarter of the Crescent itself is made up of much sought-after houses that sell for around £500,000. It's about three stops on the bus from Hampstead Heath: Keats House, expensive tea shops, Michael Foot.

But it's also a street market that, like many places of its kind, is eerily deserted come evening, except for teenagers hanging uselessly on street corners, and boozed-up blokes stumbling between pubs. On a Saturday morning it can seem like a fictional community, a multi-generational Anglo-Irish-Caribbean tribe of gossips. On a Saturday night, it's not somewhere you'd choose to walk alone. A couple of years ago a man was shot as he left an off-licence in Queen's Crescent. The gunmen said only two words before he fired: 'You're dead.'

'Ronald knew people from Kentish Town who had got into trouble,' said Tracy. 'He didn't want to follow that path. He did things the right way. He had a real sense of justice.'

On the map, the short distance Ronald moved from his family home in Queen's Crescent to his own place near Camden Square appears trivial. But it separated him from an inward-looking street culture that was turning nasty. His brother Michael told me that he thought Ronald, having left the Crescent, had not fully grasped the consequences of the changes that had taken place in the neighbourhood.

'Not long before he died,' recalled Michael, 'he tried to stop a fight between two old friends. They were arguing over drugs. I told him: "Don't get caught in the middle. Things have got serious. These people use knives."'

Ron's mother, Daisy Gobay, lives two streets from the Crescent in Grafton Terrace, a wide street with neat little houses in which Karl Marx once lived. Nearly three years ago, she received a call on a Saturday night that had already turned into a Sunday morning. It was from Tracy, telling her that Ronald was in the Royal Free Hospital in Hampstead.

She went immediately, but her son had already been pronounced dead on arrival at 1.30am. Daisy's compact home is filled with photographs of Ronald. A generous-hearted woman who is easily moved to laughter, she is not a mournful character by nature. But when she talks of her son, the sense of a mother's loss is chokingly obvious. 'I know I would say this because I am his mother,' she explained, 'but he was such a nice bloke.'

Her daughter Julie, a legal representative with a diligent manner, carefully went over the information she had gathered from the police, Ronald's friends and talk on the street. But, to her own and her mother's continuing frustration, that information is severely limited. The police have been very protective of their evidence. And for a variety of reasons, Ronald's friends have only partial stories to tell. That leaves street talk.

That Ronald's killer is free is of course distressing, but the confusion that surrounds the murder itself is an additional emotional burden for Ronald's family, and one that is unlikely to be lifted without a trial.

At around the time Ronald and his friends arrived at Barzaar, they were met by two other men, a couple of black friends from south London. 'This is where the big blur comes in,' Julie told me.

When the police arrived at Barzaar, they found one man unconscious outside the bar, another dazed and regaining consciousness and a third bleeding profusely under the railway bridge less than a hundred yards away. All of them were black. More than two hundred other customers were either milling around or streaming away. The only person to be arrested at the scene was the dazed man, who, on coming to, began shouting.

DCI John Sweeney is now in charge of the Hinkson murder inquiry. When I visited him at the murder squad's headquarters in Hendon, he played down the significance of Ronald's friend's arrest. 'It would have been for his own protection,' he explained.

DCI Sweeney is an engaging 40-year-old. There is little trace of pedantic Scotland Yard formality in his manner. He's open, without giving anything away, and not overly defensive, although he never goes so far as to accept police failings or incompetence.

'What I find surprising,' said Julie, 'is that when the police arrived, the 200 people on site all walked away. Then we had this pathetic appeals for witnesses to come forward the following week.'

She says the police did not even interview Ronald's friends that night and that it was only after Daisy made one of them go along to the station the next day that the police agreed to speak to him about what he'd seen.

'Other than the stabbing,' counters DCI Sweeney, 'the scene would have looked very much like any other Saturday-night fight when the police arrived. It's impossible to hold that many people. The first priority is preserving life, then the scene of the crime.'

In her experience, Julie had found the police were more than capable of containing that number of people. 'I've been to black clubs and there has been trouble and the police lock you in and you have to say who you are to leave.'

Here is the unspoken issue that has dogged, without ever quite dominating, the case: race. Ronald and the four other black men who made up his party were possibly the only black people in Barzaar that night. Two of them were badly beaten up and the the third, Ronald, was murdered.

It was not unheard of for black people to go to the bar, but they were the exception. The image Barzaar had was of a hang-out for white toughs, men who either wanted to look the part of the well-connected hardnut - so-called plastic gangsters - or who were well-connected hardnuts, the real thing.

'That's where the chaps went,' one local told me, meaning the 'faces', the kind of people who boasted a reputation and, not infrequently, a record. Ernest James, chair of Camden's licensing committee, described the bar as a 'safe place to be for a certain class of person' and somewhere that attracted a 'working-class racist element'.

The first officer to lead the inquiry, chief inspector David Brown, discounted the notion of a racially motivated crime pretty much from the outset. Daisy, in particular, was disappointed by what she saw as a reluctance on the police's behalf to explore the question of race, particularly as none of the three white men in Ronald's party was injured or, indeed, attacked.

'If they [the police] had found a blonde girl stabbed to death,' Julie suggested, 'I think they would have reacted more quickly and more effectively.'

DCI Brown was replaced last year by DCI Sweeney. Before he left the case, his investigation was taken to task by the local newspaper, Camden New Journal, which voiced some of Daisy's complaints. As tensions grew between the Hinksons and the police, the findings of the Stephen Lawrence inquiry were making headlines. The Metropolitan Police were held responsible for 'institutional racism' - a charge which the botched initial investigation of the murder of Michael Menson, the black musician who was set alight by a gang, served only to underline. Brown sued the newspaper, which settled out of court.

At the time the Journal ran its piece, the case papers had been sent for review to Assistant Commissioner John Grieve, the head of the Racial and Violent Crimes Task Force. It was Grieve's men who relabelled Menson's 'suicide' a homicide and went on to bring his killers to justice.

DCI Sweeney says that Grieve has maintained a watching brief on Ronald's murder, and has been on hand for advice if needed, but that essentially the crime is not being treated as racial, although, he adds, the police are sensitive to any issues connected to race. Grieve helped launch a new appeal for evidence in the case when he unveiled the railway bridge poster to the press.

Relations between the Hinksons and the police have improved since Sweeney's appointment. One of the recommendations of the Lawrence inquiry that has since become standard practice was the assignment of a family liaison officer. DC Curtis visits Daisy and Julie once a week, as well as seeing Tracy Hill. For Tracy, being able to talk to someone has made a difference. 'The liaison officer is fantastic,' she told me.

Daisy and Julie are also appreciative but impatient at what they see as the slow progress of the inquiry. 'He [the liaison officer] tells us what he can but he can't tell us anything,' Julie said. 'But he tries. There is access now.'

Daisy has begun to worry that no one will be arrested for Ronald's murder. Yet DCI Sweeney remains confident that, as with most murders, this one will be solved and the police will get their man. But who killed Ronald and why? And where is he now?

Once inside Barzaar, Ronald and his friends continued the party. It was the first time Ron had ever been to the bar, despite living nearby. His brother felt that it was not the kind of place a black man should have gone unless he was certain of what to expect. But the atmosphere was heady and Ronald was in high spirits. As his sister put it to me: 'Apart from the murder, it was a good night.'

At a point just after 12.30am, an argument started. Accounts differ as to its origin because some of Ronald's friends say they were in the lavatory or were out of ear shot. But none would speak to me.

From witness statements, DCI Sweeney was able to tell me that a dispute apparently arose between one of Ronald's party and a man who may or may not have been working at the bar. It seems that Ronald's friend might have been smoking a joint. 'Ronald doesn't take drugs,' said his brother, using the present tense of bereavement.

'My son's a big fella,' Daisy said. 'I've got a feeling one of his friends was getting mistreated and he stepped in.'

According to some testaments, Ronald intervened as a mediator, attempting to calm the situation. The man then said something to Ronald and thrust a glass in his face. Whatever happened next was viciously quick and hauntingly beyond reason. Ronald and two of his friends were pushed outside and followed by a large gang of men. The two friends were knocked out. They think they were attacked with baseball bats. Ronald was stabbed 10 times. Two of the wounds - in the neck and the heart - were fatal.

No one reported hearing any racial slurs or insults and thus the police informed Daisy early on in the investigation that they did not think racism came into play. 'But how can you stab someone 10 times without hatred?' she asked me. Standing 6ft 2in and weighing nearly 20 stone, Ronald was indeed a big man. More than that, he was a big black man, and in our society that makes many people nervous. Ronald himself knew how he could be wrongly perceived.

'Ron was aware that people would judge him on sight,' said Tracy, who is white. 'But he never accepted that. He would mix with anyone and, because of that, he rarely came up against racism.'

What Ronald came up against that night may not have been racism, but it was, as his mother rightly said, a demonstration of hatred. His life bleeding away, Ronald staggered along Camden Road, in the direction of his flat, where Tracy and their baby son were asleep. He was less than 10 minutes walk from home when he collapsed under the railway bridge from which his poster would later hang.

Tracy was woken by one of Ronald's distraught friends. 'It's serious,' he said. 'I'm not joking.' He gave her the hospital's number.

'I knew as soon as I spoke to them that he was dead. They asked me to describe him. They wouldn't tell me anything, but said they'd send a police car.' The car never came.

At no time was a 999 call to the police made from the bar. The police arrived, and promptly, because they were summoned by a nearby businessman who saw the commotion. Barzaar did not react in the manner which inspired confidence in its role as a licensed premise. The bar's owner was determined not to let the murder interfere with usual business. Julie explained her family's feelings on the matter.

'The club had to be sealed off for a while, but within nine days they were up and trading again as normal. I saw that as a huge insult. Ronald's body was kept as evidence.'

'For nine weeks I couldn't bury my child,' Daisy added.

The Hinksons were sickened. They mounted a vigil outside Barzaar and put together a petition to have it closed down. As they stood in front of the bar collecting signatures, they began to hear a rumour repeatedly mentioned. Barzaar, people said, was frequented by the same north London crime family my friend from Queen's Crescent had told me controlled the local drug market.

The police have consistently denied that there is any evidence linking the family to the events that night at Barzaar. DCI Sweeney was firm if not adamant. 'People say they are behind everything,' he said. 'In almost every murder that takes place in north London their name is mentioned.'

In a sense, the family have become modern-day bogeymen. Ever since they came to public attention, they have been accused of a daunting number of crimes and have been associated with a still-larger number of 'legitimate' money-laundering operations. That their name does not exist on any papers concerning the pubs, clubs and mini-cab firms they supposedly run does little to undermine the rumours. Indeed, their absence from the documentation, say their accusers, serves as proof of their backdoor involvement.

But very few people really know. And those who do, don't talk. What is certain, though, is that the man who is the sole suspect in Ronald's murder disappeared shortly after it was committed. Around Kentish Town his name is openly discussed. They say he is abroad. There were reports a while back that he was in Spain.

The apparent speed and ease with which the suspect vanished has only added weight to the speculation that he was aided by organised criminals. That suspicion is further deepened by his continuing ability to remain beyond the reach of the law.

And, perhaps most notably, the £21,000 reward on offer seems to have had next to no effect in pinpointing the murderer's whereabouts. The money was painstakingly raised by the Hinksons, including Ronald's stepfather Ozzie Gobay, from local people without at first any help from the police.

The family was offended by the police attitude towards the reward, a slight which compounded the communication problems between the two. Then the police had a change of heart and donated some money.

'Up until this case,' DCI Sweeney informed me, 'the Met had never contributed to a reward. This case made history.'

The only source from which the family pointedly refused to accept money was the owner of Barzaar. The bar was eventually closed when it was refused a new licence by Camden Council, but before that decision was made the Hinksons' picket had effectively prevented Barzaar from opening again as a workable concern.

However, the bar's former landlord is still in business in the area. He runs a pub in a leafy neighbourhood that, while less than a mile from the spot where Ronald was killed, seems a world away from gangsters and weapons and drug dealers. I visited the well-known pub to speak to the man, to ask him what he knew of the murder, but the bar staff denied all knowledge of him. I checked with various sources, all of whom confirmed that I had the right man and the right place, and phoned the pub again a number of times. The same story. Never heard of him, said his staff, don't know who you're talking about.

For whatever reasons, he clearly did not want to talk to me. In fact, very few people wanted to talk to me. Even Ronald's friends avoided my calls.

'I suspect,' said DCI Sweeney, 'there are people that we have spoken to who haven't told us all they know.'

Although a number of men took part in the attack on the two men who were beaten unconscious on the night of Ronald's murder, the police are not pursuing them on related charges. The decision has been made that it would not be in the public interest.

At the same time, the police are unwilling to release any more information regarding the suspect for whom they're looking. They feel that to do so might jeopardise a trial. So no photos of the man the police want to interview will be issued. And, furthermore, the police say they do not know where he is.

The rest is silence. Officially. Of course, people talk all the time. They talk about how the area of Ronald's and my childhood, of Queen's Crescent, has declined, about how bad the heroin and crack problem has become, about the guns and the gangsters, about how you can't trust anyone, and about how they want to move away.

Ronald Hinkson had moved away. He was not a troublemaker but a peacemaker. He lived an unremarkable life in many ways. What marked him out was his willingness to stand up and intervene when he saw something he thought was wrong. He was killed because he tried to smooth a situation in which a friend was under threat for smoking a cannabis joint, in an environment that was warped by hard drugs and cowed by the criminals that supplied them.

The last time I drove through Kentish Town, I noticed that Ronald's poster had been taken down. His photo is gone but, if his memory means anything, its appeal remains: who will stand up for Ronald?

He lived a couple of streets from me, went to the same primary and secondary schools, and had a brother in my tutor group. I often saw Ronald around the neighbourhood and we'd usually exchange a smile or an acknowledgment, but we were never friends, just as we were never enemies. For some reason, which I never thought about, I liked him. And I was not alone. Over 1,000 people packed into a small church in Gospel Oak, north London, for his memorial service. When I read that he'd been killed, I felt a muted kind of sadness. I thought about his family and their loss, but I suppose I thought not unselfishly about myself, about the unseen proximity of death and the tragedy of meeting it in your thirties. And I thought about the aching smallness of it all. Ronald was murdered half a mile from his home, and less than a mile from our old school. He was in a bar on a night out with his friends. That was back in September 1997. I didn't follow the story very closely. After the initial shock, I stored the glumness away in a mental file that was beginning to overflow with bad news from my childhood neighbourhood: murders, drug wars, imprisoned friends, a cousin who'd become a junkie and petty criminal, another who'd committed suicide, stabbings, beatings and muggings - contemporary street life. All of this in the semi-gentrified area of Kentish Town. While I didn't exactly forget about Ron, I let him become another grim anecdote to share with people I'd run into from my teenage days. Then, just before Christmas, I was driving through Kentish Town when I saw a huge poster draped over a railway bridge. Emblazoned on it was an image of Ronald, not the amused kid in the imaginary school photo, but a grown man, a father it turned out, a pensive adult with plans and responsibilities. The message read: You know who killed Ronald Hinkson You know where his killer is You saw or heard what happened You could secure justice for Ron's family Underneath there was a Crimestoppers number to call and a police inquiry line. The message also included an offer of a reward of £21,000. The wording was disturbing, more like an accusation aimed at unnamed locals than a communal appeal for information. The whole effect was immediately striking, not least because it made me realise that more than two years later the man responsible for Ronald's death had still not been found. How could someone be murdered in front of hundreds of witnesses and his killer get away? And why? Was he just in the wrong place at the wrong time or was the wrong of a deeper, more threatening nature? On the night he was slain, Ronald was taking part in a celebration that he and some of his friends had made an irregular social ritual. About once every couple of months, five or so friends would meet up for an evening to mark one of the group members' birthdays. Having become the father of a baby son, Reuben, earlier that year, Ronald seldom went out to pubs or clubs. He worked most nights as a graphic designer. On his last day alive, he spent the morning and afternoon laying a floor in the home he shared with his son's mother, Tracy Hill, in Camden Town. At that small flat, I visited Tracy one afternoon this spring. A resolute young woman with strong dark hair and a handsome face made unjustly sad, she spoke of Ronald and herself as a couple who were arriving at the good part of their lives. 'Having Reuben was the best thing that ever happened to us.' Photographs of Reuben decorated the walls and there was a striking shot of Ronald in sharp profile with close-shaved head, wearing a white T-shirt. 'He was terrible at DIY,' Tracy recalled. 'I usually did it all. But he was proud of the floor and my parents came to see it.' At around 5pm on 13 September 1997, Ronald and Tracy went to a neighbour's party for an hour or so until Ronald's friend Joel called by to pick him up. 'They left at about 6.30,' she remembered. Then, without pausing, she turned the everyday banality of that detail into crushing finality. 'And that was the last time I saw him.' Sometimes, especially after a spate of violent crime, there is a ready impression, picked up from press and TV reports, that people are murdered all the time. The reality is less dramatic and much less dangerous. Statistically, in any given year, there is a 1-in-80,000 chance of suffering a violent death. And the probability of being murdered by a stranger is significantly smaller, moving towards the 1-in-a-million mark. That figure begins to rise again, however, if you live in the inner city and you are male and black and under 35, like Ronald. But it's still negligible. In other words, neither Ronald nor Tracy had any reason to expect that evening to be his last. After collecting a couple of other friends, the group headed for the Vulture's Perch, a renovated pub in Kentish Town Road, the high street, that is already beginning to look ancient. The shops change and the pubs change - or at least their names do - but Kentish Town Road has remained stubbornly the same for as long as I can remember. There were now six friends - Joel, Gary, Richard, Nicholas, Gary and Ronald. Not that they would have been concerned with the symmetry, nor perhaps even noticed it, but three were black and three were white. Kentish Town is not immune to racism and there are pubs in which few black faces are seen. On the whole, though, it is an unaffectedly integrated area: Ronald's mix of friends was not in the least conspicuous. Richard had turned 30 and they were drinking champagne. By all accounts, it was a lively evening, and the group joshed with anyone who came within its orbit. When closing time arrived, they were keen to continue the celebrations. There were few options after 11pm. The choice was between the after-hours places in Little Cyprus, in Camden Town, or Barzaar, a late-night bar on Camden Road. Ronald said he knew a doorman at Barzaar. As they left the Vulture's, Ronald put a phone call in to Tracy to say he would be late. If the high street has stayed much the same over the years, the rest of Kentish Town has undergone huge changes. In the 70s and 80s, middle-class families moved into those parts of the neighbourhood whose Victorian housing had survived Camden Council's year-zero plan to replace terraced streets with council estates. In the 80s, and increasingly in the 90s, the drug economy replaced some of the traditional employment, such as the railways and Camden Council, which had off-loaded workers. Between 1992 and 1997, drug trafficking offences in the borough went up five-fold. It's a cycle that has been repeated in inner cities all over Britain. The only difference with Camden is that the results sit cheek-by-jowl with the equally dramatic influx of monied professionals. The effects have been particularly extreme in one corner of the borough, the area surrounding Queen's Crescent market, which is almost landlocked by railway lines and road-blocks. Walking with an old school friend around Queen's Crescent, where Ron and I grew up, I was surprised at the number of places he pointed out that are now drug-dealing houses. He told me about an old neighbour and schoolmate of ours who was jailed a couple of years ago for the murder of another local in what was described as a disagreement over drugs. Before the case came to trial, the main witness, who refused police protection, was also shot dead. Jesus, I thought, that's the kind of thing that happens in The Sopranos, not Kentish Town. 'Queen's Crescent has become a no-go area,' said another former resident, some weeks later, as we drove through. A few days previously, a 58-year-old woman had been sexually assaulted in Marsden Street, in the heart of the neighbourhood. Two days later a man was found dead, one block away, on the corner of Rhyl Street - my old street - and Malden Road. At first, people were saying he'd been shot. But a post-mortem found that he had died as a result of an epileptic fit. Yet rumours as to the cause of death persisted when it emerged that the previous day he'd been set upon by a gang of youths. It seemed instructive that the first assumption locals jumped to was that the poor man had been gunned down. My school friend, a giant hulk of a man, and not an easily intimidated character, was anxious to remain anonymous. According to him, the main dealers were linked in various ways to a north London crime family that has gained near legendary status for its ruthlessness. The family's name has been connected with countless murders as well as a multi-million pound drug empire. On the surface, Queen's Crescent makes for an unconvincing no-go area. For a start, a quarter of the Crescent itself is made up of much sought-after houses that sell for around £500,000. It's about three stops on the bus from Hampstead Heath: Keats House, expensive tea shops, Michael Foot. But it's also a street market that, like many places of its kind, is eerily deserted come evening, except for teenagers hanging uselessly on street corners, and boozed-up blokes stumbling between pubs. On a Saturday morning it can seem like a fictional community, a multi-generational Anglo-Irish-Caribbean tribe of gossips. On a Saturday night, it's not somewhere you'd choose to walk alone. A couple of years ago a man was shot as he left an off-licence in Queen's Crescent. The gunmen said only two words before he fired: 'You're dead.' 'Ronald knew people from Kentish Town who had got into trouble,' said Tracy. 'He didn't want to follow that path. He did things the right way. He had a real sense of justice.' On the map, the short distance Ronald moved from his family home in Queen's Crescent to his own place near Camden Square appears trivial. But it separated him from an inward-looking street culture that was turning nasty. His brother Michael told me that he thought Ronald, having left the Crescent, had not fully grasped the consequences of the changes that had taken place in the neighbourhood. 'Not long before he died,' recalled Michael, 'he tried to stop a fight between two old friends. They were arguing over drugs. I told him: "Don't get caught in the middle. Things have got serious. These people use knives."' Ron's mother, Daisy Gobay, lives two streets from the Crescent in Grafton Terrace, a wide street with neat little houses in which Karl Marx once lived. Nearly three years ago, she received a call on a Saturday night that had already turned into a Sunday morning. It was from Tracy, telling her that Ronald was in the Royal Free Hospital in Hampstead. She went immediately, but her son had already been pronounced dead on arrival at 1.30am. Daisy's compact home is filled with photographs of Ronald. A generous-hearted woman who is easily moved to laughter, she is not a mournful character by nature. But when she talks of her son, the sense of a mother's loss is chokingly obvious. 'I know I would say this because I am his mother,' she explained, 'but he was such a nice bloke.' Her daughter Julie, a legal representative with a diligent manner, carefully went over the information she had gathered from the police, Ronald's friends and talk on the street. But, to her own and her mother's continuing frustration, that information is severely limited. The police have been very protective of their evidence. And for a variety of reasons, Ronald's friends have only partial stories to tell. That leaves street talk. That Ronald's killer is free is of course distressing, but the confusion that surrounds the murder itself is an additional emotional burden for Ronald's family, and one that is unlikely to be lifted without a trial. At around the time Ronald and his friends arrived at Barzaar, they were met by two other men, a couple of black friends from south London. 'This is where the big blur comes in,' Julie told me. When the police arrived at Barzaar, they found one man unconscious outside the bar, another dazed and regaining consciousness and a third bleeding profusely under the railway bridge less than a hundred yards away. All of them were black. More than two hundred other customers were either milling around or streaming away. The only person to be arrested at the scene was the dazed man, who, on coming to, began shouting. DCI John Sweeney is now in charge of the Hinkson murder inquiry. When I visited him at the murder squad's headquarters in Hendon, he played down the significance of Ronald's friend's arrest. 'It would have been for his own protection,' he explained. DCI Sweeney is an engaging 40-year-old. There is little trace of pedantic Scotland Yard formality in his manner. He's open, without giving anything away, and not overly defensive, although he never goes so far as to accept police failings or incompetence. 'What I find surprising,' said Julie, 'is that when the police arrived, the 200 people on site all walked away. Then we had this pathetic appeals for witnesses to come forward the following week.' She says the police did not even interview Ronald's friends that night and that it was only after Daisy made one of them go along to the station the next day that the police agreed to speak to him about what he'd seen. 'Other than the stabbing,' counters DCI Sweeney, 'the scene would have looked very much like any other Saturday-night fight when the police arrived. It's impossible to hold that many people. The first priority is preserving life, then the scene of the crime.' In her experience, Julie had found the police were more than capable of containing that number of people. 'I've been to black clubs and there has been trouble and the police lock you in and you have to say who you are to leave.' Here is the unspoken issue that has dogged, without ever quite dominating, the case: race. Ronald and the four other black men who made up his party were possibly the only black people in Barzaar that night. Two of them were badly beaten up and the the third, Ronald, was murdered. It was not unheard of for black people to go to the bar, but they were the exception. The image Barzaar had was of a hang-out for white toughs, men who either wanted to look the part of the well-connected hardnut - so-called plastic gangsters - or who were well-connected hardnuts, the real thing. 'That's where the chaps went,' one local told me, meaning the 'faces', the kind of people who boasted a reputation and, not infrequently, a record. Ernest James, chair of Camden's licensing committee, described the bar as a 'safe place to be for a certain class of person' and somewhere that attracted a 'working-class racist element'. The first officer to lead the inquiry, chief inspector David Brown, discounted the notion of a racially motivated crime pretty much from the outset. Daisy, in particular, was disappointed by what she saw as a reluctance on the police's behalf to explore the question of race, particularly as none of the three white men in Ronald's party was injured or, indeed, attacked. 'If they [the police] had found a blonde girl stabbed to death,' Julie suggested, 'I think they would have reacted more quickly and more effectively.' DCI Brown was replaced last year by DCI Sweeney. Before he left the case, his investigation was taken to task by the local newspaper, Camden New Journal, which voiced some of Daisy's complaints. As tensions grew between the Hinksons and the police, the findings of the Stephen Lawrence inquiry were making headlines. The Metropolitan Police were held responsible for 'institutional racism' - a charge which the botched initial investigation of the murder of Michael Menson, the black musician who was set alight by a gang, served only to underline. Brown sued the newspaper, which settled out of court. At the time the Journal ran its piece, the case papers had been sent for review to Assistant Commissioner John Grieve, the head of the Racial and Violent Crimes Task Force. It was Grieve's men who relabelled Menson's 'suicide' a homicide and went on to bring his killers to justice. DCI Sweeney says that Grieve has maintained a watching brief on Ronald's murder, and has been on hand for advice if needed, but that essentially the crime is not being treated as racial, although, he adds, the police are sensitive to any issues connected to race. Grieve helped launch a new appeal for evidence in the case when he unveiled the railway bridge poster to the press. Relations between the Hinksons and the police have improved since Sweeney's appointment. One of the recommendations of the Lawrence inquiry that has since become standard practice was the assignment of a family liaison officer. DC Curtis visits Daisy and Julie once a week, as well as seeing Tracy Hill. For Tracy, being able to talk to someone has made a difference. 'The liaison officer is fantastic,' she told me. Daisy and Julie are also appreciative but impatient at what they see as the slow progress of the inquiry. 'He [the liaison officer] tells us what he can but he can't tell us anything,' Julie said. 'But he tries. There is access now.' Daisy has begun to worry that no one will be arrested for Ronald's murder. Yet DCI Sweeney remains confident that, as with most murders, this one will be solved and the police will get their man. But who killed Ronald and why? And where is he now? Once inside Barzaar, Ronald and his friends continued the party. It was the first time Ron had ever been to the bar, despite living nearby. His brother felt that it was not the kind of place a black man should have gone unless he was certain of what to expect. But the atmosphere was heady and Ronald was in high spirits. As his sister put it to me: 'Apart from the murder, it was a good night.' At a point just after 12.30am, an argument started. Accounts differ as to its origin because some of Ronald's friends say they were in the lavatory or were out of ear shot. But none would speak to me. From witness statements, DCI Sweeney was able to tell me that a dispute apparently arose between one of Ronald's party and a man who may or may not have been working at the bar. It seems that Ronald's friend might have been smoking a joint. 'Ronald doesn't take drugs,' said his brother, using the present tense of bereavement. 'My son's a big fella,' Daisy said. 'I've got a feeling one of his friends was getting mistreated and he stepped in.' According to some testaments, Ronald intervened as a mediator, attempting to calm the situation. The man then said something to Ronald and thrust a glass in his face. Whatever happened next was viciously quick and hauntingly beyond reason. Ronald and two of his friends were pushed outside and followed by a large gang of men. The two friends were knocked out. They think they were attacked with baseball bats. Ronald was stabbed 10 times. Two of the wounds - in the neck and the heart - were fatal. No one reported hearing any racial slurs or insults and thus the police informed Daisy early on in the investigation that they did not think racism came into play. 'But how can you stab someone 10 times without hatred?' she asked me. Standing 6ft 2in and weighing nearly 20 stone, Ronald was indeed a big man. More than that, he was a big black man, and in our society that makes many people nervous. Ronald himself knew how he could be wrongly perceived. 'Ron was aware that people would judge him on sight,' said Tracy, who is white. 'But he never accepted that. He would mix with anyone and, because of that, he rarely came up against racism.' What Ronald came up against that night may not have been racism, but it was, as his mother rightly said, a demonstration of hatred. His life bleeding away, Ronald staggered along Camden Road, in the direction of his flat, where Tracy and their baby son were asleep. He was less than 10 minutes walk from home when he collapsed under the railway bridge from which his poster would later hang. Tracy was woken by one of Ronald's distraught friends. 'It's serious,' he said. 'I'm not joking.' He gave her the hospital's number. 'I knew as soon as I spoke to them that he was dead. They asked me to describe him. They wouldn't tell me anything, but said they'd send a police car.' The car never came. At no time was a 999 call to the police made from the bar. The police arrived, and promptly, because they were summoned by a nearby businessman who saw the commotion. Barzaar did not react in the manner which inspired confidence in its role as a licensed premise. The bar's owner was determined not to let the murder interfere with usual business. Julie explained her family's feelings on the matter. 'The club had to be sealed off for a while, but within nine days they were up and trading again as normal. I saw that as a huge insult. Ronald's body was kept as evidence.' 'For nine weeks I couldn't bury my child,' Daisy added. The Hinksons were sickened. They mounted a vigil outside Barzaar and put together a petition to have it closed down. As they stood in front of the bar collecting signatures, they began to hear a rumour repeatedly mentioned. Barzaar, people said, was frequented by the same north London crime family my friend from Queen's Crescent had told me controlled the local drug market. The police have consistently denied that there is any evidence linking the family to the events that night at Barzaar. DCI Sweeney was firm if not adamant. 'People say they are behind everything,' he said. 'In almost every murder that takes place in north London their name is mentioned.' In a sense, the family have become modern-day bogeymen. Ever since they came to public attention, they have been accused of a daunting number of crimes and have been associated with a still-larger number of 'legitimate' money-laundering operations. That their name does not exist on any papers concerning the pubs, clubs and mini-cab firms they supposedly run does little to undermine the rumours. Indeed, their absence from the documentation, say their accusers, serves as proof of their backdoor involvement. But very few people really know. And those who do, don't talk. What is certain, though, is that the man who is the sole suspect in Ronald's murder disappeared shortly after it was committed. Around Kentish Town his name is openly discussed. They say he is abroad. There were reports a while back that he was in Spain. The apparent speed and ease with which the suspect vanished has only added weight to the speculation that he was aided by organised criminals. That suspicion is further deepened by his continuing ability to remain beyond the reach of the law. And, perhaps most notably, the £21,000 reward on offer seems to have had next to no effect in pinpointing the murderer's whereabouts. The money was painstakingly raised by the Hinksons, including Ronald's stepfather Ozzie Gobay, from local people without at first any help from the police. The family was offended by the police attitude towards the reward, a slight which compounded the communication problems between the two. Then the police had a change of heart and donated some money. 'Up until this case,' DCI Sweeney informed me, 'the Met had never contributed to a reward. This case made history.' The only source from which the family pointedly refused to accept money was the owner of Barzaar. The bar was eventually closed when it was refused a new licence by Camden Council, but before that decision was made the Hinksons' picket had effectively prevented Barzaar from opening again as a workable concern. However, the bar's former landlord is still in business in the area. He runs a pub in a leafy neighbourhood that, while less than a mile from the spot where Ronald was killed, seems a world away from gangsters and weapons and drug dealers. I visited the well-known pub to speak to the man, to ask him what he knew of the murder, but the bar staff denied all knowledge of him. I checked with various sources, all of whom confirmed that I had the right man and the right place, and phoned the pub again a number of times. The same story. Never heard of him, said his staff, don't know who you're talking about. For whatever reasons, he clearly did not want to talk to me. In fact, very few people wanted to talk to me. Even Ronald's friends avoided my calls. 'I suspect,' said DCI Sweeney, 'there are people that we have spoken to who haven't told us all they know.' Although a number of men took part in the attack on the two men who were beaten unconscious on the night of Ronald's murder, the police are not pursuing them on related charges. The decision has been made that it would not be in the public interest. At the same time, the police are unwilling to release any more information regarding the suspect for whom they're looking. They feel that to do so might jeopardise a trial. So no photos of the man the police want to interview will be issued. And, furthermore, the police say they do not know where he is. The rest is silence. Officially. Of course, people talk all the time. They talk about how the area of Ronald's and my childhood, of Queen's Crescent, has declined, about how bad the heroin and crack problem has become, about the guns and the gangsters, about how you can't trust anyone, and about how they want to move away. Ronald Hinkson had moved away. He was not a troublemaker but a peacemaker. He lived an unremarkable life in many ways. What marked him out was his willingness to stand up and intervene when he saw something he thought was wrong. He was killed because he tried to smooth a situation in which a friend was under threat for smoking a cannabis joint, in an environment that was warped by hard drugs and cowed by the criminals that supplied them. The last time I drove through Kentish Town, I noticed that Ronald's poster had been taken down. His photo is gone but, if his memory means anything, its appeal remains: who will stand up for Ronald?

fields.headline: Jay talking
fields.standfirst: With his taste for ocean-going yachts and flashy gold watches, Peter Jay obviously knows a thing or two about money. Small wonder the BBC chose him to present its new no-expenses-spared series on the economic history of man
fields.trailText: With his taste for ocean-going yachts and flashy gold watches, Peter Jay obviously knows a thing or two about money. Small wonder the BBC chose him to present its new no-expenses-spared series on the economic history of man
fields.body:
Odd to see a 63-year-old economics expert announcing excitedly to camera, 'I have learned two big things - one is that money is brilliantly useful and the other is that it tells the world who you are!' Gosh, even I know that - you'd think Peter Jay would have learned it by now, what with his Winchester schooling, his Oxford first in PPE, his Treasury background, his long career as an economics journalist, and his current post as head of economics at the BBC. Admittedly, we all might have forgotten the latter because he is a very rare visitor to our screens, but he has held the job for the past 10 years, and you'd expect knowledge of the usefulness of money to be part of the remit.

Sneaky colleagues complain that he has not been seen in his BBC office for years and that last time he appeared onscreen, for the Budget, he had to have a special briefing. But now all is explained. For the past three years, since the 1997 election, he has been working on a 'landmark' television series which will tell the economic history of man from caveman to computer wizard. It is called Road to Riches, and starts on 9 July.

You can certainly see the riches on the screen - Proust with an all-star cast might have been cheaper. Jay complains that budgetary constraints forced him to miss out India, but he manages to visit China, Turkey, Jordan, Greece, Italy (where he bumps into Roy Hattersley for a quick chinwag about Diocletian), South America, North America and even the Yap Islands of the Pacific, where the currency is large round immoveable boulders. The road to riches, it seems, is location, location, location.

Jay ambles round the world like a sluggish David Attenborough, wearing one of those white canvas sunhats that are only ever seen on elderly public-school Englishmen abroad, and once or twice unforgivably wearing lace-up shoes with shorts. According to the series editor Barbara Want, it was a nightmare to dress him at all - he is a man who refuses to enter shops and believes that fashion is 'logically and morally objectionable' - so she had to kit him out with an overcoat, a jacket, an anorak, shirts, trousers and a fur hat for Russia. His only contribution was the sunhat. 'He was really thrilled,' she says sweetly, 'to get all these new clothes.'

Younger viewers, seeing this harmless old buffer on television, will be puzzled as to why their elders suddenly start shouting at the screen. But the name Peter Jay rouses extraordinary ire in my generation. I have friends who remember exactly where they were standing in May 1977 when they heard that he was being appointed British Ambassador to the United States. It was the most blatant nepotism, and from a Labour prime minister - Peter Jay was married to Jim Callaghan's daughter Margaret (now Baroness Jay). He was supposed to be 'the cleverest young man in England', but nothing in his previous career - civil servant at the Treasury, TV presenter, economics columnist for The Times - entitled him to the top job in diplomacy, and he was already, even then at 40, beginning to look like a rocket that had fizzled. In fact, he was a perfectly good ambassador till he was recalled by Mrs Thatcher, but the fury aroused by that appointment can never be erased, and partly explains the gleeful Schadenfreude that has greeted every stage in his subsequent downfall.

And downfall it has been. Soon after he returned from the Embassy, Nora Ephron published a wickedly funny novel, Heart- burn, saying that while he was ambassador, his wife was having an affair with her husband Carl Bernstein, The Washington Post journalist of Watergate fame. This was embarrassing enough, but a year or two later, the Jays' nanny, Jane Tustian, revealed that while Margaret Jay was bonking Bernstein, Peter Jay was bonking her - and she had an illegitimate son to prove it. Jay was slow to accept paternity - he said the child could be by his rival-in-love, the embassy chauffeur - and Tustian had to take him to court and get a blood test before he would pay maintenance. Naturally, the tabloids went to town.

Meanwhile, Peter Jay had found new work setting up TV-am, to bid for the ITV breakfast franchise. He won the franchise and launched the station with much ballyhoo about its 'mission to explain' and its Famous Five presenters (David Frost, Angela Rippon, Michael Parkinson, Anna Ford and Robert Kee). Viewers turned off in droves. A month after the launch, the ratings were down to 400,000 and Jay resigned, stabbed not in the back but in the front by his co-director and former friend Jonathan Aitken in a boardroom coup. Greg Dyke stepped in to save the station with Roland Rat.

Jay resurfaced two years later in a very strange job, as Robert Maxwell's 'Chief of Staff' according to himself, or 'Head of Paperclips' according to the staff. Maxwell would wheel him in to meet visiting bigwigs and address him as 'Mr Ambassador' - but would also ring him in the middle of the night to ask what time it was, or call him in for 'crisis' meetings at the weekend about why a secretary had misfiled a letter. He also ordered him to bug Tom Bower's house when Bower was writing his Maxwell biography. Jay didn't do it - but he did discuss it with a security firm. He was finally rescued by his old friend John Birt, who made him head of economics at the BBC. He gave a brilliant account of the events of Black Wednesday in 1992, but has rarely appeared since.

A curious career then, much of which is commemorated in the study at his home in Woodstock, Oxfordshire, which is effectively a Peter Jay museum. The only person I have interviewed with a similar shrine to themselves is Edward Heath, but Heath's shrine is considerably smaller than Jay's which fills a whole converted barn. His HM Ambassador briefcase has pride of place on top of the bookcase, then there is an array of sailing mementos - he owned an ocean- going yacht for 18 years - and hundreds, literally hundreds, of photographs of himself looking thoughtful, looking dashing, looking macho at the helm of his yacht, meeting world leaders, meeting royalty, sharing a joke with the Famous Five. Many of the photos show him with Margaret Jay; hardly any show him with Emma, his second. If I were Emma I would torch the lot, but she is obviously far too nice. The book of Road to Riches is dedicated to her and to his seven children and first grandchild.

The Road to Riches begins, 'After sex, money is our second appetite. Understand- ing comes third.' This is a peculiar statement because of course most people put sustenance first (and judging from the size of his stomach Jay does, too), but it gives the BBC an excuse to show a cheesy nude couple with an apple, supposedly Adam and Eve, in the opening credits. Anyway, it's nice to know he's keen on sex - but does he really put money that high?

'Oh I'm sure I like money. One of the reasons why I was quite keen to get into television was it paid for that...,' he waves his hand at all the photographs of his yacht. 'I had this great ambition, call it a dream, call it what you like, to sail across the ocean - and boats cost money. So I am absolutely not indifferent to money. I love money and I'm very keen to have money.'

But he is not 'good with money' - on the contrary, he says, he's useless when it comes to investments, is permanently bearish, never believes in buying shares, and thinks the whole stock market is a lottery. (And he has never bought a lottery ticket either.) In fact his attitude to money, for all his vast economics expertise, seems to be on much the same peasant-cunning level as mine, or at least that seems to be the moral of the curious story he told me about his watch.

I asked about his watch because it seemed so out of keeping with his clothes. His clothes consisted of scruffy old trousers and a shirt so shrunken and threadbare it barely met across his gut. But his watch was a flashy gold bracelet job, as worn by bookmakers and friends of Arabs. He said it was a Rolex Oyster Perpetual GMT Master, and he acquired it thus: 'I once had an old metal Rolex watch which I used mainly for sailing and I took it in to be serviced and Rolex lost it. This was in about 1973. And they said they would replace it with a new watch of the same type - or , they said, I could buy any watch from their catalogue at 40 per cent of its retail price. So I said, "Well I'll have the most expensive watch then", because I thought to myself in a rather naughty way, "I will insure it, because I'm bound to lose it sooner or later, and then I will make a huge profit" - though I wouldn't lose it deliberately because that would be dishonest. And I've had it for 27 years and I'm still waiting to lose it!'

He sucks up to important people and doesn't bother with underlings. He slights people constantly. The journalist Joanna Coles remembers once sitting next to him at a dinner and him giving her a brief once-over and turning to the more attractive woman on his other side and never uttering another word to her. He famously told a Times sub-editor who queried something in his copy that he was writing for three people in the world and he - the sub-editor - wasn't one of them.

In the preface to Road to Riches he takes a swipe at the 'clerks and clowns' in the BBC accounts department who dared to query his expenses. It doesn't seem to occur to him that most readers of his book will be licence-payers who quite favour the idea of licence money being accountable. But he sees the world as his fan club; he imagines we must all be as devoted to promoting the comfort and enrichment of Peter Jay as he is himself. It is arrogance, but also a sort of naivety.

He grew up in Hampstead intellectual royalty - his father Douglas Jay MP was a Labour Minister (and, incidentally, a notorious womaniser); his mother was a GLC councillor. He went through prep school and Winchester winning all the prizes, with the applause of schoolmasters ringing in his ears. 'I was one of those people who always found it great fun to compete. Everything was a form of game. You were put on square one of the board - whether it was history or maths or cricket or chess or life - and you went ahead, competitively enjoying the game.' But in one respect he was entirely ignorant. 'I could almost literally say I never met a member of the opposite sex, apart from my mother and grandmother, till I was past 21.' I think she had doubts but she wasn't allowed to express them, because my enthusiasm would brook no hesitation.'

They married in 1961 as soon as they graduated, and had three children. But he was soon unfaithful. Typically, he had a theory about marriage, which he now thinks was immature. And yet I also thought that the very strict traditional Victorian kind of morality was all a lot of eyewash. And the upshot of all of that was that you end up sort of playing God with your life. You assume that you have much more control than you do. You don't control in the end what people do or don't know, and what consequences it has.'

In other words, he was unfaithful and got found out. If Nora Ephron's Heartburn is to be believed, Margaret Jay also had several affairs, which he knew about. And for another four or five years I tried very hard to do that but I was wrong - it wasn't possible.'

They only finally divorced in 1985, and he married Emma Thornton the next year. She was a history teacher and furniture designer, young enough to be his daughter, whom he met through sailing. He always wanted to be married. 'I am very uxorious. I detest being on my own. And on the occasions when I found myself on my own, I was very active in filling that void in one way or another - not, for quite a while, in ways which were really very grown-up or satisfactory.' He says, 'There's a sense in which, after the Embassy, I ceased to have any feeling of a career, or a trajectory. I thereafter thought of all my working activities as a kind of epilogue.' And he admits that he was always wrong about what he was good at: he thought he was good at running big organisations, but he now accepts, or partly accepts, that he is better working on his own.
