But here again he was a victim of his own naivety or his inability to understand other people. He compares himself to Othello being taken in by Iago - the Iago, presumably, being Jonathan Aitken, though he doesn't confirm it. 'I find it exceedingly difficult, and have done all my life, to believe that the person I'm talking to is not everything that they seem to be. And yet I have been deceived, almost disastrously so, twice in my working life, once at TV-am and once at the Embassy. webTitle: Fast forward: the loafer's guide to popular culture

fields.headline: Fast forward: the loafer's guide to popular culture
fields.standfirst: This week: Captain Beefheart
fields.trailText: This week: Captain Beefheart
fields.body:
Who's he again? The musical persona of one Don Van Vliet. He hasn't made a record since 1982, but his groundbreaking 1969 album Trout Mask Replica still regularly features in Top 100 album polls worldwide. Rock critic Lester Bangs described it as 'a previously unimaginable landscape of guitars splintering and sproning and slanging and actually swinging in every direction'. Add to that the Captain's raucous blues voice and bawdy humour ('Men, let your wallets flop out and women, open your purses' ) and you have an enduring influence on bands as diverse as The Clash, Pulp and Underworld. He himself is a fan (and friend) of Polly Harvey's.

So what has he been doing since 1982? Abandoning avant-garde music for painting and ditching the Captain Beefheart moniker to be plain Don Van Vliet. He'd been painting for years, and had a solo exhibition in 1972 at the Bluecoat Gallery in Liverpool. At age six he'd lock himself in his bedroom to make animal sculptures, while his parents pushed food under the door. He's still an obsessive: these days he's become a Salinger-like recluse, rarely straying from the home he shares with his wife Jan on the north coast of California. 'I don't like going out when I could be painting,' he says.

What does he paint? Mostly landscapes populated by abstracted animals. There is some debate about whether he's an Outsider, a Rural expressionist or a Modernist Primitive. A new biography, Captain Beefheart by Mike Barnes (Quartet, £14), concludes that he's a One-Off.

What's new about this biography? Well, it's about the whole artist - the painter and musician - which, roughly translated, means 300 plus pages on Captain Beefheart the musician, and about 40 on Don Van Vliet the painter.

Any scandal? This is a critical biography, which means it's based on the work rather than the man. Which is just as well because 'the man' said he 'wanted nothing whatsoever to do with the project'. Barnes has made up for this by using secondary sources such as a Tarot card reader in Camden Lock who reveals that Van Vliet 'reacts to what he sees with his inner eye and can create nothing but problems'.

Worth reading, then? The truth is the Captain Beefheart/Don Van Vliet story is an interesting one...still waiting to be told.
fields.bodyText: Who's he again? The musical persona of one Don Van Vliet. He hasn't made a record since 1982, but his groundbreaking 1969 album Trout Mask Replica still regularly features in Top 100 album polls worldwide. Rock critic Lester Bangs described it as 'a previously unimaginable landscape of guitars splintering and sproning and slanging and actually swinging in every direction'. Add to that the Captain's raucous blues voice and bawdy humour ('Men, let your wallets flop out and women, open your purses' ) and you have an enduring influence on bands as diverse as The Clash, Pulp and Underworld. He himself is a fan (and friend) of Polly Harvey's. So what has he been doing since 1982? Abandoning avant-garde music for painting and ditching the Captain Beefheart moniker to be plain Don Van Vliet. He'd been painting for years, and had a solo exhibition in 1972 at the Bluecoat Gallery in Liverpool. At age six he'd lock himself in his bedroom to make animal sculptures, while his parents pushed food under the door. He's still an obsessive: these days he's become a Salinger-like recluse, rarely straying from the home he shares with his wife Jan on the north coast of California. 'I don't like going out when I could be painting,' he says. What does he paint? Mostly landscapes populated by abstracted animals. There is some debate about whether he's an Outsider, a Rural expressionist or a Modernist Primitive. A new biography, Captain Beefheart by Mike Barnes (Quartet, £14), concludes that he's a One-Off. What's new about this biography? Well, it's about the whole artist - the painter and musician - which, roughly translated, means 300 plus pages on Captain Beefheart the musician, and about 40 on Don Van Vliet the painter. Any scandal? This is a critical biography, which means it's based on the work rather than the man. Which is just as well because 'the man' said he 'wanted nothing whatsoever to do with the project'. Barnes has made up for this by using secondary sources such as a Tarot card reader in Camden Lock who reveals that Van Vliet 'reacts to what he sees with his inner eye and can create nothing but problems'. Worth reading, then? The truth is the Captain Beefheart/Don Van Vliet story is an interesting one...still waiting to be told.

fields.headline: The children are revolting
fields.trailText: I can't quite work it out, but there has to be some reason why our fun-loving 11-year-old turns into a monosyllabic sociopath the minute I collect him from school. Hay fever? Lack of essential vitamins and minerals? Bad day's Pokémon trading?
fields.body:
I can't quite work it out, but there has to be some reason why our fun-loving 11-year-old turns into a monosyllabic sociopath the minute I collect him from school. Hay fever? Lack of essential vitamins and minerals? Bad day's Pokémon trading?

'Good day today?' I ask.

'Nnnn.'

'Excellent. Better tie those laces, you'll be tripping over them.'

He ignores me.

'Laces, please.'

'Dad, don't bother, OK?'

Don't bother. What does that mean?

'Look,' I say, 'either you fasten those shoelaces or you don't get in the car.'

He shrugs. 'I don't care.'

I lean towards him. 'You will care in a minute,' I hiss, which is his cue to recoil dramatically, as if I'm about to beat him with a golf club, a ploy he has picked up from Grange Hill as the one best calculated to trigger a show of synchronised turning heads from teachers and other parents.

I manage an indulgent smile while he takes all day tucking his laces in.

'So. Where's your lunchbox?' I ask briskly, chivvying in tone but not without warmth, cleverly changing the subject with a question he might be able to answer without spitting at me. He sighs. 'Duh, how about... in my bag ?' he says, adopting his bug-eyed home lobotomy kit expression.

I ignore him now. 'So - everyone else all right?' I say, turning to the neglected other two, who of course don't care what mood their big brother is in so long as he's not giving them grief about breathing too loud when he's trying to watch Buffy the Vampire Slayer, or why they insist on having such sad hair when they could have it glued down with an upturned skateboard run at the front like any normal kids who know the first thing about being fashionable.

I march Mr Impossible to the car. 'In the car,' I bark. 'Hurry up.' Soon we are roaring away on two wheels as if there's a helicopter gunship from the battlestar Unintuitive Parent Minor on our tail as we make our escape from the powerful forcefield of what his schoolmates think of him.

'Can we have the tape on, Dad?' he says with sudden brightness, clearly having decided to miraculously change back into Doctor Jekyll for the purposes of getting home with musical accompaniment.

I drive on, tight-lipped.

'Daaad?'

The thing is, am I now supposed to lighten up and pretend nothing has happened or does the punishment of my own now uncommunicative, sullen bearing fit the crime of his? Do two wrongs make a right? Am I being Edwardian? I tut heavily and switch it on.

'Love you, Dad!' he says, as though we have spent the last 15 minutes healthily bonding. What is his problem?

'Love you,' I say, even though my memory is longer than his.

When we get back, my wife is busy pressing karate outfits. 'He's probably just embarrassed at being picked up from school,' she says. 'It's probably hormones.'

Maybe she's right. He has been spending a lot of time in the bathroom recently spraying himself indiscriminately with Lynx body spray specially formulated for 18-30 holidays. And, come to think of it, what was it I heard on Radio 4 recently about scientists discovering that pubescent children start growing more brain cells than they know what to do with, causing untold consternation in the prefrontal cortex as they are confronted by a bewilderment of moral choices before the survival of the most sensible synaptic connections prevails in a frenzy of neural Darwinism, by which time the erstwhile deviants have settled safely into careers as civil engineers and assume habits no more objectionable than a spot of karaoke?

'He's growing up,' my wife says.

He dashes breathless into the house wearing only mud and a pair of Day-Glo shorts, beside himself with excitement because our three-year-old has urinated into a cup and thrown the contents all over him. Perhaps they have a future as performance artists.

'Er... have you thought about washing your hands,' I say.

'Don't bother, Dad,' he says, standing at the fridge door guzzling a pint of milk before charging out again. OK, I won't.

webTitle: Why I never scored with Gary Lineker

fields.headline: Why I never scored with Gary Lineker
fields.trailText: It's at times like these that I remember my relationship with Gary Lineker during the 1990 World Cup tournament. We were an unconventional couple - all the excitement and intensity of a true lovematch, with the added piquancy that I never actually met him.
fields.body:
It's at times like these that I remember my relationship with Gary Lineker during the 1990 World Cup tournament. We were an unconventional couple - all the excitement and intensity of a true lovematch, with the added piquancy that I never actually met him. A friend of mine, Fiona, was also having a relationship with Gary at exactly the same time. She'd never met Gary either, which hurt at first - was he stringing along every woman he'd never met? However, eventually, Fiona and I settled our differences, and decided to 'share' Gary - a bit like you'd share a KitKat, or the way Barbara Dickson and Elaine Paige share their man in the song 'I Know Him So Well', only with us it was more a case of 'We Don't Know Him At All'.

If we were stalkers, we were the laziest, most unsuccessful stalkers you could hope to be stalked by. We didn't so much stalk as skulk in the house, snipping out newspaper shots of 'Gary in action'. Gary standing purposefully near the goal, waiting for the ball to be kicked his way. Gary standing purposefully near the goal, waiting for the ball to be headed his way. Gary simply standing purposefully near the goal. Was there no end to this man's versatility? Soon we'd accumulated huge amounts of clippings. They were festooned around the place, like those scenes in movies, when the cops eventually track down the serial killer in his photograph-strewn lair. Despite a mystifying lack of support from our then-boyfriends, we put our 'archives' to good use by producing our very own fanzine, entitled Ooh Gary, Gary! after the famous terrace chant. It was then our lives changed forever. Or something.

Inadvertently, we'd managed to produce the first fanzine dedicated to one player, which had the bonus gimmick of being written by idiot females who clearly knew nothing about football. As if this wasn't achievement enough, we'd also managed to revolutionise the concept of 'match reporting' by neither attending the matches, nor reporting on them. No wonder, then, that as editors of Ooh Gary, Gary!, we were featured in magazines, and an interview with us giggling in short skirts about how much we 'admired' Gary was used on Grandstand.

However, it wasn't all non-stop glamour and warm beer at When Saturday Comes parties. After meeting with us, Right To Reply decided to use someone else to front its report on 'Female Football Fans', apparently unimpressed by our argument that we didn't like other women getting into football, we wanted all the attention for ourselves ( Right To Reply 's loss, I think you'd agree). Then, disaster struck.

Word came back from our contact at Gary's club fanzine, The Spur, that Gary didn't dig what we were doing, didn't realise in those pre-ladette times that we were pioneers (man), and deserved a little respect (goddamit) from the male beauty we were stalking. Asked about Ooh Gary, Gary! during an interview, he'd allegedly tut-tutted, sneered, and said: 'Oh, them.'

Was this all the thanks we were going to get for our slavish devotion to England's foremost striker? For 'tut-tut' had we purchased every paper every day for six months in the hope of getting an elusive shot of Gary not standing near a goal mouth? For a sneer and an 'Oh, them ' had we bought Paul Gascoigne's expensive stupid book, and stood patiently in line for hours to get it signed, thereby giving us the opportunity to pass a copy of Ooh Gary, Gary! to Gascoigne and ask him to give it to Gary? ('We'll see he gets it', said Gazza's manager, tossing it into a bin seconds later.)

It was a sobering moment, but also an instructive one. These days, I'm so 'over' Gary. I see him on TV presenting sport, team leading on They Think It's All Over, or advertising crisps, and I'm able to marvel at his easy charm and raffish good looks without feeling the slightest urge to kidnap him. That isn't to say my relationship with Gary ended totally without scar tissue, good and bad. It has left me with an abiding affection for men in shorts, as well as sympathy for those celebrity stalkers that get lambasted by the tabloids for scaring the bejesus out of casts of soap operas. There but for the grace of God... and all that. As Fiona pointed out at the time, while it is true that we didn't hang around outside the Tottenham ground waiting for Gary, it was only because there was a pub situated tantalisingly nearby.

We also learned that some bubbles in life exist to be popped by reality. They say you should never meet your heroes, but maybe it's even more of a mistake not to meet them. Maybe if Gary had met Fiona and me, it would have given him the opportunity he needed not to ask us to marry him, and then we would have gone away, and he wouldn't have had to go 'tut tut' like that. Then again, at the end of the day, all things considered (etc), maybe we are all the better and wiser for the experience. As the man should have said, it is better to have stalked and lost, than never to have stalked at all.

fields.headline: The cost of...
fields.standfirst: ...being a student
fields.trailText: ...being a student
fields.body:
Of the students currently taking their A-levels, roughly 250,000 will be hoping to continue their studies at a university. But how much will their degree cost them? For a start, it is their parents who are most likely to be signing the cheques, and the recent introduction of tuition fees adds to the financial burden. Parents earning less than £17,370 need not worry, but those whose income exceeds £28,000 face an additional £1,025 annually. Of course, Scottish students have already had their fees replaced by a post-graduation payment, and applications by Scots to Scottish universities have duly rocketed.

Various surveys confirm that average annual expenditure by students ranges from £5,800 to £7,000 for students living in London. Given that the maximum loan entitlement is £3,635 per year (£4,480 for Londoners, with interest rates linked to inflation), there is clearly some discrepancy. Banks offer credit cards and interest-free overdrafts, but the result is that students now emerge from higher education with debts of between £5,000 and £7,000. The class of 1999 collectively owed £1bn.

So what exactly do students spend all this money on? Accommodation is the largest outlay, costing between £1,700 and £2,300 per year. This figure varies according to region: average weekly rent in Newcastle is £35, but almost twice as much in London.

Next on the list is entertainment, although conflicting pictures are presented. The NUS suggests that students spend about £770 per year, while the Policy Studies Institute figures are closer to £1,200. However, students have shed their old image of being baggy-jumpered, drunken loafers. They are now far more likely to sport mobile phones (£200 per year) and run their own dotcom start-up.

There are still ways of reducing costs: not only do science students spend less on books and leisure, but they are also far more employable after graduation than arts students.

However, as Laura Spence will be aware, board and tuition alone cost £20,000 at Harvard University in the US, although endowments totalling £8.3bn mean that three-quarters of its students are subsidised to some extent.

Cost of three-year course, outside London

(Loans £10,000 repaid on employment after graduation)

Tuition fees £3,075

Accommodation £5,000

Food & household expenses £3,300

Travel £1,500

Books £1,350

Entertainment £3,000

Total from £17,000

webTitle: Wading through excrement is not my idea of fun

fields.headline: Wading through excrement is not my idea of fun
fields.standfirst: Muddy fields, watered-down lager and emetic, overpriced junk food - count me out of the pop festival season
fields.trailText: Muddy fields, watered-down lager and emetic, overpriced junk food - count me out of the pop festival season
fields.body:
'Here will we sit, and let the sounds of music

Creep in our ears; soft stillness and the night

Become the touches of sweet harmony

But, whilst this muddy vesture of decay

Doth grossly close it in, we cannot hear it'

The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 1

Granted, Lorenzo was referring to man's mortality rather than the effect of standing in a marshy, urine-smelling field listening to Radiohead, but you get the idea. Music festivals are the bane of young people's summers all over the developed world, and particularly so in this country, which, with a climate so ill-suited to outdoor activities of any kind, hosts more than 10 big, open-air pop extravaganzas every year.

Starting with Glastonbury next week, hundreds of thousands of virginal physics students, tattooed ladettes, Home Counties homies and malodorous dog-lovers will swarm to the great cultural centres of our time - a large field near Reading, a large field near Leeds, a large field near Chelmsford, a large field near Kinross - to contract some hideous skin infection and spend 40 minutes trying to work out if the tiny figure on the distant stage is really the singer from the Stereophonics or the ugly guy who sold you that emetic curry the night before.

Why do they do it? A mixture of masochism and tradition. Your First Glastonbury is now a student rite of passage, like Lighting Your First Fart or Stealing Your First Road Cone While Butt Naked. You expect some damage; it's part of the deal. And you don't really expect to enjoy it, except in retrospect. As it happens, I had a fantastic time at my first Glastonbury, but that had more to do with the potency of the magic mushroom tea I drank than the music or the ancient druid vibe or the myriad other 'entertainments' on offer.

This is one of the perfidious myths about the modern music festival, the theory of multiple leisure activities. In fact, all festivals offer is a really crap version of the kind of entertainments you would find in even the dumpiest small town in Nottinghamshire: no TV or cinema, but - hey - they show football matches on giant screens; no pubs, but - wow - you can buy watered-down lager in flimsy plastic glasses for only £3 a pint; no nightclubs or restaurants, but - cool - you can squelch in time with a faraway beat as you wait for your microwaved beanburger.

Festivals offer all the hassles and horrors of urban life with none of its compensating conveniences. It is claustrophobically crowded and crime is rife, but you can't ring up and order a pizza at 3am. The old hippies who have been going every year since 1970 will tell you it has been 'hijacked by the corporations'. If only this were true! The very least people deserve in such a hellhole is access to proper brand names like Pret à Manger, John Lewis and J.D. Wetherspoon. Being overcharged for a tub of coleslaw that tastes like white spirit by a small stallholder glorying in the name 'Salad Daze' is not evidence of a healthy alternative sector, it's just second-rate commercialism. Festivals are the last bastion of bad value - like a British airport circa 1985 with liquid excrement smeared all over the tile flooring and a muffled echo of Rage Against the Machine being piped through the Tannoy instead of 'Yesterday' played on a xylophone.

I'm sure that, at this point, some of our younger readers are shaking their heads and pointing out that I am a cynical old hack with no real love of music. Well, I'm nearly 30 - and pretty cynical too. Oddly enough, though, I love sweaty gigs in small, dark, badly ventilated venues. I hate sitting down to watch a band, despise executive boxes, and spit on the Royal Albert Hall. But feeling damp, cold and ripped-off does not add anything to the music.

And if you're still determined to trek over to Glastonbury on Friday, then you're either very brave or very stupid. A final word of advice: pack a toothbrush, a torch, a mobile phone, waterproofs and a very large bag of magic mushrooms.

The old hippies who have been going every year since 1970 will tell you it has been 'hijacked by the corporations'. If only this were true! The very least people deserve in such a hellhole is access to proper brand names like Pret à Manger, John Lewis and J.D. Wetherspoon. Being overcharged for a tub of coleslaw that tastes like white spirit by a small stallholder glorying in the name 'Salad Daze' is not evidence of a healthy alternative sector, it's just second-rate commercialism. Festivals are the last bastion of bad value - like a British airport circa 1985 with liquid excrement smeared all over the tile flooring and a muffled echo of Rage Against the Machine being piped through the Tannoy instead of 'Yesterday' played on a xylophone. I'm sure that, at this point, some of our younger readers are shaking their heads and pointing out that I am a cynical old hack with no real love of music. Well, I'm nearly 30 - and pretty cynical too. Oddly enough, though, I love sweaty gigs in small, dark, badly ventilated venues. I hate sitting down to watch a band, despise executive boxes, and spit on the Royal Albert Hall. But feeling damp, cold and ripped-off does not add anything to the music. And if you're still determined to trek over to Glastonbury on Friday, then you're either very brave or very stupid. A final word of advice: pack a toothbrush, a torch, a mobile phone, waterproofs and a very large bag of magic mushrooms.

fields.headline: A soldier to cry on
fields.standfirst: Ralph Fiennes is a repellent Coriolanus, Barbara Jefford riveting as his tyrant mother - when you can hear them
fields.trailText: Coriolanus | The Heiress | Hamlet
fields.body:
Coriolanus
Gainsborough, London N1

The Heiress
Lyttelton, London SE1

Hamlet
The Globe, London SE1

Anyone who wants to see a great Shakespearean actor should go to Jonathan Kent's production of Coriolanus. The Almeida's tenancy of the beautiful, derelict Gainsborough Studios has been presented as a Ralph Fiennes season. But it is Barbara Jefford - who first appeared in a Shakespeare play over 50 years ago - who causes the audience to be rapt. As the tyrant mother Volumnia - the person who taught Coriolanus how to bully - she uncoils herself to assume an easy grandeur of gesture. She is statuesque. She uses the verse like a knife. She subdues the vast space of this stage - just as she does her whimpering son.

The Almeida are having an imaginative sojourn in Shoreditch. They have linked two of Shakespeare's least cajoling plays - Richard II and Coriolanus - and established a kinship between them. Both plays deal with men who are ill-equipped for power; both these men have rivals who can be seen as echoes. In both cases, these second selves have been played with admirable tautness by Linus Roache. And in both cases they have proved that Ralph Fiennes is a bold actor.

Fiennes has made both his characters repellent. He might have been expected to be a melancholy, brooding Richard: instead, he was spiky. He might have been expected to smoulder as Coriolanus, but he plays him like a teenager trying out a series of different parts: he's in turn headstrong, petulant and scornful. He pretends to be a baby with silly walks and mocking voices - and then breaks down into real babyish tears.

This intricate unpacking of a part - nearly always full-face to the audience as if this were his looking glass - is always intelligent, but better suited to the self-conscious, self-regarding Richard II than to Coriolanus. This is a play which has been seen as an argument for revolution and as an argument against it. It has no point of rest, no haven of sympathy. It snarls in all directions. Its lack of certainty can make it seem peculiarly modern. It doesn't seem so here.

Too much of this production is smudged. The staging is full of big effects, some of them tremendous. In Paul Brown's design, the jagged lightning fissure which splits the rough brick wall at the back of the stage becomes filled with smoke; the glass floor of the stage turns blood-red after battle; a massive, rusty gate clangs down like a guillotine. But a lot of the verse can't be heard. A lot of it is bellowed. There's a miasma of muttering, and a roaring, sword-waving way of going on. The crowd is a weeny huddle of blokes energetically pretending to be poor people. Despite the flares of excitement which are sent up, it's a production which lacks a sense of an outside world and of political consequence.

Why would anyone looking for a melodrama pick on a writer whose prose is made up of qualifications, reservations and ambiguities? It's perverse. But it's what Ruth and Augustus Goetz did when, in 1947, they turned Henry James's novel Washington Square into a play and retitled it, with giveaway crudeness, The Heiress. Now this work has been revived, and brought, creaking and crinolined, to the Lyttelton.

The flavour of James's novel is in its complications and nuances. A homely, unsophisticated, prosperous young woman lives coweringly with a father who despises her. She falls for a fortune-seeker who makes her happy. Her father sees through the young man, protects his daughter from him, and in doing so exposes her to a lifetime of clear-sighted unhappiness.

It's a novel in which bad motives are seen to have amiable consequences, and in which correct behaviour proceeds from contempt. It is penetrating about psycholog ical dependence. Such subtleties are banished here. Alan Howard plays the father with a fluting whimsy which sanitises his danger. As his interfering sister, Maggie Steed produces a range of fruity gurgles and wobbly gestures worthy of a pantomime dame. Most damagingly, Ben Porter plays the young man as a self-evident cad, so that there's little tension in the heroine's progress: for most of the play she looks like a dope; at the end of it, her sacrifice seems trivial.

As the heroine, the gifted young actress Eve Best needs all her large resources of composure to stay afloat, clinging to a thankless part, in which moves from blank-faced glumness - her eyes meeting no one's and her arms held wide apart as if to balance her on a pair of invisible stilts - to a silent, bitter serenity.

Gideon Davey's design is a lovely region of eau-de-nil and pale yellow which is warmed by a golden glow and, between scenes, raked by a chill white light. In this place of changing colours and shadowy nooks, a Henry James novel might have been staged to perfection.

There are always moments during a Globe production which seem to play upon the heritage aspect of the building, but which produce in the audience a modern self-consciousness, drawing attention to the artificiality of what's going on. In this season's Hamlet , when Mark Rylance, taking the role he played at the RSC some 10 years ago, speaks of the noisy groundlings, he points accusingly at the standing figures beneath him.

Giles Block's production is sometimes raggedly acted, and heavily traditional in appearance. The Ghost clanks across the stage in heavy-duty black armour. Got up in doublet and hose of mustard and crimson, the male members of the cast look like pear-drops. No man should ever roll on the floor with his legs in the air if he's wearing d-and-h.

But the scenes are dovetailed, so that the action moves swiftly. Rylance - dainty, doleful and witty - brings to the speaking of the verse his own mix of gravity and lightness. He glides into a modern cadence without losing the beat of the line. He works variations on the soliloquies, sometimes speaking with his back to the audience, sometimes sidling round as if to beckon them into his thoughts, sometimes berating them as if they were creatures in his dreams.

fields.headline: Elian nation
fields.standfirst:
Rafael Garcia-Navarro grew up in exile in Florida, Cuba-bound bombs in the bathroom. So who better to take you through the paranoia, passion and sheer lunacy that broke out when a six-year-old boy washed up on the shores of the banana republic of Miami?
Cuba after Castro - Observer special
fields.trailText: Rafael Garcia-Navarro grew up in exile in Florida, Cuba-bound bombs in the bathroom. So who better to take you through the paranoia, passion and sheer lunacy that broke out when a six-year-old boy washed  up on the shores of the banana republic of Miami?
fields.body:
He will receive a hero's welcome; that much is certain. There will be more marching, more throngs, more propaganda. And it will seem utterly familiar to him. Elián Gonzalez was five years old, and a casualty of the revolution, when he fled Cuba. He's six now and has become the revolution's pre-eminent icon. How confused he might be about that rests on what he can remember of his life before the escape, and what he can forget about the city of Miami.

Though a great deal of his story remains a mystery, we do know his voyage from Cuba to Miami. Late last November, Elián departed, quietly and secretly, with his mother, her boyfriend, his family and a few friends, headed for Florida. It was a desperate act. Their boat was too small - and with 14 people on board, overloaded. A faulty outboard motor required one stopover and more ruinous efforts to repair it, but was soon on the blink again. The boat capsized during a brutal squall off the Florida coast. Three inner tubes were all they had for an emergency; now here it was, crashing upon them. They held on and drifted feebly in the powerful swells. At one point, the lights of Miami shimmered in the horizon. It was too late for heroics; the current pulled them back and, one by one, they let go. Eleven died. On Thanksgiving Day, Elián was discovered floating alone near Fort Lauderdale (two others were rescued further south). Strangely, he didn't require hospitalisation. How long he'd braved the waters is anyone's guess. He couldn't remember. Some say 50 hours.

Elián had lost his mother. He'd watched her drown. His father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, remained in Cuba, along with the rest of his immediate family. Yet there were more traumas lying in store. His extraordinary survival had, unbeknown to him, sliced open an old wound between two parallel worlds, one in Havana, another in Miami; between native Cubans and exiled Cubans, between the branch of Elián's family in Cuba and another he'd never met in the US. For five surreal months, the saga of Elián rekindled Cold War vigils and terrors on a vast political scale. Somewhere in that senseless battlefield, his welfare was laid bare.

It was never a simple custody matter. It wasn't even an immigration dispute. From the start, it was a war of competing ideolo gies and prejudices, and they were out in force. There was jubilation in Havana on Easter Saturday, the day Elián was whisked away from his Miami relatives at gunpoint and delivered to his father in Washington, DC - and destruction on the streets of Miami, where more than 100 fires were ignited. A week later, 80,000 marched in protest through the neighbourhood known as 'Little Havana', this time without violence. Women were asked to wear black, which, despite the sweltering heat, they did in large numbers. Some carried effigies of Elián, others raised billboard-sized banners displaying a familiar red-white-and-blue striped motif: the flag of Cuba. The American flag was also unfurled - upside down.

Miami had splintered. A few miles away, another 3,000-strong 'pro-American' demonstration offered a sight rarely witnessed there before: blacks marching alongside whites - the whites brandishing Confederate flags. Some of the protestors held Bibles up to the sky. Hatred and anger were visible everywhere.

In Cuba, meanwhile, Fidel Castro launched the biggest public-relations blitz since he arrived in Havana as conqueror in 1959. It was a political opportunity not to be missed. If Castro lost, the court of world public opinion would surely endorse his standing on the boy's right to be with his father. If he won, the resulting two-fingered salute to the yanquis - and, more crucially, to the Cuban-exile community in Miami - would pay handsome dividends on the street. Earlier this month, on the day after the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta denied the Miami-based Gonzalez family's appeal for an asylum hearing, 500,000 women marched in Havana, a city whose entire population is just 2 million. The protest was against Elián observing the court order to remain in the US for 14 days while the Miami clan filed another appeal, possibly with the Supreme Court.

Miami is unlike any other city. American only in name, it's a city of racial rancours and political grudges. More significantly, it is a city of exiles - from Haiti, El Salvador, Panama, Nicaragua, Argentina, Colombia. The largest, most powerful group is Cuban. According to the US Census Bureau, Hispanics make up 12 per cent of the United States population. Cubans constitute a small minority of those, a meagre six per cent. In Florida's Dade County, Cubans constitute 40 per cent of the population - a large, successful, noisy majority. Alone, they make up 55 per cent of Miami.

After Fidel Castro swept into power, the exodus to Florida began. The regime that keeps him happily in Havana keeps the exiles furious in Miami. Some saw Miami as un pueblo de campo (an outback village) when they arrived, but no longer. Today, with its big urban skyline and financial gateway to Latin America, Miami is a bedrock, conducted largely en español , by Cubans. Often in defiance of reason, their dream - a return to the promised land - perseveres.

For these Cubans came to fight Castro, not build a city. The metropolis evolved as years dragged on, along with an ambivalence to America's government and culture. The maladroit Bay of Pigs invasion in 1961 was the first breach, followed by the missile crisis in 1962. Throughout the 60s and early 70s, exile parents found the prospect of their sons being drafted to Vietnam difficult to reconcile with watching Marxist Cuba being allowed to continue only 90 miles from Florida. Subsequent US interventions in Chile, Grenada and Panama have added to the disenchantment. Life in Havana permeates every aspect of life in Miami, a phenomenon by turns understandable, peculiar, outrageous and, occasionally, embarrassing.

The Elián political spectacle has uncaged circus animals of every stripe. One recent example from the menagerie of local politics: Miami has a Cuban-American mayor. His name is Joe Carollo, though lately he has been going by 'Crazy Joe' Carollo. During the protests leading up to the Easter raid - amid the clamour for solidarity within this largest voting portion - the mayor went on Spanish-language radio stations, local news shows, even on CNN, to warn that his police department would not assist federal law-enforcement officials if they came after the boy. They did - and afterwards he went on a televised sacking spree. His first volley was to eject the well-regarded (non-Hispanic) chief of police, on the grounds that he knew about the raid and neglected to inform him. The city's non-Hispanic city manager refused to unseat the police chief - who resigned anyway. The mayor dismissed the city manager. Now Miami has a Cuban mayor, a Cuban city manager, a Cuban chief of police, a Cuban city attorney, and a Cuban majority in the commission. The city, meanwhile, is more divided than ever. As the Elián affair turned the spotlight on the exile community, the latter has responded less like the old guard and more like a marginalised fundamentalist fringe. There's no small amount of paranoia, plus a dose of the sheer lunacy for which Miami is famous.

An insult lives many lives here. After the mayor's antics were compared to the shenanigans of a banana-republic politico, a banana war was declared, no one knows by whom - a war which is still being waged by sides equally keen to claim the fruit as their emblem. Someone drew a circle of bananas around Miami's seal and left it outside City Hall. Bananas were hurled near the entrance on a daily basis. More recent protests have produced bananas as symbols of defiance and solidarity: opponents of the mayor point the banana down; supporters point it up. No fatalities have been reported.

A banana flag already exists. Designed by Barbara Dabney and manufactured at her 'Freedom Flag and Banner' plant in Miami, it has been a runaway success. The flag features a redesigned city seal - citing the founding date of the republic as the year 2000 - arranged over a field of bananas. Dabney's business has flourished in recent times; from April through May, thousands of Cuban and US flags have been ordered for protesters on opposite sides of the barricade. For all the ranting, few entrepreneurs have thought twice about cashing in on Elián. And not merely on 'Free Elián' buttons and T-shirts sanctifying his image. No, 'real sand' from the Cuban Gonzalez family hometown of Cárdenas. Little Havana 'holy water' fresh from a tap near the Miami Gonzalez home. Elián's cup. Elián's tennis ball. Elián's hair. The online shopping mall eBay has listed upwards of 134 items, from Elián rosaries to pray for the boy ($59) to more preposterous articles: a picture painted on a license plate of Elián urinating on Fidel Castro ($4.99); the very raft used by the boy at sea (bids scaled to $10 million), though this item was pulled when it suddenly dawned on prospective buyers that Elián had been clinging to an inner tube, not a raft.

The internet war has been extreme. Janet Reno perhaps expected to retire to her hometown of Miami after her time as attorney general. She may want to review her plans. The electronic postcards I received from Miami speak for themselves: one is a variant on the famous Associated Press photograph taken on the day of the seizure. Elián is crying, but not because he's facing a submachine gun - instead, Reno has burst through the door and flashed her breasts. In another there's no Elián this time, simply Reno superimposed upon a pornographic picture of a pre-operation transsexual.

Not surprisingly, Bill Clinton has also been ushered onstage for comic relief. The AP photograph of the raid has the president pushing through the door, smiling, with rifle in hand, while Fidel Castro, in battle fatigues, follows in behind him. T-shirts with this picture are for sale all over Little Havana - the caption reads: 'Federal Child Abuse'. Porn isn't the only exile weapon on the web. The site www.nocastro.com offers propaganda plus a trip down memory lane. We are reminded in an Amnesty International summary that, as recently as 1994, Castro ordered the sinking of the tugboat 13 de Mayo leaving for Miami, in which 35 men, women and children perished. Cuban exiles understand the situation in Cuba completely. It's a matter of record that the Cuban republic claims a child belongs to the state, not its father, and a matter of policy that children constitute a goodly portion of the Cuban labour force.

'The Elián phenomenon is like a virus,' says Jim Mullin, editor of the Miami newspaper New Times , 'everything it touches gets infected.' This statement could easily apply to Cuba and the entire exile theme. One of the editors I worked with during my eight years in Miami, Mullin came from California in 1988 and still remains baffled by the exiles. 'For a journalist this is hog heaven. It's fascinating trying to figure this place out. I've been trying for 12 years.' Will he stay in Miami? 'I'll stay until Castro falls and Cuba is restored.' He could be waiting a long while yet.

Waiting for Fidel is a story that's decades old. It is my family's story and, to a lesser degree, my own. My exile began before I was born. Conceived in Cuba in 1958, I was delivered in Florida in 1959, eight months after Castro received his own hero's welcome. My heritage has been a meandering rootlessness. Some members of my family came immediately, some stayed and came later, some stayed indefinitely. Less a political upheaval than an illustration of families split down the middle, the circumstances of my family's path in Cuba were typical. My great-grandfather, General Emilio Nuñez, was a hero of the revolution that ended the Spanish-American War in 1898 and founded the Cuban republic. A devoted friend of José Martí, Cuba's greatest poet, the general was chosen to introduce and raise the Cuban flag at the Morro Castle when independence was declared; later he served as vice-president.

My grandfather, Emilio Nuñez Portuondo, was a well-known politician and diplomat. In the 50s, he became a leading anti-communist at the United Nations, where he headed the Security Council. No supporter of Batista, he nonetheless represented him at the UN. His final political act was to resign the post of prime minister after serving barely 10 days, when Batista expressed his intention to withdraw constitutional guarantees. 'It's the beginning of the end,' he told my mother.

Much to my grandfather's dismay, his eldest son had fallen in love with Myrta Diaz-Balart, a young divorcee, and they were married. Her former husband was Fidel Castro. She remains the only woman El Máximo has ever married. The marriage also produced a son, Fidel Jr, the only one from Castro's unofficial brood of 11 to be deemed 'legitimate'. Conflicts of interest, political and personal, coincided with a revolution. When it came, there was ample reason to leave. The scene in Miami was characteristic: fistfights at the airport broke out between fidelistas headed to Havana and batistianos fleeing Cuba. The televised executions during January and February 1959, when enemies were led to the paredón and shot, made for grisly viewing - especially for my grandparents, who could easily imagine a similar march. Their Cuban days were over.

My father was 22 at that time. In the affluent climate of 50s Cuba, he was already going places. He had secured a loan of $5 million from a Canadian bank in order to develop a casino and hotel resort within family-owned land in the province of Pinar del Rio. Things changed after Castro. Now he had a wife, three children and no job, in a foreign country. His early exile was a time of desperate moves, some towards a career and others to restore Cuba. For a time, he received soldiers of fortune in our little house in Fort Lauderdale, and played a small part in plots to put away Fidel. An explosive device supposedly to be flown and dropped over Castro at a rally was kept for a while in our bathroom. The pilot lost his nerve, the plot fizzled, and the device was disassembled. My father succeeded in business later on, but the loss of Cuba was a sadness he carried within, until to the end of his life.

My aunt Myrta eventually left Cuba and moved to Spain. She was never denied access to Fidelito, but had to travel great distances to see him. Fidelito trained in the Soviet Union as a nuclear physicist. Not unlike Elián, he was a state trophy. He has led an obscure life back in Cuba and is said to be close to Fidel now, and has been spotted in recent protests standing beside his father. I have never met Fidelito, nor any others from Castro's side of the family. Fidelito's cousins include Florida state senator Mario Diaz-Balart and US congressman Lincoln Diaz-Balart, both vehemently anti-Castro - marking yet another split in one family.

Metaphors common and strange have pelted down on Elián's fragile bones like hail - a miracle, an angel, a martyr, a saviour. There have been visions of sacred dolphins and a weeping Virgin Mary. Hosannas have been offered to the 'fisherman' who 'rescued' Elián. Everyone wants to provide a segment of the hagiography. Even the Spanish-speaking world's best-known novelists have weighed in, from Peru's Mario Vargas Llosa to Chile's Ariel Dorfman to Colombia's (or, these days, Mexico's) Gabriel García Márquez; the greatest living Cuban writer, Guillermo Cabrera Infante, who lives in London, published an article drawing a parallel between Elián and the Yoruba deity, Eleguá, to underscore his eternal place in Cuban folklore. The act of consecration is always peculiar, whether it takes place in Little Miami or Kensington Palace.

But the featured players of The Elián Show are all too human, starting with the Miami Gonzalezes. Ah, the character issue: in pursuit of their custody suit, they were quick to sling mud, but might have looked closer to home first. Great-uncles Lázaro and Delfin Gonzalez, at the forefront of the custody war, share drunk-driving convictions. Elián's cousin, Marisleysis - who, bidding for the part of surrogate mother of a saint, wept buckets after the raid, and then delivered an attack on Janet Reno's sexuality - has been hospitalised some eight times since November, citing 'stress'. Lázaro and Delfin's twin nephews, José and Luis Cid, photographed playing with the boy soon after his rescue, would have raised the eyebrows of any judge deciding on custody: José has a criminal record for grand theft, forgery and violating probation. Luis was arrested for allegedly robbing a tourist in Little Havana. And amid the screeching over Cuba's brainwashing machinery, which member of the household was responsible for the 40-second video, shot at 1am, showing an exhausted Elián telling his father he wanted to stay in Miami?

It shouldn't come as a surprise that 'the fisherman' - el pescador - who 'saved' Elián is not a saint, let alone a St Peter. Donato Dalrymple, a house cleaner, was on his first fishing trip with his cousin when he laid eyes on Elián. The cousin was actually the one who lifted Elián from the inner tube. Of Donato's three failed marriages, two have been to brides of the mail-order variety. He has no children and says he doesn't want any. Dalrymple's brother, Lindy, is in prison for beating his son, not quite four years old, to death. Donato defends his sibling, 'the kindest person' he has ever known, with the same fervency he lavishes upon his love for the 'miracle child'. It was Dalrymple who was clutching Elián in the AP photograph. El pescador, who insists on calling himself 'saviour', first filed a suit seeking to remove Lázaro Gonzalez as custodian, a moot point after Elián's transfer to Washington. Then he filed a $100 million suit against Janet Reno for depriving him of his civil rights during the raid. A few days ago he touted his new celebrity on the ABC programme Politically Incorrect. Immortality will doubtless follow on Trivial Pursuit.

Exile madness extends to more honourable professions and even to non-Hispanics. Kendall Coffey, the attorney leading the Miami Gonzalez defence team, is no stranger to scandal. After losing a bid for office in 1992, he was appointed to replace Janet Reno as federal prosecutor. There, Coffey lost a landmark case against a pair of alleged drug smugglers who were accused of importing 75 tons of cocaine, worth roughly $2 billion. It was the biggest drug-trafficking trial ever lost by federal prosecutors.

Understandably feeling a bit down, Coffey didn't leave home without his American Express card on the evening in February 1996, when he drove to Lipstik, a nude strip bar. He ordered a magnum of Dom Pérignon and charged it before sitting down for a private nude-dancing 'session' with stripper Tamara 'Tiffany' Gutierrez. She had good cause to complain when the tip came in the form of Coffey lunging at her breast in a huff and settling for her arm, which he promptly bit. He was escorted out of the premises. Later that night, Coffey's father tried to destroy the credit-card slip and offered cash, but the story was out. Coffey fils resigned soon afterwards.

Fear has fuelled a history of exile violence that no amount of whitewashing can unstain. Occasionally it has highlighted inadequacies among Miami's elected officials when dealing with fringe terrorism. Between 1974 and 1994, 10 bombs were deposited at the office of Spanish-language magazine Réplica, for simply advocating a 'dialogue' with Castro. Between 1980 and 2000, stores shipping packages to Cuba have been bombed, travel agencies arranging travel to Cuba have been bombed, businesses shipping medical supplies to Cuba have been bombed. Many refuse to own up to the mantle of extremism: 'Some people in the community haven't wanted to face up to a history of violence,' says Enrique Fernandez. A Cuban journalist writing in English, Fernandez is a rarity in Florida journalism. His weekly column for Fort Lauderdale's newspaper, the Sun-Sentinel , has sought to accept things for what they are. The politicians, he wrote recently, are vexing but soon pass. Where the larger culture is concerned, viva la diferencia

His rationale for Miami's irreconcilable differences is simply: 'History. This has never been a decent place. It was a gangster hangout in the 20s when there was gambling. It was a den of racist Jim Crow laws in the 50s. The exiles came and history has persisted. That's no surprise.' Fernandez doesn't agree with the theory that too much time has elapsed for Miami Cubans to consider repatriation. He doesn't even like the term 'Cuban-American': 'Being Cuban is something you feel; it's something you can't readily explain - a spirit that's simply there. However different each person's relationship to Cuba may be, I think people here see themselves first as Cubans and secondly as Americans.' More disturbing, perhaps, is how Americans see them. Based on recent polls, the Cuban-exile community, until recently a respected minority with considerable clout inside Washington, appears to have shed some of its good regard and political capital fighting the Elián war.

Nine US presidents down and counting, Fidel Castro is alive and well. The tragic flotilla of rafts continues across the waters. In Miami, the streets are suddenly quiet with the air of resignation. Crazy Joe Carollo is up for re-election in November 2001; bananas may well be licensed weapons by then. The Miami Gonzalezes are moving away from Little Havana. Some have suggested making their former rented home a museum; the landlord is weighing up the numbers. Three Elián movies are currently in production, one of them, produced by notorious low-budget shlockmeister Menahem Golan, is being filmed in Cuba. In a move by congressmen from the farm states of the American midwest, there is now serious talk about ending the Cuban embargo. Elián Gonzalez works in mysterious ways.

fields.bodyText: He will receive a hero's welcome; that much is certain. There will be more marching, more throngs, more propaganda. And it will seem utterly familiar to him. Elián Gonzalez was five years old, and a casualty of the revolution, when he fled Cuba. He's six now and has become the revolution's pre-eminent icon. How confused he might be about that rests on what he can remember of his life before the escape, and what he can forget about the city of Miami. Though a great deal of his story remains a mystery, we do know his voyage from Cuba to Miami. Late last November, Elián departed, quietly and secretly, with his mother, her boyfriend, his family and a few friends, headed for Florida. It was a desperate act. Their boat was too small - and with 14 people on board, overloaded. A faulty outboard motor required one stopover and more ruinous efforts to repair it, but was soon on the blink again. The boat capsized during a brutal squall off the Florida coast. Three inner tubes were all they had for an emergency; now here it was, crashing upon them. They held on and drifted feebly in the powerful swells. At one point, the lights of Miami shimmered in the horizon. It was too late for heroics; the current pulled them back and, one by one, they let go. Eleven died. On Thanksgiving Day, Elián was discovered floating alone near Fort Lauderdale (two others were rescued further south). Strangely, he didn't require hospitalisation. How long he'd braved the waters is anyone's guess. He couldn't remember. Some say 50 hours. Elián had lost his mother. He'd watched her drown. His father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, remained in Cuba, along with the rest of his immediate family. Yet there were more traumas lying in store. His extraordinary survival had, unbeknown to him, sliced open an old wound between two parallel worlds, one in Havana, another in Miami; between native Cubans and exiled Cubans, between the branch of Elián's family in Cuba and another he'd never met in the US. For five surreal months, the saga of Elián rekindled Cold War vigils and terrors on a vast political scale. Somewhere in that senseless battlefield, his welfare was laid bare. It was never a simple custody matter. It wasn't even an immigration dispute. From the start, it was a war of competing ideolo gies and prejudices, and they were out in force. There was jubilation in Havana on Easter Saturday, the day Elián was whisked away from his Miami relatives at gunpoint and delivered to his father in Washington, DC - and destruction on the streets of Miami, where more than 100 fires were ignited. A week later, 80,000 marched in protest through the neighbourhood known as 'Little Havana', this time without violence. Women were asked to wear black, which, despite the sweltering heat, they did in large numbers. Some carried effigies of Elián, others raised billboard-sized banners displaying a familiar red-white-and-blue striped motif: the flag of Cuba. The American flag was also unfurled - upside down. Miami had splintered. A few miles away, another 3,000-strong 'pro-American' demonstration offered a sight rarely witnessed there before: blacks marching alongside whites - the whites brandishing Confederate flags. Some of the protestors held Bibles up to the sky. Hatred and anger were visible everywhere. In Cuba, meanwhile, Fidel Castro launched the biggest public-relations blitz since he arrived in Havana as conqueror in 1959. It was a political opportunity not to be missed. If Castro lost, the court of world public opinion would surely endorse his standing on the boy's right to be with his father. If he won, the resulting two-fingered salute to the yanquis - and, more crucially, to the Cuban-exile community in Miami - would pay handsome dividends on the street. Earlier this month, on the day after the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta denied the Miami-based Gonzalez family's appeal for an asylum hearing, 500,000 women marched in Havana, a city whose entire population is just 2 million. The protest was against Elián observing the court order to remain in the US for 14 days while the Miami clan filed another appeal, possibly with the Supreme Court. Miami is unlike any other city. American only in name, it's a city of racial rancours and political grudges. More significantly, it is a city of exiles - from Haiti, El Salvador, Panama, Nicaragua, Argentina, Colombia. The largest, most powerful group is Cuban. According to the US Census Bureau, Hispanics make up 12 per cent of the United States population. Cubans constitute a small minority of those, a meagre six per cent. In Florida's Dade County, Cubans constitute 40 per cent of the population - a large, successful, noisy majority. Alone, they make up 55 per cent of Miami. After Fidel Castro swept into power, the exodus to Florida began. The regime that keeps him happily in Havana keeps the exiles furious in Miami. Some saw Miami as un pueblo de campo (an outback village) when they arrived, but no longer. Today, with its big urban skyline and financial gateway to Latin America, Miami is a bedrock, conducted largely en español , by Cubans. Often in defiance of reason, their dream - a return to the promised land - perseveres. For these Cubans came to fight Castro, not build a city. The metropolis evolved as years dragged on, along with an ambivalence to America's government and culture. The maladroit Bay of Pigs invasion in 1961 was the first breach, followed by the missile crisis in 1962. Throughout the 60s and early 70s, exile parents found the prospect of their sons being drafted to Vietnam difficult to reconcile with watching Marxist Cuba being allowed to continue only 90 miles from Florida. Subsequent US interventions in Chile, Grenada and Panama have added to the disenchantment. Life in Havana permeates every aspect of life in Miami, a phenomenon by turns understandable, peculiar, outrageous and, occasionally, embarrassing. The Elián political spectacle has uncaged circus animals of every stripe. One recent example from the menagerie of local politics: Miami has a Cuban-American mayor. His name is Joe Carollo, though lately he has been going by 'Crazy Joe' Carollo. During the protests leading up to the Easter raid - amid the clamour for solidarity within this largest voting portion - the mayor went on Spanish-language radio stations, local news shows, even on CNN, to warn that his police department would not assist federal law-enforcement officials if they came after the boy. They did - and afterwards he went on a televised sacking spree. His first volley was to eject the well-regarded (non-Hispanic) chief of police, on the grounds that he knew about the raid and neglected to inform him. The city's non-Hispanic city manager refused to unseat the police chief - who resigned anyway. The mayor dismissed the city manager. Now Miami has a Cuban mayor, a Cuban city manager, a Cuban chief of police, a Cuban city attorney, and a Cuban majority in the commission. The city, meanwhile, is more divided than ever. As the Elián affair turned the spotlight on the exile community, the latter has responded less like the old guard and more like a marginalised fundamentalist fringe. There's no small amount of paranoia, plus a dose of the sheer lunacy for which Miami is famous. An insult lives many lives here. After the mayor's antics were compared to the shenanigans of a banana-republic politico, a banana war was declared, no one knows by whom - a war which is still being waged by sides equally keen to claim the fruit as their emblem. Someone drew a circle of bananas around Miami's seal and left it outside City Hall. Bananas were hurled near the entrance on a daily basis. More recent protests have produced bananas as symbols of defiance and solidarity: opponents of the mayor point the banana down; supporters point it up. No fatalities have been reported. A banana flag already exists. Designed by Barbara Dabney and manufactured at her 'Freedom Flag and Banner' plant in Miami, it has been a runaway success. The flag features a redesigned city seal - citing the founding date of the republic as the year 2000 - arranged over a field of bananas. Dabney's business has flourished in recent times; from April through May, thousands of Cuban and US flags have been ordered for protesters on opposite sides of the barricade. For all the ranting, few entrepreneurs have thought twice about cashing in on Elián. And not merely on 'Free Elián' buttons and T-shirts sanctifying his image. No, 'real sand' from the Cuban Gonzalez family hometown of Cárdenas. Little Havana 'holy water' fresh from a tap near the Miami Gonzalez home. Elián's cup. Elián's tennis ball. Elián's hair. The online shopping mall eBay has listed upwards of 134 items, from Elián rosaries to pray for the boy ($59) to more preposterous articles: a picture painted on a license plate of Elián urinating on Fidel Castro ($4.99); the very raft used by the boy at sea (bids scaled to $10 million), though this item was pulled when it suddenly dawned on prospective buyers that Elián had been clinging to an inner tube, not a raft. The internet war has been extreme. Janet Reno perhaps expected to retire to her hometown of Miami after her time as attorney general. She may want to review her plans. The electronic postcards I received from Miami speak for themselves: one is a variant on the famous Associated Press photograph taken on the day of the seizure. Elián is crying, but not because he's facing a submachine gun - instead, Reno has burst through the door and flashed her breasts. In another there's no Elián this time, simply Reno superimposed upon a pornographic picture of a pre-operation transsexual. Not surprisingly, Bill Clinton has also been ushered onstage for comic relief. The AP photograph of the raid has the president pushing through the door, smiling, with rifle in hand, while Fidel Castro, in battle fatigues, follows in behind him. T-shirts with this picture are for sale all over Little Havana - the caption reads: 'Federal Child Abuse'. Porn isn't the only exile weapon on the web. The site www.nocastro.com offers propaganda plus a trip down memory lane. We are reminded in an Amnesty International summary that, as recently as 1994, Castro ordered the sinking of the tugboat 13 de Mayo leaving for Miami, in which 35 men, women and children perished. Cuban exiles understand the situation in Cuba completely. It's a matter of record that the Cuban republic claims a child belongs to the state, not its father, and a matter of policy that children constitute a goodly portion of the Cuban labour force. 'The Elián phenomenon is like a virus,' says Jim Mullin, editor of the Miami newspaper New Times , 'everything it touches gets infected.' This statement could easily apply to Cuba and the entire exile theme. One of the editors I worked with during my eight years in Miami, Mullin came from California in 1988 and still remains baffled by the exiles. 'For a journalist this is hog heaven. It's fascinating trying to figure this place out. I've been trying for 12 years.' Will he stay in Miami? 'I'll stay until Castro falls and Cuba is restored.' He could be waiting a long while yet. Waiting for Fidel is a story that's decades old. It is my family's story and, to a lesser degree, my own. My exile began before I was born. Conceived in Cuba in 1958, I was delivered in Florida in 1959, eight months after Castro received his own hero's welcome. My heritage has been a meandering rootlessness. Some members of my family came immediately, some stayed and came later, some stayed indefinitely. Less a political upheaval than an illustration of families split down the middle, the circumstances of my family's path in Cuba were typical. My great-grandfather, General Emilio Nuñez, was a hero of the revolution that ended the Spanish-American War in 1898 and founded the Cuban republic. A devoted friend of José Martí, Cuba's greatest poet, the general was chosen to introduce and raise the Cuban flag at the Morro Castle when independence was declared; later he served as vice-president. My grandfather, Emilio Nuñez Portuondo, was a well-known politician and diplomat. In the 50s, he became a leading anti-communist at the United Nations, where he headed the Security Council. No supporter of Batista, he nonetheless represented him at the UN. His final political act was to resign the post of prime minister after serving barely 10 days, when Batista expressed his intention to withdraw constitutional guarantees. 'It's the beginning of the end,' he told my mother. Much to my grandfather's dismay, his eldest son had fallen in love with Myrta Diaz-Balart, a young divorcee, and they were married. Her former husband was Fidel Castro. She remains the only woman El Máximo has ever married. The marriage also produced a son, Fidel Jr, the only one from Castro's unofficial brood of 11 to be deemed 'legitimate'. Conflicts of interest, political and personal, coincided with a revolution. When it came, there was ample reason to leave. The scene in Miami was characteristic: fistfights at the airport broke out between fidelistas headed to Havana and batistianos fleeing Cuba. The televised executions during January and February 1959, when enemies were led to the paredón and shot, made for grisly viewing - especially for my grandparents, who could easily imagine a similar march. Their Cuban days were over. My father was 22 at that time. In the affluent climate of 50s Cuba, he was already going places. He had secured a loan of $5 million from a Canadian bank in order to develop a casino and hotel resort within family-owned land in the province of Pinar del Rio. Things changed after Castro. Now he had a wife, three children and no job, in a foreign country. His early exile was a time of desperate moves, some towards a career and others to restore Cuba. For a time, he received soldiers of fortune in our little house in Fort Lauderdale, and played a small part in plots to put away Fidel. An explosive device supposedly to be flown and dropped over Castro at a rally was kept for a while in our bathroom. The pilot lost his nerve, the plot fizzled, and the device was disassembled. My father succeeded in business later on, but the loss of Cuba was a sadness he carried within, until to the end of his life. My aunt Myrta eventually left Cuba and moved to Spain. She was never denied access to Fidelito, but had to travel great distances to see him. Fidelito trained in the Soviet Union as a nuclear physicist. Not unlike Elián, he was a state trophy. He has led an obscure life back in Cuba and is said to be close to Fidel now, and has been spotted in recent protests standing beside his father. I have never met Fidelito, nor any others from Castro's side of the family. Fidelito's cousins include Florida state senator Mario Diaz-Balart and US congressman Lincoln Diaz-Balart, both vehemently anti-Castro - marking yet another split in one family. Metaphors common and strange have pelted down on Elián's fragile bones like hail - a miracle, an angel, a martyr, a saviour. There have been visions of sacred dolphins and a weeping Virgin Mary. Hosannas have been offered to the 'fisherman' who 'rescued' Elián. Everyone wants to provide a segment of the hagiography. Even the Spanish-speaking world's best-known novelists have weighed in, from Peru's Mario Vargas Llosa to Chile's Ariel Dorfman to Colombia's (or, these days, Mexico's) Gabriel García Márquez; the greatest living Cuban writer, Guillermo Cabrera Infante, who lives in London, published an article drawing a parallel between Elián and the Yoruba deity, Eleguá, to underscore his eternal place in Cuban folklore. The act of consecration is always peculiar, whether it takes place in Little Miami or Kensington Palace. But the featured players of The Elián Show are all too human, starting with the Miami Gonzalezes. Great-uncles Lázaro and Delfin Gonzalez, at the forefront of the custody war, share drunk-driving convictions. Elián's cousin, Marisleysis - who, bidding for the part of surrogate mother of a saint, wept buckets after the raid, and then delivered an attack on Janet Reno's sexuality - has been hospitalised some eight times since November, citing 'stress'. Lázaro and Delfin's twin nephews, José and Luis Cid, photographed playing with the boy soon after his rescue, would have raised the eyebrows of any judge deciding on custody: José has a criminal record for grand theft, forgery and violating probation. Luis was arrested for allegedly robbing a tourist in Little Havana. It shouldn't come as a surprise that 'the fisherman' - el pescador - who 'saved' Elián is not a saint, let alone a St Peter. Donato Dalrymple, a house cleaner, was on his first fishing trip with his cousin when he laid eyes on Elián. The cousin was actually the one who lifted Elián from the inner tube. Of Donato's three failed marriages, two have been to brides of the mail-order variety. He has no children and says he doesn't want any. Dalrymple's brother, Lindy, is in prison for beating his son, not quite four years old, to death. Donato defends his sibling, 'the kindest person' he has ever known, with the same fervency he lavishes upon his love for the 'miracle child'. It was Dalrymple who was clutching Elián in the AP photograph. El pescador, who insists on calling himself 'saviour', first filed a suit seeking to remove Lázaro Gonzalez as custodian, a moot point after Elián's transfer to Washington. webTitle: Top staff leave Queen's in employment row

fields.headline: Top staff leave Queen's in employment row
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Amid renewed concerns about its fair employment record, Queen's University, Belfast, is facing a loss of academic talent to its main rival.
fields.body:
Amid renewed concerns about its fair employment record, Queen's University, Belfast, is facing a loss of academic talent to its main rival.

At least 10 highly respected academics have 'transferred' to the University of Ulster in the past year, taking at least £5.5 million of research funding with them. It is believed others may follow.

This is bad news for Queen's vice-chancellor George Bain, who is trying to raise funds for a major new campus development called Lanyon II. A spend of £57 million is budgeted over 10 years, but it is unclear where the money will come from.

The university met a severe setback when Boston-based software millionaire John Cullinane, one of the university's most munificent benefactors, refused to make a donation to the restoration fund for the great hall in the original Lanyon building.

It is understood that he refused because the university had not resolved problems over fair employment practices.

Queen's was dogged by controversy in the Nineties over a massive preponderance of Protestants among academic and administrative staff recruited from within Northern Ireland. The university's annual review, published in March, claimed that measures taken since had made it 'an exemplar'.

In 1998 Professor Bain was appointed vice-chancellor and asserted that the fair employment problem was over. According to university insiders, at least 10 new fair employment cases have been brought in the past year. Each lost case typically cost the university £100,000.
